Kiddushin



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A woman is acquired</b> by, i.e., becomes betrothed to, a man to be his wife <b>in three ways, and she acquires herself,</b> i.e., she terminates her marriage, <b>in two ways.</b> The mishna elaborates: <b>She is acquired through money, through a document, and through sexual intercourse.</b> With regard to a betrothal <b>through money,</b> there is a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>: <b>Beit Shammai say</b> that she can be acquired <b>with one dinar or with</b> anything that is <b>worth one dinar. And Beit Hillel say:</b> She can be acquired <b>with one <i>peruta</i>,</b> a small copper coin, <b>or with</b> anything that is <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b> The mishna further clarifies: <b>And how much is</b> the value of <b>one <i>peruta</i>,</b> by the fixed value of silver? The mishna explains that it is <b>one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>,</b> which is a small silver coin.
<b>And</b> a woman <b>acquires herself through a bill of divorce or through the death of the husband. A woman whose husband, who had a brother, died childless [<i>yevama</i></b>], can be <b>acquired</b> by the deceased husband’s brother, the <i>yavam</i>, only <b>through intercourse. And she acquires herself,</b> i.e., she is released from her levirate bond, <b>through <i>ḥalitza</i> or through the death of the <i>yavam</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that <b>a woman</b> can be <b>acquired</b> in three ways. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different here that</b> this mishna <b>teaches: A woman is acquired,</b> using the language of acquisition, <b>and what is different there,</b> in the beginning of the next chapter (42a), <b>which teaches: A man betroths,</b> using the language of betrothal? The Gemara explains: In this mishna the <i>tanna</i> utilized the language of acquisition <b>because he wanted to teach</b> about betrothal through <b>money,</b> which is the standard means of exchange in an act of acquisition.
The Gemara continues its explanation: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that betrothal is accomplished by means of giving <b>money?</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the term expressing <b>taking</b> stated with regard to betrothal and <b>from</b> the term expressing <b>taking</b> with regard to <b>the field of Ephron.</b> How so? <b>It is written here,</b> with regard to marriage: <b>“When a man takes a woman”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and it is written there,</b> concerning Abraham’s purchase of the field of the Cave of Machpelah from Ephron the Hittite: <b>“I will give money for the field; take it from me”</b> (Genesis 23:13). This verbal analogy teaches that just as Ephron’s field was acquired with money, so too, a woman can be acquired with money.
The Gemara continues: <b>And</b> the <b>taking</b> of Ephron’s field <b>is called an acquisition</b> in the Torah, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the same issue: <b>“The field which Abraham acquired”</b> (Genesis 25:10).

Daf 2b

<b>Alternatively,</b> it can be proven that purchasing a field with money is called an acquisition from the verse: <b>“They shall acquire fields with money”</b> (Jeremiah 32:44). Consequently, as the <i>tanna</i> wanted to teach that a woman can be betrothed with money, <b>he taught: A woman is acquired.</b> This explains why the terminology of acquisition is used in this mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>But let</b> the mishna <b>teach there,</b> in the next chapter: <b>A man acquires.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Initially,</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> using <b>the language of the Torah,</b> in which betrothal is called taking. <b>And ultimately,</b> in the next chapter, <b>it taught</b> using <b>the language of the Sages. And what</b> is the reason that betrothal is called <i>kiddushin</i>, literally, consecration, in the <b>language of the Sages?</b> The reason is <b>that</b> through betrothal the husband <b>renders her forbidden to everyone like consecrated</b> property. Therefore, this act is referred to as consecration.
The Gemara asks another question with regard to the difference in wording between the two <i>mishnayot</i>: <b>And let it teach here,</b> as in the following chapter: <b>A man acquires.</b> Why does this mishna teach: The woman is acquired, with the woman as the subject of the sentence? The Gemara answers: This is <b>because</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wanted to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And she acquires herself,</b> which is stated <b>with regard to her.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>also taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> stated <b>with regard to her</b> in <b>the first clause.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>But</b> if this is the reason, the mishna could have been formulated entirely differently. <b>Let it teach: The man can acquire</b> a woman <b>and transfer</b> authority, i.e., grant her the release from marriage in the form of a bill of divorce. The Gemara answers: The mishna could not use the expression: Transfer, <b>because there is</b> the case of <b>the husband’s death, in</b> which <b>it is not he who transfers</b> authority. Rather, <b>it is from Heaven that</b> her freedom <b>is transferred to her.</b> Therefore, the mishna could not issue a general statement that the man can actively transfer to the woman her release from marriage.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead another explanation. <b>If</b> the mishna had <b>taught:</b> The man <b>acquires</b> the woman, <b>I would say</b> that he can acquire her <b>even against her will,</b> as indicated by the expression: He acquires. One might have assumed that the betrothal depends on the husband, without the need for the woman’s consent. Therefore the mishna <b>taught: The woman is acquired,</b> from which it may be inferred <b>that with her consent, yes,</b> he can acquire her as a wife, but <b>when</b> he acts <b>without her consent, no,</b> she is not betrothed to him.
The Gemara continues to analyze the style of the mishna: <b>And why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach: Three [<i>shalosh</i>]</b> ways, formulated in the feminine? <b>Let it teach: Three [<i>shelosha</i>]</b> ways, formulated in the masculine. The Gemara explains: The mishna uses this form <b>because it wants to teach</b> the word <b>way [<i>derekh</i>], and <i>derekh</i> is formulated</b> in the <b>feminine, as it is written: “And you shall show them the way [<i>derekh</i>] in which [<i>bah</i>] they must walk”</b> (Exodus 18:20). The term <i>bah</i>, which is referring to <i>derekh</i>, is formulated in the feminine.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that which is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 65b): <b>One examines a <i>zav</i> in seven [<i>shiva</i>] ways [<i>derakhim</i>],</b> where <i>shiva</i> is formulated in the masculine, <b>let it teach: Seven [<i>sheva</i>]</b> ways, formulated in the feminine. The Gemara answers: The mishna uses the masculine formulation of the term seven <b>because it wanted to teach: <i>Derekh</i>, and we find</b> that the word <b><i>derekh</i> is referred to</b> in the <b>masculine form, as it is written: “They shall come out against you one way [<i>derekh</i>], and shall flee before you seven [<i>shiva</i>] ways”</b> (Deuteronomy 28:7). The Gemara asks: <b>If so, the verses contradict each other,</b> as in one verse the term <i>derekh</i> is masculine, and in the other verse it is feminine. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>the <i>mishnayot</i> contradict each other,</b> as in one mishna <i>derekh</i> is masculine while in the other it is feminine.
The Gemara answers: <b>The verses do not contradict each other. Here,</b> that verse: “The way in which they must walk” (Exodus 18:20), <b>is referring to the Torah,</b> i.e., the way mentioned here is referring to the path of the Torah, <b>and Torah is referred to</b> in the <b>feminine form, as it is written: “The Torah of the Lord is perfect [<i>temima</i>], restoring the soul”</b> (Psalms 19:8). The word <i>temima</i> is in the feminine. Consequently, in reference to the Torah the verse <b>writes:</b> <i>Derekh</i>, <b>formulated</b> in the <b>feminine. There, that</b> verse: “Shall flee before you seven ways” (Deuteronomy 28:7), <b>is referring to war,</b> and <b>as it is the way of a man to wage war and it is not the way of a woman to wage war,</b> it is appropriate to speak in the masculine. Therefore, the verse <b>writes</b> the word <i>derekh</i> <b>formulated</b> in the <b>masculine.</b>
Likewise, the <b><i>mishnayot</i> do not contradict each other: Here, where it is referring to a woman, the mishna teaches</b> <i>derekh</i> <b>formulated</b> in the <b>feminine. There,</b> with regard to the examination of a <i>zav</i>, <b>where it is referring to a man, as</b> it is <b>common for a man to undergo an examination</b> to determine if his emission has a cause other than a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>ziva</i>] <b>but it is not common for a woman to undergo an examination, since,</b> unlike a man, <b>a woman is rendered impure even by circumstances beyond</b> her <b>control, it taught</b> and used the word <i>derekh</i> <b>formulated</b> in the <b>masculine.</b> Even if a woman has an emission of blood for a reason other than illness, she is still impure. Consequently, in her case there is no reason for an examination to see what might have caused her discharge.
The Gemara asks another question with regard to the language of the mishna: <b>What is the reason</b> that the mishna <b>teaches: Three [<i>shalosh</i>],</b> formulated in the feminine? This is <b>because</b> it wanted to teach: <b>Ways. But</b> if so, <b>let it teach</b> instead the word: <b>Matters,</b> i.e., a woman can be acquired through three matters, <b>and</b> as this term is masculine, <b>let it teach three [<i>shelosha</i>],</b> in the masculine. The Gemara answers: The mishna did do so <b>because it wanted to teach intercourse</b> as one of these ways, <b>and intercourse is called a way</b> in the Torah, <b>as it is written: “And the way of a man with a young woman, so is the way of an adulterous woman”</b> (Proverbs 30:19–20). For this reason the mishna used the term ways rather than matters.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This works out well</b> with regard to <b>intercourse,</b> which is referred to as a way. But <b>what is there to say</b> concerning <b>money and a document?</b> The mishna could have used the word matters with regard to these modes of betrothal. The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> it was necessary to mention <b>intercourse,</b> which is called a way, the mishna used the word way in reference to the other two modes as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> would the mishna <b>teach two</b> cases in a particular manner <b>due to one?</b> Since the word way suits only one of the three modes of betrothal, why didn’t the mishna use the term: Matters, on account of the other two? The Gemara answers: <b>These, too, are for the sake of sexual intercourse.</b> Since the marital relationship, in which intercourse is paramount, is the ultimate purpose of betrothal, the mishna considers this clause as the most important part of the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna, which teaches <i>derekh</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: For what</b> reason <b>did the Torah say: “When a man takes a woman”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:13) <b>and did not write: “When a woman is taken by a man? Because it is the way [<i>derekh</i>] of a man to pursue a woman, and it is not the way of a woman to pursue a man.</b> The Gemara cites <b>a parable of a man who lost an item. Who searches for what?</b> Certainly <b>the owner of the lost item searches for his lost item,</b> not the other way around. Since woman was created from man’s lost side, the man seeks that which he has lost. To allude to this statement of Rabbi Shimon, the mishna employs the term <i>derekh</i> in this context.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One examines a <i>zav</i> in seven ways,</b> why does it use this phraseology? <b>Let it teach</b> the word: <b>Matters.</b> The Gemara answers that the mishna <b>there teaches us this</b> <i>halakha</i>, <b>that it is the way of excessive eating to lead to <i>ziva</i>, and</b> likewise <b>it is the way of excessive drinking to lead to <i>ziva</i>.</b> Therefore, the mishna uses the phrase: Seven ways, to emphasize that there are ways of behavior that can cause the emission of a <i>zav</i>.
The Gemara further challenges: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bikkurim</i> 2:6): The <i>halakhot</i> of <b>an <i>etrog</i></b> tree <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>a tree in three ways. Let it teach</b> instead: Three <b>matters.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Because it wants to teach in</b> the <b>latter clause: And</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of an <i>etrog</i> tree correspond <b>to</b> those of <b>a vegetable in one way,</b> therefore the mishna uses the term: Ways, in the first clause as well. The Gemara asks: In the <b>latter clause too, let</b> the mishna <b>teach: Matter,</b> rather than: Way.

Daf 3a

The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> the mishna <b>teaches us this, that</b> the <b>way an <i>etrog</i></b> grows is <b>like a vegetable: Just as it is the way of a vegetable to grow by</b> being watered by <b>all water,</b> i.e., in addition to rainwater it requires irrigation, <b>and its tithing is according to when it is harvested,</b> i.e., its tithing is based on when it is collected from the field, <b>so too, it is the way of an <i>etrog</i> to grow by</b> being watered by <b>all water,</b> as it requires more water than rain provides, <b>and its tithing is according to the time when it is harvested.</b> If, for example, a vegetable is collected during a year when poor man’s tithe is given, that tithe is separated from it, even if it formed a bud during the previous year, when second tithe was separated. The same applies to an <i>etrog</i>. Therefore, the mishna specifically uses the term: Way, to allude to this reason.
The Gemara further asks: <b>But</b> concerning <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bikkurim</i> 2:8): With regard to <b>a <i>koy</i>,</b> an animal whose classification was uncertain, as the Sages were unsure whether it is a domesticated or a non-domesticated animal, <b>there are ways,</b> i.e., <i>halakhot</i>, <b>in</b> which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>a non-domesticated animal and there are ways in</b> which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>a domesticated animal. And there are ways in</b> which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of both <b>a non-domesticated animal and a domesticated animal, and there are ways in</b> which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>neither a non-domesticated animal nor a domesticated animal. Let</b> that mishna <b>teach</b> the term: <b>Matters. And furthermore,</b> with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 9a): <b>This is one of the ways in which</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>bills of divorce correspond to</b> those of bills of <b>manumission, let</b> that mishna <b>teach</b> the word: <b>Matters.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects the previous explanations, as the phraseology is not dependent on the nature of the topic at hand. Instead, <b>anywhere that there is a distinction</b> with regard to an issue the mishna <b>teaches</b> the term: <b>Ways,</b> as there are different ways or possibilities available. <b>And anywhere that there is no distinction it teaches</b> the word: <b>Matters.</b> The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise</b> in this regard, <b>as it teaches in the latter clause</b> of that mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of <b>an <i>etrog</i></b> tree <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>a tree with regard to every matter.</b> This indicates that when no distinctions apply, the mishna will use the term matter. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from</b> this clause in the mishna that this explanation is correct.
§ The Gemara continues to analyze the language of the mishna: With regard to <b>the number in the first clause</b> of the mishna, i.e., a woman is acquired in three ways, this serves <b>to exclude what?</b> The fact that the mishna mentions a number indicates that other modes of acquisition do not apply to betrothal. What mode is excluded? Similarly, <b>the number in the latter clause</b> of the mishna, that a woman acquires herself in two ways, serves <b>to exclude what?</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The number in the first clause</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> a wedding <b>canopy,</b> which does not effect betrothal. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, who said:</b> A wedding <b>canopy acquires</b> a woman, and it alone could be a mode of betrothal, as derived <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference (see 5a), this number serves <b>to exclude what?</b>
The Gemara answers: The number serves <b>to exclude</b> acquisition through symbolic <b>exchange,</b> i.e., a <i>pro forma</i> act of acquisition effecting the transfer of ownership of an article. Although a woman can be betrothed by means of money or an item of monetary value, she is not betrothed if she is given an item by symbolic exchange. The Gemara explains why this needs to be excluded: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> the Sages <b>derive</b> the acquisition of a woman by verbal analogy between the term expressing <b>taking</b> stated with regard to betrothal <b>from</b> the term expressing <b>taking</b> with regard to <b>the field of Ephron,</b> it can be suggested that <b>just as a field can be acquired through</b> symbolic <b>exchange, so too, a woman can be acquired through</b> symbolic <b>exchange.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> perhaps one should <b>say</b> that <b>so too,</b> it is possible to betroth a woman by means of symbolic exchange. The Gemara answers: This cannot be the case, as symbolic <b>exchange is</b> effective <b>using</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>, and with</b> an item worth <b>less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>, a woman</b>

Daf 3b

<b>does not render herself acquired</b> by a man.
The Gemara asks: <b>The number in the latter clause</b> of the mishna, that a woman acquires herself in two ways, serves <b>to exclude what?</b> The Gemara answers that it serves <b>to exclude <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> i.e., a woman is not released from marriage through <i>ḥalitza</i>. Without this exclusion it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that this <b>can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> as follows: <b>Just as a <i>yevama</i>, who is not released</b> from the <i>yavam</i> <b>through a bill of divorce, is</b> nevertheless <b>released</b> from him <b>through <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> with regard to <b>this</b> married woman, <b>who can be released</b> from her husband <b>through a bill of divorce, is it not logical that she can be released</b> from him <b>through <i>ḥalitza</i>?</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that a married woman cannot be released from her husband by means of <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> perhaps one should <b>say</b> that <b>so too,</b> this is the case, i.e., a married woman can be released from marriage through <i>ḥalitza</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states</b> with regard to divorce: <b>“A scroll of severance”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:3), which teaches: <b>A scroll,</b> i.e., a written document, <b>severs her</b> from her husband, <b>and nothing else severs her</b> from him.
§ The mishna teaches that a woman can be acquired <b>with money.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that a woman can be acquired through money? <b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 46b): <b>A father has authority</b> over <b>his daughter with regard to her betrothal,</b> whether it is <b>through money, through a document, or through sexual intercourse, from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> she <b>is acquired</b> by her husband <b>with money, and</b> that this <b>money is her father’s?</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The reason is <b>that the verse states</b> with regard to a Hebrew maidservant acquiring freedom from her master: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing, without money”</b> (Exodus 21:11). The extraneous phrase: Without money, indicates that <b>there is no money for this master,</b> i.e., in this case the master she leaves loses the money he paid for her, <b>but there is money for a different master,</b> i.e., another master receives money for her when she leaves his authority. <b>And who is</b> the other master who can transfer her to someone else and receives money for her? This is her <b>father.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that this money is given <b>to her?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can</b> one suggest <b>this? Her father receives her betrothal,</b> i.e., the money or document of betrothal, when he marries her off to her husband, <b>as it is written: “I gave my daughter to this man”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:16), <b>and</b> shall <b>she take the money?</b> Since he is the one who marries her off, he is certainly entitled to the money of her betrothal.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>applies</b> only when she is <b>a minor girl, as she does not have the power to receive</b> her <b>betrothal.</b> Since she lacks the intellectual capacity, she likewise does not have the legal right to conduct this transaction. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a young woman, who does have the power to receive</b> her <b>betrothal,</b> as a female older than twelve years is considered an adult, <b>let her betroth herself and take the money.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “Being in her youth, in her father’s house”</b> (Numbers 30:17), which teaches: <b>Any profit</b> she gains in her <b>youth</b> belongs <b>to her father.</b>
The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that which Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the earnings of a daughter,</b> i.e., the profit from her labor, belongs <b>to</b> her <b>father? As it is stated: “And if a man sells his daughter as a maidservant”</b> (Exodus 21:7). This comparison between a daughter and a Hebrew maidservant teaches the following: <b>Just as</b> with regard to a Hebrew <b>maidservant, her earnings</b> belong <b>to her master, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a daughter, her earnings</b> belong <b>to her father.</b> The Gemara now asks: Why does Rav Huna need this derivation? <b>Let him derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the verse <b>“being in her youth, in her father’s house,”</b> which indicates that any profit from her earnings as a young woman belongs to her father.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav Huna maintains that <b>that</b> verse <b>is written with regard to the nullification of vows,</b> and it is not referring to the <i>halakhot</i> of acquisition. The Gemara asks: If that is so, then <b>so too,</b> with regard to her betrothal money, one can say that this verse <b>is written</b> only <b>with regard to the nullification of vows</b> and does not apply to betrothal money. <b>And if you would say: Let us derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of her betrothal money <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the nullification of vows, i.e., just as a father has the right to nullify his daughter’s vows when she is a young woman, so too, he has rights to her money, this is not possible, as there is a principle: <b>We do not derive monetary matters from ritual matters.</b>
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> of the betrothal of a young woman <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>fines,</b> as it is stated explicitly in the Torah that a man who rapes a young woman must pay a fine to her father, there is another principle that is applicable here: <b>We do not derive monetary matters from fines,</b> as the imposition of a fine is considered a unique case from which ordinary monetary rights cannot be derived.
<b>And if you would say: Let us derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the reimbursements for the <b>humiliation and degradation</b> of a young woman who was raped, which are also given to the father, one can answer that the following distinction applies: Reimbursement for <b>humiliation and degradation</b> are <b>different, as her father has an interest in them.</b> The father has the ability to derive benefit from her humiliation and degradation in other ways, e.g., by marrying her to a man afflicted with boils, which would humiliate her and cause a reduction in her value. Therefore, one cannot derive from the fact that the father receives the reimbursements for the humiliation and degradation of a young woman who was raped that he receives other monies due to her.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a young woman’s betrothal money belongs to her father is derived from the verse: “Then shall she go out for nothing, without money” (Exodus 21:11), as previously stated. As for the question why the money does not belong to her, the Gemara answers that <b>it is reasonable that when</b> the verse <b>excludes</b> another situation and indicates that there is no money for this master but there is money for a different master,

Daf 4a

<b>it excludes a departure</b> that is <b>like it,</b> i.e., a departure wherein the two masters are the potential recipients. Just as when no money is paid, the individual who might have received the payment is her master, so too, when money is paid, in a different set of circumstances, the money goes to the one who has authority over her, i.e., her father.
The Gemara asks: <b>But this departure is not similar to that departure,</b> as <b>there, she leaves the authority of the master entirely</b> upon being freed and she no longer retains any connection to him, <b>and here, she still lacks</b> the act of <b>passing</b> her over <b>to the</b> wedding <b>canopy.</b> Until she actually enters the wedding canopy, she has not left her father’s authority completely. The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, there is a similarity between her departures in both cases, as <b>she leaves</b> her father’s <b>authority at least as</b> far as <b>the nullification of vows</b> is concerned. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 66b): With regard to <b>a betrothed young woman, her father and her husband</b> together <b>nullify her vows,</b> and her father cannot nullify them alone.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does <b>this</b> verse: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing”</b> (Exodus 21:11), <b>come for that</b> purpose, to teach that there is no money for this master, but there is money for a different master? <b>But it is required for that which is taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse “Then shall she go out for nothing, without money” should be understood as follows: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing”; these</b> words <b>are</b> referring to <b>the days of adulthood,</b> i.e., a Hebrew maidservant leaves her owner’s authority once she becomes an adult. <b>“Without money [<i>ein kasef</i> ]”; these</b> words <b>are</b> referring to <b>the days of</b> her <b>youth,</b> i.e., when she becomes a young woman she leaves his authority.
<b>Ravina said: If so,</b> that the verse is to be used only for this derivation, <b>let the verse say: <i>En kasef</i>,</b> without the letter <i>yod</i>. <b>What</b> is indicated by the full spelling with a <i>yod</i>: <b><i>Ein kasef</i>?</b> This serves to teach the <i>halakha</i> stated above: <b>There is no money for this master, but there is money for a different master. And who is he?</b> He is her <b>father,</b> who has a right to receive the money when his daughter leaves his authority upon her betrothal.
The Gemara explains: <b>And from where</b> is it derived that <b>one interprets</b> the verse <b>homiletically</b> in <b>this</b> manner? How is it known that the full form of the word <i>ein</i> teaches a <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the daughter of a priest who married a non-priest and was subsequently widowed or divorced: <b>“And she has no child,</b> and is returned to her father’s house, as in her youth, she may eat of her father’s bread” (Leviticus 22:13). This verse indicates that if she has no children from her non-priest husband she may once again partake of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>her</b> actual <b>children. From where</b> do I derive that <b>her children’s children</b> are equivalent to children with regard to this <i>halakha</i>? <b>The verse states: “She has no [<i>ein lah</i>] child,”</b> where <i>ein</i> is spelled with a <i>yod</i> inserted in the middle. This additional letter serves to enable an alternative articulation of the term, specifically, <b>one examines her [<i>ayyein lah</i>]</b> to see if she has any descendants. <b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>children</b> of <b>unflawed</b> lineage, i.e., her legitimate offspring. <b>From where</b> do I derive that <b>children</b> of <b>flawed</b> lineage, e.g., <i>mamzerim</i>, are also considered her children for the purposes of this <i>halakha</i>? <b>The verse states: “She has no child,”</b> which indicates that <b>one examines her,</b> as explained above.
With regard to the last derivation, the Gemara asks: <b>But you have</b> already <b>derived</b> one <i>halakha</i> from this word, that <b>her children’s children</b> are considered like her children in this case. The Gemara answers: In fact, <b>a verse was not necessary</b> to teach about <b>her children’s children, as</b> there is an established principle that <b>children’s children are</b> considered <b>like children.</b> And therefore, <b>when the verse was necessary,</b> it was to teach the requirement of examining her <b>for children</b> of <b>flawed</b> lineage.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the <i>tanna</i> himself, from where does he</b> know <b>that</b> one <b>can expound</b> the <i>yod</i> in <i>ein</i> in <b>this</b> manner? The Gemara answers: <b>They say</b> in explanation that it is <b>written: “Balaam refuses [<i>me’en</i>]”</b> (Numbers 22:14), <b>and</b> it is similarly written: <b>“My <i>yavam</i> refuses [<i>me’en</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:7), and <b>in neither</b> case <b>is a <i>yod</i> written. And here</b> the word <i>ein</i> <b>is written with a <i>yod</i>. Learn from it that</b> the <i>yod</i> is superfluous and <b>comes</b> for the sake of <b>an exposition.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And it was necessary to write</b> a verse that teaches that <b>her betrothal,</b> i.e., the money or document of betrothal, belongs <b>to her father, and it was necessary to write</b> another verse that teaches that <b>her earnings</b> belong <b>to her father,</b> as one could not derive one <i>halakha</i> from the other. <b>As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only that <b>her betrothal</b> money belongs <b>to her father, I would say</b> that this is <b>because she did not toil for it</b> and therefore is not entitled to this sum. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>her earnings, for which she toiled, say</b> that <b>they are hers.</b> Therefore, it is necessary to state that her earnings also belong to her father.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the verse <b>had taught us</b> only the <i>halakha</i> of <b>her earnings,</b> one would have said <b>that</b> they belong to her father because his daughter <b>is sustained by him</b> through his property. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>her betrothal,</b> i.e., the money or document of betrothal, <b>which comes to her from an external</b> source, I would <b>say</b> that <b>it is hers.</b> Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the verse to teach both <i>halakhot</i>.
The Gemara returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself:</b> The <i>baraita</i> states with regard to a Hebrew maidservant: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing,” these are the days of adulthood; “without money,” these are the days of</b> her <b>youth.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And let the Merciful One write</b> that she leaves her master when she reaches her <b>youth, and it would not be necessary</b> to state that she leaves upon reaching <b>adulthood.</b> If she has already left her master when she becomes a young woman, it is not necessary to state that she leaves him upon reaching adulthood.
<b>Rabba says: This</b> phrase <b>comes and teaches about that</b> phrase. In other words, since it is not explicitly stated that this particular verse is referring to her departure when she becomes a young woman, if there was only one superfluous phrase one would conclude that it is referring to adulthood, as the <i>halakha</i> that she leaves the master when she becomes an adult is a lesser novelty. Therefore, two extraneous verses are required.
Rabba cites an analogous case. This is <b>just as it is</b> with regard to <b>a tenant and a hired worker. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning <i>teruma</i>: The verse states: “A tenant of a priest or a hired worker shall not eat of the consecrated” (Leviticus 22:10). <b>“A tenant”; this</b> is referring to a Hebrew slave <b>who has been acquired as a permanent acquisition,</b> i.e., one who said he wishes to stay with his master. This Hebrew slave has his ear pierced and he remains with his master until the Jubilee Year. <b>“A hired worker”; this</b> is referring to a Hebrew slave who has been <b>acquired for an acquisition of</b> six <b>years,</b> the standard period of servitude for a Hebrew slave.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Let</b> the verse <b>say “tenant” and let it not say “hired worker,” and I</b> would <b>say:</b> If one who is acquired <b>as a permanent acquisition does not partake</b> of his owner’s, i.e., the priest’s, <i>teruma</i>, as despite his status as a Hebrew slave he is not considered his owner’s property, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that <b>one who is acquired for an acquisition of</b> six <b>years</b> should not be permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>?
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>If so,</b> that the verse were stated in this manner, <b>I would say: “A tenant”; this is one who was acquired for an acquisition of</b> six <b>years,</b> as the term itself is ambiguous. <b>But one who was acquired as a permanent acquisition may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, the term <b>“hired worker,”</b> which is certainly referring to one who is less permanent than a tenant, <b>comes and teaches about</b> the meaning of the term <b>“tenant,” that even if</b> a Hebrew slave <b>was acquired as a permanent acquisition he may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. A similar line of reasoning applies in the above case of a young woman and an adult.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>Are</b> these cases really <b>comparable? There,</b> the tenant and the hired worker <b>are two bodies.</b> This is significant, <b>as even if the Merciful One had written</b> explicitly that <b>a pierced tenant may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, from which the <i>halakha</i> of a Hebrew slave for six years could have been inferred, <b>and then</b> the Merciful One <b>wrote the other</b> case of a Hebrew slave acquired temporarily, this would not present a serious difficulty. The reason is that, although the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a hired worker is a matter</b> that could <b>be derived by</b> means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, and therefore it does not have to be stated explicitly, there is a principle: Sometimes with regard to <b>a matter that can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, the <b>verse</b> nevertheless <b>takes the trouble and writes it</b> explicitly.
<b>But here,</b> with regard to a woman, <b>she is one body,</b> i.e., it is the same Hebrew maidservant. <b>Once she has left upon</b> the arrival of her <b>youth, what</b> is she <b>doing in his</b> authority as <b>an adult?</b> It is entirely unnecessary for the verse to teach that she leaves her master upon becoming an adult, as she has already left him.
<b>Rather, Abaye</b> rejects the previous suggestion that one verse teaches about the other, and <b>said:</b> The claim that the verse “Then shall she go out for nothing” is referring to adulthood <b>is necessary only for the adulthood of a sexually underdeveloped woman</b> who is incapable of bearing children <b>[<i>ailonit</i>].</b> An <i>ailonit</i> will never develop the physical signs of maturity, i.e., two pubic hairs. Consequently, she does not go through the halakhic stage of a young woman. Instead, she remains a minor until the age of twenty, at which point she immediately becomes an adult.
Consequently, if the Torah did not teach that a Hebrew maidservant leaves her master upon becoming an adult, it might <b>enter your mind to say: She leaves</b> only <b>when</b> entering her <b>youth,</b> but <b>when</b> entering <b>adulthood</b> directly <b>she does not leave.</b> Since an <i>ailonit</i> is never classified as a young woman, she would never leave servitude. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that a Hebrew maidservant leaves her master even if she reaches adulthood directly.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi objects to this: But is it not an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? <b>And if the signs</b> indicating that a young woman has entered <b>puberty do not</b> fully <b>release</b> a young woman <b>from her father’s authority,</b> as he can still betroth her, nevertheless, <b>they do release</b> her <b>from the master’s authority; is it not logical that adulthood, which</b> completely <b>releases</b> her <b>from her father’s authority, should release</b> her <b>from</b> the <b>master’s authority?</b> If so, one can derive by this reasoning that an <i>ailonit</i> leaves her master in adulthood, which means the verse is unnecessary.
<b>Rather, Mar bar Rav Ashi says:</b> This verse <b>is necessary only with regard to the basic</b> <i>halakha</i> of the <b>sale of an <i>ailonit</i></b> as a Hebrew maidservant. As it might <b>enter your mind to say that</b> if a female <b>will show</b> the <b>signs of a young woman,</b> i.e., puberty, her sale <b>is</b> a valid <b>sale,</b> whereas in a case <b>where</b> she <b>will not show</b> the <b>signs of a young woman, her sale is not</b> a valid <b>sale.</b> The reason one might think this is the case is that if the maidservant turns out to be an <i>ailonit</i>, one cannot fulfill the requirements of the verse, as she will never become a young woman.

Daf 4b

Therefore the superfluous phrase: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing,</b> without money” (Exodus 21:11), <b>teaches us</b> that even an <i>ailonit</i> can be sold as a Hebrew maidservant and is released upon reaching adulthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi, who said: But is it not an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that adulthood releases a woman from her master’s authority, how does he respond to the fact that <b>we say</b> in general, with regard to <b>a matter that can be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, the <b>verse</b> nevertheless <b>takes the trouble and writes it</b> explicitly? The Gemara answers: <b>That matter</b> applies only where there <b>is no</b> other way <b>to resolve</b> the difficulty of why a <i>halakha</i> is written when it could be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference. <b>But when there is</b> another, more substantial way <b>to resolve</b> the difficulty, <b>one resolves</b> it in that manner.
§ The Gemara notes: <b>And a <i>tanna</i> cites</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a woman can be betrothed with money <b>from here,</b> a different source. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that when the verse states: <b>“When a man takes a woman and engages in sexual intercourse with her, and it comes to pass, if she finds no favor in his eyes, because he has found</b> some unseemly matter <b>in her,</b> and he writes her a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:1), in this verse, the term <b>taking is only with money. And so it says: “I will give money for the field; take it from me”</b> (Genesis 23:13).
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> is there any need for this derivation? Could this <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference,</b> as follows: <b>And if</b> a Hebrew <b>maidservant, who cannot be acquired</b> as a maidservant <b>through intercourse,</b> nevertheless <b>can be acquired through money, is it not logical that this</b> woman, <b>who can be acquired through intercourse</b> for the purpose of betrothal, <b>can</b> likewise <b>be acquired through money?</b>
Nevertheless, this <i>a fortiori</i> inference can be refuted. <b>A <i>yevama</i> proves</b> otherwise, <b>as she is acquired</b> by the <i>yavam</i> <b>through intercourse, and</b> yet <b>she cannot be acquired through money.</b> The Gemara rejects this refutation: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>a <i>yevama</i></b> is <b>that</b> she <b>cannot be acquired through a document. Will you say</b> that the same applies <b>to this</b> woman, <b>who can be acquired through a document</b> for the purpose of betrothal, and consequently the acquisition of money applies to her as well?
The Gemara reiterates its question. <b>The verse states: “When a man takes</b> a woman.” <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> for <b>this</b> purpose? <b>It was</b> already <b>derived</b> through this <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as the proposed refutation of this inference was rejected. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is needed <b>because one can say that</b> the <b>refutation of the</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> is present <b>from the outset,</b> i.e., there is a difficulty with the comparison between a woman and a Hebrew maidservant.
Rav Ashi elaborates: <b>From where do you derive</b> that a woman can be betrothed with money? It is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a Hebrew maidservant.</b> This derivation can be refuted. <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a Hebrew maidservant is that</b> she can be <b>released with money,</b> i.e., she pays her master her value as a maidservant and she is then freed, and therefore she can likewise be acquired through money. <b>Will you say</b> the same with regard to <b>this</b> woman, <b>who cannot be released,</b> i.e., divorced, <b>through money?</b> Since this <i>a fortiori</i> inference is rejected, one must rely on the source cited in the <i>baraita</i>, that <b>the verse states: “When a man takes.”</b>
After mentioning an additional proof for the option of betrothal with money, the Gemara comments: <b>And it was necessary</b> for the Torah <b>to write,</b> with regard to a Hebrew maidservant: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing,” and it was</b> also <b>necessary to write: “When a man takes</b> a woman.” <b>As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“When he takes,” I would say:</b> The <b>betrothal money that the husband gives her is</b> invariably <b>hers.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Then shall she go out for nothing,”</b> to teach that when she is not an adult her father has the right to her betrothal money.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>had the Merciful One written</b> only: <b>“Then shall she go out for nothing,” I would say</b> that in a case <b>where she gave him</b> money <b>and betrothed him, it is</b> a valid <b>betrothal,</b> as this verse does not specify who gives the money to whom. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “When he takes,” and not: When she takes,</b> to teach that only a man may betroth a woman, not vice versa.
The <i>baraita</i> continues to interpret the verse. The phrase: <b>“And engages in sexual intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>teaches that</b> a woman <b>can be acquired through intercourse.</b> Why is it necessary for the verse to state this explicitly? Could this <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: And if a <i>yevama</i>, who cannot be acquired through money, can be acquired through intercourse, is it not logical that this</b> woman, <b>who can be acquired through money,</b> as derived above, <b>can</b> also <b>be acquired through intercourse?</b>
The Gemara counters: The case of <b>a Hebrew maidservant proves</b> otherwise, <b>as she is acquired through money and</b> yet she <b>cannot be acquired through intercourse.</b> The Gemara dismisses this refutation: <b>What</b> is distinct about <b>a Hebrew maidservant</b> is <b>that her acquisition is not for the sake of marriage,</b> as she is acquired as a servant. <b>Will you say</b> the same <b>with regard to this</b> woman, <b>whose acquisition is for the sake of marriage?</b> Therefore, it is logical that a woman can be acquired through sexual intercourse.
The Gemara reiterates its question. <b>The verse states: “And engages in sexual intercourse with her.” But why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> for this purpose? <b>It was</b> already <b>derived</b> through the above <i>a fortiori</i> inference. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is needed <b>because it</b> is possible <b>to say that</b> the <b>refutation of the</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> is present <b>from the outset. From where do you derive</b> that intercourse is a mode of acquisition? <b>From</b> the case of <b>a <i>yevama</i>.</b>
One could say: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>a <i>yevama</i></b> is that she <b>is bound</b> to the <i>yavam</i> <b>and stands</b> waiting for him to act, and for this reason sexual intercourse is sufficient to render her his wife. <b>Will you say</b> the same <b>with regard to this</b> woman, <b>who is not bound and</b> is not <b>standing</b> waiting for anyone? It is therefore possible that intercourse is not enough to acquire a woman in ordinary circumstances. Consequently, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference does not bear close scrutiny. For this reason an additional proof is required, that <b>the verse states: “And engages in sexual intercourse with her.”</b>

Daf 5a

The <i>baraita</i> continues to discuss the modes of betrothal: <b>And from where</b> is it derived that a woman can be acquired <b>even by</b> means of <b>a document?</b> The Gemara answers: This <b>is a logical derivation,</b> made by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>And if money, which does not release</b> a woman from her husband, nevertheless can <b>bring</b> her <b>into</b> a husband’s domain by betrothal, <b>is it not logical that a document, which releases</b> a woman from her husband in the form of a bill of divorce, <b>can bring</b> her <b>into</b> a husband’s domain by betrothal?
The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>money</b> is that it can effect acquisition in many contexts, <b>as one can redeem with it consecrated</b> property <b>and second tithe. Will you say</b> that the same also applies to <b>a document, with which one cannot redeem consecrated</b> property <b>and second tithe?</b> The proof that one may redeem consecrated property only by means of money is <b>that it is written: “And he will give the money and it will be assured to him”</b> (see Leviticus 27:19). Consequently, this <i>halakha</i> cannot be derived by logical reasoning.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And she leaves</b> his house and goes <b>and becomes</b> another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2). This verse <b>juxtaposes becoming,</b> i.e., betrothal, <b>to leaving,</b> i.e., divorce. <b>Just as leaving</b> is performed <b>through a document,</b> i.e., a bill of divorce, <b>so too, becoming</b> can be performed <b>through a document.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And let one also juxtapose leaving to becoming,</b> in the opposite direction: <b>Just as becoming is</b> performed <b>through money, so too, leaving</b> can be effected <b>through money.</b>
<b>Abaye says:</b> If so, people <b>will say: Money brings in and money releases;</b> if so, can <b>an advocate [<i>saneigor</i>] become a prosecutor [<i>kateigor</i>]?</b> It is improper for the same mode that draws man and woman together to be used for the termination of their relationship. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then with regard to <b>a document too, they will say: A document brings in and a document releases;</b> if so, can <b>a prosecutor become an advocate?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The words of this</b> betrothal <b>document are discrete,</b> i.e., distinct, <b>and the words of this</b> divorce <b>document are discrete,</b> i.e., the two documents differ in content. The Gemara asks: <b>Here too, this money is discrete and this money is discrete,</b> as one coin is for the betrothal and a different coin is used for the divorce. The Gemara answers: <b>In any event, the coin</b> itself <b>is one,</b> i.e., there is no noticeable difference between the coin used for betrothal and one that would be used for divorce. The same cannot be said with regard to documents, as particular texts serve specific purposes, and the same document could not be used for both betrothal and divorce.
<b>Rava said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that a woman cannot be divorced by means of money is derived from a different source. <b>The verse states: “And he writes her</b> a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:3). This indicates that a woman <b>is divorced</b> only <b>through writing and she is not divorced through money.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> as this point is not stated explicitly and is inferred from the verse, one can instead <b>say</b> the following interpretation: <b>She is divorced through writing, and she is not betrothed through writing.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion. It is <b>written: “And she leaves and becomes”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:2), which <b>juxtaposes</b> betrothal to divorce, indicating that betrothal can be effected with a document.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that you interpreted the verses in this manner? One can say the reverse, that the juxtaposition between betrothal and divorce teaches that in both cases money is effective, while the verse: “And he writes her,” means that she can be divorced but not betrothed through writing. The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that when the verse is <b>referring to divorce</b> it <b>excludes</b> a different mode of <b>divorce.</b> Would a verse be <b>referring to divorce and exclude</b> a mode of <b>betrothal?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who derives a different exposition from this verse, from where does he</b> derive <b>that</b> a woman <b>cannot be divorced through money?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “A scroll of severance,”</b> which teaches: <b>A scroll,</b> i.e., a written document, <b>severs her</b> from her husband, <b>and nothing else severs her</b> from him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, <b>what do they do with this</b> verse: “A scroll of <b>severance”?</b> How do they interpret it? The Gemara answers: They <b>require it for</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a document of divorce must be <b>a matter that</b> entirely <b>severs him from her.</b> The text of the bill of divorce must completely terminate the relationship between them.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Gittin</i> 5:12) that if a husband says to his wife: <b>This is your bill of divorce on the condition that you will not</b> ever <b>drink wine,</b> or: <b>On the condition that you will never go to your father’s house, that is not</b> an act of <b>severance,</b> as she remains restricted by him indefinitely. If he stipulates that she may not do so for <b>thirty days, that is</b> an act of <b>severance.</b> The Rabbis derive from the term severance that any indefinite condition prevents the divorce from taking effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> from where does he derive this requirement that a bill of divorce must completely sever the ties between husband and wife? The Gemara answers that <b>he derives it from</b> the fact that the verse does not utilize the basic form of the word severance, i.e., <b><i>karet</i>,</b> but rather its conjugate, <b><i>keritut</i>.</b> This indicates an additional principle that is derived from the term. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the other</b> Sages derive from the seemingly superfluous use of this word? The Gemara answers: <b>They do not interpret</b> the distinction between <b><i>karet</i></b> and <b><i>keritut</i>.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: It has been shown that <b>one</b> mode of betrothal <b>cannot be derived from another</b> mode of betrothal, as explained in the <i>baraita</i>, but why not <b>let one be derived from</b> the other <b>two</b> methods? The Gemara answers: This is not possible, as, <b>which</b> method <b>will be derived</b> from the others? If you say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> that a woman can be betrothed <b>through a document, and</b> one can <b>derive</b> this mode of acquisition <b>from these</b> modes of acquisition, i.e., intercourse and money, this claim can be refuted. <b>What</b> is unique <b>about these</b> other modes is that <b>their benefit is great,</b> relative to a document, as a woman experiences no enjoyment upon receiving a document.
And if you say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> that a woman can be acquired <b>through sexual intercourse, and</b> one can <b>derive</b> this mode <b>from these</b> modes of acquisition, i.e., money and a document, this too is not possible, as, <b>what</b> is unique <b>about these</b> modes of betrothal is that <b>their acquisition is great.</b> In other words, these modes of acquisition apply in many other situations. Therefore, one cannot derive the unusual acquisition of sexual intercourse from these methods.
If you say: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> that a woman can be acquired <b>through money, and</b> one can <b>derive</b> this mode <b>from these</b> other modes of acquisition, this is also not possible, as <b>what</b> is unique <b>about these</b> is that they apply <b>against her will.</b> A <i>yavam</i> acquires a <i>yevama</i> through intercourse even against her will, while a document releases a woman from marriage without her consent in the case of a bill of divorce.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>money also</b> applies <b>against her will,</b> in the case <b>of a Hebrew maidservant,</b> whose father can sell her to a master without her consent, enabling one to therefore derive from the other two modes of acquisition, i.e., intercourse and a document, that a woman can be acquired through money, this opinion can be refuted as well: <b>In any event, with regard to marriage, we do not find</b> a case in which a woman can be acquired through money against her will. Consequently, none of these modes of acquisition can be derived from any of the others.
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The ceremony of the wedding <b>canopy effects acquisition</b> of the woman, as is derived <b>through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If money, which does not enable</b> the wife <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as the daughter of a non-priest betrothed to a priest may not yet partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>effects acquisition</b> of a woman for betrothal, <b>is it not logical that</b> a wedding <b>canopy, which enables her to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as once a woman has entered the wedding canopy it is permitted for her to partake of <i>teruma</i> due to her husband the priest, <b>should</b> also <b>effect acquisition</b> of a woman by her husband?
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> betrothal <b>money not enable</b> a woman <b>to partake of</b> <i>teruma</i>? <b>But didn’t Ulla say: By Torah law the daughter of a non-priest</b> who is <b>betrothed</b> to a priest may <b>partake of <i>teruma</i></b> immediately upon her betrothal, <b>as it is stated: “But if a priest buy any soul, the acquisition of his money,</b> he may eat of it” (Leviticus 22:11), <b>and this</b> woman <b>is</b> considered <b>the acquisition of his money.</b>
<b>And what is the reason</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>? It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest they pour her a cup</b> of <i>teruma</i> wine <b>in her father’s house,</b> where she is staying before her marriage, <b>and she give to her brothers and sisters to drink,</b> as it is prohibited for them to partake of <i>teruma</i>. If so, by Torah law a woman may partake of <i>teruma</i> once she has been betrothed with money. Consequently, the above <i>a fortiori</i> inference that entering a wedding canopy can effect betrothal is invalid.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara emends Rav Huna’s statement and says that <b>he refutes</b> the opinion that entering a wedding canopy does not effect betrothal <b>as follows: If money, which does not complete</b> the acquisition of a woman, as a young woman remains under her father’s authority with regard to certain issues, nevertheless <b>effects acquisition</b> of her for the stage of betrothal,

Daf 5b

<b>is it not logical that</b> a wedding <b>canopy, which completes</b> the marriage, since it entirely removes a young woman from her father’s authority, <b>can effect acquisition</b> for betrothal on its own? The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about money is that</b> it can effect acquisition in many contexts, <b>as one can redeem with it consecrated</b> property <b>and second tithe.</b> This is not so with regard to a wedding canopy, which is ineffective in effecting any acquisition other than marriage. Therefore, in the case of betrothal, money can effect betrothal while a wedding canopy cannot. The Gemara counters: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>sexual intercourse proves</b> otherwise, as this act serves to effect acquisition of a woman despite the fact that it is not a valid mode of acquisition in any other case.
The Gemara counters: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>sexual intercourse</b> is <b>that it effects acquisition of a <i>yevama</i>,</b> whereas a <i>yavam</i> does not acquire her via a wedding canopy. The Gemara answers: <b>Money proves</b> otherwise, as money cannot be used to acquire a <i>yevama</i>, and yet it is a valid mode for acquiring a woman. <b>And the derivation has reverted</b> to its starting point: <b>The aspect of this</b> mode, money, <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> mode, intercourse, <b>and the aspect of that</b> mode, intercourse, <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> mode, money. <b>Their common denominator is that they generally effect acquisition, and they effect acquisition here,</b> with regard to betrothal. <b>Likewise, I will bring</b> the mode of a wedding <b>canopy, which generally effects acquisition,</b> rendering a woman as married, <b>and</b> therefore it should also <b>effect acquisition here.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> about the fact that <b>the common denominator of</b> money and intercourse is <b>that their benefit,</b> i.e., pleasure, <b>is great?</b> The Gemara says: The case of <b>a document proves</b> otherwise, as no great pleasure is derived from receiving a document, and yet it can be used to acquire a woman. The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>a document is that it can release a Jewish woman</b> from her husband in the form of a bill of divorce. The Gemara answers: <b>Money and intercourse prove</b> otherwise, as they do not release a woman and yet they are valid modes of acquisition for betrothal.
<b>And</b> once again, <b>the derivation has reverted</b> to its starting point: <b>The aspect of this</b> mode <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> mode, <b>and the aspect of that</b> mode <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> mode. <b>Their common denominator is that they generally effect acquisition and they effect acquisition here,</b> with regard to betrothal. <b>Likewise, I will bring</b> the mode of a wedding <b>canopy, which generally effects acquisition, and</b> therefore it should also <b>effect acquisition here.</b>
The Gemara again rejects this claim: <b>What</b> about the fact that <b>the common denominator of</b> all three modes of acquisition is <b>that they are</b> effective in certain situations <b>against her will?</b> A bill of divorce, sexual intercourse in the case of a <i>yevama</i>, and money with regard to a Hebrew maidservant all effect acquisition of a woman against her will. Therefore, the mode of a wedding canopy cannot be derived from these methods, as a wedding canopy is effective only when the woman enters it willingly. <b>And</b> in response to this claim <b>Rav Huna</b> would answer: <b>In any event, with regard to marriage, we have not found</b> a case in which a woman can be acquired through <b>money against her will.</b> Consequently, it is possible to learn from the modes of money, a document, and intercourse that a wedding canopy likewise effects betrothal.
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>two refutations of</b> this <b>matter,</b> i.e., it is possible to refute Rav Huna’s opinion in two ways. <b>One</b> opinion is <b>that we learned</b> in the mishna that a woman can be acquired through <b>three</b> modes of acquisition, <b>and we did not learn</b> that there are <b>four</b> modes. This indicates that there are no other ways to acquire a woman apart from the three listed in the mishna.
<b>And furthermore,</b> Rava disagrees with the main point of the proof, which was based on the fact that a wedding canopy completes a marriage: <b>Doesn’t</b> entering a wedding <b>canopy complete</b> a marriage <b>only by</b> means of an act of <b>betrothal,</b> which precedes the wedding canopy? <b>And can one derive</b> that entering a wedding <b>canopy</b> effects acquisition <b>without betrothal from</b> the case of entering a wedding <b>canopy that</b> effects acquisition <b>by</b> means of <b>betrothal?</b> Consequently, entering a wedding canopy alone cannot effect a betrothal.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava in response to his two claims: With regard to <b>that which you said,</b> that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna <b>three</b> modes <b>and we did not learn</b> that there are <b>four</b> modes, this is no proof, as the <b><i>tanna</i> teaches</b> only <b>a matter that is explicitly written</b> in the Torah, and <b>does not teach a matter that is not explicitly written</b> in the Torah, such as a wedding canopy.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which you said: Doesn’t</b> entering a wedding <b>canopy complete</b> a marriage <b>only by</b> means of an act of <b>betrothal, this is also what Rav Huna is saying,</b> i.e., Rav Huna incorporates this claim into his reasoning: <b>If money, which does not complete</b> a marriage <b>after money,</b> i.e., after a woman has been betrothed through money an additional monetary gift cannot render her a fully married woman, <b>effects acquisition</b> of the woman in the form of betrothal, <b>is it not logical that</b> entering a wedding <b>canopy,</b> which is more powerful than money in that it <b>completes</b> a marriage <b>after money, should effect acquisition</b> and be used to perform betrothal by itself?
§ After discussing the sources for the modes of acquisition listed in the mishna, the Gemara analyzes these <i>halakhot</i> in greater detail. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 1:1): <b>How</b> is betrothal performed <b>through money?</b> If a man <b>gave</b> a woman <b>money or</b> an item <b>worth money, and</b> he <b>said to her: You are hereby betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>You are hereby betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>You are to me as a wife,</b> then <b>she is betrothed. But</b> if <b>she</b> is the one <b>who gave</b> the money to him, <b>and she said: I am hereby betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>] to you,</b> or: <b>I am hereby betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>] to you,</b> or: <b>I am hereby to you as a wife,</b> then <b>she is not betrothed.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this:</b> This <i>baraita</i> contains an internal contradiction. The first part of the <i>baraita</i> states: If a man gave a woman money and said to her: You are hereby betrothed to me, from which it may be inferred <b>that the reason</b> the woman is betrothed is that <b>he gave</b> her money <b>and he said</b> the appropriate formula. This leads to the conclusion that if <b>he gave</b> her money <b>and she said</b> the formula, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> Now <b>say the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But</b> if <b>she</b> is the one <b>who gave</b> the money to him, <b>and she said:</b> I am hereby betrothed to you, then <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>betrothal.</b> Rav Pappa infers: <b>The reason</b> that it is not a valid betrothal is that <b>she gave</b> money to him <b>and she said</b> the appropriate formula, from which it may be inferred that if <b>he gave</b> money to her <b>and she said</b> the appropriate formula, then <b>this is</b> a valid <b>betrothal.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>exact,</b> and therefore it is correct to infer that which was not explicitly stated from this ruling. By contrast, <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> was <b>cited for no reason,</b> i.e., it was simply formulated in the opposite manner of the first clause, and the <i>baraita</i> is not exact in the wording of this case. Therefore, one should not analyze this clause too carefully and infer <i>halakhot</i> from it. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> would the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> in <b>the latter clause a matter that contradicts the first clause?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara retracts the previous explanation in favor of the following. <b>This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>he gave</b> the money <b>and he said</b> the formula, it <b>is obvious that it is</b> a valid <b>betrothal.</b> If <b>he gave</b> the money <b>and she said</b> the formula, <b>it is considered as though she gave</b> the money <b>and she said</b> the formula, <b>and</b> therefore <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>betrothal. And if you wish, say</b> a different explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he gave</b> the money and <b>he said</b> the formula, <b>she is betrothed.</b> If <b>she gave</b> the money <b>and she said</b> the formula, <b>she is not betrothed</b> at all. If <b>he gave</b> the money <b>and she said</b> the formula, the ruling <b>is uncertain, and by rabbinic law we are concerned</b> that this might actually be a betrothal.
The Gemara continues to discuss the language of betrothal. <b>Shmuel says: With regard to betrothal,</b> if <b>he gave her money or</b> an item <b>worth money, and said to her: You are hereby betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>],</b> or: <b>You are hereby betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>],</b> or: <b>You are hereby as a wife,</b> then <b>she is betrothed.</b> If he said: <b>I am hereby your man,</b> or: <b>I am hereby your husband,</b> or: <b>I am hereby your betrothed,</b> then <b>there is no room for concern here.</b> In these cases there is no possibility that it might be a valid betrothal, as betrothal is effective only if its formulation defines the relationship in terms of the woman’s connection to the man, not the reverse.
<b>And similarly, with regard to divorce,</b> if a husband <b>gave</b> his wife a bill of divorce <b>and said to her: You are hereby sent away,</b> or: <b>You are hereby divorced,</b> or: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man,</b> then <b>she is divorced.</b> If he said: <b>I am not your man,</b> or: <b>I am not your husband,</b> or: <b>I am not your betrothed,</b> then <b>there is no room for concern,</b> as a bill of divorce is effective only if its formulation defines the relationship in terms of the woman’s connection to the man, not the reverse.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Is this to say that Shmuel holds</b> that <b>ambiguous intimations,</b> i.e., incomplete expressions that can be understood only from their context, <b>are</b> considered like unambiguous <b>intimations?</b> In the cases listed by Shmuel, the woman is betrothed despite the fact that the man did not say: You are hereby betrothed to me, but merely: You are hereby betrothed. The statement itself does not include the detail that the speaker intends to betroth her to himself, and yet Shmuel maintains that the betrothal is valid.
Rav Pappa asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 2a) that <b>one who says: I shall be, is a nazirite? And we discussed</b> this ruling: <b>But perhaps</b> he meant <b>to say: I will be in a fast? And Shmuel said</b> that <b>this</b> mishna <b>is</b> referring to a particular set of circumstances, that he said: I shall be, <b>when a nazirite was passing before him.</b> In that context it is clear the individual meant that he too will be a nazirite. Rav Pappa analyzes this statement: <b>The reason</b> that he is a nazirite is only due to the fact <b>that a nazirite passes before him.</b> But <b>if this</b> were <b>not</b> the case, <b>no,</b> his statement would not be considered a naziriteship vow. This indicates that according to Shmuel, ambiguous intimations are not considered like unambiguous intimations.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> Shmuel is referring to a case <b>where he said</b> the formulation and added the phrase: <b>To me.</b> For example, he said to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what is</b> Shmuel <b>teaching us?</b> If the man stated the full formula it is obvious that she is betrothed, as he used the standard expression of betrothal. The Gemara answers: <b>These</b>

Daf 6a

<b>last expressions</b> are <b>what he teaches us.</b> The novelty of Shmuel’s statement is that with regard to the second set of pronouncements there is no concern at all that a valid betrothal or divorce might have been performed. The Gemara explains why according to Shmuel these pronouncements are not of concern. <b>Here,</b> in the case of betrothal, it is <b>written: “When</b> a man <b>takes</b> a woman” (Deuteronomy 24:1), which indicates that the man is acting to change the status of the woman, <b>and</b> it is <b>not</b> written <b>that he takes himself</b> or gives himself to her, as in the case of one who says: I am hereby your man. <b>And</b> likewise, it is <b>written here,</b> with regard to divorce: <b>“And sends her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and</b> it is <b>not</b> written <b>that he sends himself</b> from her, as in the case of one who says: I am not your man.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if a man says to a woman: <b>You are hereby my wife,</b> or: <b>You are hereby my betrothed,</b> or: <b>You are hereby acquired to me,</b> then <b>she is betrothed.</b> If he said to her: <b>You are hereby mine,</b> or: <b>You are hereby under my authority,</b> or: <b>You are hereby bound to me,</b> then <b>she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is that she is betrothed with regard to both sets of statements, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach all of them together.</b> Why does the <i>baraita</i> divide these statements into two groups? The Gemara answers: <b>The <i>tanna</i> heard them as two sets of three, and</b> consequently <b>he taught them</b> in that form. He heard each sequence of three cases as a separate <i>halakha</i> from his teachers, and therefore he preserved them as two sets of three.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If a man betrothing a woman said: You are hereby <b>unique to me, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is this woman betrothed? Similarly, if he said to her: You are hereby <b>designated to me, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>my helper, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>my counterpart, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>my gathered one, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>my rib, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>my closed one, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>beneath me, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If he said: You are hereby <b>my seized one, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Finally, if he said: You are hereby <b>my taken one, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Resolve at least one</b> of these dilemmas, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who says</b> to a woman: You are hereby <b>my taken one, she is betrothed, because it is stated: “When a man takes a woman”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1).
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If a man says to a woman: You are hereby <b>my espoused one [<i>ḥarufati</i>], what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that with regard to <b>one who says:</b> You are hereby <b>my espoused one, she is betrothed, as in Judea they call a betrothed woman a <i>ḥarufa</i>, an espoused woman.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And is Judea most of the world?</b> Even if this is true in Judea, why should a <i>halakha</i> that applies in all locations be based on this local custom?
The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>one who says:</b> You are hereby <b>my espoused one, she is betrothed, as it is stated: “Who is a maidservant espoused [<i>neḥerefet</i>] to a man”</b> (Leviticus 19:20). This verse means that she is betrothed to a certain man. <b>And furthermore,</b> the <i>baraita</i> adds another proof for this claim: <b>In Judea they call a betrothed woman a <i>ḥarufa</i>, an espoused woman.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it reasonable to introduce the custom in <b>Judea</b> with the term: <b>And furthermore,</b> as proof <b>to</b> a <i>halakha</i> derived from <b>a verse? Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>one who says:</b> You are hereby <b>espoused, in Judea, she is betrothed, as in Judea they call a betrothed woman a <i>ḥarufa</i>, an espoused woman.</b>
The Gemara asks a general question with regard to all the previously mentioned expressions: <b>With what are we dealing? If we say</b> that these dilemmas are referring to a case <b>where he was not speaking with her about matters of her bill of divorce or her betrothal,</b> but suddenly issued this statement to her, <b>from where does she know what he is saying to her?</b> Out of context, these statements are not necessarily referring to betrothal. <b>Rather,</b> they are referring to a case <b>where he was speaking to her about matters of her bill of divorce and her betrothal.</b>But if so, <b>even though he did not say</b> anything, she would <b>also</b> be betrothed if he gave her money for the purpose of betrothal.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 4:7): If <b>one was speaking with a woman about matters of her bill of divorce or her betrothal, and he gave her a bill of divorce or her betrothal,</b> i.e., the money or a document of betrothal, <b>but did not clarify</b> his action, <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> This <b>is sufficient for him,</b> i.e., it is a valid divorce or betrothal because she will understand his intention from the context. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He is required to clarify</b> the meaning of his behavior. <b>And Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> If so, even if he said nothing to her she would still be betrothed, and this should certainly be the case if he says one of the statements under discussion.
The Sages <b>say</b> in explanation of this matter: <b>Actually,</b> we are dealing with cases <b>where he was speaking to her about matters of her bill of divorce and her betrothal, and if</b> it was referring to a case <b>where he</b> had <b>given her</b> the money <b>and been silent, so too</b> it would have been a valid betrothal. <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> This is a case <b>where he gave her</b> something <b>and said to her</b> one <b>of these expressions.</b>
<b>And this is the dilemma raised before</b> the Sages: <b>These expressions, did he say them to her for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal, or perhaps he said</b> them <b>to her for</b> the purpose of <b>labor?</b> He might have intended to hire her, withdrawing his previous intention to betroth her. In other words, his statement in conjunction with his giving of an item renders the meaning of the expression less clear than if he had remained silent. The Gemara leaves most of these issues unanswered, and states that the dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself:</b> If <b>he was speaking to the woman about matters of her bill of divorce or her betrothal, and he gave her bill of divorce or her betrothal to her and did not clarify</b> his intention, <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> This <b>is sufficient for him. Rabbi Yehuda says: He is required to clarify. Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> provided <b>that they were discussing the same issue</b> and had not moved on to a different topic.
<b>And likewise, Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says: And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> provided <b>that they were discussing the same issue.</b> The Gemara comments: This disagreement is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> on this topic. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> provided <b>that they were discussing the same issue. Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon says:</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>despite</b> the fact <b>that they were not discussing the same issue.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And if they were not discussing the same issue, from where does she know what he is saying to her?</b> They have already changed the topic of conversation, and these expressions on their own are ambiguous. <b>Abaye said:</b> They have not changed to an entirely different topic; rather, they changed <b>from</b> discussing one <b>topic to</b> discussing another <b>topic within the same</b> general <b>topic.</b> In other words, they were no longer speaking directly about divorce or betrothal, but they were still discussing related matters. Therefore, his intention was clear to her when he made his statement.
<b>Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. Rav Yeimar said to Rav Ashi: But</b> if so, with regard to <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Anyone who does not know the nature of bills of divorce and betrothals should have no dealings in them,</b> i.e., he may not serve as a judge in cases of this kind lest he permit that which is prohibited, does this principle apply <b>even</b> if that individual <b>did not hear this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Shmuel says?</b> Since this type of case is uncommon, should such an individual be considered unfamiliar with the <i>halakhot</i> of bills of divorce and betrothals? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Yes,</b> it <b>is indeed so;</b> this person is considered to lack the requisite knowledge to deal with these cases.
