This ruling is an important matter with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of betrothal, and one who is unaware of it might err.
The Gemara returns to Shmuel’s statement. <b>And similarly, with regard to divorce:</b> If a husband <b>gave</b> his wife <b>her bill of divorce and said to her: You are hereby sent away,</b> or: <b>You are hereby divorced,</b> or: <b>You are hereby permitted to</b> marry <b>any man,</b> then <b>she is divorced.</b> The Gemara comments: It <b>is obvious</b> that if a husband <b>gave her a bill of divorce and said to his wife: You are hereby a free woman,</b>

Daf 6b

<b>he has said nothing,</b> as this statement is not a valid expression of divorce. Similarly, if a master <b>said to his female</b> Canaanite <b>slave</b> upon emancipating her: <b>You are hereby permitted to any man, he has not said anything.</b>
The Gemara addresses a less straightforward case: If a man <b>said to his wife: You are hereby for yourself, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that <b>he said</b> this <b>to her only with regard to work?</b> In other words, he might have meant that she may keep her earnings. <b>Or perhaps he said to her</b> that she is on her own <b>entirely,</b> i.e., she is divorced.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The essence of a bill of manumission</b> is the expression: <b>You are hereby a freeman,</b> or: <b>You are hereby for yourself. Now</b> consider, <b>if</b> in the case of <b>a Canaanite slave, whose body belongs to</b> the master, even so, <b>when</b> the master <b>says to him: You are hereby for yourself,</b> this is considered as though <b>he said to him</b> that he <b>is entirely</b> on his own and is freed, then <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear <b>that a wife, whose body is not owned</b> by her husband, is divorced by means of this expression?
With regard to the same issue, <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> If <b>one said to his</b> Canaanite <b>slave: I have no business with you, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that when <b>he said to him: I have no business with you,</b> he meant <b>entirely,</b> and therefore the slave is freed? <b>Or</b> did he <b>perhaps say</b> this <b>to him with regard to labor?</b> In other words, it is possible that the master is relieving the slave of his obligation to perform labor without actually emancipating him from slavery.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to Rav Ashi, and some say Rav Ḥanin from Meḥoza</b> said <b>to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>one who sells his</b> Canaanite <b>slave to a gentile,</b> the slave <b>is emancipated but</b> nevertheless <b>requires a bill [<i>get</i>] of manumission from his first master.</b> In this manner the Sages penalized this owner for preventing the slave from fulfilling the mitzvot in which he is obligated.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> in addition to this: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> This is referring to a situation <b>where he did not write a document [<i>ono</i>] for</b> the slave when he sold him to the gentile. <b>But</b> if <b>he wrote a document for him, this</b> itself <b>is his emancipation.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this <b>document? Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>he writes to him: When you escape from him I have no business with you.</b> This indicates that the formula: I have no business with you, is a valid expression of emancipation.
§ <b>Abaye says:</b> With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan,</b> i.e., he previously lent this woman money and he now says that she is betrothed to him by means of that loan, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> The reason is that a woman can be betrothed only through her acceptance of money, or an item that has monetary value, at the time of the betrothal. Although this woman owes the man money, at the time the man states that she is betrothed to him, the loan is not in fact money but an obligation. Therefore, he does not actually give her anything at the time of the betrothal. By contrast, if he betroths her <b>by</b> means of <b>the benefit of the loan, she is betrothed. But it is prohibited to do so, due to</b> the fact that betrothing a woman via the benefit of a loan is <b>an artifice</b> used to circumvent the prohibition <b>of</b> receiving <b>interest,</b> as this enables the husband to gain an additional benefit from the loan.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is meant</b> by <b>this</b> term: <b>The benefit of the loan? If we say that</b> it means that <b>he established</b> interest <b>upon it</b> when she took the loan, e.g., <b>he said to her</b> that he is lending her <b>four</b> coins <b>in</b> exchange for the repayment of <b>five,</b> and he betroths her by releasing her from the obligation to pay this additional coin, <b>this is</b> a case of <b>full-fledged interest,</b> not merely an artifice used to circumvent the prohibition of receiving interest. He is receiving full payment of the loan and an additional benefit. <b>And furthermore,</b> when he releases her from the obligation to pay this additional coin, he is simply forgoing another obligation she has toward him; he is not giving her anything. <b>This is</b> like a regular case of a betrothal with <b>a loan,</b> and therefore she should not be betrothed.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he extended the time</b> of the loan <b>for her.</b> When the time for her to repay the loan arrived he extended the deadline and betrothed her with the financial benefit she receives from the extra time he is giving her to use the money. In this case he does betroth her with the value he is giving her at that time, but it is similar to interest, as it is included in the prohibition of interest to pay the creditor for an extension of the time of a loan.
§ <b>Rava says:</b> With regard to one who says to another: <b>Here are one hundred dinars for you</b> that I am giving you <b>on the condition that you return them to me,</b> if he gave these one hundred dinars as part <b>of a purchase, he does not acquire</b> the item, as he has not given the seller any money. And similarly, <b>with regard to a woman,</b> if he gave her money for her betrothal on the condition that she return it, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> If one gave money in this manner <b>for</b> the <b>redemption of</b> his firstborn <b>son,</b> for which a priest must receive five <i>sela</i>, <b>his son is not redeemed.</b>
If one does this <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., he gives produce to a priest as <i>teruma</i> on the condition that it will be returned, <b>he has</b> technically <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation of <b>giving.</b> Once he gets the <i>teruma</i> back it belongs to him, as he is the original owner, and although it is prohibited for him to partake of it, as he is a non-priest, he may sell it to a different priest. <b>But it is prohibited to do this,</b> i.e., give <i>teruma</i> in this manner, <i>ab initio</i>, <b>because</b> this priest receiving the <i>teruma</i> <b>appears like a priest who assists at the threshing floor,</b> as he presumably agrees to this arrangement in return for some gain.
The Gemara asks: <b>What does Rava maintain? If he maintains</b> that <b>a gift</b> given <b>on the condition that it is returned is called a gift,</b> this should apply not only to <i>teruma</i> but <b>even</b> to <b>all</b> the other cases, i.e., it should be considered a valid gift in all of the above cases. <b>And if he maintains</b> that a gift of this kind <b>is not called a gift,</b> then <b>even</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> it</b> should <b>not</b> be considered a legitimate form of giving.
<b>And furthermore, Rava is the one who says: A gift given on the condition that it is</b> later <b>returned is called a gift. As Rava said</b> that if one says to another on the first day of the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>: <b>Take this <i>etrog</i> on the condition that you return it to me,</b> and the recipient <b>takes it,</b> recites a blessing over it, <b>and returns it, he has fulfilled</b> his obligation, despite the fact that one must own the <i>etrog</i> he uses for the mitzva on the first day of <i>Sukkot</i>. <b>And if he does not</b> return it <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation, as he gave him the gift only on the condition that it would be returned. This indicates that in the opinion of Rava, a gift that is given on the condition that it is returned is considered a gift.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: In all of these</b> cases the gift is <b>acquired, except for</b> the betrothal of <b>a woman, because a woman cannot be acquired by</b> means of symbolic <b>exchange. Rav Huna Mar, son of Rav Neḥemya, said to Rav Ashi: We say this in the name of Rava in accordance with your</b> opinion, not in accordance with the previous ruling.
§ <b>Rava says</b> that if a woman said to a man: <b>Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so</b>

Daf 7a

<b>and I will be betrothed to you</b> by means of these one hundred dinars that you give to that individual, <b>she is betrothed,</b> as derived <b>from</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> of <b>a guarantor.</b> How so? With regard to <b>a guarantor,</b> is it <b>not</b> the case that <b>he commits himself</b> to repaying the debt <b>even though he receives no benefit,</b> as the money from the loan is given to the debtor? And with regard to <b>this woman too, even though she receives no benefit,</b> as the one hundred dinars are given to someone else, nevertheless <b>she commits and transfers herself</b> to the man who gives the money.
The Gemara discusses a similar case: If a man gives one hundred dinars to a woman and says to her: <b>Here are one hundred dinars for you, and</b> with this money you <b>become betrothed to so-and-so, she is betrothed,</b> as derived <b>from</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> of emancipating <b>a Canaanite slave.</b> With regard to <b>a Canaanite slave,</b> is it <b>not</b> the case that <b>he acquires himself</b> and is freed when someone gives his master money to emancipate the slave, <b>even though he loses nothing</b> of his own? With regard to <b>this man too,</b> i.e., the third party, <b>even though he loses nothing</b> of his own, <b>he acquires this woman</b> by means of the other man’s payment.
The Gemara discusses a similar case: A woman says to a man: <b>Give one hundred dinars to so-and-so and I will be betrothed to him.</b> If he gives the money, <b>she is betrothed,</b> as is derived <b>from</b> a combination of the <b><i>halakha</i></b> of <b>both of</b> these cases, that of a guarantor and a Canaanite slave. How so? With regard to <b>a guarantor,</b> is it <b>not</b> the case that <b>he commits himself</b> to repaying the debt <b>even though he receives no benefit?</b> With regard to <b>this woman too, even though she receives no benefit,</b> nevertheless <b>she commits and transfers herself.</b>
This consideration alone is insufficient, as one could still ask: <b>Are</b> these cases <b>comparable?</b> In the case of <b>a guarantor, the one who acquires</b> the item in question, which in this case is the commitment of the guarantor, is the one <b>who loses money</b> when he gives the loan. By contrast, in the situation at hand, <b>this man,</b> the third party, <b>acquires the woman and loses nothing</b> of his own. Therefore, the Gemara comments: The emancipating of <b>a Canaanite slave can prove it, as he does not lose</b> his own <b>money and</b> nevertheless <b>he acquires himself.</b>
This consideration alone is insufficient, as one could still ask: <b>Are</b> these cases <b>comparable? There,</b> with regard to a slave, <b>the one who transfers</b> ownership <b>is the one who acquires</b> it, as the master transfers ownership of the slave to the slave, and he himself acquires the money from the donor. <b>Here, this woman transfers herself and she does not acquire anything.</b> Rather, in this regard the case of <b>a guarantor can prove it,</b> as <b>even though he receives no benefit</b> from the creditor, nevertheless, he <b>commits himself,</b> just like the woman in this case. In this manner one can derive that the woman is betrothed in this case from a combination of those two <i>halakhot</i>.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> If a woman said to a man: <b>Here are one hundred dinars and I will be betrothed to you, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Mar Zutra said in the name of Rav Pappa: She is betrothed. Rav Ashi said to Mar Zutra: If so, this is</b> an example of a case in which <b>property that serves as a guarantee is acquired with property that is not guaranteed.</b> Land is property that serves as a guarantee, and, as derived by way of a verbal analogy, the same applies to people. Money is property that does not serve as a guarantee. Through his acquisition of the money, this man acquires the woman as well.
Rav Ashi asks: <b>But we learned the opposite</b> in a mishna (26a): <b>Property that does not serve as a guarantee can be acquired with property that serves as a guarantee through</b> giving <b>money, through</b> giving <b>a document, or through</b> taking <b>possession</b> of them. By contrast, property that serves as a guarantee cannot be acquired by means of acquiring property that does not serve as a guarantee. Mar Zutra <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>Do you maintain that she</b> wants her acquisition to be performed <b>by means of</b> money, i.e., he will acquire her as well through monetary acquisition? Not so, as <b>here we are dealing with an important man, as, due to the benefit</b> she receives from the fact <b>that he</b> consents to <b>accept a gift from her, she agrees to transfer herself</b> to him.
The Gemara reverts back to the earlier discussion with regard to the derivation from the cases of a guarantor and a Canaanite slave. <b>It was also stated in the name of Rava: And similarly, with regard to monetary matters,</b> one can conduct a valid acquisition in the modes derived from the cases of a guarantor and a Canaanite slave. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to both betrothal and monetary acquisitions.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>As, had he taught us</b> only the case of <b>betrothal,</b> one would have said that this <i>halakha</i> applies specifically in that case, <b>because a woman is amenable</b> to be betrothed <b>with any</b> form of benefit, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Reish Lakish. As Reish Lakish said:</b> There is a popular saying among women: <b>It is better to sit</b> as <b>two bodies,</b> i.e., be married, <b>than to sit</b> alone like a <b>widow.</b> A woman prefers any type of husband to being left alone. Consequently, she would be willing to commit herself to betrothal by any form of benefit. <b>But with regard to monetary matters,</b> one might <b>say</b> that these types of unusual acquisitions are <b>not</b> effective.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if he had taught us</b> only that this is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>monetary matters,</b> one might have said that it applies solely to a case of this kind, <b>because</b> a monetary claim <b>can be waived.</b> One can relinquish his claim to money that is in someone else’s possession without receiving anything in return. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>betrothal,</b> which does not entirely depend on the will and agreement of the woman, as she must actually receive her betrothal money, one might <b>say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of a guarantor and a Canaanite slave are <b>not</b> comparable to this case. Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to state that this is the <i>halakha</i> in both cases.
§ <b>Rava says</b> that if a man says to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to half of me, she is betrothed.</b> But if he said to her: <b>Half of you is betrothed to me, she is not betrothed. Abaye said to Rava: What is different</b> between the two cases <b>that</b> if he says: <b>Half of you is betrothed to me, she is not betrothed?</b> Is it because <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “When a man takes a woman, and marries her” (Deuteronomy 24:1), indicating he must take <b>“a woman,” and not half a woman? So too, the Merciful One states: “A man,” and not half a man.</b>
Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There, a woman is not eligible for two</b> men. If one attempts to betroth half a woman it means he wants to leave her other half for someone else. This is impossible, as a woman cannot be married to two men. <b>But isn’t a man eligible to</b> marry <b>two</b> women? <b>And</b> when he declares: Be betrothed to half of me, <b>this is what he is saying to her: If I wish to marry another</b> woman, <b>I will marry</b> another woman.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: But</b> in a case where he says to her: Half of you is betrothed to me, <b>let the betrothal spread through all of her,</b> and she will be completely betrothed. <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Temura</i> 1:5) that if <b>one says</b> about an animal: <b>The leg of this</b> animal <b>is a burnt-offering, all of it is a burnt-offering,</b> as the sanctity of the leg spreads throughout the animal’s entire body?
Mar Zutra adds: <b>And even according to the one who says</b> that <b>it is not entirely a burnt-offering, that statement</b> applies only <b>where he consecrated</b> the leg of the animal, which is <b>not a matter upon which</b> the animal’s <b>life depends.</b> It is possible for an animal to survive the removal of a leg. <b>But</b> if <b>one consecrates a matter upon which</b> the animal’s <b>life depends,</b> everyone agrees that <b>all of it is a burnt-offering.</b> Here too, as the woman cannot survive without half of her body, why doesn’t the betrothal spread throughout all of her?
The Gemara rejects this opinion: <b>Is it comparable? There,</b> in the case of the <b>animal,</b> it involves a creature without intellectual capacity. <b>Here,</b> the issue depends on <b>another mind,</b> that of the woman herself. The woman must indicate that she wants the betrothal to be effective.
<b>This</b> case <b>is comparable only to that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>which Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b>an animal</b> that <b>belongs to two partners,</b> if one of them <b>consecrated</b> the <b>half of it</b> that belonged to him, <b>and</b> he <b>goes back and acquires</b> the other half from his partner <b>and consecrates</b> the other half, it is <b>consecrated,</b> despite the fact that it was consecrated on two separate occasions. <b>But</b> although it is consecrated, <b>it may not be sacrificed,</b> because when he first sanctified it the animal was not fit to be sacrificed. The consecration does not spread throughout the entire animal without the consent of the other partner. This flaw cannot be remedied and the animal is permanently disqualified from being sacrificed as an offering.
<b>But,</b> as it is consecrated now, this is enough to <b>render</b> a non-sacred animal that is exchanged with it <b>a substitute.</b> If one exchanges this animal with another, non-consecrated, animal, the second animal becomes consecrated as well. <b>And</b> yet <b>its substitution is like it,</b> i.e., it too is consecrated but may not be sacrificed either.
The Gemara comments: One can <b>learn from</b> the statement <b>three</b> <i>halakhot</i>.

Daf 7b

<b>Conclude from it that living things can be</b> permanently <b>deferred.</b> Not only an offering that has already been slaughtered, but also a living animal that has been separated as an offering for which it is disqualified, is permanently deferred from being sacrificed on the altar. Likewise here, when he consecrated only half of it, the animal cannot be offered and is rejected. This ruling is in opposition to the claim that only slaughtered animals are permanently rejected.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>learn from it that deferral at the outset,</b> i.e., a condition disqualifying the animal from being sacrificed that was present when the animal was first consecrated, <b>is</b> considered a permanent <b>deferral.</b> One does not say that the <i>halakha</i> of deferral applies only to an animal that was eligible to be sacrificed at the time it was consecrated and later was deferred. <b>And learn from it</b> that <b>there is deferral</b> not only with regard to an offering itself, but also <b>with regard to monetary</b> value, i.e., deferral applies even to an animal whose value was consecrated. In this case, half of an animal is not consecrated to be sacrificed as an offering, and yet it can still be permanently deferred from the altar.
§ <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> If a man says to a woman: <b>Half of you</b> is betrothed <b>with half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i>, and half of you with half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does one say that <b>since he said to her: Half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i>, he has divided</b> his statement? In other words, by specifying half of one <i>peruta</i> he intended the betrothal to be performed in two stages, with one half-<i>peruta</i> for each stage, and half of one <i>peruta</i> does not effect betrothal. <b>Or perhaps he was counting</b> toward the full sum of the betrothal money, and intends for the betrothal to take effect at one time.
And <b>if you say</b> that in that case it is considered as though <b>he were counting,</b> then if he said to her: <b>Half of you</b> is betrothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i> and half of you with one <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does one say that <b>since he said to her: With one <i>peruta</i> and one <i>peruta</i>, he divided his statement</b> and intended to betroth her two halves separately, and one cannot betroth half a woman? <b>Or perhaps anything</b> that he does <b>on</b> that <b>day is</b> considered as if <b>he were counting,</b> i.e., since he intended to complete the action that day it is as though she were betrothed with two <i>perutot</i>.
And <b>if you say</b> that <b>everything</b> he does <b>on</b> that <b>day</b> is considered as if <b>he were counting,</b> then if he said to her: <b>Half of you</b> is betrothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i> today, and half of you</b> is betrothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i> tomorrow, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does one say that <b>since he said to her: Tomorrow,</b> he has <b>divided</b> his statement, which prevents the days from being combined, <b>or perhaps this is what he is saying to her: The betrothal begins from now, and</b> it <b>will not be completed until tomorrow.</b>
Rava further inquires: If he said to her: <b>Your two halves</b> are be-trothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Here, he certainly spoke to her at one time,</b> i.e., he did not divide his statement into two, and therefore it should be a valid betrothal, <b>or perhaps a woman may not be betrothed in halves at all.</b> No resolution was found for any of these questions, and therefore the Gemara says that the dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava raises</b> another <b>dilemma.</b> If one man said to another: Let <b>your two daughters</b> be betrothed <b>to my two sons with one <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains the two sides of the dilemma: Do <b>we follow the giver and recipient, and</b> as the giver bestows one <i>peruta</i> and the recipient receives one <i>peruta</i> <b>there is money</b> here, since one <i>peruta</i> is considered money and therefore the betrothal is valid. <b>Or perhaps we follow them,</b> i.e., those affected by the issue, in this case the sons and the daughters, <b>and there is not</b> one <i>peruta</i> for each of these individuals, and therefore the betrothal is not valid? This problem is also left unanswered, and therefore the Gemara says that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> If one man said to another: I hereby acquire <b>your daughter and your cow with one <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that he meant: <b>Your daughter</b> should be betrothed <b>with half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i> and your cow</b> purchased <b>with half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i>?</b> In that case neither the betrothal nor the acquisition take effect. <b>Or perhaps</b> he meant: <b>Your daughter</b> should be betrothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i> and your cow</b> should be acquired <b>by pulling?</b> No satisfactory answer was found in this case either, and the Gemara says that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> If he said: I hereby acquire <b>your daughter and your land with one <i>peruta</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does this mean: <b>Your daughter</b> should be betrothed <b>with half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i> and your land</b> should be acquired <b>with half</b> of <b>one <i>peruta</i>? Or perhaps</b> it means: <b>Your daughter</b> should be betrothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i> and your land</b> should be acquired <b>through</b> the act of <b>taking possession?</b> This question is also left unanswered, and the Gemara again says that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with silk [<i>beshira’ei</i>]</b> garments. <b>Rabba said: An appraisal</b> of the value of the garments is <b>not necessary,</b> as they are certainly worth more than one <i>peruta</i>. <b>Rav Yosef said: An appraisal</b> of the value of the garments is <b>necessary,</b> and as the man did not determine the value of the silk garments before the betrothal, the betrothal is invalid. The Gemara comments: <b>If he said to her</b> that she should become betrothed to him <b>by any amount,</b> regardless of the value of the silk garments, <b>everyone agrees that</b> the garments do <b>not require appraisal,</b> as they are undoubtedly worth more than one <i>peruta</i>.
Conversely, <b>if he said to her</b> that they are worth <b>fifty</b> dinars, <b>and they are not worth fifty</b> dinars, then everyone agrees that the betrothal is not valid, as <b>they are not worth</b> the amount he specified. <b>They disagree when he said</b> that they are worth <b>fifty</b> dinars, <b>and</b> in actuality <b>they are worth fifty</b> dinars. <b>Rabba said: An appraisal</b> of the value of the garments is <b>not necessary</b> before the betrothal, <b>as they are worth fifty</b> dinars. <b>Rav Yosef said: An appraisal</b> of the value of the garments is <b>necessary, because the woman</b> herself <b>is not an expert in appraisal</b> and <b>she does not rely on</b> his assessment. Since she is unsure if the garments are actually worth fifty dinars as he claimed, she does not agree to be betrothed.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>even</b> in a case where he says to her: Be betrothed to me with these silk garments, <b>whatever</b> they are worth, the <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i>. The reason for the dispute in this case is as follows. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> An item <b>worth money is like money</b> in every way. <b>Just as money is set,</b> i.e., it has a clearly defined value,

Daf 8a

<b>so too,</b> an item with an item <b>worth money</b> must be <b>set,</b> i.e., it must have a clearly defined value.
<b>Rav Yosef said: From where do I say</b> this opinion? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to redeeming a Hebrew slave: “He shall give back the price of his redemption <b>out of the money that he was bought for”</b> (Leviticus 25:51), which indicates: <b>He is acquired</b> specifically <b>through money and he is not acquired through grain or vessels.</b>
Rav Yosef explains: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>these grains and vessels? If we say that</b> a Hebrew slave <b>cannot be acquired through them at all,</b> as money alone may be used, <b>the Merciful One states: “He shall give back the price of his redemption,”</b> which serves <b>to include</b> all modes of repayment as valid equivalents of money, i.e., an item <b>worth money</b> is the same <b>as money.</b> There is no requirement to use money in particular; it is also possible to use items with monetary value.
<b>And if</b> you say <b>that they do not have the value of one <i>peruta</i>, why</b> mention <b>specifically grain and vessels? Even money</b> that is not worth one <i>peruta</i> cannot be used for acquiring a slave. <b>Rather, is it not</b> speaking here about a case <b>where</b> the grain and vessels <b>do have the value of one <i>peruta</i>, but since they lack a set</b> value, <b>no,</b> a Hebrew slave cannot be redeemed with them? The comparison with money teaches that a Hebrew slave can be redeemed only with an item that has a clearly defined value, like money.
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabba, who maintains that appraisal is not necessary, would respond: The <i>tanna</i> is referring to an item worth one <i>peruta</i>, but he is not teaching that one cannot redeem a slave with items whose value is not set. Rather, <b>this is what he is saying:</b> A Hebrew slave <b>is acquired through the mode of money, and he is not acquired through the mode of grain or vessels. And what is this</b> mode particular to the acquisition of grain and vessels? This is referring to symbolic <b>exchange.</b> A slave cannot be acquired through the mode of acquisition of symbolic exchange.
The Gemara notes: This explanation is valid only according to those who say that grain can be acquired through the mode of exchange; <b>but according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman, who said</b> that <b>produce cannot effect</b> symbolic <b>exchange,</b> as this mode of acquisition applies only to vessels, <b>what can be said?</b> Why does the <i>tanna</i> mention grain if grain cannot be used in symbolic exchange? <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects this explanation in favor of the following: <b>Actually,</b> this is referring to a case where the grain and utensils <b>do not have the value of one <i>peruta</i>. And as for that which you said: Why</b> mention <b>specifically grain and vessels; even money</b> that is not worth one <i>peruta</i> cannot acquire <b>either,</b> one could say that the <i>tanna</i> <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>It is not necessary</b> to state with regard to <b>money that if it has the value of one <i>peruta</i>, yes,</b> one effects acquisition with it, and <b>if not,</b> then <b>no,</b> one cannot effect acquisition with it. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>grain and vessels,</b> one might <b>say that</b> as <b>their benefit is</b> readily <b>available,</b> i.e., one can enjoy them immediately in their current state, perhaps the slave <b>decides and transfers</b> ownership of <b>himself</b> to the master by even less than the worth of one <i>peruta</i>. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that an article less than the value of one <i>peruta</i> cannot effect acquisition notwithstanding the above reasoning.
<b>Rav Yosef said: From where do I say</b> that betrothal can be effected only with an item with a clearly defined value? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 6:4), that if one says to a priest: <b>This calf</b> should be <b>for the redemption of my</b> firstborn <b>son,</b> or: <b>This cloak</b> should be <b>for the redemption of my</b> firstborn <b>son,</b> then <b>he has said nothing.</b> But if he said: <b>This calf</b> worth the value <b>of five <i>sela</i></b> should be <b>for the redemption of my</b> firstborn <b>son,</b> or: <b>This cloak</b> worth the value <b>of five <i>sela</i></b> should be <b>for the redemption of my</b> firstborn <b>son,</b> then <b>his son is redeemed.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> with regard to <b>this redemption</b> with a calf or a cloak that has no clearly defined value? <b>If we say that they are not worth</b> five <i>sela</i>, <b>is it in his</b> power to give a priest less than the established amount? Why would it even be considered that perhaps the son is redeemed? <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case where <b>even though they are worth</b> this amount, one <b>may not</b> redeem with them in the case of the first clause <b>since their value is not set?</b> This shows that there is a difference between an item that has a set value and one that does not.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No; actually,</b> this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the calf or cloak <b>is not worth</b> five <i>sela</i>, <b>and</b> the latter clause is referring to a case <b>where the priest accepted upon himself</b> to value the items as though they were worth this amount, which is why the son is redeemed. <b>This is like this</b> incident in <b>which Rav Kahana,</b> who was a priest, <b>took a cloth [<i>sudara</i>] from the house</b> of a man obligated to perform <b>the redemption of</b> his firstborn <b>son.</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> the man: <b>For me, I view</b> this cloth as though it were worth <b>five <i>sela</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: We said</b> that it is possible to redeem one’s son in this manner <b>only</b> when the priest is an individual <b>such as Rav Kahana, who is a great man and is required</b> to wear <b>a cloth on his head.</b> It was common practice for important people to wear a scarf on their heads. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>everyone</b> else, i.e., those who do not wear these cloths and cannot say it is worth that amount to them, <b>no,</b> they may not perform the redemption of the firstborn son in this manner. The Gemara cites a proof that a distinguished individual who needs a cloth will pay a large amount for one. <b>This is like this</b> incident in <b>which Mar bar Rav Ashi bought a cloth from Rabba’s mother from Kovei for thirteen</b> dinars, despite the fact that it was <b>worth ten,</b> because he needed a cloth.
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars, and he gave her</b> one <b>dinar</b> out of the one hundred, <b>she is betrothed</b> immediately <b>and he must</b> subsequently <b>complete</b> the payment of the remainder of the amount he promised her. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Since he said to her:</b> Be betrothed to me with <b>one hundred dinars, and</b> yet <b>he gave her</b> only one <b>dinar, he is like one who said to her:</b> Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition</b> that I will give you one hundred dinars. In other words, he betroths her now with one dinar on the condition he will pay the remaining ninety-nine in the future. The betrothal therefore takes effect immediately, and he owes her the rest of the one hundred dinars.
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> this is in accordance with the opinion that <b>Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>anyone who states</b> a provision employing the phrase: <b>On the condition, it is</b> tantamount to his <b>stipulating</b> that the agreement take effect retroactively <b>from now.</b> An agreement stipulated by means of the phrase: On the condition, takes effect immediately. This is not like an ordinary agreement, which takes effect only after the condition has been fulfilled.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:10). If a man says to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars, and</b> while <b>he was counting</b> the money, <b>one of them wanted to retract</b> the betrothal, <b>it is in the power</b> of either of them to do so <b>even when</b> only <b>the last</b> dinar remains to be given. This indicates that the betrothal does not take effect until the entire one hundred dinars has been paid.
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> This is a case <b>where he says</b> to the woman: Be betrothed to me <b>with this one hundred dinars.</b> In this case the entire one hundred dinars, not just the first dinar, constitutes the betrothal money. The Gemara raises a difficulty with this answer: <b>From</b> the fact that <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> uses the expression: <b>With this one hundred dinars,</b> it can be inferred that <b>the first clause</b> is dealing with <b>an unspecified one hundred dinars.</b>
<b>As it is taught in the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i>, if <b>he said</b> to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with this one hundred dinars, and it was found to be one hundred dinars less a dinar, or</b> if it included <b>a dinar of copper</b> instead of silver, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> If one of the dinars was found to be <b>a flawed dinar,</b> i.e., it was a silver dinar but it was so worn that it would not be universally accepted, <b>she is betrothed, and he must exchange</b> that dinar for a different one. Since the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> emphasizes the term: This one hundred dinars, evidently the first clause of the <i>baraita</i> must be referring to an unspecified one hundred dinars.
The Gemara rejects this opinion: <b>No;</b> one can say that the <b>first clause and the latter clause</b> are both referring to a case <b>where he said: With this one hundred dinars, and</b> the latter clause <b>is explaining</b> the first clause, as follows: If <b>one of them wishes to retract the</b> betrothal, <b>it is in the power</b> of either of them to do so <b>even when</b> only <b>the last</b> dinar remains to be given. <b>How so?</b> This is referring to a case <b>where he said to her: With this one hundred dinars.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And so too, it is reasonable</b> to explain the <i>baraita</i> this way, <b>as, if it enters your mind</b> that <b>the first clause</b> is referring <b>to an unspecified one hundred dinars,</b> consider the following: <b>Now</b> if <b>it is not a betrothal in</b> a case involving <b>an unspecified one hundred dinars,</b> and she can retract her agreement to the betrothal, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that she can retract it when he says: <b>With this one hundred dinars?</b> If that were the correct interpretation of the first clause, the ruling in the last clause would be unnecessary.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>If it is due to that</b> reason, <b>there is no</b> conclusive <b>argument,</b> i.e., the proof of the argument is inconclusive. The reason is that one could say that the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught the latter clause to reveal</b> the meaning of <b>the first clause.</b> The function of the latter clause is not to teach a novel <i>halakha</i>, but to preempt a mistaken reading of the first clause. The latter clause was stated so <b>that you should not</b> mistakenly <b>say that the first clause</b> is referring only to a situation when he said: <b>With this one hundred dinars, but in</b> a case of <b>an unspecified one hundred dinars, it</b> would be <b>a betrothal.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in <b>the latter clause: With this one hundred dinars,</b> which teaches <b>by inference that the first clause</b> is referring <b>to an unspecified one hundred dinars, and even so it is not a betrothal.</b> Although this proof is rejected, the Gemara remains with its explanation that the first clause is referring to a case where he said to her: With this one hundred dinars.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is unnecessary to explain that the first clause of the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where he said: With this one hundred dinars, as a situation where he <b>was counting</b> the money <b>is different.</b> The reason is <b>that she has the entirety</b> of the one hundred dinars <b>in mind,</b> and therefore she will not be content with some of the money. His continuous action indicates that they both expect that he will give her the entire one hundred dinars, and consequently both parties can retract their agreement until he finishes counting.
The Gemara further analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What are the circumstances of this copper dinar</b> mentioned here? <b>If she knows that it</b> is a copper dinar, <b>she knew and accepted</b> this coin as a dinar. If so, she cannot later retract her betrothal. The Gemara answers: <b>No;</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he gave her</b> this dinar <b>at night</b> and at the time she did not see that it was copper. <b>Alternatively, it was found among</b> the other <b>dinars,</b> and she did not notice that one of them one was copper.
The Gemara further asks: <b>What are the circumstances of this flawed dinar,</b> also mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If it cannot be spent,</b> i.e., it cannot pass as a silver dinar, <b>this is</b> exactly like <b>a copper dinar,</b> as it too is not worth a full dinar. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where</b> the dinar <b>can be spent with difficulty,</b> i.e., it is difficult, but not impossible, to find someone who will accept it.
§ <b>Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> If <b>one said to</b> a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars, and</b> instead of giving it to her <b>he gave her collateral for</b> the money, <b>she is not betrothed.</b>

Daf 8b

<b>There is no one hundred dinars here,</b> as he has not yet given her one hundred dinars, and <b>there is no collateral here,</b> since this collateral is not a gift but merely a security. He has therefore not given her anything. <b>Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he betrothed her with collateral, she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> it is referring <b>to collateral</b> belonging <b>to other</b> people, which was in the possession of the man who betrothed her, <b>and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak.</b>
<b>As Rabbi Yitzḥak says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a creditor acquires collateral,</b> i.e., that the individual in possession of the collateral has the actual rights to it? <b>As it is stated:</b> “You shall surely restore him the pledge when the sun goes down that he may sleep in his garment, and bless you; <b>and it shall be righteousness to you”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:13). <b>If</b> the creditor <b>does not acquire</b> the pledge or collateral, <b>from where</b> does this considering his return of the collateral as <b>righteousness</b> stem? The creditor is not giving an item belonging to him; why is this considered a righteous act? Rather, <b>from here</b> it is derived <b>that a creditor acquires collateral</b> to a certain extent.
The Gemara relates: <b>The sons of Rav Huna bar Avin bought a certain maidservant</b> on the condition that they would pay <b>with</b> copper <b><i>perutot</i>. They did not have</b> the money at the time, and therefore <b>they gave a piece of silver [<i>naskha</i>] for her</b> as collateral. <b>Ultimately,</b> the price of the <b>maidservant increased</b> and the sellers wanted to cancel the sale. <b>They came before Rabbi Ami</b> for his ruling and <b>he said to them: There are no <i>perutot</i> here,</b> and <b>there is no piece of silver here</b> either. There was no valid act of acquisition at all because they did not actually give the money, and the collateral does not transfer ownership.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:9): If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars,</b> and <b>she took it</b> from his hand <b>and threw it into the sea, or into the fire, or into anything that destroys, she is not betrothed.</b> The Gemara expresses surprise at this ruling: The <i>baraita</i> indicates that she is not betrothed only if the one hundred dinars are destroyed, <b>but</b> if she <b>threw the coins before him</b> but did not destroy them, <b>that is a betrothal.</b> Why should this be? By throwing the coins at him <b>she is</b> effectively <b>saying to him: Take</b> this; <b>I do not want</b> your betrothal.
The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is speaking</b> using the style of: <b>It is not necessary,</b> as follows: <b>It is not necessary</b> to state in a case where <b>she throws</b> the money <b>before him that it is not a betrothal,</b> as her action indicates that she does not want to be betrothed. <b>But</b> when <b>she throws it into the sea or into the fire,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>since she is obligated</b> to pay <b>for</b> the money he gave her, perhaps <b>she betrothed herself</b> with the money she received. <b>And as</b> for the reason why <b>she did this</b> act of destroying the money, <b>she thought: I will test this man</b> to see <b>if he is</b> an individual of <b>an angry</b> temperament <b>or not.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that even in that case it is not a betrothal.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:9): If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars,</b> and she said to him: <b>Give</b> the money <b>to</b> my <b>father,</b> or: Give the money <b>to your father, she is not betrothed.</b> If she said: Give the money to my father, or Give the money to your father <b>on the condition that he accepts them for me, she is betrothed.</b>
The Gemara comments: The <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> the case where she said: Give the money to my <b>father, to convey the far-reaching nature of</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the first clause.</b> If she simply said that he should give the money to anybody else, even her own father, whom it can be assumed she wants to benefit, she is still not betrothed. And the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> the case where she said: Give the money to <b>your father, to convey the far-reaching nature of</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the latter clause.</b> If she said that someone else should receive the money on her behalf, it is a valid betrothal even if she said the money should be given to his father.
The Gemara cites a similar case. If he said to her: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars,</b> and she said to him: <b>Give them to so-and-so, she is not betrothed.</b> But if she said to him: <b>On the condition that he accepts them for me, she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>It is necessary</b> to issue this ruling, despite the fact that it is apparently identical to the previous <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara elaborates: This is <b>because if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us</b> only the case where she said: <b>Give</b> the money <b>to</b> my <b>father,</b> or: Give the money <b>to your father,</b> one would say that <b>it is</b> in that case <b>there, when she said: On the condition that</b> one of these relatives <b>accepts them for me,</b> that <b>it is a betrothal, as she relies on them</b> and she <b>thinks: They will do my bidding for me</b> and will hold this money on my behalf. <b>But</b> if she says: Give it to <b>so-and-so,</b> someone who is not related to either of them, <b>no,</b> the betrothal is not valid.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>so-and-so,</b> one might say: <b>It is here, when she said: Give it to so-and-so,</b> that <b>it is not a betrothal,</b> as <b>she is not close to him</b> and is not interested in <b>giving him</b> this money <b>as a gift. But</b> if she said: <b>Give</b> the money <b>to</b> my <b>father,</b> or: Give the money <b>to your father, to whom she is close,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>she gave it to them as a gift,</b> i.e., she accepted the sum as her betrothal money and decided to give it as a gift. If so, she should be betrothed. <b>It was</b> therefore <b>necessary</b> for the <i>tanna</i> to issue both rulings and clarify that she is not betrothed in either case.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars,</b> and she said to him: <b>Place them on a rock, she is not betrothed. And if</b> the <b>rock was hers, she is betrothed. Rav Beivai raises a dilemma:</b> If the <b>rock was</b> the property <b>of both of them, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? No answer was found, and the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara discusses a similar case. If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with a loaf</b> of bread, and she said to him: <b>Give it to a dog, she is not betrothed. And if</b> this <b>dog was hers, she is betrothed. Rav Mari raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>a dog</b> was <b>chasing her</b> to bite her, and she said to him: Give the loaf to the dog, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara presents the two sides of the dilemma: Does one say that <b>she commits herself</b> to betrothal <b>and transfers herself</b> to him <b>through this benefit that</b> she receives <b>by being rescued</b> from the dog? <b>Or perhaps she can say to him: By Torah law you are required to rescue me,</b> due to the injunction: “Neither shall you stand idly by the blood of your neighbor” (Leviticus 19:16), and therefore she is not betrothed with the loaf because she does not owe him anything. This problem is also left unanswered, and the Gemara again states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with a loaf</b> of bread, and she said: <b>Give it to a poor person, she is not betrothed, even</b> if it was <b>a poor person who is dependent upon her,</b> i.e., a poor person who regularly receives food from that woman. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? She could <b>say to him: Just as I am required</b> to give charity to <b>him, so too you are required</b> to give charity to <b>him.</b> Therefore, this donation is not an indication that she has agreed to the betrothal.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who was selling</b>

Daf 9a

<b>beads [<i>ḥumrei</i>]of glass [<i>petakhyata</i>]. A certain woman came</b> and <b>said to him: Give me one string. He said to her: If I give you</b> this string <b>will you be betrothed to me</b> with it? <b>She said to him: Give, give. Rav Ḥama said: Any</b> use of the expression: <b>Give, give, is nothing.</b> Although she said: Give, give, she did not agree to the condition, as she was mocking him and had no intention of actually becoming betrothed.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <b>a certain man who was drinking wine in a store. A woman came</b> in and <b>said to him: Give me one cup</b> of wine. <b>He said to her: If I give you</b> a cup of wine will <b>you be betrothed to me</b> with it? <b>She said to him: Give to drink, give</b> it <b>to me to drink. Rav Ḥama said</b> that <b>any</b> use of the expression: <b>Give to drink, give</b> it <b>to me to drink, is nothing,</b> i.e., she certainly did not intend to accept the condition and she is not betrothed.
The Gemara further relates: There was <b>a certain man who was picking dates from a date tree. A certain woman came</b> and <b>said to him: Throw me two. He said to her: If I throw</b> two dates <b>to you</b> will <b>you be betrothed to me</b> with them? <b>She said to him: Throw, throw. Rav Zevid said: Any use</b> of the expression: <b>Throw, throw, is nothing,</b> and she is not betrothed.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If she said: <b>Give,</b> or: <b>Give to drink,</b> or: <b>Throw,</b> without the additional emphasis of the repetition, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does this straightforward statement indicate that she actually meant him to give it to her in accordance with his stated condition, or does she not agree to betrothal even here? <b>Ravina said: She is betrothed. Rav Sama bar Rakta said</b> in the form of an oath: <b>By the king’s crown! She is not betrothed.</b> The Gemara states: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>she is not betrothed.</b>
The Gemara issues further rulings concerning the previous cases. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: With regard to <b>silk</b> garments that are worth more than one <i>peruta</i>, <b>appraisal</b> is <b>not necessary</b> before a woman can be betrothed with them. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> that if a man promised a woman one hundred dinars as betrothal money and gave her only a dinar, she is betrothed. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> who said that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that if he promised one hundred dinars and gave her only collateral, this is not a valid betrothal.
§ <b>The Sages taught: How is</b> betrothal performed <b>with a document?</b> If he <b>wrote</b> the following <b>for</b> a young woman’s father <b>on paper or earthenware, despite</b> the fact <b>that</b> the paper or earthenware <b>is not worth one <i>peruta</i>: Your daughter is betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>Your daughter is betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>Your daughter is to me as a wife,</b> then <b>she is betrothed.</b> There is no requirement for the paper or earthenware to be worth one <i>peruta</i>, as she is not betrothed through the value of the paper or earthenware.
<b>Rabbi Zeira bar Memel objects to this</b> description of the writing of the document: <b>But this document is not comparable to a bill of sale. There,</b> in the case of a bill of sale, the <b>seller</b> is the one who <b>writes to</b> the buyer: <b>My field is sold to you. Here,</b> the <b>husband,</b> who is akin to a buyer, is the one who <b>writes: Your daughter is betrothed to me.</b>
<b>Rava said: There,</b> in the case of a sale, the formulation of the document is taken <b>from the context of the verse, and here,</b> in the case of betrothal, the formulation of the document is likewise taken <b>from the context of the verse.</b> Rava elaborates: <b>There,</b> with regard to a sale, <b>it is written: “And sells of his ancestral land”</b> (Leviticus 25:25), which indicates that <b>the Merciful One renders</b> the transaction <b>dependent on the seller. Here, it is written: “If</b> a man <b>takes</b> a woman” (Deuteronomy 22:13), meaning that <b>the Merciful One renders</b> the betrothal <b>dependent on the husband.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>There,</b> in the case of a sale, <b>it is also written: “Men shall buy [<i>yiknu</i>] fields for money”</b> (Jeremiah 32:44), which indicates that the matter depends upon the buyer. The Gemara answers: <b>Read into</b> the verse: Shall sell <b>[<i>yikkanu</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>you read it</b> as <b><i>yikkanu</i>; because it is written</b> in the verse in Leviticus: <b>“And sells,”</b> and there is a preference to have the verse from the Prophets accord with that of the Torah? <b>So too,</b> instead of: “If a man takes [<i>ki yikaḥ</i>]” (Deuteronomy 22:13), <b>read into</b> the verse: When he is given <b>[<i>ki yakiaḥ</i>], as it is written: “I gave my daughter to this man”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:16), so that the verses will accord with each other.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> There is no proof from the verses for these rulings, as <b>they are a <i>halakha</i></b> received through tradition, <b>and the Sages based them on</b> the <b>verses. And if you wish, say: There too,</b> in the case in Jeremiah, <b>it is written</b> with regard to the buyer: <b>“And I took the deed of purchase”</b> (Jeremiah 32:11), thereby indicating that it is the seller who writes the document.
<b>And Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> If he <b>wrote</b> the following <b>for him on paper or earthenware, despite</b> the fact <b>that</b> the paper or earthenware <b>is not worth one <i>peruta</i>: Your daughter is betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>Your daughter is betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>Your daughter is to me as a wife, whether</b> he gave it <b>to her father or whether</b> he gave it directly <b>to her, she is betrothed with the consent</b> of her father. <b>And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> provided <b>that she has not</b> yet <b>reached her majority,</b> before which her father alone has the authority to betroth her.
<b>If he wrote for her on paper or earthenware, despite</b> the fact <b>that</b> the paper or earthenware <b>is not worth one <i>peruta</i>: You are hereby betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>You are hereby to me as a wife,</b> or: <b>You are hereby betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>] to me,</b> then <b>she is betrothed whether</b> he gave it <b>to her father</b> or <b>to her,</b> as long as this was <b>with her consent. And this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> provided <b>that she has reached her majority</b> and is under her own authority.
§ <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a document of betrothal that was written not for her sake,</b> i.e., not for this particular woman, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>we juxtapose</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the <b>modes of becoming</b> betrothed <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the <b>modes of leaving</b> a marriage, i.e., divorce? If so, one should say: <b>Just as</b>

Daf 9b

<b>we require</b> that the document of <b>leaving,</b> i.e., a bill of divorce, must be written specifically <b>for her sake, so too, we require</b> that the document of <b>becoming</b> betrothed be written <b>for her sake. Or perhaps we juxtapose</b> the different <b>modes of becoming</b> betrothed <b>to each other</b> and say: <b>Just as we do not require</b> that <b>becoming</b> betrothed <b>with money</b> must be carried out with coins minted <b>for her sake, so too, we do not require</b> that <b>becoming</b> betrothed <b>with a document</b> must be with a document written <b>for her sake.</b>
<b>After he raised the dilemma,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>then resolved it. We juxtapose becoming</b> betrothed <b>to leaving</b> a marriage, <b>as the verse states: “And she departs</b> out of his house, and goes <b>and becomes”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:2). This shows that the <i>halakhot</i> of a betrothal document are derived from those of a bill of divorce, and therefore a document of betrothal must also be written for her sake.
<b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the following issue: If a man <b>wrote</b> a document of betrothal <b>for her sake but without her consent,</b> i.e., she did not know at the time that they were writing it but accepted it afterward, <b>Rava and Ravina say: She is betrothed. Rav Pappa and Rav Sherevya say: She is not betrothed. Rav Pappa said: I will say their reason and I will say my reason. I will state their reason, as it is written: “And she departs</b> out of his house, and goes <b>and becomes,”</b> by which the verse <b>juxtaposes becoming</b> betrothed <b>to leaving</b> a marriage. <b>Just as</b> a bill of divorce, written for <b>leaving</b> a marriage must be written <b>for her own sake but</b> can be written <b>without her consent, so too,</b> a document written for <b>becoming</b> betrothed must be written <b>for her own sake and</b> can even be <b>without her consent.</b>
<b>And I will say my reason:</b> The verse says: <b>“And she departs</b> out of his house, and goes <b>and becomes.”</b> The verse <b>juxtaposes becoming</b> betrothed <b>to leaving</b> a marriage. <b>Just as</b> with regard to a bill of divorce, written for <b>leaving</b> a marriage, <b>we require the consent of the one transferring</b> ownership, i.e., the man, as he divorces and transfers authority of the woman to herself, <b>so too,</b> with regard to a document written for <b>becoming</b> betrothed, <b>we require the consent of the one transferring</b> ownership, which in this case is the woman, who must agree to the marriage.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 167b) against the opinion that she is betrothed if the document was written without her consent. <b>One writes documents of betrothal and marriage only with the consent of both</b> the man and woman. <b>What, is</b> the mishna <b>not</b> referring to <b>actual documents of betrothal and marriage,</b> which indicates that the document must be written with the woman’s consent? The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No,</b> this is referring to <b>documents of stipulation,</b> which contain the details of the dowry. <b>And</b> this statement is <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Giddel</b> says that <b>Rav says.</b>
<b>As Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If the father of one member of the couple says to the father of the other: <b>How much are you giving to your son?</b> And he answers: <b>Such and such,</b> and adds: How much are you giving <b>to your daughter?</b> And the other responds: <b>Such and such,</b> then if <b>they,</b> the couple, subsequently <b>arose and</b> became <b>betrothed, they acquire</b> everything that was promised. <b>These are the matters that are acquired through speech,</b> and they do not require an act of acquisition. The documents of betrothal mentioned here that require the woman’s consent are those which contain this type of monetary obligation, not actual documents of betrothal.
§ The mishna teaches that a woman can be betrothed <b>through sexual intercourse.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>the verse states:</b> “If a man be found lying with <b>a married woman [<i>beulat ba’al</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:22). This <b>teaches that he becomes her husband [<i>ba’al</i>] by means of sexual intercourse [<i>be’ila</i>]. Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Abbahu, and some say</b> it was <b>Reish Lakish</b> who said this <b>to Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> Is <b>this</b> other proof, <b>taught by Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>unacceptable:</b> “When a man takes a woman <b>and engages in sexual intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1)? This verse <b>teaches</b> that <b>she can be acquired through intercourse.</b>
The Gemara answers that the verse cited by Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is insufficient proof that a woman can be betrothed via intercourse, as, <b>if</b> this <i>halakha</i> were derived only <b>from there, I would say</b> that she is not considered his wife <b>unless he</b> first <b>betroths</b> her through money, indicated by the phrase “takes a woman,” <b>and then engages in intercourse</b> with her. This is the only valid mode of betrothal, and intercourse alone is not enough. Therefore, the verse states “a married woman [<i>beulat ba’al</i>]” and <b>teaches us</b> that intercourse by itself is a valid means of betrothal.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel objects to this:</b> The above suggestion, that both money and sexual intercourse are required for betrothal, cannot be the correct interpretation of the verse: “When a man takes a woman and engages in sexual intercourse with her.” This is because, <b>if</b> it is <b>so,</b> that a woman can be acquired only through both betrothal money and intercourse, the case of one who engages in intercourse with <b>a betrothed young woman,</b> concerning which <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that he is punished <b>by stoning</b> (see Deuteronomy 22:23–24)<b>, how can you find</b> a case where he is liable to be punished in this manner?
Rabbi Abba bar Memel elaborates: <b>If</b> this is referring to a case <b>where he betrothed</b> her with money <b>and then engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with her, <b>she is a non-virgin,</b> and the punishment of stoning applies only to one who engages in intercourse with a betrothed young virgin. <b>If</b> it is referring to a case <b>where he betrothed</b> her with money <b>and did not engage in intercourse</b> with her, this <b>is nothing,</b> as the betrothal has not been completed. <b>The Rabbis said before Abaye: You find it</b> in a case <b>where</b> he betrothed her with money and then the <b>betrothed man engaged in intercourse with her in an atypical manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse. Despite the fact that she is still a virgin, the betrothal has taken effect by means of this type of sexual intercourse.
<b>Abaye said to</b> those Sages: The verse cannot be explained in that manner, as <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the Rabbis disagree only with regard to another</b> man, i.e., whether a woman is considered to be a virgin after engaging in anal intercourse with another man. <b>But</b> with regard to her <b>husband, everyone agrees</b> that <b>if he engages in intercourse in an atypical manner with her he has rendered her a non-virgin.</b> If so, she is no longer considered a virgin with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of a betrothed young woman.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is</b> the dispute to which Abaye refers? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 10:4): If <b>ten men engaged in sexual intercourse with</b> a betrothed young woman, <b>and she is still a virgin,</b> as they engaged in anal intercourse with her, <b>they are all</b> punished <b>by stoning. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say</b> that <b>the first</b> one is punished <b>by stoning,</b> as he engaged in intercourse with a virgin young woman, <b>but all</b> the others are punished <b>by strangulation.</b> Once the first man engages in intercourse with her she is no longer considered a virgin, even if he engaged in anal intercourse with her.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> a different answer to Rabbi Abba bar Memel’s question: <b>You find</b> a situation where a man who engages in intercourse with a betrothed young woman is punished by stoning in a case <b>where he betrothed her with a document.</b> Everyone agrees that <b>since</b> a document, i.e., a bill of divorce, <b>completely removes</b> a woman from her husband, without the need for an additional act, it also <b>completely brings</b> her into the state of betrothal. If a young woman is betrothed by means of a document, she can be a betrothed young woman while remaining a virgin.
The Gemara returns to the different derivations of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Yoḥanan. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who maintains that the mode of betrothal through intercourse is derived from the verse: “If a man be found lying with a married woman [<i>beulat ba’al</i>]” (Deuteronomy 22:22), what does he <b>do with this</b> verse: “When a man takes a woman <b>and engages in sexual intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1)? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires that</b> verse for a different <i>halakha</i>, as he maintains that it teaches that <b>this</b> woman <b>can be acquired through intercourse, but a Hebrew maidservant cannot be acquired through intercourse.</b>
As it might <b>enter your mind to say: Let</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a Hebrew maidservant <b>be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>yevama</i>: Just as a <i>yevama</i>, who cannot be acquired through money</b> at all, nevertheless <b>can be acquired through intercourse,</b> which indicates that the ability of an act of sexual intercourse to effect acquisition is greater than that of money, <b>is it not logical that this</b> Hebrew maidservant, <b>who can be acquired through money, can</b> also <b>be acquired through intercourse?</b>
The Gemara rejects this opinion: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a <i>yevama</i> is that she is bound and standing</b> waiting for the <i>yavam</i>, i.e., there is already a connection between them. Perhaps it is for this reason that intercourse enables a <i>yavam</i> to acquire a <i>yevama</i>, and the same cannot be said of a maidservant. Rather, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> a different claim: <b>Since it is written</b> with regard to a the master of a Hebrew maidservant: <b>“If he take himself another</b> wife” (Exodus 21:10), this <b>verse juxtaposes</b> a Hebrew maidservant <b>with another</b> woman that a master marries: <b>Just as another</b> woman that a master marries <b>can be acquired through intercourse, so too, a Hebrew maidservant can be acquired through intercourse. Therefore,</b> the verse <b>teaches us,</b> with the phrase “and engages in sexual intercourse with her,” that this is not the case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who learns that betrothal can be effected through sexual intercourse from this verse, <b>from where does he</b> derive <b>this conclusion</b> that a Hebrew maidservant cannot be acquired through intercourse? The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that this verse is teaching only one <i>halakha</i>, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> simply: <b>And he engages in sexual intercourse. What</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>“And he engages in sexual intercourse with her”? Learn two</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from it.</b> One can learn from this verse both that a woman can be acquired through intercourse, and that an ordinary woman can be betrothed through intercourse but a Hebrew maidservant cannot be acquired through intercourse.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, who said: Bar Ahina explained this to me</b> by citing a proof from the following verse: <b>“When a man takes a woman and engages in sexual intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), which teaches that <b>betrothal that is given to consummation,</b> i.e., betrothal when it is permitted for the man and woman to engage in intercourse, <b>is a betrothal,</b> but <b>betrothal that is not given to consummation is not</b> a valid <b>betrothal, what is there to say?</b> Since he uses this verse for a different purpose, from where does Rava derive that a woman can be betrothed through intercourse and that a Hebrew maidservant cannot be acquired in this manner?
The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that a woman cannot be betrothed through intercourse, <b>let the verse write:</b> When a man takes a woman <b>or engages in intercourse with her. What is</b> indicated by the phrase: <b>“And engages in sexual intercourse with her”?</b> One can <b>learn from</b> the verse <b>all</b> these <i>halakhot</i>, that intercourse is a valid mode of betrothing a woman but not acquiring a maidservant, and betrothal is effective only when it is given to consummation.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>what does he do with this</b> verse: “If a man be found lying with <b>a married woman [<i>beulat ba’al</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:22), from which Rabbi Yoḥanan derives that intercourse is a valid means of betrothal? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>requires this</b> verse for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>the husband renders her a non-virgin</b> even if he engages <b>in intercourse</b> with her <b>in an atypical manner, but no other</b> man <b>renders her a non-virgin</b> by engaging <b>in intercourse</b> with her <b>in an atypical manner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>accept this opinion? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>ten men engaged in intercourse with</b> a betrothed young woman, <b>and she is still a virgin, they are all</b> punished <b>by stoning. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say</b> that <b>the first</b> one is punished <b>by stoning, but</b> the others are <b>all</b> punished <b>by strangulation.</b> This proves that in the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, even one who is not her husband can render a woman a non-virgin by engaging in anal intercourse with her.

Daf 10a

<b>Rabbi Zeira said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>concedes with regard to</b> the <b>fine</b> of a rapist and a seducer <b>that they all pay</b> this fine, and they are not exempt merely because their acts of intercourse were with a non-virgin. The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> the <b>death</b> penalty? With respect to the death penalty they are punished as though they engaged in intercourse with a betrothed non-virgin, and yet concerning the fine, they pay as though they engaged in intercourse with a virgin. The Gemara answers: It <b>is different there,</b> with regard to capital punishment, <b>as the verse states: “Then the man only who lay with her shall die”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:25), which indicates that only one man is executed for having sexual intercourse with a virgin, and no more.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis, what do they do with this</b> term <b>“only”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They require it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. The verse states: <b>“Then they shall both of them die”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:22). This indicates that this is not the case <b>unless</b> the two of them <b>are equal,</b> i.e., both deserve punishment. But if one of them cannot be punished, e.g., if he is a minor, the other is not executed either. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Oshaya. Rabbi Yonatan says</b> that the verse: <b>“Then the man only who lay with her shall die,”</b> indicates that in some cases only one of them is liable to receive the death penalty.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan, from where does he</b> derive <b>this conclusion</b> that only a woman’s husband can render her a non-virgin through intercourse in an atypical manner, if he uses this verse to derive the mode of betrothal by means of sexual intercourse? The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that this verse is teaching only one <i>halakha</i>, <b>let the verse write:</b> If a man be found lying with <b>a <i>beulat ish</i>,</b> literally, a woman who engaged in sexual intercourse with a man. <b>What</b> is indicated by the term <b>“<i>beulat ba’al</i>,”</b> literally, who engaged in sexual intercourse with a husband? <b>Learn two</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from it:</b> First, that one can betroth a woman through intercourse, and second, that only a woman’s husband can render her a non-virgin by intercourse in an atypical manner.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Since intercourse is not a momentary act but has different stages, does <b>the beginning of intercourse effect acquisition or</b> does <b>the end of intercourse effect acquisition?</b> When exactly is the moment of betrothal? The Gemara comments: The <b>practical difference</b> resulting from this question is in a case <b>where</b> one <b>engaged in</b> only <b>the initial stage of intercourse with her and</b> in the meantime <b>she reached her hand out and accepted betrothal from another</b> man. If the beginning of sexual intercourse effects acquisition, the other man’s betrothal is meaningless. If the end of sexual intercourse effects acquisition, she is betrothed to the other man.
<b>Alternatively,</b> there is a difference with regard <b>to a High Priest who acquires a virgin through sexual intercourse.</b> If only the end of intercourse effects acquisition, she is no longer a virgin at the time of the betrothal, which would mean that a High Priest cannot acquire a woman through intercourse, as it is prohibited for him to marry a non-virgin (Leviticus 21:14). <b>What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Ameimar said in the name of Rava: Anyone who engages in sexual intercourse has the completion of</b> the act of <b>intercourse in mind,</b> not the beginning. Therefore, the acquisition is complete only when the act has been completed.
Additionally, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does the <b>sexual intercourse</b> that is performed to effect betrothal <b>effect marriage</b> at the same time that it effects betrothal, <b>or</b> does it <b>effect</b> only <b>betrothal? The practical difference</b> that arises from this question concerns all cases where it matters whether a woman is betrothed or married. For example, one issue is whether the act allows him <b>to inherit</b> property from <b>her.</b> If he betroths her through intercourse, does he inherit her property when she dies as he would if they were married?
<b>And</b> if he is a priest, is he required <b>to become ritually impure to</b> bury <b>her,</b> as he must do for his wife? <b>And</b> similarly, does a betrothal through intercourse allow him <b>to nullify her vows</b> by himself, without her father’s participation? <b>If you say</b> that intercourse <b>effects marriage, he inherits</b> property from <b>her, and he becomes impure to</b> bury <b>her, and he nullifies her vows</b> alone. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>it effects</b> only <b>betrothal, he does not inherit</b> property from <b>her, and he does not become ritually impure to</b> bury <b>her, and he cannot nullify her vows</b> alone. <b>What,</b> then, is the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from the following mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 46b): <b>A father has authority</b> over <b>his daughter with regard to her betrothal,</b> whether it is <b>through money, through a document, or through sexual intercourse.</b> Likewise, a father <b>has a right to items she</b> has <b>found, and to her earnings, and to</b> effect <b>the nullification of her vows,</b> i.e., a father may nullify his daughter’s vows. <b>And he accepts her bill of divorce</b> on her behalf if she is divorced from betrothal before she becomes a grown woman. <b>And</b> although he inherits her property when she dies, e.g., property she inherited from her mother’s family, <b>he does not enjoy the profits</b> of her property <b>during her lifetime.</b> If the daughter <b>married, the husband has more</b> rights and obligations <b>than</b> her father had before the marriage, <b>as he enjoys the profits</b> of her property <b>during her lifetime.</b>
The mishna <b>teaches</b> that a man has rights to his daughter’s betrothal through <b>sexual intercourse, and</b> it subsequently <b>teaches:</b> If the daughter <b>married.</b> This indicates that intercourse effects only betrothal. The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>When it teaches:</b> If the daughter <b>married,</b> that is referring <b>to the other</b> modes mentioned here, i.e., betrothal by means of money or a document. In these cases there is a difference between betrothal and marriage, while it is possible that betrothal through intercourse effects marriage as well.
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a <i>baraita</i>: A girl who is <b>three years and one day old can be betrothed through intercourse, and if</b> her <b><i>yavam</i> engaged in intercourse with her, he has acquired her. And</b> if she is married, <b>one is liable</b> if he engages in intercourse <b>with her, due to</b> her status as <b>a married woman. And</b> if she is impure as a menstruating woman, <b>she renders one who engages in intercourse with her ritually impure</b> for seven days.

Daf 10b

And he <b>renders impure the object upon which he lies like the upper one.</b> One who engages in sexual intercourse with a menstruating woman renders the objects upon which he lies ritually impure even if he has no direct contact with them.
<b>And if she marries a priest she may partake of <i>teruma</i></b> from that point onward. <b>And if one of those with whom sexual relations are forbidden by the Torah</b> (see Leviticus, chapter 18) <b>engages in intercourse with her, he is put to death due to</b> his sin with <b>her, and she is exempt</b> from punishment as a minor. <b>And if someone of unfit</b> lineage, i.e., a man who would disqualify her from marrying a priest if he engaged in sexual intercourse with her, <b>engages in intercourse with her, he has disqualified her from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara analyzes this source. <b>It is taught</b> in that <i>baraita</i>: She can be betrothed through <b>sexual intercourse, and it is taught</b> separately: And if <b>she marries</b> a priest. This indicates that intercourse does not effect marriage.
