The Gemara rejects this: <b>This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>said: If this</b> betrothal through intercourse <b>is a marriage to a priest, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> It is possible that there are not two separate stages here but a single action, as sexual intercourse effects marriage.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And Yoḥanan ben Bag Bag already sent</b> a message <b>to Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira in</b> the city of <b>Netzivin: I heard about you that you say</b> that <b>the daughter of a non-priest betrothed</b> to a priest <b>may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira <b>sent</b> back this reply <b>to him: And do you not say so? I know about you that you are an expert in</b> many <b>areas of Torah; do you not know how to teach</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>based on an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference?
The <i>a fortiori</i> inference is as follows: <b>If</b> in the case of <b>a Canaanite maidservant, whose sexual intercourse</b> with a priest <b>does not allow her to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as she is not betrothed to him, <b>her money,</b> i.e., if a priest acquires her through money, <b>allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, is it not logical</b> with regard to <b>this</b> betrothed woman, <b>whose sexual intercourse</b> with a priest <b>allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> that <b>her</b> betrothal <b>money</b> from the priest should <b>allow her to partake of <i>teruma</i>?</b> If this is indeed the case, the daughter of a non-priest betrothed to a priest should be permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But what can I do, as the Sages said:</b> By rabbinic law, <b>the daughter of a non-priest betrothed</b> to a priest <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i> until she enters the</b> wedding <b>canopy.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the comparison between money and sexual intercourse? <b>If</b> it is referring to a case <b>of sexual intercourse by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy,</b> i.e., after they are married, <b>and</b> betrothal through <b>money</b> where the marriage is then completed <b>by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy, in both</b> cases <b>she may partake of</b> <i>teruma</i> even by rabbinic law, as she is a full-fledged married woman.
<b>Or rather</b> one could say that this comparison is referring to <b>sexual intercourse by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy, and</b> betrothal through <b>money not by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy.</b> If so, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not valid, as <b>here,</b> in the case of intercourse, there are <b>two</b> stages of acquisition, intercourse followed by the wedding canopy, <b>and here,</b> in the case of money, there is only <b>one</b> stage. <b>Rather, is it not</b> correct to say that the comparison between money and intercourse is referring <b>to sexual intercourse not by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy and</b> also <b>money not by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy?</b>
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that intercourse by itself <b>effects marriage,</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that it <b>is obvious to</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira <b>that</b> the mode of <b>sexual intercourse is stronger than money,</b> and allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But if you say</b> that sexual intercourse <b>effects</b> only <b>betrothal, what is different here,</b> in the case of betrothal through intercourse, <b>that it is obvious to him</b> that it allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and what is different here,</b> in the case of betrothal through money, <b>that he is uncertain</b> and must derive the matter through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference? In both cases she is only betrothed.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Actually, I will say to you</b> that he is speaking <b>about sexual intercourse by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy and money not by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy. And</b> as for <b>that which you said</b> in opposition to this <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>Here</b> there are <b>two</b> stages of acquisition, <b>and here</b> there is only <b>one</b> stage. <b>In any event, there is</b> a valid <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
<b>And this is what</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira <b>sent him,</b> i.e., his statement should be understood as follows: <b>If a Canaanite maidservant, whose intercourse</b> with a priest <b>does not allow her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, even by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy,</b> and yet <b>her money allows her to partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>without</b> the means of a wedding <b>canopy, is it not logical</b> with regard to <b>this</b> betrothed woman, <b>whose intercourse</b> with a priest <b>allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i> by means of</b> a wedding <b>canopy,</b> that <b>her</b> betrothal <b>money</b> from the priest should <b>allow her to partake of <i>teruma</i> without</b> the means of a wedding <b>canopy?</b>
<b>But what can I do, as the Sages said:</b> By rabbinic law, <b>the daughter of a non-priest betrothed</b> to a priest <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i> until she enters the</b> wedding <b>canopy, due to</b> the reason stated <b>by Ulla.</b> According to Ulla, there is a concern that she may feed her siblings or members of her family <i>teruma</i> while she is still living in her father’s house.
<b>And ben Bag Bag</b> explains why one cannot accept this <i>a fortiori</i> inference involving a Canaanite maidservant: <b>With regard to a Canaanite maidservant</b> who is purchased with money, the buyer <b>does not leave out</b> anything <b>from her acquisition,</b> i.e., he completes the purchase in full. <b>Here,</b> in the case of betrothal, <b>he leaves out</b> part <b>of her acquisition,</b> as the stage of marriage has yet to be performed. Therefore, these two cases are dissimilar.
<b>Ravina said</b> that <b>by Torah law, it is obvious to</b> Yoḥanan ben Bag Bag <b>that</b> she <b>may partake of</b> <i>teruma</i> also when she is betrothed to a priest through money alone, as she is acquired with his money. <b>And</b> the question <b>that he sent him</b> is referring to the <i>halakha</i> <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
Ravina elaborates: <b>And this is</b> the question <b>that he sent to him: I heard about you that you say</b> that in practice <b>the daughter of a non-priest betrothed</b> to a priest <b>may partake of <i>teruma</i>, and we are not concerned about an annulling factor [<i>simfon</i>],</b> i.e., that he might find some blemish in her through which the betrothal would be considered retroactively invalid. If so, she would have eaten <i>teruma</i> when she was not permitted to do so. And it was with regard to this issue that Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira <b>sent to him: And do you not say this? I know about you that you are an expert in</b> many <b>areas of Torah; do you not know how to teach</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>based on an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference?
The <i>a fortiori</i> inference is as follows: <b>If a Canaanite maidservant, whose</b> engaging in <b>intercourse</b> with a priest <b>does not allow her to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> and yet <b>her</b> receiving purchase <b>money allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, and we are not concerned about <i>simfon</i>,</b> i.e., that the Canaanite maidservant may have some physical blemish that nullifies her purchase retroactively, <b>is it not logical</b> with regard to <b>this</b> betrothed woman, <b>whose intercourse</b> with a priest <b>allows her to partake of <i>teruma</i>, that her</b> receiving betrothal <b>money</b> from the priest should <b>allow her to partake of <i>teruma</i></b> even before entering the wedding canopy, <b>and we should not be concerned about <i>simfon</i>? But what can I do, as the Sages said:</b> By rabbinic law <b>the daughter of a non-priest betrothed</b> to a priest <b>may not partake of <i>teruma</i></b>

Daf 11a

<b>until she enters the</b> wedding <b>canopy, due to</b> the reason <b>of Ulla,</b> lest she feed her non-priestly family members the <i>teruma</i> that her husband has given her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And ben Bag Bag,</b> what does he say about this <i>a fortiori</i> inference? The Gemara answers that he maintains that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference is invalid because <b>he does not accept</b> that there can be a claim of <b><i>simfon</i> with regard to</b> the acquisition <b>of slaves.</b> The reason is that <b>if it is an exposed blemish</b> that the master found on the slave, <b>he saw</b> the blemish and purchased him regardless. Therefore, he cannot later claim that the transaction was unfair. <b>If</b> it is <b>due to hidden blemishes</b> on his slave, <b>what difference does that make to him?</b> Why should it matter if a slave has hidden blemishes? <b>He needs him</b> only <b>for labor,</b> and <b>he does not care</b> if he has hidden blemishes that do not impair his ability to perform labor.
And even if this slave <b>is discovered</b> to be <b>a thief or a gambler [<i>kuvyustus</i>],</b> which are considered hidden blemishes that affect his work, <b>it has come to him,</b> i.e., the slave is acquired by the one who purchased him and the transaction is non-refundable. The reason is that the buyer should have suspected behavior of this kind, which is common among slaves, and therefore he suffers the loss. <b>What do you say?</b> Perhaps he discovered that the slave is <b>an armed bandit</b> and subject to be killed by the government for this, <b>or sentenced</b> to death <b>by the government</b> for another reason, and is sought by the authorities. This is not a valid claim, since <b>these</b> matters <b>generate publicity,</b> and therefore he is assumed to have taken the risk into consideration.
The Gemara asks: <b>Now, both according to</b> the one <b>Master,</b> Yoḥanan ben Bag Bag, <b>and according to</b> the other <b>Master,</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, the daughter of a non-priest betrothed to a priest <b>may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> by rabbinic decree. <b>What,</b> then, <b>is</b> the difference <b>between them?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> difference <b>between them</b> involves three cases. The Gemara elaborates: If the husband initially <b>accepted</b> her blemishes, there is no concern that an annulling factor might lead to the nullification of the betrothal, but there is still concern that she might feed <i>teruma</i> to the members of her family. If her father <b>transferred</b> her to the betrothed husband’s agents, <b>or</b> if the father’s agents <b>walked</b> with the husband’s messenger, and therefore she is no longer in her father’s house, there is no concern that she might feed her family members <i>teruma</i>, but it remains possible that the betrothal will be nullified.
§ The Gemara returns to the <i>halakhot</i> of the mishna. The mishna teaches that if one betroths a woman <b>with money, Beit Shammai say</b> he must betroth her <b>with</b> at least <b>one dinar,</b> whereas according to the opinion of Beit Hillel even one <i>peruta</i> is sufficient. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Beit Shammai? Rabbi Zeira says:</b> Their reasoning is <b>that a woman is particular about herself</b> and considers it beneath her dignity to be acquired with a paltry sum, <b>and</b> therefore she <b>will not</b> agree to <b>be betrothed with less than one dinar.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: If that is so, with regard to Rabbi Yannai’s daughters, for example, who are</b> very <b>particular about themselves</b> and their honor, <b>and they will not</b> agree to <b>be betrothed with less than three <i>kav</i> of dinars</b> due to their status, <b>so too</b> will you say <b>that if she reaches out her hand and accepts one dinar from another</b> man, <b>so too,</b> this <b>is not a betrothal?</b>
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>I did not say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> includes a case where <b>she reached out her hand and accepted</b> a betrothal. She has the right to willingly relinquish her dignity. <b>When I said</b> this <i>halakha</i> I was referring to a case <b>where he betrothed her at night</b> and she did not see what she was being given. <b>Alternatively, where she appointed an agent</b> to betroth her but did not explicitly tell him how much she wished to receive for her betrothal. In these cases it is assumed that she is particular about her honor and will not agree to be betrothed for less than one dinar.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> a different explanation: <b>The reasoning of Beit Shammai is in accordance with</b> that <b>which Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Rav Asi says. As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says: Every</b> sum of <b>money mentioned in the Torah is</b> in <b>Tyrian coinage,</b> i.e., dinars from Tyre, which have a high value. <b>And</b> any amount of money set <b>by rabbinic law</b> is measured by <b>provincial coinage.</b> Local currency, i.e., that which existed at the time of the Sages of the Mishna, was worth about one-eighth of the value of Tyrian coinage. Beit Shammai follow the standard sum of the Torah, and the smallest possible amount in Tyrian currency is the silver coin, which is worth one dinar.
The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says: Every</b> sum of <b>money mentioned in the Torah is Tyrian coinage, and</b> any amount of money set <b>by rabbinic law</b> is measured by <b>provincial coinage.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> it an established <b>principle</b> that any mention of money in the Torah is referring to a silver coin worth at least one dinar?

Daf 11b

<b>But</b> with regard to <b>a claim that</b> someone has not returned a deposit or loan, when the defendant admits that only part of the claim is true, <b>it is written: “If a man deliver to his neighbor money or vessels to guard</b> and it be stolen out of the man’s house” (Exodus 22:6). The following verses teach that if the thief is not found, the case is brought to a court, where the defendant must take an oath. <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna with regard to one who admits to part of a claim (<i>Shevuot</i> 38b): <b>The oath</b> administered <b>by the judges</b> to one who admits to part of a claim is administered only when <b>the claim</b> is for at least <b>two silver</b> <i>ma’a</i>, <b>and the</b> defendant’s <b>admission</b> is to at least <b>the value of one <i>peruta</i>.</b> If every sum of money mentioned in the Torah is referring to Tyrian coinage, how did the Sages arrive at the amount of two <i>ma’a</i> in this case?
The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is derived from a juxtaposition, as the “money” mentioned in the verse is <b>similar to “vessels”: Just as</b> the word <b>“vessels”</b> indicates at least <b>two, so too “money”</b> is referring to at least <b>two</b> coins. <b>And just as money is a significant item, so too</b> the <b>vessels</b> must be <b>a significant item.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> there is the case of the redemption of second <b>tithe, as it is written: “And bind up the money in your hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:25). <b>And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 2:8): With regard to <b>one who exchanges</b> copper coins <b>of second-tithe money</b> for <b>a <i>sela</i>,</b> Beit Shammai say: He may exchange the copper coins for the entire silver <i>sela</i>. This mishna indicates that second-tithe money, mentioned in the Torah, can be in the form of copper coins, and it is not required to be in the form of silver coins. The Gemara explains that the verse does not say <b>money,</b> but <b>“the money.”</b> The addition of the article <b>serves as an amplification.</b> In other words, this addition teaches that second-tithe money can be in any coinage, including copper coins.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> there is the case of <b>consecrated</b> property, <b>as it is written: “And he will give the money and it will be assured to him”</b> (see Leviticus 27:19). <b>And Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>consecrated</b> property <b>worth one hundred dinars, which was redeemed for</b> an item <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>, it is redeemed.</b> Although the word “money” is stated in the Torah, a copper <i>peruta</i> may be used. The Gemara answers: <b>There too,</b> there is a reason for this unusual <i>halakha</i>, as <b>he derives</b> this ruling from a verbal analogy of the terms <b>“money”</b> mentioned here and <b>“money” from tithes.</b> Consequently, one may use any type of coin in this case as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> there is the case of <b>the betrothal of a woman, as it is written: “When a man takes a woman and engages in sexual intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>and one derives</b> betrothal through money by a verbal analogy of the term <b>“taking”</b> used here and <b>“taking” from</b> the case of <b>the field of Ephron. And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Beit Hillel say</b> one can betroth a woman <b>with one <i>peruta</i> or with</b> any item that is <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b> If so, <b>shall we say</b> that <b>Rav Asi,</b> who claims that all sums of money mentioned in the Torah are in Tyrian coinage, <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests an alternative explanation: <b>If</b> this <b>was stated,</b> it <b>was stated like this: Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says: Every set</b> amount of <b>money stated in the Torah,</b> i.e., when a specific amount is mentioned, is referring to <b>Tyrian coinage, and</b> any amount of money set <b>by rabbinic law</b> is in <b>provincial coinage.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>what is</b> Rav Asi <b>teaching us?</b> We have already <b>learned</b> all of these <i>halakhot</i> explicitly (<i>Bekhorot</i> 49b): The payment of <b>five <i>sela</i> for</b> the redemption of a firstborn <b>son</b> (Numbers 18:16);the payment of <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i> <b>for a slave,</b> paid by the owner of the ox that killed the slave (Exodus 21:32); the <b>fifty</b> <i>sela</i> paid <b>by a rapist and by a seducer</b> (Deuteronomy 22:29); the <b>one hundred</b> <i>sela</i> paid <b>by a defamer</b> (Deuteronomy 22:19); <b>all of these are</b> paid <b>in the sacred shekel,</b> which is <b>one hundred dinars in Tyrian</b> coinage. All of the cases in which a defined amount is mentioned by the Torah have already been taught, and it is unclear what Rav Asi adds.
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary for</b> Rav Asi to teach: <b>And</b> any amount of money set <b>by rabbinic law</b> is in <b>provincial coinage, as we did not learn</b> that <i>halakha</i> in that mishna. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Sages established that <b>one who strikes another</b> as an act of disrespect <b>must give him one <i>sela</i></b> as a fine. <b>And</b> Rav Asi is teaching that one should <b>not say: What</b> is the meaning of <b>one <i>sela</i>?</b> It is a Tyrian <i>sela</i> worth <b>four dinar. Rather, what</b> is the meaning of <b>one <i>sela</i>?</b> This is the <i>sela</i> of provincial coinage, which is worth <b>half a dinar, as people commonly call half a dinar</b> by the name <b><i>sela</i> [<i>isteira</i>].</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> a different explanation: <b>The reasoning of Beit Shammai,</b> that the minimum amount with which a woman can be betrothed is one dinar, is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Ḥizkiyya. As Ḥizkiyya says</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to a Hebrew maidservant: <b>“Then he shall let her be redeemed”</b> (Exodus 21:8), which <b>teaches that she can deduct</b> an amount <b>from</b> the price of <b>her redemption and leave</b> before her time of slavery is complete. If she comes into possession of money, she can pay the master for her value, less the work she has performed. Beit Shammai derive the <i>halakhot</i> of regular betrothal from the case of a Hebrew maidservant, as explained below.
<b>Granted, if you say that</b> when she was acquired <b>he gave her</b> at least <b>one dinar, this is</b> the meaning of the statement <b>that she may continually deduct</b> from that amount <b>up to one <i>peruta</i>. But if you say that</b> he <b>gave her one <i>peruta</i></b> when he purchased her as a maidservant, can <b>she deduct from one <i>peruta</i>?</b> One <i>peruta</i> is already the smallest possible sum of money. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>But perhaps this is what the Merciful One is saying:</b> In a case <b>where he gave her one dinar, she deducts</b> from that amount <b>up to one <i>peruta</i>;</b> in <b>a case where he gave her one <i>peruta</i> she cannot deduct at all.</b> If he paid one <i>peruta</i> for her, the option of redemption does not apply.

Daf 12a

The Gemara rejects this suggestion: This <b>cannot enter your mind,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> of deduction must be <b>similar</b> to the <i>halakha</i> of <b>designation,</b> i.e., the process by which a master designates his Hebrew maidservant as a wife for him or his son (Exodus 21:8–9). <b>Just as</b> with <b>designation, although</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>if he desires, he may designate</b> her <b>and if he does not desire, he</b> is <b>not</b> required to <b>designate</b> her, nevertheless <b>anywhere that he cannot designate</b> her, e.g., in a case where they are related and she is therefore forbidden to him, <b>her sale is not</b> a valid <b>sale, so too</b> here, with regard to her redemption, <b>anywhere that she cannot deduct</b> an amount from her purchase price, <b>her sale is not</b> a valid <b>sale.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai</b> the mode of <b>betrothal of a woman</b> by money <b>is derived from</b> the case of <b>a Hebrew maidservant,</b> as follows: <b>Just as a Hebrew maidservant cannot be acquired with one <i>peruta</i>, so too a woman cannot be betrothed with one <i>peruta</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: Even if Beit Shammai derive their opinion from here, how does this prove that a woman can be betrothed only with a minimum of one dinar? <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> she can be betrothed with <b>half a dinar, or say</b> that she can be betrothed with <b>two <i>perutot</i>,</b> as it is possible to fulfill the redemption of a Hebrew maidservant if her sale was for either of these amounts? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> this comparison <b>excludes</b> betrothal <b>with one <i>peruta</i>,</b> as it indicates that a woman can be betrothed only with money of significant value, the Sages <b>established</b> the minimum amount <b>at one dinar,</b> which is a coin of substantial value.
<b>Rava said</b> a different explanation: <b>This is the reasoning of Beit Shammai,</b> who hold that a woman can be betrothed only with a minimum of one dinar: <b>The daughters of Israel should not be</b> treated <b>like ownerless</b> property. Allowing women to be betrothed with such a small amount as one <i>peruta</i> is disrespectful to them.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And Beit Hillel say</b> that a woman can be betrothed <b>with one <i>peruta</i>,</b> or with any item that is worth one <i>peruta</i>. <b>Rav Yosef thought to say: One <i>peruta</i></b> means <b>any amount.</b> There is no defined value, as a woman may be betrothed with one <i>peruta</i> regardless of its value at the time. <b>Abaye said to him: But isn’t it taught with regard to</b> this in the mishna itself: <b>How much is one <i>peruta</i>?</b> It is <b>one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>.</b> This shows there is a defined value for one <i>peruta</i>.
<b>And if you would say: This statement</b> applies <b>only to the generation of Moses,</b> i.e., this was the value of one <i>peruta</i> in the time of the Torah, <b>but now,</b> at any later time, its value is determined by <b>that which people consider</b> one <i>peruta</i>, that claim cannot be correct. <b>As when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said: Rabbi Simai estimated in his generation: How much is one <i>peruta</i>?</b> It is <b>one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>. And when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Dostai and Rabbi Yannai and Rabbi Oshaya estimated: How much is one <i>peruta</i>?</b> It is <b>one-sixth of the Italian <i>issar</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Abaye: <b>If so,</b> then <b>this is</b> in conflict with that <b>which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Go and calculate how many <i>perutot</i> there are in two <i>sela</i>: More than two thousand. Now there are not</b> even <b>two thousand, and you call them: More than two thousand?</b> Rather, the <i>peruta</i> is certainly worth less than one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>. <b>A certain old man said to them: I teach this</b> <i>baraita</i> as saying: <b>Close to two thousand.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately,</b> according to the calculation of one-eighth of an <i>issar</i>, the number of <i>perutot</i> in two <i>sela</i> <b>is 1,536,</b> which is nowhere near two thousand. The Gemara answers: <b>Since it passes half</b> of the second thousand <b>it is called: Close to two thousand.</b>
The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said: Rabbi Simai estimated in his generation: How much is one <i>peruta</i>?</b> It is <b>one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>. And when Ravin came he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Dostai and Rabbi Yannai and Rabbi Oshaya estimated: How much is one <i>peruta</i>?</b> It is <b>one-sixth of the Italian <i>issar</i>. Abaye said to Rav Dimi: Shall we say</b> that <b>you and Ravin disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between these <i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b><i>peruta</i> mentioned by the Sages</b> is <b>one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>. Six silver <i>ma’a</i></b> are one <b>dinar,</b> and one <b><i>ma’a</i></b> is worth <b>two <i>pundeyon</i>.</b> In <b>a <i>pundeyon</i></b> there are <b>two <i>issar</i>,</b> and <b>an <i>issar</i></b> is <b>two <i>masmas</i>. A <i>masmas</i></b> is worth <b>two <i>konterank</i>,</b> and a <b><i>konterank</i></b> is <b>two <i>perutot</i>.</b> By this calculation, one <b>finds</b> that <b>one <i>peruta</i></b> is <b>one-eighth of the Italian <i>issar</i>.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> This is not the case; rather, there are <b>three <i>hadreis</i> to a <i>ma’a</i>, two <i>henetz</i> to a <i>hadreis</i>, two <i>shamin</i> to a <i>henetz</i>,</b> and <b>two <i>perutot</i> to a <i>shamin</i>.</b> Consequently, one <b>finds</b> that one <b><i>peruta</i></b> is <b>one-sixth of the Italian <i>issar</i>. Shall we say that</b> one <b>Master agrees with the first <i>tanna</i>, and Ravin, who said</b> his ruling in the name of Rabbi Dostai and Rabbi Yannai and Rabbi Oshaya, <b>agrees with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel?</b>
Rav Dimi <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Both my</b> statement <b>and</b> that of <b>Ravin</b> are <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>, and it</b> is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement of mine is referring to <b>when</b> the <b><i>issar</i> increased in value</b> in relation to silver coins, and <b>this</b> statement of Ravin is referring to <b>when</b> the <b><i>issar</i> decreased in value.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>When</b> the <b><i>issar</i> increased in value, twenty-four</b> <i>issar</i> <b>stood at one dinar; when</b> they <b>decreased in value, thirty-two</b> <i>issar</i> <b>stood at one dinar.</b> If so, there is a set ratio between the value of a <i>peruta</i> and the value of silver, and there are 192 <i>perutot</i> in one dinar. By contrast, the ratio between the value of a copper <i>issar</i> and silver dinars fluctuates, so that sometimes an <i>issar</i> will be worth eight <i>perutot</i> while at other times it is worth only six.
§ <b>Shmuel says:</b> If man <b>betrothed</b> a woman <b>with a date, she is betrothed even</b> if <b>a <i>kor</i> of dates is worth one dinar,</b> which would mean that one date is worth much less than one <i>peruta</i>. The reason is that although a date has little value here, <b>we are concerned that perhaps it is worth one <i>peruta</i> in Media</b> or in some other distant place where dates are expensive. Therefore, she is betrothed in this location as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the <b>mishna</b> that <b>Beit Hillel say: With one <i>peruta</i> or with</b> an item <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>,</b> but not less? The Gemara explains: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement in the mishna is referring <b>to betrothal</b> whose status is <b>certain.</b> Betrothal with one <i>peruta</i> or an item worth one <i>peruta</i> is certainly valid. Conversely, <b>this</b> case stated by Shmuel is referring <b>to betrothal</b> whose status is <b>uncertain.</b> Although the item is not worth one <i>peruta</i> here, there is a concern that the betrothal might nevertheless be valid.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with a bundle of rags [<i>zavda de’urdei</i>]. Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya sat before Rav and examined</b> the bundle to see <b>if it had the value of one <i>peruta</i>.</b> If it was worth one <i>peruta</i>, <b>yes,</b> she was betrothed, <b>and if not, no,</b> she was not betrothed. The Gemara asks: <b>And if it does not have the value of one <i>peruta</i>,</b> is she <b>not</b> betrothed? <b>But didn’t Shmuel say</b> that <b>we are concerned</b> that the item might be worth one <i>peruta</i> in Media? The Gemara explains: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> ruling of Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya is referring <b>to betrothal</b> whose status is <b>certain,</b> whereas <b>this</b> statement of Shmuel is referring <b>to betrothal</b> whose status is <b>uncertain.</b>
The Gemara further relates: There was <b>a certain man who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with a blue marble stone. Rav Ḥisda sat and estimated</b> whether <b>it</b> was worth one <i>peruta</i>. <b>If it was worth one <i>peruta</i>, yes,</b> she was betrothed, <b>and if not, no,</b> she was not betrothed. The Gemara asks: <b>And if it does not have the value of one <i>peruta</i>,</b> is she <b>not</b> betrothed? <b>But didn’t Shmuel say</b> that <b>we are concerned</b> that the item might be worth one <i>peruta</i> in Media? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Ḥisda does not hold</b> in accordance with <b>that</b> opinion <b>of Shmuel,</b> as he holds that if the item is not worth one <i>peruta</i> in the place where the betrothal occurred, the betrothal is invalid.
<b>The mother of</b> the man who offered the betrothal <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>But on that day that he betrothed her it was worth one <i>peruta</i>. He said to</b> the mother: <b>It is not in your</b> power <b>to render her forbidden to a later</b> man. If another comes and betroths her, his betrothal is not dismissed due to this earlier act. Since the marble stone is not worth one <i>peruta</i> now, the betrothal of the second man may be valid.

Daf 12b

Rav Ḥisda explained: <b>Is this not</b> similar to the case of <b>Yehudit, wife of Rabbi Ḥiyya, who would have painful childbirths</b> and therefore wished to leave Rabbi Ḥiyya? <b>She said to</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya: <b>My mother told me: When you were young your father accepted betrothal on your behalf</b> from another man, which would render Yehudit forbidden to Rabbi Ḥiyya. <b>He said to her: It is not in your mother’s</b> power <b>to render you forbidden to me,</b> as this testimony is insufficient.
Returning to the incident with the blue marble stone, the Gemara relates that <b>the Sages said to Rav Ḥisda: Why</b> do you say that she is not betrothed because the item is not worth one <i>peruta</i> in the place where the betrothal occurred? After all, <b>there are witnesses in Idit who know that on that day it had the value of one <i>peruta</i>.</b> Rav Ḥisda said to them: <b>Now, in any event, they are not here,</b> and therefore their potential testimony is disregarded.
Rav Ḥisda cites a proof for his statement: <b>Isn’t this</b> the same as the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina?</b> In the case of a woman who appeared before the court and said that she was taken captive but remained undefiled, if there are no witnesses that she was captured, her entire claim must be accepted, and therefore she is permitted to her husband. Although there are witnesses elsewhere who can testify that she was taken captive, and consequently, the court need not rely on her statement alone, <b>as Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> When <b>her witnesses</b> are far away <b>in the north [<i>istan</i>], will she be forbidden?</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Abaye and Rava do not hold</b> in accordance <b>with this</b> statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> with regard to betrothal. In their opinion one cannot learn the <i>halakha</i> here from Rabbi Ḥanina’s statement, as there is a difference between the cases: <b>If</b> in the case of Rabbi Ḥanina the Sages <b>were lenient with regard to a captive woman, who makes herself appear repulsive before her captor</b> so that he will not rape her, and it is therefore believable that she was not violated, <b>shall we be lenient with regard to</b> the serious prohibition of <b>a married woman?</b>
The Gemara reports: Descendants <b>of the family</b> of the woman who had been betrothed with a blue marble stone <b>remained in Sura,</b> as after Rav Ḥisda ruled that that woman’s first betrothal was invalid, she married another man and had children. <b>But the Sages avoided</b> the family and refused to marry into it due to the concern that it was founded on a possibly adulterous relationship, which would render the descendants of the family <i>mamzerim</i>. The Gemara comments: <b>And it was not because they maintained,</b> in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> that there is a concern that any item might be worth one <i>peruta</i> somewhere else. <b>Rather,</b> it was <b>because they held</b> in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye and Rava,</b> who said: Since there are witnesses in a different place, one must take them into account.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with a myrtle branch in the marketplace. Rav Aḥa bar Huna sent</b> this dilemma <b>before Rav Yosef: In a case like this, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yosef <b>sent</b> a response <b>to him: Flog him, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, and require</b> her to receive <b>a bill of divorce, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> in case the myrtle branch is worth one <i>peruta</i> somewhere else.
The Gemara explains <b>that Rav</b> would <b>flog</b> a man <b>for betrothing</b> a woman <b>in the marketplace,</b> because this is disrespectful and crude, <b>and for betrothing</b> a woman <b>through sexual intercourse,</b> as it is unsavory to invite witnesses to observe a man and woman enter a room to engage in intercourse. <b>And</b> he would also flog a man <b>for betrothing</b> a woman <b>without an arrangement [<i>shiddukhei</i>],</b> i.e., if he did not discuss betrothal with the woman before betrothing her. Each of these acts is considered indecent behavior.
<b>And</b> likewise, Rav would flog a man <b>for nullifying a bill of divorce</b> he has already sent to his wife, <b>and for issuing a declaration</b> preemptively invalidating <b>a bill of divorce.</b> The latter case is referring to one who announces before giving a bill of divorce that he is divorcing his wife against his will, thereby rendering the document ineffective. This behavior might lead to a grave sin if the wife marries another man under the mistaken impression that she is divorced. <b>And</b> similarly, Rav would flog anyone <b>for tormenting a messenger of the Sages,</b> as this indicates a lack of regard for the Sages. <b>And</b> Rav would flog <b>one who had an excommunication take effect on him for thirty days</b> and yet does not repent or appeal to the Sages to annul his censure.
<b>And</b> Rav would flog <b>a son-in-law who lives in his father-in-law’s house,</b> as there is a concern that he might sin with his mother-in-law. The Gemara comments: This indicates that with regard to one <b>who lives</b> in his father-in-law’s house permanently, <b>yes,</b> he is flogged, whereas with regard to one who only <b>passes by</b> his father-in-law’s house, <b>no,</b> he is not flogged. <b>But</b> there was <b>a certain son-in-law who passed by the entrance of his father-in-law’s house and Rav Sheshet flogged him</b> due to licentiousness. The Gemara explains: In <b>that</b> case, <b>there were suspicions [<i>dayma</i>] about him and his mother-in-law,</b> i.e., about rumors of intimacy between them. In walking by the house he contributed to these rumors, which is why he was flogged.
The Sages <b>of Neharde’a say: Rav would not flog</b> a violator <b>in all of</b> the cases listed, <b>but</b> he would in fact flog a man <b>for betrothing</b> a woman <b>through sexual intercourse without</b> a prior <b>arrangement. And there are</b> those <b>who say: Even if</b> there was <b>an arrangement beforehand,</b> he would <b>also</b> flog a man for betrothing a woman with intercourse, <b>due to licentiousness,</b> as it is indecent to have witnesses observe a man and woman enter a room to engage in intercourse.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with a mat of myrtle branches.</b> People who were present <b>said to him: But it is not worth one <i>peruta</i>. He said to them:</b> If so, <b>let her be betrothed with</b> the <b>four dinars that are</b> wrapped <b>in</b> the mat. The woman <b>took</b> the mat <b>and was silent. Rava said: This is silence after</b> the <b>money is given, and any silence after</b> the <b>money is given is nothing.</b> Since it was assumed at the time that he gave her an item worth less than one <i>peruta</i>, there is no proof that she acted in accordance with his subsequent statement. It is possible that she ignored him and did not intend to become betrothed with the four dinars.
<b>Rava said: From where do I state</b> this opinion? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that in a case where a man <b>said to</b> a woman: <b>Take this <i>sela</i> as a deposit, and he</b> subsequently <b>went back and said to her: Be betrothed to me with it,</b> if he said this <b>at the time</b> the <b>money</b> was <b>given, she is betrothed.</b> In a case where he said this <b>after</b> the <b>money</b> was <b>given,</b> then if <b>she wanted</b> to be betrothed in this manner, <b>she is betrothed.</b> If <b>she did not want</b> it, <b>she is not betrothed.</b>
The Gemara inquires: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>She wanted, and what</b> is the meaning of: <b>She did not want? If we say</b> that: <b>She wanted,</b> means <b>that she said yes,</b> she wishes to be betrothed, and: <b>She did not want,</b> means that <b>she</b> explicitly <b>said no,</b> one can learn <b>by inference</b> that in <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, when he spoke as he gave her the money and no difference is suggested between her wanting or not wanting,

Daf 13a

that <b>if</b> she <b>said: No, it would also be</b> a <b>betrothal.</b> But <b>why</b> should that be the case? After all, <b>she said: No. Rather, is it not</b> to be explained in this manner, i.e., that the phrase: <b>She wanted,</b> means <b>she said yes,</b> and: <b>She did not want,</b> means <b>that she remained silent. And</b> one can <b>learn from this</b> that <b>silence after</b> the <b>money is given is nothing.</b> Her silence is not interpreted as an agreement to the betrothal.
<b>In</b> the city of <b>Pum Nahara they raised a difficulty against</b> Rava’s proof, <b>in the name of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: Is it comparable? There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>he gave her</b> the money <b>as a deposit</b> but they are his. She therefore <b>thinks: If I throw them and they break I will be obligated</b> to pay <b>for them,</b> as would anyone who destroys another person’s property. Consequently, her silence is interpreted as consent only to continue in her role of holding it as a deposit. By contrast, <b>here he gives them to her as betrothal</b> money so that they would belong to her. <b>And if it is so, that she is not amenable</b> to being betrothed, <b>let her throw them</b> away.
<b>Rav Aḥai refutes</b> this argument: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>all women are learned</b> in <b><i>halakha</i>?</b> In this case <b>also, she thinks: If I throw them and they break I will be responsible for them.</b> Therefore, I will not throw them. One cannot deduce from the fact that she does not throw the coins that she accepted them as betrothal money. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav, sent</b> this question <b>to Ravina: In a case like this, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Ravina <b>sent</b> the following response <b>to him: We did not hear this statement of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua.</b> Therefore, we do not need to take it into consideration. <b>You, who heard it, should be concerned about</b> a possible betrothal.
§ The Gemara further relates: There was <b>a certain woman who was selling belts. A certain man came</b> and <b>snatched a belt [<i>varshekha</i>] from her. She said to him: Give</b> it <b>to me. He said to her: If I give</b> it <b>to you will you be betrothed to me? She took it and was silent, and Rav Naḥman said: She could say: Yes, I took</b> it, but <b>I took my</b> property. There is no proof that she agreed to accept it as a betrothal.
<b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If a man <b>betrothed</b> a woman <b>with</b> property that was taken <b>by robbery; or</b> with property taken <b>by a forced transaction,</b> when the owner was reluctant to sell, <b>or</b> with property that was taken <b>by theft; or if he grabbed a <i>sela</i> from her hand and betrothed her</b> with it, <b>she is betrothed.</b> If so, why does Rav Naḥman say here that when he took it from her and betrothed her she is not betrothed? Rav Naḥman answered: <b>There,</b> it is referring to a case where <b>he</b> had previously <b>arranged</b> to marry her, and therefore if she remained silent she certainly agreed to the betrothal.
<b>And from where do you say that there is a difference</b> between a case <b>where he</b> had previously <b>arranged</b> to marry her <b>and where he had not arranged</b> to do so? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that with regard to a man who <b>said to</b> a woman: <b>Take this <i>sela</i> that I owe you, and he went back and said to her: Be betrothed to me with it,</b> if he said this <b>at the time the money was given</b> and <b>she wanted</b> it, <b>she is betrothed;</b> if <b>she did not want</b> it, <b>she is not betrothed.</b> If he issued his statement <b>after</b> the <b>money was given,</b> then <b>even if she wanted</b> it, <b>she is not betrothed.</b>
Rav Naḥman clarifies: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>She wanted, and what</b> is the meaning of: <b>She did not want? If we say</b> that: <b>She wanted,</b> means <b>that she said yes,</b> and: <b>She did not want,</b> means that <b>she</b> explicitly <b>said no,</b> it can be inferred that if <b>she was silent it is</b> a valid <b>betrothal. But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> simply that <b>she is betrothed, without specification, as</b> it did <b>there</b> in the previous case, with regard to one who said: Take this <i>sela</i> as a deposit. It is obvious that if she explicitly said no, she is not betrothed.
<b>Rather,</b> the phrase: <b>She wanted,</b> means <b>she said yes,</b> and: <b>She did not want,</b> means <b>that she remained silent. And</b> in this case of silence the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught that she is not betrothed. What is the reason</b> that she is not betrothed if she remained silent? It is that <b>she can say: Yes I took</b> it, <b>but I took my own</b> property and did not intend to become betrothed.
<b>But this</b> is <b>difficult</b> with regard to <b>that</b> which we learned, that if a man <b>betrothed her with</b> property that was taken <b>by robbery, or</b> with property taken <b>by a forced transaction, or</b> with property that was taken <b>by theft, or if he grabbed a <i>sela</i> from her hand and betrothed her</b> with it, <b>she is betrothed. Rather, isn’t it</b> correct to <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>this</b> ruling, that she is betrothed if she was silent, is referring to a case <b>where he arranged</b> the marriage beforehand, whereas <b>this</b> ruling, that she is not betrothed when she remained silent, is referring to a situation <b>where he did not arrange</b> it beforehand?
§ The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Asi died, the Sages assembled to collect his statements,</b> i.e., they wished to review his rulings of <i>halakha</i> lest they be forgotten. <b>A certain</b> member <b>of the Sages, and Rabbi Ya’akov was his name, said to them: This</b> is what <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Mani said: Just as a woman cannot be acquired by less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>, so</b> too <b>land cannot be acquired by less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>. They said to him: But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Although a woman cannot be acquired by less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>, land can be acquired by less than the value of one <i>peruta</i>?</b>
Rabbi Ya’akov <b>said to them: When that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught</b> to the effect that land can be acquired by less than the value of one <i>peruta</i> but a woman cannot, it was <b>with regard to</b> acquisition through symbolic <b>exchange,</b> i.e., a legal act of acquisition formalizing the transfer of ownership of an article. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One can acquire</b> land and movable items through a symbolic exchange <b>by</b> giving <b>a vessel, even though it is not worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b>
<b>They then sat and said</b> additional statements in the name of Rabbi Asi. One statement concerned <b>that which Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Anyone who does not know the nature of bills of divorce and betrothals should have no dealings in them,</b> as his ignorance might lead people to commit serious sins. In this context, <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And</b> those who deal with these issues without proper knowledge <b>are worse for the world than the generation of the flood, as it is stated: “Swearing and lying, and killing, and stealing, and committing adultery. They break all bounds, and blood touches blood”</b> (Hosea 4:2).
The Gemara asks: <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred</b> that this verse is referring to individuals of this kind and that they are worse for the world than the generation of the flood? The Gemara explains: <b>As Rav Yosef translated</b> the phrase “and committing adultery, they break all bounds, and blood touches blood,” as: <b>They give birth to children through the wives of others; they add sins upon sins.</b>
<b>And it is written</b> in the next verse: <b>“Therefore the land mourns and everyone who dwells there languishes, with the beasts of the field and the fowls of heaven, and the fishes of the sea are also taken away”</b> (Hosea 4:3). This indicates that those who cause illegitimate children to be born lead to such a great tragedy that even the fish of the sea will die, <b>whereas in the generation of the flood the decree was not imposed upon the fish in the sea, as it is stated: “Whatever was on dry land died”</b> (Genesis 7:22). The explicit mention of dry land indicates that <b>the fish in the sea did not</b> die. <b>But here,</b> in the punishment described in the verses in Hosea, <b>even the fish in the sea</b> died.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that this punishment is not administered <b>until they perform all of them,</b> i.e., only if they commit all of the sins mentioned in the verse, including taking false oaths, committing murder, and stealing. The Gemara answers: It should <b>not enter your mind</b> to say this, <b>as it is written: “For because of swearing the land mourns”</b> (Jeremiah 23:10). This verse teaches that on account of taking false oaths alone the world can be destroyed, from which it may be inferred that each these acts on its own is enough to warrant destruction.
The Gemara further asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that taking a false <b>oath is distinct,</b> as it involves the desecration of God’s name, <b>and these</b> other sins <b>are distinct,</b> i.e., they are less severe offenses that entail a less serious punishment. Therefore, it is possible that this great tragedy will result only if one performs all of them.

Daf 13b

The Gemara explains: <b>Is it written: And they break all bounds,</b> with the conjunction: And, which would indicate that all the sins are included as one unit? Rather, it <b>is written: “They break all bounds,”</b> from which it may be inferred that this punishment is given separately for each one of these sins.
§ <b>They then sat and said</b> additional statements in the name of Rav Asi, one of which concerned <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kinnim</i> 2:5): With regard to <b>a woman</b> after childbirth <b>who brought her sin-offering</b> for her ritual purification <b>and died, the heirs bring her burnt-offering</b> to fulfill her remaining sacrificial obligations. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: And</b> this <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when</b> the woman herself had already <b>separated,</b> i.e., designated, the animal for the burnt-offering <b>in her lifetime. But</b> if she <b>had not separated it in her lifetime, no,</b> the heirs are not required to bring a burnt-offering on her behalf.
The Gemara concludes: <b>Apparently,</b> Shmuel <b>maintains</b> that the property of a debtor is <b>not liened by Torah law.</b> In other words, one does not say that because she was required to bring a burnt-offering there is a lien on her property and the debt must be paid even if she did not set aside the animal before her death. <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though she did not separate</b> the burnt-offering <b>in her lifetime. Apparently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>maintains</b> that the property of a debtor is <b>liened by Torah law.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> these Sages already <b>disagreed about</b> this issue <b>once;</b> why would they engage in the same dispute with regard to multiple applications? <b>As Rav and Shmuel both say:</b> With regard to <b>a loan</b> granted <b>by oral</b> agreement, i.e., without a document that places a lien on the land, if the debtor dies, the creditor <b>cannot collect</b> the loan <b>from the heirs or from those who purchased</b> the land. This is the <i>halakha</i> even if it is clear that there was a loan and the debtors do not dispute this fact. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both say:</b> With regard to <b>a loan by oral</b> agreement, the creditor can <b>collect from the heirs and from those who purchased</b> from the debtor. This shows that those same Sages already disagreed as to whether a lien on a property exists by Torah law in the absence of a document.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to teach both cases <b>as, if</b> it <b>were stated</b> only <b>about this</b> case of a loan, one might say: It is only <b>with regard to this</b> situation <b>that Shmuel says</b> there is no lien on property, <b>because it is a loan that is not written in the Torah.</b> This loan is merely a private agreement between two individuals. <b>But with regard to this</b> obligation of a woman to bring a burnt-offering, one might <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan and to Reish Lakish.</b> Since this woman’s obligation to bring a burnt-offering is written in the Torah, perhaps it creates a lien on her property despite the fact that there is no document to that effect.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>had</b> the <i>amora’im</i> <b>taught us about</b> their dispute only in <b>this</b> case of the burnt-offering of a woman following childbirth, one might say that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the Torah imposes a lien only in <b>this</b> case of the burnt-offering, as <b>a loan written in the Torah is like one written in a document. But with regard to this</b> private loan, one might <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Shmuel</b> that the lien does not apply by Torah law. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state the dispute in both cases.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is as follows: With regard to <b>a loan by oral</b> agreement, the creditor can <b>collect from the heirs but he cannot collect from those who purchased</b> from the debtor. The reason <b>he can collect from the heirs</b> is that the accepted opinion is that the property of a debtor is <b>liened by Torah law. But he cannot collect from those who purchased</b> from the debtor, because a loan by oral agreement <b>does not generate publicity,</b> i.e., people will not have heard about it. Therefore, they are not careful to avoid buying property from the debtor. These purchasers should not suffer due to a lien that was not well known.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> a woman <b>acquires herself through a bill of divorce or through the death of the husband.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a bill of divorce, as it is written</b> explicitly in the Torah: <b>“And he writes for her a scroll of severance,</b> and gives it in her hand, and sends her out of his house; and she departs out of his house and she goes and becomes another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:1–2). This indicates that a bill of divorce enables a woman to marry whomever she wishes after the divorce.
<b>But from where do we</b> derive that <b>the death of the husband</b> also enables a woman to remarry? The Gemara answers: This <b>is</b> based on <b>logical reasoning: He,</b> the husband, <b>rendered her forbidden</b> to every man, <b>and he</b> has <b>permitted her.</b> Since the husband is no longer alive, there is no one who renders her forbidden.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> consider the status of <b>those with whom relations are forbidden, as he renders</b> her <b>forbidden to them, and</b> yet he <b>does not permit</b> her <b>to them</b> when he dies. For example, one may not marry one’s father’s wife even after the father dies. <b>Rather, from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One states</b> that <b>a <i>yevama</i> who does not have children</b> from her deceased husband <b>is prohibited</b> from marrying anyone besides the <i>yavam</i>, it may be inferred that a widow <b>who has children</b> from her deceased husband <b>is permitted</b> to remarry.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> one should infer the following from that <i>halakha</i>: A woman who <b>does not have children</b> from her deceased husband <b>is forbidden to everyone and permitted to the <i>yavam</i>, and</b> a woman who <b>has children</b> from her deceased husband <b>is forbidden to everyone also. Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the death of the husband permits a woman to marry another man is derived <b>from</b> the fact that <b>the Merciful One states</b> that <b>a widow is forbidden to a High Priest.</b> This indicates that it is <b>permitted</b> for her <b>to</b> marry <b>a common priest,</b> and the same certainly applies to a non-priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> one can say that she is forbidden <b>to a High Priest by a prohibition,</b> whereas she is forbidden <b>to everyone else</b> only <b>by</b> dint of <b>a positive mitzva.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This positive mitzva, what is its purpose? If the death of the husband affects</b> her status, <b>she should be entirely permitted,</b> and <b>if the death of the husband does not affect</b> her status <b>she remains in her initial state</b> when her husband was alive, and therefore those who engage in sexual intercourse with her would be liable to receive the death penalty.
The Gemara answers: And <b>why</b> is this suggestion <b>not</b> considered reasonable? One could argue that the death of the husband <b>removed her from</b> the class of people with whom one is punished with <b>death</b> for engaging in intercourse, <b>and placed her in</b> the class of people with whom one is prohibited to engage in intercourse due to <b>a positive mitzva, just as it is with consecrated</b> animals <b>that have been disqualified.</b> This is referring to animals that were designated as offerings but became invalid due to some blemish.
The Gemara explains: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to such animals is <b>that initially,</b> when they are unblemished, <b>they are subject</b> to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse,</b> i.e., if one benefited from them he has misused consecrated items. <b>And</b> likewise <b>shearing</b> them and performing <b>labor</b> with them <b>is prohibited.</b> Once these animals have developed a blemish and <b>one has redeemed them,</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated items <b>does not apply to them,</b> but <b>shearing</b> them and performing <b>labor</b> with them remains <b>prohibited.</b> Based on this example, it is possible that the death of the husband does not render the woman entirely permitted. If so, one cannot derive from here that it is permitted for a wife whose husband has passed away to marry another man.
<b>Rather,</b> the source that a widow may remarry is <b>from that</b> which <b>the verse states: “Lest he die in battle and another man take her”</b> (Deuteronomy 20:7). This indicates that a man may marry a widow. <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to this:</b> One can <b>say: Who is</b> this <b>other</b> man mentioned by the verse? It is <b>a <i>yavam</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that there are <b>two refutations of</b> this <b>statement: First, a <i>yavam</i> is not called “another,”</b> as his relationship with her is not entirely separate from that of the first husband. <b>And furthermore, it is written: “And the latter husband hates her, and writes her a scroll of severance and gives it in her hand and sends her out of his house, or if the latter husband dies”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:3). In this manner the verse <b>juxtaposes death to divorce: Just as divorce permits</b> a woman to everyone <b>and completes</b> the severing of a husband from his wife, thereby allowing her to marry another man, <b>so too, death permits</b> her <b>and completes</b> the severing, allowing her to marry another man.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And a <i>yevama</i></b> can be <b>acquired</b> by the deceased husband’s brother, the <i>yavam</i>, only <b>through intercourse.</b> And she acquires herself through <i>ḥalitza</i> or through the death of the <i>yavam</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that she can be acquired <b>through intercourse? The verse states:</b>

Daf 14a

<b>“Her brother-in-law will engage in sexual intercourse with her and take her to him as a wife,</b> and perform levirate marriage with her” (Deuteronomy 25:5), which indicates that intercourse renders her his wife. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>with regard to all matters</b> she is <b>like a wife,</b> and therefore she can also be acquired with money or a document like any other woman. The Gemara answers: It could <b>not enter your mind</b> to say this, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>money and a document can complete</b> the acquisition of a <i>yevama</i> and cause her to be married, <b>in the manner that intercourse completes</b> her acquisition. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And perform levirate marriage with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:5), which indicates that only <b>intercourse completes her</b> acquisition, <b>but money or a document do not complete her</b> acquisition.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say: What</b> is the meaning of: <b>“And perform levirate marriage with her”?</b> It teaches <b>that he can perform levirate marriage without her consent,</b> as unlike an ordinary marriage, a levirate marriage does not require the woman’s agreement. The Gemara answers: <b>If so, let the verse say: And perform levirate marriage,</b> and one would understand that the matter depends entirely on him. <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>“And perform levirate marriage with her”? Learn two</b> conclusions <b>from this:</b> First, that a levirate marriage can be performed against her will, and second, that the only way to acquire a <i>yevama</i> is through sexual intercourse.
§ The mishna teaches that the <i>yevama</i> acquires herself <b>through <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written</b> with regard to levirate marriage, after the <i>yavam</i> has performed <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>“And his name shall be called in Israel: The house of him who had his shoe removed”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:10). This indicates: <b>Once</b> his <b>shoe is removed by her, she is permitted to all of Israel.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> term <b>“Israel,” does it come</b> to teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>It is required for that which is taught</b> by <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda:</b> The verse says <b>“in Israel”</b> to teach that <i>ḥalitza</i> may be performed only <b>in a Jewish court, but not in a gentile court.</b> The Gemara answers that the phrase <b>“in Israel” is written twice</b> in that chapter: “And his name shall be called in Israel” (Deuteronomy 25:10), and: “To establish a name for his brother in Israel” (Deuteronomy 25:7). A different <i>halakha</i> is derived from each of these instances.
The Gemara asks: <b>But still, we</b> also <b>require</b> the additional term “in Israel” <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Once we were sitting before Rabbi Tarfon and a <i>yevama</i> came to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. And</b> Rabbi Tarfon <b>said to us</b> after the <i>ḥalitza</i>: <b>All of you</b> should <b>answer and say: The one whose shoe was removed, the one whose shoe was removed.</b> This indicates that the phrase: “And his name shall be called in Israel” (Deuteronomy 25:10), teaches that the matter must be announced and publicized throughout the nation. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> is not derived from the phrase “in Israel.” Rather, <b>it is derived from: “And his name shall be called,”</b> which indicates that it must be announced that this is his name.
§ The mishna further teaches that a <i>yevama</i> is released from levirate marriage and may remarry <b>through the death of the <i>yavam</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers that it is <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If,</b> with regard to <b>a married woman, who is</b> forbidden to other men by a prohibition punished <b>with strangulation,</b> and yet <b>the death of her husband renders her permitted,</b> is <b>it not all the more so</b> that with regard to <b>a <i>yevama</i>, who is</b> forbidden to other men while the <i>yavam</i> is alive <b>by</b> only a mere <b>prohibition,</b> that the death of the <i>yavam</i> should render her permitted?
The Gemara raises a difficulty against this <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a married woman</b> is <b>that she can leave through a bill of divorce</b> as well. Will <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to this</b> <i>yevama</i>, <b>who does not leave through a bill of divorce?</b> The Gemara answers: This is an insufficient refutation of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as <b>this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>also leaves through <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> which serves the same function as a bill of divorce.
<b>Rather,</b> one can challenge this <i>a fortiori</i> inference in the following manner. <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a married woman</b> is <b>that</b> the one who <b>renders her forbidden</b> to everyone else, i.e., her husband, also <b>renders her permitted</b> when he dies. This is not so with regard to a <i>yevama</i>, as she is rendered forbidden upon the death of her husband. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> With regard to <b>this</b> <i>yevama</i> <b>as well,</b> he who <b>renders her forbidden</b> is also the one who <b>renders her permitted:</b> The <b><i>yavam</i> renders her forbidden,</b> because if he was not alive she would automatically be permitted to other men. Likewise, the <b><i>yavam</i> renders her permitted</b> through <i>ḥalitza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let a married woman leave</b> a marriage <b>through <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as derived <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If a <i>yevama</i>, who cannot leave through a bill of divorce, can leave through <i>ḥalitza</i>, is it not logical</b> that <b>this</b> married woman, <b>who can leave through a bill of divorce, can</b> likewise <b>leave through <i>ḥalitza</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states</b> with regard to a married woman: <b>“A scroll of severance”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:3), which indicates that <b>a scroll,</b> i.e., a written document, <b>severs her</b> from her husband <b>and nothing else severs her</b> from him. While the husband is alive only a bill of divorce can dissolve a marriage.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And let a <i>yevama</i> leave through a bill of divorce,</b> as derived <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If a married woman, who cannot leave through <i>ḥalitza</i>, can leave through a bill of divorce, is it not logical</b> that <b>this</b> <i>yevama</i>, <b>who can leave through <i>ḥalitza</i>, can</b> also <b>leave through a bill of divorce?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The verse states: “So</b> shall it be done to the man” (Deuteronomy 25:9), with regard to the <i>ḥalitza</i> of a <i>yevama</i>, <b>and “so” precludes</b> another option.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it true that <b>anywhere that there is</b> a term that <b>precludes</b> another option <b>one cannot learn an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? <b>But there is</b> the case of the designation of the goats on <b>Yom Kippur, as it is written:</b> “The goat upon which the <b>lot</b> came up for the Lord” (Leviticus 16:9), <b>and:</b> “This shall be an everlasting <b>statute</b> to you” (Leviticus 16:34), which indicates that everything stated with regard to the mitzvot of Yom Kippur is critical to the performance of the service of the day.
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states: “Aaron shall bring forward the goat upon which the lot came up for the Lord, <b>and he shall offer it for a sin-offering”</b> (Leviticus 16:9). The verse indicates that <b>the lottery renders</b> it <b>a sin-offering,</b> but <b>a verbal designation</b> of the goat with the status of a sin-offering <b>does not render</b> it <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: A verse is necessary to teach this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the opposite conclusion is correct: Could this <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference,</b> as follows: <b>Just as in a case in which</b> the use of <b>a lottery does not effect the consecration</b> of the animals with a specific designation, e.g., with regard to a woman who has given birth and must bring two birds, one as a sin-offering and one as a burnt-offering, and nevertheless <b>a verbal designation</b> of the animals with the required status <b>does effect the consecration</b> of them, so too, in <b>a case in which</b> the use of <b>a lottery does effect the consecration</b> of the animals, <b>is it not</b> logically <b>right that a verbal designation</b> of the animals with the required status <b>should effect the consecration</b> of them?
To counter this reasoning, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the goat: <b>“He shall offer it for a sin-offering”</b> (Leviticus 16:9), to indicate that <b>the lottery renders</b> it <b>a sin-offering, but a verbal designation</b> of the goat with the status of a sin-offering <b>does not render</b> it <b>a sin-offering. And the reason</b> that a verbal designation is ineffective <b>is that the verse excluded</b> this possibility, from which it may be inferred <b>that if it were not so, one would learn an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, <b>even though it is written with regard to it “statute.”</b> The same logic should apply in the case of <i>ḥalitza</i>, i.e., the term “so” should not prevent one from learning an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, and therefore it might be argued that a <i>yevama</i> can be released through a bill of divorce.
Rather, the Gemara explains that here too, there is a limitation derived from a verse. <b>The verse states</b> with regard to a bill of divorce: “And write <b>for her</b> a scroll of severance” (Deuteronomy 24:3). <b>“For her”</b> is a limitation, which teaches: A bill of divorce is effective for a regular woman <b>but not for a <i>yevama</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the phrase <b>“for her”</b> indicates that the bill of divorce must be written <b>for her sake.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>“For her” is written twice</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1, 3), and therefore both <i>halakhot</i> can be derived. The Gemara asks: <b>And still, one</b> instance of: <b>“For her” is required</b> to teach that the bill of divorce must be written <b>for her sake, and the other “for her”</b> is needed to teach: For her <b>and not</b> both <b>for her and for another,</b> i.e., her rival wife. One bill of divorce cannot be used for two women.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara suggests a different explanation as to why a bill of divorce is ineffective for a <i>yevama</i>. With regard to a <i>yevama</i> <b>the verse states:</b> “The house of him who had his <b>shoe</b> removed” (Deuteronomy 25:10), which teaches: If she is released by the <i>ḥalitza</i> of the <b>shoe, yes,</b> she is released from the <i>yavam</i>, but if she was released by means of <b>something else, no,</b> she is not released.
The Gemara asks: <b>But this</b> term <b>“shoe,” does it come</b> to teach <b>this? It is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse said: “And remove <b>his shoe”</b> (Deuteronomy 25:9). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>his shoe</b> may be used. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the <b>shoe of any person</b> may also be used for <i>ḥalitza</i>?
<b>The verse states “shoe,”</b> and states again in the next verse <b>“shoe,”</b> which <b>includes</b> any other shoe. <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “his shoe,”</b> which is apparently referring to the shoe of that particular man? This teaches that it must be <b>his shoe that is fit for him, excluding</b> a shoe so <b>large that he cannot walk in it,</b> and <b>excluding</b> a shoe so <b>small that it does not cover most of his foot,</b> and <b>excluding</b>

Daf 14b

<b>sandals [<i>mesulayim</i>] that have no heels,</b> which do not qualify as shoes. The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that the term is stated only for that purpose, <b>let the verse write “shoe.” What</b> is the meaning of <b>“the shoe”? Learn</b> the <b>two</b> previously stated conclusions <b>from it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A Hebrew slave</b> can be <b>acquired</b> by his master <b>through money or through a document, and</b> he can <b>acquire himself,</b> i.e., he is emancipated, <b>through years,</b> i.e., when he completes his six years of labor, <b>or through the</b> advent of the <b>Jubilee</b> Year, <b>or through the deduction of money.</b> The slave can redeem himself during the six years by paying for his remaining years of slavery. <b>A Hebrew maidservant</b> has one mode of emancipation <b>more than him, as she acquires herself through signs</b> indicating puberty. A slave <b>who is pierced</b> after serving six years is <b>acquired</b> as a slave for a longer period <b>through piercing</b> his ear with an awl, <b>and</b> he <b>acquires himself through the</b> advent of the <b>Jubilee</b> Year <b>or through</b> the <b>death of the master.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that <b>a Hebrew slave</b> can be <b>acquired through money.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers that the <b>verse states: “Out of the money that he was bought for”</b> (Leviticus 25:51), which <b>teaches</b> that he can be <b>acquired through money.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> that <b>a Hebrew slave who is sold to a gentile</b> is acquired with money, which is the case discussed in that verse, but this proves nothing with regard to a Jew sold to a Jew. One could argue that <b>since all of the acquisitions</b> of a gentile are performed only <b>with money,</b> he can likewise purchase a Hebrew slave with money.
But <b>from where do we</b> derive that a Hebrew slave can be <b>sold to a Jew</b> with money? The Gemara explains that with regard to a Hebrew maidservant, the <b>verse states:</b> “Then he shall let her <b>be redeemed”</b> (Exodus 21:8), which <b>teaches</b> that if she acquires money and wishes to be emancipated before her time is complete, she <b>deducts</b> a sum <b>from her redemption.</b> The maidservant can deduct the value of time served from her purchase price and pay the remaining amount, and she then <b>is emancipated.</b> This teaches that a Hebrew maidservant is acquired through money, a <i>halakha</i> that applies to a male slave as well.
The Gemara asks: Although <b>we found</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a Hebrew maidservant,</b> one cannot extrapolate from there to this case, as it is possible that it applies only to a female. The reason for this is that <b>since</b> she is ordinarily <b>betrothed through money,</b> she can also be <b>acquired</b> as a maidservant <b>through money. From where do we</b> derive that <b>a Hebrew slave</b> can likewise be acquired through money? The Gemara answers that the <b>verse states: “If your brother, a Hebrew man, or a Hebrew woman is sold to you, and he shall serve you six years”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:12). This verse <b>juxtaposes a Hebrew man to a Hebrew woman,</b> indicating that the modes through which they are acquired are the same.
The Gemara further asks: <b>We found</b> a source in this verse for <b>a slave who is sold by the court.</b> This verse is referring to a thief who is unable to repay the value of his theft and is sold as a slave so that he can repay his debt. One can therefore argue that this case is unique, <b>since</b> he is <b>sold against his will. From where do we</b> derive that one who <b>sells himself</b> can be sold through money?
The Gemara answers: One <b>derives</b> this through a verbal analogy between the terms <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker.”</b> This term appears both with regard to one who sells himself: “As a hired worker and as a settler he shall be with you” (Leviticus 25:40), and with regard to one who is sold by the court: “For double of the hire of a hired worker he has served you” (Deuteronomy 15:18). The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who</b> derives this verbal analogy between the terms <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker.” But according to the one who does not derive</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,” what can be said?</b> From where does he derive that one who sells himself may be purchased with money?
The Gemara answers: The <b>verse states</b> at the start of the passage dealing with one sold to a gentile: <b>“And if</b> a stranger who is a settler with you <b>becomes rich”</b> (Leviticus 25:47). The conjunction “and” serves to <b>add to the first matter,</b> i.e., the passage discussing one who sells himself to a Jew, as it joins the two issues. And therefore <b>let the above case</b> of one who sells himself to a Jew <b>be derived from the case below</b> of one who is sold to a gentile: Just as one who is sold to a gentile can be acquired with money, so too, one who sells himself to a Jew can be acquired with money.
The Gemara comments: <b>And who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> <b>who does not derive</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker”? It is this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i>: One who <b>sells himself</b> as a slave <b>is sold for six</b> years, <b>and</b> if he wishes he can be sold for <b>more than six</b> years, whereas one who is <b>sold by the court is sold only for six</b> years, but no more.
The <i>baraita</i> adds that there are additional differences between these two slaves: <b>One who sells himself may not be pierced</b> with an awl, whereas one who is <b>sold by the court may be pierced</b> with an awl. One who <b>sells himself is not granted</b> a severance gift by his master when he is emancipated, whereas one who is <b>sold by the court is granted</b> a severance gift. With regard to <b>one who sells himself, his master may not provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant</b> as a wife to produce slave children, whereas with regard to one <b>sold by the court, his master may provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that there is no difference between these two types of slaves. Rather, both <b>this</b> slave <b>and that</b> slave may be <b>sold for only six</b> years; both <b>this and that</b> one may be <b>pierced</b> with an awl, both <b>this and that</b> one <b>are granted</b> a severance gift, and in both <b>this</b> case <b>and that</b> case <b>his master may provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant. What, is it not</b> the case that <b>they disagree with regard to this, that the first <i>tanna</i> does not derive</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,” and Rabbi Elazar derives</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker”?</b> If one holds that the two cases are juxtaposed, one will equate the <i>halakhot</i> of both slaves. This is the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, in contrast to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, who holds that the <i>halakhot</i> of each type of slave are discrete.
<b>Rav Tavyumei said in the name of Abaye:</b> That is not so; rather, <b>everyone derives</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,” and here,</b> in the dispute in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>they disagree about this</b> following <b>verse. What is the reasoning</b> of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>, who says</b> that one who <b>sells himself is sold for six</b> years <b>and more than six</b> years? He maintains that with regard to one <b>sold by the court, the Merciful One excludes</b> a certain case by the verse: “If your brother, a Hebrew man, or a Hebrew woman, is sold to you, <b>and he shall serve you six years”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:12). That teaches that only <b>this</b> type of slave serves for six years and no more, but the same does <b>not</b> apply to one who <b>sells himself.</b> If he so stipulates, he may serve for more than six years.
The Gemara explains: <b>And the other,</b> Rabbi Elazar, learns a different <i>halakha</i> from this verse. <b>“And he shall serve you”</b> means that he works <b>for you and not for an heir</b> other than a son. If a master has no sons, his slave is not transferred as an inheritance to a daughter or to a brother like his other property. If he does have sons, they inherit a Hebrew slave.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the other,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, from where does he derive that a slave is not transferred as an inheritance?
