The Gemara answers that the phrase, <b>“And he shall serve you,”</b> is <b>written another</b> time, and he derives this <i>halakha</i> from there. The Gemara asks: <b>And the other,</b> Rabbi Elazar, what does he do with that other verse? The Gemara answers: In his opinion <b>that</b> verse <b>comes to appease the master.</b> The verse emphasizes that the servitude is of limited duration to encourage the master to free the slave without hesitation.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of the first <i>tanna</i>, who says</b> that one who <b>sells himself is not pierced</b> with an awl? The Gemara answers: He derives this <b>from</b> the fact that <b>with regard to one sold by the court, the Merciful One excludes</b> a certain case by the verse: <b>“And his master shall pierce his ear with an awl”</b> (Exodus 21:6), which teaches: <b>His ear,</b> of this slave, <b>and not the ear of</b> a slave who <b>sells himself.</b>

Daf 15a

<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, would say: <b>That</b> term, “his ear,” <b>comes for a verbal analogy. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: From where</b> is it derived that the <b>piercing</b> of a Hebrew slave’s ear with an awl is performed <b>on the right ear? It is stated: Ear, here,</b> with regard to a Hebrew slave, <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the ritual purification of a leper: “The right <b>ear</b> of he who is to be purified” (Leviticus 14:14). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to a leper, it specifies the <b>right</b> ear explicitly, <b>so too here,</b> the piercing of a slave must be performed on the <b>right</b> ear.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, derive that this piercing can be performed only on the right ear? The Gemara answers: He would argue that <b>if it is so</b> that the word “ear” is stated only for the sake of the verbal analogy, <b>let the verse say</b> merely: <b>Ear,</b> and one would learn the <i>halakha</i> through a verbal analogy from the case of the leper’s ear. <b>What</b> is the reason that it states <b>“his ear”?</b> This serves to teach that one who sells himself may not be pierced.
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, would answer: <b>That</b> formulation <b>is necessary</b> to teach that the mitzva of piercing applies to <b>“his ear” but not her ear.</b> He learns from the pronoun that piercing may be performed only on a male slave, not a maidservant. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from</b> the verse: <b>“But if the slave shall say”</b> (Exodus 21:5). This indicates that piercing applies to <b>the slave but not</b> to <b>a maidservant.</b>
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, who does not derive this ruling in the same manner as the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>requires</b> this verse for a different <i>halakha</i>: A slave may declare that he wishes to be pierced <b>provided that he says</b> this <b>when he is</b> still <b>a slave.</b> After he has been emancipated, he can no longer say that he wishes to remain with his master.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, learn this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara responds: <b>He derives</b> it <b>from</b> the terms: <b>Slave,</b> and <b>“the slave.”</b> If the verse had stated only: Slave, one would have learned that a slave may say this only while still a slave. Since it is actually written “the slave,” this teaches the other <i>halakha</i> as well, that a slave may be pierced but a maidservant may not. The Gemara comments: <b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, <b>does not learn</b> a <i>halakha</i> from this slight difference between: <b>Slave,</b> and <b>“the slave.”</b>
The Gemara clarifies additional details with regard to this dispute: <b>What is the reasoning of the first <i>tanna</i>, who says</b> that <b>one does not grant</b> a severance gift <b>to one who sells himself? With regard to one sold by the court, the Merciful One excludes</b> a certain case by the verse: <b>“You shall give a severance gift to him”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:14). <b>“To him”</b> means to one who is sold by the court, <b>but not to one who sells himself.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, derive from that verse? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires that</b> verse to teach the following: <b>“To him”</b> means that one grants a severance gift only to the slave himself <b>but not to his heirs.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why not</b> give this gift <b>to his heirs?</b> After all, <b>the Merciful One calls</b> a Hebrew slave <b>“a hired worker.” Just as</b> payment for <b>the labor of a hired worker</b> is given <b>to his heirs</b> when he dies, <b>so too this</b> severance gift for <b>his labor</b> should be given <b>to his heirs</b> when he dies. <b>Rather,</b> this verse teaches <b>“to him,” but not to</b> the slave’s <b>creditor.</b> One to whom the slave owes money may not collect the slave’s severance gift as repayment of the debt.
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to emphasize that a creditor has no rights to the severance gift? That is necessary due to the fact <b>that we generally hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> in the case of <b>one who lends one hundred dinars to another, and the other</b> lends a similar sum <b>to</b> yet <b>another,</b> a third person, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> the court <b>appropriates</b> the money <b>from this one,</b> the third person, <b>and gives</b> it <b>to that one,</b> the first creditor, without going through the second person, who owes money to the first and is owed that same amount by the third? <b>The verse states: “And he shall give it to him whom he has wronged”</b> (Numbers 5:7), which indicates that the loan should be repaid to the creditor to whom the money is ultimately owed.
Therefore, the term <b>“to him” comes to exclude</b> this possibility, as the severance gift is given to the slave and not to his creditor. <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, respond to this claim? He maintains that <b>we generally do not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan.</b> Consequently, this exposition is unnecessary.
The Gemara continues to ask: <b>What is the reasoning of the first <i>tanna</i>, who says</b> that if <b>one sells himself his master does not provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to one sold by the court, the Merciful One excludes</b> a certain case by the verse: <b>“If his master give to him a wife”</b> (Exodus 21:4). This serves to emphasize <b>“to him” but not to one who sells himself. And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, explains: <b>“To him”</b> means even <b>against his will.</b>
<b>And</b> from where does <b>the other</b> Sage, the first <i>tanna</i>, derive that the slave must remain with this maidservant against his will? <b>He derives</b> it <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“For double of the hire of a hired worker</b> he has served you” (Deuteronomy 15:18). <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that this verse: <b>“For double of the hire of a hired worker he has served you,”</b> indicates that <b>a hired worker works only during the day,</b> whereas <b>a Hebrew slave works both during the day and at night.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And can it enter your mind that a Hebrew slave</b> actually <b>works both during the day and at night? But isn’t it already stated: “Because he fares well with you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:16), which teaches that he must be <b>with you in food</b> and <b>with you in drink?</b> All of the slave’s needs must be fulfilled, and his living conditions must be equal to those of the master himself. If so, he cannot be forced to work under unreasonable conditions. <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> in explanation of this <i>halakha</i>: <b>From here</b> it is derived <b>that his master may provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant</b> against his will to produce children for the master. This is the service he performs at night.
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Elazar, would say that this is no proof, because <b>if</b> it is derived <b>from there</b> alone <b>I would say: This matter applies</b> only <b>with his consent; but</b> as for his master forcing him to live with a maidservant <b>against his will, I would say no,</b> he cannot do this. Therefore, the term “to him” <b>teaches us</b> that the master can even provide him with a Canaanite maidservant against his will.
§ According to the above explanation, both Rabbi Elazar and the first <i>tanna</i> accept the verbal analogy between “hired worker” and “hired worker.” <b>Rather, who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who <b>does not derive</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker”? It is this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> as follows with regard to the verse: “He shall labor with you until the Jubilee Year, then he shall go out from you, he and his children with him, <b>and shall return to his own family</b> and to the possession of his fathers he shall return” (Leviticus 25:40–41). <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: What is the verse speaking of</b> when it states: “And shall return to his own family”? <b>If</b> it is speaking <b>of one who sold himself</b> and the Jubilee Year arrived during his six years of slavery, this <b>is already stated:</b> “He shall labor with you until the Jubilee Year, then he shall go out from you” (Leviticus 25:40).
<b>If</b> it is speaking <b>of a pierced</b> slave, it <b>is already stated,</b> as will be explained. It must be that <b>the verse is speaking of nothing other</b> than a man <b>sold by the court two or three years before the Jubilee</b> Year, and it teaches <b>that the Jubilee</b> Year <b>releases him</b> from slavery. The Gemara analyzes this opinion: <b>And if</b> it would <b>enter your mind</b> that Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov <b>derives</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,” why do I</b> need this verse? <b>Let him derive</b> that a man sold by the court is released in the Jubilee Year by the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,”</b> from the case of one who sold himself.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that this claim can be refuted: <b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov <b>derives</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker”</b> as well, <b>and</b> even so it <b>was necessary</b> for him to learn that <i>halakha</i> from a verse. The reason is that it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>one who sells himself, who did not commit a transgression,</b> is emancipated at the onset of the Jubilee Year even if six years have not passed, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>one sold by the court, who did commit a transgression,</b> as he was sold because he was unable to repay the value of his theft, one might <b>say</b> that <b>we should penalize him</b> and therefore he should not be emancipated in the Jubilee Year. Consequently, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that even this slave is emancipated in the Jubilee Year.
<b>The Master said</b> earlier, in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> it is speaking <b>about a pierced</b> slave, it <b>is already stated.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the verse that teaches that a pierced slave is released in the Jubilee Year? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states: <b>“And you shall return, each man to his land, and</b> you shall return, <b>each man to his family”</b> (Leviticus 25:10). <b>What is the verse speaking of? If</b> it is speaking <b>of one who sells himself,</b> it <b>is already stated:</b> “He shall labor with you until the Jubilee Year” (Leviticus 25:40).
<b>If</b> it is speaking <b>of one who was sold by the court,</b> it <b>is already stated:</b> “Then he shall go out from you, he and his children with him, and shall return to his own family” (Leviticus 25:41). It must be that <b>the verse is speaking of nothing other</b> than a slave <b>who is pierced two or three years before the Jubilee</b> Year, and <b>that the Jubilee</b> Year <b>releases him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred</b> that the verse is specifically referring to a pierced slave? <b>Rava bar Sheila said</b> that <b>the verse states “man.” What matter applies to a man and does not apply to a woman? You must say</b> that <b>this is piercing</b> a Hebrew slave’s ear with an awl.
The Gemara comments: <b>And it was necessary</b> for the Torah <b>to write</b> that <b>one sold by the court</b> leaves in the Jubilee Year, <b>and it was</b> also <b>necessary to write</b> the same with regard to <b>a pierced</b> slave, as neither case can be derived from the other. The Gemara elaborates: <b>As, if</b> the Torah had <b>informed us</b> only about <b>one who was sold by the court,</b> one might say that the Jubilee Year releases him <b>because his time had not come</b> to be freed. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a pierced</b> slave, <b>whose time had come</b> but he did not wish to be freed, one might <b>say</b> that <b>we should penalize him</b> and he should remain a permanent slave.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the Torah had <b>informed us</b> only about a <b>pierced</b> slave, one might say that the Jubilee Year releases him <b>because he has served</b> the master <b>for six</b> years, as required, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>one who was sold by the court,</b> who <b>has not</b> yet <b>served</b> his master <b>for six</b> years, one might <b>say</b> that he should <b>not</b> be freed in the Jubilee Year. Therefore, <b>it was necessary</b> for the Torah to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to both cases.
<b>And</b> likewise, <b>it was necessary</b> for the Torah <b>to write</b> with regard to the release of a pierced slave in the Jubilee Year: <b>“And you shall return,</b> each man to his land” (Leviticus 25:10), <b>and it was necessary to write</b> as well: “And he shall serve him <b>forever”</b> (Exodus 21:6), which is interpreted by the Sages as referring to until the Jubilee Year. <b>As, if the Merciful One</b> had <b>written</b> only <b>“forever,” I would say</b> that this <b>actually</b> means <b>forever,</b> i.e., for his entire life. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “And you shall return.”</b>
<b>And if the Merciful One</b> had <b>written</b> only <b>“and you shall return,” I would say</b> that <b>this statement applies</b> only <b>where he did not serve six</b> years after being pierced; <b>but</b> in a case <b>where he did serve six</b> years after he was pierced, one might argue as follows: <b>His final</b> stage, after he is pierced, <b>should not be stricter than his initial</b> stage, when he was first sold: <b>Just as</b> after <b>his initial</b> stage he serves only <b>six</b> years, <b>so too</b> in <b>his final</b> stage he serves only <b>six</b> years and no longer. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us “forever,”</b> which means <b>forever until the Jubilee</b> Year, even if the Jubilee Year arrives many years later. In any case, with regard to the issue at hand there is no proof that Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov does not derive the verbal analogy between “hired worker” and “hired worker.”
<b>Rather, who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who <b>does not derive</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker”? It is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 15b

A Hebrew slave sold to a gentile can be redeemed by his relatives, as it is stated: <b>“And if he is not redeemed by any of these,</b> then he shall go out in the Jubilee Year” (Leviticus 25:54). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He can be redeemed</b> only <b>through these,</b> i.e., the assistance of his relatives, <b>and he is not redeemed after six</b> years of labor.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi elaborates: <b>As I might have</b> argued that one sold to a gentile should be released after six years. Could this <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: If one who cannot be redeemed by these</b> relatives, i.e., a Hebrew slave who was sold to a Jew, as he cannot be redeemed by his rela-tives, nevertheless <b>is redeemed after six</b> years of labor, <b>is it not logical</b> that <b>this</b> Hebrew slave sold to a gentile, <b>who can be redeemed by these</b> relatives, <b>can</b> likewise <b>be redeemed after six</b> years of work? Therefore, <b>the verse states “by any of these,”</b> to emphasize that one sold to a gentile <b>can be redeemed</b> only <b>through these</b> relatives, <b>and he cannot be redeemed after six</b> years.
The Gemara explains the proof: <b>And if it enters your mind that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>derives</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,” why</b> does he <b>say: If one who cannot be redeemed by these,</b> with regard to one who is sold to a Jew? <b>Let him derive</b> that <i>halakha</i> from the case of one sold to a gentile, through the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker.”</b> The term “hired worker” is used in reference to one sold to a gentile as well: “As a hired worker year by year he shall be with him” (Leviticus 25:53), and accordingly one can say that even one sold to a Jew can be redeemed by his relatives. The fact that he does not accept this claim indicates that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi rejects the verbal analogy between “hired worker” and “hired worker.”
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This proof can be refuted, as one can say that <b>actually</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>does derive</b> the verbal analogy between <b>“hired worker”</b> and <b>“hired worker,” and it is different here,</b> with regard to one sold to a gentile, <b>as the verse states:</b> “Either his uncle or his uncle’s son <b>may redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:49). This emphasis of “him” teaches that redemption is an option only <b>for this</b> slave <b>and not for another</b> type of slave.
With regard to the dispute itself the Gemara inquires: <b>And who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who <b>disagrees with Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi with regard to this? It is <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning the verse: “And if <b>he is not redeemed by any of these”</b> (Leviticus 25:54), that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says:</b> The expression <b>“by any of these”</b> indicates that redemption by one’s relatives is <b>to freedom,</b> i.e., one becomes an entirely free man. But if a slave is redeemed <b>by anyone else</b> who pays the gentile master, it is <b>to slavery.</b> The redeemed slave becomes indentured to his redeemer until he repays the cost of his redemption through his work. <b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> the opposite: <b>By these</b> relatives he is redeemed <b>to slavery,</b> whereas if he is redeemed <b>by anyone else,</b> it is <b>to freedom.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? The verse states</b> concerning a redeemed slave who is emancipated: <b>“If he is not redeemed by any of these”</b> relatives; <b>but</b> if he is redeemed <b>by another, “then he shall go out in the Jubilee Year,”</b> not earlier, as he becomes enslaved to him. <b>And Rabbi Akiva says: “If he is not redeemed”</b> in any other manner but <b>only “by any of these,” “then he shall go out in the Jubilee Year,”</b> i.e., if he is redeemed by relatives, he is emancipated only at the close of Yom Kippur of the Jubilee Year. By contrast, if he is redeemed by others he is emancipated immediately. <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> respond to this claim? He would ask: <b>Is it written: Only by any of these?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> as this suggested interpretation of the verse by Rabbi Akiva is clearly problematic, the Gemara retracts the previous explanation of the dispute and instead says that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the precise meaning of <b>this verse:</b> “Either his uncle or his uncle’s son may redeem him, or any that is near of kin unto him of his family may redeem him; or if he becomes rich, and he is redeemed” (Leviticus 25:49). <b>“Either his uncle or his uncle’s son may redeem him”; this is the redemption</b> performed <b>by relatives. “Or if he becomes rich”</b>; <b>this is redemption</b> by <b>himself. “And he is redeemed”; this is redemption by other</b> people.
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains: A verse is interpreted homiletically</b> based on its juxtaposition to the verse immediately <b>preceding it.</b> Therefore, one should <b>cast,</b> i.e., compare, the case of <b>redemption</b> performed <b>by relatives to</b> the case of <b>redemption</b> performed <b>by himself: Just as redemption</b> performed <b>by himself</b> leads <b>to</b> complete <b>freedom, so too, redemption</b> performed <b>by relatives</b> leads <b>to freedom. And Rabbi Akiva maintains</b> that <b>a verse is interpreted homiletically</b> based on its juxtaposition to the verse immediately <b>after it.</b> Therefore one should <b>cast</b> the case of <b>redemption</b> performed <b>by others to</b> the case of <b>redemption</b> performed <b>by himself: Just as redemption</b> performed <b>by himself is to freedom, so too, redemption</b> performed <b>by others is to freedom,</b> whereas if he is redeemed by his relatives, he becomes enslaved to them.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that this is their dispute, <b>why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“by any of these,”</b> according to both Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it were <b>not</b> for the phrase <b>“by any of these,” I would say</b> that <b>a verse is interpreted homiletically</b> based on its juxtaposition to the verse immediately <b>preceding it as well as</b> to the verse immediately <b>after it, and</b> therefore in <b>every</b> manner in which he is redeemed it is <b>to freedom.</b> The phrase “by any of these” limits this freedom either to relatives or other people, according to the respective opinions of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that the different opinions are based on the phrase “by any of these,” then <b>the difficulty</b> with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, that the verse does not say: If he is not redeemed in any other manner but only by any of these, <b>has returned to its place,</b> i.e., it is still valid, as this phrase indicates that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s interpretation of the verse is correct. <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva <b>disagree with regard to reason.</b> Their dispute is a matter of logic and does not concern textual interpretation.
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains: It stands to reason</b> that <b>redemption</b> performed <b>by others</b> is <b>to slavery, as, if you say</b> it is <b>to freedom, they will refrain and will not redeem him.</b> If the slave is required to serve them, and they incur no financial loss, they will redeem him. <b>And Rabbi Akiva maintains: It stands to reason</b> that <b>redemption</b> performed <b>by relatives</b> is <b>to slavery, as, if you say</b> it is <b>to freedom, each and every day he will go and sell himself</b> over and again, relying on his relatives to free him.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Akiva,</b> who hold that a slave is not invariably freed whenever he is redeemed from his gentile master. <b>But the Rabbis say</b> that in <b>every</b> case, when he is emancipated it is <b>to freedom.</b>
The Gemara inquires: <b>Who</b> are these <b>Rabbis?</b> It is <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who derives another exposition from this</b> term <b>“by any of these,”</b> as stated above. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi maintains that <b>a verse is interpreted homiletically</b> based on its juxtaposition to the verse immediately <b>preceding it as well as</b> to the verse immediately <b>after it.</b> Consequently, the Hebrew slave of a gentile is emancipated regardless of whether he is redeemed by relatives or other people.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>what does he do with</b> the verse: “And if he is not redeemed by any of these means, <b>then he shall go out in the Jubilee Year”</b> (Leviticus 25:54)? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires</b> this verse <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“Then he shall go out in the Jubilee Year.”</b> If the slave is not redeemed prior to this point in time he leaves his gentile master only in the Jubilee Year.

Daf 16a

This indicates that the verse is stated <b>with regard to a gentile who is under your authority,</b> i.e., one who is subject to Jewish rule. <b>Or</b> perhaps you will say that the verse is stated <b>only with regard to a gentile who is not under your authority.</b> This is not possible, as <b>you say: But what can be done to him</b> to compel him to obey the Torah’s commands? Consequently, <b>the verse must be speaking of nothing other</b> than <b>a gentile who is under your authority.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: A Hebrew slave can be acquired by his master through money <b>or through a document.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that he can be acquired through a document? <b>Ulla said: The verse states</b> with regard to a Hebrew maidservant: <b>“If he takes himself another wife”</b> (Exodus 21:10). <b>The verse</b> thereby <b>juxtaposes</b> a Hebrew maidservant <b>to another</b> woman who is betrothed: <b>Just as another</b> woman <b>can be acquired</b> by her husband <b>through a document</b> (see 2a), <b>so too, a Hebrew maidservant can be acquired through a document.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that the <b>master writes the document</b> of a <b>Hebrew maidservant,</b> just as a betrothal document is written by the husband. <b>But according the one who says</b> that the <b>father writes it,</b> in the manner of a document of sale, <b>what can be said?</b> According to that opinion, the document of a Hebrew maidservant is not similar to a betrothal document. <b>As it was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed about this matter: With regard to <b>the document</b> of <b>a Hebrew maidservant, who writes it? Rav Huna says:</b> The <b>master writes it. Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The <b>father writes it. This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, but according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda, what can be said?</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from a different source. <b>The verse states</b> with regard to a Hebrew maidservant: <b>“She shall not go out as the men slaves do”</b> (Exodus 21:7). One can infer: <b>But she can be acquired in</b> the manner of <b>the acquisition of</b> Canaanite <b>male slaves. And what is</b> this mode of acquisition? It is <b>a document.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the inference should be a different one: <b>But she can be acquired in</b> the manner of <b>the acquisition of</b> Canaanite <b>male slaves, and what is</b> this mode of acquisition? It is <b>possession.</b> The Gemara answers that one cannot interpret that verse in this manner, as <b>the verse states</b> with regard to Canaanite slaves: <b>“And you shall bequeath them to your children after you”</b> (Leviticus 25:46), which indicates that you can acquire only <b>them,</b> i.e., Canaanite slaves, <b>through possession,</b> like an inherited tract of land, <b>but other</b> slaves <b>cannot</b> be acquired <b>through possession.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, one can equally <b>say</b> that <b>they,</b> Canaanite slaves, can be acquired <b>through a document, but others cannot</b> be acquired <b>through a document.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Isn’t it written: “She shall not go out as the men slaves do”</b> (Exodus 21:7), and this is explained to mean that she, like other slaves, can be acquired through a document. The Gemara asks: Since these two verses can be explained in either manner, <b>what did you see</b> that led you to compare a Hebrew maidservant to a Canaanite slave with regard to a document, and what led you to differentiate her from a Canaanite slave with regard to acquisition through possession? Perhaps the opposite should be the case, i.e., she is similar to a Canaanite slave with regard to possession and differs from him concerning acquisition through a document?
The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that <b>a document should be included</b> in the acquisition of a slave, <b>as</b> a document is powerful in that it can <b>release a Jewish woman,</b> in the form of a bill of divorce. The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>On the contrary, possession should be included, as it can effect acquisition</b> in the case <b>of the property of a convert</b> who died without leaving heirs, whereas no other mode can be used to acquire such property. The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, <b>with regard to marriage, in any event, one does not find</b> acquisition by means of possession. <b>If you wish, say</b> another answer: It is <b>to that end,</b> i.e., to determine in which way to compare a Hebrew maidservant to a Canaanite slave, that the verse <b>“if</b> he takes <b>another,” is effective,</b> as it indicates that the acquisition of a Hebrew maidservant includes a mode of acquisition used in betrothal, i.e., a document.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav Huna, what does he learn from this</b> verse: <b>“She shall not go out as the men slaves do”</b> (Exodus 21:7)? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires that</b> verse to teach <b>that she is not released on</b> account of an injury <b>to</b> the <b>extremities like</b> a Canaanite <b>slave.</b> If a master injures one of her limbs she is not emancipated, as explained in greater detail below. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav Ḥisda,</b> from where does he derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that it is teaching only one <i>halakha</i>, <b>let the verse write: She shall not go out as the men slaves. What</b> is the reason for the additional term <b>“as the men slaves do”? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it:</b> She is not freed due to injured limbs, and like a slave, she too can be acquired by means of a document.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> a Hebrew slave <b>can acquire himself after</b> six <b>years</b> of work. The Gemara cites the source for this <i>halakha</i>: <b>As it is written: “Six years he shall labor; and in the seventh</b> he shall go out free for nothing” (Exodus 21:2).
§ The mishna further states that a Hebrew slave is emancipated <b>in the Jubilee</b> Year. The Gemara explains that this is <b>as it is written: “He shall labor with you until the Jubilee Year”</b> (Leviticus 25:40).
§ The mishna teaches that a Hebrew slave can be freed <b>through the deduction of money. Ḥizkiyya says</b> that the reason is <b>that the verse states: “Then he shall let her be redeemed”</b> (Exodus 21:8), which <b>teaches that</b> if she acquires money and wishes to be emancipated before her time is complete, she <b>deducts</b> the value of the years that she has not yet worked from the cost of <b>her redemption, and is emancipated.</b> The same <i>halakha</i> applies to a slave. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught: And</b> a slave <b>can acquire himself with money, with</b> an item <b>worth money, and with a document.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted,</b> he can be acquired through <b>money, as it is written: “Out of the money that he was bought for”</b> (Leviticus 25:51). Likewise, it is <b>also</b> clear that he can be acquired with an item <b>worth money,</b> as <b>the Merciful One states: “He shall give back the price of his redemption”</b> (Leviticus 25:51), which serves <b>to include</b> an item of <b>monetary value,</b> which is considered <b>like money.</b> In other words, any item of value can be used to redeem a slave. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>this document</b> mentioned here, <b>what are the circumstances? If we say that</b> the slave <b>wrote</b> a promissory <b>note for his own money, that is</b> the same as <b>money.</b> What is the difference between the two cases?
<b>Rather,</b> this is referring to a document of <b>manumission</b> written by the master when the slave is emancipated. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a document</b> for this purpose? <b>Let him say in the presence of two</b> witnesses: <b>Go</b> free. <b>Alternatively,</b> let him say <b>before a court: Go</b> free. <b>Rava says: That is to say</b> that <b>the body of a Hebrew slave is owned</b> by his master, and this is not merely a monetary debt. <b>And</b> in the case of <b>a master who relinquishes his deduction,</b> i.e., the money that the slave must return for the years he has not yet served, <b>his deduction is not relinquished.</b> Although one can relinquish a monetary debt verbally, this is insufficient to release a slave whose body is owned by his master. A document is required to effect his freedom.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>a Hebrew maidservant has</b> one mode of emancipation <b>more than</b> a Hebrew slave, as she acquires herself through signs indicating puberty. <b>Reish Lakish says: A Hebrew maidservant acquires herself from the master’s authority through the death of</b> her <b>father.</b> This is derived <b>through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If signs</b> indicating puberty, <b>which do not release her from</b> her <b>father’s authority,</b> as, although she develops signs of puberty she remains under her father’s authority with regard to certain matters, nevertheless <b>release her from the master’s authority, is it not logical that death, which releases her</b> entirely <b>from</b> her <b>father’s authority,</b> should <b>release her from</b> her <b>master’s authority?</b>
<b>Rav Hoshaya raises an objection</b> from the mishna: <b>A Hebrew maidservant has</b> one mode of emancipation <b>more than</b> a Hebrew slave, <b>as she acquires herself through signs</b> indicating puberty. <b>And if it is so</b> that she also acquires herself through her father’s death, as claimed by Reish Lakish, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach also</b> that she is released through <b>the death of the father.</b> The Gemara answers: The absence of an explicit statement is not proof, as the mishna <b>taught</b> one difference between a male slave and a maidservant <b>and omitted</b> others.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> else <b>did he omit that he omitted this?</b> The <i>tanna</i> would certainly not leave out only one <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> <b>omitted the death of the master.</b> In the event of the master’s death, the Hebrew maidservant is emancipated and is not inherited by the master’s heirs. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>If</b> it is <b>due to the death of the master, that is not an omission.</b> The reason is <b>that since there is also</b> a similar <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a man,</b> i.e., a pierced slave, the mishna <b>does not teach</b> this case.
<b>But</b> if so, the question remains: <b>Rather, let it teach</b> that she is emancipated through the death of her father. The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> in the mishna <b>teaches a matter that has a set time,</b> and <b>he does not teach a matter that does not have a set time,</b> e.g., the death of her father.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> there is the case of <b>signs</b> indicating puberty, <b>which do not have a set time,</b> as young women exhibit these signs of puberty at different ages, <b>and</b> yet <b>it teaches</b> this mode of emancipation anyway. <b>Rav Safra says:</b> Admittedly, these signs <b>have no maximum set time,</b> as once she reaches the age of twelve she is emancipated whenever she develops these signs, <b>but they do have a set time</b>

Daf 16b

with regard to the <b>minimum</b> age at which these signs are taken into consideration. In other words, there is a lower limit, as any signs of puberty before a certain age are ignored.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Everyone agrees with regard to <b>a nine-year-old</b> boy <b>who developed two</b> pubic <b>hairs</b> that this is not considered a sign of adulthood, as they are treated as hairs that grow on <b>a mole. From</b> the age of <b>nine years and one day until</b> the age of <b>twelve years and one day,</b> even if <b>they are still on him</b> and have not fallen out, this is still considered <b>a mole. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> It is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty. If he is <b>thirteen years and one day old</b> and grows two hairs, <b>everyone agrees</b> that this is <b>a sign</b> indicating puberty.
<b>Rav Sheshet raises an objection:</b> It is taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> There are <b>four</b> different ways of emancipating slaves, and when they are emancipated <b>one grants them a severance gift.</b> Of these, <b>three</b> apply <b>to a man,</b> i.e., a Hebrew slave, <b>and three</b> apply <b>to a woman,</b> a Hebrew maidservant. <b>And you cannot say</b> that there are <b>four</b> ways <b>for</b> either <b>one</b> of them, <b>because there is no</b> emancipation through <b>signs</b> indicating puberty <b>for a man, and there is no</b> emancipation through <b>piercing</b> the ear <b>for a woman.</b> Consequently, there are only three modes of emancipation for each.
The Gemara clarifies the difficulty: <b>And if it is so</b> that a Hebrew maidservant acquires herself through her father’s death, as claimed by Reish Lakish, <b>let him teach also</b> that a Hebrew maidservant is emancipated at <b>the death of the father. And if you would say, here too he taught</b> some differences between a Hebrew slave and a Hebrew maidservant <b>and omitted</b> others, this cannot be the case, as <b>he teaches:</b> There are <b>four</b> ways of emancipating slaves. The mention of a number indicates that there is a set number of ways. <b>And if you would say</b> that the <b><i>tanna</i> teaches a matter that has a set time and does not teach a matter that does not have a set time, as</b> there is the <i>halakha</i> of <b>signs</b> indicating puberty, <b>which do not have a set time, and</b> nevertheless <b>he teaches</b> it.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here, too,</b> this is <b>in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rav Safra,</b> that signs have a minimum set time, <b>there is still the death of the master,</b> which <b>does not have a set time, and</b> yet he <b>taught</b> it. The Gemara answers: <b>The death of the master is not taught either,</b> i.e., this mode of emancipation is not counted among the four modes mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if you do not count the death of the master, <b>what are these four</b> methods? The Gemara answers: A Hebrew slave or maidservant is emancipated after serving six <b>years and</b> in <b>the Jubilee</b> Year, even if it occurs within those six years. <b>And the Jubilee</b> Year also emancipates a slave, even <b>after</b> the act of <b>piercing</b> a Hebrew slave’s ear with an awl extended his term of slavery, <b>and a Hebrew maidservant</b> is emancipated <b>with signs</b> indicating puberty.
The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> that this is the correct interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>as it teaches in the last clause: You cannot say</b> that there are <b>four</b> modes <b>for</b> either <b>one of them, because there is no</b> emancipation through <b>signs</b> indicating puberty <b>for a man, and there is no</b> emancipation through <b>piercing for a woman. And if it is so</b> that the death of the master is included, in the case <b>of a woman, at least, you find four</b> ways that she can be freed: Six years of service, the Jubilee Year, signs of puberty, and the death of the master. The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that it is so.
<b>Rav Amram</b> also <b>raises an objection</b> against the opinion of Reish Lakish from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And these</b> are the slaves <b>to whom one grants a severance gift: One who leaves through</b> six <b>years</b> of service, <b>and</b> one who leaves <b>in the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>and</b> one who leaves <b>through the death of the master, and a Hebrew maidservant</b> who is released <b>by signs</b> indicating puberty. <b>And if it is so</b> that she is emancipated through her father’s death as well, as claimed by Reish Lakish, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>also teach</b> that she is released through <b>the death of the father. And if you would say, here too, he taught</b> some differences between a Hebrew slave and maidservant <b>and omitted</b> others, <b>he teaches: These,</b> which indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to a slave freed in these ways and no others.
<b>And if you would say</b> that the <b><i>tanna</i> teaches a matter that has a set time and does not teach a matter that does not have a set time, but</b> isn’t there the case of <b>signs</b> indicating puberty, <b>which do not have a set time, and</b> nevertheless <b>he teaches</b> it. <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here too,</b> this is <b>in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rav Safra</b> that signs have a minimum set time, <b>there is the death of the master,</b> which <b>does not have a set time, and</b> yet <b>he taught</b> it. Therefore, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>The refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish is</b> indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the ruling of <b>Reish Lakish</b> is based on <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, and nothing has been said to contradict his reasoning. The Gemara answers: <b>The <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>is refutable, because</b> it <b>can be refuted</b> in the following manner: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about signs</b> indicating puberty is that they indicate <b>that her body has changed,</b> and perhaps she is emancipated because she is now considered a different person. <b>Will you say</b> the same <b>with regard to the death of the father, as</b> her <b>body has not changed?</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>The severance gift</b> bestowed upon <b>a Hebrew slave</b> when he is emancipated is given <b>to</b> the slave <b>himself, and the severance gift</b> bestowed upon <b>a Hebrew maidservant</b> is given <b>to</b> the maidservant <b>herself. And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The <b>severance gift of a Hebrew maidservant and</b> any <b>lost items</b> she finds belong <b>to her father, and her master has only</b> the <b>reimbursement for her lost time.</b> He is paid the money he would have earned if she had been working instead of carrying home the items she found.
The Gemara suggests: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that the difference between the two <i>baraitot</i> is that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which says that the severance gift is given to her father, is referring to <b>when she leaves through signs</b> indicating puberty, as she is a young woman and still under the authority of her father with regard to certain matters, <b>and this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which states that the severance gift is given to her, is referring to a case <b>when she leaves through the death of the father.</b> Since she does not have a father she keeps the severance gift herself. This explanation is in accordance with the opinion of Reish Lakish, that she is emancipated through the death of her father, and it contradicts the conclusion that his ruling should be rejected.
The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>No,</b> both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are referring to a maidservant <b>who left through signs</b> indicating puberty, <b>and it</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where there is a father</b> who can take the gift, and <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where there is no father,</b> i.e., he died before she developed the signs of puberty. In that case she receives the severance gift herself.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted,</b> one can understand the <i>baraita</i> that taught that the <b>severance gift of a Hebrew maidservant</b> is <b>for herself,</b> as this serves <b>to exclude</b> the maidservant’s <b>brothers.</b> These brothers do not receive the gifts after her father’s death, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And you shall bequeath them to your children after you”</b> (Leviticus 25:46). This verse indicates that <b>they,</b> Canaanite slaves, are bequeathed <b>to your sons, but your daughters</b> are <b>not</b> bequeathed <b>to your sons. From here</b> it is derived <b>that a person may not bequeath</b> his <b>rights to</b> profits generated by <b>his daughter to his son.</b>
<b>But it is obvious</b> that <b>the severance gift of a Hebrew slave is for himself. Rather, to whom</b> could it be given? <b>Rav Yosef said: I see here</b> a small letter <b><i>yod</i></b> that has been made into a large <b>city.</b> In other words, although it was not necessary for the <i>tanna</i> to teach this <i>halakha</i>, he stated it out of habit despite the fact that this ruling does not teach anything novel.
<b>Abaye said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said like this:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of the Sage <b>Tutai. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Tutai says:</b> The verse: “You shall grant severance <b>to him”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:14), indicates that it is given to a Hebrew slave <b>but not to his creditor.</b> Even if the slave owes money, this gift is not given to the creditor.
The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. And these</b> are the Hebrew slaves <b>to whom one grants a severance gift: One who leaves through</b> completing six <b>years</b> of service, <b>and</b> one who leaves <b>in the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>and</b> one who leaves <b>through the death of the master, and a Hebrew maidservant</b> who is released <b>by signs</b> indicating the onset of puberty. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>one who flees</b> from his master <b>or one who is released by deducting money, one does not grant a severance gift to him. Rabbi Meir says:</b> With regard to <b>one who flees, one does not grant a severance gift to him, but</b> in the case of <b>one who is released by deducting money, one does grant a severance gift to him.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> There are <b>four</b> different ways of emancipating a Hebrew slave, and when Hebrew slaves are emancipated <b>one grants them a severance gift.</b> Of these methods, <b>three</b> apply <b>to a man and three</b> apply <b>to a woman. And you cannot say four</b> modes apply <b>for</b> either <b>one</b> of them, <b>because there is no</b> emancipation through <b>signs</b> indicating puberty <b>for a man, and there is no piercing for a woman.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? The Gemara explains that this is <b>as the Sages taught:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one grants a severance gift only to</b> a Hebrew slave <b>who is released after six</b> years. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> that one grants a severance gift to one who <b>left in the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>and</b> one freed <b>through the death of the master, and a Hebrew maidservant</b> who leaves <b>through signs</b> indicating puberty? <b>The verse states:</b> “You shall not <b>send him,”</b> and: <b>“And when you send him”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:13). These phrases serve to expand the <i>halakha</i> of severance to include any Hebrew slave who is emancipated.
I <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include</b> a Hebrew slave <b>who flees and</b> one <b>who is released through the deduction of money.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And when you send him free from you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:13), which is referring to <b>one who was sent from you</b> with your knowledge and consent. This <b>excludes</b> a Hebrew slave <b>who flees</b> from his master <b>and</b> one who <b>is released through the deduction of money, who are not sent away from you</b> with your permission. <b>Rabbi Meir says: One does not grant a severance gift to</b> a Hebrew slave <b>who flees, as he is not sent away from you,</b> because he left on his own. <b>But</b> with regard to a Hebrew slave who <b>is released through the deduction of money, who is sent from you,</b> he is granted a severance gift, as this deduction payment requires the agreement of the master.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t a Hebrew slave <b>who flees required to complete</b> the remaining years of his contract, at which point he should be entitled to receive a severance gift? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived with regard to a Hebrew slave <b>who flees</b> his master <b>that he is obligated to complete</b> his term? <b>The verse states: “Six years he shall labor”</b> (Exodus 21:2), and no less. Therefore, if a Hebrew slave runs away in the middle of this period, he is required to complete his six years of service.

Daf 17a

One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> a slave who <b>became sick</b> and is unable to work must work additional time to compensate for the time missed. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And in the seventh he shall go out”</b> (Exodus 21:2), which indicates that he leaves his master in any case, even if he has not worked the full six years.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: With what are we dealing here?</b> This concerns a case <b>where he fled and the Jubilee</b> Year <b>arrived</b> immediately afterward, and therefore he did not complete the six years of servitude. The novelty of this <i>halakha</i> is as follows. <b>Lest you say: Since the Jubilee</b> Year <b>released him, he is considered sent away by you,</b> the master, <b>and</b> therefore <b>we should not penalize him but grant him the severance gift,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that once he flees he forfeits his right to the severance gift.
<b>The Master said</b> above: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> a slave who <b>became sick</b> and was unable to work must work additional time to compensate for the time missed. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And in the seventh he shall go out”</b> (Exodus 21:2). The Gemara asks: Is he excused from working additional time <b>even</b> if <b>he was sick for all six</b> years? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he was sick</b> for <b>three</b> years <b>and served</b> for <b>three</b> years, <b>he is not obligated to complete</b> the six years of actual labor, but if <b>he was sick</b> for <b>all six</b> years <b>he is obligated to complete</b> the six years of actual labor. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is referring to a case where he is unable to perform strenuous labor but can execute minor tasks, such <b>as performing needlework</b> or sewing clothes. Since he can perform work of some kind, this slave is not required to work additional time to compensate for the time missed, even if he was ill for all six years.
The Gemara comments: <b>This matter itself is difficult,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> is apparently self-contradictory. On the one hand, <b>you said</b> that if <b>he was sick for three</b> years <b>and he served for</b> the other <b>three</b> years <b>he is not obligated to complete</b> the six years of actual labor. <b>This</b> indicates that if he was ill for <b>four</b> years <b>he is obligated to complete</b> the six years of labor. On the other hand, <b>say the last clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he was sick</b> for <b>all six</b> years <b>he is obligated to complete</b> the six years of actual labor. <b>That</b> indicates that if he was ill for <b>four</b> years <b>he is not obligated to complete</b> the six years of actual labor. The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>he was sick</b> for <b>four</b> years <b>he becomes as one who was sick for all six</b> years, <b>and</b> therefore <b>he is required to complete</b> the six years of actual labor.
§ <b>The Sages taught: How much does one grant</b> a freed slave as <b>a severance gift?</b> It is <b>five <i>sela</i></b> in value <b>of each and every type</b> mentioned in this verse: “And you shall grant severance to him out of your flock, and out of your threshing floor, and out of your winepress” (Deuteronomy 15:14), <b>which is</b> a total of <b>fifteen <i>sela</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> He is given <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i> in total, <b>like the thirty</b> shekels <b>of</b> the fine that is paid for <b>a slave</b> (see Exodus 21:32). <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The master gives him <b>fifty</b> shekels, <b>like</b> the sum <b>of valuations,</b> in which fifty shekels is the largest designated amount for a man (see Leviticus 27:3).
<b>The Master said</b> above: The master gives <b>five <i>sela</i> of each and every type, which is fifteen <i>sela</i>;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi Meir come to teach us</b> to <b>count?</b> His novelty certainly cannot be that three fives equal fifteen. The Gemara answers that Rabbi Meir <b>teaches us this:</b> The master may <b>not</b> give <b>less than this</b> total <b>number, but if he gives him less of one type and more of one</b> other <b>type, we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> and he has fulfilled the mitzva.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Meir?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>He derives</b> a verbal analogy from <b>“empty”</b> stated with regard to the severance gift: “You shall not send him away empty” (Deuteronomy 15:13), and <b>“empty”</b> stated <b>with regard to a firstborn:</b> “All the firstborn of your sons you shall redeem; and none shall appear before Me empty” (Exodus 34:20). <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of the firstborn, one must give <b>five <i>sela</i>, so too here,</b> in the case of severance gifts, one must give <b>five <i>sela</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that he is obligated to give only <b>five <i>sela</i></b> in total <b>from all of</b> the three types listed in the verse. The Gemara answers: <b>If “empty” were written at the end</b> of the verse, i.e., Deuteronomy 15:14, the <i>halakha</i> would be <b>as you said.</b> But <b>now that “empty” is written before</b> the verse, i.e., at the end of Deuteronomy 15:13, <b>apply</b> the phrase “Do not send him away <b>empty” to “flock,”</b> and apply <b>“empty” to “threshing floor,”</b> and likewise apply <b>“empty” to “winepress.”</b> Consequently, there must be five <i>sela</i> for each type.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us derive</b> a verbal analogy between <b>“empty”</b> and <b>“empty” from</b> the case of <b>the burnt-offering of appearance</b> in the Temple brought on the pilgrimage Festivals, with regard to which it is said: “And they shall not appear before the Lord empty” (Deuteronomy 16:16). The burnt-offering of appearance has no fixed value. The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “Of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:14), which indicates that one must give a respectable amount as a severance gift.
The <i>baraita</i> states that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that a freed slave is given <b>thirty</b> <i>sela</i> in total, <b>like the thirty</b> shekels of the fine that is paid <b>for a slave.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> a verbal analogy between <b>giving,</b> as stated with regard to the severance gift, <b>from</b> the expression of <b>giving</b> stated in connection to a Canaanite <b>slave</b> gored by an ox: “He shall give to their master thirty shekels of silver” (Exodus 21:32). <b>Just as there,</b> he must pay <b>thirty</b> shekels for the slave, <b>so too here,</b> in the case of a severance gift, he must pay <b>thirty.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But let him derive</b> a similar verbal analogy between <b>“giving”</b> stated with regard to the severance gift and <b>“giving” from valuations</b> (see Leviticus 27:23): <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of valuations, it is <b>fifty</b> shekels for an adult male, <b>so too here,</b> it should be <b>fifty.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>One</b> answer is, as people say, <b>that if you grasped too much, you did not grasp anything; if you grasped a bit, you grasped</b> something. In other words, if there are two possible sources from which to derive the sum of the severance gift, then without conclusive proof one may not presume that the Torah intended to teach the larger amount. Consequently, the master should be required to give only thirty shekels, not fifty. <b>And furthermore, one should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of a slave,</b> i.e., the severance gift, <b>from</b> another case involving <b>a slave,</b> i.e., the thirty shekels paid when a Canaanite slave is gored by an ox, rather than derive the <i>halakha</i> of the severance gift from valuations, which apply to all people.
The <i>baraita</i> further teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The master gives him <b>fifty</b> shekels, <b>like the fifty</b> shekels <b>of valuations</b> for an adult male. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon? He derived</b> a verbal analogy between <b>“giving”</b> and <b>“giving” from valuations</b> (Leviticus 27:23): <b>Just as there,</b> he pays <b>fifty, so too here,</b> he pays <b>fifty.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that as this verbal analogy is referring to valuations in general, he should pay <b>the smallest of the valuations,</b> which is merely three <i>sela</i>. The Gemara answers that <b>it is written: “Of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:14), which indicates that one must give a respectable amount as a severance gift.
The Gemara asks: <b>But let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>derive,</b> like Rabbi Yehuda, the verbal analogy between <b>“giving”</b> and <b>“giving” from</b> the verses discussing the goring of a Canaanite <b>slave,</b> teaching that <b>just as there</b> he pays <b>thirty, so too here,</b> he pays <b>thirty?</b> The Gemara adds that there are two reasons to prefer this derivation, as stated above: <b>One</b> reason is <b>that if you grasped too much, you did not grasp anything; if you grasped a bit, you grasped</b> something. <b>And furthermore, one should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of a slave from</b> another case involving <b>a slave.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Shimon derives</b> a verbal analogy between <b>poverty</b> and <b>poverty.</b> With regard to valuations the Torah states: “But if he is too poor” (Leviticus 27:8), and concerning a Hebrew slave the verse says: “And if your brother grows poor” (Leviticus 25:39).
Having ascertained the source for each of the opinions in the <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara analyzes their opinions. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, this is as it is written “flock,” “threshing floor,” and “winepress,”</b> as he derives from these three terms that the severance gift must be worth fifteen <i>sela</i>. <b>But according to</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, why do I</b> need <b>these</b> terms <b>“flock,” “threshing floor,” and “winepress,”</b> in light of the fact that one may give his slave any product?
The Gemara answers: <b>These</b> terms <b>are necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one grants severance gifts only</b> from <b>the flock, the threshing floor, and the winepress; from where</b> is it derived <b>to include every matter? The verse states: “Of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:14). <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “flock,” “threshing floor,” and “winepress”?</b> This serves <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as a flock, a threshing floor, and a winepress are unique in that they are included in</b> the category of <b>blessing,</b> i.e., they grow and multiply, <b>so too all</b> items <b>that are included in</b> the category of <b>blessing</b> may be given as a severance gift. This <b>excludes money,</b> which does not increase on its own. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> This <b>excludes mules,</b> which cannot reproduce.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Shimon,</b> why does he exclude money but not mules? The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>mules, their bodies</b> grow and <b>enhance.</b> Although they do not reproduce, they still grow. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> why doesn’t he exclude money? He maintains that <b>one can conduct business with money</b> and thereby profit from it. In this manner money can increase.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it is necessary</b> for the Torah to mention a flock, a threshing floor, and a winepress, <b>as, if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>“flock,” I would say</b> that <b>animals, yes,</b> the master may give them to his slave upon his release, but that which <b>grows from the ground, no,</b> he may not give them. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes “threshing floor.” And if</b> the Torah <b>had written</b> only <b>“threshing floor,” I would say</b> that that which <b>grows from the ground, yes,</b> he may give them, but <b>animals, no,</b> he may not give them. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes “flock.”</b> The Gemara asks: Since threshing floor is stated, <b>why do I</b> need the mention of <b>a winepress?</b>

Daf 17b

The Gemara answers: According <b>to</b> one <b>Master,</b> Rabbi Shimon, this term serves <b>to exclude money.</b> According <b>to</b> the other <b>Master,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, it serves <b>to exclude mules.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to the verse: “And you shall grant severance to him out of your flock, and out of your threshing floor, and out of your winepress, <b>of that with which the Lord your God has blessed you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:14). One <b>might</b> have thought that if the <b>house is blessed due to him,</b> then the master <b>grants him a severance gift,</b> and if the <b>house is not blessed due to him,</b> he <b>does not grant him a severance gift.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall grant severance [<i>ha’anek ta’anik</i>],”</b> with the doubled form of the verb used for emphasis, to indicate that you must grant him a severance gift <b>in any case. If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Of that with which</b> the Lord your God <b>has blessed you”?</b> This teaches that <b>all</b> that one <b>gives him</b> as a severance gift should be <b>in accordance with the blessing</b> one possesses.
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b> The meaning of the <b>statements</b> of the Torah is <b>as they are written,</b> i.e., as indicated by a straightforward reading of the verse. Therefore, if <b>the house was blessed due to him,</b> the master <b>grants him a severance gift,</b> and if <b>the house was not blessed due to him,</b> he <b>does not grant him a severance gift</b> at all. <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “You shall grant severance [<i>ha’anek ta’anik</i>],”</b> with the doubled form of the verb? <b>The Torah spoke in the language of people,</b> i.e., the emphasis of the doubled verb is merely stylistic, but does not serve to teach a novel <i>halakha</i>.
§ <b>The Sages taught: A Hebrew slave serves the son</b> of his deceased master <b>but does not serve the daughter. A Hebrew maidservant serves neither the son nor the daughter,</b> but only the master. <b>A pierced</b> slave <b>and</b> a Hebrew slave <b>sold to a gentile serve neither the son nor the daughter. The Master said</b> above: <b>A Hebrew slave serves the son but does not serve the daughter.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived?
<b>As the Sages taught,</b> with regard to a verse that deals with a Hebrew slave: <b>“And he shall serve you six years”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:12). This indicates that he serves <b>you and not an heir,</b> i.e., if the master dies his slave does not serve one who inherits his estate. Do <b>you say: You and not an heir, or</b> perhaps <b>is it even: You and not a son?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When it says: “Six years he shall labor”</b> (Exodus 21:2), which does not indicate any exclusion, the inclusion of <b>a son is</b> thereby <b>stated. How</b> then <b>do I uphold</b> the other verse: <b>“And he shall serve you six years”?</b> The expression “serve you” emphasizes that he serves only <b>you but</b> he does <b>not</b> serve <b>an heir</b> other than a son.
The Gemara asks: <b>What did you see</b> that led you <b>to include the son</b> who inherits a Hebrew slave <b>and to exclude the brother</b> from inheriting his brother’s slave? The Gemara answers: <b>I include the son, as he stands in place of his father to designate her.</b> Just as a father can designate a Hebrew maidservant as a wife for himself, so too can he betroth her on behalf of his son. <b>And</b> similarly, he replaces his father with regard <b>to an ancestral field</b> (see Leviticus 27:16–21). If one redeems a field consecrated by his father, it is considered as though the father himself had redeemed it, which means that the field returns to the family in the Jubilee Year. If someone else redeems the field, including a brother, it does not return to the family.
The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary, I</b> should <b>include the brother, as he stands in his brother’s place with regard to levirate marriage.</b> The Gemara responds: This is insufficient proof, as <b>is there levirate marriage other</b> than <b>in a case when there is no son?</b> If <b>there is a son, there is no levirate marriage.</b> This indicates that a son replaces the deceased before a brother, even with regard to levirate marriage.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, the reason for</b> this <i>halakha</i> is specifically that <b>there is this refutation</b> that a levirate marriage applies only when there is no son. Does that not indicate that <b>without this</b> consideration I would say that <b>a brother is preferable</b> to a son? <b>But let me derive</b> that a son has a greater claim of standing in place of his father than a brother <b>from</b> the fact that <b>here,</b> with regard to the preference of a son, there are <b>two</b> cases: Designation of a Hebrew maidservant and an ancestral field, <b>and here,</b> in the case of a brother, there is only <b>one:</b> Levirate marriage.
The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>an ancestral field too, the <i>tanna</i> derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>from this</b> same <b>refutation.</b> The <i>tanna</i> learns from the case of levirate marriage that only the son, not the brother, takes the place of his father for the redemption of the field, employing the same reasoning mentioned above: <b>Is there levirate marriage other</b> than <b>in a case when there is no son?</b> Therefore, without this consideration there is only one supporting example for each claim.
§ The <i>baraita</i> taught that <b>a Hebrew maidservant serves neither the brother nor the daughter.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Padda said: As the verse states</b> with regard to a pierced Hebrew slave: <b>“And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:17). <b>The verse juxtaposes</b> a Hebrew maidservant <b>to a pierced</b> slave: <b>Just as a pierced</b> slave <b>serves neither the son nor the daughter, so too a Hebrew maidservant serves neither the son nor the daughter.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>this</b> verse: <b>“And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise,” come</b> to teach <b>this</b> matter? The <i>tanna</i> <b>requires it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that the verse: <b>“And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise,”</b> is a command <b>to grant</b> her <b>a severance gift.</b>
Do <b>you say</b> that this comparison obligates one <b>to grant a severance gift</b> to a Hebrew maidservant, <b>or is it</b> teaching <b>only</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>piercing</b> a Hebrew slave’s ear with an awl, which is stated immediately beforehand, applies to a Hebrew maidservant as well? The Gemara explains: <b>When it says</b> with regard to piercing: <b>“But if the slave shall say”</b> (Exodus 21:5), which indicates that a Hebrew slave can issue this declaration <b>but a Hebrew maidservant cannot,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>piercing is</b> thereby <b>stated</b> and accounted for.
<b>How do I realize</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And also to your maidservant you shall do likewise”?</b> This obligates a master <b>to grant a severance gift</b> to a freed Hebrew maidservant. If so, one cannot derive from this verse that a Hebrew maidservant serves neither the son nor the daughter. The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that it comes only to compare her to a pierced Hebrew slave, <b>let the verse write</b> merely: <b>To your maidservant likewise. What</b> is the meaning of the additional phrase: <b>“You shall do”? Draw two conclusions from</b> this: A Hebrew maidservant does not serve the son, and she is granted severance gifts.
§ The <i>baraita</i> further teaches that <b>a pierced</b> Hebrew slave <b>and one sold to a gentile serve neither the son nor the daughter.</b> The Gemara explains: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>a pierced</b> slave is <b>as it is written: “And his master shall pierce his ear with an awl, and he shall serve him forever”</b> (Exodus 21:6), which indicates that he serves this master, <b>but not the son or the daughter.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to a Hebrew slave <b>sold to a gentile? Ḥizkiyya says</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the emancipating of a slave who was sold to a gentile: <b>“And he shall reckon with his purchaser”</b> (Leviticus 25:50), which teaches that this applies only to his purchaser <b>but not to the heirs of his purchaser.</b>
<b>Rava says: By Torah law a gentile inherits</b> the property of <b>his father, as it is stated</b> with regard to one sold to a gentile: <b>“And he shall reckon with his purchaser,” but not with his purchaser’s heirs.</b> One can derive from here <b>by inference</b> that ordinarily a gentile <b>has heirs.</b> By contrast, <b>by Torah law a convert does not</b> inherit the property of his father or any other <b>gentile,</b> as once he converts he is considered a new person with no ties to his previous family. <b>Rather,</b> a convert inherits the property of his father <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 6:10): With regard to <b>a convert and a gentile who inherited</b> property <b>from their gentile father, the convert can say to the gentile: You take</b> the objects of <b>idol worship and I</b> will take <b>money; you take wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> to idolatry <b>and I</b> will take <b>produce.</b> Provided that these objects have not entered the domain of the convert, he may divide everything with his brother so that his brother takes as an inheritance the items that the convert is prohibited from using as a Jew. But <b>once they have come into the convert’s possession,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for him to exchange these objects with his brother, as he would thereby be benefiting from idolatry.
<b>And if it would enter your mind</b> that a convert inherits property from his father <b>by Torah law, it</b> should be prohibited <b>when</b> these objects <b>have not</b> yet <b>come into his possession as well,</b> as <b>when he takes</b> money or produce and gives the idols to the gentile, <b>he takes</b> an item that has been <b>exchanged for</b> objects of <b>idol worship.</b> Since he receives half the inheritance at the moment when his father dies, he has a share in these items as well.
<b>Rather,</b> a convert inherits property from his father <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as this is <b>a decree that the Sages instituted lest he return to his</b> previous <b>wayward path [<i>suro</i>].</b> The Sages were concerned that due to his concern over losing his inheritance, a convert might return to his gentile lifestyle. In any event, as he does not inherit his father’s property by Torah law, the idols are not considered his property. <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> He may do this <b>when they inherited. But when</b> the convert and the gentile <b>formed a partnership, it is prohibited</b> for him to divide the property so that the gentile takes the idols, as the convert benefits from them indirectly.
With regard to the same issue it is taught: <b>By Torah law and by rabbinic law a gentile does not</b> inherit property <b>from</b> his father who is <b>a convert, nor</b> does <b>a convert</b> inherit property <b>from</b> his father who is <b>a convert. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 10:9): If one <b>borrowed money from a convert whose sons converted with him,</b> and therefore when they converted there were no longer any legal ties between the sons and the father, <b>he does not return</b> it <b>to</b> the creditor’s <b>sons,</b> as they are not considered his heirs. <b>And if he</b> does <b>return</b> it, <b>the Sages are not pleased with him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>the Sages are pleased with him?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> it is referring to a convert <b>whose conception and birth were not in sanctity</b> of the Jewish people, i.e., his father was a gentile when he was born and afterward the son converted. In this case there are no legal ties between the father and the son, and therefore one who owes money to the father is not required to pay the son.

Daf 18a

<b>And here</b> it is referring to a case <b>where he was not conceived in sanctity,</b> i.e., his mother conceived him before she converted, <b>and</b> only <b>his birth was in sanctity,</b> as she converted when pregnant. It is appropriate to return money to this individual.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin</b> says that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: By Torah law a gentile inherits</b> from <b>his father, as it is written: “Because I have given mount Seir to Esau as an inheritance”</b> (Deuteronomy 2:5). The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> it <b>is different</b> with regard to <b>an apostate Jew?</b> In other words, it is possible that Esau was not considered a gentile but rather Jewish, like the Patriarchs. Consequently, he is categorized as an apostate Jew. <b>Rather,</b> the proof is <b>from here: “Because I have given Ar to the children of Lot as an inheritance”</b> (Deuteronomy 2:9), and the descendants of Lot were certainly gentiles.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin, what is the reason</b> that he <b>did not state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rava,</b> who derives the inheritance of gentiles from the verse: “And he shall reckon with his purchaser” (Leviticus 25:50)? The Gemara answers: <b>Is it written</b> explicitly in the Torah: <b>And he shall reckon with his purchaser and not with the heirs of his purchaser?</b> This proof is based on an exposition, not on an explicit source.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And Rava, what is the reason</b> that he <b>did not state</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin?</b> The Gemara answers: Perhaps <b>due to the honor of Abraham</b> it <b>is different.</b> It is possible that for the sake of Abraham an inheritance was given to the members of his family. The same may not apply to gentiles in general.
§ <b>The Sages taught: There are</b> details <b>of</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a Hebrew</b> slave <b>that do not</b> apply <b>to</b> the case of <b>a Hebrew</b> maidservant and <b>there are</b> details <b>of</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a Hebrew</b> maidservant <b>that do not</b> apply <b>to a Hebrew</b> slave. The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>There are</b> unique details <b>in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of emancipating <b>a Hebrew</b> slave, <b>as he leaves through</b> serving a term of six <b>years, and</b> he leaves <b>through the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>and</b> he leaves <b>through the death of the master, which is not the case for a Hebrew</b> maidservant. <b>And there are</b> unique details <b>in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of emancipating <b>a Hebrew</b> maidservant, <b>as a Hebrew</b> maidservant <b>leaves through signs</b> indicating puberty, <b>and</b> she is <b>not sold for a second time, and one can redeem her against his will,</b> as the Gemara will explain, <b>which is not the case for a Hebrew</b> slave.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> above: <b>There are</b> details <b>of</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of emancipating <b>a Hebrew</b> slave <b>that do not</b> apply <b>to</b> the case of <b>a Hebrew</b> maidservant. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the mishna: <b>A Hebrew maidservant has</b> one mode of emancipation <b>more than him, as she acquires herself through signs</b> indicating puberty. The expression: More than him, indicates that all of the modes through which a Hebrew slave can be freed apply to a Hebrew maidservant as well. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the master <b>designated her</b> to marry him during the six years. Consequently, she cannot be released from his authority by all of the modes through which a Hebrew slave can be freed, as she is his wife.
The Gemara asks: If <b>he designated her, it is obvious</b> that she cannot be released in the manner of a slave, as she is his wife and therefore <b>requires a bill of divorce.</b> The Gemara says: It is necessary to state this explicitly, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>the</b> primary <b><i>halakha</i> is not nullified with regard to her,</b> i.e., even after she has been designated she can still be freed as a slave would be, without a bill of divorce. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that this is referring to a case where he designated her, <b>why does she leave through signs</b> indicating puberty? If he designated her she becomes his wife, and signs indicating the onset of puberty should not affect her status. The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: If he did not designate her, she leaves also through signs</b> indicating puberty.
§ The <i>baraita</i> teaches: <b>And</b> a Hebrew maidservant is <b>not sold a second time.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>From the fact</b> that the <i>baraita</i> says this about a Hebrew maidservant, it can be inferred that <b>a Hebrew slave can be sold a second time. But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse: “And he is sold <b>for his theft”</b> (Exodus 22:2), means that he can be sold to pay for the items that he has stolen <b>but not</b> to pay <b>for his double payment?</b> Although one can be sold into slavery to reimburse the owner for the principal of his theft, he cannot be sold to pay the fine.
