Furthermore, <b>“for his theft”</b> indicates: <b>But not</b> to pay <b>for his conspiring testimony.</b> If he is a conspiring witness, who is required to pay the value of what he testified that another had stolen but he does not have the money to do so, he is not sold as a slave. Additionally, the phrase <b>“for his theft”</b> teaches that he can be sold for stealing only once, and <b>once he has been sold one time you may not sell him again.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, it is referring <b>to one theft,</b> i.e., he stole a large amount but he is not worth enough as a slave for the proceeds of his sale to repay his entire debt. In that case he cannot be sold a second time. <b>There,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to <b>two thefts,</b> as he may be sold a second time if he stole once, was sold, and subsequently stole again.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: The expression <b>“for his theft” indicates</b> even <b>many</b> thefts. <b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, it is referring <b>to</b> one who stole from <b>one person.</b> This thief cannot be sold a second time even for several thefts. <b>There,</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>, it is referring <b>to</b> thefts from <b>two people.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If the <b>property he stole</b> was worth <b>one thousand and</b> as a slave he <b>is worth</b> only <b>five hundred, he is sold and sold again.</b> If the <b>property he stole</b> was worth <b>five hundred</b> and he <b>is worth one thousand, he is not sold at all. Rabbi Eliezer says: If</b> the <b>property he stole was</b> exactly <b>equal to</b> his value if he were <b>sold, he is sold; and if not, he is not sold.</b>
<b>Rava said: In this</b> case <b>Rabbi Eliezer triumphed over the Rabbis, as what is different</b> in a case where the <b>property he stole</b> is worth <b>five hundred and he is worth one thousand</b> that they concede <b>that he is not sold?</b> The reason is that <b>the Merciful One states that he is sold in his entirety, and not part of him. So too,</b> if he is worth less than the value of the property he stole, one can say: <b>The Merciful One states</b> that <b>he is sold for his theft, and he is not sold for part of his theft.</b>
§ The <i>baraita</i> further teaches: <b>And one can redeem</b> a Hebrew maidservant <b>against his will. Rava thought to say</b> that this means <b>against the will of the master,</b> i.e., she can be redeemed even if he refuses. <b>Abaye said to him: What is</b> the mechanism for emancipating her against the will of her master? Is it <b>that one writes a document to him for her value,</b> and when she has the money she repays this debt? <b>Why</b> should it be possible to force the master to free her in this manner? He <b>is holding a pearl [<i>marganita</i>] in his hand</b> and <b>one gives him a shard</b> instead, as this document is currently useless.
<b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> She can be redeemed <b>against the will of</b> her <b>father, due to the family flaw,</b> i.e., the harm caused to the family name by her status. The court pressures the father as much as possible to redeem her, as it is disgraceful to a family if one of its daughters is a maidservant. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, one should force the family of a Hebrew slave</b> to redeem him <b>also, due to the family flaw.</b> The Gemara answers: There is a concern that <b>he will go back and sell himself</b> and earn money in this manner at his family’s expense.
The Gemara asks: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of a Hebrew maidservant, the father <b>might go back and sell her</b> as a maidservant again and receive money for her a second time. The Gemara answers that it <b>is taught:</b> A maidservant <b>is not sold a second time. And whose</b> opinion is this? <b>It is</b> that of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One can sell,</b> i.e., transfer, <b>his</b> young <b>daughter in marriage and</b> go back and betroth her <b>again</b> if she was divorced or widowed. Likewise, he can sell her <b>into slavery and</b> transfer her <b>again,</b> this time <b>for marriage, after</b> he sold her into <b>slavery. But</b> one <b>cannot</b> sell his daughter into <b>slavery after marriage. Rabbi Shimon says: Just as a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after marriage, so too, a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after slavery.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this issue is taught <b>in the dispute</b> between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “He shall have no power to sell her to a foreign people, seeing that he has dealt deceitfully with her [<i>bevigdo vah</i>]” (Exodus 21:8).

Daf 18b

This verse indicates that <b>once</b> the master <b>has spread his garment over her,</b> thereby designating her as his wife, her father <b>may no longer sell her.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva,</b> who interprets <i>bevigdo</i> as related to <i>beged</i>, meaning garment. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: “<i>Bevigdo vah</i>”</b> means that <b>since</b> the father <b>dealt deceitfully [<i>bagad</i>] with her</b> and sold her once, <b>he cannot sell her again.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> they <b>disagree? Rabbi Eliezer maintains</b> that <b>the tradition</b> of the manner in which the verses in the Torah are written is <b>authoritative,</b> and one derives <i>halakhot</i> based on the spelling of the words. One relies on the way a word is written, without the traditional vocalization, and therefore it is read as though it were vocalized as <i>bevagdo</i>, which refers to betrayal, not a garment. <b>And Rabbi Akiva maintains</b> that the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>is authoritative,</b> meaning that one derives <i>halakhot</i> based on the pronunciation of the words, although it diverges from the spelling, and since one pronounces the term as <i>bevigdo</i>, it is related to the word <i>beged</i>, meaning garment. <b>And Rabbi Shimon maintains</b> that both the <b>vocalization</b> of the Torah <b>and the tradition</b> of the manner in which the verses in the Torah are written are <b>authoritative.</b> Consequently, she cannot be sold as a slave after she has been taken as a wife, nor can she be sold again after she has already been sold once.
<b>Rabba bar Avuh raises a dilemma:</b> Does <b>designation</b> of a Hebrew maidservant for betrothal by her master <b>effect marriage or</b> does it <b>effect</b> only <b>betrothal?</b> The <b>practical difference</b> of the outcome of this dilemma is <b>whether he inherits her</b> property, i.e., does her husband inherit her property if she dies as he would if she were married to him; <b>and</b> whether he is obligated to <b>become impure to</b> bury <b>her</b> when she dies, if he is a priest; <b>and</b> whether he can <b>nullify her vows</b> on his own without her father, as is the case with a married woman. <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this dilemma. <b>“<i>Bevigdo vah</i>”</b> means: <b>Once</b> her master <b>has spread his garment over her,</b> the father <b>may no longer sell her.</b> The Gemara analyzes this statement: This indicates that her father <b>cannot sell her</b> afterward, but he <b>can designate her</b> for another man if the master dies or divorces her. <b>And if you say</b> that designation <b>effects marriage, once she is married her father no longer has authority over her. Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> correct to <b>learn from this</b> that designation <b>effects</b> only <b>betrothal?</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that this argument can be refuted. <b>Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is <b>dealing with</b> the <b>ordinary betrothal</b> of one’s daughter, not to one who sells his daughter as a maidservant. <b>And this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Since her father gave her,</b> i.e., betrothed her, <b>to one who is obligated to</b> provide <b>her food, her clothing, and</b> fulfill <b>her conjugal rights, he can no longer sell her.</b> Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> proves nothing with regard to the issue of whether or not designation effects marriage.
The Gemara cites another relevant source. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> A father <b>cannot sell</b> his daughter as a maidservant <b>to relatives</b> with whom she is prohibited from engaging in sexual intercourse, as they cannot fulfill the mitzva of designation. <b>They said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: He can sell her to relatives,</b> because designation is merely an option and its inapplicability does not negate the possibility of a sale. <b>And they agree that he can sell her to a High Priest</b> if she is <b>a widow,</b> or <b>to a common priest</b> if she is <b>a divorcée or a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>].</b> Although it is prohibited for her to marry these men, their betrothal is effective, and therefore designation is not entirely impossible in these cases.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances of this widow? If we say that</b> she <b>betrothed herself</b> when she was a minor and her husband died, is <b>she called a widow?</b> Since the initial betrothal was entirely ineffective, as a minor cannot accept betrothal independently, she would not be considered his wife. <b>Rather,</b> one must say <b>that her father betrothed her</b> and she was subsequently widowed. But if that is the case, <b>can he sell her? But</b> it was taught that <b>a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after marriage.</b>
<b>And Rav Amram says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: Here,</b> it is referring <b>to</b> a woman widowed from <b>betrothal of designation, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who says: The original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was not given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal</b> but as payment for her work, and if the master wishes to designate her he must give her additional money for that purpose. The relevance of this assertion will be clarified below. The Gemara explains the proof from this <i>baraita</i>: <b>And if you say</b> that designation <b>effects marriage, once she is married her father no longer has authority over her.</b> How can he sell her a second time after the death of her first husband?
The Gemara asks from the other perspective: <b>Rather, what</b> will you say, that designation <b>effects</b> only <b>betrothal?</b> If so, why does the <i>baraita</i> state: <b>And they agree that he can sell her?</b> After all, <b>a person cannot sell his daughter into slavery after matrimony.</b> This <i>baraita</i> also refers to a case where a woman was betrothed but the marriage was not consummated. <b>Rather, what have you to say? Betrothal</b> effected <b>by her is different from betrothal</b> effected <b>by her father.</b> Since the marriage was not performed through her father but by the master giving her additional money, as held by Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, the principle that one cannot sell his daughter into slavery after betrothal does not apply. But by the same reasoning, <b>even</b> if <b>you say</b> that designation <b>effects marriage,</b> you can argue that <b>marriage</b> effected <b>by her is different from marriage</b> effected <b>by her father.</b>
This challenge is rejected: <b>What</b> is <b>this</b> comparison? <b>Granted,</b> one form of <b>betrothal is different from</b> the other <b>betrothal,</b> i.e., there is a difference between standard betrothal with the father’s consent and betrothal through designation, which is performed upon the master’s initiative. After that type of betrothal the father can, in fact, sell her a second time. <b>But</b> with regard to one mode of effecting <b>marriage</b> in relation <b>to</b> another mode of effecting <b>marriage,</b>

Daf 19a

<b>is</b> the matter <b>different?</b> In both cases she is fully released from her father’s authority by Torah law, and therefore he should not be able to sell her again afterward.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, who says</b> that <b>even</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, the original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal, in accordance with whose</b> opinion does <b>he establish</b> the <i>baraita</i> that permits a father to sell his widowed daughter? After giving her in marriage a father may no longer sell his daughter into slavery. The Gemara explains: <b>He establishes it in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says: It is for slavery after slavery that he is not able to sell her, but he is able to sell her into slavery after marriage.</b>
§ <b>Reish Lakish raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to the possibility <b>that a person can designate</b> a Hebrew maidservant <b>for his minor son, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara clarifies the sides of this dilemma. Does one learn from the verse: “And if he designates her for <b>his son”</b> (Exodus 21:9), that <b>the Merciful One states</b> that this applies to <b>any son,</b> even if he is too young to be married? <b>Or perhaps</b> it means <b>his son</b> who is <b>similar to him: Just as he is an adult man, so too, his son</b> must be <b>an adult man.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this dilemma from the verse: “And the man who commits adultery with the wife of another man, even he that commits adultery with his neighbor’s wife, both the adulterer and the adulteress shall surely be put to death” (Leviticus 20:10). The Sages expounded that the term <b>“man”</b> serves <b>to exclude a minor</b> who commits adultery. The phrase <b>“who commits adultery with the wife of another man”</b> serves <b>to exclude the wife of a minor,</b> as the marriage of a minor is invalid. <b>And if you say</b> that a father can <b>designate</b> a wife for his minor son, and designation effects betrothal or marriage, <b>we find</b> that there is <b>marriage for a minor.</b>
The Gemara challenges this proof: <b>But rather, what</b> will you say, that a master <b>cannot designate</b> a maidservant for his son who is a minor? If so, <b>why does the verse exclude him?</b> If the marriage of a minor is never valid, why is it necessary for the verse to exclude him? On the contrary, <b>resolve from here that one can designate</b> for his minor son. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> One could say that <b>here,</b> when this verse excludes the wife of a minor, <b>we are dealing with a <i>yavam</i></b> who is <b>nine years and one day old who engaged in sexual intercourse with his <i>yevama</i>,</b> and his intercourse is considered valid.
The unique feature of this case is <b>that by Torah law</b> she <b>is fit for him.</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of levirate marriage do not stipulate the minimum age of the <i>yavam</i>. Sexual intercourse with a boy aged nine years and one day is legally considered intercourse, and therefore this verse is necessary, <b>lest you say: Since by Torah law she is fit for him, and his sexual intercourse</b> is considered proper <b>intercourse;</b> therefore, he acquires her and she is his wife in all regards. Consequently, <b>one who engages in intercourse with her becomes liable for</b> violating the prohibition against engaging in intercourse with <b>a married woman.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that despite this consideration, she is not considered a full-fledged married woman.
The Gemara asks: Ultimately, <b>what</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter of designation for a minor son? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear,</b> as <b>Rabbi Aivu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says: Designation applies only to an adult man,</b> and <b>designation applies only with consent.</b> The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to teach these <b>two</b> <i>halakhot</i> with regard to this matter? It can be derived from the statement that designation requires consent that it applies only to an adult, as a minor is legally incapable of consent. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yannai <b>is saying: What is the reason,</b> i.e., <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>designation applies only to an adult man?</b> It is <b>because designation applies only with consent.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> an alternative explanation. <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>With consent?</b> It means <b>with her consent. As Abaye, son of Rabbi Abbahu, taught:</b> The verse <b>“who did not designate her [<i>ye’adah</i>]”</b> (Exodus 21:8), <b>teaches that he is required to inform her [<i>ya’adah</i>].</b>
<b>He teaches it and he says it:</b> This is referring <b>to betrothal through designation, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: The original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was not given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal.</b> For this reason, an additional act of betrothal must be performed with her consent. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the original money <b>was given for betrothal, it is different here, as the Merciful One states “designate her [<i>ye’adah</i>].”</b> This unusual expression alludes to the <i>halakha</i> that this act must be performed with her consent.
After mentioning the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, several times, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the source in which the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> is stated? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “Who did not <b>designate her, then he shall let her be redeemed”</b> (Exodus 21:8). This juxtaposition indicates that designation applies only when she can be redeemed. Consequently, if she is at the end of her service <b>it is necessary that</b> when he designates her <b>there must be enough time</b> remaining <b>in the day for redemption.</b> There must be sufficient time for her to be redeemed, and if only a short amount of time remains, during which she would be unable to perform work worth one <i>peruta</i>, the master does not have the option of redeeming her.
<b>From here Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: If there is enough time</b> left <b>in the day for her to perform</b> work that is <b>worth one <i>peruta</i> for him, she is betrothed,</b> as he betroths her with the amount she owes him for her work, which is the value of one <i>peruta</i>. <b>And if not, she is not betrothed. Apparently, he maintains</b> that <b>the original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was not given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the original money <b>was given for betrothal,</b> one can explain this <i>halakha</i> as follows: <b>It is different here, as the Merciful One states</b> by means of the juxtaposition: “Who did not designate her, <b>then he shall let her be redeemed,”</b> that by a Torah edict the designation must be performed at a stage when she can still be redeemed.
§ <b>Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says: A person</b> may <b>say to his minor daughter: Go out and accept your betrothal,</b> and when she accepts the betrothal it is as though she were appointed the father’s agent for her betrothal, despite the fact she is not halakhically competent. From where is this derived? It is derived <b>from that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda</b> said.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, say that the original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was not given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal, and if</b> enough time for <b>her</b> to perform work <b>worth one <i>peruta</i> remains, it is a betrothal?</b> This indicates that when the father sells his daughter he effectively appoints her as her own agent to receive her betrothal, if the master wishes to designate her for himself. At the time of the designation the father receives nothing, while the daughter accepts the value of one <i>peruta</i> for her work as betrothal. <b>Here too, it is no different,</b> and therefore a minor can accept her betrothal with the consent of her father.
<b>And Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan for which there is collateral,</b> i.e., he relinquishes his claim to a loan that she owes him and he returns the collateral she gave him, <b>she is betrothed.</b> This is derived <b>from that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> said. <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, say that the original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was not given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal?</b> If so, <b>this</b> daughter’s requirement to serve <b>is</b> similar to <b>a loan,</b> as there is no actual money but only an obligation, <b>and she herself is the collateral.</b> In other words, her body is the security that the loan will be repaid.

Daf 19b

<b>And</b> yet <b>if</b> time for <b>her</b> to perform work <b>worth one <i>peruta</i> remains, and he designates</b> her, <b>it is a betrothal.</b> This shows that he can betroth her with a loan, i.e., the value of the remaining time of her servitude, for which she herself is collateral. <b>Here too, it is no different,</b> and in general one may betroth a woman with a loan for which there is collateral.
§ <b>The Sages taught: How is the mitzva of designation</b> performed? The master <b>says to her before two</b> witnesses: <b>You are hereby betrothed [<i>mekuddeshet</i>] to me,</b> or: <b>You are hereby betrothed [<i>me’oreset</i>] to me.</b> The designation is effective <b>even</b> if he said this <b>at the end of six</b> years of work, <b>and even</b> if it is <b>close to sunset</b> on the last day of her term. <b>And</b> once he designates her <b>he treats her in the manner of marriage and may not treat her in the manner of slavery. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: If there is enough time</b> left <b>in that day for her to perform</b> for <b>him</b> work <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed, and if not, she is not betrothed.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: This can be understood by way of <b>a parable</b> comparing this <i>halakha</i> <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me from now after thirty days, and another man came and betrothed her within thirty days.</b> In this case the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that she is betrothed to the first</b> man. The Gemara inquires: <b>According to whom</b> is this <b>parable</b> suggested? Of the two opinions cited in the <i>baraita</i>, whose opinion accords with the <i>halakha</i> in the case of the parable?
<b>If we say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> in the case of the <b>parable is</b> compared <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> didn’t he say: <b>If there is enough time on that day for her to perform</b> for <b>him</b> work <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed, and if not,</b> she is <b>not</b> betrothed? Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, maintains that she is not considered betrothed conditionally when she is initially acquired as a Hebrew maidservant. Rather, the betrothal takes effect only when he designates her. This is evident from the fact that enough time must remain for her to perform work worth one <i>peruta</i>, as she is betrothed with that amount. If so, one cannot compare his ruling to the case of the parable, where the betrothal of the first was given before that of the second.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> in the case of the <b>parable is</b> compared <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> i.e., the first opinion cited in the <i>baraita</i>, who say that when she was initially acquired as a Hebrew maidservant it is as though he had betrothed her on condition that she would be retroactively betrothed whenever her master desired. This indicates that retroactive betrothal is possible. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it obvious</b> that this comparison is correct? Why would the <i>baraita</i> need to state a parable?
The Gemara explains: The <i>baraita</i> needs to state a parable <b>lest you say</b> that the Rabbis hold she is betrothed to the master even if the master <b>did not say to</b> the father that she is betrothed to him <b>from now.</b> The parable therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the case of the master is comparable to a case where the first man said to her: From now, and if the master did not state this term when acquiring her as a Hebrew maidservant, then she is not betrothed to him.
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who</b> first <b>sells his daughter</b> as a Hebrew maidservant <b>and</b> then <b>goes and betroths her to another</b> man, he <b>mocks the master, and she is betrothed to the second</b> man. Although he sold her as a Hebrew maidservant, he can remove her from the authority of the master, and this is seen as mocking him. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say: If</b> the master <b>wants to designate</b> her, he can <b>designate</b> her, and the second man’s betrothal is void.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: This can be understood by way of <b>a parable</b> comparing this <i>halakha</i> <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me after thirty days, and another man came and betrothed her within thirty days.</b> In this case the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that she is betrothed to the second</b> man. The Gemara inquires: <b>According to whom</b> is this <b>parable</b> suggested? Of the two opinions cited in the <i>baraita</i>, whose opinion accords with the <i>halakha</i> in the case of the parable?
<b>If we say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> in the case of the <b>parable is</b> compared <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, don’t the Rabbis say</b> that <b>if</b> the master <b>wants to designate</b> her, <b>he may designate</b> her, and the second man’s betrothal does not take effect? In the case of the parable, she is betrothed to the second man, and the first cannot prevent this.
<b>Rather, Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> in the case of the <b>parable is</b> compared <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it obvious</b> that this comparison is correct? Why would the <i>baraita</i> need to state a parable?
The Gemara explains: The <i>baraita</i> needs to state a parable <b>lest you say</b> that the case of the Hebrew maidservant is different, as <b>he did not say to her</b> when he acquired her: <b>After thirty days.</b> One might argue that the reason Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds that she is not betrothed to the master is that he did not state when he acquired her that she should be designated at a specific time in the future, but if he would have stated this at the time he acquired her as a Hebrew maidservant, the designation would then take effect. By comparing this case to the case of the parable, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, would hold that the designation does not take effect even if the master had said at the time of the acquisition that designation should take effect in thirty days, provided that her father betroths her to another in the interim.
§ <b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who sells his daughter and stipulates</b> with the buyer that the sale applies <b>on the condition that he does not designate</b> her, <b>the condition stands.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: If</b> the master <b>wants to designate</b> her <b>he may designate her, because</b> the father <b>stipulated counter to that which is written in the Torah,</b> as the Torah permits the designation of a Hebrew maidservant. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>anyone who stipulates counter to that which is written in the Torah, his condition is void.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> does <b>his condition stand</b> in that case? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me on the condition that you do not have against me</b> any claims of <b>food, clothing, and conjugal rights, she is betrothed and his condition is void;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: With regard to monetary matters,</b> e.g., food and clothing, <b>his condition stands.</b> This indicates that Rabbi Meir maintains that one cannot stipulate counter to that which is written in the Torah.
<b>Ḥizkiyya said:</b> It <b>is different here, as the verse states:</b> “And if a man sells his daughter <b>as a maidservant”</b> (Exodus 21:7), from which it is derived: There are <b>times when he sells her only as a maidservant,</b> not for the sake of marriage. This indicates that the designation of a maidservant is not a Torah obligation but is optional. Therefore, one can issue a stipulation that runs counter to the master designating her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis, what do they do with this</b> phrase: <b>“As a maidservant”?</b> How do they interpret it? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> expression is <b>necessary for them for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states <b>“as a maidservant.”</b> This <b>teaches that he can sell her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage, e.g., a <i>mamzer</i>, whom she is prohibited from marrying but whose betrothal is effective.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: Why is it necessary to derive that <i>halakha</i> from the verse? <b>But</b> could this <b>not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference: If</b> her father <b>can betroth her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage, can he <b>not sell her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage? The <i>baraita</i> answers: The verse is necessary, as <b>what</b> is unique about <b>betrothal to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage is that <b>a person can betroth his daughter</b> even <b>when she is a young woman,</b> i.e., between the ages of twelve and twelve and a half. Therefore, one cannot learn from this that <b>he can</b> also <b>sell her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage because that case is different, <b>as a person cannot sell his daughter when she is a young woman.</b> The <i>halakha</i> that a person can betroth his daughter even when she is a young woman demonstrates that the rights that a father has with regard to his daughter’s betrothal are more extensive than his right to sell her. Therefore, <b>the verse states “as a maidservant,”</b> which <b>teaches that</b> he can, in fact, <b>sell her to disqualified people.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If</b> that verse serves <b>to teach that he can sell her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage, it is unnecessary, <b>as it is already stated: “If she does not please her master,</b> who designated her” (Exodus 21:8). This indicates <b>that she is displeasing in her marriage,</b> i.e., marriage to him was forbidden, and yet the sale is valid. If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “as a maidservant”?</b> This <b>teaches that he can sell her</b>

Daf 20a

<b>to relatives,</b> e.g., his father, despite the fact that sexual intercourse between them is prohibited.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: Why is it necessary to derive that <i>halakha</i> from the verse? <b>But</b> could this <b>not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference: If he can sell her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage, can he <b>not sell her to relatives?</b> The <i>baraita</i> answers: The verse is necessary, as <b>what</b> is unique <b>about selling her to</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage is <b>that if</b> that master <b>wants to designate</b> her, <b>he can designate</b> her. Although it is prohibited for these people to marry her, nevertheless the betrothal would take effect. Therefore, one cannot learn from this that <b>he can</b> also <b>sell her to relatives.</b> This is a situation <b>where if</b> this master <b>wants to designate</b> her, <b>he cannot designate</b> her, as betrothal is ineffective. Therefore, <b>the verse states “as a maidservant,”</b> which <b>teaches that he can sell her to relatives.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who derived from the term “as a maidservant” that one can stipulate that she cannot be designated, how does he know that one can sell her as a maidservant to people of unflawed lineage or relatives? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> that she can be sold to people of <b>flawed</b> lineage <b>from</b> the verse <b>where Rabbi Eliezer derives</b> it: “If she does not please her master” (Exodus 21:8). <b>With regard to relatives, he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that <b>he cannot sell her to relatives.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One can sell</b> his daughter <b>to his father, but he cannot sell her to his son. And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>He cannot sell her to his father nor to his son.</b> The Gemara clarifies this issue: <b>Granted,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that states that <b>he cannot sell her to his father nor to his son</b> is in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who say that he cannot sell her to relatives whom she cannot marry. <b>But in accordance with whose</b> opinion is the <i>baraita</i> that states that <b>he can sell her to his father but he cannot sell her to his son?</b>
<b>It is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who forbid selling her to any relative, <b>and it is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who permits selling her to all relatives. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Although they say he cannot sell her to relatives, <b>the Rabbis concede</b> that he is permitted to do so <b>where there is a possibility of designation.</b> In this case, although the father of the girl’s father cannot marry her, he can designate her as a wife for his other son, who is the girl’s uncle. Since this uncle can marry her, designation is a possibility, and therefore the sale is effective.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> concerning the following verse, which is referring to a Hebrew slave: <b>“If he comes in <i>begappo</i> he shall leave <i>begappo</i>”</b> (Exodus 21:3), which means that if <b>he enters with his body [<i>begufo</i>] he shall leave with his body [<i>begufo</i>]. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> If <b>he enters alone he shall leave alone.</b> The Gemara clarifies. <b>What</b> is the meaning of the ruling that if <b>he enters with his body he shall leave with his body? Rava said:</b> This means <b>to say that he is not released through</b> the loss of his <b>extremities like</b> a Canaanite <b>slave</b> (Exodus 21:26), meaning he does not leave his master because of damage done to his body. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived</b> from a different verse: <b>“She shall not go out as the men slaves do”</b> (Exodus 21:7).
Rava answers: <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>were</b> derived only <b>from there, I would say:</b> The master <b>should give him the value of the eye</b> that he took out <b>and let him be released.</b> In other words, one could say that the verse which states that a Hebrew maidservant does not leave as Canaanite slaves leave, which would serve as the source for the <i>halakha</i> of a Hebrew slave as well, does not mean that she is not released at all due to the loss of her extremities. Rather, it means that unlike Canaanite slaves, she receives compensation for the injury as well as being released. Therefore, the verse: “If he comes in with his body he shall leave with his body,” <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so. Rather, although the master must reimburse him for the loss of his eye, he is not freed as a result of the injury.
The Gemara discusses the second opinion in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> If <b>he enters alone, he shall leave alone.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>He shall leave alone? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>this is what</b> Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov <b>is saying:</b> If the Hebrew slave <b>has a wife and children</b> when he is purchased, <b>his master may provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant.</b> But if <b>he did not have a wife and children,</b> i.e., he enters alone, <b>his master may not provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to a slave who <b>was sold for one hundred dinars and increased</b> in value during his term, <b>and</b> his value <b>stood at two hundred</b> dinars, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> if he wishes to redeem himself <b>one assesses him,</b> for the payment of the remainder of his service, based <b>only</b> on the calculation of <b>one hundred dinars,</b> his value when originally purchased? <b>As it is stated: “Out of the money that he was bought for”</b> (Leviticus 25:51).
If <b>he was sold for two hundred</b> dinars <b>and decreased</b> in value <b>and stood at one hundred dinars, from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> when he is redeemed <b>one assesses him</b> based <b>only</b> on the calculation of <b>one hundred dinars? The verse states: “According to his years</b> he shall give back the price of his redemption” (Leviticus 25:52), meaning that he pays in accordance with the value of his remaining years of service.
<b>I have</b> derived this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in the case of <b>a slave sold to a gentile, since</b> the Torah is lenient with regard to his redemption, as <b>he may be redeemed</b> even <b>by relatives</b> who pay his money and free him. Consequently, in this case the owner <b>is at a disadvantage,</b> and regardless of whether his value increased or decreased the slave always pays the lower amount.
In a case where the slave was <b>sold to a Jew, from where do we</b> derive that this <i>halakha</i> also applies to him? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to a Hebrew slave sold to a Jew: “As <b>a hired worker</b> and as a settler he shall be with you” (Leviticus 25:40), and it states with regard to one sold to a gentile: “As <b>a hired worker</b> year by year he shall be with him” (Leviticus 25:53), <b>for a verbal analogy.</b> This verbal analogy teaches that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to one sold to a gentile as to one sold to a Jew.
When he was in a good mood, <b>Abaye</b> once <b>said: Behold I am like</b> the intellectually sharp <b>ben Azzai,</b> who would regularly expound on the Torah <b>in the markets of Tiberias.</b> I too am ready to answer any question put to me. <b>One of the Sages said to Abaye: After all,</b> with regard to <b>those verses:</b> “Out of the money that he was bought for” and “according to his years,” <b>one could expound them leniently,</b> and assess the cost of redemption at the lower amount. <b>And one could,</b> in equal measure, <b>expound them stringently,</b> i.e., one could say that if a slave was worth more when he was purchased, he pays according to “the money that he was bought for,” and if he increased in value he must pay “according to his years,” i.e., by his present worth. <b>What did you see</b> to cause you to decide <b>to expound them leniently? Let us expound them stringently.</b>
Abaye answered: <b>It cannot enter your mind</b> to expound the verses stringently, as indicated <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One is lenient with regard to</b> a slave and is concerned about his well-being. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states concerning a Hebrew slave: <b>“Because he fares well with you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:16), which teaches that the slave should be <b>with you,</b> i.e., treated as your equal, <b>in food,</b> meaning that his food must be of the same quality as yours, and <b>with you in drink.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: This means <b>that there shall not</b> be a situation in <b>which you eat fine bread and he eats inferior bread [<i>kibbar</i>],</b> bread from coarse flour mixed with bran, which is low quality. There shall not be a situation in which <b>you drink aged wine and he drinks</b> inferior <b>new wine.</b> There shall not be a situation in which <b>you sleep</b> comfortably <b>on</b> bedding made from <b>soft sheets and he sleeps on straw. From here</b> the Sages <b>stated: Anyone who acquires a Hebrew slave</b> is considered <b>like one who acquires a master for himself,</b> because he must be careful that the slave’s living conditions are equal to his own.
That Sage asked Abaye: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>this</b> leniency in the case of a Hebrew slave <b>applies</b> only <b>to the matter of eating and drinking, so</b> as <b>not to cause him suffering.</b> But with regard <b>to the matter of redemption,</b> perhaps <b>one should be stringent with him.</b> The reason to be stringent is <b>based on</b> a statement <b>of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: Come and see how harsh is</b> the violation of even <b>a hint of the Sabbatical</b> Year, i.e., how great are the punishments not just for working the land, but also for treating lightly the sanctity of Sabbatical-Year produce.
If <b>a person has commercial dealings with Sabbatical-</b>Year <b>produce,</b> which is prohibited, <b>ultimately</b> he will become so poor that <b>he will</b> have to <b>sell his movable property, as it is stated: “In</b> this <b>Jubilee Year you shall return every man to his land”</b> (Leviticus 25:13), <b>and juxtaposed to it</b> is the verse: <b>“And if you sell any item to your neighbor or buy from your neighbor’s hand”</b> (Leviticus 25:14), which is referring to <b>an item acquired</b> by passing it <b>from hand to hand.</b> This teaches that if one sins with regard to the Jubilee Year or the Sabbatical Year, which have many identical <i>halakhot</i>, he will eventually have to sell his movable property.
If one <b>does not sense</b> that he is being punished and does not repent, <b>ultimately he</b> will have to <b>sell his fields, as it is stated</b> in an adjacent verse: <b>“If your brother grows poor and sells of his ancestral land”</b> (Leviticus 25:25). If <b>no</b> move toward repentance <b>comes to his hand, he will</b> have to <b>sell his house, as it is stated:</b> “And if a man <b>sells a dwelling-house in a walled city”</b> (Leviticus 25:29).
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different there,</b> in the first sentence, <b>in</b> which the <i>tanna</i> <b>says: He does not sense, and what is different here,</b> in the continuation, <b>in</b> which he <b>says:</b> If <b>no</b> move toward repentance <b>comes to his hand?</b> The Gemara answers that this is <b>in accordance with</b> a statement <b>of Rav Huna. As Rav Huna says: Once a person commits a transgression and repeats it, it is permitted to him.</b> The Gemara is surprised at this: <b>Can it enter your mind that it is permitted to him</b> merely because he has sinned twice? <b>Rather,</b> say that <b>it becomes to him as though</b> it is <b>permitted.</b> Therefore, when he violates a prohi-bition a second time, the <i>baraita</i> takes for granted that he does not sense that he is performing a sin, and employs a different terminology.
The Gemara resumes its citation of the <i>baraita</i>: If <b>no</b> move toward repentance <b>comes to his hand,</b> his poverty will increase <b>until he sells his daughter, as it is stated: “And when a man sells his daughter as a maidservant”</b> (Exodus 21:7). The Gemara comments: <b>And even though “his daughter” is not written with regard to that matter</b> in Leviticus 25 but in Exodus, nevertheless, <b>it teaches us this</b> principle: <b>A person will sell his daughter rather than borrow with interest</b>. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>His daughter can</b> occasionally <b>deduct</b> money from her debt <b>and</b> use it to <b>leave</b> her master, <b>but this</b> interest <b>continuously increases.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues its exposition of the verses in Leviticus: If <b>no</b> move toward repentance <b>comes to his hand, he</b> will eventually need to <b>borrow with interest, as it is stated: “And if your brother grows poor and his means fails with you”</b> (Leviticus 25:35), <b>and juxtaposed to it</b> is the verse: <b>“Take no</b> usury or interest <b>from him”</b> (Leviticus 25:36). If <b>no</b> move toward repentance <b>comes to his hand, he will</b> eventually need to <b>sell himself, as it is stated: “And if your brother grows poor</b> with you <b>and sells himself to you”</b> (Leviticus 25:39).
The <i>baraita</i> further states: <b>Not</b> only will he be sold <b>to you,</b> a born Jew, <b>but</b> he will even be sold <b>to a stranger, as it is stated:</b> “And sells himself <b>to a stranger [<i>ger</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 25:47). <b>And</b> this sale to a <i>ger</i> is <b>not</b> referring to a sale <b>to a righteous convert [<i>ger tzedek</i>], but</b> even <b>to a gentile who resides in Eretz Yisrael and observes the seven Noahide mitzvot [<i>ger toshav</i>], as it is stated:</b> “And sells himself to <b>a stranger who is a settler [<i>ger toshav</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 25:47). With regard to the continuation of the verse, “or to an offshoot of a stranger’s family,” the Gemara expounds: <b>“A stranger’s family”; this is a gentile,</b> i.e., he will reach a state where he has no choice but to sell himself to a gentile. <b>When it says: “To an offshoot</b> of a stranger’s family,”

Daf 20b

<b>this is</b> referring to <b>one sold for idol worship itself,</b> i.e., he is forced to sell himself as a slave to work in a temple of idol worship. The <i>baraita</i> teaches that it is only due to a person’s sins that he reaches a point where he has to sell himself as a slave. Therefore, one should be stringent with him with regard to his redemption and not allow him to be redeemed easily.
Abaye <b>said to</b> that Sage: <b>There, the verse brings him back,</b> i.e., one must strive to redeem a Jew who has been sold as a slave. <b>As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Since this</b> person who sold himself as a slave <b>has gone and become a priest for idol worship,</b> one might <b>say: Let us throw a stone after the fallen,</b> that is, since he has reached this nadir one should abandon him. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “After he is sold he shall be redeemed; one of his brothers may redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:48).
The Gemara further asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> as follows: <b>“He shall be redeemed,”</b> so that <b>he will not be assimilated among the gentiles.</b> But <b>with regard to the matter of</b> his <b>redemption</b> and freedom, <b>let us act strictly with him,</b> as derived <b>from that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> said, that one is sold as a slave due to his sins.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Two verses are written</b> with regard to the redemption of a slave sold to a gentile. <b>It is written: “If there be yet many of the years,</b> according to them he shall give back the price of his redemption out of the money that he was bought for” (Leviticus 25:51), <b>and it is written: “And if there remain but few of the years</b> until the Jubilee Year, and he shall reckon with him, according to his years” (Leviticus 25:52). <b>But</b> how can <b>there be</b> both <b>many years and few years</b> when, in any case, he will not serve for more than six years? <b>Rather,</b> this means that as the <b>money</b> of <b>his</b> value <b>increased</b> with the passage of time, he is redeemed <b>“out of the money that he was bought for,”</b> i.e., the price for which he was originally sold, which is the lower sum. And if <b>his monetary</b> value <b>decreased</b> over time, one determines his value <b>“according to his years,”</b> i.e., according to his current value.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>this is what</b> the Torah <b>is saying:</b> In a case <b>where he served</b> for <b>two</b> years <b>and</b> an additional <b>four years remain for his</b> service, as indicated by the phrase “if there be yet many of the years,” <b>let him give</b> his redemption money for the <b>four</b> years he owes him <b>“out of the money that he was bought for.”</b> If <b>he served four</b> years <b>and two years remain for his</b> service, as is stated “and if there remain but few of the years,” <b>let him give</b> his redemption money the value of the <b>two</b> years, <b>“according to his years.”</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>If so, let the verse write: If there be yet many years,</b> and: <b>If there remain but few years. What</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>“of the years”?</b> This teaches that if <b>his monetary</b> value <b>increased over the years</b> of his servitude, he is redeemed <b>“out of the money that he was bought for,”</b> which is the lower sum. And if <b>his monetary</b> value <b>decreased over the years</b> of his servitude, one determines his value <b>“according to his years.”</b> Upon hearing this statement, <b>Rav Yosef said: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> homiletically <b>interpreted these verses like Sinai.</b> His exposition reflects the truth of Torah as it was given at Mount Sinai, as every matter is fully resolved.
The Gemara records <b>a mnemonic</b> device for the upcoming discussions: <b>Slave, house, partial, house, slave,</b> and <b>relatives. Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> With regard to <b>a Hebrew slave who is sold to a gentile,</b> can he <b>be partially redeemed, or can he not be partially redeemed?</b> Does this slave have the option of paying part of his value and thereby reducing his remaining period of service?
The Gemara analyzes the sides of the dilemma: With regard to a Hebrew slave sold to a gentile, the verse states: “According to his years he shall give back the price of <b>his redemption [<i>ge’ullato</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 25:52), and the meaning of the term “<i>ge’ullato</i>” can be <b>derived from</b> the same term stated with regard to the redemption of an ancestral field: “And he becomes rich and finds sufficient means to <b>redeem it [<i>ge’ullato</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 25:26). Accordingly, <b>just as an ancestral field cannot be partially redeemed,</b> but is either fully redeemed or not at all, <b>so too, this</b> slave <b>cannot be partially redeemed. Or perhaps we say</b> that he cannot be partially redeemed only if that leads <b>to a leniency,</b> but <b>we do not say</b> that he cannot be redeemed if it leads <b>to a stringency.</b>
Rav Sheshet <b>said to him: Didn’t you say there,</b> with regard to a thief who is sold to repay what he stole, that the verse: “And he is sold” (Exodus 22:2), teaches that <b>all of him is sold but not part of him?</b> If he is worth one thousand, and he owes five hundred for theft, he cannot be sold. <b>So too,</b> in the case of one who was sold to a gentile, the phrase <b>“he is redeemed”</b> (Leviticus 25:49) means <b>all of him and not part of him.</b>
<b>Abaye said: If you say</b> that <b>he is partially redeemed, you find</b> elements <b>of leniency and stringency.</b> This ruling can lead <b>to a leniency</b> in the following case: A master <b>purchased</b> a Hebrew slave <b>for one hundred</b> and the redeemer <b>gives him fifty,</b> which is <b>half of his value, and</b> afterward the slave <b>increased</b> in value <b>and stood at two hundred. If you say</b> that <b>he can be partially redeemed</b> he is already half-redeemed. Consequently, the redeemer <b>gives him one hundred,</b> half of his current value, <b>and</b> the slave <b>goes out,</b> i.e., is redeemed. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>he cannot be partially redeemed,</b> the redeemer <b>gives</b> the owner an additional <b>one hundred and fifty and</b> the slave <b>goes out,</b> as the initial fifty serves merely as the first payment, and he is now worth two hundred.
The Gemara asks: <b>But you said</b> that if the <b>money</b> of <b>his</b> value <b>increased,</b> one always pays <b>“out of the money that he was bought for”</b> (Leviticus 25:51), i.e., one calculates the value of the slave in accordance with his value at the time when he was acquired, even if that is less than his present value. Why, then, should one have to pay the full two hundred? The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case <b>where</b> he initially, before being sold, <b>increased in value,</b> was then sold for two hundred, <b>and</b> afterward <b>decreased</b> in value to one hundred, <b>and</b> subsequently he again <b>increased in value</b> so that he was worth the same amount as he was originally. In this case, his value of two hundred remains determinative.
Abaye proceeds to describe how <b>you find</b> a case that leads <b>to a stringency.</b> A master <b>purchased</b> a Hebrew slave <b>for two hundred</b> and the redeemer <b>gave one hundred,</b> which is <b>half of his value, and</b> the slave <b>decreased</b> in value <b>and stood at</b> a value of <b>one hundred. If you say</b> that <b>he can be partially redeemed,</b> the redeemer <b>gives fifty and</b> the slave <b>goes out,</b> i.e., is redeemed. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>he cannot be partially redeemed, these one hundred are a deposit with him.</b> Therefore, the redeemer <b>gives it to him</b> at the time of the redemption <b>and</b> the slave <b>goes out.</b> There is no reason to pay him more money, as he is now worth one hundred.
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet</b> with regard to a similar topic: In the case of <b>one who sells a house from among the houses of walled cities,</b> which can be redeemed only during the first year after the sale, can it <b>be partially redeemed, or can it not be partially redeemed?</b> The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: Does he <b>derive</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“<i>ge’ullato</i>”</b> (Leviticus 25:29) and <b>“<i>ge’ullato</i>”</b> (Leviticus 25:26) <b>from</b> the case of <b>an ancestral field</b> and say that <b>just as ancestral land cannot be partially redeemed, so too, this</b> house <b>cannot be partially redeemed?</b>
<b>Or perhaps</b> one should say: In a case <b>where</b> the verse explicitly <b>revealed</b> that it cannot be redeemed partially, as it does in the context of an ancestral field, <b>it revealed</b> it. With regard to one who redeems an ancestral field, it is written: “And he becomes rich and finds sufficient means to redeem it” (Leviticus 25:26), indicating that he has enough money to redeem the whole field, not part of it. By contrast, in a case <b>where</b> the Torah <b>did not reveal</b> that it cannot be redeemed, <b>it did not reveal</b> it, and therefore a house from a walled city can be partially redeemed, as the verse does not state this condition in that context.
Rav Sheshet <b>said to him: From Rabbi Shimon’s interpretation one learns that</b> with regard to houses in walled cities, <b>one can borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> them, <b>and</b> similarly that one <b>can partially redeem</b> them. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a verse that describes one who consecrates his field: <b>“And if he will redeem [<i>ga’ol yigal</i>]</b> the field” (Leviticus 27:19). The repetition of the verb <b>teaches that one can borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> houses in walled cities <b>and</b> that <b>one can</b> also <b>partially redeem</b> them.
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? This is <b>because we find with regard to one who sells his ancestral field that his power is enhanced, as, if the Jubilee</b> Year <b>arrives and it is not redeemed,</b> the ancestral field <b>returns to its owners in the Jubilee</b> Year without them having to pay for it. Therefore, <b>the power</b> of the seller <b>is diminished in</b> that <b>he cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> the field but must have the money to do so on his own, <b>and</b> he cannot <b>partially redeem</b> it.
By contrast, if <b>one consecrates</b> his field <b>his power is diminished, as, if the Jubilee</b> Year <b>arrives and he did not redeem it</b> in the meantime, and the Temple treasurer sold it to someone else, the ancestral field <b>goes out</b> and becomes the property <b>of the priests in the Jubilee</b> Year and does not return to its original owners. Consequently, in order to offset this stringency <b>his power is enhanced</b> in <b>that he may borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> the field, <b>and partially redeem</b> it.
According to this explanation, with regard to <b>this one who sells a house from among the houses of walled cities, since his power is also diminished, as, if a full year passes and</b> the house <b>has not been redeemed</b> it remains the <b>permanent</b> property of the buyer, in order to offset this stringency, <b>his power</b> should be <b>enhanced in</b> that <b>he may borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> the house, <b>and partially redeem</b> it.
Rava bar Ḥinnana <b>raised an objection to</b> this opinion from a <i>baraita</i>. The verse states with regard to one who consecrates his field: <b>“And if he will redeem [<i>ga’ol yigal</i>]</b> the field” (Leviticus 27:19). This <b>teaches that he may borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> it, <b>and partially redeem</b> it.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought: Could this <b>not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: Just as</b> with regard to <b>one who sells an ancestral field that his power is enhanced, as if the Jubilee</b> Year <b>arrives and it is not redeemed, it returns to its owners in the Jubilee</b> Year, and yet <b>his power is diminished</b> in <b>that he cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> the field <b>and</b> he cannot <b>partially redeem</b> it; with regard to <b>one who consecrates</b> a field, where <b>his power is diminished, for if the Jubilee</b> Year <b>arrives and it was not redeemed it goes out to the priests in the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>is it not logical that his power is diminished</b> in <b>that he cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> the field <b>and</b> he cannot <b>partially redeem</b> it?
The <i>baraita</i> raises a difficulty against this <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about</b> one who <b>sells his ancestral field</b> is that <b>his power is diminished with regard to redeeming</b> it <b>immediately,</b> as he cannot redeem his field right away but must wait at least two years. Shall <b>you say</b> that the same <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>with regard to one who consecrates</b> his field, <b>as his power is enhanced with regard to redeeming</b> it <b>immediately?</b> One who has consecrated his field can redeem it as soon as he has the money to do so. If so, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not valid.
The <i>baraita</i> responds: The case of one who <b>sells a house from among</b> the <b>houses of walled cities can prove</b> otherwise, <b>as his power is enhanced with regard to redeeming</b> it <b>immediately,</b> and yet <b>he cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> the house <b>and</b> he cannot <b>partially redeem</b> it. In any case, with regard to the issue at hand, the <i>baraita</i> indicates the opposite of the previous conclusion: One who sells a house in a walled city cannot partially redeem it. Rav Sheshet answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b>

Daf 21a

<b>This</b> second <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that one can borrow money and redeem the house and partially redeem it, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara states: It <b>is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i> with regard to the houses of walled cities: <b>One can borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> it, <b>and</b> one can <b>partially redeem</b> it, <b>and</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> it, <b>nor</b> can one <b>partially redeem.</b> Apparently, there is a contradiction between these two <i>baraitot</i>. The Gemara answers as above: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> device for the names of the Sages who raise the dilemmas cited below and those to whom the questions are addressed: <b><i>Ḥeresh</i>, <i>ḥavash</i>, <i>zeman</i>.</b> They allude to the following interlocutors: <i>Ḥeresh</i> alludes to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, and Rav Ashi; <i>ḥavash</i> alludes to Rav Aḥa Sava and Rav Ashi; and <i>zeman</i> alludes to Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, and Ravina.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> The comparison detailed earlier (20b) between one who sells a house and one who consecrates a field, <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>one who sells a house among the houses of walled cities</b> is that <b>his power is diminished,</b> in that he is not able <b>to redeem</b> it <b>forever,</b> since he cannot redeem it after a year has passed (see Leviticus 25:30). Shall <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to one who consecrates</b> his field, <b>as his power is enhanced</b> in that he is able <b>to redeem forever?</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa Sava said to Rav Ashi:</b> The comparison is valid, <b>because it can be said</b> that <b>the argument returns,</b> as one can learn in a different manner. <b>Let</b> this matter <b>be derived by</b> an analogy derived from <b>the common factor</b> of two sources: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who sells an ancestral field can prove it, as his power is enhanced</b> in that he is able <b>to redeem</b> the field <b>forever, and he cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> it, <b>and</b> he cannot <b>partially redeem</b> it. And if you say: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>one who sells an ancestral field is that his power is diminished</b> in that he is not able <b>to redeem</b> it <b>immediately,</b> the case of <b>one who sells a house from among houses of walled cities can prove</b> otherwise. Although one can redeem the house immediately, he cannot borrow money and redeem it, nor partially redeem it.
<b>And the derivation has reverted</b> to its starting point, as one could alternate the explanations for each side with their respective refutations. Ultimately, the <b>aspect of this</b> case, an ancestral field, <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case, a house from among houses of walled cities. <b>Their common denominator is that they can be redeemed, and one cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> them, <b>and</b> likewise, one cannot <b>partially redeem</b> them. <b>I will also bring</b> the case of <b>one who consecrates</b> his field and rule <b>that it may be redeemed, but one cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> it, <b>and</b> one cannot <b>partially redeem</b> it.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina:</b> This derivation, based on the common denominator, <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>to their common denominator is that their power is diminished</b> in that they are unable <b>to redeem</b> the respective properties <b>during the second year,</b> as in neither case can they be redeemed in the second year. One who sells a house in a walled city cannot redeem it beyond the first year, while one who sells an ancestral field cannot redeem it during the first two years. Shall <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to one who consecrated</b> his field, <b>as his power is enhanced</b> in that he is able <b>to redeem</b> the field <b>in the second year?</b>
<b>Ravina said to him</b> that the derivation is valid <b>because it can be said</b> that the case of <b>a Hebrew slave sold to a gentile can prove</b> otherwise, <b>as his power enhanced</b> in that he is able <b>to redeem</b> himself <b>in the second year, and</b> nevertheless <b>he cannot borrow</b> money <b>and redeem</b> himself, <b>and</b> he cannot <b>partially redeem</b> himself.
The Gemara discusses a similar matter. <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet:</b> In the case of <b>one who sells a house from among the houses of walled cities, can</b> it <b>be redeemed by relatives or can</b> it <b>not be redeemed by relatives?</b> Is the ability to redeem a house limited to the seller himself? The Gemara presents the two sides of the dilemma: Does one <b>derive</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“<i>ge’ullato</i>”</b> (Leviticus 25:29) and <b>“<i>ge’ullato</i>”</b> (Leviticus 25:26) <b>from an ancestral field</b> in this manner: <b>Just as an ancestral field cannot be partially redeemed and</b> yet it <b>can be redeemed by relatives, so too, this</b> house <b>also cannot be partially redeemed and</b> yet <b>it can be redeemed by relatives?</b>
<b>Or perhaps, when</b> the word <b><i>ge’ula</i> is written</b> in the case of an ancestral field, <b>it is written with regard to partial</b> redemption; but the word redemption <b>is not written with regard to relatives.</b> If so, the verbal analogy does not apply to the <i>halakha</i> of redemption by relatives. Rav Sheshet <b>said to him:</b> The house <b>cannot be redeemed</b> by relatives.
Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana <b>raised an objection to</b> the ruling of Rav Sheshet from a <i>baraita</i> that deals with the verse: “And <b>in all</b> of your ancestral land <b>you shall grant redemption</b> for the land” (Leviticus 25:24). This verse serves <b>to include houses and a Hebrew slave. What, is it not</b> correct to say that the term houses is referring to <b>houses of walled cities,</b> indicating that they can also be redeemed by relatives? The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> this is referring to <b>houses in open areas</b> without walls.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>houses in open areas</b> without walls, <b>it is explicitly written: “Shall be reckoned with the field of the country”</b> (Leviticus 25:31), meaning that they are like ancestral fields. If so, there is no need for another verse to teach this <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse: “And in all of your ancestral land you shall grant redemption for the land” (Leviticus 25:24), serves <b>to establish</b> that redemption by relatives is <b>an obligation, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, with regard to a verse that deals with one who sells ancestral land: <b>“And he shall redeem that which his brother has sold”</b> (Leviticus 25:25), this redemption is <b>optional,</b> i.e., if he wishes to do so he may redeem the land. Do <b>you say</b> that it is <b>optional or is it nothing other</b> than <b>an obligation? The verse states</b> concerning an ancestral field that was sold: <b>“And if a man has no one to redeem it”</b> (Leviticus 25:26). This verse is puzzling: <b>But is there a man in Israel who does not have redeemers?</b> Every Jew has a relative of some sort, even if he must trace his family tree back all the way to Jacob. <b>Rather,</b> this is referring to <b>one who has</b> a relative <b>who does not want to purchase,</b> i.e., redeem, the land, <b>as he has permission</b> to refrain from doing so, since this redemption is optional. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that when the verse states: <b>“And he shall redeem that which his brother has sold,”</b> this redemption is <b>an obligation.</b> Do <b>you say</b> that it is <b>an obligation, or is it only optional? The verse states:</b> “And <b>in all</b> of your ancestral land <b>you shall grant redemption</b> for the land” (Leviticus 25:24). Here <b>the verse established it as obligatory.</b> This is the interpretation of the verses according to Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>The Sages said to Rav Ashi, and some say Ravina</b> said this <b>to Rav Ashi: Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the verse serves <b>to include houses of walled cities, this is as it is written “in all.”</b> “In all” serves to include a case omitted by the phrase “you shall grant a redemption for the land.” <b>But according to the one who says</b> that it serves <b>to include houses in open areas</b> without walls, <b>what</b> is meant by the term <b>“in all”?</b> It was already taught that these houses are included in the category of ancestral fields, and therefore they are referred to by the expression “redemption for the land.” No answer was found to this question and the Gemara states that it is <b>a difficulty.</b>
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> this opinion that houses in walled cities cannot be redeemed by relatives. It is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> does it mean when <b>the verse states: “May redeem him,” “may redeem him,”</b> and <b>“may redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:48–49), <b>three times?</b> This serves <b>to include all redemptions,</b> and <b>that they are redeemed in this order:</b> In the case of a Hebrew slave sold to a gentile, if he does not redeem himself he can be redeemed by a brother; if he is not redeemed by a brother, then he can be redeemed by an uncle or some other relative. <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that this inclusion is referring to <b>houses of walled cities and a Hebrew slave,</b> that they too can be redeemed by relatives? The Gemara rejects this interpretation: <b>No,</b> it includes <b>houses in open areas and an ancestral field.</b>
The Gemara asks: But the cases of <b>houses in open areas and</b> the case of <b>an ancestral field</b> are <b>written explicitly: “Shall be reckoned with the field of the country”</b> (Leviticus 25:31). The Gemara answers: This is <b>as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said,</b> that the verse detailing the redemption by relatives stated with regard to an ancestral field teaches that <b>the closer</b> of a relative one is to the seller, the <b>earlier</b> one is in the order of redeeming the ancestral field. The obligation or merit to redeem the field applies first to one who is more closely related to the seller. <b>So too,</b> with regard to houses in open areas, this verse teaches that <b>the closer</b> of a relative one is to the seller, the <b>earlier</b> one is in the order of redeeming the house.
The Gemara asks: <b>Where was</b> this opinion <b>of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> originally <b>stated?</b> The Gemara answers that it was stated <b>with regard to this</b> issue, <b>as a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Can <b>a Hebrew slave sold to a Jew be redeemed by</b> his <b>relatives or can he not be redeemed by</b> his <b>relatives?</b> The Gemara comments: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>you should not raise the dilemma, as he says: One who is not redeemed by these</b> relatives <b>is redeemed by six</b> years of service. <b>Evidently,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that a Hebrew slave sold to a gentile <b>cannot be redeemed</b> by his relatives.
<b>When you raise the dilemma,</b> it is <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Does one <b>derive</b> the verbal analogy comparing <b>“hired worker”</b> (Leviticus 25:40) and <b>“hired worker”</b> (Leviticus 25:53) from the case of a Jew sold to a gentile, and say that just as one can be redeemed by one’s relatives if sold to a gentile, so too, one can be redeemed if sold to a Jew? <b>And</b> at the same time <b>one does not interpret homiletically</b> the phrase <b>“may redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:48), stated with regard to one sold to a gentile, as a restricting term. <b>Or perhaps</b> the phrase <b>“may redeem him”</b> is in fact a restricting term, which indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies only <b>to this</b> slave, i.e., only one sold to a gentile can be redeemed by relatives, <b>and</b> it does <b>not</b> apply <b>to another</b> slave, one sold to a Jew.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: “And <b>in all</b> of your ancestral land <b>you shall grant redemption</b> for the land” (Leviticus 25:24). The inclusive expression “in all” serves <b>to include houses and a Hebrew slave. What, is it not</b> correct to say that this includes <b>houses of walled cities and a Hebrew slave sold to a Jew?</b> The Gemara rejects this interpretation: <b>No,</b> one can say that this is referring to <b>a Hebrew slave sold to a gentile.</b>
The Gemara asks: It is <b>explicitly written with regard to a Hebrew slave sold to a gentile: “Either his uncle or his uncle’s son may redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:49). If so, it is unnecessary to derive the option of redemption by a relative from an inclusive expression in a different verse.

Daf 21b

The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse serves <b>to establish</b> that redeeming him is <b>an obligation. And even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who says that there is no requirement to redeem land, this case is different, as it is proper to redeem him to prevent him from being assimilated by gentiles.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “May redeem him,” “may redeem him,”</b> and <b>“may redeem him”</b> (Leviticus 25:48–49), <b>three times?</b> This serves <b>to include all redemptions,</b> and <b>that they are redeemed in this order. What, is it not</b> correct to say that this inclusion is referring both to <b>houses of walled cities and a Hebrew slave sold to a Jew,</b> that they can be redeemed by relatives? The Gemara rejects this interpretation: <b>No,</b> it includes <b>houses in open areas and an ancestral field.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Concerning houses in open areas and an ancestral field, it is written explicitly: “Shall be reckoned with the field of the country”</b> (Leviticus 25:31). <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This teaches that <b>the closer</b> of a relative one is to the seller, the <b>earlier</b> one is in the order of redeeming the house or the field. This is the context of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s statement.
§ The Gemara returns to the mishna, which teaches: <b>And</b> a Hebrew slave <b>who is pierced</b> after serving six years <b>is acquired</b> as a slave for a longer period <b>through piercing his ear with an awl.</b> The Gemara explains that this is <b>as it is written: “And his master shall pierce his ear with an awl,</b> and he shall serve him forever” (Exodus 21:6).
The mishna further teaches that a pierced slave <b>acquires himself through</b> the advent of <b>the Jubilee</b> Year <b>and through the master’s death.</b> The Gemara explains that this is <b>as it is written: “And he shall serve him</b> forever” (Exodus 21:6). This term indicates that he serves only the master, <b>but not the son and not the daughter.</b> The term <b>“forever”</b> is referring <b>to</b> the <b>forever</b> represented <b>by the Jubilee</b> Year. The word “forever” does not mean for eternity, but refers to the end of the cycle of the Jubilee Year.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> From the term <b>“an awl” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a master can pierce the ear of a Hebrew slave <b>with an awl. From where</b> do I derive that <b>a sharp thorn [<i>sol</i>], a thorn [<i>sira</i>], a needle, an auger, and a stylus</b> used to engrave in wax may be used? <b>The verse states: “And you shall take</b> the awl” (Deuteronomy 15:17). This term “and you shall take” serves <b>to include any implement that can be taken in the</b> master’s <b>hand.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> Not all of these utensils may be used for piercing. <b>Just as an awl is unique</b> in that it is made <b>of metal, so too any</b> tool made <b>of metal</b> can be used; one may not pierce a slave’s ear with non-metal implements. <b>Alternatively,</b> the verse states: “And you shall take <b>the awl,” to include the large awl</b> for piercing.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: Yudan the Distinguished would teach</b> as follows: <b>When they pierce, they pierce only the earlobe. And the Rabbis say:</b> The piercing is not performed on the earlobe, as the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>a Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest is not pierced</b> at all <b>because</b> the piercing <b>renders him blemished</b> and unfit to serve in the Temple. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>they pierce</b> a slave’s <b>earlobe, how does a Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest become blemished</b> through piercing? A pierced earlobe is not considered a blemish. This indicates that <b>he is pierced only on the upper part of the ear</b> through the cartilage. The Gemara inquires: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>disagree?</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>expounds</b> the verses by means of the hermeneutical principle of reading the verse as consisting of <b>generalizations and details.</b> Accordingly, he maintains that the term <b>“and you shall take”</b> is <b>a generalization</b> that indicates piercing may be performed with any implement. <b>“An awl”</b> is <b>a detail,</b> and when the verse states: <b>“Through his ear and into the door”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:17), <b>it then generalized</b> again. When the verse writes <b>a generalization and a detail and a generalization, you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail: Just as the explicit detail</b> mentions an awl, which is made <b>of metal, so too, any</b> utensil used for piercing must be made <b>of metal.</b>
By contrast, <b>Rabbi Yosei expounds</b> the verses by means of the hermeneutical principle of reading the verse as consisting of <b>amplifications and restrictions.</b> Accordingly, he learns that the term <b>“and you shall take” amplifies,</b> i.e., it includes any item that can be taken in one’s hand. The term <b>“an awl” restricts.</b> When the verse states <b>“through his ear and into the door,” it then amplifies again.</b> When the verse <b>amplifies, restricts, and amplifies, it has amplified</b> the <i>halakha</i> to include <b>everything</b> except one item.
<b>What has it amplified,</b> i.e., included beyond an awl? <b>It has amplified</b> the category to include <b>everything</b> that can pierce an ear. <b>What has it restricted</b> from inclusion in the category? It excludes only the method that is most dissimilar to the use of an awl, which is <b>a corrosive substance.</b> Producing a hole in the slave’s ear with a substance of this kind is not a valid form of piercing.
<b>The Master said</b> above: <b>“The awl,”</b> this serves <b>to include the large awl</b> for piercing. The Gemara asks: <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred</b> that this expression is referring to a large awl? The Gemara answers that this is <b>as Rava said</b> with regard to the verse: “The sinew of the thigh vein which is upon the hollow of <b>the thigh”</b> (Genesis 32:33), that this is referring to <b>the most important [<i>meyummenet</i>]</b> part of <b>the thigh.</b> The definite article indicates something clear and obvious. <b>Here too,</b> the term <b>“the awl”</b> is referring to <b>a special awl.</b>
