It was further stated in the above <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said: Yudan the Distinguished would teach: When they pierce</b> a slave <b>they pierce only the earlobe. And the Rabbis say: A Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest is not pierced</b> at all, <b>because</b> piercing <b>renders him blemished.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> let him be pierced and <b>be rendered blemished</b> and disqualified for Temple service. Why is it prohibited to do this? <b>Rabba bar Rav Sheila says: The verse states</b> concerning a Hebrew slave at the end of his servitude: <b>“And he shall return to his own family”</b> (Leviticus 25:41), i.e., <b>to his status in his family.</b> He must be able to return to the position he had as a member of his family. If he was rendered a blemished priest while a slave, once he is emancipated he can no longer return to his status as a priest who can perform the Temple service.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>a Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the permissibility <b>for his master to provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant</b> with whom to engage in sexual intercourse? The Gemara analyzes the two sides of the dilemma: Does one say that the <i>halakha</i> permitting a Hebrew slave to engage in intercourse with a Canaanite maidservant <b>is</b> a halakhic <b>novelty,</b> as a Jew is generally prohibited from engaging in intercourse with a gentile, and in light of this novelty, <b>it is no different</b> in the case of <b>priests and no different</b> in the case of <b>an Israelite?</b>
<b>Or perhaps</b> the case of <b>priests is different</b> from Israelites, <b>since the Torah includes additional mitzvot for them,</b> which do not apply to all Jews. Therefore, it is prohibited for a priest to engage in sexual intercourse with a Canaanite maidservant, despite the fact she is permitted to a non-priest. The <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to this issue. <b>Rav said: It is permitted</b> for the master to provide him with a Canaanite maidservant, <b>and Shmuel said it is prohibited.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said to Rav Anan: When you were</b> studying <b>in the house of Mar Shmuel</b> did <b>you play with tokens [<i>iskumadri</i>]?</b> Didn’t you take your studies seriously? <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>you do not say</b> a proof <b>to him from that</b> which we learned: <b>And the Rabbis say: A Hebrew slave</b> who is <b>a priest is not pierced</b> at all <b>because</b> piercing <b>renders him blemished.</b>
Rav Naḥman explains the proof: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>if his master cannot provide him</b> with <b>a Canaanite maidservant,</b> it is not even relevant to suggest that a slave of priestly lineage could be pierced, as the fact that he cannot be pierced <b>could be derived</b> from another point, <b>as I require</b> the slave to say: <b>“I love my master, my wife, and my children”</b> (Exodus 21:5), <b>and</b> that declaration <b>cannot</b> be issued by a priest if his master may not provide him with a Canaanite maidservant. And <b>nothing more</b> can be answered to this proof. The reason given by the Rabbis proves that a Canaanite maidservant can be provided even to a priest.
Similarly, <b>a dilemma was raised before them: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the permissibility <b>for a priest</b> who goes to war to engage in intercourse <b>with a beautiful woman</b> captured in that war? Does one say that the case of a beautiful woman <b>is a novelty</b> in that the Torah permits a man to engage in intercourse with a gentile woman? Consequently, it <b>is no different</b> in the case of <b>a priest and no different</b> in the case of <b>an Israelite,</b> as both are permitted to engage in intercourse with this woman. <b>Or perhaps</b> the case of <b>priests is different, since</b> the Torah <b>includes additional mitzvot for them? Rav said:</b> It is <b>permitted, and Shmuel said:</b> It is <b>prohibited.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>With regard to the first act of sexual intercourse</b> between the soldier priest and the gentile woman, <b>everyone agrees that</b> it is permitted, <b>as the Torah spoke only in response to the evil inclination,</b> and the evil inclination of a priest is as strong as that of an Israelite. This passage serves to prevent intercourse performed in a prohibited manner, which is relevant to a priest as well.
<b>When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to the second act of sexual intercourse.</b> Is a priest permitted to bring the captive into his house, convert her, and marry her? <b>Rav said</b> it is <b>permitted, and Shmuel said</b> it is <b>prohibited.</b> Their reasoning is as follows: <b>Rav said</b> it is <b>permitted: Since</b> she was <b>permitted</b> to him once, she remains <b>permitted</b> to him. <b>And Shmuel said</b> it is <b>prohibited, as</b> ultimately <b>she is a convert, and a convert is not fit to</b> marry <b>a priest.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of this dispute. <b>With regard to the second act of intercourse everyone agrees that it is prohibited, as she is a convert,</b> and a priest may not marry a convert. <b>When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to the first act of intercourse. Rav said</b> it is <b>permitted, as the Torah spoke only in response to the evil inclination. And Shmuel said it is prohibited,</b> as <b>any</b> situation <b>that one can read with regard to it: “Then you shall bring her home to your house”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:12), <b>one</b> can also <b>read</b> and fulfill <b>with regard to</b> the earlier command of: <b>“And see among the captives</b> a beautiful woman, and you have a desire for her, and would take her to you as a wife” (Deuteronomy 21:11). Conversely, <b>any</b> situation <b>that one cannot read with regard to it: “Then you shall bring her home to your house,”</b> i.e., if the soldier may not marry her, <b>one does not read with regard to it: “And sees among the captives,”</b> and one may not engage in sexual intercourse with her.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to a beautiful captive, the verse states: <b>“And sees among the captives,”</b> teaching that this <i>halakha</i> applies only if he notices her <b>when she is a captive.</b> The expression <b>“a woman”</b> teaches that she is permitted <b>even</b> if she is <b>a married woman.</b> The phrase <b>“a beautiful woman”</b> indicates that <b>the Torah</b> here <b>spoke only in response to the evil inclination,</b> as it is due to her beauty that he desired her. And why does the Torah permit this? <b>It is preferable for Jews to eat the meat</b>

Daf 22a

<b>of dying animals</b> that were <b>slaughtered, and let them not eat the meat of dying animals</b> that were not slaughtered but which will become <b>carcasses.</b> In other words, it is preferable for this act to be performed in a somewhat permitted way rather than in a manner that is entirely prohibited. The expression: <b>“And you have a desire</b> for her and would take her to you as a wife” (Deuteronomy 21:11), teaches that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even if she is not pretty,</b> as this is a subjective judgment dependent on one’s desire. The term <b>“for her”</b> indicates that he may take her, <b>but not her and another</b> woman. A soldier is allowed to take only one captive in this manner.
The phrase <b>“and would take her”</b> teaches: <b>You have</b> the ability to <b>take her,</b> i.e., to marry her. <b>“To you as a wife”</b> teaches <b>that he may not take two women, one for him and one for his father,</b> or <b>one for him and one for his son.</b> The verse: <b>“Then you shall bring her</b> home into your house” (Deuteronomy 21:12), <b>teaches that he should not pressure her</b> to engage in sexual intercourse <b>during the war,</b> but he should first take her into his home.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> It is stated with regard to a pierced slave: <b>“But if</b> the slave <b>shall say [<i>amor yomar</i>]:</b> I love my master, my wife, and my children, I will not go out free” (Exodus 21:5). The repeated verb teaches that he is not pierced <b>unless he says</b> this statement <b>and repeats</b> it. If <b>he said at the beginning</b> of his <b>six</b> years of service that he wants to be pierced, <b>but he did not say</b> it <b>at the end of six</b> years, <b>he is not pierced, as it is stated: “I will not go out free,”</b> i.e., he is not pierced <b>unless he says</b> it <b>when he leaves.</b>
If <b>he said</b> this statement <b>at the end of six</b> years <b>but did not say</b> it <b>at the beginning of</b> his <b>six</b> years, he is likewise <b>not pierced, as it is stated: “If the slave shall say [<i>amor yomar</i>],”</b> which indicates that he is not pierced <b>unless he states</b> it <b>while he is</b> still <b>a slave.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> above: If <b>he said</b> it <b>at the beginning of</b> his <b>six</b> years <b>and he did not say</b> it <b>at the end of six</b> years, <b>he is not pierced, as it is stated: “I will not go out free.”</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> does the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> learn this <i>halakha</i> <b>specifically from</b> the phrase <b>“I will not go out free”? Let him derive</b> it from the fact <b>that we require</b> another condition. He has to be able to say: <b>“I love my master, my wife, and my children”</b> (Exodus 21:5) in order to become a pierced slave, <b>and</b> he <b>cannot</b> say this, as at the start of the six years he does not yet have children from the Canaanite maidservant his master provided for him.
<b>And furthermore,</b> the <i>baraita</i> states that if <b>he said</b> this statement <b>at the end of six</b> years <b>but did not say</b> it <b>at the beginning of</b> his <b>six</b> years, he is likewise <b>not pierced, as it is stated “the slave.” Is that to say</b> that <b>he is not a slave at the end of six</b> years? <b>Rava said: What</b> is the meaning of: <b>At the beginning of six?</b> This is not referring to the actual beginning of his six years of service, but <b>to the beginning of</b> the <b>last <i>peruta</i>,</b> i.e., when he reaches the start of his final stage of work worth one <i>peruta</i>, when he is still a slave. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>At the end of six? At the end of</b> the <b>last <i>peruta</i>.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If the slave <b>has a wife and children and his master does not have a wife and children, he is not pierced, as it is stated: “Because he loves you and your house”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:16). The word “house” is referring to a wife and children, and therefore if the master does not have a wife and children the verse cannot be fulfilled, and the slave is not pierced. Similarly, if <b>his master has a wife and children and he does not have a wife and children, he is not pierced, as it is stated: “I love my master, my wife, and my children”</b> (Exodus 21:5).
Furthermore, if <b>he loves his master but his master does not love him, he is not pierced, as it is stated: “Because he fares well with you”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:16), which indicates that it is good for both of them to be with each other. If <b>his master loves him but he does not love his master, he is not pierced, as it is stated: “Because he loves you.”</b> If <b>he is ill and his master is not ill, he is not pierced, as it is stated: “Because he fares well with you,”</b> which excludes a sick person. Similarly, if <b>his master is ill and he is not ill, he is not pierced, as it is stated “with you,”</b> which equates the well-being of the pair.
<b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye raised a dilemma:</b> If <b>both of them are ill, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we require</b> only that the slave be <b>“with you,”</b> i.e., in the same condition as the master, <b>and that is</b> the case <b>here,</b> as they are both ill, and the slave can be pierced? <b>Or perhaps we require “because he fares well with you,”</b> i.e., it must be good for both of them, <b>and that is not</b> the case <b>here,</b> as they are both ill. If so, he cannot be pierced. No answer was found, and therefore the Gemara says that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states concerning a Hebrew slave: <b>“Because he fares well with you,”</b> which teaches that the slave should be <b>with you,</b> i.e., treated as your equal, <b>in food,</b> meaning that his food must be of the same quality as yours, and <b>with you in drink.</b> This means <b>that there shall not</b> be a situation in <b>which you eat fine bread and he eats inferior bread,</b> bread from coarse flour mixed with bran, which is low quality. There shall not be a situation in which <b>you drink aged wine and he drinks</b> inferior <b>new wine.</b> There shall not be a situation in which <b>you sleep</b> comfortably <b>on</b> bedding made from <b>soft sheets and he sleeps on straw. From here</b> the Sages <b>stated: Anyone who acquires a Hebrew slave</b> is considered <b>like one who acquires a master for himself,</b> because he must be careful that the slave’s living conditions are equal to his own.
<b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to a verse that deals with the emancipation of a slave: <b>“Then he shall go out from you, he and his children with him”</b> (Leviticus 25:41). <b>Rabbi Shimon said:</b> This verse is puzzling, as, <b>if he is sold, are his sons and daughters sold?</b> Rather, <b>from here</b> it is derived that <b>his master is obligated to</b> provide <b>sustenance for his children,</b> and when the slave is emancipated his sons are released as well. <b>You say something similar</b> with regard to the verse: <b>“If he is married then his wife shall go out with him”</b> (Exodus 21:3). <b>Rabbi Shimon said: If he is sold, is his wife sold?</b> Rather, <b>from here</b> it is derived <b>that his master is obligated to</b> provide <b>sustenance for his wife.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And it is necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to mention both cases, <b>as if it</b> had <b>taught us</b> only that the master is required to provide sustenance for the slave’s <b>children,</b> one might say that this is <b>because they are not fit to work and eat.</b> Since they are unable to support themselves, the master is required to support them. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>his wife, who can eat and work,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>she should work and eat</b> in payment for her work, and the master is not required to support her for free.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>baraita</i> had <b>taught us</b> only about <b>his wife,</b> one might say that the master is required to support her <b>since it is not her manner to circulate</b> and collect charity, as she is too embarrassed to do this. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>his children, since it is their manner to circulate</b> and beg, i.e., this is not beneath their dignity, one might <b>say no,</b> he is not required to support them. Therefore it is <b>necessary</b> to issue both rulings.
<b>The Sages taught:</b>

Daf 22b

<b>Had</b> the verse <b>stated: His ear to the door, I would say: He should pierce, opposite his ear, into the door</b> alone. In other words, with regard to <b>the door, yes,</b> it should be pierced, but <b>his ear</b> itself, <b>no,</b> it should not be pierced. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how could it even be suggested that <b>his ear</b> should <b>not</b> be pierced? <b>But isn’t it written: “And his master shall pierce his ear with an awl”</b> (Exodus 21:6)?
<b>Rather, I would say</b> that the master <b>should pierce his ear outside,</b> i.e., not at the door, <b>and he should place it</b> afterward <b>on the door, and</b> then <b>he should pierce opposite his ear on the door.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall take the awl and place it <b>through his ear and into the door”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:17). <b>How so? He bores through</b> his ear <b>until he reaches the door.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> adds: Since the verse states <b>“door,” I</b> would <b>derive</b> that this applies to any door, regardless of <b>whether</b> it is <b>detached</b> from its doorpost or <b>whether it is not detached.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Then his master shall bring him to the court, and shall bring him to the door, or to the <b>doorpost”</b> (Exodus 21:6): <b>Just as a doorpost is upright</b> and attached, <b>so too, a door</b> must be <b>upright</b> and attached to the doorpost.
<b>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai would expound this verse as a type of decorative wreath [<i>ḥomer</i>],</b> i.e., as an allegory: <b>Why is the ear different from all the other limbs in the body,</b> as the ear alone is pierced? <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said:</b> This <b>ear heard My voice on Mount Sinai when I said: “For to Me the children of Israel are slaves”</b> (Leviticus 25:55), which indicates: <b>And</b> they should <b>not</b> be <b>slaves to slaves. And</b> yet <b>this</b> man <b>went and</b> willingly <b>acquired a master for himself.</b> Therefore, <b>let</b> this ear <b>be pierced.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>would</b> likewise <b>expound this verse as a type of decorative wreath: Why are the door and a doorpost different from all other objects in the house,</b> that the piercing is performed with them? <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: The door and the doorpost were witnesses in Egypt when I passed over the lintel and</b> when I passed <b>over the two doorposts</b> of houses in which there were Jews (Exodus, chapter 12), <b>and I said: “For to Me the children of Israel are slaves,” and</b> they should <b>not</b> be <b>slaves to slaves. And I delivered them</b> at that time <b>from slavery to freedom, and</b> yet <b>this</b> man <b>went and acquired a master for himself.</b> Therefore, <b>let him be pierced before them,</b> as they are witnesses that he violated God’s will.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A Canaanite slave is acquired by</b> means of <b>money, by</b> means of <b>a document, or by</b> means of the master <b>taking possession</b> of him. <b>And he can acquire himself,</b> i.e., his freedom, <b>by</b> means of <b>money</b> given <b>by others,</b> i.e., other people can give money to his master, <b>and by</b> means of <b>a bill</b> of manumission if he accepts it <b>by himself.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> The slave can be freed <b>by</b> means of <b>money</b> given <b>by himself, and by</b> means of <b>a bill</b> of manumission if it is accepted <b>by others, provided that the money</b> he gives <b>belongs to others,</b> not to him. This is because the slave cannot possess property, as anything owned by a slave is considered his master’s.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that these are the modes by which a slave can be acquired? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written</b> with regard to Canaanite slaves: <b>“And you shall bequeath them to your children as an ancestral inheritance”</b> (Leviticus 25:46). <b>The verse juxtaposes</b> Canaanite slaves <b>to an ancestral field: Just as an ancestral field can be acquired by</b> means of <b>money, by</b> means of <b>a document, or by</b> means of the owner <b>taking possession</b> of it, <b>so too, a Canaanite slave can be acquired by</b> means of <b>money, by</b> means of <b>a document, or by</b> means of the master <b>taking possession</b> of him.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, perhaps one can interpret this juxtaposition differently: <b>Just as an ancestral field returns to its owners in the Jubilee</b> Year, <b>so too a Canaanite slave returns to his</b> prior <b>owners in the Jubilee</b> Year. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Of them you may take your slaves forever”</b> (Leviticus 25:46), which indicates that the sale is permanent.
A Sage <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that a Canaanite slave can <b>also</b> be acquired <b>by</b> means of symbolic <b>exchange,</b> i.e., a <i>pro forma</i> act of acquisition performed by the giving of an item, usually a kerchief, effecting the transfer of ownership of an article. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why doesn’t <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna mention acquisition through symbolic exchange? The Gemara answers: He <b>teaches</b> only the effectiveness of <b>modes</b> of acquisition <b>which are not</b> effective in transferring the ownership <b>of movable property,</b> as it is a novelty that these are effective, as one may have thought that a slave can be acquired only in the same manner as movable property is acquired. He does <b>not teach</b> the effectiveness of <b>modes</b> of acquisition <b>which are</b> effective in transferring the ownership <b>of movable property,</b> as it is not a novelty that a slave can be acquired in that manner.
<b>Shmuel says: A Canaanite slave can be acquired by</b> means of <b>pulling,</b> as can movable property. <b>How</b> is pulling performed in the case of a slave? If the master <b>took him by force and</b> the slave <b>came to him, he has</b> thereby <b>acquired him.</b> But if the master <b>called him and he came to him</b> willingly, <b>he has not acquired him.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna, it is clear why he did not list pulling as a mode of acquisition, as <b>he</b> does <b>not teach</b> the effectiveness of <b>modes</b> of acquisition <b>that are</b> effective in transferring the ownership <b>of movable property;</b> he <b>teaches</b> only the effectiveness of <b>modes</b> of acquisition <b>that are not</b> effective in transferring the ownership <b>of movable property.</b> Pulling is effective with movable property. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i>,</b> who taught the mode of symbolic exchange, <b>let him teach pulling</b> as well. The Gemara answers: <b>When he teaches</b> his <i>baraita</i>, which includes acquisition through symbolic exchange, he teaches the effectiveness of <b>modes</b> of acquisition <b>that are</b> effective in transferring the ownership of <b>both land and movable property. He does not teach</b> the effectiveness of <b>pulling, which is</b> effective in transferring the ownership <b>of movable property</b> but <b>is not</b> effective in transferring the ownership <b>of land.</b>
The Gemara returns to analyze Shmuel’s statement: <b>How</b> does one acquire a slave through pulling? If the master <b>took him by force and he came to him,</b> he has <b>acquired him.</b> If <b>he called him and he came to him,</b> he has <b>not acquired him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> has he <b>not</b> acquired him if <b>he called him? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How</b> is an animal acquired <b>through passing?</b> If <b>he grabbed it by its hoof,</b> or <b>by its hair,</b> or <b>by the saddle on it,</b> or <b>by the load [<i>shalif</i> ] on it,</b> or <b>by the bit [<i>bifrumbiya</i>] in its mouth,</b> or <b>by the bell on its neck, he has acquired it.</b>
<b>How</b> is an animal acquired <b>by pulling?</b> If <b>he calls it and it comes, or he</b> if <b>hits it with a stick and it runs before him, once it lifts a foreleg and a hind leg</b> from where it was standing, he <b>acquires it. Rabbi Asi, and some say Rabbi Aḥa, says:</b> It is not enough if the animal lifts its feet. Rather, one does not acquire it <b>until it walks</b> the distance of <b>its full height in the presence of</b> the one acquiring it. In any event, this indicates that calling is an effective use of the mode of pulling.
The Sages <b>say</b> in response that there is a difference between the acquisition of a slave and that of an animal. <b>An animal walks by the will of its owner,</b> as it is domesticated and follows the orders of its master. Consequently, if it comes when called it is as though it was pulled. By contrast, <b>a slave walks by his own will.</b> Consequently, even if a slave comes when called, this cannot be considered acquisition through pulling, as the master has performed no act of acquisition. <b>Rav Ashi said: A slave who is a minor is considered like an animal.</b> Since he has no will of his own, he can be acquired through calling, like an animal.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i> 1:5): <b>How</b> does one acquire a slave <b>though possession?</b> If the slave <b>removes</b> the master’s <b>shoe,</b> or <b>carries his garments after him to the bathhouse,</b> or <b>undresses him,</b> or <b>bathes him,</b> or <b>anoints him,</b> or <b>scrubs</b> the oil off him, or <b>dresses him,</b> or <b>puts on his shoes, or lifts him,</b> the master <b>acquires him. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Acquisition through the mode of <b>possession should not be considered greater than</b> acquisition using the mode of <b>lifting, as lifting acquires</b> property <b>in any situation.</b> With regard to this last statement the Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>saying</b> here? The first <i>tanna</i> also said that a slave can be acquired by lifting.
<b>Rav Ashi says</b> that one can infer from the statement of the first <i>tanna</i>: If a slave <b>lifts his master,</b> the master <b>acquires him,</b> as he is performing labor for the master. But if <b>his master lifts</b> the slave, the master <b>does not acquire him,</b> as the slave has not performed labor for his master. With regard to this <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> Acquisition through <b>possession should not be greater than</b> acquisition through <b>lifting, as lifting acquires</b> property <b>in any situation.</b> Consequently, one can acquire a slave even by lifting him.
The Gemara asks: <b>Now that you said</b> that if a slave <b>lifts his master,</b> the master <b>acquires him,</b> consider the following ramification of this ruling: <b>If that is so, let a Canaanite maidservant be acquired by</b> means of <b>sexual intercourse</b> with the master, as it is possible to claim she lifts him during the act of intercourse. The Gemara answers: <b>When we say</b> that one acquires a slave through the labor the slave performs for him, that applies to a situation where <b>this</b> master <b>benefits and that</b> slave <b>suffers.</b> In this manner the master exercises his authority over the slave. <b>Here,</b> with regard to sexual intercourse, <b>it is</b> a case where <b>this</b> master <b>benefits and this</b> Canaanite maidservant likewise <b>benefits.</b> Since both sides derive benefit, it cannot be seen as an act of acquisition.
The Gemara asks: If he engages in intercourse <b>in an atypical manner,</b> i.e., anal intercourse, with her, <b>what can be said?</b> In that case the woman does not benefit from the intercourse. <b>Rav Aḥai bar Adda of</b> the place called <b>Aḥa said: Who will tell us,</b> i.e., it is not obvious, <b>that there is no benefit for both of them,</b> i.e., there is benefit only for the man, when they engage in intercourse in an atypical manner? <b>And furthermore, it is written: “Lyings with a woman”</b> (Leviticus 18:22). The plural form indicates that there are two ways of engaging in sexual intercourse with a woman: In this manner <b>the verse compares typical</b> sexual intercourse <b>to</b> intercourse in <b>an atypical manner.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Yehuda from India was a convert who had no heirs.</b> When <b>he became ill Mar Zutra entered to ask</b> about his health. When he <b>saw that his condition intensified,</b> i.e., that he was about to die, Mar Zutra <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda’s <b>slave: Remove my shoes and take them to my house.</b> He wanted to acquire the slave upon the death of his master, as when a convert without heirs dies, the first person to claim his property acquires it. The Gemara comments: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this slave <b>was an adult man,</b>

Daf 23a

and <b>this</b> person, Rabbi Yehuda from India, <b>departed to death, and that</b> individual, Mar Zutra, <b>departed to life</b> by receiving a slave.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this slave <b>was a minor, and</b> Mar Zutra did <b>not</b> act <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a convert who dies</b> without heirs <b>and Jews plundered his property,</b> as it is considered ownerless, <b>and among</b> his possessions <b>were slaves,</b> then, <b>whether</b> the slaves were <b>adults or minors, they acquire</b> ownership of <b>themselves</b> and become <b>freemen,</b> as they can acquire themselves from the ownerless property. <b>Abba Shaul says: Adult</b> slaves <b>acquire</b> ownership of <b>themselves</b> and become <b>freemen.</b> But with regard to <b>minor</b> slaves, <b>anyone who takes possession of them acquires them.</b> According to the opinion of Abba Shaul, Mar Zutra did not have to hasten to acquire the slave during Rabbi Yehuda’s lifetime before the slave would acquire himself. He could have waited until Rabbi Yehuda died before acquiring the slave.
§ The mishna teaches that a slave can acquire himself <b>by</b> means of <b>money,</b> and Rabbi Meir rules that this money must be given by others. The Gemara comments: This ruling indicates that <b>with money</b> given <b>by others, yes,</b> the slave can be freed in this manner, <b>but not by</b> giving money <b>himself.</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>With what are we dealing? If we say</b> that this is referring to emancipating the Canaanite slave <b>without his consent,</b> that creates a difficulty. <b>After all, we have heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir</b> is the one <b>who says: It is against the slave’s interest to leave his master’s authority for freedom,</b> as he thereby loses out on certain benefits; <b>and we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One can act in a person’s interest in his absence, but one can act against a person’s interest only in his presence.</b> How can one act against the slave’s interest and free him without his consent?
<b>Rather,</b> it <b>is obvious</b> that this slave was freed <b>with his consent, and</b> the mishna <b>teaches us this:</b> With money given <b>by others, yes,</b> the slave can be freed in this manner, but <b>by</b> giving money <b>himself, no,</b> he cannot be freed in this manner, despite his consent. <b>Evidently, a slave has no acquisition without his master.</b> It is impossible for a slave to perform an independent act of acquisition, as everything acquired by him immediately belongs to his master. Consequently, he cannot be in possession of money with which he can acquire himself. Instead, the money must be given to his owner by somebody else.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: He can be freed <b>by</b> means of <b>a bill</b> of manumission if he accepts it <b>by himself.</b> The Gemara analyzes this ruling: If he accepts it <b>by himself, yes,</b> but if it is accepted <b>by others, no,</b> he cannot acquire his freedom in this manner. <b>And if</b> this document is produced <b>with</b> the slave’s <b>consent,</b> as claimed above, <b>why</b> is it <b>not</b> effective if it is accepted <b>by others?</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>And if you would say</b> in response: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: If he accepts it <b>by himself?</b> This means that in addition to being freed if the bill of manumission is accepted by others, <b>he can also</b> be freed if he accepts it <b>by himself, and</b> according to <b>this</b> interpretation the mishna <b>teaches us this,</b> that <b>his bill</b> of manumission <b>and his ability</b> to acquire himself <b>come simultaneously.</b> In other words, although he did not have the legal power to acquire himself while he was still a slave, when he receives his bill of manumission he attains this ability at that same moment. The Gemara explains why this interpretation of the mishna is problematic: <b>But</b> Rabbi Meir <b>did not teach this</b> ruling, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A slave can be freed <b>by</b> means of <b>a bill</b> of manumission if he accepts it <b>by himself, but not</b> if it is accepted <b>by others;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>Abaye said: Actually,</b> according to Rabbi Meir the mishna is referring to a case where the master received money <b>without</b> the slave’s <b>consent, and</b> acquisition effected with the giving of <b>money is different: Since it acquires him against his will</b> from another master, as the slave’s consent is not necessary in that case, it likewise <b>acquires him for himself against his will.</b> His consent is not required, despite the fact that it is against his interest to be freed.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> that a slave can be freed with the giving of money without his consent is predicated on the <i>halakha</i> that he can be acquired by means of the giving of money to his previous master without his consent, he should <b>also</b> be freed with <b>a document</b> if it is accepted by others without his consent. The Gemara answers: <b>This document is discrete, and this document is discrete,</b> i.e., the comparison between the acquisition of a slave and his emancipation is invalid in the case of a document, as a document of sale is not similar to a bill of manumission.
The Gemara asks: <b>Here too, this money is discrete and this money is discrete,</b> as the money is given for a different purpose in the cases of acquisition and manumission. The Gemara answers: <b>In any event, the coin</b> itself <b>is one,</b> i.e., there is no noticeable difference between the coin used for acquisition of a slave and one that would be used for emancipating him. The same cannot be said with regard to documents, as particular texts serve specific purposes, and the same document could not be used for both acquiring a slave and emancipating him.
<b>Rava said</b> the following distinction: With regard to emancipation by means of <b>money, his master’s receipt</b> of the money <b>causes him</b> to be freed, not the giving of the money by others. Therefore, they are not considered to have harmed the slave without his consent. By contrast, in the case of <b>a document,</b> the <b>receipt</b> of the document <b>by others</b> on behalf of the slave <b>causes him</b> to be freed, and one can incur liability for another person only in his presence.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The slave can be freed <b>by</b> means of <b>money</b> given <b>by himself.</b> The Gemara analyzes this ruling: <b>By</b> means of <b>money</b> given <b>by himself, yes,</b> he can be emancipated in this manner, but with money given <b>by others, no,</b> he cannot be emancipated in this manner. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> not? <b>Although</b> this was <b>indeed</b> performed <b>without</b> the slave’s <b>consent, after all, we heard that the Rabbis say: It is in</b> a slave’s <b>interest to go out from the master’s authority to freedom. And we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One can act in a person’s interest in his absence, but one can act against a person’s interest only in his presence.</b> Why, then, isn’t he freed when others give the money, considering that this change of status is to his advantage?
<b>And if you would say: What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>By</b> means of <b>money</b> given <b>by himself?</b> This means that not only can he be redeemed by means of money given to others but he can be redeemed <b>even by</b> means of money given to <b>himself, and it teaches us that a slave has</b> the ability to receive <b>an acquisition without his master. If so, say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: He can be freed <b>by</b> means of <b>a bill</b> of manumission if it is accepted <b>by others.</b> This indicates: If it is accepted by others <b>but not</b> if he accepts it <b>by himself. And</b> yet <b>we maintain</b> that according to the Rabbis <b>his bill</b> of manumission <b>and his ability to acquire</b> his freedom <b>come simultaneously.</b> If so, why can’t he be freed through a document he accepts by himself?
<b>And if you would say: What</b> is the meaning of: If it is accepted <b>by others?</b> This means that not only can he be emancipated if he accepts the bill of manumission by himself, but he can <b>even</b> be freed if it is accepted <b>by others, and</b> the mishna <b>teaches us this:</b> That <b>it is in a slave’s interest to go out from the master’s authority to freedom. If so,</b> there is no difference between emancipation by means of money and emancipation by means of a document, and therefore <b>let us combine them and teach them</b> together and say: A slave can be freed <b>by</b> means of <b>money and by</b> means of <b>a bill</b> of manumission, <b>whether by others</b> or <b>whether by himself.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is clear that there is a difference between money and a document. When he is emancipated <b>by</b> means of <b>money,</b> a slave can be freed <b>whether</b> by means of money given <b>by others</b> or <b>whether</b> by means of money given <b>by himself.</b> In the case <b>of a bill</b> of manumission, he can be emancipated if it is accepted <b>by others but not</b> if he accepts it <b>by himself. And</b> this latter clause <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> A slave can <b>also</b> be freed <b>with a bill</b> of manumission if it is accepted <b>by others but not</b> if he accepts it <b>by himself. And</b> there are <b>three disputes with regard to the matter.</b> There are the opinions of Rabbi Meir, the Rabbis, and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.
<b>Rabba said: What is the reason of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar? He derives</b> this by means of a verbal analogy, understanding the meaning of <b>“to her [<i>lah</i>],”</b> written with regard to a maidservant in the verse: “Nor was freedom given to her” (Leviticus 19:20), <b>from</b> the meaning of <b>“for her [<i>lah</i>],”</b> written with regard to <b>a wife:</b> “And he writes for her a bill of divorce” (Deuteronomy 24:3). <b>Just as a woman</b> is not divorced <b>until</b> the husband <b>moves</b> the <b>bill of divorce</b> from his domain <b>to a domain that is not his,</b> and the bill of divorce is ineffective as long as it remains in his domain; <b>so too, a slave</b> is not freed <b>unless</b> the master <b>moves</b> the <b>bill</b> of manumission <b>to a domain that is not his.</b> Since the slave belongs to him, the document will remain the master’s even if he gives it to the slave. Therefore, he can be freed by means of a document only through other people who receive the document on his behalf.
<b>Rabba raises a dilemma:</b>

Daf 23b

<b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> in the case of <b>a Canaanite slave, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the possibility <b>that</b> a slave <b>can appoint an agent to accept his bill</b> of manumission <b>from the hand of his master?</b> Does one say that <b>since</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar <b>derives</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“<i>lah</i>”</b> and <b>“<i>lah</i>” from a woman,</b> which teaches that a slave can be freed with a document, therefore, a slave is also <b>like a woman</b> in that he too can appoint an agent?
<b>Or perhaps,</b> in the case of <b>a woman, as she can accept her bill of divorce</b> herself, <b>she can also appoint an agent,</b> whereas <b>a slave</b> is different, <b>as he cannot accept his bill</b> of manumission himself, and consequently <b>he cannot appoint an agent either. After raising the dilemma,</b> Rabba <b>subsequently resolved it:</b> Since Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar derives the verbal analogy of <b>“<i>lah</i>”</b> and <b>“<i>lah</i>” from a woman,</b> a slave is also treated <b>like a woman</b> with regard to his ability to appoint an agent.
The Gemara comments: <b>But</b> consider <b>that which Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says</b> with regard to the service in the Temple: <b>These priests are the agents of the Merciful One,</b> i.e., they perform the Temple service as the emissaries of God. <b>As if it enters your mind</b> that <b>they are our agents, is there anything that we cannot do but</b> agents <b>can do</b> on our behalf? Since it is prohibited for non-priests to serve in the Temple, priests cannot be considered the agents of the Jewish people.
This statement leads to the following question: <b>But</b> is it <b>not</b> true that an agent can be appointed to perform a task that cannot be done by the one who sent him? <b>But</b> according to Rava’s conclusion there is the case of <b>a slave, who is unable to accept his bill</b> of manumission <b>himself, and</b> yet <b>he can appoint an agent</b> to receive it for him.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>And</b> that <b>is not so.</b> The difference between the cases is that <b>an Israelite is not involved in the <i>halakhot</i> of offerings at all,</b> as a non-priest is never permitted to sacrifice offerings. By contrast, <b>a slave is</b> somewhat <b>involved in bills</b> of manumission, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It seems that a slave can accept the bill</b> of manumission <b>of another</b> slave <b>from the hand of the master of</b> that <b>other</b> slave. <b>But</b> he <b>cannot</b> accept a bill of manumission <b>from the hand of his own master,</b> who wishes to free another of his slaves. In this case there is no acquisition, as the document has not left the master’s property, as anything given to a slave is considered the property of his master. With regard to the issue at hand, since a slave can accept a bill of manumission, at least on behalf of another slave, the <i>halakhot</i> of these documents are relevant to him, and therefore he can appoint an agent to receive his bill of manumission.
§ The mishna teaches that according to Rabbi Meir the slave can be freed by means of money given by others, while the Rabbis hold that he can be freed by means of money given by himself, <b>provided that the money</b> he gives <b>belongs to others.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to this</b> principle, and <b>that Rabbi Meir maintains: There is no acquisition for a slave without his master,</b> i.e., a slave has no personal property and therefore his master immediately owns whatever the slave acquires, which means a slave cannot receive his redemption money himself. <b>And</b> similarly <b>there is no acquisition for a woman without her husband. And the Rabbis maintain: There is acquisition for a slave without his master, and there is acquisition for a woman without her husband.</b>
<b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said: Everyone agrees</b> that <b>there is no acquisition for a slave without his master, and there is no acquisition for a woman without her husband, and</b> so, <b>with what are we dealing here?</b> This is a unique case in <b>which another</b> individual <b>transferred one hundred dinars to</b> a slave <b>and said to him:</b> I am giving this to you <b>on the condition that your master has no rights to it.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the two opinions according to this explanation. <b>Rabbi Meir maintains</b> that <b>when</b> this third party <b>said to</b> the Canaanite slave: <b>Acquire</b> the money, the <b>slave acquires</b> it and <b>his master</b> immediately <b>acquires</b> it. <b>And when he said to him: On the condition</b> that your master has no rights to it, <b>he has said nothing to him,</b> i.e., his condition is ineffective. <b>And the Rabbis maintain</b> that <b>since he said to him: On the condition, his condition is effective</b> and the master does not acquire the money. Therefore, the slave owns this money, with which he can redeem himself.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar said:</b> In <b>a case like this, everyone agrees that</b> the <b>slave acquires</b> the money, <b>and his master</b> automatically <b>acquires</b> that which was acquired by the slave. <b>And with what are we dealing here,</b> in the dispute between the Sages and Rabbi Meir? This is referring to a case <b>where another</b> person <b>transferred one hundred dinars to him and said to him: On the condition that you are emancipated with it.</b>
The Gemara explains the dispute according to this interpretation. <b>Rabbi Meir maintains</b> that <b>when he said to him: Acquire</b> the money, the <b>slave acquires</b> it, <b>and his master</b> immediately <b>acquires</b> the one hundred dinars from him. <b>And when he said to him: On the condition, he has said nothing to him. And the Rabbis maintain: He</b> does <b>not transfer</b> the money <b>to</b> the slave himself, <b>as he said to him only: On the condition that you are emancipated with it.</b> In other words, he gave it to the slave only for him to hand over the money to his master for his emancipation. His condition is valid and the slave is emancipated.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> between one statement <b>of Rabbi Meir and</b> a second statement <b>of Rabbi Meir, and</b> it <b>raises a contradiction between</b> one statement of <b>the Rabbis</b> and a second statement of <b>the Rabbis. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 24a

<b>A woman may not redeem</b> her husband’s <b>second tithe without</b> adding <b>one-fifth</b> of its value to the redemption money, as is required from all those who redeem their own second tithe. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said in the name of Rabbi Meir: A woman may redeem second tithe without</b> adding <b>one-fifth.</b> The Gemara inquires: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that she redeems second tithe <b>with</b> her <b>husband’s money,</b> which he gave her for this purpose, <b>and the tithe</b> belongs <b>to</b> her <b>husband,</b> in this case <b>she acts</b> with <b>the agency of</b> her <b>husband.</b> Just as he is required to add one-fifth when he redeems his own second tithe, it is clear that she too must add one-fifth.
<b>But rather,</b> one might say that this is referring <b>to</b> a case where she uses <b>her money and</b> it is <b>his tithe.</b> This is also difficult, as in this case the Rabbis would agree that she is exempt from paying the additional fifth, as <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And if <b>a man</b> shall redeem any of his tithe” (Leviticus 27:31). The emphasis of the term “man” teaches: This applies to a man, <b>but</b> this does <b>not</b> apply to <b>a woman</b> who redeems her husband’s tithe.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> correct to say that we are dealing with <b>a case like this</b> following one: <b>Where another</b> person <b>transferred one hundred dinars to her, and said to her:</b> I am giving this to you <b>on the condition that you redeem</b> your husband’s <b>tithe with it? And</b> if so, <b>we heard them</b> say the <b>opposite</b> with regard to the issue of whether such a condition is effective. According to Rabbi Meir’s reasoning presented in the case of a slave, anything a woman acquires should be acquired by her husband, which would mean that it is as though her husband himself redeemed it. How, then, could Rabbi Meir rule that a woman redeems second tithe with adding one-fifth? Additionally, the Rabbis said that the money received by the slave is not immediately acquired by his master, and yet here they consider the money received by the wife as belonging to her husband.
<b>Abaye said: Reverse</b> the opinions in the case of redemption of tithes. <b>Rava said: Actually do not reverse</b> them, <b>and here, with regard to tithes, we are dealing with tithe she received from her father’s house</b> as an inheritance. <b>And Rabbi Meir</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Tithe is property</b> that belongs to the <b>Temple</b> treasury, <b>and</b> therefore <b>the husband does not acquire it,</b> unlike the regular property a woman brings to her marriage. Consequently, a woman can redeem it with her husband’s money without adding one-fifth, as the husband is not the owner of the tithe.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> conform <b>to their</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as they say: Tithe is common,</b> i.e., non-sacred, <b>property.</b> It is not owned by the Temple treasury. <b>And</b> consequently, the <b>husband acquires it</b> like other property of his wife, to whose profits he is entitled. <b>Therefore, she performs</b> with <b>the agency of</b> her <b>husband</b> and must add the fifth.
§ A Sage <b>taught:</b> A Canaanite slave <b>is emancipated through a tooth and an eye and</b> through permanent damage to other <b>extremities that do not regenerate</b> if they are severed. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, a tooth and an eye,</b> these body parts are explicitly <b>written,</b> as the Torah states clearly that if a master damages a tooth or blinds an eye the slave is emancipated (Exodus 21:26–27). <b>But from where do we</b> derive that if the master permanently damages other <b>extremities</b> the slave is likewise emancipated? The Gemara answers: These extremities are <b>similar to a tooth and an eye: Just as</b> the removal of <b>a tooth and an eye</b> leads to <b>exposed,</b> i.e., external, <b>blemishes that do not regenerate, so too,</b> the same applies to <b>all blemishes</b> caused by the slave’s master that are <b>exposed and that do not regenerate.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the examples of <b>a tooth and an eye are like two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., they teach the same matter, <b>and</b> there is a principle that <b>any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their <i>halakha</i> so that it can be applied to other cases. If so, a slave should be emancipated only for an injury to a tooth or an eye. The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to mention both a tooth and an eye, as neither <i>halakha</i> could not be derived from the other. Consequently, they are not considered to be like two verses that come as one. The Gemara elaborates: <b>As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>tooth, I would say</b> that <b>even</b>

Daf 24b

<b>a milk tooth,</b> a child’s tooth that will eventually fall out to be replaced by another, is included in this <i>halakha</i>. Therefore <b>the Merciful One writes “eye,”</b> to teach that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to a body part that does not regenerate, like an eye. <b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>“eye,” I would say</b> that <b>just as an eye was created with him</b> in the womb, <b>so too,</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>anything that was created with him</b> in the womb. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a tooth,</b> which grows later, perhaps he would <b>not</b> be emancipated if his master knocked it out. Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to mention both cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> the following argument: <b>“If</b> a man <b>smites”</b> (Exodus 21:26), is <b>a generalization; “a tooth” and “an eye”</b> are each <b>a detail.</b> If so, this should be read as <b>a generalization and a detail,</b> and the hermeneutical principle in a case of this kind is that <b>the generalization includes only what is</b> mentioned explicitly <b>in the detail.</b> Consequently, <b>a tooth and an eye are</b> included, but <b>not other matters.</b>
The Gemara answers that when each verse states: <b>“To freedom shall he send him”</b> (Exodus 21:26, 27), <b>it then generalized</b> again. Consequently, this should be read as <b>a generalization and a detail and a generalization.</b> In this case, the hermeneutical principle is that <b>you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail: Just as the explicit detail</b> is <b>an exposed blemish</b> that <b>does not regenerate</b> itself, <b>so too, any</b> body parts that are <b>exposed blemishes and that do not regenerate</b> themselves are included in this <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, one can limit this category even further: <b>Just as with the explicit details,</b> they are referring to <b>exposed blemishes and</b> the body part <b>is prevented from</b> performing <b>its</b> regular <b>function and does not regenerate, so too,</b> a slave should be emancipated as a result of an injury to <b>all exposed blemishes that do not regenerate and</b> where the body part <b>is prevented from</b> performing <b>its</b> regular <b>function. Why,</b> then, <b>is it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the master <b>pulled out his beard and dislocated a bone in</b> the slave’s jaw, <b>the slave is emancipated by means of</b> this injury. In this case there is no loss of function. The Gemara answers: <b>“To freedom shall he send him”</b> (Exodus 21:26–27), <b>is an amplification,</b> which includes an injury that is not exactly the same as the detail.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if it is an amplification,</b> which includes additional injuries, the slave should <b>also</b> be emancipated <b>even if he struck him on his hand and it withered,</b> i.e., became temporarily paralyzed, <b>but would eventually</b> be expected to <b>regenerate. Why,</b> then, <b>is it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>he struck him on his hand and</b> the hand <b>withered but</b> it <b>will eventually regenerate, the slave is not emancipated by means of</b> this injury? The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that even limbs that will eventually regain their function are included in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>what</b> purpose do the examples of <b>tooth and eye serve?</b> These two items that are explicitly stated in the verse would not exclude anything. Rather, only injuries similar to the details of an tooth and an eye are included, but not temporary injuries.
<b>The Sages taught: With regard to any of</b> the twenty-four extremities, if a master strikes his slave and injures him there, <b>the slave is emancipated by means of</b> these injuries, <b>and</b> he <b>requires a bill of manumission</b> from his master. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Meir says: He does not require</b> a bill of manumission. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: He requires</b> one. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: He does not require</b> one. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: He requires</b> one.
<b>Those who</b> discuss matters and <b>decide before the Sages say</b> the following compromise: <b>Rabbi Tarfon’s statement appears</b> correct <b>with regard to a tooth and an eye, since</b> in these cases <b>the Torah</b> explicitly <b>benefitted him.</b> Because his right to emancipation is stated explicitly in the verse, the slave does not require a bill of manumission. <b>And Rabbi Akiva’s statement</b> is reasonable <b>with regard to other limbs, since it is a rabbinic penalty.</b> The Gemara is puzzled by this claim: <b>Is it</b> a rabbinic <b>penalty? We interpret</b> the <b>verses,</b> and therefore this <i>halakha</i> applies to the other limbs by Torah law. <b>Rather,</b> these Sages meant that is necessary to give a bill of manumission <b>since it is a rabbinic interpretation</b> and is not written explicitly in the Torah.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Shimon? He derives</b> a verbal analogy between: <b>Sending away,</b> “to freedom shall he send him” (Exodus 21:26, 27), and: <b>Sending away,</b> “and sends her out of his house” (Deuteronomy 24:1), <b>from</b> the case of <b>a woman. Just as a woman</b> can be released from her husband only <b>by</b> means of <b>a document, so too, a slave</b> can <b>also</b> be released from his master only <b>by</b> means of <b>a document. And Rabbi Meir</b> would say that <b>if</b> the term <b>“freedom” was written at the end</b> of the phrase, i.e., if the verse had stated: He shall send him away to freedom, it would be <b>as you said,</b> that he must be given a bill of manumission before he can be emancipated. <b>Now that it is written “to freedom shall he send him,”</b> this indicates that <b>he is free from the beginning,</b> i.e., no additional act of emancipation is required.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Kamma</i> 9:26): If a slave owner <b>struck</b> his slave <b>on his eye and blinded him,</b> or <b>on his ear and deafened him, the slave is emancipated by means of these</b> injuries. If he struck <b>near his eye and</b> as a result <b>he does not see,</b> or <b>near his ear and he does not hear, the slave is not emancipated by means of these</b> injuries. <b>Rav Shemen said to Rav Ashi: Is this to say that a sound</b> that causes damage <b>is nothing?</b>
<b>But didn’t Rami bar Yeḥezkel teach</b> a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a rooster that stuck its head into the airspace of a glass vessel and crowed into it and</b> the noise <b>broke it,</b> its owner <b>pays the full</b> cost of the <b>damage</b> like a regular case of damage. <b>And Rav Yosef said</b> that the Sages of <b>Rav’s study hall say:</b> With regard to <b>a horse that neighed or a donkey that brayed and they</b> thereby <b>broke vessels in the house,</b> their owners must <b>pay</b> for <b>half</b> of <b>the damage.</b> Although these two examples are different, as one results in full payment and the other in half payment, it is clear that sound can be a source of liability for damages.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: A person is different, as, since he is</b> mentally <b>competent it is he who frightened himself.</b> It was not the physical sound that caused the damage but the slave’s subjective fear, which is not a direct result of the action. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Kamma</i> 6:16) that injury can result from being frightened: <b>One who frightens another</b> and causes him injury is <b>exempt according to human laws but liable according to the laws of Heaven. How so?</b> If <b>one shouted into</b> another’s <b>ear and deafened him,</b> he is <b>exempt.</b> But if <b>he held him and shouted into his ear and deafened him,</b> he is <b>liable</b> according to human laws as well, as he took physical hold of him. Once he physically took hold of him, he is liable for all the resultant damage.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Kamma</i> 9:9): In a case where the master <b>struck him on his eye and weakened</b> his vision without blinding him, or he struck him <b>on his tooth and loosened it, if he can use</b> the eye or the tooth <b>now,</b> the <b>slave is not emancipated by means of them. And if</b> he can <b>no</b> longer use them at all, then the <b>slave is emancipated by means of them. It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> clause in that <i>baraita</i>: In a case <b>where</b> the slave’s <b>eye was weak</b> prior to this incident, <b>and</b> the master <b>blinded it</b> entirely, or if the slave’s <b>tooth was loose and</b> his master <b>knocked it out, if he</b> was <b>able to use them before</b> the master struck him, the <b>slave is emancipated by means of them, and if not,</b> then the <b>slave is not emancipated by means of them.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state both <i>halakhot</i>, despite the fact that they apparently teach the same <i>halakha</i> that a weakened eye is not considered a significant injury, <b>as, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us</b> only <b>this first</b> <i>halakha</i>, I would say that he is emancipated, <b>because at the outset</b> his <b>vision was strong and now</b> his <b>vision is weak. But here,</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>where his vision was also weak at the outset,</b> I would <b>say</b> he is <b>not</b> emancipated if the master blinded him entirely, as his eye did not function properly even beforehand.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>tanna</i> had <b>taught us</b> only <b>this</b> second <i>halakha</i>, I would say that he is emancipated <b>because he blinded</b> him <b>entirely. But there,</b> where <b>he did not blind</b> him <b>entirely</b> I would <b>say no,</b> he is not emancipated, despite the fact that he weakened his vision. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state both <i>halakhot</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bava Kamma</i> 9:9): In a case <b>where his master was a doctor and</b> the slave <b>said to him to paint his eye</b> with a medicament, <b>and</b> the master <b>blinded it</b> in the process, or he asked him <b>to drill his</b> aching <b>tooth, and</b> the master <b>knocked it out,</b> the slave <b>laughs at the master and is emancipated. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that the verse: “And if a man smites the eye of his slave, or the eye of his maidservant, <b>and destroys it,</b> to freedom shall he send him for his eye’s sake” (Exodus 21:26), means that the slave is not emancipated <b>unless</b> the master <b>intends to destroy it.</b> If he intended to heal him, the slave is not freed, even if the master did, in fact, injure him.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis, what do they do with this</b> verse <b>“and destroys it”?</b> What do they derive from this phrase? The Gemara answers: <b>They require</b> it <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that in a case <b>where</b> the master <b>stuck his hand into the womb of his maidservant</b> to assist her in giving birth <b>and he blinded the fetus in her womb, he is exempt</b> and the fetus is not emancipated when born. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>As the verse states “and destroys it,”</b> meaning <b>unless he intends to destroy</b> it, and in this case he did not mean to touch the fetus’s eye.
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, would say that that <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived from</b> the fact that the verse could have said: <b>And destroys,</b> and instead said <b>“destroys it.” And the other</b> Sage, i.e., the Rabbis, how do they respond to this argument? <b>They do not expound</b> the difference between <b>“destroys”</b> and <b>“destroys it,”</b> i.e., they maintain that this is not a significant deviation from which one can derive a <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rav Sheshet says:</b> In a case <b>where</b> the slave’s <b>eye was blind and</b> the master <b>removed it</b> entirely, the <b>slave is emancipated by means of</b> this injury. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>He is</b> now <b>lacking a limb,</b> which is worse than a mere blemish.
<b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of a <i>baraita</i> also <b>taught:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of <b>unblemished status,</b> i.e., that an offering must not contain a blemish, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>male status</b> apply <b>to animal</b> offerings, <b>but</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>unblemished status and</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>male status</b> do <b>not</b> apply <b>to bird</b> offerings.
The Gemara comments: One <b>might</b> have thought that if one brings a bird <b>whose wing is dried,</b> or whose <b>leg is severed,</b> or whose <b>eye was removed,</b> that it too is acceptable as an offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And if his offering to the Lord is a burnt-offering <b>from birds”</b> (Leviticus 1:14). This phrase indicates that only some birds can be sacrificed as offerings, <b>but not all birds.</b> This teaches that a bird can be disqualified due to a blemish. For example, if a significant part of the bird is missing, e.g., a limb, the bird is not acceptable as an offering. This indicates that the actual loss of an eye is considered a greater blemish than blindness. Consequently, if his master takes out the slave’s blind eye, he is emancipated.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If the slave <b>had</b>

Daf 25a

<b>an extra</b> finger, i.e., six fingers on his hand, <b>and</b> the master <b>severed it,</b> the <b>slave is emancipated by means of</b> this injury. <b>Rav Huna says: And this</b> <i>halakha</i> applies <b>when</b> the finger <b>can be counted along the back of the hand,</b> i.e., the extra finger is on the same line as the others. If it protrudes from another spot, then it is not classified as a finger but a mere growth, and destroying it is not considered the removal of a limb.
§ The Gemara relates: <b>The Elders of</b> the city of <b>Nezonya did not come to Rav Ḥisda’s lecture.</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>said to Rav Hamnuna: Go</b> and <b>ostracize them [<i>tzaninhu</i>]</b> because they act disrespectfully toward the Sages. Rav Hamnuna <b>went</b> and <b>said to</b> the Elders of Nezonya: <b>What is the reason that the rabbis did not come to the lecture? They said to him: Why should we come, as we asked him</b> about <b>a matter and he did not resolve it for us.</b> We have nothing to learn from him. Rav Hamnuna <b>said to them: Have you asked me anything that I did not resolve for you?</b> Ask me your question.
<b>They raised</b> the following <b>dilemma before him:</b> With regard to <b>a slave whose master castrates his testicles, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is that considered an exposed blemish</b> that is sufficient to emancipate him <b>or not?</b> An answer to their dilemma <b>was not available to</b> Rav Hamnuna. <b>They said to him: What is your name? He said to them: Hamnuna. They said to him</b> in jest: You should <b>not</b> be called <b>Hamnuna,</b> a good hot fish; <b>rather,</b> your name should be <b>Karnuna,</b> a cold fish that is no longer tasty.
After this encounter Rav Hamnuna <b>came before Rav Ḥisda</b> and told him what had happened. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: They raised before you a dilemma</b> that can be resolved from <b>a <i>baraita</i>,</b> which was cited in connection to a mishna, and you did not know how to answer them. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 6:7): There are <b>twenty-four extremities in a person, none of which can become ritually impure due to unaffected skin.</b> The Torah states that if a leprous spot contains some healthy flesh, the person is immediately rendered impure (Leviticus 13:14). The <i>halakha</i> of unaffected skin does not apply to the extremities because the priest must be able to see the entirety of the untainted area at once. Due to the shape of the twenty-four extremities, it is impossible to see the entirety of the area from a single vantage point. Consequently, the <i>halakha</i> of unaffected skin does not apply to them.
<b>And these are</b> the twenty-four extremities: <b>The extremities of the fingers and toes,</b> twenty in total, <b>and the extremities of the ears, and the extremity of the nose, and the extremity of the penis, and the extremities of the nipples of a woman. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> the nipples <b>of a man</b> are included. <b>And it is taught in that regard</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A slave is emancipated for</b> injuries to <b>all of them.</b> The body parts listed with regard to leprosy are the same ones that, when injured, lead to the emancipation of a slave. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Also, the castration</b> of a slave by his master entails his freedom. <b>Ben Azzai says: The tongue</b> is <b>also</b> considered an exposed body part, as it is exposed when one speaks. Consequently, if the master severs his slave’s tongue, the slave goes free.
<b>The Master said</b> above that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Also castration.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Castration of what? If we say</b> that it is referring to <b>castration of</b> the <b>penis,</b> i.e., that the master severed the slave’s penis, <b>this is</b> the same as the mishna that already mentioned <b>a penis.</b> What, then, does Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi add? <b>Rather, is it not</b> correct to say that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is referring to <b>castration of the testicles?</b> If so, this <i>baraita</i> resolves the dilemma raised by the Elders of Nezonya.
The Gemara further analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Also castration,</b> but he does not include the tongue, unlike ben Azzai. The Gemara inquires: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, is the <b>tongue not</b> considered exposed? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the following: In a case <b>where one was sprinkling</b> the purification water of the red heifer on another person in order to purify him from ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, <b>and a sprinkling</b> of water <b>landed on his mouth, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He has sprinkled,</b> i.e., this is a valid form of sprinkling and the impure person is purified. <b>And the Rabbis say: He has not sprinkled,</b> i.e., this is an invalid form of sprinkling because water of purification must be sprinkled on exposed limbs.
The Gemara clarifies the difficulty from this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What, is it not</b> the case that this is referring to a situation where water was sprinkled <b>on his tongue,</b> which would indicate that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi maintains that the tongue is an exposed limb? The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> this is referring to one who had water sprinkled <b>on his lips.</b> The Gemara asks: If it was sprinkled <b>on his lips, isn’t it obvious</b> that he is ritually pure, as the lips are exposed? The Gemara answers: It is necessary to state this, <b>lest you say</b> that at <b>times, he closes his lips</b> tightly, and consequently they should be considered an unexposed part of the body. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi one’s lips are considered exposed.
The Gemara further asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> that if one had water sprinkled <b>on his tongue</b> he is ritually pure according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi? <b>And it is further taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> dealing with the blemishes of priests and offerings <b>that</b> if <b>most of his tongue was removed,</b> this is a blemish; and <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> This is referring to a case where the part removed was <b>most of the part of his tongue</b> that <b>he uses for speaking</b> and pronouncing words, which is the tip of the tongue, not most of its length. This indicates that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi maintains that if the tongue is removed, that is considered a blemish.
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be explained as follows. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Castration</b> is included, <b>and it is not necessary</b> to say that if the slave’s <b>tongue</b> is removed he is emancipated, as the tongue is exposed. <b>Ben Azzai says:</b> The loss of his <b>tongue</b> emancipates him, <b>but castration</b> does <b>not. And what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Also,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, which indicates that ben Azzai is adding to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement? He is adding <b>to the first</b> statement of the first <i>tanna</i>, not to the immediately preceding ruling of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> the statement <b>of ben Azzai should be first,</b> as he adds one item, i.e., the tongue, to the ruling of the first <i>tanna</i>, while Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi further adds the case of castration to ben Azzai’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> should have been formulated in this manner, but the <b><i>tanna</i></b> first <b>heard</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and set it</b> in his version of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and</b> afterward <b>he heard</b> the opinion of <b>ben Azzai and taught</b> it at the end. <b>And</b> although it would be appropriate to change the order of the statements, he did not do so because <b>a mishna does not move from its place.</b> Once it has been taught in a certain manner, the <i>tanna</i> will not change the text of a mishna, in order to avoid confusion.
<b>Ulla says: All concede with regard to a tongue</b> that <b>in the matter of ritual impurity it is</b> considered <b>exposed with respect to a dead creeping animal</b> and other items that impart impurity. In other words, if an individual comes into contact with a source of ritual impurity with his tongue, he is rendered impure. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The Merciful One states: “Whom he touches”</b> (Leviticus 15:11), <b>and this</b> tongue <b>can also touch.</b> It is possible for one to touch objects with his tongue.
Similarly, all agree about a tongue with regard <b>to the matter of immersion</b> that the tongue <b>is considered concealed,</b> and therefore one need not open his mouth so that the water touches his tongue. For an immersion to be valid, the water must come into contact with the entire outside of one’s body. Ulla teaches that this does not include the tongue. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The Merciful One states: “And he shall immerse his flesh in water”</b> (Leviticus 15:13). <b>Just as his flesh is on the outside, so too everything</b> that requires immersion is <b>on the outside,</b> and this does not include what is ordinarily on the inside.
<b>They disagreed only</b> with regard <b>to</b> whether the tongue is considered exposed or concealed in <b>the matter of sprinkling. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>compares</b> sprinkling <b>to impurity,</b> where the tongue is considered exposed, <b>and the Rabbis compare it to immersion,</b> where the tongue is considered concealed.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> the <b>two of them disagree with regard to</b> the meaning of <b>this verse: “And the pure person shall sprinkle upon the impure person</b> on the third day and on the seventh day, and he shall purify him on the seventh day and he shall wash his clothes and immerse in water and he shall become pure in the evening” (Numbers 19:19). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>maintains</b> that the verse should be read as: <b>“And the pure person shall sprinkle upon the impure person on the third day and on the seventh day, and he shall purify him.”</b> This indicates that sprinkling is compared to ritual impurity, which means that it is effective if the water lands on any part of the body that can become impure.
Conversely, <b>the Rabbis maintain</b> that one should read the phrase “and he shall purify him” with the last part of the verse, as follows: <b>“And he shall purify him on the seventh day and he shall wash his clothes and immerse in water.”</b> According to this reading, sprinkling is compared to immersion, which means that the water must be sprinkled on part of the body that requires immersion.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis as well, let us compare</b> sprinkling <b>to impurity.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>One should derive purification from purification.</b> Just as immersion is a method of purification, so too sprinkling is a method of purification, and therefore it is appropriate to compare these two cases. The Gemara asks from the other perspective: <b>And</b> with regard to the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>let us compare</b> sprinkling <b>to immersion.</b> The Gemara answers that the phrase <b>“and he shall wash his clothes” concludes</b> the discussion of <b>that matter,</b> i.e., this expression indicates that a new clause begins from here, and therefore sprinkling should not be compared to immersion but to impurity, which is mentioned prior to it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>maintain</b> with regard <b>to the matter of immersion</b> that the tongue <b>is considered concealed? But doesn’t Ravin say</b> that <b>Rav Adda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> There was <b>an incident involving a maidservant of the household of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>who immersed</b> herself, <b>and she ascended</b> from her immersion <b>and a bone was found between her teeth, and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>required her</b> to perform <b>another immersion?</b> This indicates that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi one may not have a foreign object even inside one’s mouth during immersion. If so, the tongue should require immersion as well.
The Gemara answers: That is no proof, as it is <b>granted that we do not require immersion in water,</b> i.e., the water need not actually enter one’s mouth. But <b>we require</b> that the mouth be <b>a place</b> that is <b>fit for water to enter.</b> If there is a foreign object, the water cannot enter that spot.
This is <b>in accordance with that</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Zeira. As Rabbi Zeira says</b> with regard to meal-offerings: For <b>any</b> amount of flour <b>suitable for mingling</b> with oil in a meal-offering, <b>mingling is not indispensable for it.</b> Although it is a mitzva to mingle the flour and oil <i>ab initio</i>, if they were not mingled the meal-offering is still valid. <b>But</b> for <b>any</b> amount of flour <b>not suitable for mingling, mingling is indispensable for it,</b> and such a meal-offering is invalid. The principle is: <i>Ab initio</i> requirements prevent the fulfillment of a mitzva in situations where they are not merely absent but impossible. Here too, although there is no need for the water to actually enter the concealed spaces of the body, it is still necessary that these places be fit for immersion without the interposition of a foreign object.

Daf 25b

The Gemara comments that the first question with regard to castration of the testicles is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> It is stated with regard to animals that cannot be used as offerings due to blemishes: <b>“That whose stones are bruised, or crushed, or torn, or cut</b> you shall not sacrifice to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:24). <b>All</b> of these blemishes <b>are</b> referring <b>to</b> the animal’s <b>testicles;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara asks: Could Rabbi Yehuda possibly mean that these blemishes apply only <b>to the testicles and not to the penis?</b> Certainly these should also be considered blemishes if they affect the penis, which is more exposed than the testicles. <b>Rather,</b> this is what the <i>baraita</i> is saying: <b>All of</b> these blemishes apply <b>to the testicles also;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: All of them</b> apply only <b>to the penis. Rabbi Yosei states</b> the following distinction: <b>“Bruised or crushed”</b> applies <b>to the testicles also.</b> Conversely, when there are areas that are <b>“broken or cut” on the penis, yes,</b> these are considered a blemish, but <b>on the testicles, no,</b> they are not a blemish.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A large domesticated animal is acquired by passing,</b> when its current owner transfers it to a buyer by giving him the reins or the bit. <b>And a small</b> domesticated animal is acquired <b>by lifting.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say: A small domesticated animal can be acquired by pulling</b> also, and there is no need to lift it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav taught in</b> the town of <b>Kimḥonya: A large domesticated animal is acquired by pulling. Shmuel found Rav’s students</b> and <b>said to them: Did Rav</b> actually <b>say that a large domesticated animal is acquired by pulling? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that it is acquired <b>by passing? And</b> several times I <b>also</b> heard <b>Rav say</b> that it is acquired <b>by passing.</b> Did <b>he retract that</b> ruling? Rav’s students replied: In fact, Rav retracted that ruling and <b>he states</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And the Rabbis say: Both</b> small and large domesticated animals <b>are acquired by pulling. Rabbi Shimon says: Both</b> are acquired <b>by lifting.</b>
