<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> that women are exempt from <b>appearance, and had not written</b> that they are exempt from donning <b>phylacteries, I would say: I will compare phylacteries to <i>mezuza</i>,</b> which would mean that women are obligated in the mitzva of phylacteries. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> for both phylacteries and appearance, and they are not two verses that come as one.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> the verses concerning <b><i>matza</i> and assembly</b> are <b>also necessary,</b> each for its own reason, and they are not two verses that come as one either. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>For what</b> purpose are both of them <b>necessary? Granted, if the Merciful One had written</b> that women are obligated in the mitzva of <b>assembly but had not written</b> that they are obligated in eating <b><i>matza</i>, I would say: Derive</b> a verbal analogy with regard to Passover, where the verse states: “And on the <b>fifteenth</b> day of the same month is the festival of Passover” (Leviticus 23:6), from <i>Sukkot</i>, where the verse states: “On the <b>fifteenth</b> day of this seventh month is the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>” (Leviticus 23:34), teaching that women are exempt from eating <i>matza</i>, just as they are exempt from residing in a <i>sukka</i>. Therefore, it is necessary for a verse to teach that women are obligated in eating <i>matza</i>.
<b>But let the Merciful One write</b> that women are obligated in eating <b><i>matza</i>, and it</b> would <b>not</b> be <b>necessary</b> to state the same <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>assembly, and I</b> would <b>say</b> on my own: If <b>children are obligated</b> in assembly, as is stated explicitly in the verse “Assemble the people, the men and the women and the children” (Deuteronomy 31:12), are <b>women not all the more so</b> obligated? <b>Therefore,</b> as it is explicitly stated that women are obligated in assembly, the verses concerning <i>matza</i> and assembly are <b>two verses that come as one, and</b> consequently do <b>not teach</b> a precedent.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> as a principle that two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> a precedent. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one <b>do teach</b> a precedent, <b>what can be said?</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> one can ask: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>women are obligated in positive mitzvot that are not time bound?</b> The Gemara answers <b>that</b> one <b>derives</b> this <b>from</b> the mitzva of <b>fearing</b> one’s mother and father: <b>Just as women are obligated</b> in the mitzva of <b>fear</b> (Leviticus 19:3), <b>so too, women are obligated in every positive mitzva that is not time bound.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>derive</b> the opposite <b>from Torah study:</b> Just as women are exempt from Torah study, so too they should be exempt from all positive mitzvot that are not time bound. The Gemara answers: One cannot derive an exemption for women from their exemption from Torah study, <b>because Torah study and procreation are two verses that come as one,</b> as in both cases women are exempt, despite the fact that these are not time-bound mitzvot. <b>And any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a precedent.

Daf 35a

The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, who says</b> that <b>with regard to both of them,</b> men and women, the verse <b>states: “And God blessed them,</b> and God said to them: <b>Be fruitful and multiply,</b> replenish the earth and conquer it” (Genesis 1:28), <b>what can be said?</b> According to his opinion, women are exempt from only one positive mitzva that is not time bound, Torah study; why not derive other mitzvot from this case? The Gemara answers: The reason this is not a difficulty is <b>because Torah study and the redemption of the firstborn son,</b> from which women are also exempt, <b>are two verses that come as one, and any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a precedent.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka as well, let procreation,</b> which he maintains applies to women, <b>and fear</b> of one’s mother and father <b>be</b> considered <b>two verses that come as one and</b> they should <b>not teach</b> a precedent. The Gemara answers: Both cases <b>are necessary. As, if the Merciful One had written</b> only that women are obligated in <b>fear</b> of their parents, <b>and had not written</b> that they are obligated in <b>procreation, I would say</b> that as <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “Be fruitful and multiply, replenish the earth <b>and conquer it”</b> (Genesis 1:28), this leads to the conclusion that women are exempt from procreation, by the following reasoning: <b>As</b> it is <b>the manner of a man</b> to go to war and <b>to conquer, yes,</b> he is obligated in procreation, but <b>as it is not the manner of a woman to conquer,</b> she is <b>not</b> obligated in procreation.
<b>And if</b> the Merciful One <b>had written</b> only that women are obligated in the mitzva of <b>procreation, and had not written</b> that they are obligated to <b>fear</b> their parents, <b>I would say:</b> With regard to <b>a man, as</b> it is <b>in his power to perform</b> this mitzva, <b>yes,</b> he is obligated to fear his mother and father, but with regard to <b>a woman, as</b> it is <b>not in her power to perform</b> this mitzva when she is married, since her obligations to her husband may prevent her from doing so, she is <b>not</b> obligated. <b>And as</b> it is <b>not in her power to perform</b> this mitzva when she is married, perhaps women <b>should not be obligated at all</b> and there should be no difference between a married and an unmarried woman. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the Torah to state that women are obligated in both procreation and the fear of parents, and these are not considered two verses that come as one.
The Gemara notes that the earlier question remains difficult: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a precedent. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one <b>do teach</b> a precedent, <b>what can be said?</b> According to this opinion it can be derived that women are obligated in positive, time-bound mitzvot from <i>matza</i> and assembly, and that they are exempt from positive mitzvot that are not time bound, from Torah study and the redemption of the firstborn son. <b>Rava said:</b> The Sages <b>of Pafunya know the reason for this matter.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And who is</b> the scholar called by the nickname: The Sages of Paphunya? It is <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov,</b> who said as follows: <b>The verse states</b> with regard to phylacteries: <b>“And it shall be a sign for you on your arm and for a memorial between your eyes, that the Torah of the Lord may be in your mouth”</b> (Exodus 13:9). In this manner <b>the entire Torah is juxtaposed to phylacteries: Just as</b> donning <b>phylacteries is a positive, time-bound mitzva and women are exempt</b> from it, <b>so too are women exempt</b> from <b>every positive, time-bound mitzva</b> in the Torah. <b>And from the fact</b> that <b>women are exempt from</b> every <b>positive, time-bound mitzva,</b> one can learn <b>by inference</b> that <b>women are obligated in</b> every <b>positive mitzva that is not time bound.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that the mitzva of donning <b>phylacteries</b> is <b>a positive, time-bound mitzva. But according to the one who says</b> that donning <b>phylacteries</b> is <b>a positive mitzva that is not time bound,</b> as it is applicable the entire year, day and night, <b>what can be said?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Who did you hear who said</b> that donning <b>phylacteries</b> is <b>a positive mitzva that is not time bound?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Meir, and he holds</b> that <i>matza</i> and assembly are <b>verses that come as one, and</b> he further maintains that <b>any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a precedent.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says</b> that <b>two verses that come as one do teach</b> a precedent, <b>and</b> who also says that donning <b>phylacteries is a positive mitzva that is not time bound, what can be said?</b> The Gemara answers: It is not derived from here that women are obligated in positive, time-bound mitzvot <b>because</b> the verses that mention <b><i>matza</i>, rejoicing, and assembly are three verses that come as one, and</b> everyone agrees <b>three verses that come as one do not teach</b> a precedent.
§ The mishna further teaches: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all prohibitions,</b> whether or not they are time bound, both men and women are obligated to observe them. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says, and likewise the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: The verse states</b> with regard to a guilt-offering: <b>“When a man or woman shall commit any sin that a person commits”</b> (Numbers 5:6). <b>The verse equates a woman to a man with regard to all punishments in the Torah,</b> as a woman is also required to bring an offering for atonement.
<b>The school of Rabbi Eliezer taught</b> as follows. <b>The verse states:</b> “Now these are the ordinances <b>which you shall set before them”</b> (Exodus 21:1), stating “them” in the plural. This <b>verse equates a woman to a man</b> with regard <b>to all judgments in the Torah,</b> i.e., monetary cases and damages. <b>The school of Ḥizkiyya taught: The verse states,</b> with regard to the ransom one pays if his animal killed a person: <b>“And killed a man or woman”</b> (Exodus 21:29). Here too, <b>the verse equates a woman to a man,</b> with regard <b>to all deaths in the Torah,</b> i.e., the same <i>halakha</i> applies to an animal that kills either a man or a woman.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state all three of these verses. <b>As, if</b> the Torah <b>had taught us</b> only <b>this first</b> case, with regard to a woman’s obligation to sacrifice guilt-offerings, I would say that <b>the Merciful One has pity on her due to atonement,</b> i.e., God gave her the possibility to atone for her sin through an offering. <b>But</b> with regard to monetary <b>judgments, I</b> would <b>say</b> that with regard to <b>a man, who</b> generally <b>conducts</b> business <b>negotiations, yes,</b> these <i>halakhot</i> apply to him, but in the case of <b>a woman,</b> who generally does not conduct business negotiations, <b>no,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of monetary judgments do not apply to her.
<b>And</b> similarly <b>if</b> the Torah <b>had taught us</b> only <b>this</b> case of monetary judgments, I would say that these judgments apply to a woman, <b>because</b> there are circumstances where engaging in business <b>is her livelihood. But</b> with regard to the <b>ransom</b> that is paid when one’s animal killed someone, <b>I</b> would <b>say:</b>

Daf 35b

If the animal killed <b>a man, who is commanded in</b> all <b>mitzvot, yes,</b> its owner should have to pay the ransom, but if the animal killed <b>a woman,</b> who is obligated in only some mitzvot, <b>no,</b> he is exempt from the ransom. <b>And</b> conversely: <b>If</b> the Torah had <b>taught us</b> that men and women are equated only in <b>this</b> case of the ransom, one might say that <b>because there is the loss of life the Merciful One has pity on her</b> and therefore the owner of the animal is always obligated to pay the ransom. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>those two</b> other categories, <b>I</b> might <b>say no,</b> a woman is not equated to a man. Therefore it was <b>necessary</b> to mention them all.
§ The mishna teaches that women are obligated in all prohibitions <b>except for</b> the prohibitions of: <b>Do not round</b> the corners of one’s head, <b>and: Do not destroy</b> the corners of your beard, and: Do not contract ritual impurity from a corpse. The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> a woman of priestly lineage is not obligated in the mitzva of: <b>Do not contract ritual impurity from a corpse, as it is written: “Speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron,</b> and say to them: None shall become impure for the dead among his people” (Leviticus 21:1). This verse teaches that the prohibition applies to <b>the sons of Aaron, but not the daughters of Aaron. But from where do we</b> derive the prohibitions of: <b>Do not round</b> the corners of one’s head, <b>and: Do not destroy</b> the corners of your beard?
The Gemara answers that this is <b>as it is written: “You shall not round the corners of your head and you shall not destroy the corners of your beard”</b> (Leviticus 19:27). The juxtaposition of the two prohibitions teaches that <b>anyone who is</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition against <b>destroying</b> the beard <b>is</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition against <b>rounding</b> the head. <b>And since these women are not</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition against <b>destroying, they are</b> also <b>not</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition against <b>rounding</b> the head.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> women <b>are not</b> obligated <b>in</b> the prohibition against <b>destroying</b> the corners of one’s beard? The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, propose</b> a logical <b>reason, as</b> ordinarily women <b>do not have a beard. And if you wish, cite a verse</b> that teaches this point, <b>as the verse states: “You shall not round the corners of your head [<i>roshekhem</i>] and you shall not destroy the corners of your beard [<i>zekanekha</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 19:27).
The Gemara explains: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the verse changed its language,</b> as the term “your head [<i>roshekhem</i>]” is in the plural while “your beard [<i>zekanekha</i>]” is in the singular, it can be inferred that <b>if so,</b> if the prohibition against destroying one’s beard applied to everyone, <b>let the Merciful One write:</b> And you shall not destroy the <b>corners of your beards [<i>zekanekhem</i>],</b> in the plural, so that the end of the verse parallels the beginning. <b>What</b> is indicated by the fact that the verse states: “And you shall not destroy the corners of <b>your beard [<i>zekanekha</i>],”</b> in the singular? This serves to teach: <b>Your beard</b> is included, <b>but not your wife’s beard.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is a woman <b>not</b> included in this prohibition? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nega’im</i> 4:8): <b>The beard of a woman and</b> that of <b>a eunuch, if they grow</b> facial <b>hair, are considered like a beard for all matters. What, is it not</b> the case that this statement is referring <b>to</b> the prohibition against <b>destroying?</b>
<b>Abaye said: You cannot say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to destroying, as it is derived</b> that a woman is exempt through the verbal analogy of <b>“the corners</b> of your beard” (Leviticus 19:27) here and <b>“the corners</b> of their beard” (Leviticus 21:5) <b>from the sons of Aaron: Just as there,</b> in the case of priests, <b>women are</b> certainly <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva, as the verse is referring to the male descendants of Aaron who perform the Temple service and not to women, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the prohibition against destroying one’s beard, which is stated to all Jews, <b>women are exempt.</b> At this stage the Gemara assumes that the exclusion of women denoted by the verse: “Speak to the priests, the sons of Aaron” (Leviticus 21:1), which excludes women, is applied to all the mitzvot stated in that chapter, including destroying the corners of one’s beard.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if we maintain that when</b> the Merciful One <b>writes: “The sons of Aaron”</b> (Leviticus 21:1), it <b>is written with regard to the entire manner</b> of that chapter, including the prohibition against destroying one’s beard, <b>let the verse,</b> i.e., the Torah, <b>be silent</b> and not state <b>about</b> this prohibition concerning all Jews. <b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>could be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as <b>I</b> could <b>say</b> the following: <b>And if</b> with regard to <b>priests, for whom the verse includes additional mitzvot,</b> this prohibition applies only to <b>the sons of Aaron and not the daughters of Aaron,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> the case with regard to <b>Israelites,</b> who have fewer mitzvot, that only men should be obligated and not women?
The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, the verbal analogy is necessary. <b>Were it not for</b> the <b>verbal analogy, I would say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity <b>concluded</b> discussion of <b>that matter.</b> In other words, the exclusion of women denoted by the phrase “the sons of Aaron” applies only to the <i>halakhot</i> of impurity, which appear immediately after that phrase. Conversely, the other <i>halakhot</i> mentioned in this chapter, including the prohibition against destroying the beard, apply to women as well.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>now too, let us say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity <b>concluded</b> discussion of <b>that matter,</b> and the daughters of Aaron are also prohibited to destroy their beards. <b>And if</b> you maintain that the reason the prohibition stated with regard to priests does not apply to women is <b>due to</b> the <b>verbal analogy</b> employing the term “the corners of,” which serves to connect the <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to priests with the <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to all Jews, that verbal analogy <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to priests: <b>“Neither shall they shave off</b> the corners of their beard” (Leviticus 21:5). One <b>might</b> have thought that a priest <b>would be liable</b> even if <b>he shaved his</b> beard <b>with scissors.</b> Therefore <b>the verse states,</b> in a command issued to all Jews: <b>“And you shall not destroy</b> the corners of your beard” (Leviticus 19:27). This teaches that one is liable only for destroying the beard to the root, which is not achieved with scissors.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>if he extracted</b> his hairs <b>with tweezers,</b> which uproot hairs, <b>or</b> small <b>planes [<i>uvirhitni</i>], he should</b> likewise <b>be liable</b> for destroying his hair. <b>The verse</b> therefore <b>states: “Neither shall they shave off</b> the corners of their beard,” to teach that shaving alone is prohibited and these actions are not considered shaving. <b>How</b> can both <b>these</b> requirements for the prohibition be met? The verse is referring to a type of <b>shaving that involves destruction. You must say</b> this <b>is</b> shaving with <b>a razor.</b> According to this <i>baraita</i>, the verbal analogy is necessary to define the action included in the prohibition against destroying, not to teach who is included in the prohibition.
The Gemara explains: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that the verbal analogy teaches only which action is included in the prohibition against destroying, <b>let the verse write: That which is of your beard. What</b> is added by the expression <b>“the corners of your beard”? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it,</b> both the definition of the prohibition against shaving and the exemption of women.
The Gemara returns to its question. <b>But that which is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The beard of a woman and</b> that of <b>a eunuch, if they grew</b> facial <b>hair, are considered like a beard for all matters, with regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this stated? <b>Mar Zutra says:</b> It is stated <b>with regard to ritual impurity from leprosy.</b> A leprous sore in the beard of a woman or a eunuch is treated like an affliction of the beard, not like an affliction on the skin. Different <i>halakhot</i> apply to leprous sores that develop on various parts of the body.
The Gemara objects: Concerning <b>ritual impurity from leprosy, it is written explicitly: “And when a man or woman has a plague upon the head or upon the beard”</b> (Leviticus 13:29). This indicates that there is no difference between a man and woman with regard to the beard in the case of leprosy. The <i>baraita</i> would not state a <i>halakha</i> that is explicit in the verse. <b>Rather, Mar Zutra says:</b> This <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to ritual purification from leprosy,</b> i.e., women can also be purified from leprosy of the beard.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>ritual purification from leprosy it is also obvious: Since impurity applies to</b> a woman, <b>purity</b> likewise <b>applies to her.</b> The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary</b> to state this with regard to the impurity of afflictions of the beard, as <b>it might enter your mind to say</b> that this verse <b>is written disjunctively,</b> i.e., that the phrase: <b>“And when a man or woman has a plague upon the head,”</b> applies to both a man or a woman; whereas when it states: <b>“Or upon the beard,” we have come back to</b> the case of <b>a man</b> alone. Therefore the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this phrase is not referring solely to a man, as there is no difference between a man and a woman with regard to leprosy.
<b>Isi taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Women are also exempt</b> from the prohibition: <b>Do not make baldness</b> upon your heads, a prohibition against tearing out one’s hair in grief over someone’s death. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Isi?</b> The Gemara explains <b>that he teaches as follows:</b> The verse states: <b>“You are the sons of the Lord your God; you shall not cut yourselves, nor make any baldness between your eyes for the dead. For you are a holy people to the Lord your God”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:1–2). This verse, which applies to <b>sons and not daughters,</b> is referring <b>to</b> causing <b>baldness,</b> and therefore this prohibition includes only men.
The Gemara asks: Do <b>you say</b> that this is referring <b>to</b> causing <b>baldness, or is it</b> perhaps referring <b>only to</b> the prohibition against <b>cutting,</b> which appears first? The Gemara answers that <b>when it states: “For you are a holy people to the Lord your God,”</b> it <b>is stated</b> with regard to the prohibition against <b>cutting,</b> and this verse applies to both men and women, as they are all members of God’s people. <b>How</b> then <b>do I realize</b> and explain the emphasis on <b>sons and not daughters?</b> This is referring <b>to</b> the prohibition against causing <b>baldness.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see to include cutting and to exclude</b> causing <b>baldness?</b> Perhaps the opposite is true, and causing baldness applies to men and women whereas cutting applies only to men. The Gemara answers: <b>I include cutting,</b> whose prohibition is broader, <b>as it is</b> applicable both <b>in a place of hair and not in a place of hair; and I exclude</b> causing <b>baldness,</b> which is more limited, <b>as it</b> applies <b>only in a place of hair.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the limitation of <b>sons and not daughters</b> applies <b>both to</b> causing <b>baldness and to cutting, and when</b> the verse <b>writes: “For you are a holy people to the Lord your God,” that is written with regard to scoring</b> oneself. The prohibition against scoring oneself is derived from a verbal analogy from a verse stated with regard to priests (see Leviticus 21:5), which applies to both men and women. The Gemara answers: <b>Isi maintains</b> that <b>scoring</b> oneself <b>and cutting</b>

Daf 36a

<b>are one</b> prohibition.
<b>Abaye said</b> that <b>this is the reason of Isi</b> for exempting women from the prohibition against baldness: <b>As he learns</b> the prohibition against causing <b>baldness</b> in grief over someone who is dead through a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the prohibition against causing <b>baldness</b> stated with regard to <b>the sons of Aaron.</b> The verse states with regard to priests: “They shall not make baldness upon their head” (Leviticus 21:5). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to priests, <b>women are exempt,</b> as the expression “the sons of Aaron” serves to exclude the daughters of Aaron, <b>so too here, women are exempt.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But if we maintain that when</b> the Merciful One <b>writes:</b> “The sons of Aaron” (Leviticus 21:1), it <b>is written with regard to the entire matter</b> of that chapter, including the prohibition against causing baldness, <b>let the verse be silent about</b> this prohibition concerning all Jews. <b>And</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>could be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, as <b>I</b> could <b>say</b> the following: <b>If</b> in the case of <b>priests, for whom the verse includes additional mitzvot,</b> the prohibition against causing baldness applies only to <b>the sons of Aaron and not the daughters of Aaron,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> the case with regard to <b>Israelites,</b> who have fewer mitzvot, that only the men should be obligated and not the women?
The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, the verbal analogy is necessary. As, <b>were it not for</b> the <b>verbal analogy I would say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity <b>concluded</b> discussion of <b>that matter,</b> and the prohibition against causing baldness applies to all the descendants of Aaron, including women.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>now too, let us say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity <b>concluded</b> discussion of <b>that matter,</b> and it is prohibited for the daughters of Aaron as well to cause baldness. <b>And if</b> you maintain that the reason the prohibition stated with regard to priests does not apply to women is <b>due to</b> the <b>verbal analogy</b> employing the term “make baldness,” which serves to connect the <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to priests with the <i>halakha</i> stated with regard to all Jews, this verbal analogy <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“They shall not make baldness [<i>yikreḥu</i></b> <i>korḥa</i>]” (Leviticus 21:5). If the verse had stated only “<i>yikreḥu</i>,” one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> if <b>one made four or five</b> patches of <b>baldness he would be obligated</b> for <b>only one</b> violation, as there is only one prohibition against making a bald spot. Therefore <b>the verse also states “<i>korḥa</i>,” to render him liable for each and every one</b> of the bald spots.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Upon their head”</b> (Leviticus 21:5), with regard to the prohibition against a priest causing baldness? <b>Because it is stated: “You shall not cut yourselves, nor make any baldness between your eyes for the dead”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:1), one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he is obligated only for</b> removing the hair <b>between the eyes. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include the entire head</b> in this prohibition? When <b>the verse states “upon their head,”</b> it serves <b>to render</b> a priest <b>liable</b> for removing hair <b>on</b> his entire <b>head like</b> the spot <b>between the eyes.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>priests, for whom the verse includes additional mitzvot; from where do we</b> derive that it applies to every <b>Israelite,</b> i.e., all Jews are liable for each and every bald spot and for the entire head? <b>It is stated here,</b> with regard to priests, <b>“baldness,” and it is stated there,</b> with regard to non-priests, <b>“baldness.” Just as here,</b> with regard to priests, <b>one is obligated for each and every bald spot, and one is obligated for the entire head like</b> the spot <b>between the eyes, so too there,</b> with regard to all Jews, <b>one is obligated for each and every bald spot, and one is obligated for the entire head like</b> the spot <b>between the eyes.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> conversely, <b>just as there,</b> in the case of Israelites, it is referring specifically to causing baldness <b>over</b> someone who is <b>dead, so too here,</b> with regard to priests, it is prohibited to cause baldness only <b>over</b> someone who is <b>dead,</b> not in other circumstances. This <i>baraita</i> shows that the verbal analogy is required for the <i>halakhot</i> of bald spots. How, then, can it teach the exemption of women? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that it may be used only for one purpose, <b>let the verse be written</b> merely <b>bald [<i>keraḥ</i>]. What</b> is meant by the term <b>“baldness [<i>korḥa</i>]”? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it,</b> both the verbal analogy that exempts women and the <i>halakha</i> that each bald spot constitutes a separate violation.
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>this is Isi’s reason, as he derives</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“between your eyes”</b> with regard to baldness <b>from phylacteries,</b> concerning which it says: “And they shall be for frontlets between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 11:18): <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to phylacteries, <b>women are exempt, so too here,</b> in the case of baldness, <b>women are exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rava did not state</b> the same reason <b>as Abaye?</b> The Gemara answers: Rava <b>does not learn</b> anything from the distinction between <b><i>keraḥ</i></b> and <b><i>korḥa</i>,</b> as he maintains that no <i>halakha</i> can be derived from this slight difference in language.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Abaye did not state</b> the same reason <b>as Rava?</b> The Gemara answers that Abaye could have <b>said to you: Phylacteries themselves are derived from here,</b> i.e., the meaning of the phrase “between your eyes” stated with regard to phylacteries is understood from the case of baldness: <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to a bald spot, “between your eyes” is referring to <b>a place where baldness is formed,</b> a spot where there is hair, which is <b>on the upper part of the head</b> but not actually between the eyes, <b>so too, the place</b> where phylacteries are <b>donned is on the upper part of the head.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And both Abaye and Rava, what do they derive from this</b> verse: <b>“You are the sons</b> to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 14:1)? According to the first explanation of Isi’s opinion, the exclusion of women is derived from this phrase, whereas they derive that <i>halakha</i> from a different source. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> verse <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse: <b>“You are the sons to the Lord your God,”</b> indicates that <b>when you act like sons</b> and cleave to the Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>you are called sons,</b> but when <b>you do not act like sons you are not called sons.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Meir says: Either way you are</b> still <b>called sons, as it is stated: “They are foolish sons”</b> (Jeremiah 4:22). <b>And it</b> also <b>states: “Sons in whom there is no faithfulness”</b> (Deuteronomy 32:20). <b>And it states: “A seed of evildoers, sons who deal corruptly”</b> (Isaiah 1:4). <b>And it states: “And it shall come to pass that, instead of what was said to them: You are not My people, it shall be said to them: Sons of the living God”</b> (Hosea 2:1).
The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is it necessary to cite these additional proofs introduced by the phrase: <b>And it states?</b> All these verses apparently make the same point. The Gemara explains why all the quotes are necessary. <b>And if you would say:</b> Granted, when they are <b>foolish they are</b> still <b>called sons,</b> as the verse states: “Foolish sons,” but <b>when they do not have faithfulness they are not called sons;</b> therefore, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> another verse. <b>And</b> that verse <b>states: “Sons in whom there is no faithfulness.”</b>
<b>And if you would say: It is when they do not have faithfulness that they are called sons,</b> as stated, but <b>when</b> they <b>worship idols they are not called sons</b> anymore; therefore, <b>come</b> and <b>hear: And</b> the verse <b>states: “A seed of evildoers, sons who deal corruptly,”</b> which alludes to the corruption of idol worship. <b>And if you would say</b> that although <b>they are called “sons who deal corruptly,” they are no</b> longer <b>called full-fledged sons</b> of God once they have sinned, <b>come</b> and <b>hear: And</b> the <b>verse states: “And it shall come to pass that, instead of what was said to them: You are not My people, it shall be said to them: Sons of the living God.”</b> This verse indicates that when the Jews repent they are again called full-fledged sons of God.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on the head of an offering, <b>and the waving</b> of certain offerings, <b>and the bringing near</b> of meal-offerings to the corner of the altar, <b>and the removal of a handful</b> from meal-offerings, <b>and the burning</b> of sacrificial parts on the altar, <b>and the pinching</b> of bird-offerings, <b>and the collecting</b> of blood of offerings in a vessel, <b>and the sprinkling</b> of blood, these <b>apply to men and not to women.</b> All these mitzvot apply specifically to men and not to women, <b>except for the meal-offering of a <i>sota</i>, and</b> the meal-offering of <b>a nazirite woman, which</b> these women <b>wave.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> From where is it derived that <b>placing</b> of <b>hands</b> on the head of an offering applies only to men? <b>As it is written: “Speak to the sons of Israel…and he shall place</b> his hand” (Leviticus 1:2–4), which indicates that <b>the sons of Israel place hands</b> on offerings, <b>but the daughters of Israel do not place hands.</b>
The Gemara explains that the <i>halakha</i> of <b>waving</b> is derived from the following verse: <b>“Speak to the sons of Israel…and he shall wave”</b> (see Leviticus 7:29–30), which likewise teaches that <b>the sons of Israel wave, but the daughters of Israel do not wave.</b>
§ With regard to <b>bringing near,</b> this is <b>as it is written: “And this is the law of the meal-offering: The sons of Aaron shall bring it near”</b> (Leviticus 6:7). This teaches that <b>the sons of Aaron</b> bring the meal-offering near, <b>but not the daughters of Aaron.</b>
With regard to <b>the removal of a handful,</b> this is <b>as it is written: “And he shall bring it to the sons of Aaron,</b> the priests, <b>and he shall remove a handful”</b> (Leviticus 2:2). This teaches that <b>the sons of Aaron</b> take a handful, <b>but not the daughters of Aaron.</b>
With regard to the <b>burning</b> of sacrificial parts, this is <b>as it is written: “And the sons of Aaron shall burn it”</b> (Leviticus 3:5). This teaches that it is <b>the sons of Aaron</b> who burn the parts, <b>but not the daughters of Aaron.</b>
With regard to <b>pinching,</b> this is <b>as it is written: “And he shall pinch…and he shall burn”</b> (Leviticus 1:15). The verse <b>juxtaposes killing to burning,</b> and just as the burning of an offering must be performed by men, so too pinching may be performed only by men.
With regard to <b>receiving,</b> this is <b>as it is written: “And the sons of Aaron shall present</b> the blood” (Leviticus 1:5). <b>And the Master said</b> in explanation of this verse:

Daf 36b

<b>“And</b> the sons of Aaron <b>shall present,” this is collecting the blood.</b>
The Gemara discusses the mishna’s ruling that women do not perform <b>sprinkling: To which sprinkling</b> is this referring? <b>If</b> this is the sprinkling of the ashes <b>of</b> the red <b>heifer, “Elazar” is written with regard to that</b> action (Numbers 19:4), i.e., this sprinkling is performed by the deputy High Priest. If even other priests cannot perform it, certainly women cannot. <b>If</b> this is referring <b>to</b> the sprinkling performed <b>inside</b> the Holy of Holies, the phrase: <b>“The anointed priest”</b> (Leviticus 4:16), <b>is written with regard to that</b> rite, and consequently there is no question that women are ineligible. <b>Rather,</b> it is referring to <b>sprinkling</b> the blood <b>of a bird</b>-offering.
The Gemara explains <b>that this is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from a sheep</b> offering: <b>If</b> with regard to <b>a sheep</b> offering, concerning <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did not establish a priest for its slaughter,</b> since it may be slaughtered by anybody, the Torah nevertheless <b>established a priest for its sprinkling,</b> as the verse states: “And the sons of Aaron, the priests, shall sprinkle its blood” (Leviticus 1:11), <b>is it not logical</b> that with regard to <b>a bird</b>-offering, concerning <b>which</b> the Torah <b>established a priest for its pinching,</b> an act parallel to slaughtering a sheep, the Torah likewise <b>established a priest for its sprinkling?</b> This proves that the sprinkling of the blood of a bird-offering can be performed only by priests, not by women.
§ The mishna teaches that these mitzvot apply specifically to men but not to women, <b>except for the meal-offering of a <i>sota</i> and a nazirite woman,</b> which these women wave. <b>Rabbi Elazar said to Rabbi Yoshiya of his generation,</b> i.e., the <i>amora</i> who was his contemporary, not the <i>tanna</i> with the same name who lived earlier: <b>Do not sit down until you explain this statement to me; from where</b> is it derived <b>that the meal-offering of a <i>sota</i> requires waving?</b> The Gemara expresses surprise: What is the meaning of the question: <b>From where do we</b> derive it? <b>It is written in</b> the chapter dealing with a <i>sota</i> <b>itself: “And he shall wave the meal-offering”</b> (Numbers 5:25). <b>Rather,</b> the question is as follows: <b>From where do we</b> derive that the <b>waving</b> is performed <b>by the owners?</b> Perhaps only the priest waves it?
Rabbi Yoshiya responded: This <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived</b> through the verbal analogy of the term <b>“hand”</b> stated with regard to a <i>sota</i> <b>from</b> the term <b>“hand”</b> stated with regard to <b>a peace-offering. It is written here,</b> with regard to the meal-offering of a <i>sota</i>: <b>“And the priest shall take</b> the meal-offering of jealousy <b>from the woman’s hand</b> and he shall wave the meal-offering” (Numbers 5:25), <b>and it is written there: “His own hands shall bring</b> the offerings of the Lord made by fire; the fat with the breast shall he bring, that the breast may be waved before the Lord” (Leviticus 7:30).
<b>Just as here,</b> with regard to a <i>sota</i>, <b>a priest</b> performs the waving, <b>so too there,</b> with regard to a peace-offering, <b>a priest</b> performs the waving. And <b>just as there,</b> with regard to a peace-offering, the <b>owner</b> performs the waving, as indicated by the verse, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to a <i>sota</i>, the <b>owner</b> performs the waving. <b>How so?</b> How can both the priest and the owner perform the waving? The owner places his hands beneath the peace-offering, and the <b>priest places his hand under the hand of the owner and waves</b> it together with him.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the meal-offering of <b>a <i>sota</i>; from where do we</b> derive that <b>a nazirite woman</b> also waves her meal-offering? The Gemara answers: <b>It is derived</b> through a verbal analogy of the term <b>“palm”</b> stated with regard to naziriteship <b>from</b> the term <b>“palm”</b> stated with regard to <b>a <i>sota</i>.</b> The verse concerning naziriteship states: “And he shall place them upon the palms of the nazirite” (Numbers 6:19), and the verse concerning a <i>sota</i> states: “And he shall place it on her palms” (Numbers 5:18). Just as a <i>sota</i> waves her meal-offering, so too, a nazirite woman waves hers.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any mitzva that is dependent on the land [<i>aretz</i>] applies only in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>and</b> any mitzva <b>that is not dependent on the land applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.

Daf 37a

This is <b>apart from</b> the mitzvot of <b><i>orla</i> and diverse kinds,</b> which apply even outside of Eretz Yisrael. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> with regard to the prohibition to eat from the <b>new crop</b> before the <i>omer</i> offering has been brought on the sixteenth of Nisan.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by mitzvot that are <b>dependent</b> on the land, <b>and what</b> is meant by mitzvot <b>that are not dependent</b> on the land? <b>If we say</b> that a mitzva is called <b>dependent</b> in a case <b>where it is written</b> in a verse <b>with regard to it: Coming</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>and</b> a mitzva <b>that is not dependent</b> on the land is one concerning <b>which</b> the verb: <b>Coming,</b> or the verb: Bringing, <b>is not written</b> in a verse <b>with regard to it,</b> that would lead to a difficulty: <b>But aren’t there</b> the mitzvot of donning <b>phylacteries and the</b> redemption of the <b>firstborn donkey, in which</b> the verse <b>states: Bringing,</b> in the passage: “And it shall be when the Lord shall bring you to the land of the Canaanite…And every firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb…And it shall be for a sign upon your hand, and for frontlets between your eyes” (Exodus 13:11–16), <b>and</b> yet those mitzvot <b>apply both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: Any mitzva that is an obligation of the body,</b> i.e., an obligation upon the person, <b>applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. Conversely, <b>an obligation of the land,</b> that is, a mitzva that applies specifically to the earth and its growths, <b>applies only in Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? The Gemara answers: This is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “These are the statutes and the ordinances that you shall observe to do in the land that the Lord, the God of your fathers, has given you to possess it, all the days that you live upon the earth” (Deuteronomy 12:1). This verse is interpreted as follows: The phrase <b>“these are the statutes”</b> means that <b>these are the expositions</b> that the Sages learn from verses. With regard to the phrase <b>“and the ordinances,” these are</b> monetary <b>laws.</b> With regard to <b>“that you shall observe,” this is</b> referring to the <b>study</b> of matters that must be observed for one to perform them. And as for the phrase <b>“to do,” this is</b> referring to <b>action,</b> the actual performance of mitzvot.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: From the phrase <b>“in the land [<i>ba’aretz</i>],”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>all mitzvot apply only in Eretz</b> Yisrael. Therefore, <b>the verse</b> also <b>states “all the days that you live upon the earth,”</b> i.e., wherever you live. Furthermore, <b>if</b> the Merciful One had written only the phrase <b>“all the days,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that all mitzvot <b>should apply both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. Therefore, <b>the verse</b> also <b>states “in the land.”</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Once the verse includes</b> areas outside of Eretz Yisrael <b>and</b> also <b>excludes</b> areas outside of Eretz Yisrael, how is it determined which mitzvot apply outside the land and which do not? The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>Go and learn from what is stated with regard to</b> a different <b>issue</b> that appears in the next verse: <b>“You shall destroy all the places where</b> the nations that you are to dispossess <b>served</b> their gods” (Deuteronomy 12:2). <b>Just as</b> the prohibition of <b>idol worship is distinct</b> in <b>that it is an obligation of the body, and it applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>so too, any</b> mitzva <b>that is an obligation of the body applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. Conversely, mitzvot that are an obligation connected to the land apply only in Eretz Yisrael.
§ The mishna teaches that all mitzvot that are dependent on the land apply only in Eretz Yisrael, <b>apart from <i>orla</i> and</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds.</b> Rabbi Eliezer says: This is the <i>halakha</i> even with regard to the prohibition to eat from the new crop. <b>A dilemma was raised before them:</b> Does <b>Rabbi Eliezer disagree</b> with the first <i>tanna</i> with the intent to rule more <b>leniently or</b> does <b>he disagree</b> with the first <i>tanna</i> with the intent to rule more <b>stringently?</b>
The Gemara elaborates: It is possible that Rabbi Eliezer <b>disagrees</b> with the first <i>tanna</i> with the intent to rule more <b>stringently, and this is what the first <i>tanna</i> is saying:</b> All mitzvot that are dependent on the land apply only in Eretz Yisrael, <b>apart from <i>orla</i> and diverse kinds, as we learned this <i>halakha</i> through a tradition</b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai. <b>Although one could say</b> that each of them <b>is an obligation of the land</b> and should apply only in Eretz Yisrael, nevertheless they are obligatory outside of Eretz Yisrael as well. <b>But</b> the prohibition of the <b>new crop,</b> which is an obligation of the land, <b>yes,</b> it applies <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, but <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>no,</b> it does not apply.
<b>What is the reason</b> of the first <i>tanna</i>? In the verse that states with regard to the new crop: “In all your dwellings” (Leviticus 23:14), the term <b>dwelling</b> does not mean that this <i>halakha</i> applies wherever Jews live. Rather, it means that the mitzva is applicable only in Eretz Yisrael, as this phrase <b>indicates</b> a time <b>after inheritance and settlement</b> of Eretz Yisrael by the Jewish people, when they are actually dwelling in the land, not when they are in the process of conquering it. This is the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer comes to say: Even</b> the prohibition with regard to the <b>new crop applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. <b>What is the reason</b> for his opinion? He explains that the term <b>dwelling</b> means <b>wherever you dwell.</b> This is one possible way to understand the dispute, according to which the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer is more stringent than that of the first <i>tanna</i>.
<b>Or perhaps</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>disagrees</b> with the first <i>tanna</i> with the intent to rule more <b>leniently, and this is what the first <i>tanna</i> is saying:</b> All mitzvot that are dependent on the land apply only in Eretz Yisrael, <b>apart from <i>orla</i> and diverse kinds, as we learned this <i>halakha</i> through tradition, and all the more so</b> apart from the <b>new crop,</b> which applies outside of Eretz Yisrael, <b>as</b> the term <b>dwelling indicates wherever you dwell.</b> This is the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer comes to say:</b> The prohibition of the <b>new crop applies only in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>as</b> the term <b>dwelling indicates</b> a time <b>after inheritance and settlement</b> of Eretz Yisrael by the Jewish people. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> accordingly, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the word: <b>Even,</b> with which Rabbi Eliezer begins his statement? It is not referring to <i>orla</i> and diverse kinds, which apply outside of Eretz Yisrael, but <b>to the first</b> clause, which states that a mitzva that is dependent on the land applies only in Eretz Yisrael. Rabbi Eliezer adds that this principle includes the new crop as well.
Having presented the two ways in which one can explain the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, the Gemara attempts to prove which is correct and suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that <b>which Abaye said: Who</b> is the <b><i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Eliezer? It is Rabbi Yishmael. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the mitzva of bringing libations with offerings: This serves <b>to teach you that wherever</b> the term <b>dwelling is stated,</b> the mitzva in question applies <b>only after</b> the <b>inheritance and settlement</b> of Eretz Yisrael. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva said to him:</b> But there is the case of <b>Shabbat, in which it is stated:</b> “It is a Shabbat to the Lord in all your <b>dwellings”</b> (Leviticus 23:3), <b>and</b> this mitzva <b>applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to</b> Rabbi Akiva: <b>Shabbat is derived through</b> the following <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If less stringent mitzvot apply both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, is it <b>not all the more so</b> reasonable that <b>Shabbat,</b> which is <b>a stringent</b> mitzva, should apply everywhere?
The Gemara explains the proof. <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Abaye said: Who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Eliezer,</b> it is <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> and Rabbi Yishmael says that the term dwelling means that the mitzva applies after Eretz Yisrael has been entirely settled, one can <b>conclude from</b> it that <b>Rabbi Eliezer disagrees</b> with the first <i>tanna</i> with the intent to rule more <b>stringently,</b> as he evidently maintains that the term dwelling means wherever Jews are located. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> that <i>baraita</i> that it is so.
The Gemara asks an incidental question with regard to Rabbi Yishmael’s opinion. <b>Now, where does Rabbi Yishmael stand,</b> i.e., to which specific mitzva is he referring? He is referring <b>to</b> the obligation to bring <b>libations,</b> from which he learns that all mitzvot that feature the term dwelling apply only after Eretz Yisrael had been conquered and settled. <b>With regard to libations</b>

Daf 37b

both the term: <b>Coming, and</b> the term: <b>Dwelling, are written:</b> “When you come into the land of your dwellings” (Numbers 15:2). How, then, can Rabbi Yishmael cite this example to teach about cases where only the term dwelling is written? The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: This teaches that wherever</b> both <b>coming and dwelling are stated,</b> it applies <b>only after inheritance and settlement</b> of Eretz Yisrael; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> consider that <b>Rabbi Akiva said to him:</b> But there is the verse stated with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> (Leviticus 23:3), <b>in which it is stated “dwellings,” and</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to him: Shabbat is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. But <b>let</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>say to</b> Rabbi Akiva instead: <b>I say</b> my principle only when <b>coming and dwelling</b> are both written, and in the case of Shabbat the verse states only the term dwelling. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yishmael <b>states one</b> reason <b>and</b> adds <b>another</b> reason. <b>One</b> reason is <b>that I say</b> my principle only when <b>coming and dwelling</b> are written together. <b>And another</b> reason: With regard to <b>that which you say</b> that there is the case of <b>Shabbat, in which it is stated “dwellings,” Shabbat is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do</b> Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They disagree</b> with regard to whether the Jews <b>sacrificed libations in the wilderness. Rabbi Yishmael maintains: They did not sacrifice libations in the wilderness,</b> as the obligation to sacrifice libations came into effect only once they were living in Eretz Yisrael. <b>And Rabbi Akiva maintains: They did sacrifice libations in the wilderness.</b> Rabbi Akiva derives a different <i>halakha</i> from the term dwelling.
<b>Abaye said: This</b> statement of the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael,</b> that only when the terms coming and dwelling are both written does the mitzva takes effect after settling Eretz Yisrael, <b>diverges from another</b> statement of the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
This is <b>as</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Since</b> instances of <b>coming</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>are mentioned in the Torah</b> in connection to several mitzvot, <b>without specifying</b> precisely when the Jewish people are considered to have arrived there, <b>and the verse specified in one of</b> its references that it applies only <b>after inheritance and settlement</b> of Eretz Yisrael, in the mitzva of appointing a king: “When you come to the land…and you inherit it and settle it” (Deuteronomy 17:14), <b>so too, wherever</b> coming to the land is mentioned without qualification, it means <b>after inheritance and settlement.</b> According to this opinion, there is no need for the verse to also mention the term dwelling.
<b>And</b> the <b>other</b> <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, cited in the dispute with Rabbi Akiva, would say that this is no proof, <b>because there is</b> not only the case of <b>a king</b> but also the mitzva of <b>first fruits,</b> where the verse also uses the terms of coming, inheriting, and dwelling (see Deuteronomy 26:1). Consequently, these are <b>two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., to teach the same matter. <b>And any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a precedent that applies to other cases.
<b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, i.e., the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael cited by Abaye, would answer: Both these cases <b>are necessary,</b> as one cannot be derived from the other. <b>As, if the Merciful One</b> had <b>written</b> this matter only with regard to <b>a king, and had not written</b> it concerning <b>first fruits, I would say:</b> This delay applies only to the mitzva of appointing a king, whereas with regard to the mitzva of <b>first fruits, since one benefits</b> from eating the fruit he should have to bring it <b>immediately</b> and not wait until the land has been inherited and settled. <b>And</b> conversely, <b>had</b> the Merciful One <b>written</b> this matter only with regard to <b>first fruits and had not written</b> it in the case of <b>a king, I would say</b> that as it is <b>the manner of a king to conquer,</b> one must be appointed <b>immediately,</b> even before entering Eretz Yisrael.
<b>And the other,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, cited in the dispute with Rabbi Akiva, would respond: <b>Let the Merciful One write</b> this with regard to <b>a king, and it would not be required</b> to write it in the case of <b>first fruits,</b> as <b>I would say: And if a king, whose</b> task is <b>to conquer</b> Eretz Yisrael, nevertheless is appointed only <b>after inheritance and settlement,</b> with regard to <b>first fruits</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> reasonable that a similar <i>halakha</i> apply to them? If so, these are two verses that come as one, which do not teach a precedent.
<b>And the other,</b> i.e., the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael cited by Abaye, would say: <b>If</b> the Merciful One had <b>written this</b> only with regard to a king, <b>I would say</b> that the Jews should be obligated in the mitzva of first fruits immediately upon entering Eretz Yisrael, and I would not derive the <i>halakha</i> of first fruits from that of appointing a king, <b>just as it is with regard to</b> the separation of <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> another priestly gift from one’s produce, which applied immediately upon the entrance to Eretz Yisrael. Therefore the verse is necessary, as it <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And now that you said</b> that <b>an obligation of the body applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“dwelling” that the Merciful One writes with regard to Shabbat</b> (Leviticus 23:3)? The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to say this, as <b>it might enter your mind to say: Since</b> the mitzva of Shabbat <b>was written in the context of the Festivals, it should require sanctification</b> by the court, <b>like the Festivals,</b> which rely on the sanctification of the New Moon by the court. Therefore the verse <b>teaches us</b> that this is not required.
The Gemara further asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the term <b>dwelling, which the Merciful One writes with regard to</b> the consumption of forbidden <b>fat and blood</b> in the verse: “A perpetual statute throughout your generations in all your dwellings, that you shall eat neither forbidden fat nor blood” (Leviticus 3:17)? The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to state this, as <b>it might enter your mind to say: Since</b> these prohibitions <b>are written in the context of the offerings,</b> then <b>when there is an offering</b> and the priests sacrifice fat and blood upon the altar, i.e., when the Temple is standing, that is when forbidden <b>fat and blood are forbidden</b> for consumption. But <b>when there is no offering,</b> forbidden fat and blood are <b>not</b> forbidden. The verse therefore <b>teaches us</b> that they are always forbidden.
Additionally, the Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the term <b>dwelling, which the Merciful One writes with regard to <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs,</b> in the verse: “In all your dwellings you shall eat <i>matza</i>” (Exodus 12:20)? The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to state this, as <b>it might enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since it is written: “They shall eat</b> the Paschal offering <b>with <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs”</b> (Numbers 9:11), <b>when there is a Paschal offering, yes,</b> one must eat it with <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs, but <b>when there is no Paschal offering,</b> i.e., when the Temple is not standing, there is <b>no</b> obligation to eat <i>matza</i> and bitter herbs. The verse therefore <b>teaches us</b> that these mitzvot apply every Passover, whether or not the Temple is standing.
The Gemara further asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the term <b>coming, which the Merciful One writes with regard to phylacteries and the firstborn donkey,</b> at the start of the Torah passage which discusses these mitzvot: “And it shall be when the Lord will bring you into the land of the Canaanite” (Exodus 13:11)? The Gemara answers: <b>That verse is necessary for that which</b> the <i>tanna</i> of <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Perform this mitzva</b> of donning phylacteries, <b>on account of which</b> you shall be rewarded and <b>enter Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara asks about the term dwelling, written in connection to the prohibition of the new crop. <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the term <b>dwelling indicates wherever you dwell, this</b> explains the fact <b>that it is written</b> with regard to the Jewish people immediately after they entered Eretz Yisrael: <b>“And they ate the produce of the land on the morrow after the Passover”</b> (Joshua 5:11). This means that <b>on the day after the Passover</b> they <b>ate</b> the produce of Eretz Yisrael, but <b>initially,</b> before that date, they <b>did not eat</b> it. <b>Apparently,</b>

Daf 38a

<b>they sacrificed the <i>omer</i> and</b> only <b>afterward</b> did they <b>eat.</b>
<b>But according to the one who says</b> that the term dwelling indicates that the prohibition of the new crop applies only <b>after inheritance and settlement</b> of Eretz Yisrael, <b>let</b> the Jews <b>eat</b> the produce of the land <b>immediately.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They did not need</b> to eat the new produce, as they still had manna. Although they did not eat the new crop of Eretz Yisrael, the reason was not that it was prohibited.
This is <b>as it is written: “And the children of Israel ate the manna forty years until they came to a settled land; they ate the manna until they came to the borders of the land of Canaan”</b> (Exodus 16:35). The Gemara analyzes this verse: <b>One cannot say</b> they ate <b>“until they came to a settled land,”</b> i.e., that they were still eating the manna when they entered Eretz Yisrael, <b>as it is already stated: “To the borders of the land of Canaan,”</b> which indicates that they stopped eating manna before entering Eretz Yisrael, on the plains of Moab. <b>And one cannot say</b> that they ate manna only until they reached <b>“to the borders of the land of Canaan,” as it is already stated: “Until they came to a settled land.” How</b> can <b>these</b> clauses be reconciled? <b>Moses died on the seventh of Adar and the manna ceased falling, and they ate the manna that was</b> left <b>in their vessels until the sixteenth of Nisan,</b> even after they entered Eretz Yisrael.
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And the children of Israel ate the manna forty years”</b> (Exodus 16:35). <b>But did they</b> really <b>eat</b> it for <b>forty years? But didn’t they eat</b> it for <b>forty years less thirty days?</b> The manna began to fall on the sixteenth of Iyyar in the first year in the wilderness, and they stopped eating it on the sixteenth of Nisan in the fortieth year. <b>Rather, this</b> verse comes <b>to tell you</b> that <b>they tasted the taste of manna</b> in the unleavened <b>cakes that they took out from Egypt</b> on the fifteenth of Nisan in their first year, and this sustained them until the manna fell.
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Moses died on the seventh of Adar, and he was</b> likewise <b>born on the seventh of Adar. From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> Moses <b>died on the seventh of Adar? As it is stated: “So Moses, the servant of the Lord, died there”</b> (Deuteronomy 34:5), <b>and it is written: “And the children of Israel wept for Moses in the plains of Moab thirty days”</b> (Deuteronomy 34:8). <b>And it is written: “Now it came to pass after the death of Moses, the servant of the Lord”</b> (Joshua 1:1), <b>and it is written: “Moses, My servant, is dead; now arise, cross</b> this Jordan” (Joshua 1:2).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And it is written: “Pass through the midst of the camp and command the people, saying: Prepare your victuals, for within three days you are to cross the Jordan”</b> (Joshua 1:11). <b>And it is written: “And the people came up out of the Jordan on the tenth day of the first month”</b> (Joshua 4:19). <b>Subtract retroactively from</b> that date, the tenth of Nisan, <b>the last thirty-three days,</b> i.e., the thirty days of mourning for Moses and the three days of preparation before crossing the Jordan, and you <b>learn</b> from here <b>that Moses died on the seventh of Adar.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from where</b> is it derived that <b>Moses was born on the seventh of Adar?</b> It is <b>as it is stated: “And he said to them, I am one hundred and twenty years old today; I can no more go out and come in”</b> (Deuteronomy 31:2). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state “today,”</b> since Moses could have said simply: I am one hundred and twenty years old. <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “today”?</b> One can learn from it that Moses was born on that date, i.e., he was exactly one hundred and twenty years old. <b>This teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, sits and completes the years of the righteous from day to day and from month to month, as it is stated: “The number of your days I will fulfill”</b> (Exodus 23:26).
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: The Jewish people were commanded</b> to perform <b>three mitzvot</b> immediately <b>upon entering Eretz</b> Yisrael: The new crop, diverse kinds, and <i>orla</i>, <b>and</b> these <b>apply both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>And it is logical,</b> i.e., one can derive through an <i>a fortiori</i> argument <b>that</b> each of these mitzvot <b>should apply</b> everywhere. <b>If</b> the prohibition of the <b>new crop, whose prohibition is not a permanent prohibition,</b> as it does not apply to grain that grows after the <i>omer</i> has been sacrificed on the sixteenth of Nisan, <b>and whose prohibition is not a prohibition against</b> deriving <b>benefit,</b> since usages other than eating are permitted, <b>and there is dissolution for its prohibition,</b> i.e., grain that grew before the sixteenth of Nisan becomes permitted after the <i>omer</i> offering has been brought, <b>applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, the same <i>halakha</i> should certainly apply to diverse kinds.
Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai elaborates: With regard to <b>diverse kinds, whose prohibition is a permanent prohibition,</b> as it never expires, <b>and whose prohibition is a prohibition against</b> deriving <b>benefit,</b> since one may not benefit in any manner from diverse kinds of the vine, <b>and there is no dissolution for its prohibition, is it not logical that it should apply both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael? <b>And the same is true of <i>orla</i> with regard to two</b> of those points. <i>Orla</i> is not a permanent prohibition, as it applies only for the first three years that a tree produces fruit, but one may not derive benefit from it, and produce from the first three years never becomes permitted.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says:</b>

Daf 38b

<b>Any mitzva that the Jewish people were commanded</b> to perform <b>before entering Eretz</b> Yisrael, i.e., it was not linked to entry into the land, <b>applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. Conversely, any mitzva that they were commanded to perform <b>after they entered Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>applies only in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>except for</b> the <b>abrogation of monetary</b> debts in the Sabbatical Year (see Deuteronomy 15:1–2), <b>and</b> the <b>emancipation of slaves</b> in the Jubilee Year (see Leviticus 25:39–41). <b>Even though</b> the Jews <b>were commanded with regard to these</b> mitzvot that they were to perform them only <b>after their entry into Eretz</b> Yisrael, these mitzvot <b>apply both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara questions the need for this ruling: <b>The abrogation of monetary</b> debts <b>is an obligation of the body.</b> Since this mitzva is not referring to the land, what is the novelty of the ruling that it applies even outside of Eretz Yisrael?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is necessary</b> to mention the cancellation of debts <b>only for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The verse states in the context of the cancellation of debts: <b>“And this is the manner of the abrogation: He shall abrogate”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:2). <b>The verse speaks of two</b> types of <b>abrogation: One</b> is <b>the release of land and one</b> is the <b>abrogation of monetary</b> debts. Since the two are juxtaposed, one can learn the following: <b>At a time when you release land,</b> when the Jubilee Year is practiced, <b>you abrogate monetary</b> debts; <b>at a time when you do not release land,</b> such as the present time, when the Jubilee Year is no longer practiced, <b>you</b> also <b>do not abrogate monetary</b> debts.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say</b> that one can learn the following from this juxtaposition: <b>In a place</b> where <b>you release land,</b> i.e., in Eretz Yisrael, <b>you abrogate monetary</b> debts, <b>and in a place</b> where <b>you do not release land, you do not abrogate monetary</b> debts. If so, the abrogation of debts would apply only in Eretz Yisrael, despite the fact that this obligation is not related to the land. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Because the Lord’s abrogation has been proclaimed”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:2), to indicate that this obligation applies <b>in any case,</b> even outside of Eretz Yisrael. This is the novelty of the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.
The Gemara questions the need for second ruling of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon: <b>The emancipation of slaves is</b> also <b>an obligation of the body,</b> not one that applies to the land. What is novel about this ruling? The Gemara answers that <b>it might enter your mind to say: Since it is written: “And proclaim liberty throughout the land</b> unto all the inhabitants thereof” (Leviticus 25:10), one could say: <b>“Throughout the land,” yes,</b> this mitzva applies, but <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>no,</b> the emancipation does not take effect. Therefore <b>the</b> same <b>verse</b> also <b>states</b> the seemingly superfluous phrase: <b>“It shall be a Jubilee”</b> (Leviticus 25:10), to indicate that it applies <b>in any case,</b> in all places.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Throughout the land”?</b> The Gemara answers that this phrase teaches: <b>When the liberty</b> of slaves <b>applies in Eretz</b> Yisrael, it also <b>applies outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, and when <b>the liberty</b> of slaves <b>does not apply in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>it does not apply outside</b> of <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael. The mitzva depends on whether the Jubilee Year is in effect, not on the place in question.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Orla</i> 3:9): <b>The new crop is forbidden by Torah law everywhere; <i>orla</i></b> is forbidden outside of Eretz Yisrael according to <b>a <i>halakha</i>,</b> as the Gemara will immediately explain; <b>and diverse kinds</b> are forbidden outside the land <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is this <b><i>halakha</i>,</b> mentioned with regard to <i>orla</i>? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> It is the <b>local <i>halakha</i>,</b> i.e., this was the practice of Jews in places where they settled. <b>Ulla</b> says that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b>
<b>Ulla said to Rav Yehuda: Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say</b> in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan that the mishna means that this is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai, this is</b> the reason <b>why we distinguish between</b> fruit whose status as <b><i>orla</i></b> is <b>uncertain,</b> which is forbidden outside of Eretz Yisrael according to the <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and</b> produce whose status as <b>diverse kinds</b> is <b>uncertain,</b> which is permitted outside of Eretz Yisrael, as the prohibition of diverse kinds applies outside of Eretz Yisrael only by rabbinic law.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Orla</i> 3:9): Fruit whose status as <b><i>orla</i></b> is <b>uncertain is forbidden in Eretz</b> Yisrael, and <b>it is permitted in Syria</b> with no concern about its uncertain status. <b>Outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, a Jew may <b>go down</b> into the gentile’s field <b>and purchase</b> fruit that is <i>orla</i> from the gentile, <b>provided that</b> the Jew <b>does not see him gather</b> it.
<b>Nevertheless, we learned</b> in a mishna <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>diverse kinds</b> (<i>Orla</i> 3:9): If <b>a vineyard has vegetables planted in it, and</b> there are <b>vegetables being sold outside</b> the vineyard, but there is no proof that these vegetables came from the vineyard, <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael they are <b>forbidden.</b> The reason is that as it is possible that the vegetables came from the vineyard, the <i>halakha</i> is stringent in a case involving a prohibition by Torah law. <b>In Syria</b> these vegetables are <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, if the gentile owner of a field containing diverse kinds <b>goes down</b> into his field <b>and gathers</b> produce, then, <b>provided that</b> the Jew <b>does not gather</b> it <b>by hand,</b> he may purchase the produce from the gentile. This indicates that outside of Eretz Yisrael there is a difference between <i>orla</i> of uncertain status and diverse kinds of uncertain status. This is understandable if <i>orla</i> is forbidden by a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, while diverse kinds are forbidden by rabbinic law.
<b>But according to your</b> opinion, that neither <i>orla</i> nor diverse kinds is forbidden by Torah law,

Daf 39a

<b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> in the same manner in both cases, <b>either</b> by stating in <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case that <b>one may go down and purchase</b> the produce, <b>or</b> by stating in <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case that <b>one may go down and gather</b> the produce. The Gemara answers: <b>Didn’t Shmuel say to Rav Anan</b> that one should <b>teach it either</b> as stating in <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case that <b>one may go down and purchase</b> the produce, <b>or</b> in <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case that <b>one may go down and gather</b> the produce? <b>Mar, son of Rabbana, taught this</b> mishna according to the following <b>lenient</b> version: In <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case <b>one may go down and gather</b> the produce, <b>provided that he does not gather</b> it <b>with</b> his own <b>hand.</b>
§ With regard to the prohibition of <i>orla</i> outside of Eretz Yisrael, the Gemara relates that <b>Levi said to Shmuel: Aryokh,</b> Shmuel’s nickname, <b>supply me</b> with such food, as I will not pick it on my own, <b>and</b> if you do so <b>I will eat</b> it. There is no reason for concern with regard to <i>orla</i> outside of Eretz Yisrael. <b>Rav Avya and Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan would supply</b> produce whose <i>orla</i> status was uncertain <b>for each other,</b> as it is forbidden only if one takes the <i>orla</i> on his own. <b>The sharp</b> Sages <b>of Pumbedita said:</b> The prohibition of <b><i>orla</i> does not</b> apply at all <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>Rav Yehuda sent</b> a question <b>to Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> concerning the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <i>orla</i> outside of Eretz Yisrael. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan sent him</b> the following response: <b>Conceal,</b> i.e., do not publicize, the <i>halakha</i> that produce whose <i>orla</i> status is <b>uncertain</b> is permitted; <b>and destroy,</b> i.e., prohibit entirely, produce whose <i>orla</i> status is <b>certain; and with regard to</b> the <b>produce of</b> those who are lenient in this <i>halakha</i>, <b>declare that it requires interment,</b> as it is prohibited to derive benefit from such produce. <b>And whoever says</b> that there is <b>no</b> prohibition of <b><i>orla</i> outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>will have neither a child nor a grandchild “who shall cast the line by lot in the congregation of the Lord”</b> (Micah 2:5).
The Gemara asks: <b>And in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do</b> the sharp Sages of Pumbedita <b>hold</b> when they state this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: They hold <b>in accordance with that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in the name of Rabbi Yosei ben Durmaska, who said in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, who said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer the Great:</b> The prohibition of <b><i>orla</i></b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this ruling: <b>But</b> does it <b>not</b> apply? Does Rabbi Eliezer maintain that the prohibition of <i>orla</i> does not apply outside of Eretz Yisrael? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Even</b> the <b>new crop,</b> which indicates that he agrees that <i>orla</i> and diverse kinds are forbidden outside of Eretz Yisrael? The Gemara answers that one should not <b>teach</b> that Rabbi Eliezer said: Even the new crop, but rather teach only the words: The <b>new crop,</b> i.e., Rabbi Eliezer maintains that only this prohibition applies outside of Eretz Yisrael.
<b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: <i>Orla</i></b> is forbidden <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael by <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Asi: But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to produce whose status concerning <b><i>orla</i></b> is <b>uncertain, in Eretz</b> Yisrael it is <b>forbidden, in Syria</b> it is <b>permitted,</b> and <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>one goes down and gathers</b> it? And if <i>orla</i> is forbidden outside of Eretz Yisrael by a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, why is produce whose status concerning <i>orla</i> is uncertain permitted in Syria? Rabbi Zeira <b>“was dismayed for a while”</b> (Daniel 4:16), and then Rabbi Asi <b>said to him: Say</b> that <b>it is stated like this,</b> i.e., explain that the <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai was that outside of Eretz Yisrael produce whose status concerning <i>orla</i> is <b>uncertain</b> is <b>permitted, and</b> produce whose status concerning <i>orla</i> is <b>certain</b> is <b>forbidden.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Offenders <b>are flogged for</b> transgressing the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds</b> outside of Eretz Yisrael <b>by Torah law. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said to him: But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (<i>Orla</i> 3:9) that the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds</b> applies <b>by rabbinic law</b> outside of Eretz Yisrael? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b> The mishna <b>here</b> is referring <b>to diverse kinds in a vineyard,</b> which is prohibited outside of Eretz Yisrael by rabbinic law, whereas <b>there,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is referring <b>to</b> the <b>grafting of a tree</b> onto a different species.
The Gemara adds that this <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel says:</b> The verse states: <b>“You shall keep My statutes”</b> (Leviticus 19:19), which means that one must keep even the <b>statutes that I have already instituted for you</b> when you were merely descendants of Noah, before the giving of the Torah. Shmuel elaborates: This is referring to the prohibitions stated in that same verse: <b>“You shall not let your cattle gender with a diverse kind; you shall not sow your field</b> with two kinds of seed” (Leviticus 19:19).
Additionally, the juxtaposition of these prohibitions teaches that <b>just as</b> the prohibition of diverse kinds stated with regard to <b>your animal</b> applies only <b>to mating</b> one species with another, <b>so too,</b> the prohibition of diverse kinds with regard to <b>your field</b> is referring only <b>to grafting</b> one type of tree to another type, and it does not apply to planting two species together.
