<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: Everyone agrees that there is no agent for transgression. Nevertheless, Shammai holds that <b>there,</b> with regard to killing, it <b>is different, since the Merciful One reveals: “Him you have slain with the sword of the children of Ammon,”</b> explicitly rendering David accountable for this transgression and indicating that killing is different from all other transgressions.
<b>And the other</b> opinion, i.e., the first <i>tanna</i>, who holds that the one who appoints the killer is exempt, explains the verse as follows: <b>Behold</b> this killing is <b>for you like the sword of Ammon. Just as you are not punished</b> for those killed by <b>the sword of Ammon</b> in the course of the war, <b>so too you are not punished for</b> the death of <b>Uriah the Hittite,</b> not even according to the laws of Heaven. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Uriah <b>was a rebel against the monarchy</b> and was consequently liable to the death penalty, <b>as he said to</b> King David: <b>“And my lord Joab, and the servants of my lord, are encamped in the open field”</b> (II Samuel 11:11). By referring to Joab as his lord in front of the king, he indicated that he answered to Joab rather than to the king, which is tantamount to rebellion.
<b>Rava said: If you say</b> that <b>Shammai holds</b> that <b>two verses that come as one do teach</b> a precedent, <b>and he does not interpret</b> the variation from <b>“<i>hu</i>”</b> to <b>“<i>hahu</i>,”</b> the combination of which would result in him holding that there is agency for transgression in all cases, even he <b>concedes with regard to one who says to his agent: Go and engage in sexual intercourse with a forbidden relative,</b> or: Go <b>and eat</b> forbidden <b>fat, that</b> the agent <b>is liable and the one who appointed him is exempt, as we have not found in the entire Torah</b> a case where <b>this</b> person physically <b>benefits</b> from the transgression <b>but that</b> one <b>becomes liable.</b>
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> engaged in a dispute concerning the following issue: <b>Rav says: An agent can become a witness.</b> If one was appointed as an agent to perform a certain task, he can then serve as a witness that the action was performed. <b>In the school of Rabbi Sheila they say: An agent cannot become a witness.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of the school of Rabbi Sheila? If we say</b> it is <b>because</b> the one who appointed him <b>did not say to</b> the agent: <b>Be a witness for me,</b> and appointed him only as an agent; <b>if that is so,</b> if one <b>betrothed a woman in the presence of two</b> people <b>and did not say to them: You are my witnesses, so too</b> would they hold <b>that it is not a betrothal?</b> It is not necessary to explicitly appoint witnesses.
<b>Rather,</b> the dispute is as follows. <b>Rav says: An agent can become a witness,</b> since <b>we strengthen his words</b> of testimony because he attests to a matter of which he is certain, as he is the one that performed the action. <b>In the school of Rabbi Sheila they say: An agent cannot become a witness. Since the Master said</b> that the legal status of <b>a person’s agent is like</b> that of <b>himself,</b> the agent <b>is considered like</b> the one who appointed him <b>himself.</b> Just as one cannot testify with regard to a matter that concerns himself, the same applies to one’s agent.
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> to the statement of Rav: If one <b>said to three</b> people: <b>Go out and betroth the woman for me,</b> then <b>one</b> of them is the <b>agent</b> for the betrothal <b>and two</b> of them serve as <b>witnesses;</b> this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say: They are all</b> potential <b>agents, and</b> as <b>an agent cannot become a witness</b> none of them can be witnesses. Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <b>disagree only with regard to</b> a case where one said this to <b>three</b> people. <b>But with regard to two</b> people, <b>all agree</b> that agents are <b>not</b> able to serve as witnesses.
The Gemara answers: It was <b>he,</b> Rav, <b>who said</b> his ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the version of Beit Shammai as presented by Rabbi Natan. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan says: Beit Shammai say</b> that <b>the agent and one witness</b> are sufficient to carry out the agency and testify, <b>and Beit Hillel say: The agent and two witnesses</b> are needed. The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>And</b> would <b>Rav</b> rule <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the opinions, so that it is Beit Hillel who said that the agent and one witness suffice. <b>And Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, taught</b> the dispute of the <i>amora’im</i> in the <b>opposite</b> manner. <b>Rav says: An agent cannot become a witness,</b> and <b>in the school of Rabbi Sheila they say: An agent can become a witness.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>an agent can become a witness.</b>
<b>Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> It follows that if one <b>said to two</b> people: <b>Go and betroth the woman for me, the very same</b> people who are <b>his agents</b> for the betrothal <b>are his witnesses. And a similar</b> <i>halakha</i> is true <b>with regard to divorce:</b> If a man sent a bill of divorce to his wife with two people, they serve both as agents of delivery and as witnesses to the divorce.

Daf 43b

<b>And a similar</b> <i>halakha</i> applies <b>with regard to</b> cases of <b>monetary law.</b> If one appoints agents to perform a transaction for him, e.g., paying a debt to his creditor, they can testify that he has paid.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for Rav Naḥman to teach this <i>halakha</i> in each of these legal domains, <b>as had he taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only in</b> the case of <b>betrothal</b> one could say that the agents can serve as witnesses <b>because</b> they <b>are coming to render her forbidden</b> to everyone else, and therefore there is no reason to suspect them of lying, as their testimony renders her forbidden to them as well. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>divorce, we should be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the agent <b>cast his eyes upon her</b> and is testifying falsely so that he can marry her.
<b>And had</b> Rav Naḥman <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only in the case of <b>divorce,</b> it could have been said that the agents are not suspected of lying <b>because a woman is not fit for</b> marrying <b>two</b> people, and since they testify as a pair there is no concern that they both might have designs upon her. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>money,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>these</b> two can <b>divide</b> it between them, and perhaps they never paid the debt but kept the money themselves. Therefore, all the examples <b>are necessary.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> Rav Naḥman <b>hold? If he holds</b> that in the case of <b>one who lends</b> money to <b>another in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> the debtor <b>must repay him in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> then <b>these</b> agents <b>are affected by their testimony. As, if they say: We did not repay him</b> but returned the money to the one who appointed us, then the one who appointed them will <b>say to them: Pay me</b> back the money I gave you to repay the debt. The agents are considered as the debtors of the one who appointed them, as they took money from him. They would not be deemed credible to state that they returned the money to the one who appointed them, as they do not have witnesses that they did so. Consequently, they have a financial incentive to testify falsely that they fulfilled their agency and repaid the debt.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav Naḥman <b>actually holds</b> that in the case of <b>one who lends</b> money to <b>another in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses,</b> the debtor <b>does not need to repay him in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses. And since</b> the agents <b>are able to say: We returned</b> the money <b>to the debtor,</b> even without there being witnesses to substantiate their claim, <b>they can</b> also be deemed credible <b>to say: We repaid the creditor,</b> as they have no financial incentive to lie.
The Gemara comments: <b>And now,</b> since the time of Rav Naḥman, <b>when the Sages instituted an oath of inducement,</b> an oath instituted by the Sages in a case where a defendant completely denies a claim, these witnesses are affected by their testimony. If they were to claim that they returned the money to the one who appointed them, they would be required to take an oath of inducement to that effect. Consequently, they have an incentive to lie and claim that they fulfilled their agency and repaid the loan. Therefore, their testimony that they fulfilled their agency is not deemed credible. Instead, <b>these witnesses take an oath</b> in court <b>that they gave</b> the money <b>to him,</b> i.e., the lender, <b>and</b> the <b>lender</b> in turn <b>takes an oath that he did not take</b> the money owed to him, <b>and</b> then <b>the debtor pays the lender</b> his debt a second time, as the Sages ruled in similar cases.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>a man can betroth his daughter</b> to a man when she is a young woman. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Gittin</i> 64b): With regard to <b>a betrothed young woman, she and her father</b> are each eligible to <b>receive her bill of divorce. Rabbi Yehuda said: Two hands do not</b> have the right to <b>acquire</b> an item on behalf of one person <b>as one.</b> If the young woman is able to acquire an item on her own, her father cannot receive her bill of divorce. Conversely, if she is not able to acquire an item on her own, only her father can receive the bill of divorce. <b>Rather, her father</b> alone <b>receives her bill of divorce</b> on her behalf. The mishna states another principle: <b>And any</b> female <b>who is unable to safeguard her bill of divorce,</b> either due to her young age or mental incompetence, <b>is unable to be divorced,</b> since a bill of divorce is effective only for one who understands the severing of ties that a divorce engenders.
<b>Reish Lakish says: Just as</b> there is <b>a dispute with regard to divorce,</b> as to whether both a young woman and her father can accept her bill of divorce or only the father can do so, <b>so too</b> there is <b>a dispute with regard to betrothal. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The dispute is with regard to divorce, but</b> with regard to <b>betrothal everyone agrees</b> that <b>her father</b> has the right to accept it <b>but not her.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What is the reason of Rabbi Yoḥanan, in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> that there is a distinction between divorce and betrothal? In the case of <b>divorce, when she brings herself</b> back <b>into her father’s authority</b> by means of the bill of divorce, it is considered as though the father has obtained the bill of divorce via his daughter, and therefore <b>either she or her father</b> can receive it. In the case of <b>betrothal, where she removes herself from her father’s authority,</b> she cannot do this by herself. Consequently, only <b>her father</b> can accept the betrothal, <b>but not her.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the case of <b>levirate betrothal,</b> where the <i>yevama</i> <b>removes herself from her father’s authority, and</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 44a

If <b>a minor girl</b> was widowed <b>after</b> her <b>betrothal,</b> a surviving brother of her betrothed <b>can perform levirate betrothal only with the consent of her father. And</b> in the case of <b>a young woman,</b> he can do so <b>either with her consent [<i>mida’at atzmah</i>] or with the consent of her father, unlike</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> standard <b>betrothal.</b> This indicates that a young woman can accept levirate betrothal on her own, despite the fact that it removes her from her father’s authority.
<b>Rather, if</b> it <b>was stated, it was stated like this: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says: What is</b> the <b>reason of Rabbi Yoḥanan, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis?</b> With regard to <b>betrothal, which</b> takes effect only <b>with</b> the <b>consent</b> of the one who accepts the betrothal, <b>her father</b> can accept it <b>but not her,</b> since betrothal requires his approval. With regard to a bill of <b>divorce,</b> which can be given <b>without her consent, either she or her father</b> can receive it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t levirate betrothal</b> valid only <b>with her consent,</b> like other betrothals, <b>and</b> yet <b>it teaches</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>either she or her father</b> can accept it? The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> it is referring <b>to levirate betrothal that is</b> performed <b>against her will, and it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a <i>yavam</i> <b>performs levirate betrothal with his <i>yevama</i> without her consent, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The <i>yavam</i> <b>acquires</b> her. <b>And the Rabbis say: He does not acquire</b> her.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? <b>He derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of levirate betrothal <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>sexual intercourse that</b> a <i>yavam</i> engages in with <b>a <i>yevama</i>: Just as intercourse with</b> the <b><i>yevama</i></b> renders her acquired even if it is done <b>against her will, so too here,</b> in the case of levirate betrothal, the <i>yavam</i> can betroth her <b>against her will. And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of levirate betrothal <b>from</b> standard <b>betrothal: Just as betrothal</b> can be performed only <b>with her consent, so too here,</b> levirate betrothal can be performed only <b>with her consent.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>one should derive matters</b> involving <b>a <i>yevama</i> from</b> other matters involving <b>a <i>yevama</i>,</b> and the marriage between a <i>yevama</i> and a <i>yavam</i> can be formalized against her will. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>one should derive</b> matters involving <b>betrothal from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>betrothal,</b> as levirate betrothal is structured like standard betrothal in other respects.
The Gemara comments: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to rule with regard to betrothal <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan explains,</b> that only the father can accept betrothal, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches</b> in the <b>latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> that with regard to levirate betrothal, in the case of <b>a young woman,</b> the <i>yavam</i> can perform it either with her consent or with the consent of her father, <b>unlike</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> standard <b>betrothal.</b> This indicates that she can be betrothed in standard betrothal only with her father’s agreement. The Gemara asks: <b>Then shall we say</b> that <b>this should be a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish,</b> who holds that according to the Rabbis a young woman can also accept her own betrothal? The Gemara answers: <b>Reish Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says: Two hands do not acquire</b> an item <b>as one.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> why does the <i>baraita</i> state: <b>Unlike</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> standard <b>betrothal? It should</b> have stated: <b>Unlike</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to divorce,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda stated his opinion in the mishna with regard to divorce, not betrothal. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so,</b> it should have referred to divorce, but <b>since it taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>levirate betrothal, which</b> is <b>similar to betrothal, it also taught: Unlike</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> standard <b>betrothal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is levirate betrothal different from</b> divorce? Why can a young woman accept the former but not receive a bill of divorce, when both levirate betrothal and divorce can be performed without her consent? The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> of levirate betrothal is different. <b>Since she is bonded</b> to the <i>yavam</i> <b>and standing</b> in wait for him, acceptance of the betrothal money by the <i>yevama</i> suffices to effect the levirate betrothal. The Gemara comments: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> explanation, the statement of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan also should not pose a difficulty for you from the outset.</b> One cannot question his statement with regard to the Rabbis’ opinion in the case of betrothal. <b>Levirate betrothal is different, since</b> the <i>yevama</i> <b>is bonded</b> to the <i>yavam</i> <b>and standing</b> in wait for him.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>a man can betroth his daughter</b> to a man <b>when she is a young woman, by himself or by</b> means of <b>his agent.</b> The Gemara analyzes this: <b>Yes,</b> he can betroth her <b>by himself or by</b> means of <b>his agent, but no,</b> she cannot become betrothed <b>by herself or by</b> means of <b>her agent.</b> This is <b>a conclusive refutation of Reish Lakish,</b> who holds that according to the opinion of the Rabbis a young woman can accept her own betrothal. The Gemara answers: <b>Reish Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you: This</b> mishna <b>too is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But can you establish this</b> mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda? But the last clause,</b> in the following mishna (46b), <b>teaches:</b> In the case of <b>one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me with this date</b> and adds: <b>Be betrothed to me with that</b> date, she is betrothed only if one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i> on its own. <b>And we say: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that the two dates are valued separately only if he said: <b>Become betrothed</b> and: <b>Become betrothed,</b> in a separate statement when giving each date, but that if he said: Become betrothed, only once, the value of the two dates are added together?
<b>And Rabba said: It is Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that one is not liable to bring multiple offerings for taking false oaths to multiple people in the same utterance. For example, if one says: I take an oath that I do not have your item, nor yours, nor yours, he brings a single offering. This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>unless one states</b> an expression of <b>an oath to each and every one</b> of the plaintiffs, by stating: I take an oath I do not have yours; I take an oath I do not have yours, in which case he brings multiple offerings. Consequently, the <i>tanna</i> of this mishna is Rabbi Shimon, not Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>And if you would say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the <b>entire</b> mishna concerning betrothal is <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> that <b>with regard to the specification</b> of separate oaths <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> this cannot be. <b>But does he</b> in fact <b>hold in accordance</b> with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon with regard to the specification of separate oaths?
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is the principle</b> with regard to one’s liability to bring offerings for a false oath: If he <b>included</b> all the statements in one oath <b>he is liable</b> for <b>only one</b> oath, but if he <b>specified</b> them, <b>he is liable for each and every one;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If one said: I take <b>an oath</b> that I do not have your deposit, <b>nor yours, nor yours, nor yours,</b> and he was found to have taken a false oath, <b>he is liable</b> to bring an offering <b>for each and every one. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> If he said: I do <b>not</b> have <b>yours, nor yours, nor yours, and nor yours,</b> I take <b>an oath,</b> then <b>he is liable for each and every one.</b> Since he stated the oath at the end, it refers back to each element of his statement. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: He is liable</b> to bring more than one offering <b>only if</b> he <b>states</b> an expression of <b>an oath for each and every one.</b> This indicates that Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with Rabbi Shimon with regard to the question of when oaths are considered distinct.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains in the opposite manner: The <i>tanna</i> of the <b>entire</b> mishna concerning betrothal is <b>Rabbi Shimon, and with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>agency he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> that only the father of a young woman can appoint an agent to accept her betrothal or receive her bill of divorce.
The Gemara relates: One day <b>Rabbi Asi did not go to the study hall. He found Rabbi Zeira</b> and <b>said to him: What was said today in the study hall?</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: I too did not go,</b> but <b>Rabbi Avin is the one who went, and he said: The entire coterie</b> sided <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that there is a difference between betrothal and divorce in the case of a young woman. <b>And Reish Lakish screamed</b> at them <b>like a crane:</b> Doesn’t the verse state: <b>“And she departs</b> out of his house <b>and</b> goes and <b>becomes</b> another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2), juxtaposing the <i>halakhot</i> of divorce and betrothal? <b>But no one paid any attention to him.</b> Rabbi Asi <b>said to him:</b> Is <b>Rabbi Avin reliable?</b> Can one be sure that he transmitted an accurate report? Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: Yes,</b> in this case he can be trusted, since the elapsed time <b>was</b> only <b>like</b> the interval between catching a fish <b>from the sea</b> and bringing it <b>to a frying pan [<i>tignei</i>].</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says:</b> When <b>I</b> quote this statement, I do <b>not</b> state it in the name of <b>Rabbi Avin, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, nor Rabbi Avin bar Kahana, but</b> in the name of <b>Rabbi Avin, without specification.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is there?</b> Why does it matter which Rabbi Avin is cited as the source of this statement? The Gemara answers: It would matter if one were <b>to raise a contradiction between</b> one of <b>his</b> rulings and another one of <b>his</b> rulings. If there were to be a conflicting opinion attributed to a specific Rabbi Avin, e.g., Rabbi Avin, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, it would not be a true contradiction, as this statement might have been issued by a different Rabbi Avin.
<b>Rava asked Rav Naḥman:</b>

Daf 44b

According to the Rabbis, who hold that a young woman can accept her own bill of divorce, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the ability of <b>a young woman to appoint an agent to receive her bill of divorce from the hand of her husband?</b> The Gemara explains the two sides of this question: Since a young woman is under her father’s jurisdiction, is she, with regard to acquisitions, <b>considered like</b> an extension of <b>her father’s hand, or</b> is she <b>considered like her father’s courtyard?</b> The Gemara clarifies: She might be <b>considered like her father’s hand,</b> and <b>just as her father can appoint an agent, so too she can appoint an agent. Or perhaps</b> she is <b>considered like her father’s courtyard, and</b> therefore <b>she is not divorced until the bill of divorce</b> actually <b>reaches her possession,</b> as a courtyard cannot appoint an agent, but it can receive a bill of divorce, in the sense that a bill of divorce thrown in his courtyard is considered to be in his possession.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is Rava uncertain</b> about <b>this</b> matter? <b>But doesn’t Rava say:</b> If one <b>wrote a bill of divorce and placed it in the hand of</b> his wife’s <b>slave,</b> who is <b>sleeping, but</b> she <b>is guarding him,</b> then <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b> If the slave was <b>awake,</b> then <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. Why is it not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce</b> if he is <b>awake?</b> It is because the slave is <b>for her a courtyard that is not consciously secured by her,</b> i.e., when the slave is awake, he is not fully controlled by her. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that a young woman is <b>considered like her father’s courtyard,</b> then <b>even when the bill of divorce reaches her possession she should not be divorced, since she is</b> like <b>a courtyard that is not consciously secured by her father.</b>
<b>Rather, it is actually obvious to</b> Rava <b>that</b> a young woman <b>is considered like her father’s hand</b> and not like his courtyard, <b>and this is what he was asking: Is</b> she just <b>as strong as her father’s hand,</b> to the extent <b>that she can appoint an agent, or not?</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: She cannot appoint an agent.</b>
Rava <b>raised an objection to him</b> from a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 65a): In the case of <b>a minor girl who said</b> to an agent: <b>Receive my bill of divorce for me, it is not</b> a <b>valid bill of divorce until the bill of divorce reaches her possession,</b> since a minor is not considered halakhically competent and cannot appoint an agent. Rava inferred from this: <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a young woman, it is a bill of divorce,</b> which indicates that a young woman can appoint an agent. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a situation <b>where she does not have a father,</b> and she can appoint an agent since she is of age and is under her own authority. But a betrothed young woman whose father is still alive is under his authority and cannot appoint an agent.
The Gemara asks: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter</b> clause of that same mishna <b>teaches: If her father said</b> to an agent: <b>Go out and receive a bill of divorce for my daughter,</b> then <b>if the husband seeks to retract</b> his decision after he has given the bill of divorce to the agent <b>he cannot retract</b> it, since it is as though the bill of divorce reached her possession, <b>by inference,</b> one can say <b>that</b> in <b>the first</b> clause <b>we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where she has a father.</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and this is what it is teaching:</b> In the case of <b>a minor girl who said: Receive my bill of divorce for me, it is not a bill of divorce until the bill of divorce reaches her possession. But</b> in the case of <b>a young woman, it is a bill of divorce</b> as soon as it reaches her agent’s possession. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>when she does not have a father. But</b> if <b>she has a father, and her father said</b> to an agent: <b>Go out and receive my daughter’s bill of divorce on</b> her behalf, <b>and the husband seeks to retract</b> his decision, <b>he cannot retract</b> it.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed in the case of <b>a minor who became betrothed without her father’s consent. Shmuel says:</b> If her husband seeks to divorce her <b>she requires a bill of divorce</b> to sever the marriage, <b>and she</b> also <b>requires refusal,</b> which annuls a betrothal that is valid by rabbinic law but not by Torah law. <b>Karna says:</b> There are puzzling <b>matters</b> included <b>within</b> this statement, since it is self-contradictory: <b>If</b> she needs <b>a bill of divorce,</b> and the betrothal is evidently treated as a proper betrothal, <b>why</b> does she require <b>refusal?</b> Conversely, <b>if</b> she requires <b>refusal,</b> indicating that her betrothal was of no consequence by Torah law, <b>why</b> does she require <b>a bill of divorce?</b>
The Sages <b>said to him: Now</b> that <b>Mar Ukva and his court are in</b> the town of <b>Kafrei,</b> let us pose the question to them. Furthermore, <b>they reversed</b> the names of the respective opinions of Shmuel and Karna and <b>sent</b> the question <b>before Rav.</b> He <b>said to</b> the messengers in the form of an oath: <b>By God! She requires a bill of divorce and she requires refusal. And</b> God <b>forbid that the seed of Abba bar Abba,</b> i.e., Shmuel, should <b>say such</b> a thing, that she does not require both.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that there is a need for both a bill of divorce and refusal? <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: She requires a bill of divorce</b> because <b>perhaps the father desired the betrothal,</b> which would mean it would take effect retroactively. <b>She</b> also <b>requires refusal</b> because <b>perhaps the father did not desire the betrothal,</b> and it did not take effect. If she receives only a bill of divorce, <b>and</b> her former husband proceeds to betroth her sister, people <b>will say</b> that the <b>betrothal does not take effect with her sister.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that betrothal can take effect with the sister of one’s wife or former wife only after the first wife has died. She is therefore required to perform refusal, to indicate that the validity of her betrothal was uncertain. If he later betroths her sister, he would be required to divorce her due to the uncertainty if this second betrothal took effect.
<b>Rav Naḥman said: And this</b> concern that the father of a minor might later state that he desired her betrothal is relevant only <b>when they arranged</b> the match before she betrothed herself, as in that case it is likely that the father desired the betrothal.
The Gemara quotes another opinion. <b>Ulla said:</b> If a minor accepted betrothal without her father’s consent, her betrothal does not take effect, and <b>she does not even require refusal.</b> The Gemara asks: Does Ulla’s statement apply <b>even though they arranged</b> the match? The Gemara answers: <b>He who teaches this does not teach that.</b> The one who cited Ulla’s statement does not hold that Shmuel’s ruling applies only in the case of an arranged match, rather it applies in all cases. According to this opinion, Ulla stated his <i>halakha</i> only in a case where the match was not arranged. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Ulla says:</b> If <b>a minor became betrothed without her father’s consent, she does not even require refusal,</b> including a case where the match was arranged.
<b>Rav Kahana raises an objection:</b> The mishna in <i>Yevamot</i> (2a) teaches that if a potential <i>yevama</i> is in one of the fifteen categories of women forbidden to the <i>yavam</i> as a relative, not only is she forbidden to him, but he also may not perform levirate marriage with any of her rival wives. The Sages then clarified this <i>halakha</i>: <b>And if,</b> before the husband had died, <b>any of</b> those forbidden women <b>had died, or had performed refusal; or had been divorced; or had been found</b> to be <b>a sexually underdeveloped woman [<i>ailonit</i>],</b> who is incapable of bearing children, then <b>her rival wives are permitted</b> to the <i>yavam</i>.
Rav Kahana focuses on the case of one who performed refusal: With regard to this refusal that she performed, what type of betrothal did it follow? <b>When she was betrothed by whom? If we say</b> that <b>her father betrothed her</b> to the brother who died, is <b>refusal</b> alone <b>enough for her</b> to dissolve the marriage? Doesn’t she <b>require a proper bill of divorce? Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where she betrothed herself</b> when she was a minor, <b>and</b> the mishna nevertheless <b>teaches that she requires refusal.</b> This presents a difficulty for Ulla, who holds that she does not need even refusal.
The Gemara comments: Rav Kahana <b>raised the objection and he resolved it:</b> The mishna refers to a case <b>where she became</b> like <b>an orphan in her father’s lifetime,</b> i.e., her father betrothed her to a man, and she was subsequently widowed or divorced while still a minor. In that case, the same <i>halakha</i> as that of an orphan applies to her, in that her father does not have the right to betroth her again, although he is still alive. If she then would betroth herself, her betrothal is not effective by Torah law, because she is still a minor. It does take effect by rabbinic law, and she can annul that marriage by performing refusal. This would not be a question for Ulla, as he stated his ruling in a case where it was the first betrothal of the minor.
<b>Rav Hamnuna raises an objection:</b> It is taught in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a Hebrew maidservant: A father <b>cannot sell</b> his minor daughter as a Hebrew maidservant <b>to</b> her <b>relatives</b> because the Torah requires that the one who purchases a maidservant be able to marry her. The Sages <b>said in the name of Rabbi Elazar:</b> He can <b>sell her</b> even <b>to</b> her <b>relatives,</b> as sometimes a Hebrew maidservant serves only in that capacity, without marrying the master.

Daf 45a

<b>And they agree that he can sell her to a High Priest</b> even if she is <b>a widow,</b> or <b>to a common priest</b> even if she is <b>a divorcée or</b> is <b>a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>].</b> Although such marriages are prohibited, they do take effect. The Gemara analyzes this: <b>What are the circumstances of this widow</b> who can be sold as a maidservant by her father? <b>If we say</b> that <b>her father betrothed her</b> and her husband subsequently died while she was still a minor, <b>is he able to sell her</b> after her betrothal? <b>A person cannot sell his daughter into servitude after</b> he has <b>betrothed</b> her. <b>Rather, isn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> referring to a case <b>when she betrothed herself</b> as a minor, <b>and</b> yet it <b>calls her a widow,</b> indicating that such a betrothal is effective, contrary to the opinion of Ulla.
<b>Rav Amram said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Here</b> it deals with a minor girl widowed <b>from a betrothal of designation,</b> i.e., her father sold her as a Hebrew maidservant, and the master designated her as his wife but died before he married her. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who says: The original money</b> of the sale of the maidservant <b>was not given for</b> the purpose of <b>betrothal.</b> Rather, her betrothal goes into effect when her master relinquishes his rights to have her serve as a Hebrew maidservant. Since this betrothal was not accepted by the father, he is later permitted to sell her as a maidservant again.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> If a man who betrothed a minor without her father’s consent <b>died, and she happened before his brothers for levirate marriage, Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> She <b>performs refusal for his levirate betrothal,</b> i.e., if the <i>yavam</i> performed levirate betrothal with her, divorce is effected only by means of refusal in addition to a bill of divorce, <b>but she</b> does not <b>perform refusal for his</b> levirate <b>bond</b> to her. If he did not perform levirate betrothal, she does not require refusal as well as <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>How so?</b> If <b>he performed levirate betrothal with her, she requires a bill of divorce, and she requires <i>ḥalitza</i>, and she requires refusal.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>She requires a bill of divorce,</b> as <b>perhaps the father desired the betrothal of</b> only <b>the second</b> man. Levirate betrothal is performed in the same manner as standard betrothal, i.e., by giving money. If the father did not desire the first betrothal she is not a <i>yevama</i>, and the second betrothal goes into effect, requiring a bill of divorce to end the betrothal. She <b>requires <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as <b>perhaps the father desired the betrothal of the first</b> man, in which case she is a regular <i>yevama</i>, who requires <i>ḥalitza</i> to be released from the <i>yavam</i>. <b>She requires refusal,</b> as <b>perhaps the father did not desire either the betrothal of the first</b> man <b>or the betrothal of the second</b> man. If she receives a bill of divorce and performs <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>and</b> the second man proceeds to betroth her sister, people <b>will say</b> that the <b>betrothal does not take effect with her sister,</b> as they will think that the first betrothal was fully valid.
If <b>he did not perform levirate betrothal with her, she requires only <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>If you say</b> that <b>she should require refusal as well, lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>betrothal does not take effect with her sister,</b> that is unnecessary. <b>Everyone knows</b> that <b>a sister of</b> one’s <b><i>ḥalutza</i></b> is forbidden <b>by rabbinic law</b> only; therefore, they also know that betrothal with the sister would be effective, and they would not permit the sister to marry others without receiving a bill of divorce. This is <b>as Reish Lakish said</b> with regard to the wording of a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 41a): <b>Here Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi incidentally <b>taught</b> that <b>a sister of</b> one’s <b>divorcée</b> is forbidden to him <b>by Torah law,</b> whereas <b>a sister of</b> one’s <b><i>ḥalutza</i></b> is forbidden to him <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: There were <b>these two</b> people <b>that were</b> sitting and <b>drinking wine under poplar trees [<i>tzifei</i>] in Babylonia. One of them took a cup of wine</b> and <b>gave it to his friend. He said: Betroth for me your daughter to my son</b> by receiving this cup of wine. <b>Ravina says: Even according to the one who says</b> that in the case of a minor girl who became betrothed without her father’s consent, <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the father desired</b> the betrothal,

Daf 45b

and <b>we do not say</b> that <b>perhaps the son desired</b> the betrothal. <b>The Sages said to Ravina: But perhaps</b> the son <b>appointed</b> his father as <b>an agent</b> to betroth her, and the betrothal should take effect. He replied: <b>A person is not</b> so <b>brazen</b> as <b>to appoint his father</b> as his <b>agent</b> and thereby treat him as an assistant of sorts. They further inquired: <b>But perhaps</b> the son <b>made his desire</b> known <b>to</b> his father by speaking of his desire to marry the woman, and the father acted of his own accord upon his son’s wishes and betrothed her to him. <b>Rabba bar Shimi said to</b> Ravina: This is not a concern, <b>since the Master,</b> i.e., Ravina, <b>explicitly said that he does not agree with this</b> opinion <b>of Rav and Shmuel</b> that when a minor girl accepts betrothal there is a concern that perhaps the father desired it. So too, there is no concern that a father can act for the son without his awareness.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who betrothed</b> a minor girl without her father’s consent <b>with a bundle of vegetables in the marketplace. Ravina says: Even according to the one who says</b> that when a minor becomes betrothed without her father’s consent <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the father desired</b> the betrothal, <b>this matter applies</b> only if the man betrothed her <b>in a dignified manner. But</b> as the betrothal in this case was done <b>in a degrading manner,</b> there is <b>no</b> concern.
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: What</b> was the <b>degradation</b> in this manner of betrothal? <b>Was</b> the <b>degradation</b> from the fact <b>that</b> he used <b>vegetables,</b> or <b>was</b> the <b>degradation</b> due to the betrothal having been performed <b>in the marketplace?</b> The <b>practical difference</b> concerns cases <b>where one betrothed</b> a minor girl <b>with money in the marketplace, or</b> where one betrothed a minor girl <b>with a bundle of vegetables in a house. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Ravina <b>said to him:</b> Both <b>this and that,</b> i.e., each of them <b>is</b> considered <b>a degrading manner.</b>
The Gemara further relates: A couple wanted to marry off their minor daughter. <b>That</b> one, the father, <b>said:</b> I want to marry her off <b>to my relative, while she,</b> the mother, <b>said</b> she wanted to marry the daughter off <b>to her relative.</b> His wife pressured him and <b>forced him until he said to</b> her: <b>Let</b> the girl <b>be</b> married <b>to her,</b> i.e., the mother’s, <b>relative. While they were eating and drinking</b> the festive meal before the betrothal, <b>his relative came to the roof and betrothed her</b> to himself.
The Gemara assumes that the father did not desire this betrothal. Why? <b>Abaye said: It is written: “The remnant of Israel shall not do iniquity, nor speak lies”</b> (Zephaniah 3:13). The father had agreed that she would marry his wife’s relative, and he would stand by his word. Since the betrothal of his minor daughter is dependent on his desire, there is no concern that the father desired his relative’s betrothal. <b>Rava said</b> a different reason: There is <b>a presumption that a person does not take the trouble of</b> preparing <b>a meal and</b> then <b>cause it to be lost.</b> Since he prepared a festive meal in honor of his daughter’s betrothal to his wife’s relative, he would not desire a betrothal that would render his efforts for naught.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> these two explanations? The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> difference <b>between them</b> concerns a case <b>where he did not take the trouble</b> of preparing a meal. According to Rava, since he had not gone to any effort, there should be concern that the betrothal is valid. Abaye would hold that since he would not go back on his word, they are not betrothed.
§ If a minor <b>became betrothed with her father’s consent, and her father left for overseas, and she went ahead and got married</b> of her own accord in her father’s absence, <b>Rav says:</b> If she is an Israelite who married a priest, <b>she may partake of <i>teruma</i> until her father comes and protests,</b> explicitly stating that he does not agree to the marriage. <b>Rav Asi said: She may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Perhaps her father will come and protest, and it will be found retroactively that a non-priest has partaken of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>There was an incident</b> of this kind, <b>and Rav was concerned</b> for this opinion <b>of Rav Asi</b> and did not allow a girl in this situation to partake of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says: And Rav concedes that if</b> the minor girl <b>dies,</b> the husband <b>does not inherit</b> from <b>her,</b> because of the principle: <b>Establish money in the possession of its owner.</b> Since the validity of her marriage is a matter of uncertainty, as the father might protest it, the money remains with her previous inheritors.
The Gemara cites another dispute between the Sages: If a minor <b>became betrothed with</b> her father’s <b>consent, and she married without</b> his <b>consent, and her father is here,</b> i.e., present, <b>Rav Huna said: She may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said: She may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara explains the two opinions: <b>Rav Huna said she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and even according to Rav, who said</b> that if her father is overseas <b>she may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, this is so only <b>there,</b> in the case <b>where the father is not present. But here, where the father is present,</b> he does not consent to the marriage; the reason <b>that he was silent</b> in <b>this</b> situation and refrained from protesting is that he was <b>so angry</b> that he did not wish even to speak to her. Conversely, <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said: She may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>and even according to Rav Asi, who said</b> that <b>she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>, it is <b>there</b> that there is a concern <b>that perhaps her father will come and protest. But here, from</b> the fact <b>that he was silent</b> the assumption is that <b>he is comfortable</b> with the marriage.
The Gemara cites another case: If a minor <b>became betrothed without the consent of her father, and married without</b> his <b>consent, and her father is here, Rav Huna said: She may partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said: She may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Ulla said: This</b> opinion <b>of Rav Huna,</b> that in this case she may partake of <i>teruma</i>, is irritating <b>“as vinegar to the teeth, and as smoke to the eyes”</b> (Proverbs 10:26), as it contradicts his earlier ruling. <b>Now</b> consider: <b>And what</b> about <b>there,</b> i.e., in a case where her betrothal was with her father’s consent, <b>when</b> there is at least <b>betrothal by Torah law, you said she may not partake</b> of <i>teruma</i> in case he did not consent to the marriage. Is it <b>not all the more so</b> the case that <b>here,</b> i.e., where even the betrothal was performed without her father’s consent, she should not be permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>?

Daf 46a

Rather, <b>the statement of</b> the <b>student seems</b> reasonable. Although Rav Yirmeya bar Abba was like a student compared with Rav Huna, his opinion makes more sense. <b>Rava said: What is the reason of Rav Huna? Since an action was done with her</b> that renders her like <b>an orphan in the lifetime of her father,</b> she is considered married and may partake of <i>teruma</i>. The fact that her father ignored both her betrothal and her marriage indicates that he has waived his rights to control whom she marries. She is therefore considered like an orphan, whose marriage is valid with her own consent.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disputed the following issue: In the case of <b>a minor girl who became betrothed without her father’s consent, Rav says: Either she or her father is able to prevent</b> the betrothal from taking effect. <b>And Rav Asi says: Her father</b> can prevent it <b>but not she,</b> since she initially agreed. <b>Rav Huna raised an objection to Rav Asi, and some say</b> it was <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav</b> who raised an objection <b>to Rav Asi:</b> The <i>baraita</i> states in the case of a seduced woman: <b>“If her father refuses</b> to give her to him, he shall pay money according to the dowry of virgins” (Exodus 22:16). The Sages expounded: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>her father</b> can refuse to give her to the seducer in marriage; <b>from where</b> do I derive that <b>she herself</b> can also refuse? <b>The verse states: “If he refuses [<i>ma’en yema’en</i>].”</b> The repetition of the verb indicates that the right of refusal exists <b>in any case.</b> Despite the fact that she was seduced, she can change her mind and say that she does not want to marry him.
<b>Rav said to those</b> who tried to offer support for his opinion: <b>Do not go after the opposite,</b> i.e., do not cite a proof from a source that could be understood in the opposite manner. Rav Asi <b>can answer your</b> argument by claiming that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where he</b> initially <b>seduced her not for the sake of marriage.</b> Their initial act of intercourse was not performed in order to effect betrothal, so they are not betrothed. The Gemara questions this: In the case of <b>a seduction</b> that is <b>not for the sake of marriage,</b> is <b>a verse required</b> to teach that she can refuse to marry him? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says:</b> It serves <b>to say that</b> if she refuses to marry him despite her father’s consent to the match, the seducer nevertheless <b>pays the fine like</b> a standard case of <b>a seduced woman.</b> The obligation to pay the fine is not only for a case where her father refuses to let her marry the seducer.
<b>Rav Yosef said to him: If so,</b> if the <i>baraita</i> is discussing a case where intercourse was not performed to effect betrothal, <b>this is what we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a seduced woman: <b>“He shall pay a dowry for her to be his wife”</b> (Exodus 22:15). This teaches <b>that she requires betrothal from him. And if</b> the verse is speaking of one who <b>seduced her for the sake of marriage, why do I</b> need <b>betrothal?</b> The act of intercourse can serve as the betrothal. Rather, the <i>baraita</i> must be referring to a case where he seduced her not for the sake of marriage. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> Even if he seduced her for the sake of marriage, <b>she requires</b> an additional <b>betrothal with her father’s consent,</b> since she is a minor and became betrothed without it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me with this date,</b> and adds: <b>Be betrothed to me with that</b> one, then <b>if one of</b> the dates <b>is worth one <i>peruta</i> she is betrothed, but if not, she is not betrothed,</b> since he mentioned betrothal in connection with each date. But if he said: Be betrothed to me <b>with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, then even <b>if all of them</b> together <b>are worth one <i>peruta</i> she is betrothed, but if not, she is not betrothed.</b> If he gave her dates with the intention of betrothing her with them, and <b>she was eating</b> them <b>one by one</b> as she received them, <b>she is not betrothed unless one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that it is only if he says: <b>Be betrothed to me, be betrothed to me,</b> in connection with each date that each act of betrothal is considered distinct? <b>Rabba says: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> in the context of the laws of deposit oaths: He is never liable to bring more than one offering <b>unless he will state</b> an expression of <b>an oath to each and every one.</b>
The mishna teaches: If one said: <b>With this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, she is betrothed even <b>if all of them</b> together <b>are worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b> The mishna subsequently states that if she was eating the dates one by one, she is betrothed only if one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>To which</b> clause of the mishna is the case of the woman eating the dates one by one referring? <b>If we say</b> it <b>is referring to the first clause</b> of the mishna, when he betrothed her separately with each date, <b>why</b> would the mishna <b>specifically</b> state that <b>she ate</b> them? <b>Even</b> if <b>she placed</b> them down without eating them the same <i>halakha</i> would <b>also</b> apply, <b>as he said: Be betrothed to me with this</b> date, so each date must be worth one <i>peruta</i>. <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring <b>to the latter clause,</b> when he said that he is betrothing her with all the dates. In such a situation, if she ate them one by one, she is betrothed only if one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>.
The Gemara proceeds to ask: <b>And</b> is she betrothed <b>even</b> if <b>the first</b> date is worth one <i>peruta</i>? <b>But</b> until he has given her all the dates for the betrothal, each individual date <b>is</b> considered to be <b>a loan,</b> because if he were to retract his betrothal before giving her all of the dates she would have to return them to him, and one cannot betroth a woman by giving her a loan. By the time he finishes giving her the dates, the first one has already been eaten, so it is not able to effect the betrothal. With regard to this difficulty <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is a table, and there is meat, and there is a knife, and we have nothing to eat.</b> In other words, everything in the mishna is explicit yet we cannot explain it.
<b>Rav and Shmuel both said: Actually,</b> the case of the woman eating the dates one by one <b>is referring to the first clause</b> of the mishna, where one betrothed the woman with each date separately, <b>and it is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary.</b> The mishna stated, for stylistic reasons, a <i>halakha</i> that it did not need to state, and should be understood as follows: <b>It is not necessary</b> to state the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a woman who <b>placed</b> the dates down, <b>that if</b> one of them <b>is worth one <i>peruta</i>, yes,</b> she is betrothed, and <b>if not,</b> she is <b>not</b> betrothed. <b>But</b> in a case where she was <b>eating</b> them, one might think that <b>since her benefit is immediate, say that she has decided to transfer herself</b> to him by means of that date, although it is worth less than one <i>peruta</i>. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that she is nevertheless not betrothed.
<b>Rabbi Ami said</b> a different explanation: <b>Actually,</b> the case of the woman eating the dates one by one <b>is referring to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, where he betrothed her by giving her all of the dates. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>Unless one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>?</b> It means: <b>Unless the last</b> of them <b>is worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b> But if one of the other dates is worth one <i>peruta</i> she is not betrothed, since they are considered a loan until all the dates have been given.
<b>Rava says: Conclude three</b> conclusions <b>from</b> this statement <b>of Rabbi Ami: Conclude from it</b> that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed,</b> since she is not betrothed with a date that she has already eaten. <b>And conclude from it</b> that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>by</b> forgiving <b>a loan and</b> giving her <b>one <i>peruta</i>, her mind</b> is focused <b>on the <i>peruta</i></b> although the debt is far larger, and she will be betrothed. In the latter case, although the value of the dates she ate was more than the value of the last date, which was merely worth one <i>peruta</i>, she is nevertheless betrothed.

Daf 46b

<b>And conclude from it</b> that <b>generally, money</b> that was given for a betrothal that did not take effect is <b>returned.</b> It is not viewed as a gift, but as a loan that must be repaid. This is evident from the fact that all the dates except the last one are considered a loan that must be repaid.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> In the case of <b>one who betroths his sister</b> by giving her money, <b>Rav says: The money</b> of the betrothal must be <b>returned</b> by his sister, as this betrothal does not take effect. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> This <b>money</b> is considered to be <b>a gift</b> that she may keep. The Gemara clarifies their respective opinions. <b>Rav says: The money</b> must be <b>returned,</b> since <b>a person knows that betrothal does not take effect with his sister, and he decided to give</b> the money to her <b>for the sake of a deposit.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And let him</b> explicitly <b>say to her</b> that he is giving her the money <b>for the sake of a deposit.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He thought she would not accept</b> it from him.
<b>And Shmuel maintains:</b> The <b>money</b> is considered to be <b>a gift,</b> because <b>a person knows that betrothal does not take effect with his sister, and he decided to give</b> the money to her <b>for the sake of a gift.</b> The Gemara again raises a difficulty: <b>And let him</b> explicitly <b>say to her</b> that he is giving it to her <b>for the sake of a gift.</b> The Gemara answers: He <b>thought it would be embarrassing to her</b> and she would refuse to accept the money. He therefore attempted to give it her by an alternative method.
<b>Ravina raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Ḥalla</i> 2:5): In the case of <b>one who separates his <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of dough that must be given to a priest, from <b>flour,</b> before it has been made into dough, the portion he has separated <b>is not <i>ḥalla</i>.</b> Since the Torah states: “Of the first of your dough you shall set apart” (Numbers 15:20), <i>ḥalla</i> can be separated only from dough. <b>And</b> if the priest fails to return the flour it is considered <b>stolen property in the priest’s possession.</b> Ravina asks: <b>And why</b> is it <b>stolen property in the priest’s possession?</b> In this case too, <b>let us say</b> as Shmuel does: <b>A person knows that one cannot separate <i>ḥalla</i></b> from <b>flour, and he gave</b> the flour <b>for the sake of a gift.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different.</b> The priest must return the flour <b>because</b> otherwise a <b>ruinous</b> situation may <b>emerge from it.</b> How so? <b>Sometimes the priest has,</b> on his own, <b>less than five-fourths</b> of a <i>kav</i> of <b>flour,</b> i.e., he has less than the amount necessitating the separation of <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>and</b> he also has <b>this</b> flour, which gives him a total of more than five-fourths of a <i>kav</i>, the amount necessitating the separation of <i>ḥalla</i>. <b>He will knead</b> all <b>this</b> flour <b>together and</b> will <b>think his dough has been made ready</b> with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>, since he did not have enough of his own flour to require the separation of <i>ḥalla</i> and he had added flour that had been separated as <i>ḥalla</i> to it. <b>And he will</b> then <b>come to eat it in its untithed</b> state, as the flour he received was not in fact <i>ḥalla</i>. Therefore, the Sages required him to return the flour.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say</b> that <b>a person knows that one may not separate <i>ḥalla</i></b> from <b>flour?</b> How can the priest make such an error? The Gemara answers: <b>He knows</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>but he does not know</b> the reason for the <i>halakha</i>. <b>He knows that one cannot separate <i>ḥalla</i></b> from <b>flour, but he does not know</b> the reason, <b>as he thinks: What</b> is <b>the reason</b> one may not separate <i>ḥalla</i> from flour? <b>Due to the labor of the priest,</b> i.e., to prevent the priest from having to knead it himself. And as far as <b>the labor of the priest</b> goes, he thinks: <b>I have relinquished</b> the right to have the non-priest knead it for me.
The Gemara asks a question based on a comparison to a similar case: <b>But</b> why must the priest go to the effort of returning the flour to its owner? <b>Let</b> the separated flour <b>be</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., <i>ḥalla</i>, by rabbinic law, <b>and it should not be eaten</b> by the priest <b>until he removes <i>ḥalla</i> for it from somewhere else,</b> in order to make it ready to be eaten. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 5:10): If one separated <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> produce grown in <b>a perforated</b> pot, which is obligated in <i>terumot</i> and tithes by Torah law, <b>for</b> produce that had grown in <b>a non-perforated</b> pot, which is not obligated in <i>terumot</i> and tithes according to Torah law; although the separating of <i>teruma</i> did not take effect, and the putative <i>teruma</i> is still untithed produce, it is considered to be <b><i>teruma</i></b> and remains in the possession of the priest, <b>and it may not be eaten until he removes <i>teruma</i> and tithes for it from somewhere else.</b> The same <i>halakha</i> should apply in the case of the <i>ḥalla</i>.
The Gemara answers: With regard to things that are <b>in two</b> separate <b>containers,</b> the priest <b>will listen.</b> Since the priest is well aware of the difference between a perforated and a non-perforated pot, he will accept the ruling of the Sages to separate <i>teruma</i> an additional time. With regard to something that is <b>in one container, he will not listen.</b> He does not see any difference between receiving flour or dough, and he will not accept the ruling of the Sages to separate <i>ḥalla</i> an additional time. Consequently, they required him to return the flour.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that the <i>tanna</i> has a different concern: <b>Actually, a priest will listen</b> even with regard to something in a single container, <b>and</b> the concern is that the prior <b>owner</b> of the flour <b>will think</b> that <b>his dough has been made ready</b> to eat <b>and</b> he <b>will come to eat</b> it <b>in</b> its <b>untithed</b> state.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say</b> that <b>a person knows that one may not separate <i>ḥalla</i></b> from <b>flour?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He knows</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>but he does not know</b> the reason for the <i>halakha</i>. <b>He knows that one cannot separate <i>ḥalla</i></b> from <b>flour, but he does not know</b> the reason, <b>as he thinks: What</b> is <b>the reason</b> one may not separate <i>ḥalla</i> from flour? It is <b>due to the labor of the priest.</b> And as far as <b>the labor of the priest</b> goes, he thinks: The priest <b>has accepted</b> that task upon <b>himself.</b>
The Gemara makes a suggestion based on a comparison to a similar case: <b>But let it be <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., <i>ḥalla</i>, <b>and he should separate <i>teruma</i> again. Didn’t we learn</b> a similar idea in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 5:10): If one separated <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> produce grown in <b>a non-perforated</b> pot <b>for</b> the produce of <b>a perforated</b> pot, it is <b><i>teruma</i></b> by rabbinic law, <b>but he must separate <i>teruma</i> again</b> to render the produce grown in the perforated pot ready to eat. The Gemara answers: <b>We have</b> already <b>established</b> that with regard to things that are <b>in two</b> separate <b>containers,</b> one <b>will listen,</b> but with regard to something that is <b>in one container, one will not listen.</b>
The Gemara questions this assumption: <b>And will</b> one <b>not listen</b> to a ruling to separate <i>teruma</i> a second time from a single container? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 3:1): In the case of <b>one who separated a cucumber</b> as <b><i>teruma</i></b> to give to a priest, <b>and</b> that cucumber <b>was found</b> to be so <b>bitter</b> that it was inedible, or if he separated <b>a melon and it was found</b> to be <b>spoiled,</b> his separation is still <b><i>teruma</i>, but he must separate <i>teruma</i> again?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as it is full-fledged <i>teruma</i> by Torah law,</b> and even if he does not listen and separate <i>teruma</i> again, no Torah law will be violated.
What is the source from which it is extrapolated that it is full-fledged <i>teruma</i> by Torah law? It is <b>from</b> a statement <b>of Rabbi Ilai, for Rabbi Ilai says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who separates <i>teruma</i> from poor-quality</b> produce <b>for superior-quality</b> produce, i.e., in order to fulfill the obligation of separating <i>teruma</i> from the high-quality produce, <b>that his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>? As it is stated</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>: <b>“And you shall bear no sin by reason of it, seeing that you have set apart from it the best thereof”</b> (Numbers 18:32). The verse is saying to give the best part as <i>teruma</i>, and one who gives a bad portion has committed a transgression. Nevertheless, the verse indicates that the separated produce is <i>teruma</i>; <b>if it were not sacred</b> as <i>teruma</i> <b>why</b> would one <b>bear a sin?</b> If one’s action were to no effect, he has not sinned. <b>From here</b> it is derived <b>that</b> if <b>one separates <i>teruma</i> from poor-quality</b> produce <b>for superior-quality</b> produce, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 47a

The mishna <b>taught</b> that if she ate the dates one by one their value is not added together <b>only if he said to her</b> that she is betrothed: <b>With this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, which indicates that she is not betrothed until she has received them all. <b>But</b> if <b>he said to her</b> that he is betrothing her: <b>With these,</b> i.e., with all of them together, <b>even</b> if she <b>is eating</b> them one by one she is <b>also betrothed</b> if their combined value is one <i>peruta</i>. The reason is that <b>when she eats, she eats of her own</b> food. Once she has accepted the dates as money for betrothal, they become her own property and she is betrothed.
The Gemara comments: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava:</b> If one said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with</b> the fruit of <b>an oak tree,</b> i.e., an acorn, <b>with a pomegranate, and with a nut, or if he said to her: Be betrothed to me with these, if combined they are worth one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed. But if not, she is not betrothed.</b> If he said to her: Be betrothed to me <b>with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, <b>if combined they are worth one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed. But if not, she is not betrothed.</b> If he said to her: Be betrothed to me <b>with this</b> one, and <b>she took it and ate it; with this</b> one, and <b>she took it and ate it; and also with this</b> one <b>and also with this</b> one, <b>she is not betrothed unless one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara proceeds to prove Rava’s ruling from the <i>baraita</i>. <b>What are the circumstances</b> in <b>this</b> first case, where he said: <b>With</b> the fruit of <b>an oak tree, with a pomegranate, with a nut? If we say that he said to her: Either with</b> the fruit of <b>an oak tree, or with a pomegranate, or with a nut,</b> why is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>if combined they are worth one <i>peruta</i> she is betrothed? But didn’t he say: Or,</b> which indicates that she is betrothed with only one of them, and that one item should need to be worth one <i>peruta</i>? <b>But rather,</b> if we say that he said to her: <b>With</b> the fruit of <b>an oak tree, and with a pomegranate, and with a nut</b> together, <b>that is</b> the same as saying: <b>With this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one, <b>and with this</b> one. That <i>halakha</i> is stated in the subsequent clause of the <i>baraita</i>, and would be redundant. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where he said to her:</b> Be betrothed to me <b>with these? But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches: Or if he said to her: Be betrothed to me with these, it may be inferred that</b> in <b>the first clause we are not dealing with</b> a situation where he said: <b>These.</b>
The Gemara continues with the explication of the <i>baraita</i>: Rather, it is to be understood as an initial, general statement, which the <i>tanna</i> <b>is</b> then <b>explaining,</b> as follows: If one says to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with</b> the fruit of <b>an oak tree, with a pomegranate, with a nut;</b> the <i>baraita</i> pauses and explains the circumstances of the case: <b>How so? For example, when he</b> gave her these three items and <b>said to her: Be betrothed to me with these.</b>
The Gemara continues with its proof: <b>And the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> a second possibility: If he said to her that she is betrothed: <b>With this</b> one, and she <b>took it and ate it,</b> then <b>if one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed. And if not, she is not betrothed.</b>
<b>While</b> in contrast to this, <b>in the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not distinguish between</b> a woman who <b>is eating</b> the items <b>and one who is placing</b> them in her possession. In either case, she is betrothed. You can <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that <b>any</b> case <b>where he said to her: With these,</b> if they were worth one <i>peruta</i> combined, then <b>when she is eating</b> them <b>she is eating of her own</b> food. It is not considered a loan. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that Rava’s statement is correct.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one,</b> i.e., Rabbi Ami, <b>who says</b> that the case of the woman eating the dates one by one <b>is referring to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, where he said: Be betrothed to me with this and with that, <b>and</b> who explained: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: She is not betrothed <b>unless one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>? Unless the last one is worth one <i>peruta</i>. So too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> can be explained: <b>Unless the last one is worth one <i>peruta</i>.</b>
<b>But according to Rav and Shmuel, who both say</b> that the case of the woman eating the dates one by one <b>is referring to the first clause</b> of the mishna, how would they explain the statement of the <i>baraita</i>? In the first clause of the mishna, one said: Be betrothed to me with this, be betrothed to me with that, and if one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i> she is betrothed. <b>And</b> Rav and Shmuel explained that <b>it was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to mention the case of a woman who <b>is eating</b> to teach that despite her immediate benefit, one of the dates must be worth one <i>peruta</i> for her to be betrothed. The phrase: Unless one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i>, indicates that one alone must be worth one <i>peruta</i>. But <b>here</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>lists</b> only <b>groupings;</b> it <b>does not list individual</b> items. The <i>baraita</i> states a case where he said to her: Be betrothed to me, only once, followed by a statement that the three items should serve as the betrothal money. Why, then, does one of them need to be worth one <i>peruta</i>?
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i> taught? <b>It is</b> that of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who says</b> with regard to the laws of <i>piggul</i>, which is an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume an olive-bulk of it after its appointed time or outside the boundaries of where it must be consumed: There is <b>no difference</b> whether he says that he intends to consume: <b>An olive-bulk</b> after its time, <b>an olive-bulk</b> outside its boundaries, i.e., without employing the word: And; <b>or</b> whether he said that he intends to consume <b>an olive-bulk</b> after its time <b>and an olive-bulk</b> outside its boundaries, i.e., employing the word: And. Both expressions <b>are</b> considered <b>individual</b> statements, since he is treating each statement separately, and in neither case does he intend to combine the two amounts. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, when one says: With this and with this, each statement is distinct. Consequently, although she derives immediate benefit by eating the dates she receives, she is betrothed only if one of them is worth one <i>peruta</i> on its own.
§ <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed,</b> since <b>a loan is given to be spent.</b> Consequently, from the moment the money is lent it no longer belongs to the lender, and he cannot betroth a woman with it. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed, and some say she is betrothed. What, is it not</b> that they <b>disagree with regard to this:</b> One <b>Sage holds</b> that <b>a loan is given to be spent, and</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that <b>a loan is not given to be spent?</b>
The Gemara questions this suggestion: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it that way? <b>Say the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>And they agree with regard to</b> the case of <b>a sale that he acquires</b> it. Although they disagree as to whether one can betroth a woman with a loan he has given her, they agree that a lender can purchase an item from the debtor in exchange for forgiving the money he has lent him. <b>If you say</b> that <b>a loan is given to be spent, with what has he acquired</b> it? There is no money with which to effect an acquisition. No proof can be derived from this <i>baraita</i>, which cannot be understood as stated.
<b>Rav Naḥman says: Our colleague</b> Rav <b>Huna interprets</b> the <i>baraita</i> as referring <b>to other matters</b> and not as referring to a straightforward case of a loan. <b>And with what are we dealing here?</b> A case <b>where he said to her: Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars, and it was found</b> to be <b>one hundred dinars less</b> one <b>dinar,</b> the missing dinar is considered to be a loan that he has taken from her. One <b>Sage,</b> who said the woman is not betrothed, <b>holds</b> that <b>the matter is embarrassing for her,</b> preventing her <b>from claiming</b> the final dinar from him, and since he has failed to fulfill his statement she is not betrothed. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> who said that she is betrothed, <b>holds</b> that <b>the matter is not embarrassing for her</b> and is not preventing her <b>from claiming</b> the final dinar. He is therefore considered to have fulfilled his statement and borrowed one dinar from her, which he will repay in due course, but she is nevertheless betrothed.
The Gemara asks: <b>But rather,</b> with regard to <b>that which Rabbi Elazar says:</b> If one said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with one hundred dinars, and he gave her</b> one <b>dinar, she is betrothed and he must</b> later <b>finish</b> giving the full sum; <b>let us say</b> that <b>his statement</b> is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> The Sages <b>say</b> to distinguish between the cases: Where he gave her <b>one hundred dinars less a dinar, the matter is embarrassing for her,</b> preventing her <b>from claiming</b> the final dinar from him, since he has given her almost the entire sum. But if he gave her <b>one hundred dinars less ninety-nine, the matter is not embarrassing for her</b> and is not preventing her <b>from claiming</b> the rest of the dinars. Therefore, all would agree that she is betrothed in the latter case.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rav from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me with the deposit that I have in your possession, and she went and found that</b> the deposit had been <b>stolen or that</b> it had been <b>lost, if</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> of it remains</b> she is <b>betrothed</b> with that amount. <b>And if not, she is not betrothed,</b> since there is nothing to effect the betrothal. <b>But</b> if he said to her that he is betrothing her <b>with a loan</b> that he had given her, <b>she is betrothed, even though</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> of it does not remain. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Meir: A loan</b>

Daf 47b

<b>is like a deposit.</b> The Gemara analyzes this: <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> this: There is one <b>Sage who holds</b> that one can betroth a woman with <b>a loan, even though</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> does not remain of it. And</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that if the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> remains from it, yes,</b> he can betroth her with it, <b>but if</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> does not remain of it,</b> he <b>cannot. But everyone agrees</b> that if <b>one betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is betrothed.</b> This presents a difficulty for Rav, who stated that one cannot betroth a woman with a loan.
<b>Rava said to him: And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it that way? Is <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> fully <b>explainable? It is corrupted</b> and cannot be cited as a proof.
He explains why the <i>baraita</i> must be corrupted: <b>What are the circumstances of this deposit</b> discussed in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If she assumed</b> financial <b>responsibility</b> to repay the owner <b>for it</b> if it is stolen or lost, it <b>is</b> the same as <b>a loan,</b> as even if it is entirely lost she must still repay its value. <b>If she did not assume</b> financial <b>responsibility for it,</b> then <b>if so, rather than teaching in the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But</b> if he betroths her <b>with a loan</b> that he had given her, <b>she is betrothed despite</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> of it does not remain; let him distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within the</b> case <b>itself,</b> as follows: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> that she is not betrothed if less than the value of one <i>peruta</i> remains from the deposit? <b>If she did not assume</b> financial <b>responsibility upon herself</b> for it. <b>But</b> if <b>she assumed</b> financial <b>responsibility upon herself, even though</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> did not remain from it, she is betrothed.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> since the wording of the <i>baraita</i> cannot remain as is, <b>answer this</b> way: <b>But</b> if he betroths her <b>with a loan</b> that he had given her, <b>she is not betrothed, despite</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>value of one <i>peruta</i> of it remains.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> stated that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Meir: A loan is like a deposit.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree? Rabba said: I found the scholars in the study hall of Rav who were sitting and saying: They disagree with regard to</b> the issue of whether <b>a loan</b> the debtor had not yet begun to spend is <b>in the possession of</b> the <b>owner with regard to</b> the possibility of <b>retraction</b> of the loan by the lender. <b>And the same is true,</b> i.e., they also disagree, <b>with regard to</b> who bears responsibility for <b>accidents.</b>
<b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds: A loan stands in the possession of the debtor,</b> i.e., even if it has not been spent, the lender cannot demand the return of the money. <b>And the same is true with regard to</b> responsibility for <b>accidents,</b> i.e., if the money is lost, it is considered lost from the debtor’s possession and he bears responsibility for it. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, <b>holds: A loan</b> that the debtor has not yet begun to spend <b>stands in the possession of the owner, and the same is true with regard to</b> responsibility for <b>accidents.</b> He can therefore betroth a woman with the money he has already lent her, provided that she has not yet begun to spend it.
