Rabba continues: <b>And I said to them: With regard to accidents, everyone agrees</b> that it <b>stands in the possession of the debtor</b> and he is responsible for the money. <b>What is the reason?</b> A loan of money is <b>no worse than borrowing</b> an item. <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>borrowing</b> an item, <b>whereby</b> the item is <b>returned</b> to its owner <b>intact</b> and yet the debtor <b>is liable for accidents,</b> as explicitly stated in the Torah, is it <b>not all the more so</b> that with regard to <b>a loan,</b> which the debtor spends and repays with other money, it should be considered in the debtor’s possession and he should bear responsibility for it? <b>Rather, here</b> the practical difference <b>between them</b> concerns the question of <b>a loan in the possession of the owner with regard to</b> the possibility of <b>retraction</b> of the loan. The first <i>tanna</i> is of the opinion that he cannot retract the loan, whereas Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds that he can do so.
The Gemara asks: <b>But rather,</b> with regard to <b>that which Rav Huna says:</b> In the case of <b>one who borrows an ax from his friend</b> for a certain period of time, if <b>he chops</b> wood <b>with it he has acquired it</b> in the sense that the lender cannot demand its immediate return. If <b>he has not chopped</b> wood <b>with it he has not acquired it. Let us say</b> that <b>this <i>halakha</i></b> that Rav Huna <b>stated</b> is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> According to the explanation of Rabba, it would be a dispute between the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, they disagree only with regard to a loan, which is not returned intact.</b> Since there is no need for the debtor to return the same money to the lender, this means that the money has been transferred to the debtor’s domain, and the first <i>tanna</i> holds that the lender may not retract the loan. <b>But with regard to</b> the <b>borrowing</b> of an item, for example the ax, <b>which is returned intact, everyone agrees</b> that if <b>one chopped with it, yes,</b> he has acquired it and is responsible for it. If <b>he has not chopped with it, he has not acquired it.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that Rav’s statement that one cannot betroth a woman with a loan <b>is subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> The <i>baraita</i> teaches: If one says to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with a promissory note, or if he had a loan in the possession of others and he authorized her to</b> collect the money for herself, <b>Rabbi Meir says she is betrothed and the Rabbis say she is not betrothed.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>this promissory note? If we say</b> it is <b>a promissory note of others</b> who owe him money, <b>this is</b> the same as <b>a loan in the possession of others,</b> and why would the <i>baraita</i> state it twice? <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>her promissory note,</b> i.e., a loan she has taken from him, and <b>they disagree with regard to one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan,</b> whether forgiving the debt by returning the promissory note counts as betrothal money?
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a promissory note of others, and here</b> they <b>disagree</b> in two cases: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a loan with</b> a promissory <b>note and in</b> the case of <b>a loan by oral</b> agreement.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to a loan with</b> a promissory <b>note, concerning what</b> matter <b>do they disagree? They disagree concerning the dispute between Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the Rabbis, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Letters,</b> i.e., the content of a promissory note, <b>are acquired by</b> merely <b>transferring</b> the document. If the lender hands over a promissory note to a third party, the latter can collect the debt. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say: Whether one wrote</b> a document of sale for the promissory note <b>but did not transfer</b> the promissory note itself, or <b>whether he transferred</b> the promissory note <b>but did not write</b> a document of sale for it, the recipient <b>has not acquired</b> the promissory note. The recipient acquires it only <b>once</b> the other <b>writes</b> a document of sale <b>and transfers</b> the promissory note.
The suggestion is that one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, and therefore one can betroth a woman by giving her a promissory note even without writing a document of sale for it. <b>And one Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>is not of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, and she is not betrothed because she has not received anything.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead the following answer: <b>No one is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and here</b> they <b>disagree with regard to</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa, as Rav Pappa says: This one who sells</b> a promissory <b>note to his friend must write</b> the following formula <b>for him: Let it be acquired by you, it and all its liens.</b> Otherwise, the debt discussed in the promissory note is not transferred. One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>is not of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa.</b> He holds that the debt is acquired even if one did not write this phrase, and a man can betroth a woman by giving a promissory note to her.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Everyone is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Pappa,</b> and even Rabbi Meir agrees that she is betrothed only if he wrote in the document: Let it be acquired by you, it and all its liens. <b>And here</b> they <b>disagree with regard to</b> the statement <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel says:</b>

Daf 48a

In the case of <b>one who sells a promissory note to another, and</b> he, the seller, <b>went back and forgave</b> the debtor his debt, <b>it is forgiven,</b> since the debtor essentially had a non-transferable obligation to the creditor alone. <b>And even</b> the creditor’s <b>inheritor can forgive</b> the debt. It can be explained <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel.</b> Since the man can forgive the debt, the woman will not rely on her ability to collect using the promissory note she has received for her betrothal. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>is not of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel;</b> the woman relies on her ability to collect using the promissory note and is betrothed.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel, and here</b> they <b>disagree with regard to a woman</b> who is becoming betrothed. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>a woman relies</b> on a promissory note she receives, since <b>she says</b> to herself: <b>He would not leave</b> aside <b>my</b> benefit <b>and forgive</b> the debt <b>of others. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>even a woman</b> who received the promissory note for betrothal <b>does not rely</b> on being able to collect the debt, since she is concerned he might forgive it.
Having enumerated several possibilities for the dispute in the case of a loan with a promissory note, the Gemara explains the dispute in the case of a loan by oral agreement: In the case of one who betroths a woman <b>with a loan</b> by <b>oral</b> agreement, <b>with regard to what do they disagree?</b> They disagree <b>with regard to</b> the statement <b>of Rav Huna,</b> who quoted a statement that <b>Rav says, as Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If one said to another: <b>I have one hundred dinars in your possession, give it to so-and-so,</b> if he stated this <b>in the presence of</b> all <b>three</b> parties, i.e., the one who had the money, the one who was the owner of the money, and the intended recipient, the intended recipient <b>has acquired</b> it.
One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>when Rav said</b> that it can be acquired in the presence of all three parties, <b>this applies in</b> the case of <b>a deposit,</b> since the item is intact. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a loan,</b> which is meant to be spent, he did <b>not</b> rule that it can be transferred this way, since there is no actual money but merely a debt. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds:</b> There <b>is no difference</b> whether it is <b>a loan or a deposit.</b> The third party acquires it in both cases. A woman is therefore betrothed if he gave her a loan in the above manner.
The Gemara again suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that Rav’s statement that one cannot betroth a woman with a loan is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> A <i>baraita</i> teaches: If one says to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with a document, Rabbi Meir says she is not betrothed, and Rabbi Elazar says she is betrothed, and the Rabbis say</b> the court <b>appraises the paper</b> the document is written on: <b>If</b> the paper itself <b>has the value of one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed. But if not, she is not betrothed.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the case of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>this document? If we say</b> it is <b>a promissory note</b> of a debt owed him <b>by others,</b> then the statement <b>of Rabbi Meir</b> is <b>difficult</b> in light of another statement <b>of Rabbi Meir,</b> as he stated in the previous <i>baraita</i> that a woman can be betrothed by giving her a promissory note. <b>Rather,</b> this <i>baraita</i> must be referring <b>to a promissory note of</b> a debt owed him by <b>her, and they disagree with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says</b> that this is not necessarily so. <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where he betrothed her with a document</b> of betrothal <b>that had no witnesses to it.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Meir</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says</b> with regard to a bill of divorce: <b>Signatory witnesses</b> on the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, and the same applies to a document of betrothal. Since no witnesses signed the document, it cannot be used for betrothal. <b>And Rabbi Elazar</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says: Witnesses to the transmission</b> of the bill of divorce <b>effect</b> the divorce, and she is betrothed if the document was handed over in the presence of witnesses. <b>And the Rabbis are uncertain if</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> or <b>if</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar. Therefore,</b> they rule that the betrothal is not effected by means of the document, but it is betrothal effected by means of giving an item worth money. The court <b>appraises the paper: If it has the value of one <i>peruta</i>, she is betrothed. But if not, she is not betrothed.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that this <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where he wrote</b> the document of betrothal <b>not for her sake,</b> i.e., not for this particular woman’s sake. <b>And they disagree with regard to</b> a statement <b>of Reish Lakish, as Reish Lakish asks: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a document of betrothal that</b> the scribe <b>wrote not for her sake?</b> The Gemara clarifies the question: Do <b>we juxtapose becoming</b> a wife through betrothal <b>to leaving</b> a marriage through divorce and say: <b>Just as</b> in the document that causes her to <b>leave</b> the marriage <b>we require</b> that it be written <b>for her sake, so too,</b> in the document that causes her to <b>become</b> betrothed <b>we require</b> that it be written <b>for her sake as well. Or perhaps we juxtapose</b> different ways of <b>becoming</b> betrothed <b>to each other: Just as</b> in the act of <b>becoming</b> betrothed by means <b>of money we do not require</b> that money be minted <b>for her sake</b> and he can use any money, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the act of <b>becoming</b> betrothed by means <b>of a document, we do not require</b> that it be written <b>for her sake.</b>
<b>After</b> Reish Lakish <b>raised the dilemma,</b> he <b>then resolved it:</b> The verse states: <b>“And she departs</b> out of his house and goes <b>and becomes</b> another man’s wife” (Deuteronomy 24:2). The verse thereby <b>juxtaposes</b> the verb <b>becoming to</b> the verb <b>leaving,</b> so a bill of divorce and a document of betrothal must be written for her sake to be valid. <b>One Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish,</b> and maintains that she is not betrothed if the document was not written for her sake. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>is not of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish.</b> The Rabbis remain uncertain, and therefore view the case as betrothal by means of giving an item worth money.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish, and with what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where he wrote</b> the document <b>for her sake but unbeknownst to her. And</b> they <b>disagree concerning the dispute between Rava and Ravina, and Rav Pappa and Rav Sherevya, as it was stated</b> that these <i>amora’im</i> engaged in a dispute with regard to the following issue: If <b>he wrote</b> a document of betrothal <b>for her sake but unbeknownst to her</b> and gave it to her for betrothal, <b>Rava and Ravina say she is betrothed; Rav Pappa and Rav Sherevya say she is not betrothed.</b>
The Gemara again suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that Rav’s statement that one cannot betroth a woman with a loan is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a woman gave gold to a goldsmith, instructing him: <b>Make bracelets, earrings, and rings for me, and I will be betrothed to you</b> as payment for your work, <b>once he has made them she is betrothed;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: She is not betrothed until money enters her possession.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>this money</b> mentioned by the Rabbis? <b>If we say</b> it means <b>that</b> very <b>money,</b> i.e., the jewelry she requested, then <b>by inference the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>even that</b> same <b>money is also not</b> required to be given for her to be betrothed, but she is betrothed as soon as he made the jewelry. <b>But with what</b> does he betroth her? It is only <b>with</b> the jewelry that she <b>is betrothed,</b> since he has given her nothing but the jewelry. <b>Rather, is</b> the statement of the Rabbis <b>not</b> referring to when he betroths her <b>with</b> the <b>other money,</b> i.e., the payment she owes him for his service, and they hold that she is not betrothed? <b>And conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <b>disagree with regard to one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan,</b> since the payment she owes him for making the rings is like a loan.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And</b> it must be <b>they hold that everyone agrees</b> that the obligation to pay <b>a wage is</b> incurred continuously <b>from the beginning</b> of the period he was hired <b>to</b> its <b>end,</b> i.e., the obligation to pay for a service begins when the hired party starts to work, and the sum owed increases as he proceeds. <b>And it is</b> therefore <b>a loan,</b> as when he gives her the finished article she was already obligated to pay for the work he had performed earlier. <b>What, is it not</b> the case that they <b>disagree with regard to this,</b> i.e., <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is betrothed, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it is possible that <b>everyone</b> agrees that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed, and here</b> they in fact <b>disagree</b> over the question of whether or not the obligation to pay <b>a wage is</b> incurred continuously <b>from the beginning</b> of the period he was hired <b>to</b> its <b>end.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds:</b>

Daf 48b

The obligation to pay <b>a wage is</b> incurred <b>only at the end</b> of the labor, when he returns the item to her. Since it is at this stage that he forgives the money due him and converts it to money for betrothal, it was never considered to be a loan. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds:</b> The obligation to pay <b>a wage is</b> incurred continuously <b>from the beginning</b> of the period he was hired <b>to</b> its <b>end,</b> at which point the debt is viewed as a loan that has accumulated throughout the period of hire.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that the obligation to pay <b>a wage is</b> incurred continuously <b>from the beginning</b> of the period he was hired <b>to</b> its <b>end. And</b> they also agree that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed. And here</b> the case is not discussing a hired worker but a contractor, who is entitled to payment only upon completion of the job, and they <b>disagree with regard to</b> the question of whether or not <b>a craftsman acquires</b> ownership rights through <b>enhancement of the vessel.</b> Is it viewed that the contractor has acquired the item by improving it, and he is then selling it back to the one who hired him? Or is he merely being paid for his labor? One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds: A craftsman acquires</b> ownership rights <b>through enhancement of the vessel,</b> and since he partly owns the jewelry he can betroth a woman with it. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds: A craftsman does not acquire</b> ownership rights <b>through enhancement of the vessel.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>a craftsman does not acquire</b> ownership rights <b>through enhancement of the vessel, and</b> also that the obligation to pay <b>a wage is</b> incurred continuously <b>from the beginning</b> of the period he was hired <b>to</b> its <b>end. And</b> everyone also agrees that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a loan, she is not betrothed. And with what are we dealing here?</b> A case <b>where he added a jewel [<i>nofekh</i>] of his own for her, as</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that if a man betroths a woman with <b>a loan and one <i>peruta</i>, his mind</b> is focused <b>on the <i>peruta</i>. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>his mind</b> is focused <b>on the loan.</b> Here too, the question is whether her intention is to become betrothed with the payment for the work, which is a loan, or with the jewel he added.
<b>And</b> they disagree <b>in the dispute</b> between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:4): If one says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>with the payment</b> for that <b>which I have worked for you, she is not betrothed</b> because it is a loan, since she already owes him the money. But if he said: Be betrothed to me <b>with the payment</b> for that <b>which I will work for you, she is betrothed,</b> as at the moment he becomes entitled to the money it is considered as though he gives it to her for her betrothal. <b>Rabbi Natan says:</b> If he says: <b>With the payment</b> for that <b>which I will work for you, she is not betrothed,</b> as Rabbi Natan holds that the obligation to pay a wage is incurred continuously from the beginning of the period he was hired to its end, which means that by the end of the job it is a loan. <b>And</b> this is <b>all the more so</b> if he says: <b>With the payment</b> for that <b>which I have worked for you.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> cites a third opinion: <b>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says: Actually, they said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>whether</b> he said: <b>With the payment</b> for that <b>which I have worked for you, or: With the payment</b> for that <b>which I will work for you, she is not betrothed. But if he added a <i>nofekh</i> of his own for her, she is betrothed.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the dispute: The difference <b>between the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Natan</b> concerns <b>a wage:</b> Is the obligation incurred continuously or only at the end? The difference <b>between Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi</b> is the issue of <b>a loan and one <i>peruta</i>.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Natan, <b>holds</b> that if a man betroths a woman with <b>a loan and one <i>peruta</i> his mind</b> is focused <b>on the loan,</b> and his jewel is disregarded. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>his mind</b> is focused <b>on the <i>peruta</i>,</b> and she is betrothed with the jewel.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If a man said to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with this cup of wine, and it was found</b> to be a cup <b>of honey;</b> or if he said: With this cup <b>of honey, and it was found</b> to be a cup <b>of wine;</b> or if he said: <b>With this dinar</b> made <b>of silver, and it was found</b> to be made <b>of gold;</b> or if he said: With this dinar made <b>of gold, and it was found</b> to be made <b>of silver;</b> or if he said: <b>On the condition that I am wealthy, and he was found</b> to be <b>poor;</b> or if he said: On the condition that I am <b>poor, and he was found</b> to be <b>wealthy, she is not betrothed</b> in any of these cases. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If he misled her to</b> her <b>advantage</b> by giving her something better than what he stated, or if his status was greater than he claimed, she is <b>betrothed.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to one who says to a woman: <b>Be betrothed to me with this cup,</b> without further specification, it <b>is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:3) that the betrothal is effected <b>with</b> the cup <b>and</b> also <b>with its contents. And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that the betrothal is effected <b>with</b> the cup <b>but not with its contents. And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in yet <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that the betrothal is effected <b>with its contents but not with it.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this is <b>not difficult:</b> The <i>baraitot</i> do not contradict one another since <b>this</b> one is stated <b>with regard to</b> a cup of <b>water, this</b> one is stated <b>with regard to</b> a cup of <b>wine,</b> and <b>this</b> one is stated <b>with regard to</b> a cup of <b>oil.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that Rabbi Shimon says: <b>If he misled her to</b> her <b>advantage,</b> she is <b>betrothed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Shimon accept</b> the statement of the mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 83a) that if one sells <b>wine and it was found</b> to be <b>vinegar,</b> or if he sold <b>vinegar and it was found</b> to be <b>wine, both</b> the buyer and the seller <b>can retract from</b> the sale? Although wine is more valuable than vinegar, the seller is not considered to have defrauded the buyer, in which case only the buyer could retract. <b>Apparently,</b> this is because <b>there is</b> one <b>for whom</b> it is <b>preferable</b> to have <b>vinegar and there is</b> one <b>for whom</b> it is <b>preferable</b> to have <b>wine.</b> Consequently, receiving wine instead of vinegar is not objectively better. If so, <b>here too, there is</b> one <b>for whom</b> it is <b>preferable</b> to have <b>silver and</b> it is <b>not preferable for him</b> to have <b>gold.</b> Why does Rabbi Shimon say that she is betrothed if he gave her gold instead of silver?
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi says: I found Abaye sitting and explaining</b> this mishna <b>to his son: With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where one said to his agent: Lend me a dinar</b> made <b>of silver and go and betroth for me such and such a woman</b> with it, <b>and he went and lent</b> him a dinar made <b>of gold</b> and betrothed her with that. One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that he is <b>particular</b> in his requirement that a silver dinar be used, and consequently she is not betrothed. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>he is</b> merely <b>indicating</b> his position <b>to him.</b> He stated silver only as a guideline, but does not care if it is gold.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> if the case involves an agent, why does the mishna state: <b>Be betrothed to me?</b> The mishna <b>should have</b> stated: <b>Be betrothed to him.</b> Furthermore, why does it say: <b>He misled her to</b> her <b>advantage?</b> The mishna <b>should have</b> stated: <b>He misled him to</b> his <b>advantage,</b> as the agent did not mislead the woman but the one who designated him. Similarly, there is a difficulty with regard to the wording: If it was <b>found</b> to be made of gold, as according to this explanation, <b>from the outset,</b> when the agent gave it to the woman, <b>it was also</b> known to be made <b>of gold.</b> This fact was not discovered later.
<b>Rather, Rava says: I and the lion of the group explained it,</b> and the Gemara interjects: <b>And who is</b> the lion of the group? It is <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin: With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where she said to her agent: Go and accept my betrothal for me from so-and-so, who said to me: Be betrothed to me with a dinar</b> made <b>of silver, and</b> the prospective husband <b>went and gave</b> the agent <b>a dinar</b> made <b>of gold.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that she is <b>particular</b> about becoming betrothed with a silver dinar rather than a gold one. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>she is</b> merely <b>indicating</b> her position <b>to him</b> but does not care what the agent receives from the man. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of: It was <b>found,</b> as it was evident from the outset that it was gold? The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the coin <b>was wrapped in a cloth,</b> and the agent was unaware that he was receiving a different dinar from what she had requested.
<b>Abaye said:</b> With regard to <b>Rabbi Shimon, and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and Rabbi Elazar, they all hold</b> that when one instructs an agent in such a manner <b>he is</b> merely <b>indicating</b> his position <b>to him,</b> as opposed to expressing an insistence on certain details. If the agent makes insignificant changes to the instructions the agency is still fulfilled. <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> holds this, as seen in <b>this</b> mishna <b>that we</b> just <b>said. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> holds this, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bava Batra</i> 160a):

Daf 49a

In <b>an ordinary document, its witnesses</b> are to sign <b>inside it,</b> i.e., on the written side of the paper. In a folded and <b>tied</b> document, <b>its witnesses</b> are to sign <b>on the back of it.</b> With regard to <b>an ordinary</b> document <b>whose witnesses wrote</b> their signatures <b>on the back of it, or a tied</b> document <b>whose witnesses wrote</b> their signatures <b>inside of it, both of these</b> are <b>not valid. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says: A tied</b> document <b>whose witnesses wrote</b> their signatures <b>inside of it</b> is <b>valid, because one can transform it into an ordinary</b> document by untying it. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Everything</b> is <b>in accordance with regional custom.</b> If an ordinary document is generally used and one wrote a bound one, or vice versa, the document is invalid.
<b>And we discussed it: And does the first <i>tanna</i> not accept</b> that one should follow the <b>regional custom?</b> It is not reasonable that he should take issue with such a basic concept. <b>And Rav Ashi says</b> that they have a dispute in a case where one instructed a scribe to write a document for him: If they are <b>in a place where the custom is</b> to write <b>an ordinary</b> document, <b>and he made a tied one for him; alternatively,</b> if they are <b>in a place where the custom is</b> to write <b>a tied</b> document, <b>and he made an ordinary</b> one <b>for him;</b> in both of these cases, <b>everyone agrees that</b> he was <b>certainly particular</b> in his instructions to the agent that he should follow the regional custom, and if the latter deviated from the custom the document is invalid.
The situation <b>in which they disagree</b> is where they are <b>in a place where the custom is</b> to use <b>either an ordinary</b> document <b>or a tied</b> one, <b>and</b> the one requesting the document <b>said to</b> the scribe: <b>Make an ordinary</b> document <b>for me, and</b> the scribe <b>went and made a tied</b> document <b>for him.</b> In such a case, one <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that the one requesting the document was <b>particular</b> about wanting an ordinary document, and since the scribe wrote a tied document, it is considered to have been written without his consent. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds</b> that the one requesting the document merely <b>indicating</b> his <b>position to</b> the scribe, stating that if the scribe wanted to save himself the trouble of writing a tied document there would no objection.
<b>Rabbi Elazar</b> also holds that when one instructs an agent in such a manner he is merely indicating his position to him, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 65a): If there was <b>a woman who said</b> to her agent: <b>Receive my bill of divorce for me</b> from my husband <b>in such and such a place, and he received her bill of divorce for her elsewhere, it is invalid. And Rabbi Elazar deems it valid. Apparently, he holds</b> that <b>she is</b> merely <b>indicating a place to him</b> where he can receive the bill of divorce, but she does not insist that he accept it in that particular spot.
§ <b>Ulla says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> in the mishna between the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Shimon is only where he misled her <b>with enhanced monetary</b> value, i.e., he gave her something worth more than the item he had stipulated. <b>But</b> where he misled her <b>with enhanced lineage,</b> so that she was under the impression that his genealogy was less impressive than it in fact is, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>she is not betrothed. What is the reason</b> for this? A woman says: <b>I do not desire a shoe that is larger than my foot.</b> She does not wish to marry a man whose social standing is far greater than her own. <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 2:6): <b>Rabbi Shimon concedes</b> that <b>if he misled her with enhanced lineage, she is not betrothed.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi says:</b> The wording of <b>the mishna is also precise, as</b> the following mishna (49b) <b>teaches:</b> If one betroths a woman and states that the betrothal is: <b>On the condition that I am a priest, and he was found</b> to be <b>a Levite;</b> or: On the condition that I am <b>a Levite, and he was found</b> to be <b>a priest;</b> or: On the condition that I am <b>a Gibeonite,</b> a people prohibited by rabbinic law from marrying into the congregation, i.e., from marrying a Jew of fit lineage, <b>and he was found</b> to be <b>a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> who is prohibited by Torah law from marrying into the congregation; or: On the condition that I am <b>a <i>mamzer</i>, and he was found</b> to be <b>a Gibeonite,</b> in all of these cases she is not betrothed. <b>And Rabbi Shimon does not disagree</b> with these rulings. This indicates that if one misled a woman with regard to his lineage, Rabbi Shimon concedes that she is not betrothed.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi objects to this</b> inference: <b>But</b> what about <b>that</b> which <b>is taught</b> in the same mishna: If one betroths a woman and states that the betrothal is: <b>On the condition that I have a grown daughter or maidservant, and he does not have</b> one; or if one betroths a woman <b>on the condition that he does not have</b> a grown daughter or maidservant <b>and he does have</b> one, the latter of <b>which is</b> an issue of <b>enhanced monetary</b> value, as the difference between one who has a maidservant and one who does not impacts how hard the woman will have to work in the home; in these cases will you <b>also</b> say <b>that</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>does not disagree</b> simply because the mishna does not mention his opinion in that case?
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>he disagrees in the first clause</b> of the mishna with regard to enhanced monetary value, <b>and the same is true with regard to the latter clause,</b> i.e., he also disagrees in that clause, and it was not necessary to state his dispute another time. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to lineage, <b>he disagrees in the first clause, and the same is true with regard to the latter clause.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> where <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case involve an inaccuracy <b>of enhanced monetary</b> value, it is possible that <b>he disagreed in the first clause and the same is true in the last clause,</b> and the mishna did not need to restate his opinion. But <b>here,</b> where it <b>is</b> a case <b>of enhanced lineage,</b> which is a different issue, <b>if it is so that</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>disagrees, let him teach</b> that explicitly. The fact that no dispute is recorded in the case of enhanced lineage is proof that he concedes in that case.
<b>If you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Here too,</b> the issue of a daughter or maidservant involves <b>enhanced lineage,</b> not enhanced monetary value. His statement should be understood differently. <b>Do you maintain</b> that <b>what</b> is the meaning of his statement that he has <b>a grown</b> daughter or maidservant; that she is <b>actually grown</b> up, so that she can be of help to his wife? That is not the meaning of his statement. Rather, <b>what</b> is the meaning of: <b>Grown?</b> That she <b>grows</b> and plaits hair, i.e., he has a daughter or maidservant who is a hairdresser. Why might the potential bride view this as a drawback? <b>Because she</b> can <b>say:</b> It is <b>not satisfactory for me</b> to live in the house with a hairdresser, <b>as she will take words</b> she hears <b>from me and will go pass</b> them <b>before my neighbors,</b> meaning she will gossip about me to others. This concern is more akin to a matter of lineage than a matter of monetary value.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If one said to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am literate</b> with regard to the Torah, <b>once he has read three verses in the synagogue she is betrothed. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that she is not betrothed <b>until he reads and translates</b> the verses. The Gemara asks: Does Rabbi Yehuda mean that <b>one translates</b> according to <b>his own understanding? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Megilla</i> 3:21) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One who translates a verse literally is a liar,</b> since he distorts the meaning of the text, <b>and</b> conversely, <b>one who adds</b> his own translation <b>is</b> tantamount to one who <b>curses and blasphemes</b> God? <b>Rather,</b> to <b>which translation</b> is Rabbi Yehuda referring? He is referring to <b>our</b> accepted <b>translation.</b>
<b>And this statement applies</b> only <b>if he said to her: I am literate, but</b> if <b>he said to her: I am a reader,</b> this indicates that he is an expert in the reading of the Torah, and she is not betrothed <b>unless</b> he knows how <b>to read the Torah, the Prophets, and the Writings with precision.</b>
The Gemara discusses a similar case: If one said to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I study [<i>shoneh</i>], Ḥizkiyya says</b> it means that he studies <b><i>halakhot</i>, and Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> it means that he studies <b>Torah,</b> i.e., the written Torah.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Yoḥanan from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Mishna? Rabbi Meir says <i>halakhot</i>, Rabbi Yehuda says homiletics.</b> Neither of them, however, says that it refers to the written Torah.

Daf 49b

<b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Torah,</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan said? It is <b>homiletic</b> interpretation <b>of the Torah. And this statement applies</b> only <b>if he said to her: I study [<i>taneina</i>]. But</b> if <b>he says to her: I am a <i>tanna</i> [<i>tanna ana</i>],</b> she is not betrothed <b>unless he studies <i>halakha</i>,</b> i.e., Mishna, <b><i>Sifra</i> and <i>Sifrei</i>, and <i>Tosefta</i>.</b>
If a man says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am a student</b> of Torah, <b>one does not say</b> that he must be a student who is scholarly <b>like Shimon ben Azzai or like Shimon ben Zoma,</b> who were called students despite their great knowledge, as they were never ordained. <b>Rather,</b> it means <b>anyone who,</b> when <b>he is asked one matter in any topic of his studies,</b> responds appropriately <b>and can say</b> what he has learned, <b>and</b> this suffices <b>even</b> if his statement was <b>in</b> the <b>tractate of <i>Kalla</i>.</b> Similarly, if a man says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am a scholar, one does not say</b> that he must be <b>like the scholars of Yavne, like Rabbi Akiva and his colleagues. Rather,</b> it is referring to <b>anyone who,</b> when <b>he is asked</b> about <b>a matter of wisdom on any topic</b> related to the Torah, responds appropriately <b>and can say</b> what he has learned.
If a man says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am strong, one does not say</b> that he must be as strong <b>as Abner ben Ner,</b> King Saul’s cousin and general, <b>or</b> as strong <b>as Joab ben Zeruiah,</b> King David’s nephew and general. <b>Rather,</b> it means <b>anyone of whom others are afraid due to his strength.</b> If a man says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am wealthy, one does not say</b> he must be as wealthy <b>as Rabbi Elazar ben Ḥarsom or</b> as wealthy <b>as Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, but</b> rather it can refer to <b>anyone who is honored by the members of his town due to his wealth.</b>
If one says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am</b> a <b>righteous man,</b> then <b>even if</b> he was <b>a completely wicked man she is betrothed,</b> as <b>perhaps</b> in the meantime <b>he had thoughts of repentance in his mind</b> and is now righteous. Similarly, if one says to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am a wicked man,</b> then <b>even</b> if he was <b>a completely righteous man she is betrothed,</b> as <b>perhaps he had thoughts of idol worship in his mind,</b> a serious sin that would earn him the label of wicked.
§ Apropos the discussion with regard to various attributes, the Gemara cites a related statement: <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>wisdom descended to the world; Eretz Yisrael took nine</b> of them <b>and all</b> the rest of <b>the world</b> took <b>one. Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>beauty descended to the world; Jerusalem took nine and all</b> the rest of <b>the world in its entirety</b> took <b>one. Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>wealth descended to the world; Rome took nine and all</b> the rest of <b>the world in its entirety</b> took <b>one. Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>poverty descended to the world; Babylonia took nine and all</b> the rest of <b>the world in its entirety</b> took <b>one. Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>arrogance descended to the world; Eilam took nine and all</b> the rest of <b>the world in its entirety</b> took <b>one.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But did arrogance not descend to Babylonia? But isn’t it written: “Then I lifted my eyes and saw, and behold there came forth two women, and the wind was in their wings, for they had wings like the wings of a stork. And they lifted up the measure between the earth and the heaven. Then I said to the angel that spoke with me: ‘To where do they take the measure?’ And he said to me: ‘To build her a house in the land of Shinar’”</b> (Zechariah 5:9–11). <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This</b> refers to <b>flattery and arrogance that descended to Babylonia,</b> i.e., Shinar. This indicates that arrogance reached Babylonia as well.
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it descended to here,</b> to Babylonia, <b>and it made its way to there,</b> to Eilam. The language of the verse <b>is also precise, as it teaches: “To build her a house,”</b> which indicates that the original intention was to build a house in Babylonia, but it was not built there. The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude from it</b> that arrogance did not remain in Babylonia.
The Gemara further asks: <b>Is that so? But didn’t the Master say: A sign of arrogance</b> is <b>poverty, and there is poverty in Babylonia,</b> and not in Eilam. The Gemara answers: To <b>what</b> kind of <b>poverty</b> is this referring? It is <b>poverty with regard to Torah,</b> which was characteristic of Eilam. <b>As it is written: “We have a little sister, and she has no breasts”</b> (Song of Songs 8:8), <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This</b> refers to <b>Eilam, whose</b> inhabitants <b>merited to learn but did not merit to teach.</b> They did not produce Torah scholars capable of imparting their wisdom to others.
The Gemara returns to its list of endowments of various groups: <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>strength descended to the world; the Persians took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>lice descended to the world; Media took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>witchcraft descended to the world; Egypt took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>plagues descended to the world; pigs,</b> which carry disease, <b>took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>licentiousness descended to the world; Arabia took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one.
<b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>brazenness descended to the world; Meishan,</b> near Babylonia, <b>took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>conversation descended to the world; women took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>drunkenness descended to the world; the Kushites took nine</b> and the rest of the world took one. <b>Ten <i>kav</i></b> of <b>sleep descended to the world; slaves took nine and all</b> the rest of <b>the world in its entirety took one.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one said to a woman: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that I am a priest, and he was found</b> to be <b>a Levite;</b> or if he said: <b>A Levite, and he was found</b> to be <b>a priest;</b> or if he said: Be betrothed to me on the condition that I am <b>a Gibeonite,</b> a people prohibited by rabbinic law from marrying into the congregation, i.e., from marrying a Jew of fit lineage, <b>and he was found</b> to be <b>a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> who is prohibited by Torah law to marry into the congregation; or he said: <b>A <i>mamzer</i>, and he was found</b> to be <b>a Gibeonite;</b> or if he said: Be betrothed to me on the condition that I am <b>a resident of</b> a small <b>town, and he was found</b> to be <b>a resident of</b> a large <b>city;</b> or he said: <b>A resident of a city, and he was found</b> to be <b>a resident of a town;</b> or if he said: Be betrothed to me <b>on the condition that my house is close to the bathhouse, and it was found</b> to be <b>far;</b> or he said: <b>Far</b> from the bathhouse, <b>and it was found</b> to be <b>close,</b> she is not betrothed.
Or if he said that she is betrothed to him <b>on the condition that he has a grown daughter or a maidservant, and he does not have</b> one, <b>or on the condition that he does not have</b> one <b>and he has</b> one; or <b>on the condition that he has no sons, and he has</b> sons, <b>or on the condition that he has</b> sons <b>and he does not have</b> sons, then she is not betrothed. <b>And in all these</b> cases, <b>despite</b> the fact <b>that she</b> later <b>stated: I intended to become betrothed to him nevertheless,</b> whether or not he fulfilled the condition, <b>she is not betrothed. And similarly,</b> if it was <b>she who misled him</b> by making the betrothal conditional upon a statement of hers that turned out to be incorrect, the betrothal will not take effect.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who sold his property with the intention of ascending to Eretz Yisrael, but at the time that he sold</b> the property <b>he did not say anything</b> with regard to his intention. Ultimately, he did not ascend to Eretz Yisrael, and he wished to renege on the sale. <b>Rava said:</b> Since he did not explicitly state that he was selling his property on the condition that he ascend to Eretz Yisrael, <b>that is</b> an unspoken <b>matter that</b> remained <b>in the heart, and</b> unspoken <b>matters that</b> remain <b>in the heart are not</b> significant <b>matters.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rava</b> learn <b>this</b> principle? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>from that which we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 50a

With regard to one who pledges to bring a burnt-offering, the verse states: “If his offering be a burnt-offering of the herd, he shall offer it a male without blemish; he shall bring it to the door of the Tent of Meeting, according to his will, before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:3). The seemingly superfluous words <b>“he shall offer it” teaches that they coerce him</b> to bring the offering. I <b>might</b> have thought that it can be offered entirely <b>against his will,</b> by taking it from his possession and sacrificing it; therefore, <b>the verse states: “According to his will.”</b>
<b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? <b>They coerce him until he says: I want</b> to bring the offering. The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> should this be effective; <b>but in his heart it is not satisfactory for him</b> to bring the offering, and it is not according to his will. <b>Rather, is it not because we say:</b> Unspoken <b>matters that</b> remain <b>in the heart are not</b> significant <b>matters,</b> and his intention is rendered irrelevant by his explicit statement? The Gemara rejects this: <b>But perhaps there it is different, since</b> it <b>is clear to us that it is satisfactory for him to</b> achieve <b>atonement,</b> despite his earlier statement to the contrary.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara derives a proof <b>from the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>And similarly, you find with bills of divorce of women and</b> bills <b>of manumission of slaves</b> that when the court rules that a man must divorce his wife or free his slave and he does not want to, <b>they coerce him until he says: I want</b> to divorce my wife, or: I want to free my slave. <b>But why</b> should this be effective; <b>but in his heart it is not satisfactory for him</b> to divorce her or to free him. <b>Rather, is it not because we say</b> that unspoken <b>matters that</b> remain <b>in the heart are not</b> significant <b>matters?</b> The Gemara rejects this proof as well: <b>But perhaps there it is different, because it is a mitzva to listen</b> to the <b>statements of the Sages,</b> and the assumption is that when he is required to divorce his wife or free his slave, his true desire is to perform the mitzva.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef says:</b> The proof is <b>from here</b> (64a): In the case of <b>one who betroths a woman and he said: I thought that she was</b> the daughter of <b>a priest, and she is</b> in fact the daughter of <b>a Levite;</b> or I thought <b>she</b> was the daughter of <b>a Levite, and she is found</b> to be the daughter of <b>a priest;</b> I thought <b>she</b> was <b>poor, and she is wealthy;</b> or I thought <b>she</b> was <b>wealthy, and she is poor, she is betrothed</b> despite his mistaken assumption, <b>because she did not mislead him. But why</b> is she betrothed; <b>but he said: I thought</b> that she had a different characteristic, and he betrothed her with that in mind? <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>because we say</b> that unspoken <b>matters that</b> remain <b>in the heart are not</b> significant <b>matters. Abaye said to him: Perhaps it is different there, since</b> the ruling there is that she requires a bill of divorce only <b>as a stringency,</b> and they are not definitively betrothed.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that the proof is <b>from here,</b> from the mishna: <b>And in all these</b> cases, <b>despite</b> the fact <b>that she</b> later <b>stated: I intended to become betrothed to him nevertheless, she is not betrothed. But why</b> should her betrothal not take effect at all; <b>but she said: I intended</b> to become betrothed? This clause of the mishna teaches that unspoken matters that remain in the heart are not significant. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>But perhaps it is different there, as, since he stipulated</b> explicitly that a certain condition was true, <b>it is not in her power to uproot his condition</b> through thoughts alone.
<b>Rather, Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin says: There was an incident</b> of this kind in <b>Rav Ḥisda’s study hall, and Rav Ḥisda</b> brought the case to <b>Rav Huna’s study hall, and they resolved it from this</b> mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 21a): In the case of <b>one who says to his agent: Bring me</b> such and such an item <b>from the window</b> ledge <b>or from the box [<i>hadeluskema</i>],</b> forgetting that the item in question was consecrated property and any use of it would constitute misuse of consecrated property, <b>and</b> the agent <b>brought it to him,</b> then <b>although</b> at that point <b>the owner said: My intention was</b> that you bring the item <b>only from this</b> other place, <b>once he brought</b> the item <b>to him from that</b> place that he had mentioned, once the agent uses it <b>the owner</b> is liable for <b>having misused</b> consecrated property. <b>But why</b> should he be responsible; <b>but he said: My intention</b> was for the other place, so the agent did not fulfill his mission. <b>Rather, is it not because we say</b> that unspoken <b>matters that</b> remain <b>in the heart are not</b> significant <b>matters?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>But perhaps it is different there,</b> since it is suspected <b>that he is coming to exempt himself from</b> bringing <b>an offering</b> for his misuse by claiming that he intended a different item. Since there is cause to question the truth of his statement that he had intended that the agent bring the item from the other place, his claim is not accepted. This cannot serve as a proof that in general, unspoken matters that remain in the heart are not significant.
The Gemara responds: If all he wanted to do was exempt himself from the obligation to bring an offering, <b>he could have said</b> that the misuse <b>was intentional,</b> as one who misuses consecrated property intentionally is not obligated to bring an offering. Therefore, there is no cause to question the truth of his statement that he had intended that the agent bring the item from the other place. The Gemara counters: <b>It is not common</b> for <b>a person to place himself</b> in the category of <b>a wicked person</b> by claiming to have committed a transgression intentionally. Therefore, once again, there is cause to question the truth of his statement that he had intended that the agent bring the item from the other place.
The Gemara continues to ask: To exempt himself from the obligation to bring an offering, <b>he could have said:</b> After the agent left <b>I remembered</b> that it was consecrated property. Such a claim would also have rendered him exempt, <b>as we learned</b> in that same mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 21a): If one sent an agent to bring a particular item, and <b>the owner remembered</b> that it was consecrated <b>and the agent did not remember</b> but proceeded to fulfill his agency, it is <b>the agent</b> who has <b>misused</b> consecrated property and is liable to bring an offering, not the one who designated him, since the latter remembered and canceled the agency. There is no cause to question the truth of his statement that he had intended that the agent bring the item from the other place. Therefore, the fact that this state-ment is not accepted can serve as a proof that in general, unspoken matters that remain in the heart are not significant.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who sold his property with the intention of ascending to Eretz Yisrael</b> and explicitly stated this intention to the buyer. <b>He ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>but he was not able to settle</b> there. Upon his return to Babylonia, he sought to nullify the sale. <b>Rava said: Whoever ascends</b> to Eretz Yisrael does so <b>with the intention of settling</b> there, <b>and</b> as <b>he was not able to settle</b> there he can nullify the sale. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version, that Rava said the opposite: <b>He intended to ascend</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>and he ascended,</b> so he cannot nullify the sale.
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was <b>a certain man who sold his property with the intention of ascending to Eretz Yisrael,</b> but <b>ultimately he did not ascend</b> there. <b>Rav Ashi said: If he</b> had <b>wanted</b> to do so, <b>he could have ascended.</b> Since the matter depended upon him, there are no grounds for nullifying the sale. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> Rav Ashi said as follows: <b>If he</b> had <b>wanted</b> to do so, <b>couldn’t he have ascended?</b> Since nothing prevented him from leaving, the sale is not nullified. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> the two versions of Rav Ashi’s statement? The Gemara answers: <b>There is a</b> difference <b>between them</b> in a case <b>when circumstances beyond his control</b> occurred <b>along the way,</b> preventing him from going. According to the first version of the statement of Rav Ashi, the sale is upheld; but according to the second version, where Rav Ashi responded in the form of a question, the implication is that if there actually had been something that prevented him from ascending, the sale would be nullified.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who says to his agent: Go and betroth for me so-and-so in such and such a place, and</b> the agent <b>went and betrothed her in a different place, she is not betrothed,</b> since he instructed that the betrothal take place in a particular location. But if he said: Go and betroth the woman for me, <b>she is in such and such a place; and</b> the agent <b>betrothed her in a different place, she is betrothed,</b> since he did not mean that the agent should betroth her specifically there, but was merely telling him where to find her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <b>And we also learned</b> in a mishna <b>with regard to bills of divorce</b> (<i>Gittin</i> 65a): With regard to <b>one who says</b> to his agents: <b>Give this bill of divorce to my wife in such and such a place, and they gave</b> it <b>to her in another place,</b> the divorce is <b>invalid.</b> If he said to them: <b>She is in such and such a place, and they gave</b> it <b>to her in another place,</b> it is <b>valid.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to both betrothal and divorce, <b>because had</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only <b>with regard to betrothal,</b> you might say: <b>In a case when he is coming to draw her near</b> to him through betrothal, he thinks: <b>They love me in this place and will not say</b> negative <b>remarks about me,</b> but <b>they hate me in that place and will say</b> negative <b>remarks about me.</b> Therefore, he told the agent to perform the betrothal in a certain place and is particular that it take place only there. <b>But with regard to bills of divorce, when he is coming to distance her</b> from him, you might <b>say he does not care</b> where the divorce itself is performed. The <i>tanna</i> therefore informs us that this is not the case.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>had taught us</b> only <b>with regard to divorce,</b> I would have said that he is particular only in the case of divorce, because <b>in this place</b> it is <b>acceptable for him to degrade himself</b> through divorce, whereas <b>in that place</b> it is <b>not acceptable for him</b> to do so; <b>but with regard to betrothal,</b> which involves no degradation, you might <b>say he does not care</b> where he betroths her. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state the <i>halakha</i> in both cases.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who betroths a woman on the condition that there are no vows</b> incumbent <b>upon her</b> to fulfill, <b>and it was found that there were vows</b> incumbent <b>upon her</b> to fulfill, <b>she is not betrothed,</b> since his condition was not fulfilled. If he <b>married her without specification, and it was found that there were vows</b> incumbent <b>upon her</b> to fulfill, the marriage takes effect. Nevertheless, he has the right to divorce her, and <b>she is divorced without</b> receiving payment of her <b>marriage contract,</b> as it is assumed that he would not have married her had he known that she was limited by her vows.
Similarly, if he betrothed her <b>on the condition that there are no blemishes upon her, and she was discovered to have blemishes, she is not betrothed.</b> In a case where he <b>married her without specification and she was discovered to have blemishes,</b> he has the right to divorce her, and <b>she is divorced without</b> receiving payment of her <b>marriage contract.</b> As to what is defined as a blemish, the rule is <b>that all the blemishes that disqualify priests</b> from performing the Temple service, as detailed in tractate <i>Bekhorot</i>, also <b>disqualify women</b> from receiving their marriage contract in case of divorce.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <b>And we also learned</b> a mishna <b>like this with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>marriage contracts,</b> as the same mishna appears in tractate <i>Ketubot</i> (72b). The Gemara explains: <b>Here</b> it <b>was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to mention this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>betrothal,</b> and <b>he taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>marriage contracts due to</b> teaching the <i>halakha</i> of <b>betrothal; there</b> it <b>was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to mention this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>marriage contracts,</b> and <b>he taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>betrothal due to</b> teaching the <i>halakha</i> of <b>marriage contracts.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who betroths two women</b> together <b>with</b> an item <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>,</b> so that the value of each woman’s share was not worth one <i>peruta</i>, <b>or</b> who betroths <b>one woman with</b> an item <b>worth less than one <i>peruta</i>, despite</b> the fact <b>that he later sent</b> the traditional <b>gifts [<i>sivlonot</i>]</b> of a groom to the bride,

Daf 50b

<b>she is not betrothed, because he sent</b> the gifts <b>on account of the first betrothal,</b> i.e., the item whose value to the woman was less than one <i>peruta</i>, and not to effect betrothal. <b>And similarly,</b> if there was <b>a minor who betrothed</b> a woman, and he sent her gifts after he became an adult, the assumption is that he sent them on account of his betrothal when he was still a minor, and since betrothal performed by a minor is of no account, she is not betrothed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for all these cases to be stated in the mishna, despite their apparent similarity. <b>As, had</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of one who betroths two women with an item <b>worth one <i>peruta</i>,</b> we would have said: <b>Since</b> enough <b>of his money</b> for betrothal <b>goes out,</b> i.e., is spent, <b>he errs</b> and thinks that he can betroth two women with one <i>peruta</i>, and the gifts he later sends are not for the sake of betrothal. <b>But</b> if he betrothed a woman with an item <b>worth less than one <i>peruta</i>,</b> you might <b>say: He knows that betrothal does not take effect with</b> an item <b>worth less than one <i>peruta</i>, and when he</b> later <b>sends gifts he sends</b> them <b>with the intention of betrothal,</b> and she should consequently become betrothed with them. The mishna therefore teaches us that she is not betrothed even in that case.
<b>And had he taught us</b> only <b>these two</b> cases, we would have said that they were necessary <b>because</b> the difference in <i>halakha</i> <b>between</b> betrothal performed with an item worth <b>one <i>peruta</i> and</b> betrothal performed with an item <b>worth less than one <i>peruta</i> is not established</b> or clear <b>to people,</b> and as he might have thought in those cases that his initial betrothal was valid despite each woman receiving less than one <i>peruta</i>, the gifts he sent later were not sent for the sake of betrothal. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a minor who betroths</b> a woman, <b>everyone knows that the betrothal of a minor is nothing,</b> and you might <b>say</b> that <b>when he</b> later <b>sends gifts, he sends</b> them <b>for the sake of betrothal,</b> and she is betrothed. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the same <i>halakha</i> applies in this case as well.
It <b>was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> discussed the following matter. <b>Rav Huna says: One</b> must be <b>concerned about gifts.</b> If a woman agreed to a betrothal and the prospective husband sent her gifts in the presence of witnesses, one must be concerned about the possibility that he sent them for the sake of betrothal. Therefore, the woman may not become betrothed to another man without first receiving a bill of divorce from this one. <b>And Rabba similarly says</b> that <b>one</b> must be <b>concerned about gifts. Rabba says: And we raised an objection against</b> this <b><i>halakha</i> of ours,</b> as the mishna teaches: <b>Even if he sent gifts later, she is not betrothed. Abaye said to him: There,</b> in the mishna, the <b>reason</b> is <b>as it teaches: Because he sent</b> the gifts <b>on account of the first betrothal.</b> Therefore, there is no concern that he might have sent them for the sake of betrothal. But in this case, where he had not betrothed her beforehand, he might have intended to betroth her by sending her gifts.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> a different version of this discussion. <b>Rabba says: From where do I say</b> this <i>halakha</i>, that one must be concerned about gifts? I have learned it from <b>the reason</b> she is not betrothed, <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches: Because he sent</b> the gifts <b>on account of the first betrothal.</b> This indicates that <b>it is here</b> that there is no concern for that he betrothed her, <b>since he erred</b> and thinks she is already betrothed to him by the first act of betrothal, and that there is no need to betroth her again. <b>But generally,</b> where this type of mistake is not possible, the sending of gifts <b>does</b> effect <b>betrothal.</b>
<b>And Abaye</b> rejects this proof, as perhaps the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary.</b> The mishna stated, for stylistic reasons, a <i>halakha</i> that it did not need to state, and it should be understood as follows: <b>It is not necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> <b>in general,</b> in a case that does not involve a prior act of betrothal, <b>when he had not entered the laws,</b> i.e., begun the process, <b>of betrothal at all,</b> and it would never have entered his mind that the gifts should be considered to be for betrothal. <b>Rather, even here</b> in the case of the mishna, <b>when he has</b> already <b>entered the laws of betrothal</b> by attempting to betroth this woman with less than one <i>peruta</i>, one might <b>say</b> that the gifts <b>should be</b> considered given for the sake of <b>betrothal.</b> The <i>tanna</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that there is no concern for betrothal even in that case. It is thereby possible to object to this inference of Rabba.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about it;</b> must one be concerned that the gifts might have been given for the sake of betrothal or not? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Pappa says: In a place where</b> the custom is that men first <b>betroth</b> women <b>and afterward send gifts we are concerned</b> that he might already have betrothed her or is sending the gifts for the sake of betrothal, since that is the only situation in which gifts are typically sent. But in a place where men first <b>send gifts and afterward betroth</b> women <b>we are not concerned</b> that the gifts are for betrothal.
The Gemara questions this: In a place where <b>they betroth</b> women <b>and afterward send gifts,</b> it <b>is obvious</b> that if a man sends a woman gifts he must already have betrothed her. The Gemara clarifies: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> due to a place <b>where most</b> men <b>betroth</b> women <b>and afterward send gifts, and a minority</b> of men <b>send gifts and afterward betroth</b> women. <b>Lest you say we should be concerned about the minority</b> and say she is not betrothed, Rav Pappa therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the behavior of the minority is not taken into account.
The Gemara discusses a related topic: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Huna inquired of Rava:</b> If a woman’s <b>marriage contract was established,</b> i.e., seen, by people <b>in the marketplace, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>; is she assumed to be married? Rava <b>said to him: And should we establish her as a married woman because a marriage contract was established in the marketplace?</b> Since a marriage contract can be written by a man even before betrothal and without the woman’s consent, its existence does not prove that she is married. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about it?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Ashi says: In a place where</b> men first <b>betroth</b> women <b>and afterward write a marriage contract, we are concerned</b> that he had betrothed her; but in a place where <b>they write</b> the marriage contract first <b>and afterward betroth</b> women, <b>we are not concerned.</b>
The Gemara questions this: In a place where men first <b>betroth</b> women <b>and afterward write</b> the marriage contract it <b>is obvious</b> that there should be a concern that he has betrothed her. The Gemara clarifies: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> due to a place <b>where a scribe is not commonly available. Lest you say</b> that he wrote the marriage contract early because there was <b>a scribe who happened</b> to be there, and the prospective husband took the opportunity to avail himself of the scribe’s services while intending to perform the betrothal later, Rav Ashi therefore <b>teaches us</b> that there is no concern that he might have done so since the custom is to first betroth the woman.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who betroths a woman and her daughter or a woman and her sister in one</b> act of betrothal, by saying: You are both betrothed to me, <b>neither</b> of them <b>is betrothed. And an incident</b> occurred <b>involving five women, and among them</b> were <b>two sisters, and one person gathered a basket of figs that were from their</b> field, <b>and</b> the fruit <b>was of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>and he said: You are hereby all betrothed to me with this basket, and one of them accepted</b> it <b>on behalf of all of them. And the Sages said: The sisters are not betrothed.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that betrothal does not take effect if one betroths these two women simultaneously, the Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> It is <b>as the verse states: “And you shall not take a woman to her sister, to be a rival to her”</b> (Leviticus 18:18). <b>The Torah states: When</b> he betroths them together so <b>that they</b> would <b>become rival wives to one another, he will not be able to take,</b> i.e., betroth, <b>even one of them. Rava said to him: If so,</b> how would you explain <b>this, that it is written</b> at the end of the passage: “Whoever shall do any of these abominations, <b>even the souls that do them shall be cut off from among their people”</b> (Leviticus 18:29); <b>if betrothal does not take effect with her,</b> what <b>renders</b> him <b>liable to receive excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>]?</b> If he is not betrothed to either woman, and he engages in intercourse with either one, he is not liable for <i>karet</i>, as this punishment is incurred for this sin only if he engaged in intercourse with the sister of his wife.
<b>Rather, Rava says: The verse</b> is discussing a case where he betrothed them <b>consecutively.</b> He first betrothed one sister and then engaged in intercourse with the other, which accounts for the punishment of <i>karet</i>. <b>And the mishna</b> is to be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabba, as Rabba says: Any</b> matters <b>that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially cannot be</b> accomplished <b>even</b> if one performs them <b>simultaneously.</b> Here too, since he is unable to betroth the mother and daughter or the two sisters sequentially, his betrothal of both of them simultaneously does not take effect.
The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabba says: Any</b> matters <b>that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially cannot be</b> accomplished <b>even</b> if one performs them <b>simultaneously. Abaye raised an objection to his</b> opinion from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Demai</i> 8:10):

Daf 51a

In the case of <b>one who increases tithes,</b> i.e., he tithes two-tenths instead of one-tenth of his produce, the remainder of <b>his produce is rendered fit</b> for consumption, as he tithed it properly, <b>but the tithes are ruined,</b> as the additional tithe is neither a tithe nor tithed produce. Since it is unclear which of the two-tenths is the actual tithe and which is not, the entire two-tenths may be treated neither as a tithe nor as tithed produce. <b>But</b> according to Rabba’s opinion, <b>why</b> is this produce rendered fit for consumption? <b>Let us say</b> that <b>any</b> matters <b>that cannot</b> be accomplished <b>sequentially cannot be</b> accomplished <b>even</b> if one performs them <b>simultaneously.</b> Since one cannot designate a tithe of two-tenths sequentially, one-tenth followed by a second tenth, he should be precluded from simultaneously designating two-tenths of his produce as a tithe. Accordingly, it should be considered as though he had not designated any tithe at all, and his produce should not be regarded as tithed.
Rabba <b>said to him:</b> The case of <b>tithe is different, as</b> tithe status <b>takes effect partially,</b> i.e., on less than a unit of produce. <b>As, if one said: Let half</b> of each grain <b>of wheat be designated</b> as tithe, he has <b>designated it.</b> Just as one can designate an entire grain of wheat as a tithe, he can likewise designate a half a grain. In this case too, when one tithes two-tenths of the produce, the ruling is not that one-tenth is the actual tithe and the other tenth is untithed produce. Instead, half of each grain of the designated portion is tithe, while the other half of each grain is not. Accordingly, the remainder of the produce is tithed, as one-tenth of the total has been designated as first tithe. The portion designated as the tithe is ruined, because it is impossible to identify which part of each grain is designated.
The Gemara raises another objection to Rabba’s opinion: <b>But isn’t there</b> the case of <b>animal tithe, which does not take effect partially,</b> as one cannot consecrate half an animal for his tithe. <b>And</b> likewise there is <b>no</b> possibility to separate animals <b>sequentially,</b> as once one has designated one animal as animal tithe he cannot designate another animal for the same purpose. <b>And Rava says:</b> If <b>two</b> animals <b>emerged</b> from the enclosure together <b>as the tenth, and he called them</b> both the <b>tenth,</b> the <b>tenth and eleventh</b> animals <b>are intermingled with each other.</b> One is consecrated with the sanctity of animal tithe while the other remains a peace-offering, but there is no way to determine which is which. The question arises: If the principle that any matters that cannot be accomplished sequentially cannot be accomplished even if one performs them simultaneously is correct, neither animal is consecrated, as one cannot designate both the tenth and the eleventh animals as animal tithe, one after the other.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Animal tithe is different, as</b> two animals <b>can be</b> designated as animal tithe one after the other <b>in</b> the case of <b>an error.</b> Although one cannot designate the tenth and eleventh animals as the animal tithe <i>ab initio</i>, if he did so in error they are both consecrated. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 60a): If one erred and <b>called the ninth</b> animal the <b>tenth,</b> and erred again <b>and</b> called <b>the tenth</b> animal the <b>ninth and the eleventh</b> animal the <b>tenth,</b> all <b>three</b> animals <b>are consecrated.</b> The first is consecrated because it was designated as the tenth, the second because it actually is the tenth, and the third because it was designated as the tenth. Apparently, more than one animal can be consecrated as the animal tithe, if designated in error. In Rava’s example as well, a modicum of sanctity applies to the two animals that emerged together and were together designated as the tenth.
The Gemara raises another objection to Rabba’s principle. <b>There is</b> the case of the forty loaves that accompany <b>a thanks-offering, which are not</b> consecrated if they were designated <b>in error, and are also not</b> consecrated if two sets of loaves were designated for the same offering <b>sequentially. And</b> yet <b>it was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to <b>a thanks-offering that was slaughtered</b> accompanied <b>by eighty loaves,</b> twice the required amount. <b>Ḥizkiyya said: Forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated,</b> even though their identity cannot be determined. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Not</b> even <b>forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated.</b> It would appear that these <i>amora’im</i> disagree with regard to whether or not sanctity that cannot take effect in sequence can take effect simultaneously.
The Gemara rejects this contention: <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to this</b> dispute that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: All,</b> both Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>concede</b> that <b>anywhere that</b> the one bringing the thanks-offering <b>said:</b> Let <b>forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>be consecrated,</b> the forty <b>are consecrated;</b> and in a case where he said: <b>Forty</b> loaves <b>should not be consecrated unless</b> all <b>eighty are consecrated,</b> everyone agrees that <b>they are not consecrated.</b>
<b>They disagree only with regard to</b> a case where the one bringing the thanks-offering designates eighty loaves <b>without specification</b> of how many loaves he wants consecrated. One <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds:</b> Although he designated eighty loaves, he wants to consecrate only forty, and when he sets aside eighty loaves, <b>he</b> merely <b>intends to ensure</b> that he will have forty. He therefore brought the extra loaves so that if the first forty loaves are lost or become ritually impure the second forty will be consecrated in their place. Consequently, the first forty loaves are consecrated. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds:</b> He <b>intends</b> to bring <b>a large offering</b> of eighty loaves, and therefore none of the loaves are consecrated. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s explanation of the dispute accords with Rabba’s opinion.
The Gemara turns from its analysis of Rabba’s opinion to the original issue: <b>And why does Rava explain</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba? Let him derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with a principle of his own, as elsewhere (9a) he establishes that <b>betrothal that is not given to consummation</b> is not betrothal at all, and all of <b>these</b> cases <b>are</b> in this category. Any betrothal in which it is prohibited for the couple to engage in sexual intercourse is not considered betrothal at all. Following this principle, the ruling of the mishna can be explained as follows: Since both women would be forbidden to the man in the event that they were both betrothed to him, as each would be the relative of his betrothed, the betrothals are not given to consummation. Therefore, they do not take effect at all.
The Gemara answers: Rava could have explained the mishna this way, but <b>he stated</b> his explanation <b>in accordance with the statement of Rami bar Ḥama.</b> Rava should be understood as saying: Your opinion that the ruling of the mishna is derived from a verse is incorrect, as the verse is referring only to one who betroths the two sisters or the mother and daughter sequentially. Instead, you should explain the mishna as referring to one who betroths them at the same time, with the reason being that any matters that cannot be accomplished sequentially cannot be accomplished even if one performs them simultaneously.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> had a dispute: With regard to <b>betrothal that is not given to consummation, Abaye says it is betrothal,</b> since the prohibition against engaging in sexual intercourse does not affect the betrothal itself. <b>Rava says: It is not betrothal.
