Rava says:</b> The Sage <b>bar Ahina explained to me</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the verse: <b>“When a man takes a woman and engages in sexual intercourse with her”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:1), as it indicates that <b>betrothal that is given to</b> permitted <b>consummation is betrothal,</b> whereas <b>betrothal that is not given to consummation is not betrothal.</b>
The Gemara proceeds to analyze these two opinions. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: In the case of <b>one who betroths a woman and her daughter or a woman and her sister in one</b> act of betrothal <b>neither</b> of them <b>is betrothed.</b> The Gemara analyzes this: <b>But</b> if he said he is betrothing only <b>one of</b> this pair, i.e., <b>the woman or her daughter, or</b> one <b>of</b> that pair, i.e., <b>the woman or her sister,</b> without specifying which of them, <b>she is betrothed.</b> Nevertheless, in practice it is prohibited for him to engage in intercourse with either of them, as it cannot be determined which woman he betrothed and which woman is the relative of his betrothed. <b>But why</b> should the betrothal take effect? <b>These are</b> each <b>a betrothal that is not given to consummation,</b> and should not be valid according to Rava. Shall we say this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> to the opinion <b>of Rava?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response: <b>And according to your reasoning</b> that a betrothal that is not given to consummation is still betrothal, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>An incident</b> occurred <b>involving five women, and among them</b> were <b>two sisters. And one</b> man <b>gathered a basket of figs that were from their</b> field, <b>and</b> the fruit <b>was of the Sabbatical</b> Year. <b>And he said: You are hereby all betrothed to me with this basket,</b> and one of them accepted it on behalf of all of them. <b>And the Sages said: The sisters are not betrothed.</b> This indicates that <b>it is the sisters who are not betrothed, but the unrelated women,</b> the other three women who are not related to each other, <b>are betrothed.</b>
The Gemara continues to explain what Rava could have said. <b>What are the circumstances? If we say that he said: You are all</b> betrothed to me, this <b>is</b> comparable to one who gives something to another and says: <b>Let you and the donkey acquire</b> this item. <b>And</b> in a situation where someone would say: Let <b>you and the donkey</b> acquire it, the recipient has <b>not acquired</b> the item. Since the donkey cannot acquire items the person does not acquire it either, because the owner linked the two acquisitions. Here too, since he tried to give the item of the betrothal to all of the women, some of whom, the sisters, he cannot betroth together, the betrothal should not take effect even with the other women despite the fact that they are suitable for him.

Daf 51b

<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where he said to them: One of you</b> is betrothed, <b>and it teaches</b> that <b>the sisters are not betrothed,</b> because with regard to the sisters the betrothal is not given to consummation? The Gemara comments: If so, the <b>first clause</b> of the mishna <b>is difficult for Rava,</b> while the <b>last clause is difficult for Abaye.</b> The Gemara presents a resolution: <b>Abaye explains</b> the last clause according <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> and <b>Rava explains</b> the first clause according <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning.</b>
<b>Abaye explains</b> it according <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> as follows: In the case of <b>one who betroths a woman and her daughter or a woman and her sister in one</b> act of betrothal <b>neither</b> of them <b>is betrothed. But</b> if he betrothed <b>one of</b> a pair consisting of <b>a woman and her daughter</b> or <b>a woman and her sister</b> by saying: One of you is betrothed to me, each of them is <b>betrothed</b> as a matter of uncertainty and requires a bill of divorce, despite the fact that the betrothal is not given to consummation, in case he is in fact betrothed to the other one.
The Gemara continues Abaye’s explanation: <b>And if he</b> explicitly <b>said: The one</b> of you <b>fit for sexual intercourse shall be betrothed to me, neither</b> of them <b>is betrothed,</b> as he cannot engage in intercourse with either, not knowing which of them is his betrothed and which is his betrothed’s relative. <b>And an incident also</b> occurred <b>involving five women, and among them</b> were <b>two sisters. And one</b> man <b>gathered a basket of figs and said: The one</b> among you <b>fit</b> for intercourse <b>with me shall be betrothed to me</b> with this basket, <b>and the Sages said: The sisters are not betrothed.</b>
<b>And Rava explains</b> according <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning:</b> In the case of <b>one who betroths one of</b> a pair consisting of <b>a woman and her daughter or one of</b> a pair consisting of <b>a woman and her sister it becomes as one who simultaneously betrothed a woman and her daughter or a woman and her sister, and they are not betrothed,</b> since betrothal that is not given to consummation is not considered betrothal. <b>And an incident also</b> occurred <b>involving five women, and among them</b> were <b>two sisters. And one</b> man <b>gathered a basket of figs and said: All of you, and one of</b> the <b>two sisters, are hereby betrothed to me with this basket. And the Sages said: The sisters are not betrothed.</b> Since the mishna can be read in either of these two ways, nothing can be proven from it with regard to the issue of betrothal that is not given to consummation.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (64b): In the case of <b>one who betroths his daughter</b> to a man <b>without specification,</b> i.e., without specifying which daughter he meant, <b>the grown women are not included</b> among those who might be betrothed, since he does not have the right to betroth them. The Gemara analyzes this: One can infer that the <b>minor daughters are included,</b> and each is betrothed as a matter of uncertainty. <b>But why</b> are the minor daughters betrothed? Each of <b>these</b> betrothals is a <b>betrothal that is not given to consummation,</b> since he did not specify which of his minor daughters he had in mind. Therefore, according to Rava betrothal should not take effect with regard to any of them, <b>and</b> this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rava.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rava</b> could have <b>said to you: With what are we dealing here?</b> It is <b>when there is only</b> one <b>adult</b> daughter <b>and</b> one <b>minor</b> daughter. Consequently, once the adult daughter is removed from consideration, it is clear that the father has betrothed the minor daughter, and the betrothal is given to consummation.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>But</b> that mishna <b>teaches: Grown women,</b> in the plural. The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>grown women? Grown women in general.</b> In other words, whenever people betroth their daughters without further specification, only the minor daughters, and not the adult daughters, are included. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> that there are only two daughters, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this; what novel <i>halakha</i> does it teach?
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a situation <b>where</b> his adult daughter <b>designated him</b> as her <b>agent</b> to betroth her. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>when</b> he <b>accepts betrothal</b> from someone on behalf of his daughter without further specification he <b>accepts it with her in mind,</b> and he intended to betroth her rather than his minor daughter, the mishna therefore <b>teaches us that a person does not set aside something from which he has benefit,</b> e.g., the betrothal of his minor daughter, where he keeps the betrothal money, in favor of something from which he has no benefit, e.g., the betrothal of his adult daughter, where she keeps the betrothal money.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Aren’t we</b> also <b>dealing</b> with a case <b>where</b> the adult daughter <b>said to him:</b> When you betroth me, <b>my betrothal</b> money <b>is for you?</b> Accordingly, he derives benefit from her betrothal as well. The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the father would not have intended to betroth his adult daughter, since <b>a person does not set aside a mitzva that is incumbent upon him,</b> e.g., the betrothal of his minor daughter, <b>and perform a mitzva that is not incumbent upon him,</b> e.g., the betrothal of his adult daughter.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (64b): With regard to <b>one who has two groups of daughters from two women,</b> e.g., he has multiple daughters from his first wife, and after his first wife died he remarried and had multiple daughters with his second wife, <b>and he said: I betrothed my elder daughter</b> to someone, <b>but I do not know if</b> it was the <b>eldest of the older</b> group of daughters <b>or if</b> it was <b>the eldest of the younger</b> group of daughters, or <b>if</b> it was the <b>youngest of the older</b> group, <b>who is</b> nevertheless <b>older than the eldest of the younger</b> group; <b>all</b> the daughters <b>are prohibited</b> from marrying someone else without first receiving a bill of divorce, <b>except for the youngest of the younger</b> group, who is certainly not betrothed. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> This betrothal is not given to consummation, since each daughter could be the sister of his actual betrothed, and yet the betrothal is considered valid, as otherwise they would all be permitted to marry without requiring a bill of divorce.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a situation <b>where they were identified and later intermingled.</b> In other words, this mishna is not dealing with one who betrothed a daughter without specifying which one; rather, he initially stated which daughter he intended to betroth but subsequently forgot. The actual betrothal is given to consummation, so the daughters are betrothed due to the uncertainty. The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches</b> that he said: <b>I do not know,</b> in the first person and in the present tense, indicating that he did know who it was at one point but does not know now, <b>and it does not teach</b> that he said: <b>It is not known.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from</b> the language of the mishna that we are indeed dealing with a case where the daughters were intermingled after they were identified.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this; what novel <i>halakha</i> does it teach? The Gemara answers: The mishna serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei, who says: A person does not place himself</b> into a situation <b>of uncertainty,</b> and when he said elder daughter he must have meant the eldest of the older group, who is the absolute eldest. Rabbi Meir <b>teaches us that a person does place himself</b> into a situation <b>of uncertainty,</b> and the uncertainty applies to each of his daughters, except for the youngest of the younger group.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (<i>Yevamot</i> 23b): In the case of <b>one who betrothed one of two sisters and he does not know which</b> one <b>he betrothed,</b> he must <b>give a bill of divorce to this</b> one <b>and a bill of divorce to that</b> one, due to the uncertainty. This betrothal is not given to consummation, so why do they require bills of divorce? The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is <b>when they were identified and later intermingled.</b> The actual betrothal was given to consummation, so the sisters are betrothed due to the uncertainty. The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches</b> the phrase: <b>He does not know,</b> indicating that he did know who it was at one point but now does not know, <b>and it does not teach</b> the phrase: <b>It is not known.</b>
The Gemara poses a question: <b>If so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this; what novel <i>halakha</i> does it teach? The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to teach <b>the latter clause</b> of that mishna: If this man <b>died and he had one brother,</b> the brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of</b> the sisters, but he cannot perform levirate marriage with either because one of them is the sister of his <i>yevama</i>, who is forbidden to him by rabbinic law. If <b>he had two</b> brothers, <b>one</b> of them <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one of the sisters but may not take her in levirate marriage, due to the possibility that she is the sister of a woman with whom he has a levirate bond. <b>And</b> then <b>one takes</b> the other <b>in levirate marriage</b> if he so desires. If both brothers <b>married</b> the sisters <b>before</b> consulting the court, the court does <b>not remove them from</b> their marriage and they are permitted to remain married. Although the first couple should have performed <i>ḥalitza</i>, the court does not force them to divorce.
The Gemara explains the novelty of the latter clause: This is effective <b>specifically</b> if one brother first <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and afterward</b> the second brother <b>performs levirate marriage, but</b> if one brother first <b>performs levirate marriage and afterward</b> the other brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> the levirate marriage would <b>not</b> take effect, <b>as he</b> is possibly <b>encountering the sister of</b> the woman <b>bound to him</b> by ties of levirate marriage. Until the <i>yevama</i> is released through <i>ḥalitza</i>, her sister is considered, to a certain extent, the sister of his wife, due to the ties of levirate marriage. The one who performs levirate marriage might have chosen the sister of the woman betrothed by the dead brother.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the continuation of that mishna: In the case of <b>two</b> unrelated men <b>who betrothed two sisters,</b> where <b>this</b> one <b>does not know which</b> sister <b>he betrothed and that</b> one <b>does not know which</b> sister <b>he betrothed, this</b> one <b>gives two bills of divorce,</b> one to each of the women, <b>and that</b> one <b>gives two bills of divorce.</b> Their betrothal is not given to consummation, so according to Rava why do they require a bill of divorce? The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> it is discussing a case <b>where they were identified and later intermingled.</b> The actual betrothal was given to consummation, so the sisters are betrothed due to the uncertainty. The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches</b> using the phrase: <b>Does not know,</b> indicating that at one point he did know who it was but now does not know, <b>and it does not teach: It is not known.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from it</b> that we are indeed dealing with a case where the sisters were identified and later intermingled.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this; what novel <i>halakha</i> does it teach? The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to teach <b>the latter clause</b> of that mishna: If each man <b>died</b> before he divorced, <b>and this</b> one <b>had a brother and that</b> one <b>had a brother,</b> then <b>this</b> brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of them, and that</b> brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of them.</b> Neither man may perform levirate marriage, lest he perform levirate marriage with the sister of his <i>yevama</i>. If <b>this</b> one <b>had one</b> brother <b>and that</b> one <b>had two</b> brothers,

Daf 52a

<b>the one</b> brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with both of them, and</b> of <b>the two</b> brothers, <b>one performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with one of the sisters <b>and one,</b> if he so desires, <b>performs levirate marriage</b> with the other sister. <b>If they married</b> the widows <b>before</b> consulting the court, the court <b>does not remove them from</b> the marriage, and they are permitted to remain married.
The Gemara explains the novelty of the latter clause: This is effective <b>specifically</b> if one of the two brothers first <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i> and afterward</b> the other brother <b>performs levirate marriage, but</b> if one of the two brothers first <b>performs levirate marriage and afterward</b> the other brother <b>performs <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> the levirate marriage would <b>not</b> take effect, <b>as he</b> is possibly <b>encountering a <i>yevama</i></b> getting married <b>to</b> a member of the <b>public.</b> This is because it is possible that the woman he married was not his <i>yevama</i> but someone else’s <i>yevama</i>, and until the other man’s brother performs <i>ḥalitza</i> with her it is still prohibited for her to marry other men.
The Gemara derives a proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as</b> the Sage <b>Tavyumei taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: If <b>this</b> man <b>had five sons and that</b> man <b>had five daughters, and</b> the first man <b>said: One of your daughters is betrothed to one of my sons, each and every one</b> of the daughters <b>requires five bills of divorce,</b> one from each of the sons, due to the uncertainty of who is betrothed to whom. If <b>one of the</b> sons <b>died</b> before giving his bill of divorce, <b>each and every one</b> of the daughters <b>requires four bills of divorce,</b> one from each of the surviving brothers, <b>and <i>ḥalitza</i> from one of them,</b> in case she was betrothed to the deceased son. The <i>ḥalitza</i> of one of the brothers suffices to release her from her levirate bond. According to Rava this betrothal should not be valid, as it is not given to consummation. Why, then, do they each require bills of divorce?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here too</b> it is referring to a case <b>where they were identified and later intermingled,</b> that cannot be. This is as the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: One of your daughters to one of my sons,</b> indicating that the betrothal could never have been given to consummation, and yet it is a valid betrothal. The Gemara concludes: <b>The refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rava is a conclusive refutation.</b> The Gemara further notes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Abaye</b> when he has a dispute with Rava <b>with regard to</b> six <i>halakhot</i>, as represented by the mnemonic <b><i>yod</i>, <i>ayin</i>, <i>lamed</i>, <i>kuf</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>mem</i>:</b> Despair that is not conscious [<i>yeush shelo mida’at</i>], conspiring witnesses [<i>eidim</i>] who are disqualified retroactively, a side post [<i>leḥi</i>] standing alone, betrothal [<i>kiddushin</i>] that is not given to consummation, revealing intent with a bill of divorce [<i>get</i>], and an apostate [<i>mumar</i>] who sins rebelliously. Although the <i>halakha</i> generally is in accordance with the opinion of Rava in his disputes with Abaye, in these six cases the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Abaye.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>An incident</b> occurred <b>involving five women,</b> and among them were two sisters. And one person gathered a basket of figs that were from their field, and the fruit was of the Sabbatical Year. And he said: You are hereby all betrothed to me with this basket, and one of them accepted it on behalf of all of them. And the Sages said: The sisters are not betrothed. <b>Rav says:</b> One can <b>learn four</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from the mishna.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And Rav held three</b> of them <b>in his hand,</b> i.e., knew what they were, but he was uncertain about the fourth.
Rav clarifies: <b>Learn from it</b> that with regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with produce of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>she is betrothed,</b> and you do not say that this produce can be used only for eating and not for any other purpose. <b>And learn from it</b> that if one <b>betroths</b> a woman <b>with a stolen item, even</b> if it was <b>her stolen item, she is not betrothed.</b> You do not say that her accepting from him an item that he stole from her indicates that she released him from his obligation to return it, rendering it his to use in order to betroth her. <b>From where</b> can these two <i>halakhot</i> be deduced? It is <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches</b> that the produce <b>was from their</b> field, <b>and was of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, which indicates: <b>The reason</b> it could be used for betrothal is that the produce was <b>of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>which</b> causes the figs to be <b>ownerless</b> property. <b>But</b> if it was one <b>of the other years of the seven-</b>year Sabbatical cycle, the betrothal would <b>not</b> take effect with stolen property, even if she accepted it for her betrothal.
<b>And learn from it: A woman can become an agent</b> to accept a betrothal <b>for another</b> woman, <b>and</b> this is so <b>even in a situation where she</b> thereby <b>becomes</b> the <b>rival wife of</b> the other, as in the case of the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the other</b> <i>halakha</i>, the fourth one mentioned by Rav? It is the <i>halakha</i> of <b>betrothal that is not given to consummation.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> Rav also <b>count this</b> <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara explains: He does not do so, <b>because he is uncertain whether</b> the correct interpretation of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Abaye,</b> who maintains that such a betrothal is valid, or <b>whether</b> the correct interpretation of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rava,</b> which would mean it is not betrothal.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>he stated this <i>halakha</i> before Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who <b>said to him: Did Rav</b> actually <b>say so?</b> This indicates that Rabbi Yoḥanan disagreed with the statement of Rav that these <i>halakhot</i> can be learned from the mishna, which leads the Gemara to ask: <b>But didn’t he</b> himself <b>say</b> so? <b>And didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say:</b> If one <b>robbed</b> another of an item <b>and</b> its <b>owner has not despaired</b> of recovering it, <b>neither of them can consecrate</b> the stolen item? <b>This</b> one, the robber, cannot consecrate it <b>because it is not his, and that</b> one, the owner, cannot consecrate it <b>because it is not in his possession.</b> By the same logic, one should not be able to betroth a woman with stolen property, as it is not his. The Gemara answers that Rabbi Yoḥanan was not objecting to Rav’s opinion, but <b>this is</b> what <b>he said to him: Did Rav</b> actually <b>say in accordance with my</b> opinion?
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> against Rav’s opinion that one cannot betroth a woman with stolen property, from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 4:5): If one <b>betrothed her with</b> an item taken <b>in robbery, in a forced transaction, or in theft, or if he grabbed a <i>sela</i> from her hand and betrothed her</b> with it, <b>she is betrothed.</b> This indicates that one can betroth a woman with stolen property. The Gemara answers: <b>There</b> it is referring to <b>her stolen</b> property, and by accepting it from him as betrothal, she indicates that she has released him from his obligation to return it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the last clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Or if he grabbed a <i>sela</i> of hers, it may be inferred that</b> in <b>the first clause we are dealing with</b> property <b>stolen from others.</b> The Gemara explains: These are not two separate cases. Instead, the <i>tanna</i> <b>is explaining</b> his earlier statement: If one <b>betrothed</b> a woman <b>with</b> an item taken <b>in robbery, in a forced transaction, or in theft; how so? For example, if he grabbed a <i>sela</i> from her hand and betrothed her with it.</b>

Daf 52b

The Gemara questions this analysis: <b>But</b> doesn’t <b>the mishna</b> deal <b>with</b> a case where the <b>stolen item</b> is <b>hers, and</b> yet <b>Rav says she is not betrothed.</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult; this</b> case, in the <i>baraita</i>, is referring to a situation <b>where he had arranged</b> to betroth her beforehand, which indicates that she has released him from his obligation to return it, but <b>that</b> case, in the mishna, is referring to a situation <b>where he had not arranged</b> his marriage with her, so it is stolen property and she is not betrothed.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain woman who was washing her feet in a vessel of water. A certain man came</b> along, <b>grabbed</b> a few <b>dinars from another</b> person, <b>and threw</b> them <b>to her,</b> and <b>said to her: You are betrothed to me. That man</b> subsequently <b>came before Rava,</b> to inquire as to the status of the woman. Rava <b>said: There is not</b> anyone <b>who is concerned for this</b> opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon, who said:</b> In <b>an ordinary</b> case of <b>robbery</b> the <b>owner has despaired</b> of recovering the stolen item, and it belongs to the robber. Rather, the assumption is that the owner has not despaired of recovering the stolen item. In this case, since the stolen dinars do not belong to the man, his betrothal is of no effect.
The Gemara relates another incident: The was <b>a certain sharecropper who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with a handful [<i>bemoza</i>] of onions [<i>deshamkhei</i>]</b> taken from the field where he worked. <b>He came before Rava</b> to ask about the status of the woman. Rava <b>said to him: Who relinquished</b> these onions <b>to you?</b> Since the owner did not allow you to take them, they are stolen property, and the woman is not betrothed. The Gemara comments: <b>And this matter applies</b> only <b>to a handful, but</b> if he took <b>a bundle</b> of onions and betrothed a woman with them, the sharecropper <b>can say to</b> the owner: <b>I took a bundle, you take a bundle; one bundle for</b> another <b>bundle.</b> Since in any case they divide the crop between them, it is not considered theft.
The Gemara relates another incident: There was <b>a certain brewer [<i>sarseya</i>]</b> who was making date beer for someone, <b>who betrothed</b> a woman <b>with sediment [<i>bifruma</i>] from the beer. The owner of the beer came</b> and <b>found him.</b> The owner <b>said to him: Why don’t you give</b> her the betrothal <b>from this,</b> the <b>sharp</b> sediments that are of better quality than the kind you chose? The brewer <b>came before Rava</b> to ask whether the owner’s comment indicated that he had relinquished his rights to the sediment, which would mean the woman is betrothed. Rava <b>said</b> to him: The Sages <b>said</b> that if the owner discovers that someone has taken something of his without permission and says: <b>Go to</b> and take <b>the</b> item of <b>better</b> quality, that it is a sign he agrees with the man’s action <b>only with regard to <i>teruma</i> alone,</b> and you did not have the right to use the sediment.
The Gemara explains the previous statement: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 1:5): <b>When did they say</b> that in the case where <b>one separates <i>teruma</i> without</b> the owner’s <b>consent, his <i>teruma</i> is</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>?</b> The <i>baraita</i> clarifies: In a case where <b>there was</b> someone <b>who entered another’s field and gathered</b> produce from it, <b>and separated <i>teruma</i> without</b> the owner’s <b>permission, if</b> the owner is <b>concerned about</b> his actions and view it <b>as robbery, his <i>teruma</i> is not <i>teruma</i>, but if</b> he is <b>not</b> concerned, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from where would</b> the gatherer <b>know whether</b> he should be <b>concerned</b> that the owner objects and views it <b>as robbery or not?</b> If <b>the owner came and found him</b> separating <i>teruma</i> <b>and said to him: Go to</b> take <b>the</b> produce of <b>better</b> quality and separate <i>teruma</i> from that, then <b>if</b> produce of <b>better</b> quality <b>than</b> the produce he had separated <b>is found, his <i>teruma</i> is</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> since the owner is assumed to have been sincere and pleased that the other has separated <i>teruma</i> from his produce. <b>But if not, his <i>teruma</i> is not <i>teruma</i>,</b> as it may be assumed that the owner was angry at him and was speaking sarcastically. The <i>baraita</i> adds: If <b>the owners were gathering and adding</b> to the <i>teruma</i> he had separated, indicating that they agree to his act of separation, <b>either way,</b> whether or not better-quality produce was found, <b>his <i>teruma</i> is</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>.</b>
Rava concludes the explanation of his ruling: This <i>halakha</i> applies only to <i>teruma</i>, which is a mitzva that the owner must in any case perform. <b>But here,</b> in the case of the brewer who betrothed a woman with sediment from the beer, the owner <b>acts because of embarrassment,</b> and while he does not feel comfortable protesting, he did not in fact relinquish his rights to the sediment, <b>and she is not betrothed.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a priest <b>who betroths</b> a woman <b>with his portion</b> of offerings, <b>whether</b> he did so with <b>offerings of the most sacred order</b> or <b>whether</b> he did so with <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, she is not betrothed.</b> One who betroths a woman <b>with second tithe, whether unwittingly</b> or <b>intentionally, has not betrothed</b> her; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If he did so <b>unwittingly he has not betrothed</b> her, but if he did so <b>intentionally he has betrothed</b> her.
<b>And</b> with regard to one who betroths a woman <b>with consecrated</b> property belonging to the Temple treasury, if he does so <b>intentionally he has betrothed</b> her, <b>and</b> if he does so <b>unwittingly he has not betrothed</b> her; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> the opposite: If he does so <b>unwittingly he has betrothed</b> her, but if he does so <b>intentionally he has not betrothed</b> her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states with regard to the obligation to bring an offering for taking a false oath concerning unlawful possession of the property of another: “If any one sin, <b>and he commits a trespass against the Lord,</b> and deal falsely with his neighbor in a matter of deposit, or of pledge, or of robbery, or have oppressed his neighbor” (Leviticus 5:21). As the verse is discussing property belonging to another, the phrase “a trespass against the Lord” serves <b>to include</b> in the obligation of an offering a false oath with regard to possession of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity</b> of another person, <b>which are the property</b> of the owner; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b> According to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, the portion of an offering of lesser sanctity that the priest receives belongs to him, so he should be able to betroth a woman with it.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says</b> that an offering of lesser sanctity belongs to its owner only <b>while</b> the animal is still <b>alive, but after</b> its <b>slaughter</b> it does <b>not</b> belong to the priest who receives portions from it. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>When</b> the priests <b>receive</b> their portion after the animal has been slaughtered <b>they receive</b> their portion <b>from the table of the Most High,</b> and do not own the portion itself.
The Gemara adds: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches:</b> With regard to a priest <b>who betroths</b> a woman <b>with his portion</b> of offerings, <b>whether</b> he did so with <b>offerings of the most sacred order or whether</b> he used <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, has not betrothed</b> her. The mishna does not speak of a priest who betroths a woman with a living offering of lesser sanctity but of one who betroths with the portion of the slaughtered animal he has received. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from it</b> that it is only in this case that she is not betrothed.
<b>The Sages taught: After the death of Rabbi Meir, Rabbi Yehuda said to his students: Do not let the students of Rabbi Meir enter here</b> into our house of study, <b>because they are vexatious [<i>kanteranim</i>]. And they do not come to study Torah,</b> but <b>rather they come to overwhelm me with <i>halakhot</i>. Sumakhos,</b> a student of Rabbi Meir, <b>pushed and entered</b> anyway. <b>He said to them: This</b> is what <b>Rabbi Meir taught me:</b> With regard to a priest <b>who betroths</b> a woman <b>with his portion</b> of the offerings, <b>whether</b> he did so with <b>offerings of the most sacred order or whether</b> he used <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, he has not betrothed</b> her.
Upon hearing this, <b>Rabbi Yehuda became angry with</b> his students. <b>He said to them: Didn’t I say this to you: Do not let the students of Rabbi Meir enter here</b> into our house of study, <b>because they are vexatious? And they do not come to study Torah,</b> but <b>rather they come to overwhelm me with <i>halakhot</i>.</b> Rabbi Yehuda explained his objection to the statement of Rabbi Meir: This <i>halakha</i> is not relevant, <b>as from where</b> would <b>a woman</b> appear <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard?</b> Women may not enter the area of the Temple courtyard where the priests eat the offerings of the most sacred order, so there is no reason to address an impossible scenario.
<b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who was present, <b>said: They will say: Meir died, Yehuda grew angry,</b> and <b>Yosei remained silent; what will become of the words of Torah?</b> He said: In fact, this <i>halakha</i> is relevant; <b>but isn’t it common</b> for <b>a man to accept betrothal for his daughter in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard?</b> There is no need to give the betrothal item directly to the woman; it can be given to her father. <b>And</b> additionally, <b>isn’t it common</b> for <b>a woman to designate an agent for herself to accept her betrothal in the courtyard? And furthermore: What</b> would be the <i>halakha</i> if the woman <b>pushed and entered?</b> Since it is possible for her to do so, the <i>halakha</i> in such a case must be determined.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the Sages discussed the issue of a priest who betroths a woman with his portion of offerings of the most sacred order: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says she is betrothed,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yosei says she is not betrothed. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Both of them derived</b> their opinions from <b>one verse,</b> which states that the priests have a right to a portion of offerings of the most sacred order, but they explained it in different ways. The verse states: <b>“This shall be yours of the most holy things, reserved from the fire”</b> (Numbers 18:9). <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that the term <b>“yours”</b> indicates that the portion the priest receives is intended for you, i.e., a priest, <b>and for all your needs,</b> including betrothing a woman. <b>And Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that the verse compares the priest’s portion <b>to the fire</b> on the altar: <b>Just as</b> the portion burned on the <b>fire</b> is <b>for</b> the fire’s <b>consumption, so too,</b> the priest’s portion <b>is also for consumption</b> alone, and not for any other purpose.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b>

Daf 53a

<b>They counted</b> the opinions among the Sages, <b>and they concluded:</b> With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with his portion</b> of the offerings, <b>whether</b> he did so with <b>offerings of the most sacred order or whether</b> he used the <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> he <b>has not betrothed</b> her, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. <b>And Rav says: It is still a</b> matter of <b>dispute</b> and they did not reach that conclusion. <b>Abaye said: It is reasonable</b> to rule <b>in accordance with</b> the report <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who says that the <i>halakha</i> was decided in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei.
Abaye quotes an extended <i>baraita</i> indicating that even Rabbi Yehuda accepted that the <i>halakha</i> was decided in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> priests <b>may not receive a share</b> of <b>meal-offerings in exchange for</b> portions of animal <b>offerings,</b> i.e., they may not exchange their portion of a meal-offering for the meat of an animal sacrifice of which they did not receive a portion? <b>The verse states: “And every meal-offering that is baked in the oven…shall all the sons of Aaron have”</b> (Leviticus 7:9–10). This verse emphasizes that the sons of Aaron must divide the meal-offering equally among themselves, without exchanging it for a portion of any other offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they may not receive a share</b> of <b>meal-offerings in exchange for</b> portions of animal <b>offerings since they do not substitute for them in</b> the case of <b>poverty.</b> Even one who is too poor to afford to bring an animal offering, e.g., in the case of a sin-offering determined on a sliding scale, does not bring a meal-offering in its stead. Since meal-offerings can never be brought in place of animal offerings, there is clearly no connection between them. <b>But</b> perhaps <b>they may receive a share</b> of <b>meal-offerings in exchange for</b> portions of <b>bird</b>-offerings, <b>since they do substitute for them in</b> the case of <b>poverty.</b> If one is so destitute that he cannot afford to bring a bird-offering he brings a meal-offering. Therefore, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states: “And all that is prepared in the deep pan…shall all the sons of Aaron have,”</b> again stressing that all must have an equal share in that meal-offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they may not receive a share</b> of <b>meal-offerings in exchange for</b> portions of <b>bird</b>-offerings <b>since these,</b> bird-offerings, <b>are types of</b> offer-ings that involve <b>blood</b> sprinkled on the altar, <b>and those,</b> meal-offerings, <b>are types</b> of offerings made <b>of flour. But</b> perhaps <b>they may receive a share</b> of portions of <b>bird</b>-offerings <b>in exchange for</b> portions of animal <b>offerings, since both</b> categories are <b>types of</b> offerings that involve <b>blood</b> sprinkled on the altar. Therefore, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states: “And on a griddle,”</b> a seemingly superfluous phrase, which teaches that one may not receive a share even of bird-offerings in exchange for portions of animal offerings.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they may not receive a share</b> of <b>bird</b>-offerings <b>in exchange for</b> portions of animal <b>offerings because the actions,</b> i.e., killing, of <b>these</b> birds is <b>by hand,</b> by pinching the neck, <b>and the actions,</b> i.e., killing, of <b>those</b> animals is <b>with a utensil,</b> by slaughtering with a knife. <b>But</b> perhaps <b>they may receive a share</b> of <b>meal-offerings in exchange for</b> portions of other <b>meal-offerings, since the actions with</b> both <b>these and those</b> are <b>by hand.</b> Therefore, <b>the</b> next <b>verse states: “And every meal-offering mingled with oil…shall all the sons of Aaron</b> have” (Leviticus 7:10).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they may not receive a share</b> of a meal-offering prepared on <b>a griddle in exchange for</b> portions of a meal<b>-</b>offering prepared in <b>a deep pan, or</b> portions of a meal-offering prepared in <b>a deep pan in exchange for</b> portions of a meal<b>-</b>offering prepared on <b>a griddle, since the actions</b> with <b>this</b> deep pan result in <b>a soft</b> product, <b>and the actions</b> with <b>that</b> griddle result in <b>a hard</b> product. <b>But</b> perhaps <b>they may receive a share</b> of a meal-offering prepared on <b>a griddle in exchange for</b> the portions of a meal-offering prepared on <b>a griddle, or</b> a share of a meal-offering prepared in <b>a deep pan in exchange for</b> portions of a meal-offering prepared in <b>a deep pan, since the actions</b> with both <b>these and those</b> result in <b>a hard</b> product, in the case of a griddle, or <b>alternatively,</b> with regard to a deep pan, <b>the actions</b> result in <b>a soft</b> product. Therefore, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states: “Or dry, shall all the sons of Aaron have”</b> (Leviticus 7:10).
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that they <b>may not receive a share of offerings of the most sacred order,</b> e.g., meal-offerings, in exchange for a portion of another similar offering, <b>but they may receive a share of offerings of lesser sanctity</b> in exchange for a portion of another similar offering. Therefore, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states</b> with regard to meal-offerings: “Shall all the sons of Aaron have, <b>one as well as another”</b> (Leviticus 7:10), <b>and near it</b> appears the verse: <b>“If</b> he offers it <b>for a thanks-offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:12), from which is derived: <b>Just as one may not receive a share</b> of one offering in exchange for a portion of another similar offering in the case <b>of offerings of the most sacred order, so too, one may not receive a share</b> of one offering in exchange for a portion of another similar offering in the case <b>of offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> e.g., a thanks-offering.
The <i>baraita</i> expounds this verse further: It states: <b>“One</b> as well as another [<b><i>ish</i></b> <i>ke’aḥiv</i>],” which teaches that with regard to priests, <b>a man [<i>ish</i>]</b> who is an adult <b>receives a share even</b> if he is <b>blemished, but</b> a priest who is <b>a minor may not receive a share even</b> if he is <b>unblemished.</b> This <i>baraita</i> is found in the <i>Sifra</i>, a collection of halakhic <i>midrashim</i> on the book of Leviticus. And <b>who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> to whom <b>unattributed</b> statements in the <b><i>Sifra</i></b> are assigned? It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> here <b>he says that no law of receiving a share</b> applies <b>to it at all,</b> which means that priests cannot exchange one portion of any type of offering for another portion, so they cannot use it to betroth a woman. <b>Conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Yehuda retracted his opinion and subscribes to the opinion that a priest does not own the portion of the offerings he receives.
<b>Rava said: But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Sota</i> 13:7): When the priests receive their portion of the shewbread each week, <b>the modest ones withdraw their hands</b> and do not take it, <b>and the gluttons receive</b> all the <b>shares</b> of the bread. This indicates that offerings may be apportioned according to the priests’ wishes. The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>receive</b> the <b>shares?</b> It does not mean that they exchange one portion for another with halakhic sanction; it means that <b>they</b> would <b>snatch</b> their colleagues’ portions, <b>as it teaches</b> in the <b>latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>An incident</b> occurred <b>involving one who snatched his share and his colleague’s share, and they called him ben Ḥamtzan,</b> son of the snatcher, <b>until the day he died.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Rav Sheila said: What is the verse</b> from which is derived that <i>ḥamtzan</i> means one who snatches? The verse states: <b>“My God, rescue me out of the hand of the wicked, out of the grasp of the unrighteous and grasping man [<i>ḥometz</i>]”</b> (Psalms 71:4). <b>Rabba said:</b> It is derived <b>from here: “Learn to do well; seek justice, relieve the oppressed [<i>ḥamotz</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 1:17), i.e., restore property stolen from victims of theft.
§ The mishna teaches: One who betroths a woman with <b>second tithe, whether unwittingly</b> or <b>intentionally, has not betrothed</b> her; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If he did so <b>unwittingly he has not betrothed</b> her, but if he did so <b>intentionally he has betrothed</b> her. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? From where does Rabbi Meir derive that second tithe cannot be used for betrothal? <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, says in the name of tradition:</b> The verse states: <b>“And all the tithe of the land, whether of the seed of the land, or of the fruit of the tree, is the Lord’s; it is holy to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 27:30). This verse indicates that <b>it is for the Lord, but not for betrothing a woman with it.</b>
The Gemara questions this derivation from several instances where similar wording is employed in a different verse, yet one may use those items for betrothal. But <b>there is <i>teruma</i> of the tithe,</b> about <b>which it is written: “So you also shall set apart a gift of the Lord</b> of all your tithes” (Numbers 18:28)? <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (58a): With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>teruma</i>, she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara answers: <i>Teruma</i> of the tithe is different, <b>as “to the Lord” is not written with regard to it,</b> indicating that it can be used for betrothal.
The Gemara asks: <b>But there is <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of dough that one must separate and give to a priest, <b>about which it is written:</b> “Of the first of your dough <b>you shall give to the Lord”</b> (Numbers 15:21)? <b>And we</b> also <b>learned</b> in that same mishna: With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>terumot</i>,</b> of which <i>ḥalla</i> is one type, <b>she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara answers: Although the verse does write “to the Lord,” <i>ḥalla</i> is different, <b>as</b> the word <b>“holy” was not written with regard to it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But there is</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>about which it is written: “It is a Jubilee, it shall be holy to you”</b> (Leviticus 25:12)? <b>And we learned</b> by inferring from a mishna (50b) that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with produce of the Sabbatical</b> Year, <b>she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara answers: With regard to produce of the Sabbatical Year, the verse writes “holy,” <b>but “to the Lord” is not written with regard to it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But there is <i>teruma</i>,</b> about <b>which it is written: “The Jewish people are the Lord’s holy portion, His first fruits of the increase”</b> (Jeremiah 2:3)? <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (58a) that in the case of <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>teruma</i>, she is betrothed.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>was written with regard to the Jewish people,</b> who are called the Lord’s holy portion, but not with regard to <i>teruma</i> itself.

Daf 53b

The Gemara asks: <b>But don’t you understand it by itself</b> from this verse? Since the verse compares the Jewish people to <i>teruma</i>, the categorization of “holy” evidently applies to <i>teruma</i> as well. <b>Ravin the Elder interpreted it before Rav:</b> The difference is that with regard to tithe <b>the verse states: “It is</b> for the Lord,” which indicates: <b>As it is, it should be,</b> as consecrated.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> if he betrothed a woman <b>with consecrated</b> property belonging to the Temple treasury, if he does so <b>intentionally he has betrothed</b> her, and if he does so <b>unwittingly he has not betrothed</b> her; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> the opposite: If he did so <b>unwittingly he has betrothed</b> her, but if he does so <b>intentionally he has not betrothed</b> her. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov said: I learned two</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an unwitting</b> error involving <b>tithe</b> according to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and the <i>halakha</i> of <b>an unwitting</b> error involving <b>consecrated</b> items according to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir. In both of these</b> cases <b>the woman is not betrothed with</b> the items.
He proceeds to explain. <b>One</b> of these <i>halakhot</i> is <b>because the woman does not want</b> to become betrothed with the item, <b>and</b> the reason for the <b>other</b> is <b>because neither</b> the man nor the woman <b>wants</b> it. He adds: <b>And I do not know which of them</b> is due to the woman alone, and which is due to both parties. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: Let us see</b> which reason is applicable to which case. It must be that with regard to second <b>tithe,</b> which may be eaten only in Jerusalem, it is <b>not satisfactory for her</b> to be betrothed with it <b>due to the trouble of</b> transporting it all <b>the way</b> to Jerusalem to enjoy it, whereas it is <b>satisfactory for him</b> to betroth her with it, <b>since he acquires a woman by itself,</b> i.e., by the tithe alone, without having to spend additional money of his own. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>consecrated</b> items, it is <b>not satisfactory for the two of them that consecrated</b> property <b>be desacralized by their</b> using it for betrothal.
<b>And Rabbi Ya’akov said the opposite is</b> more <b>reasonable. Couldn’t it be said</b> that in the case of second <b>tithe</b> it is <b>not satisfactory for her</b> to be betrothed with it <b>due to the trouble of</b> transporting it all <b>the way,</b> and it is <b>not satisfactory for him</b> to betroth her with it <b>due to the</b> danger of an <b>accident along the way.</b> If the second tithe gets lost on the way to Jerusalem, she will not have derived any benefit from it. It will cause her distress to think she received nothing for her betrothal, and he does not want cause her distress. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>consecrated</b> items, <b>granted</b> that with regard to <b>her,</b> it is <b>not satisfactory for her that consecrated</b> property <b>be desacralized through her, but why wouldn’t</b> it be <b>satisfactory for him to acquire a woman by itself,</b> without the expenditure of redeeming a consecrated item? Therefore, the reasons for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement cannot be determined by logic alone.
<b>Rava inquired of Rav Ḥisda:</b> According to Rabbi Meir, <b>a woman cannot be betrothed</b> by receiving consecrated money, but <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the money he gives her for betrothal: Does the <b>money become desacralized</b> as a result of the act of betrothal, as is usually the case when one uses a consecrated item for his own benefit? Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him:</b> If the <b>woman is not betrothed, how can the money become desacralized?</b> Since the money has not actually been used, nothing has changed with regard to its status.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin inquired of Rav Ḥisda: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a sale:</b> If one unwittingly uses consecrated money to purchase an item, does the sale take effect? Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: Even with regard to a sale he does not acquire</b> the item.
Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>raised an objection to him:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that if a man deposited a bundle of money with a money changer, the latter may not use the money. If the money changer untied the bundle and used the money, and it turned out that it was consecrated, the money changer is liable to bring an offering for the misuse of consecrated property, since he acted without the permission of the depositor. If the money was not in a bundle, the money changer has the right to use it, since the depositor knows that a money changer frequently distributes money. Consequently, in this case, if the money was consecrated, it is the depositor who is liable to bring an offering for the misuse of consecrated property, since the money changer is considered to have acted with his awareness. If one deposited the money with a homeowner, i.e., not a money changer, the latter may not use it in either case, and he is liable to bring an offering for the misuse of consecrated property if he does. With regard to a storekeeper, the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree: The same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a storekeeper as</b> to <b>a homeowner;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> But <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a storekeeper as</b> to <b>a money changer.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this: <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> that issue: <b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a storekeeper as</b> to <b>a money changer, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a storekeeper as</b> to <b>a homeowner. But everyone</b> agrees that <b>if</b> the storekeeper did <b>spend</b> the money, <b>he has misused</b> consecrated property. This indicates that even according to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, whatever transaction he performed did take effect. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rabbi Meir stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as follows: <b>According to me, if he spent</b> the money <b>he has also not misused</b> consecrated property, <b>but according to you, at least concede to me that</b> the same <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>a storekeeper as to a homeowner. And</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him: No,</b> I do not concede to you even with regard to this point, as I hold that the same <i>halakha</i> applies to a storekeeper <b>as</b> to <b>a money changer.</b>
The Gemara records a discussion as to the reasons for the rulings of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda. <b>Rav says:</b>

Daf 54a

<b>We reviewed all angles</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir,</b> i.e., we have examined all of Rabbi Meir’s statements with regard to consecrated property, <b>and we did not find</b> that he holds that <b>consecrated</b> property <b>is not desacralized</b> if it is misused <b>unwittingly</b> but it <b>is desacralized</b> if misused <b>intentionally.</b>
<b>And</b> as for <b>our mishna,</b> which indicates that this is Rabbi Meir’s opinion, it should not be understood as Rabbi Meir’s opinion with regard to consecrated property in general, but <b>with regard to</b> a case where a priest betrothed a woman using <b>priestly tunics that have not worn out</b> and that can still be worn during the Temple service. If a priest betrothed a woman with such garments, Rabbi Meir holds that if he did so unwittingly she is not betrothed, since clothes of this kind are not desacralized, and do not become hers. This is <b>because they were</b> initially <b>given</b> on the condition that the priests may <b>benefit from them</b> even when not performing the Temple service, <b>since the Torah was not given to the ministering angels.</b> It is impossible for a priest to wear the garments only at the moment he is performing the service and at no other time. Therefore, these garments are desacralized only if he intended to desacralize them.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with Rav’s statement. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to <b>priestly tunics that have worn out,</b> one <b>misuses</b> property consecrated to the Temple <b>by</b> using <b>them;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. What, is it not</b> so that this <i>halakha</i> would apply <b>even</b> if <b>they had not worn out,</b> and the <i>tanna</i> wanted to teach the additional <i>halakha</i> that it is still a transgression even after they are no longer fit for use? The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>specifically</b> to garments that <b>have worn out.</b> Since these cannot be used by priests, the permission to use them for non-sacred purposes lapses, and they are like other consecrated property that is subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the explanation of Rabbi Meir’s statement. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: One</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of property consecrated to the Temple <b>by</b> using <b>new</b> shekels, i.e., those given this year, which are used to purchase animals for this year’s offerings, <b>but one</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of property consecrated to the Temple <b>by</b> using <b>old</b> shekels, given by those who failed to give the previous year’s half-shekel, since these old shekels are used not to purchase offerings but for Temple maintenance; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: One</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of property consecrated to the Temple <b>even by</b> using <b>old</b> shekels, <b>as Rabbi Meir would say: One</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of property consecrated to the Temple not only <b>by</b> using money designated to purchase offerings, but even with <b>the remainder of the chamber,</b> i.e., the money that remained in the chamber after money was taken to purchase the animals used in communal offerings.
The Gemara continues the question: <b>But why</b> should one be liable for using the old shekels? <b>Let us say</b> the same logic: One is not liable, <b>because they were</b> initially <b>given</b> on the condition that people may <b>benefit</b> from them, <b>since the Torah was not given to</b> the <b>ministering angels</b> and people could not help but benefit from them. This is <b>as</b> the money to repair <b>the wall of the city and its towers comes from the remainder of the chamber, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 4:2): <b>The wall of the city, its towers, and all</b> of the <b>requirements of the city</b> of Jerusalem <b>come from the remainder of the chamber.</b> It is not possible for passersby to avoid benefiting from the shade provided by the walls of the city. The Gemara answers: <b>Do not say</b> that the opinion that one is liable for misuse of property consecrated to the Temple by using money from the remainder of the chamber is that of <b>Rabbi Meir. Rather,</b> emend the mishna and <b>say</b> that it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael bar Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> With regard to <b>stones</b> of the walls and towers <b>of Jerusalem that fell, one</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of property consecrated to the Temple <b>by</b> using <b>them;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> This indicates that according to Rabbi Meir, the use of even such stones renders one liable, despite the fact that it is not possible for people to avoid benefiting from them. The Gemara again answers: <b>Do not say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is recording the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir. Rather,</b> emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, is Jerusalem consecrated</b> at all? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 10b): If one says that an item shall be considered <b>like the lamb</b> of the daily offering, <b>like the</b> animals designated as offerings and kept in special <b>enclosures, like the wood</b> of the altar, <b>like the fires</b> on the altar, <b>like the Sanctuary, like the altar,</b> or <b>like Jerusalem,</b> it is a vow and he is prohibited to derive benefit from the item, as he has compared it to something consecrated. The essence of a vow creating a prohibition is the statement that a certain item shall be like a consecrated item. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Anyone who says</b> that an item shall be considered <b>Jerusalem has not said anything,</b> indicating that Rabbi Yehuda holds that Jerusalem is not consecrated.
<b>And if you would say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda’s reason is not that he holds that Jerusalem is not consecrated, but <b>because</b> the one stating the vow <b>did not say: Like Jerusalem,</b> but stated only that the item shall be considered Jerusalem, which is not a clear expression of a vow, <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nedarim</i> 1:6) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Anyone who says</b> that an item shall be considered <b>like Jerusalem has not said anything, until he vows by</b> comparing the item to <b>an item that is sacrificed in Jerusalem.</b> This indicates that he holds that Jerusalem itself is not consecrated.

Daf 54b

The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> and the mishna in tractate <i>Nedarim</i> <b>are two <i>tanna’im</i> and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> concerning whether or not he holds that Jerusalem itself was sanctified.
<b>Ulla said</b> a different opinion <b>in the name of bar Padda: Rabbi Meir would say: Consecrated</b> property <b>is desacralized</b> if misused <b>intentionally;</b> it <b>is not desacralized</b> if misused <b>unwittingly. And they said</b> that consecrated property that is misused <b>unwittingly is desacralized only with regard to an offering,</b> i.e., the one who misused it is liable to bring a guilt-offering for his action, but the property remains consecrated. The Gemara asks: <b>But since it is not desacralized</b> when misused unwittingly, <b>for what</b> reason is he <b>rendered liable</b> to bring <b>an offering,</b> as the action had no effect?
<b>Rather, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he explained</b> it this way <b>in the name of bar Padda: Rabbi Meir would say: Consecrated</b> property <b>is desacralized</b> if misused <b>intentionally;</b> it <b>is not desacralized</b> if misused <b>unwittingly. And they said</b> that consecrated property that is misused <b>unwittingly is desacralized only with regard to eating.</b> If one ate consecrated food, thereby consuming it completely, he is liable to bring an offering. If he merely misused consecrated money it retains its sanctity and is not desacralized, and he is not liable to bring an offering.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir with regard to</b> second <b>tithe</b> in that it is considered consecrated, <b>as</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> taught us an unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion. <b>And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to consecrated</b> property, <b>as</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> taught us an unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion.
The Gemara clarifies this statement: <b>What is</b> the unattributed mishna that is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir with regard to</b> second <b>tithe?</b> It is <b>as we learned</b> (<i>Pe’a</i> 7:6): It is prohibited to eat or derive benefit from fruit during the first three years after the tree is planted. The fruit of the fourth year is to be taken to Jerusalem and eaten there. With regard to <b>a vineyard</b> in its <b>fourth year, Beit Shammai say: It does not have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of adding <b>one-fifth,</b> i.e., if the owner himself redeems the fruit to bring money to Jerusalem to spend on food there, as one may also do with second tithe, he does not add one-fifth to its value but redeems it for its true value. <b>And it</b> also <b>does not have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>disposal,</b> i.e., there is no obligation to dispose of it on the eve of Passover of the fourth year of the Sabbatical cycle, when all tithes that have not yet been separated must be disposed of. <b>And Beit Hillel say: It does have</b> the <i>halakha</i> of adding one-fifth and the <i>halakha</i> of disposal.
That mishna continues: Furthermore, <b>Beit Shammai say: It has</b> the mitzva requiring the owner of the vineyard to leave <b>individual fallen grapes</b> for the poor <b>[<i>peret</i>], and it has</b> the mitzva requiring the owner to leave <b>incompletely formed clusters</b> of grapes for the poor <b>[<i>olelot</i>].</b> Since the vineyard is considered the owner’s property during this year, he must leave these gifts for the poor. <b>And Beit Hillel say: All of it</b> goes <b>to the winepress</b> to make wine. Since the grapes have sanctity, he is not obligated to leave these gifts for the poor.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Beit Hillel? They derive</b> a verbal analogy from the word <b>“holy”</b> stated with regard to a fourth-year vineyard, as the verse states: “Holy, for giving praise to the Lord” (Leviticus 19:24), <b>from “holy”</b> stated with regard to second <b>tithe,</b> as the verse states: “Holy to the Lord” (Leviticus 27:30). This verbal analogy teaches the following: <b>Just as</b> second <b>tithe has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of adding <b>one-fifth and it has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>disposal, so too,</b> the <b>fourth-year vineyard has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of adding <b>one-fifth and it has</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>disposal. And Beit Shammai do not derive</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“holy”</b> with regard to a fourth-year vineyard and <b>“holy” from</b> second <b>tithe.</b>
The Gemara proceeds to clarify the opinions of Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai with regard to the obligation to leave <i>peret</i> and <i>olelot</i> from a fourth-year vineyard. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>Beit Hillel,</b> who <b>say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of fourth-year produce is <b>like</b> the <i>halakha</i> of second <b>tithe, in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do they hold</b> with regard to second tithe? <b>If</b> they hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, why</b> does <b>all of it</b> go <b>to the winepress? Didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>say</b> that second <b>tithe is</b> itself <b>common,</b> i.e., non-sacred, <b>property,</b> and the owner must therefore leave <i>peret</i> and <i>olelot</i>? <b>Rather, is it not</b> the case that they hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who says that second tithe is consecrated property? The mishna aligning the opinion of Beit Hillel with that of Rabbi Meir is tantamount to there being an unattributed mishna in accordance with Rabbi Meir’s opinion, as the <i>halakha</i> is generally in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
The Gemara continues with the explanation of Rav Naḥman’s statement: <b>What is</b> the unattributed mishna that is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to consecrated</b> property? <b>As we learned</b> (<i>Me’ila</i> 21a): In a case where one sent an agent to buy something on his behalf and unwittingly gave him consecrated money to use, if he <b>sent</b> it <b>in the possession of</b> a halakhically <b>competent</b> person <b>and remembered</b> that it was consecrated money <b>before</b> the agent <b>reached the storekeeper, the storekeeper</b> will have <b>misused consecrated</b> property <b>when he will</b> later <b>spend</b> the money. This indicates that one is liable for misuse of consecrated property even when one acts unwittingly, as the storekeeper did.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> an unattributed mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to</b> second <b>tithe? But didn’t we learn</b> (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 4:3): With regard to <b>one who redeems his</b> own <b>second tithe, he adds to it its one-fifth, whether</b> the tithe was <b>from his</b> crop or <b>given to him as a gift.</b> The Gemara clarifies: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>If we say it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, can one give</b> second tithe <b>to</b> another <b>as a gift? But didn’t he say</b> that second <b>tithe is property</b> belonging to the <b>Most High,</b> which means it is not one’s own to give to another as a gift? <b>Rather, is it not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that second tithe is common property, and consequently this unattributed mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda with regard to second tithe?
The Gemara answers: <b>No, actually</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and with what are we dealing here?</b> It is not a situation where one gave second tithe itself as a gift, but <b>where he gave him</b> his entire crop <b>in its</b> state of being <b>untithed produce.</b> Consequently, the portion he gave him included tithes that had not yet been separated, <b>and he holds</b> that <b>gifts that have not been separated are not considered as though they have been separated.</b> One does not categorize the untithed produce as a mixture of regular produce and tithes, but as a non-sacred category in and of itself. Since the second tithe has not yet been separated, the produce has no sanctity, and he can give it as a gift.
The Gemara continues its line of inquiry: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another unattributed mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 4:6): With regard to <b>one who redeems his</b> own <b>fourth-year produce, he adds to it its one-fifth, whether</b> the produce was <b>from his</b> crop or was <b>given to him as a gift.</b> The Gemara inquires: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>If we say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, can one give</b> produce of the fourth year <b>to</b> another as a gift? <b>But didn’t he derive</b> that one must add one-fifth from the verbal analogy of <b>“holy”</b> for fourth-year fruit from <b>“holy” from</b> second <b>tithe?</b> This would mean that fourth-year fruit, like second tithe, is property of the Most High and cannot be given as a gift. <b>Rather, is it not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, and with what are we dealing here?</b> It is not a situation where one gave fully grown fourth-year fruit but <b>where he gave him</b> the fruit <b>when it was a bud. And this is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, who says: A bud</b> of a fruit <b>is forbidden</b> as <i>orla</i>, <b>because it is</b> already considered <b>a fruit.</b> Rabbi Meir, by contrast, holds that a fruit bud is not considered fruit. Therefore, the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>orla</i> and fourth-year fruit apply only to fruit that has grown, whereas beforehand it can be given as a gift.
The Gemara continues its line of inquiry: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another unattributed mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 4:6): If one was selling second-tithe produce, and the buyer <b>pulled tithe worth a <i>sela</i> from him,</b> thereby acquiring it, <b>and did not manage to redeem it until</b> its value <b>stood at two</b> <i>sela</i>, and he had not yet paid the seller, the buyer <b>gives a <i>sela</i></b> to the seller, <b>and he</b> thereby <b>gains a <i>sela</i> and the second tithe is his,</b> since he acquired it when he pulled it and the price was fixed at that point. The Gemara inquires: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>If we say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, why does</b> the buyer <b>gain a <i>sela</i>? The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah with regard to the redemption of consecrated property: <b>And he will give the money and it will be assured to him</b> (see Leviticus 27:19), from which it is derived that one acquires consecrated property only after paying money. This means that the value of the second tithe increased before he acquired it. <b>Rather, is it not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that second tithe is common property, and it is acquired from the moment he pulled it?
The Gemara confirms: <b>Actually,</b> this mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Nevertheless, Rav Naḥman’s statement that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to second tithe is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir is still correct, <b>as here</b> there is <b>one unattributed</b> mishna that is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, while <b>here</b> there are <b>two unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i> that indicate that Beit Hillel’s opinion is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, the one in tractate <i>Ma’aser Sheni</i>, and one in tractate <i>Eduyyot</i> (4:2).
The Gemara asks: <b>But if an unattributed</b> mishna is stated that way <b>specifically</b> to teach the <i>halakha</i>, <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if it is <b>one unattributed</b> mishna or <b>two unattributed</b> <i>mishnayot</i>? The Gemara suggests an alternate reasoning. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, since we learned</b> in a mishna in the <b>preferred</b> tractate, <i>Eduyyot</i>, <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion. Since the <i>halakha</i> is ruled in accordance with all of the <i>mishnayot</i> in <i>Eduyyot</i>, the fact that the opinion of Beit Hillel in that tractate is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir means that the <i>halakha</i> should be decided accordingly.

Daf 55a

The Gemara continues its discussion of the desacralizing of consecrated property. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shekalim</i> 20a): If there was <b>an animal</b> fit for the altar <b>that was found</b> straying, <b>from Jerusalem</b> and as far <b>as Migdal Eder, and</b> similarly if it was found <b>within that distance</b> from Jerusalem <b>in any</b> other <b>direction,</b> it is presumed that the animal came from Jerusalem. Most of the animals in Jerusalem were designated for offerings, and presumably this one was as well. <b>Males</b> are presumed to be <b>burnt-offerings,</b> as only males can be brought as burnt-offerings. <b>Females</b> are presumed to be <b>peace-offerings,</b> as it is permitted to bring a female peace-offering.
The Gemara questions this: <b>But are males</b> only <b>burnt-offerings and not</b> also <b>peace-offerings?</b> As peace-offerings can be male or female, a male animal that was found might have been designated as a peace-offering. <b>Rabbi Oshaya said:</b> We are not speaking <b>here</b> of bringing the animals themselves as offerings. Rather, <b>we are dealing with one who comes to obligate</b> himself to consecrate <b>their value.</b> The finder wants to consecrate the value of the animal in case it had been designated as an offering, thereby redeeming the animal and desacralizing it, <b>and this is</b> what the mishna is <b>saying:</b> In the case of males <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> they are <b>burnt-offerings,</b> so the money must be consecrated for the purpose of burnt-offerings as well as peace-offerings. <b>And this is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who says: Consecrated</b> property <b>is desacralized</b> if it is misused <b>intentionally.</b> Therefore, he may redeem the animal and must use the money to purchase both a peace-offering and a burnt-offering, thereby avoiding all uncertainty.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> can something that has <b>inherent sanctity,</b> such as an animal that has been designated as an offering, <b>be desacralized? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 19b): <b>There is no misuse after misuse with regard to consecrated</b> property? This means that if one misuses consecrated property, the item is immediately desacralized and the prohibition of misuse no longer applies to it. This is so <b>apart from</b> the case of the misuse of <b>an animal</b> designated as an offering <b>and</b> apart <b>from</b> the case of the misuse of <b>service vessels alone.</b> These do not become desacralized when misused, because they have inherent sanctity.
That mishna continues: <b>How</b> so? If someone <b>was riding on</b> a consecrated <b>animal,</b> and <b>another came</b> after him <b>and</b> also <b>rode</b> on it, and yet <b>another came and rode</b> on it, <b>they have all misused</b> consecrated property. Similarly, if one <b>was drinking from a golden cup</b> used in the Temple service, and <b>another came and drank</b> from it, and yet <b>another came and drank</b> from it, <b>they have all misused</b> consecrated property. The Gemara asks: As this indicates that an item that has inherent sanctity is never desacralized, how can it be redeemed? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> mishna, from tractate <i>Me’ila</i>, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> whereas <b>this</b> mishna, from tractate <i>Shekalim</i>, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us hear,</b> i.e., infer, <b>from</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir: Didn’t Rabbi Yehuda say</b> that <b>consecrated</b> property <b>is desacralized</b> if used <b>unwittingly, and</b> yet those items that have <b>inherent sanctity are not desacralized.</b> According <b>to Rabbi Meir as well, although consecrated</b> property <b>is desacralized</b> if used <b>intentionally,</b> items that have <b>inherent sanctity</b> should <b>not be desacralized.</b> The Gemara answers that there is a difference between the two opinions. <b>There,</b> in the case underlying Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, the one who misuses the consecrated item unwittingly <b>does not intend to withdraw it to a non-sacred</b> state but merely to use it, which is why an item that has inherent sanctity is not desacralized; whereas <b>here,</b> in the case underlying Rabbi Meir’s opinion, one who acts intentionally <b>does intend to withdraw it to a non-sacred</b> state, so even an item that has inherent sanctity can be desacralized.
The Gemara questions Rav Oshaya’s explanation of the mishna: <b>Say that you have heard Rabbi Meir</b> express the opinion that one can desacralize a consecrated item <b>in</b> the case of <b>offerings of the most sacred order,</b> but <b>did you hear him</b> express this opinion <b>in</b> the case of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> e.g., a peace-offering? If Rabbi Meir holds that offerings of lesser sanctity cannot be desacralized, the explanation of Rabbi Oshaya would be insufficient, as it does not account for the possibility that the animal is a peace-offering. <b>One of the Sages, and his name was Rabbi Ya’akov, said to him:</b> This is learned by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If <b>offerings of the most sacred order</b> can <b>be desacralized,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> the case that this <i>halakha</i> would apply to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity?</b>
