<b>It was also stated: Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Akiva, says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: Consecrated</b> property <b>is desacralized</b> when misused <b>intentionally,</b> but it <b>is not desacralized</b> when misused <b>unwittingly.</b> This applies <b>both</b> to <b>offerings of the most sacred order and</b> to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If <b>offerings of the most sacred order</b> can <b>be desacralized,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> the case that this <i>halakha</i> would apply to <b>offerings of lesser sanctity?</b>

Daf 55b

<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan wondered about</b> Rabbi Oshaya’s explanation of the mishna: <b>And does one say to a person: Arise and sin in order that you may gain?</b> Even if consecrated property can be desacralized intentionally, one is not allowed to redeem an animal designated to be an offering. <b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The mishna does not refer to redeeming an unblemished animal but to a case where the one who found the animal <b>waits for it until it develops a blemish.</b> At that point it would no longer have inherent sanctity but merely sanctity that inheres in its value, so the animal may be redeemed. <b>And he brings two</b> unblemished <b>animals</b> of the same value, <b>and stipulates</b> that if the animal he found was a burnt-offering, the first animal should be a burnt-offering in its stead while the other should be a voluntary peace-offering. And if the animal he found was a peace-offering, the second animal should be a peace-offering in its stead and the first should be a voluntary burnt-offering. After doing so he may eat the animal he found.
The Gemara continues to clarify the mishna. <b>The Master says</b> (55a): <b>Males</b> are presumed to be <b>burnt-offerings,</b> as only males may be brought as burnt-offerings. The Gemara asks: Why should a male necessarily be a burnt-offering; <b>perhaps it is a thanks-offering,</b> which can also be brought from a male animal? The Gemara answers: The mishna means <b>that</b> he must <b>also bring</b> a third animal and make a similar stipulation, that it should be either <b>a thanks-offering</b> in its stead or a voluntary one. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if he brings a third animal as a thanks-offering, doesn’t a thanks-offering <b>require</b> the bringing of <b>bread</b> as well? The Gemara answers: <b>He brings bread as well.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps it is a guilt-offering,</b> which is also brought only from male animals? The Gemara answers: The animal for <b>a guilt-offering</b> is <b>in its second year, and</b> the mishna is referring to a case where <b>an</b> animal <b>in its first year was found.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps it is the guilt-offering of a leper</b> or <b>the guilt-offering of a nazirite,</b> which are brought from animals in their first year? The Gemara answers: Lepers and nazirites are <b>not common,</b> and there is no need to be concerned about that possibility.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps it is a Paschal offering,</b> which is also brought from male animals? The Gemara answers: That is not likely, because with regard to <b>a Paschal offering,</b> if it is up to or <b>in its time</b> to be slaughtered, the owners <b>carefully guard it</b> to prevent it from going missing. <b>And</b> if it is a Paschal offering <b>that</b> is <b>not</b> offered <b>in its</b> proper <b>time,</b> but was left over and is offered later, <b>it</b> has the same <i>halakha</i> <b>as a peace-offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps</b> the animal he found <b>is a firstborn</b> animal, which can only be brought from male animals, <b>or</b> animal <b>tithe,</b> which can brought from male animals? The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to which <i>halakha</i></b> would the possibility that it is a firstborn or animal tithe need to be taken into account? It is with regard to the <i>halakha</i> that one is permitted <b>to eat them in their blemished</b> state, as firstborns and animal tithes do not need to be redeemed if they develop a blemish, but are eaten as such. <b>These</b> found animals <b>as well are eaten</b> only <b>in their blemished</b> state, as one may not redeem and eat them until they develop a blemish, as explained previously.
<b>The Master says</b> above: <b>Females</b> are presumed to be <b>peace-offerings,</b> as it is permitted to bring a female peace-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>Perhaps it is a thanks-offering,</b> which can also be brought from female animals? The Gemara answers: The mishna means <b>that</b> he must also <b>bring</b> a third animal and make a similar stipulation, that it is either a <b>thanks-offering</b> in the stead of the found animal, or a gift offering. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if he brings a third animal as a thanks-offering, doesn’t a thanks-offering <b>require</b> the bringing of <b>bread</b> as well? The Gemara answers: <b>He brings bread as well.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps it is a sin-offering,</b> as it is permitted to bring a female sin-offering? The Gemara answers: The animal for <b>a sin-offering</b> is always <b>in its first year, and</b> the mishna is referring to a case where <b>an</b> animal <b>in its second year was found.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps</b> it was <b>a sin-offering whose year had passed</b> without having been sacrificed? The <i>halakha</i> in such a case is that the animal is left to die. The Gemara answers: Such a case is <b>not common,</b> and there is no need to be concerned about such a possibility.
The Gemara asks: This is the case if the animal was in its second year, but <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if it <b>was found</b> when it was <b>in its first year?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ḥananya ben Ḥakhinai says:</b> If one found <b>a goat in its first year,</b> it is brought <b>as a sin-offering.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Can it enter your mind</b> that it is brought <b>as a sin</b>-<b>offering?</b> How can he sacrifice the animal as a sin-offering due to a mere possibility that it had been designated as a sin-offering? One cannot bring a voluntary sin-offering. <b>Rather, Abaye says:</b> He treats it <b>as</b> though it were <b>a sin-offering,</b> i.e., he <b>conveys it into a cell and it dies on its own.</b> Since it might be a lost sin-offering, it must be left to die.
<b>The Sages taught</b> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 1:15): <b>One may not purchase an animal with second-tithe money</b> outside of Jerusalem,

Daf 56a

<b>and if one purchased</b> an animal <b>unwittingly,</b> without realizing he was using second tithe money, <b>the money returns to its place,</b> meaning that it is considered to be an erroneous transaction and is void, because the purchaser would prefer to bring the second tithe money to Jerusalem rather than to travel with an animal to bring as an offering. If he purchased it <b>intentionally,</b> the animal <b>is brought up and eaten in</b> its proper <b>place,</b> i.e., in Jerusalem. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to</b> one who acted <b>with intent, and purchased</b> the animal from <b>the outset for the sake of a peace-offering,</b> and in any case had to bring the animal to Jerusalem. <b>But with regard to</b> one who acted <b>with intent to withdraw the second-tithe money</b> from its consecrated state <b>to a desacralized</b> state, <b>whether</b> his act was <b>unwitting,</b> in which case it is an erroneous transaction, or <b>intentional, the money returns to its place.</b>
The Gemara questions this statement: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If the second tithe was used <b>intentionally, he has betrothed</b> the woman with it, and the betrothal, which is a type of acquisition, is effective? <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is based upon the assumption that <b>a woman knows that second-tithe money is not desacralized by her</b> acceptance of the betrothal, <b>and</b> it is as though she has agreed that <b>she</b> would <b>ascend and eat it in Jerusalem.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya objects to this: But</b> there are cases of <b>a non-kosher animal, slaves, or land,</b> with regard to which <b>a person knows that second-tithe money is not desacralized by</b> being used to purchase <b>them, and we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 1:7): <b>One may not purchase a non-kosher animal, slaves, or land with second-tithe money, even in Jerusalem. And if one did purchase</b> them, <b>he must eat</b> other food <b>corresponding to their</b> value. He must take an equivalent sum of money and use it to desacralize the money in the seller’s possession, after which he proceeds to bring this money to Jerusalem and use it to buy food, which he will then consume. In this case, the seller is also presumably aware that the money is second tithe and that he himself will need to take it to Jerusalem, as was presumed in the case of the betrothed woman, so why is the <i>halakha</i> not the same?
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>here,</b> in the case of the mishna, <b>we are dealing with a woman devoted to the meticulous observance of mitzvot, especially the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity, <i>teruma</i>, and tithes [<i>ḥavera</i>], who knows</b> the laws of tithes, and accepts it for betrothal with the awareness that she must take it to Jerusalem. An ordinary person, however, is not well-versed in these <i>halakhot</i>, so in the case of the purchase of an animal the seller thinks that the second-tithe money has been desacralized through the purchase of the non-kosher animal.
<b>The Master said: If one did purchase</b> them, <b>he must eat</b> other food <b>corresponding to their</b> value. The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> should he do so? Why not say that <b>the money must return to its place,</b> just <b>as</b> was the ruling <b>there,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda said with regard to one who acted with intent to desacralize the second tithe, where the seller was penalized for acquiescing to the sale?
<b>Shmuel says:</b>

Daf 56b

The case here is <b>where</b> the seller <b>fled</b> with the money, and there is no way of voiding the sale and returning the money to the purchaser. The Gemara comments: <b>And the reason is that he fled, but had he not fled, we would penalize the seller</b> by requiring him to return the money. The Gemara asks: <b>And let us penalize the buyer</b> and require him to take an equivalent sum of money to Jerusalem. The Gemara answers: It is <b>not the mouse</b> that <b>steals, but the hole</b> that <b>steals.</b> In other words, a mouse cannot steal an item unless he has a hole in which to hide it. Here too, the money would not have been desacralized without the help of the seller.
The Gemara questions this logic: <b>But if not</b> for the <b>mouse, what has the hole done?</b> Since they both are integral to the prohibited act, each of them is deserving of a penalty. The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that <b>anywhere that the forbidden</b> item <b>is,</b> i.e., anywhere that the money is, and in this case it is with the seller, <b>there we</b> should <b>penalize.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>orla</i>,</b> i.e., fruit grown during a tree’s first three years, or <b>with diverse kinds in a vineyard,</b> i.e., grain and grapes planted together, or <b>with an ox that is</b> sentenced to be <b>stoned, or with a heifer whose neck is broken,</b> or <b>with</b> the <b>leper’s birds</b> which are designated for his offering, <b>or with a nazirite’s hair, or</b> with <b>a firstborn donkey, or</b> with <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, or</b> with <b>non-sacred</b> animals <b>that were slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> if he betroths her with any of these items, the woman <b>is not betrothed,</b> since it is prohibited to derive benefit from any of these items. By contrast, if <b>one sold them and betrothed</b> a woman <b>with</b> the <b>money</b> received from <b>their</b> sale, <b>she is betrothed,</b> as in these cases one may derive benefit from the money he receives in exchange for the forbidden item.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara explains the source of the <i>halakha</i> that it is prohibited to derive benefit from the items mentioned in the mishna. <b>With <i>orla</i>: From where do we</b> derive that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from <i>orla</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “And shall have planted all manner of trees for food, then you shall count the fruit thereof as forbidden; three years shall it be as <b>forbidden [<i>arelim</i>]</b> to you; <b>it shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 19:23). From this verse, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only a prohibition</b> against <b>eating</b> it. <b>From where</b> do I derive that one may not even derive <b>benefit</b> from it? From where do we derive <b>that one may not</b> derive <b>benefit from it</b> in another manner, <b>and one may not paint with</b> the dye that can be extracted from the fruit, <b>and one may not light a lamp with</b> its oil? <b>The verse states: “Then you shall count the fruit thereof [<i>orlato</i>] as forbidden [<i>araltem</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 19:23), <b>to include all these</b> types of benefit in the prohibition.
The mishna stated that one may not betroth a woman <b>with diverse kinds in a vineyard. From where do we</b> derive that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from diverse kinds in a vineyard? <b>Ḥizkiyya said: The verse states:</b> “You shall not sow your vineyard with diverse kinds; lest the growth of the seed that you have sown be forbidden [<i>pen tikdash</i>], together with the yield of the vineyard” (Deuteronomy 22:9). Ḥizkiyya expounds <b>“lest</b> the growth of the seed that you have sown <b>be forbidden [<i>pen tikdash</i>]”</b> as: <b>Lest it be burned [<i>pen tukad esh</i>],</b> indicating that the seed of diverse kinds must be destroyed by fire, so that no benefit is derived from it.
<b>Rav Ashi says</b> that the phrase “<i>pen tikdash</i>” indicates that it is comparable to consecrated property, as if it said: <b>Lest it become consecrated [<i>kodesh</i>],</b> and one is therefore prohibited from deriving benefit from it, just as one may not derive benefit from consecrated property. The Gemara questions Rav Ashi’s interpretation: <b>If</b> diverse kinds in a vineyard is compared to consecrated property, then <b>just as consecrated</b> property <b>transfers</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>it</b> is redeemed <b>and becomes desacralized, so too, diverse kinds in a vineyard</b> should <b>transfer</b> their sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>they</b> are redeemed <b>and become desacralized.</b> Contrary to this logic, the mishna taught that if one sells diverse kinds in a vineyard, the proceeds can be used for betrothal, indicating that it is not forbidden to derive benefit from this money. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that the correct derivation is <b>as</b> that <b>of Ḥizkiyya.</b>
The Gemara continues its analysis of the mishna: <b>From where</b> is it derived that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from <b>an ox that is</b> sentenced to be <b>stoned?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is taught <b>by inference from</b> that <b>which is stated</b> with regard to an ox that killed a person: “And if an ox gore a man or a woman, that they die, <b>the ox shall be stoned,</b> and its flesh shall not be eaten; but the owner of the ox shall be clear” (Exodus 21:28). <b>Don’t I know</b> from this verse <b>that</b> the stoning makes it an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass, and it is prohibited to eat</b> an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass? What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Its flesh shall not be eaten”?</b> The verse <b>is telling you that</b> even <b>if one slaughtered</b> the ox <b>after its verdict had been reached</b> but before it was stoned, it is still <b>prohibited to eat</b> it.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived that one is prohibited <b>from</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from the ox as well? <b>The verse states: “But the owner of the ox shall be clear.”</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred</b> that one may not derive benefit from this ox? <b>Shimon ben Zoma says:</b> This is <b>like a person who says to another: So-and-so was left clear [<i>naki</i>] of his property, and he has no benefit from it at all.</b> Similarly, “But the owner of the ox shall be clear” means that he may not derive any benefit from the ox.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is it known <b>that this</b> phrase: <b>“Its flesh shall not be eaten,” comes</b> to teach a <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to</b> a case <b>where he slaughtered</b> the ox <b>after its verdict was reached,</b> but before it was stoned? <b>Perhaps it is permitted</b> to eat the ox <b>if he slaughtered</b> it <b>after its verdict had been reached. And this</b> phrase: <b>“Shall not be eaten,” comes</b> to teach a <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case <b>where they</b> had already <b>stoned it,</b> but not to teach a prohibition against eating it, as that is already known due to the fact that it was stoned. Rather, it comes to prohibit deriving benefit from the ox, <b>and</b> that would be <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Abbahu</b> who <b>says</b> the following, citing <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b>
The Gemara continues the question: <b>As Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>wherever it is stated: “It shall not be eaten”;</b> or <b>“you,”</b> singular, <b>“shall not eat”; or “you,”</b> plural, <b>“shall not eat”; both a prohibition</b> against <b>eating and a prohibition</b> against deriving <b>benefit</b> are indicated. This is so <b>unless the verse specifies for you</b> that one may derive benefit, <b>in the manner that it specified for you with regard to an animal carcass,</b> from which the verse explicitly permits one to derive benefit, as it states: “You may sell it to a foreigner” (Deuteronomy 14:21). Here, too, with regard to the ox that is stoned, the phrase: “Its flesh shall not be eaten,” may serve to teach that one may not derive benefit from the stoned ox.
The Gemara answers: <b>This statement</b> of Rabbi Abbahu <b>applies only</b> to a case <b>where we derive the prohibition</b> against <b>eating from the words: “It may not be eaten,”</b> which is interpreted to include any manner of consumption. But <b>here, the prohibition</b> against <b>eating is derived from: “It shall be stoned,”</b> from which it is understood that since the ox becomes an unslaughtered animal carcass, it may not be eaten. <b>As if it enters your mind that</b> the phrase: “Its flesh may not be eaten,” <b>is written to prohibit</b> one from deriving <b>benefit, let the verse state: “One may not derive benefit.”</b> Why does it refer to eating if that prohibition has already been derived?
<b>Alternatively,</b> even if one would say that the phrase: <b>“It shall not be eaten,”</b> can be used to indicate that it is prohibited to derive benefit from the ox, <b>why do I</b> need the additional words <b>“its flesh”?</b> These words must teach that <b>although he slaughtered</b> the ox <b>like</b> one does with kosher <b>meat,</b> after it was condemned to be stoned, it remains <b>forbidden</b> and cannot be eaten.
<b>Mar Zutra objects to this: But say</b> that <b>this</b> prohibition against eating the ox <b>applies</b> only <b>where he examined</b> a sharp <b>stone</b> to ensure that it had no nicks, <b>and slaughtered with it</b> in a halakhically acceptable manner. That action could <b>be considered like stoning,</b> since in any event the ox was killed by a stone. The Torah teaches that even if it was killed in this manner, one is prohibited from eating it. <b>But</b> if <b>he slaughtered it with a knife,</b> he should <b>not</b> be prohibited from eating it. The Gemara expresses surprise at this reasoning: <b>Was a knife written in the Torah?</b> If one slaughters the animal in a halakhically acceptable manner, this is called slaughtering, not stoning. <b>And moreover, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ḥullin</i> 1:2): One may <b>slaughter with anything</b> that cuts cleanly, <b>whether with a stone, whether with glass, whether with the stalk of a reed.</b> Consequently, there is no difference in the <i>halakha</i> with regard to using a knife or a sharp stone.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that we have derived</b> both <b>the prohibition</b> against <b>eating and the prohibition</b> against <b>benefiting</b> from an ox sentenced to be stoned <b>from: “It shall not be eaten,” what</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>does that</b> other phrase: <b>“But the owner of the ox shall be clear,” come</b> to teach? The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to</b> teach the prohibition against deriving <b>benefit</b> from <b>its hide</b> after it has been killed. Were it not for this phrase, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that since <b>it is written: “Its flesh shall not be eaten,”</b> only <b>its flesh is forbidden, but its hide is permitted.</b> Therefore, the words “and the owner of the ox is clean” teach that its hide is forbidden as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according <b>to those <i>tanna’im</i> who expound this</b> phrase: <b>“The owner of the ox shall be clear,” to</b> teach that the owner of an innocuous ox, i.e., one that is not known to cause damage with the intent to injure, is exempt from the payment of <b>half</b> of the <b>indemnity</b> incurred if that ox killed a person, or that he is exempt from <b>payment</b> of damages <b>for</b> miscarried <b>offspring</b> if his ox gores a pregnant woman and causes her to miscarry; <b>from where do they</b> derive this prohibition against <b>benefiting from</b> the ox’s <b>hide?</b>
The Gemara answers: They derive it <b>from</b> the wording: <b>“Its flesh</b> may not be eaten [<i>velo ye’akhel <b>et besaro</b></i><b>].”</b> The verse could have been formulated: <i>Velo ye’akhel besaro</i>, which already means: And its flesh shall not be eaten. The addition of the word “<i>et</i>” teaches that the prohibition applies also to <b>that which is secondary to the flesh,</b> i.e., the hide. The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, who derives the prohibition against benefiting from the hide from the verse: “But the owner of the ox shall be clear,” what does he learn from the additional word “<i>et</i>”?

Daf 57a

The Gemara answers: This Sage <b>does not interpret</b> the word <b>“<i>et</i>”</b> as a means to derive new <i>halakhot</i>. He considers the word “<i>et</i>” to be an ordinary part of the sentence structure and not a source for exegetical exposition. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Shimon HaAmasoni, and some say</b> that it was <b>Neḥemya HaAmasoni, would interpret all</b> occurrences of the word <b>“<i>et</i>” in the Torah,</b> deriving additional <i>halakhot</i> with regard to the particular subject matter. <b>Once he reached</b> the verse: <b>“You shall fear the Lord your God”</b> (Deuteronomy 6:13), which is written with the added word “<i>et</i>,” <b>he withdrew</b> from this method of exposition, as whose fear could be an extension of the fear of God?
<b>His students said to him: Our teacher, what will be with all</b> the occurrences of the word <b>“<i>et</i>” that you interpreted</b> until now? <b>He said to them: Just as I received reward for the exposition, so I received reward for</b> my <b>withdrawal</b> from using this method of exposition. The word “<i>et</i>” in this verse was not explained <b>until Rabbi Akiva came and expounded: “You shall fear the Lord your God”:</b> The word “<i>et</i>” serves <b>to include Torah scholars,</b> i.e., that one is commanded to fear them just as one fears God. In any event, Shimon HaAmasoni no longer derived additional <i>halakhot</i> from the word <i>et</i>.
§ The mishna teaches that if a man betroths a woman <b>with a heifer whose neck is broken,</b> she is not betrothed. The Gemara clarifies: <b>From where do we</b> derive that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a heifer whose neck is broken? <b>The school of Rabbi Yannai said:</b> An expression of <b>atonement was written with regard to it.</b> The verse: “Atone for Your people Israel” (Deuteronomy 21:8), was written with regard to a heifer whose neck was broken, <b>as</b> was also written with regard to <b>sacrificial animals.</b> Therefore, one is prohibited from deriving benefit from it, just as one may not benefit from an offering.
§ The mishna teaches that if a man betroths a woman <b>with the leper’s birds,</b> she is not betrothed. The Gemara clarifies: <b>From where do we</b> derive that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a leper’s birds? <b>As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> A mitzva that <b>enables is stated</b> in the verses with regard to a leper, <b>and</b> the Torah also discusses a mitzva that <b>atones,</b> both of which are performed <b>inside</b> the Temple. Here, a mitzva that enables is a reference to the leper’s guilt-offering, which enables him to partake of offerings; and a mitzva that atones is a reference to all other offerings. <b>And</b> mitzva that <b>enables is stated</b> in the verses with regard to a leper, <b>and</b> the Torah also discusses a mitzva that <b>atones,</b> both of which are performed <b>outside</b> the Temple. Here, a mitzva that enables is a reference to the leper’s birds, which permit him to reenter the camp; and a mitzva that atones is a reference to the heifer whose neck is broken, which atones for the inhabitants of the city nearest to an unsolved murder.
<b>Just as</b> in the case of the <b>enabling and atoning</b> rites <b>stated</b> in the Torah that are performed <b>inside</b> the Temple the Torah <b>made</b> the item of <b>the enabling</b> rite, i.e., the leper’s guilt-offering, from which one is prohibited from deriving benefit, <b>like</b> the item of <b>the atoning</b> rite, i.e., offerings in general, <b>so too,</b> in the case of the <b>enabling and atoning</b> rites <b>stated</b> in the Torah that are performed <b>outside</b> the Temple the Torah <b>made</b> the item of <b>the enabling</b> rite, i.e., the leper’s birds, from which one is prohibited from deriving benefit, <b>like</b> the item of <b>the atoning</b> rite, i.e., the heifer whose neck is broken.
<b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disputed the following issue: <b>From when</b> is one <b>prohibited</b> from deriving benefit from <b>the leper’s birds? Rabbi Yoḥanan says: From the moment of</b> their <b>slaughter; and Reish Lakish says: From the moment</b> they are <b>taken</b> and designated to be a leper’s birds. The Gemara explains their respective opinions: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: From the moment of</b> their <b>slaughter,</b> because <b>it is the slaughter that prohibits them,</b> since they are not consecrated beforehand. <b>Reish Lakish says: From the moment</b> they are <b>taken,</b> since this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from the heifer whose neck is broken. Just as</b> one is prohibited from deriving benefit from <b>a heifer whose neck is broken during</b> its <b>lifetime, so too,</b> one is prohibited from deriving benefit from the <b>leper’s birds during</b> their <b>lifetime.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to it, <b>the heifer whose neck is broken, itself, from when</b> is it a forbidden item? <b>Rabbi Yannai said: I heard</b> the <b>boundary,</b> i.e., stage, beyond which <b>it</b> is forbidden, <b>but I have forgotten</b> what it is. <b>But the group</b> of scholars <b>were inclined to say</b> that <b>its descent to a hard valley,</b> where its neck is broken, <b>is</b> the action that <b>renders it forbidden.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, <b>just as</b> with <b>a heifer whose neck is broken, it is not forbidden from the moment</b> it is <b>taken</b> but only afterward, <b>so too, the leper’s birds should also not be forbidden from the moment</b> they are <b>taken.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the case of the heifer, <b>it has another boundary</b> that can render it forbidden, namely its descent to the valley; <b>here,</b> in the case of the leper’s birds, <b>does it have another boundary?</b> It is taken and immediately slaughtered.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“Of all clean birds you may eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:11). The superfluous word “all” is stated <b>to include</b> one of the leper’s birds, which is <b>sent away</b> to freedom, while the words: <b>“But these are they of which you shall not eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:12), are stated <b>to include</b> in the prohibition the other, <b>slaughtered</b> bird. Rabbi Yoḥanan asks: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that the bird <b>is forbidden from</b> when it is <b>alive, is</b> a verse <b>necessary</b> to teach that it is forbidden <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter?</b> The Gemara answers: The verse is necessary, <b>lest you say: Just as it is in</b> the case <b>of sacrificial animals, where</b> one is <b>prohibited</b> from deriving benefit from <b>them when</b> they are <b>alive, and</b> the act of <b>slaughter comes and renders them fit</b> to be eaten, so too with regard to the bird. The verse <b>teaches us</b> that with regard to the leper’s bird this is not the case, and it remains forbidden even after it has been slaughtered.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>raised</b> another <b>objection to</b> Reish Lakish: The mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:5) teaches that if one <b>slaughtered</b> one of the leper’s birds <b>and it was found</b> to be <b>a bird with a condition that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], a partner is taken for the second,</b> i.e., remaining, bird, <b>while</b> with regard to <b>the first</b> bird, i.e., the <i>tereifa</i>, one <b>is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the bird <b>is forbidden from</b> when it is <b>alive, why is</b> one <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit from the first one,</b> if the prohibition took effect before it was slaughtered? Reish Lakish <b>said to him: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the slaughtered bird <b>was found</b> to be <b>a <i>tereifa</i> in its inner organs,</b> so <b>that</b> the <b>consecration did not take effect at all,</b> as the bird was not fit to be used for this purpose.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>raised</b> another <b>objection to</b> Reish Lakish from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Nega’im</i> 8:8): If he <b>slaughtered</b> the bird <b>without</b> bringing <b>a hyssop, or without</b> bringing <b>cedar wood, or without</b> bringing <b>a scarlet thread,</b> which were all used in the rite, <b>Rabbi Ya’akov says: Since</b> the bird <b>was set aside for its mitzva,</b> it is <b>forbidden</b> anyway. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Since it was not slaughtered in accordance with its mitzva,</b> it is <b>permitted.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan infers from this: <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> this issue, that one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ya’akov, <b>holds</b> that an act of <b>slaughter that is not fit</b> for accomplishing its full ritual purpose <b>is</b> nevertheless <b>considered</b> an act of <b>slaughter,</b> and the bird is therefore forbidden; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that an act of <b>slaughter that is not fit</b> for accomplishing its full ritual purpose <b>is not considered</b> an act of <b>slaughter</b> at all, and therefore one is permitted to derive benefit from the bird. <b>But everyone agrees at least</b> that one <b>is not prohibited from</b> deriving <b>benefit from it</b> when it is <b>alive,</b> but only after it has been slaughtered.
Reish Lakish replied: I concede that this <i>baraita</i> does not accord with my opinion, but this issue <b>is</b> a dispute between the <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> A mitzva that <b>enables is stated</b> in the verses with regard to a leper, <b>and</b> the Torah also discusses a mitzva that <b>atones,</b> both of which are performed <b>inside</b> the Temple. <b>And</b> a mitzva that <b>enables is stated</b> in the verses with regard to a leper, <b>and</b> the Torah also discusses a mitzva that <b>atones,</b> both of which are performed <b>outside</b> the Temple.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Just as</b> in the case of the <b>enabling and atoning</b> rites <b>stated</b> in the Torah that are performed <b>inside</b> the Temple the Torah <b>made</b> the item of <b>the enabling</b> rite <b>like</b> the item of <b>the atoning</b> rite, <b>so too,</b> in the case of the <b>enabling and atoning</b> rites <b>stated</b> in the Torah that are performed <b>outside</b> the Temple, the Torah <b>made</b> the item of <b>the enabling</b> rite <b>like</b> the item of <b>the atoning</b> rite. The <i>baraita</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael compares the leper’s birds to a heifer whose neck is broken, and therefore would also prohibit one from deriving benefit from the birds before they are slaughtered. The opinion of Reish Lakish is therefore in accordance with that <i>baraita</i>.
With regard to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> the <i>baraita</i> teaches: The verse states: <b>“Of all clean birds you may eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:11). The superfluous word “all” is stated <b>to include</b> one of <b>the</b> leper’s birds, which is <b>sent away</b> to freedom, while the words: <b>“But these are they of which you shall not eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:12), are stated <b>to include</b> in the prohibition <b>the</b> other, <b>slaughtered</b> bird.
The Gemara questions this interpretation: <b>And I will reverse</b> the exposition, and say that one may derive benefit from the slaughtered bird and not from the one that was sent away. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> The reason to expound the verse as the <i>baraita</i> does is that <b>we have not found</b> kosher <b>living creatures that are</b> permanently <b>forbidden</b> with regard to eating. Therefore, it stands to reason that the slaughtered bird is forbidden, not the living one. <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak objects to this</b> explanation: <b>But haven’t</b> we found kosher living animals that are permanently forbidden? But <b>there are</b>

Daf 57b

the cases of an animal <b>set aside</b> as an offering to an idol, <b>and</b> an animal that was itself <b>worshipped</b> as an idol, <b>which are living creatures and</b> yet <b>are</b> permanently <b>forbidden.</b> The Gemara answers: There is a difference, as <b>when</b> they are <b>forbidden,</b> they are forbidden only to be used <b>for the Most High,</b> i.e., to be used as offerings in the Temple service, but it is permitted <b>for a common</b> Jew to derive benefit from them.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya objects to</b> the explanation of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>But</b> an animal that <b>copulated</b> with a woman, and an animal that <b>copulated</b> with a man, <b>in</b> the presence of <b>witnesses, they are living creatures and</b> yet they <b>are</b> permanently <b>forbidden,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> is that these animals are killed, and one is prohibited from deriving benefit from them once they have been sentenced. <b>Rather,</b> the above explanation should be emended to say: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai: We have not found most</b> kosher <b>living creatures that are</b> permanently <b>forbidden</b> while they are still alive, and it can be assumed that the inclusion of the verse is referring to that which is generally forbidden, even if there are exceptions.
The Gemara offers another answer to the question of how the <i>baraita</i> knew which bird the verse is permitting. <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: The verse states: “And shall let go</b> the living bird <b>into the open field”</b> (Leviticus 14:7), which indicates that the bird is <b>like a field: Just as a field is permitted, so too, this</b> bird <b>is also permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: Is <b>that</b> word <b>“field” coming to</b> teach <b>this? That</b> word <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The word <b>“field”</b> teaches <b>that one may not stand in Jaffa and throw</b> the bird that is set free <b>to the sea,</b> or stand <b>in Gevat and throw it to the desert, and that he may not stand outside the city and throw it inside the city. Rather, any</b> manner in <b>which he is standing in the city and throws it outside the wall</b> to the field is valid. The word “field” teaches that one must set it free only to the field and nowhere else, not to teach that the bird is permitted.
<b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, the school of Rabbi Yishmael, who derives that one is permitted to derive benefit from the bird based on the word “field,” replies: <b>If so,</b> that this was the only <i>halakha</i> the word is teaching, <b>let the Torah write “field”; what</b> is the significance of <b>“the field”? Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it,</b> i.e., both the place to throw the bird and the permission to derive benefit.
<b>Rava says</b> a different answer to the question of how the <i>baraita</i> knew which bird the verse is permitting: <b>The Torah did not say “let go” for</b> it to serve as a <b>stumbling block.</b> If the bird sent free was forbidden, the Torah would not have commanded him to send it away, since people might eat it unwittingly.
§ The mishna teaches that if a man betroths a woman <b>with a nazirite’s hair,</b> she is not betrothed. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a nazirite’s hair? The Gemara answers: <b>As the verse states</b> with regard to a nazirite: <b>“He shall be holy [<i>kadosh</i>], he shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow long”</b> (Numbers 6:5), which teaches: <b>His</b> hair <b>growth shall be holy.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the hair of a nazirite can be compared to consecrated property by use of the term “holy,” then <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>consecrated</b> property, it <b>transfers</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>it</b> is redeemed <b>and</b> it <b>becomes desacralized, so too, a nazirite’s hair should transfer</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>it</b> is redeemed <b>and</b> the hair itself should become <b>desacralized.</b> This is not the <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>Do we read holy [<i>kodesh</i>]</b> in this verse, which is the term the verse uses for a consecrated item (see Leviticus 22:14)? <b>We read “holy [<i>kadosh</i>].”</b> Since a different conjugation of the term is used, the <i>halakhot</i> of the hair of a nazirite are not derived from those of consecrated property.
§ The mishna teaches that if a man betroths a woman <b>with a firstborn donkey,</b> she is not betrothed. The Gemara suggests: <b>Shall we say the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a firstborn donkey,</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from it <b>is prohibited;</b>this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> it. <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> The mishna can be referring to one who betrothed a woman with a firstborn donkey <b>after</b> it has had its <b>neck broken, and everyone agrees</b> that it is prohibited to derive benefit from the donkey once its neck is broken.
§ The mishna teaches that if a man betroths a woman with <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk,</b> she is not betrothed. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from meat cooked in milk? <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The Torah states <b>three times: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk”</b> (Exodus 23:19; Exodus 34:26; Deuteronomy 14:21). <b>One</b> verse serves to teach <b>the prohibition</b> against <b>eating</b> meat cooked in milk, <b>and one</b> verse serves to teach <b>the prohibition</b> against deriving <b>benefit</b> from meat cooked in milk, <b>and one</b> verse serves to teach <b>the prohibition</b> against <b>cooking</b> meat in milk.
The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says:</b> It is <b>prohibited to eat meat</b> cooked <b>in milk but</b> one is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it, <b>as</b> it <b>is stated: “For you are a holy people to the Lord your God. You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:21), <b>and it states there</b> with regard to the prohibition of an unslaughtered animal carcass: <b>“And you shall be holy men to Me”</b> (Exodus 22:30). Since both verses employ the term “holy” he derives: <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of an animal carcass, it is <b>prohibited to eat</b> it <b>but</b> one is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it, as the Torah explicitly states that it may be sold to a gentile, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to meat cooked in milk, it is <b>prohibited to eat</b> it <b>but</b> one is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it.
§ The mishna teaches that if a man betroths a woman with the items it enumerated, <b>or</b> with <b>non-sacred</b> animals <b>that were slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> she is not betrothed. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> i.e., that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a non-sacred animal that was slaughtered in the Temple courtyard, derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said in the name of Rabbi Meir: The Torah said: Slaughter for Me,</b> i.e., for offerings to God, <b>in My</b> place, inside the Temple courtyard, <b>and your</b> non-sacred animals that are intended for eating should be slaughtered <b>in your</b> place, outside the Temple courtyard. <b>Just as</b> one is <b>prohibited</b> from deriving benefit from <b>My</b> consecrated animals if they were slaughtered <b>in your</b> place, as one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a consecrated animal slaughtered outside the Temple, <b>so too,</b> one is <b>prohibited</b> from deriving benefit from <b>your</b> non-sacred animals if they were slaughtered <b>in My</b> place.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, <b>just as</b> the act of slaughtering <b>My</b> consecrated animals <b>in your</b> place is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>, so too,</b> to the act of slaughtering <b>your</b> non-sacred animals <b>in My</b> place should be <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>.</b> To counter this logic, <b>the verse states:</b> “If a man from the house of Israel slaughters an ox or lamb…<b>and has not brought it to the door of the Tent of Meeting to sacrifice an offering to the Lord…and that man shall be cut off”</b> (Leviticus 17:3–4). This teaches that it is only <b>for an offering</b> that one slaughtered outside the Tent of Meeting of the Tabernacle, or the Temple courtyard, that <b>he is punishable with <i>karet</i>,</b> but <b>for non-sacred</b> animals that one slaughtered <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard he is not punishable with <i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: In light of the above difference in <i>halakha</i> between these two cases, the entire comparison <b>can be refuted</b> in the following manner: <b>What</b> is an aspect unique <b>to</b> slaughtering <b>My</b> consecrated animals <b>in your</b> place? It <b>is</b> that it is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>,</b> and is therefore a severe prohibition, which could explain the <i>halakha</i> that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from them. The prohibition against slaughtering a non-sacred animal in the Temple courtyard, which is not punishable by <i>karet</i>, could be regarded as a less severe prohibition, and perhaps in this case it is permitted to derive benefit from the slaughtered animal. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a non-sacred animal that was slaughtered in the Temple courtyard still does not have a source.
Abaye quotes a lengthy <i>baraita</i> that serves as a source for the <i>halakha</i> that one is prohibited from deriving benefit from a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple courtyard. <b>Rather, Abaye said</b> it is derived <b>from here:</b> The Torah states <b>three verses that</b> have <b>a superfluous</b> element with regard to the various species from which one may bring a peace-offering: The verse <b>“and he slaughters it”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), the verse <b>“and he shall slaughter it”</b> (Leviticus 3:8), and the verse <b>“and he shall slaughter it”</b> (Leviticus 3:13). The Torah could simply have stated: “And he shall slaughter,” without adding: “It.” <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> the term “it” these three times?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The source for the <i>halakha</i> is <b>because it is stated</b> with regard to the ritual slaughter of animals for meat consumption: <b>“If the place</b> which the Lord your God shall choose to put His name there <b>be too far from you, then you shall slaughter</b> of your herd and of your flock” (Deuteronomy 12:21), from which it is derived: <b>When</b> you are <b>far from the place,</b> i.e., the Temple, <b>you may slaughter</b> non-sacred animals for meat consumption, <b>but you may not slaughter</b> non-sacred animals <b>in a near place,</b> i.e., in the Temple. The verse serves to <b>exclude non-sacred</b> animals, thereby teaching <b>that they may not be slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And I have</b> derived the prohibition against slaughtering a non-sacred animal in the Temple courtyard <b>only</b> with regard to <b>unblemished</b> animals, <b>which are fit to be sacrificed. From where</b> do I know <b>to include</b> even <b>blemished</b> animals, which are not fit to be sacrificed, in this prohibition? <b>I include blemished</b> animals <b>since</b> they are at least of <b>the type that is fit</b> to be sacrificed. <b>From where</b> do I know <b>to include the undomesticated animal,</b> which is never sacrificed as an offering, in this prohibition? <b>I include the undomesticated animal since it</b> is rendered fit for consumption <b>by</b> means of <b>slaughtering, like a domesticated animal. From where</b> do I know <b>to include fowl,</b> as the Torah does not mention slaughter with regard to fowl, in this prohibition? <b>The verse states: “And he slaughters it,” “and he shall slaughter it,”</b> as well as <b>“and he shall slaughter it,”</b> employing the addition term “it” each time. These three verses teach that one may not slaughter any non-sacred animal in the Temple courtyard.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one may not slaughter</b> <i>ab initio</i> <b>but if he did slaughter it would be permitted for him</b> to eat it. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “If the place</b> which the Lord your God shall choose to put His name there <b>be too far from you, then you shall slaughter</b> of your herd and of your flock, which the Lord has given you, as I have commanded you, <b>and you shall eat</b> within your gates, after all the desire of your soul” (Deuteronomy 12:21), which is expounded as follows: <b>That which you slaughter in a far place,</b> outside the Temple, <b>you may eat, but you may not eat that which you slaughter in a near place,</b> which <b>excludes non-sacred</b> animals <b>that were slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> Therefore, it is prohibited to eat a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple courtyard even after the fact.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the prohibition against eating the meat after the fact applies to <b>unblemished</b> animals,

Daf 58a

<b>which are fit to be sacrificed. From where</b> do I know <b>to include blemished</b> animals in this prohibition? <b>I include blemished</b> animals <b>since</b> they are at least of <b>the type that is fit</b> to be sacrificed. <b>And from where</b> do I know <b>to include the undomesticated animal</b> in this prohibition? <b>I include the undomesticated animal since it</b> is rendered fit for consumption <b>by</b> means of <b>slaughtering, like a domesticated animal. From where</b> do I know <b>to include birds,</b> as the Torah does not mention slaughter with regard to birds, in this prohibition? <b>The verse states: “And he slaughters it,” “and he shall slaughter it,”</b> as well as <b>“and he shall slaughter it,”</b> employing the addition term “it” each time. These three verses teach that one may not eat from a non-sacred animal that was slaughtered in the Temple courtyard
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he may not slaughter</b> a non-sacred animal in the Temple courtyard <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but if he did slaughter</b> it, <b>he may cast it before the dogs,</b> i.e., derive benefit from it. <b>The verse states:</b> “Therefore you shall not eat any flesh that is torn of beasts in the field; <b>you shall cast it to the dogs”</b> (Exodus 22:30), which teaches that although one is prohibited from eating the meat of a <i>tereifa</i>, one may derive benefit from it. The word “it” serves to emphasize and exclude: <b>You may cast it,</b> i.e., a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>to the dogs, but you may not cast non-sacred</b> animals <b>that have been slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> as it is prohibited to derive any benefit from them.
The Gemara relates: <b>Mar Yehuda found Rav Yosef and Rav Shmuel, son of Rabba bar bar Ḥana, standing at the entrance of Rabba’s study hall. He said to them:</b> It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with a firstborn donkey, with meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, or with non-sacred</b> animals <b>slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, Rabbi Shimon says she is betrothed, and the Rabbis say she is not betrothed. Apparently, according to Rabbi Shimon,</b> the prohibition against deriving benefit from <b>non-sacred</b> animals <b>slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard is not by Torah law,</b> which is why the betrothal takes effect.
<b>And</b> Mar Yehuda <b>raises a contradiction</b> against this inference from a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Non-sacred,</b> domesticated, animals <b>slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> must <b>be burned, as well as a</b> non-sacred <b>undomesticated animal slaughtered in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> This indicates that it is prohibited to derive benefit from them. <b>They were silent</b> and had no answer.
<b>They came before Rabba</b> and told him about this difficulty. <b>He said to them: A quarrelsome</b> person <b>has put you up</b> to asking this question. <b>With what are we dealing here</b> in the first <i>baraita</i>? We are dealing with a case <b>where it was slaughtered and found</b> to be <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, and Rabbi Shimon</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning</b> that an act of slaughter which does not render the animal permitted to be eaten is not called slaughter, so the animal does not have the status of a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple courtyard.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ḥullin</i> 2:4): With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> a known <b><i>tereifa</i>, as well as one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>and it was found</b> to be <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> and <b>this and that</b> were <b>non-sacred</b> animals slaughtered <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, Rabbi Shimon permits</b> one <b>to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from them, as explained previously. <b>And the Rabbis prohibit</b> one from deriving benefit from them, since they do not distinguish between an act of slaughter that does render the animal permitted to be eaten and one that does not. It is only in a case where the man betrothed her with a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered in the Temple courtyard that Rabbi Shimon says she is betrothed, but not when the animal was not a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ The mishna teaches that if <b>one sold</b> any of the items from which one is prohibited to derive benefit <b>and betrothed</b> a woman <b>with</b> the <b>money</b> received from <b>their</b> sale, <b>she is betrothed.</b> With regard to the possibility of deriving benefit from money received in exchange for items from which benefit is forbidden, the Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that this is permitted? The Gemara answers: It is <b>from</b> the fact that <b>the Merciful One reveals</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to</b> an object of <b>idol worship: “And you shall be banned like it”</b> (Deuteronomy 7:26), which teaches that <b>anything that you</b> cause to <b>come from it,</b> i.e., in exchange for it, <b>is like it.</b> It can be understood <b>by inference that</b> with regard to <b>all</b> the other <b>prohibitions of the Torah,</b> monies received for items from which benefit is forbidden are <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>But let us derive</b> a general principle concerning other prohibitions <b>from</b> the case of idolatry. The Gemara answers: This derivation is not applied, <b>because</b> an object of <b>idol worship and</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year <b>are two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., to teach the same matter, since both prohibitions also extend to the money obtained for them, <b>and any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common aspect to apply to other cases.
The Gemara clarifies: The source indicating that this is true of an object of <b>idol worship</b> is <b>what we said. What is</b> the source indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies to produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year? The verse states: <b>“It is a Jubilee, it shall be holy to you”</b> (Leviticus 25:12), from which it is derived: <b>Just as consecrated property transfers</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>it</b> is redeemed, <b>so too,</b> produce of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year, which has the same status as the Jubilee Year, <b>transfers</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which it is redeemed. Consequently, money used to acquire the produce of the Sabbatical Year will be subject to the same <i>halakhot</i> as the produce itself.
<b>If</b> so, one could also say that <b>just as</b> with <b>consecrated</b> property, it <b>transfers</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which <b>it</b> is redeemed <b>and becomes desacralized, so too,</b> produce of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year should <b>transfer</b> its sanctity to the <b>money</b> with which it is redeemed and <b>becomes desacralized.</b> Nevertheless, <b>the verse states: “Shall be,”</b> meaning: <b>As it is,</b> so <b>it shall be,</b> indicating that the Sabbatical-Year produce does not become desacralized.
The Gemara explains: <b>How so?</b> If one <b>purchased meat with produce</b> of the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year, both <b>these and those,</b> i.e., the meat and the produce, <b>are disposed of in the Sabbatical</b> Year. The sanctity of the Sabbatical Year takes effect with regard to the meat as well. It is treated like the produce, and must be disposed of when the obligation to dispose of the Sabbatical-Year produce goes into effect. If he then purchases <b>fish with</b> this <b>meat,</b> the <b>meat loses</b> its consecrated status, and the <b>fish assumes</b> the consecrated state. If he then purchases <b>wine with</b> these <b>fish,</b> the <b>fish loses</b> its consecrated status and the <b>wine assumes</b> the consecrated state. If he then purchases <b>oil with</b> the <b>wine,</b> the <b>wine loses</b> has its consecrated status and the <b>oil assumes</b> the consecrated state. <b>How so? The final</b> item purchased has the sanctity <b>of</b> the <b>Sabbatical</b> Year <b>transferred</b> to it, <b>and the</b> Sabbatical-Year <b>produce itself</b> remains <b>forbidden.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that any two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common aspect to apply to other cases. <b>But according to the one who says that they do teach</b> their common aspect to apply to other cases, <b>what can be said?</b> Why is it not learned from these examples that money received from the sale of an item from which benefit is forbidden, is likewise forbidden? The Gemara answers: Expressions of <b>restriction are written</b> in both cases. <b>Here,</b> with regard to idol worship, it <b>is written: “For it is banned”</b> (Deuteronomy 7:26), which indicates only that it is banned, i.e., has its prohibition extend to money received from its sale, while other prohibited items are not. <b>And there,</b> with regard to produce of the Sabbatical Year, it <b>is written: “It is a Jubilee”</b> (Leviticus 25:12), which teaches that with regard to <b>“it,” yes,</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies; but this <i>halakha</i> does <b>not</b> apply to <b>anything else.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>terumot</i>, or with tithes, or with</b> the foreleg, cheeks, and stomach of an animal, which are given as <b>gifts</b> to priests, <b>or with the water of purification,</b> which is sprinkled on an impure person during the purification rite for impurity imparted by a corpse, <b>or with the ashes of purification,</b> which were mixed with the water sprinkled on an impure person during the purification rite for impurity imparted by a corpse, in all of these cases <b>she is betrothed, and</b> this is so <b>even if</b> the man betrothing her is <b>an Israelite,</b> not a priest or a Levite.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Ulla says:</b> The <b>benefit of discretion,</b> i.e., the benefit accrued from the option of giving <i>teruma</i> and tithes to whichever priest or Levite one chooses, <b>does not have monetary</b> value. <b>Rabbi Abba raised an objection to Ulla</b> from the mishna: With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>terumot</i>, or with tithes, or with gifts, with the water of purification, or with the ashes</b> of the red <b>heifer, she is betrothed, and</b> this is so <b>even if</b> the man betrothing her is <b>an Israelite.</b> This indicates that although an Israelite cannot consume the priestly gifts, he may nevertheless betroth a woman with them, since he possesses the option to give them to the priest or Levite of his choice. That benefit has monetary value, and it is that value that he uses to betroth a woman, who can then give them to whichever priest or Levite she chooses.
Ulla <b>said to him:</b> You have misunderstood the case of the mishna, since <b>here</b> the case is <b>with an Israelite who came into</b> possession of <b>untithed produce</b> as an inheritance <b>from the household of his mother’s father,</b> who was <b>a priest, and</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>holds</b> that <b>gifts that have not been separated are considered as though they have been separated.</b> The untithed produce is not viewed as one entity, but rather is viewed as a mixture of regular produce, <i>teruma</i>, and tithes. This <i>teruma</i> belonged to his grandfather, who was a priest. Since he has inherited this <i>teruma</i>, he has ownership rights to it in addition to the benefit of discretion. While he cannot consume this produce because he is an Israelite, he can sell it to a priest and keep the money. Since it has actual value, it can be used to betroth a woman.
With regard to this issue, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin inquired of Rav Huna:</b> Does the <b>benefit of discretion have monetary</b> value, <b>or does it not have monetary</b> value? Rav Huna <b>said to him: You learned it</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>terumot</i>, or with tithes, or with gifts,</b> or <b>with the water of purification, or with the ashes</b> of the red <b>heifer, she is betrothed, and</b> this is so <b>even if</b> the man betrothing her is <b>an Israelite.</b> This indicates that the benefit of discretion has monetary value. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>said to him: But didn’t we establish it,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Ulla, as referring <b>to an Israelite who came into</b> possession of <b>untithed produce</b> as an inheritance <b>from the household of his mother’s father,</b> who was <b>a priest?</b>

Daf 58b

Rav Huna <b>said to him: You are out [<i>hotza’a</i>].</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>was embarrassed,</b> as <b>he thought</b> Rav Huna <b>told him</b> he was out, i.e., wrong, <b>due to</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> he</b> stated. Sensing Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin’s embarrassment, Rav Huna <b>said to him: This is what I said:</b> You are a <i>Hutzla’a</i>, as <b>Rav Asi, from</b> the town of <b>Huzal, stands in accordance with your</b> opinion.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that it is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> The <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 3:9) taught: <b>One who steals another’s untithed produce pays him the</b> full <b>value of the other’s untithed produce;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: He pays only the value of the non-sacred</b> produce <b>that it contains. What, is it not</b> the case <b>that they disagree about this</b> issue: <b>That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that the <b>benefit of discretion has monetary</b> value, so he must be compensated beyond the value of the non-sacred produce; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that the <b>benefit of discretion does not have monetary</b> value, and only the non-sacred produce is of value to the owner.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone agrees</b> that the <b>benefit of discretion does not have monetary</b> value, <b>and here</b> the case is <b>with an Israelite who came into</b> possession of <b>untithed produce</b> as an inheritance <b>from the household of his mother’s father,</b> who was <b>a priest. And they disagree with regard to</b> the question of whether or not <b>gifts that have not been separated are considered as though they have been separated.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that they <b>are considered as though they have been separated,</b> which means that the grandson inherited the <i>teruma</i> itself from his grandfather, so the thief must repay him the value of the <i>terumot</i> and tithes as well. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that such gifts <b>are not considered as though they have been separated;</b> and the produce is viewed as regular untithed produce, where the Israelite has only the benefit of discretion, which is of no monetary value.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>everyone agrees</b> that the gifts <b>are considered as though they have been separated, and</b> that the <b>benefit of discretion does not have monetary</b> value. The case is not concerning an Israelite who came into possession of untithed produce as an inheritance from the household of his mother’s father; rather, it is concerning regular untithed produce, <b>and here</b> they <b>disagree with regard to</b> a statement <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel says:</b> By Torah law, even <b>one grain</b> given as <i>teruma</i> <b>exempts the</b> entire <b>heap,</b> since the Torah does not specify a minimum amount for <i>teruma</i>.
<b>As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel,</b> so the thief must pay the value of the untithed produce as well, since the owner can say that he would separate a single grain as <i>teruma</i> for the entire heap and the rest would remain non-sacred produce. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel,</b> which means that when the owner makes his claim he must subtract at least one-sixtieth of the total amount as <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>everyone is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel; and here, this is</b> the <b>reasoning of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: Although the benefit of discretion does not have monetary value, and by right should not lead to reimbursement, <b>the Sages penalized the thief.</b> If he did not need to pay for the <i>teruma</i> contained in the produce, he would have been able to keep it, as no priest has the legal ability to demand that the <i>teruma</i> be given specifically to him.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>everyone is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Shmuel, and here, this is</b> the <b>reasoning of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda: The Sages penalized the owner, since he should not have left his untithed produce</b> in that state, and should have separated <i>teruma</i> without delay.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>one who betroths</b> a woman <b>with <i>terumot</i>, or with tithes, or with</b> the <b>gifts</b> given to priests, or <b>with the water of purification, or with the ashes</b> of the red <b>heifer,</b> in all of these cases <b>she is betrothed, and</b> this is so <b>even if</b> the man betrothing her is <b>an Israelite. And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to this from the following <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 3:5): With regard to <b>one who accepts payment to judge, his judgments are nullified.</b> Similarly, with regard to one who accepts payment <b>to testify, his testimony is nullified.</b> With regard to one who accepts payment <b>to sprinkle</b> the purification water on one who was impure from impurity imparted by a corpse, <b>or to sanctify</b> the purification water by placing the ashes of the red heifer in them, <b>his water</b> is considered <b>cave water,</b> which is generally foul, <b>and his ashes are burnt ashes.</b> Using these items to betroth a woman is analogous to being paid for them, so they should be considered as having no monetary value, and the betrothal should not take effect.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> since <b>here,</b> the mishna is referring to one who betroths a woman <b>with</b> the value of the <b>payment for bringing and filling</b> the vessel with the purification waters, for which one is permitted to accept payment. Performing this act for the woman is comparable to giving her an item of value, since she will not have to pay someone to bring and fill the vessel for her. <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> dealing with one who accepts payment for sprinkling or sanctifying the water is referring <b>to payment for</b> the actual <b>sprinkling and sanctifying.</b>
The Gemara comments: According to this answer, the language of the mishna and the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise, as it teaches here,</b> in the mishna, that she is betrothed <b>with the water of purification or with the ashes of purification,</b> which indicates that the water and ashes have not yet been mixed together; <b>and it teaches there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>To sprinkle or to sanctify,</b> indicating that he receives payment for the actual sprinkling and sanctification. The Gemara affirms: <b>Learn from it</b> that this is the correct explanation of the mishna and the <i>baraita</i>.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one</b> man <b>who says to another: Go and betroth so-and-so to me, and</b> the latter <b>went and betrothed her to himself, she is betrothed to the second</b> man. <b>And similarly,</b> with regard to <b>one who says to a woman: You are hereby betrothed to me after thirty days, and another</b> man <b>came and betrothed her within</b> those <b>thirty days, she is betrothed to the second</b> man. This is a full-fledged betrothal, so that if she is <b>an Israelite woman</b> betrothed <b>to a priest, she may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
If the first man said to the woman: You are hereby betrothed to me <b>from now, and</b> only <b>after thirty days</b> shall the betrothal take effect, <b>and another</b> man <b>came and betrothed her within</b> those <b>thirty days,</b> there is uncertainty whether <b>she is betrothed or</b> whether <b>she is not betrothed</b> to each of them. Consequently, if she was <b>the daughter of a non-priest</b> betrothed <b>to a priest, or the daughter of a priest</b> betrothed <b>to an Israelite, she may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> Since her betrothal is uncertain, the daughter of a non-priest cannot be considered the wife of a priest, and similarly a priest’s daughter who is doubtfully married to an Israelite loses her right to partake of <i>teruma</i> as the daughter of a priest.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that in the case of <b>one</b> man <b>who says to another: Go and betroth</b> so-and-so to me, and the latter went and betrothed her to himself, she is betrothed to the second man. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> concerning this issue: <b>What he did is done;</b> it is effective and the woman is betrothed to the second man, <b>but he has treated him,</b> i.e., the first man, <b>in a deceitful manner,</b> and it is prohibited to act in this fashion. The Gemara explains: <b>And the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna, <b>when</b> he <b>teaches</b> the apparently superfluous term: <b>Went, also</b> indicates that he <b>went</b> and acted <b>deceitfully.</b>
§ The Gemara asks a question concerning the language of the mishna: <b>What is different here that</b> the mishna <b>teaches:</b> With regard to <b>one</b> man <b>who says to another,</b>

Daf 59a

<b>and what is different there,</b> in the previous chapter (50a), <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches:</b> With regard to <b>one who says to his agent,</b> go and betroth a certain woman for me in such and such a place, and he went and betrothed her in a different place, she is not betrothed? Why does the mishna there label him an agent, and here it labels him simply another?
The Gemara answers: <b>Here</b> the mishna <b>teaches us a novel</b> element <b>and there</b> it <b>teaches us a novel</b> element, through its use of these terms. The Gemara elaborates: The mishna <b>here teaches us a novel</b> element, <b>as had it taught: His agent, I would say</b> that <b>it is his agent who is</b> considered <b>a scoundrel</b> in that case, <b>as</b> one who sends an agent <b>relies</b> upon him, <b>thinking:</b> He will <b>perform my agency for me,</b> since he was sent for that purpose. <b>But</b> with regard to the use of the term: <b>Another,</b> who was not appointed and <b>upon whom he does not rely,</b> as he is not his agent, you might <b>say</b> that he <b>should not</b> be considered <b>a scoundrel.</b>
Similarly, the mishna <b>there teaches us a novel</b> element, <b>as had it taught: One who says to another, I would say</b> that <b>it is</b> in the case of <b>another that she is not betrothed if he betrothed her in a different place, as he thinks</b> that this person would <b>not</b> go to the <b>trouble</b> of looking for her elsewhere, and therefore he authorized him to betroth the woman only in that particular place. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>his agent, who</b> is assumed to take special <b>trouble</b> to fulfill his agency, you might <b>say he is</b> merely <b>showing him</b> the <b>place</b> where she is likely to be found, and she is betrothed in any case. The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that even when he appointed an agent she is not betrothed if he does not find her in the place the putative husband specified.
The Gemara relates: <b>Ravin the Pious</b> was appointed an agent and <b>went to betroth a woman to his son,</b> but in the end he <b>betrothed her to himself.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the aforementioned <i>baraita</i>: <b>What he did is done, but he has treated him in a deceitful manner?</b> How could a pious individual act in this fashion? The Gemara answers: The woman’s family <b>would not give her to</b> the son, and agreed only to let her marry the father. The Gemara further asks: Even so, before betrothing her <b>he should have</b> first <b>informed</b> his son that they refuse to let her marry him. The Gemara explains that Ravin <b>thought: In the meantime,</b> while I am busy reporting back to my son, <b>someone else</b> will <b>come</b> and <b>betroth her.</b>
The Gemara relates a similar story: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana gave money to Rav</b> and <b>said: Purchase this land for me.</b> Rav <b>went and purchased it for himself.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to an agent who acts in this manner: <b>What he did is done, but he has treated him in a deceitful manner?</b> The Gemara answers: The land <b>was</b> located <b>in a valley</b> inhabited <b>by violent</b> men, who <b>treated Rav</b> with <b>respect</b> and were prepared to sell the land to him, but who <b>did not treat Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> with <b>respect.</b> As in the case of Ravin, the Gemara questions this behavior: Nevertheless, Rav <b>should have informed him.</b> The Gemara responds that Rav <b>thought: In the meantime someone else will come</b> and <b>purchase</b> the land.
The Gemara further relates: <b>Rav Giddel was engaging in</b> the acquisition of <b>a certain</b> plot of <b>land.</b> In the meantime <b>Rabbi Abba went</b> and <b>purchased it. Rav Giddel went</b> and <b>complained about</b> Rabbi Abba <b>to Rabbi Zeira. Rabbi Zeira went and complained about</b> Rabbi Abba <b>to Rav Yitzḥak Nappaḥa.</b> Rav Yitzḥak Nappaḥa <b>said to him: Wait until</b> Rabbi Abba <b>ascends to</b> visit <b>us for the pilgrimage Festival,</b> when all come to hear the Festival sermon, on which occasion we can discuss this matter with him. <b>When</b> Rabbi Abba <b>ascended</b> Rav Yitzḥak Nappaḥa <b>found him</b> and <b>said to him:</b> If <b>a pauper is engaging in</b> the acquisition of <b>a loaf</b> of bread that he found, <b>and another came and took it from him, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>?
Rabbi Abba <b>said to him:</b> The one who took it away <b>is called wicked.</b> Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa replied: <b>But</b> if so, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>the Master acted this way?</b> Rav Giddel was negotiating the purchase of this land and you purchased it. Rabbi Abba <b>said to him: I did not know</b> that Rav Giddel was trying to acquire the land. Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa retorted: <b>Now too, the Master should give it to him,</b> since you have been made aware that he submitted the first offer. Rabbi Abba <b>said to him:</b> As for <b>selling, I will not sell it, as it is</b> the <b>first land</b> I have ever purchased, <b>and</b> this <b>matter</b> of selling one’s first acquisition <b>is not</b> a good <b>omen. If he wants</b> to accept it <b>as a gift, let him take it.</b>
<b>Rav Giddel did not descend to</b> claim this plot of land, <b>as it is written: “But he who hates gifts shall live”</b> (Proverbs 15:27), and therefore he did not wish to accept the land as a gift. <b>Rabbi Abba</b> also <b>did not descend to it, because Rav Giddel</b> was already <b>engaging in</b> the acquisition of <b>it</b> when he acquired the land. In this manner, <b>this Sage did not descend to</b> take the plot of land, <b>and that Sage did not descend to</b> take care of <b>it, and it was called the land of the Sages.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And similarly,</b> with regard to <b>one who says to a woman: Be betrothed to me</b> after thirty days, and another came and betrothed her within this period, she is betrothed to the second man. The Gemara asks: In a case where <b>another did not come and betroth her within</b> the <b>thirty</b> days, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav and Shmuel both say: She is betrothed</b> after thirty days, <b>even if the money</b> he gave for her betrothal <b>has been used</b> before the end of this period, as the betrothal takes effect from when the money is given.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason</b> that she is betrothed despite the lack of money at the end of the thirty days? The Gemara explains that <b>these dinars</b> given for her betrothal are <b>not comparable to a loan, nor</b> are they <b>comparable to a deposit</b> that was transferred into her possession and subsequently lost. In both of these cases she would not be betrothed.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>They are not comparable to a deposit,</b> as <b>a deposit is used in its owner’s possession,</b> i.e., any loss is incurred by the owner, <b>whereas these are used in her own possession,</b> as he gave her the money to keep. These dinars <b>are also not comparable to a loan; a loan is given for spending</b> and therefore no money remains at the time of the betrothal, whereas <b>these</b> dinars <b>were given to her</b> from the outset <b>for the purpose of betrothal.</b>
The Gemara asks: If <b>another did not come and betroth her, and she retracted her</b> consent to the betrothal within thirty days, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: She can retract</b> her consent. Why? This <b>statement,</b> by which she changes her mind, <b>comes and nullifies</b> her previous <b>statement</b> when she agreed to the betrothal. <b>Reish Lakish said: She cannot retract</b> her consent, as her second <b>statement does not come and nullify</b> her previous <b>statement.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish</b> from a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 3:4): In a case where someone appointed an agent to separate <i>teruma</i> from his produce on his behalf, and he subsequently <b>canceled</b> the agency, the <i>halakha</i> depends on the following: <b>If he canceled</b> the appointment <b>before</b> the agent <b>separated the <i>teruma</i>, his <i>teruma</i> is not <i>teruma</i>. And here it is</b> a case involving one <b>statement and</b> a second <b>statement,</b> as the owner of the produce appointed the agent and rescinded his appointment by speech. This shows that <b>a statement comes and nullifies</b> a previous <b>statement.</b> Reish Lakish replied: <b>Giving money to a woman is different, as it is considered like an action, and</b> a mere <b>statement does not come and nullify</b> the <b>action</b> of the transfer of money.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>raised</b> a further <b>objection</b> to Reish Lakish: With regard to <b>one who sends a bill of divorce to his wife, and</b> later the husband <b>encountered the agent or sent</b> another <b>agent after him and</b> in this manner <b>said to him: The bill of divorce that I gave you is nullified, it is thereby nullified. And giving a bill of divorce to an agent is considered</b> to be <b>like giving money to a woman, and</b> yet this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>it is nullified,</b> which indicates that speech can override even an action.
Reish Lakish answered: <b>There too, as long as the bill of divorce has not reached the woman’s hand it is</b> considered a case of one <b>statement and</b> a second <b>statement.</b> There is no halakhic significance to the transmitting of a bill of divorce to an agent, as only its delivery to the wife is considered an action.
