The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between the first <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna <b>and Rabbi Yosei,</b> as they appear to be saying the same thing? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The practical difference <b>between them</b> concerns a Jewish woman who engaged in intercourse with <b>a second</b>-generation <b>Egyptian.</b> The Torah prohibits Egyptian converts and their children from entering into the congregation by marriage, but the grandchildren of the Egyptian convert, i.e., the third generation, are permitted to marry Jews with unflawed lineage. <b>And both of them learned</b> their respective opinions <b>only from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a High Priest</b> who engaged in intercourse <b>with a widow,</b> although they derived the <i>halakha</i> in different ways.
How so? As <b>the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that this case is <b>like</b> that of <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in sexual intercourse <b>with a widow: Just as</b> with regard to <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse <b>with a widow, his</b> act of <b>intercourse</b> with her is performed <b>by</b> means of <b>a transgression and he disqualifies her</b> from marrying into the priesthood, <b>so too anyone whose</b> act of <b>intercourse</b> is <b>by</b> means of <b>a transgression,</b> such as a second-generation Egyptian who engages in intercourse with a Jewish woman, likewise <b>disqualifies her</b> from marrying into the priesthood.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that the derivation is as follows: It is <b>like a High Priest</b> who engages in sexual intercourse <b>with a widow: Just as</b> with regard to <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse <b>with a widow, whose offspring is unfit</b> for the priesthood, as they have the status of a <i>ḥalal</i>, <b>and he</b> similarly <b>disqualifies</b> her from marrying a priest by engaging in intercourse with her, <b>so too, anyone whose offspring is unfit</b> for the priesthood also <b>disqualifies</b> her from marrying a priest by engaging in intercourse with her. This comparison serves <b>to exclude a second</b>-generation <b>Egyptian, whose offspring is not unfit, as the verse states: “The children of the third generation that are born to them may enter into the congregation of the Lord”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:9). Therefore, a second-generation Egyptian does not disqualify a woman with whom he engages in intercourse from marrying a priest.
The <i>baraita</i> also taught that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Anyone whose daughter you may marry, you may marry his widow. And anyone whose daughter you may not marry, you may not marry his widow</b> either. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel?</b> They seem to be stating the same <i>halakha</i>. <b>Ulla said: The</b> difference <b>between them</b> involves a male <b>Ammonite</b> convert <b>and</b> a male <b>Moabite convert.</b> According to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, male Ammonite and Moabite converts disqualify a woman with whom they engage in sexual intercourse from marrying a priest, whereas Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says they do not disqualify her. <b>And both of them learned</b> their respective opinions <b>only from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a High Priest</b> who engaged in intercourse <b>with a widow,</b> although they derived the <i>halakha</i> in different ways.
How so? <b>As Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that this case is <b>like</b> that of <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse <b>with a widow: Just as</b> with regard to <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in sexual intercourse <b>with a widow,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that his offspring are unfit</b> for the priesthood, as they have the status of a <i>ḥalal</i>, <b>and he</b> similarly <b>disqualifies</b> her from marrying a priest by engaging in intercourse with her, <b>so too, anyone whose offspring is unfit</b> for the priesthood, including a male Ammonite or Moabite convert, also <b>disqualifies</b> her from marrying a priest by engaging in intercourse with her.
<b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> holds that the derivation is as follows: It is <b>like a High Priest</b> who engages in sexual intercourse <b>with a widow. Just as</b> with regard to <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse <b>with a widow, as all his offspring are unfit,</b> the females as well as the males, and he disqualifies her by engaging in intercourse with her, <b>so too, everyone</b> about whom the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that all his offspring are unfit, even</b> the <b>females,</b> disqualifies a woman with whom he engages in intercourse from marrying a priest. This comparison serves <b>to exclude</b> a male <b>Ammonite or Moabite convert, as</b> the <b>females</b> born to them <b>are fit to enter into the congregation. As the Master said: An Ammonite man</b> is prohibited from entering into the congregation, <b>but not an Ammonite woman;</b> similarly <b>a Moabite man</b> is prohibited from doing so, <b>but not a Moabite woman.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda says: All concede with regard to a widow of questionable lineage,</b> i.e., a widow whose husband was possibly a <i>ḥalal</i>, <b>that she is unfit to</b> marry into the <b>priesthood.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Who is the</b> most <b>lenient of these <i>tanna’im</i>?</b> It is <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and he says: Anyone whose daughter you may marry, you may marry his widow; and anyone whose daughter you may not marry, you may not marry his widow</b> either. He said the latter clause <b>to exclude what?</b> It is <b>to exclude a widow of questionable lineage;</b> and it teaches <b>that she is unfit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood,</b> since the daughter of one who was possibly a <i>ḥalal</i> is prohibited from marrying a priest.
The Gemara comments: This statement of Rav Ḥisda serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>these</b> following <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 8:3): <b>Rabbi Yehoshua and Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira testified with regard to a widow of questionable lineage, that she is fit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood. What is the reason</b> for this lenient ruling? <b>It is</b> a case of <b>a compound uncertainty, and</b> the principle is that in a case of <b>a compound uncertainty</b> the ruling <b>is to be lenient.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that according to Rabbi Eliezer, it is <b>permitted</b> for <b>those</b> with <b>definite</b> flaws to marry <b>with those</b> with <b>definite</b> flaws. For example, it is permitted for <i>mamzerim</i> and Gibeonites to marry each other. By contrast, it is prohibited for those with definite flaws to marry with those whose flaws result from an uncertainty, and it is also prohibited for those whose flaws result from an uncertainty to marry those whose flaws result from an uncertainty. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b> Rav Yehuda added: <b>When I said that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in front of Shmuel, he said to me: Hillel</b> the Elder <b>teaches</b> the mishna as stating: Jews with <b>ten</b> types of <b>lineage ascended from Babylonia, and all of them,</b> i.e., all of those who may not enter into the congregation, even those whose flaws result from an uncertainty, <b>are permitted to marry</b> into <b>each other’s</b> families; <b>and you said</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer?</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And a contradiction can be raised</b> from this statement <b>of Rav against</b> another statement <b>of Rav, and</b> similarly <b>a contradiction can be raised from</b> this statement <b>of Shmuel against</b> another statement <b>of Shmuel. As, it was stated</b> that they had the following dispute: With regard to <b>a betrothed woman who became pregnant</b> during her period of betrothal, and it is unknown whether it was her betrothed or someone else who impregnated her, <b>Rav says</b> that <b>the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> The assumption is that she was impregnated by a different man and that the child is the offspring of a betrothed woman and a man other than her betrothed. <b>And Shmuel says</b> that <b>the offspring is a <i>shetuki</i>,</b> since there is no proof that it is a <i>mamzer</i>; she might have been impregnated by her betrothed.
The Gemara explains their respective opinions: <b>Rav says the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i> and is</b> therefore <b>permitted to</b> marry <b>a <i>mamzeret</i>; and Shmuel says the offspring is a <i>shetuki</i> and is prohibited to</b> marry <b>a <i>mamzeret</i>.</b> It is seen here that Shmuel prohibits one whose flaw results from an uncertainty from marrying one with definite <i>mamzer</i> status, whereas Rav permits such a person to marry one with definite <i>mamzer</i> status. This contradicts their earlier statements, in which Rav prohibited one whose flaw results from an uncertainty from marrying one with definite <i>mamzer</i> status and Shmuel permitted it. The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the opinions in this dispute, so that <b>Rav</b> is the one who <b>says: The offspring is a <i>shetuki</i></b> and is prohibited to marry a <i>mamzeret</i>; <b>and Shmuel says: The offspring is a <i>mamzer</i></b> and may marry a <i>mamzeret</i>.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>why do I</b> need <b>two</b> instances of the same dispute? The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to state the dispute twice, <b>because if it were stated</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> mishna, which discusses an unmarried woman whose offspring is a <i>shetuki</i>, one could have said: It was <b>with regard to that</b> case that <b>Rav states</b> his opinion, <b>because the majority are fit with regard to her</b> and only a minority of men are those who are forbidden to her as relatives or are those who are disqualified from entering into the congregation. <b>But there,</b> in the case of a betrothed woman who became pregnant, <b>where the majority are unfit with regard to her</b> and she is forbidden to everyone other than her betrothed, one might <b>say that</b> Rav <b>concedes to Shmuel</b> that her child is a definite <i>mamzer</i>.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if it was stated</b> only <b>in this</b> case of a betrothed woman, one could have said it was <b>with regard to this</b> case that <b>Rav states</b> the offspring is a <i>shetuki</i>, <b>because it is</b> most reasonable <b>to ascribe</b> the pregnancy <b>to the betrothed man,</b> which would mean that the offspring is not a <i>mamzer</i>, <b>but in that</b> case of an unmarried woman, one might <b>say that he agrees with Shmuel</b> that the child is considered to be a definite <i>mamzer</i>. It is therefore <b>necessary</b> to state both cases.
<b>And if you wish, say: Actually, do not reverse</b> the opinions, <b>and what</b> is the meaning of the term <b><i>mamzer</i> that Rav is saying?</b> It does <b>not</b> signify that this offspring is <b>permitted to</b> marry <b>a <i>mamzeret</i>, but</b> merely <b>that he is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>a Jewish woman. And</b> when <b>Shmuel says the offspring is a <i>shetuki</i>,</b> he meant that he is <b>prohibited from</b> marrying <b>a Jewish woman.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, that is</b> the same as <b>Rav. Rather, what</b> is the meaning of the term <b><i>shetuki</i></b> in Shmuel’s statement? It is <b>that one silences [<i>meshattekin</i>] him,</b> i.e., disqualifies him, <b>from the <i>halakha</i> of the priesthood.</b> In other words, even if the betrothed man was a priest, the child is not considered a priest.
The Gemara questions this: Isn’t this <b>obvious? Now,</b> if <b>one silences him from the <i>halakha</i> of a Jew</b> with unflawed lineage, and he is not allowed to enter into the congregation, <b>is it necessary</b> to say that he is silenced <b>from the <i>halakha</i> of the priesthood? Rather, what</b> is the meaning of <b><i>shetuki</i></b> in Shmuel’s statement? It is <b>that one silences him from his</b> presumed <b>father’s property,</b> i.e., he does not inherit from him. The Gemara again questions: This too <b>is obvious; do we know who his father is?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where</b> this son <b>seized</b> possession of the property of the betrothed man, claiming that the betrothed man is his father. It is with regard to such a scenario that Shmuel said that the property is taken away from him, and one does not say that the burden of proof rests upon the other inheritors to demonstrate conclusively that the betrothed man is not his father.
<b>And if you wish, say: What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>shetuki</i></b> in Shmuel’s statement? It means <b><i>beduki</i>,</b> meaning <b>that they examine his mother, and</b> if <b>she says: I engaged in sexual intercourse with</b> a man with <b>unflawed</b> lineage, <b>she is deemed credible.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>halakha</i>? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel?</b> But <b>didn’t Shmuel</b> already <b>say</b> it <b>once? As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ketubot</i> 13a): If an unmarried woman <b>was pregnant, and</b> people <b>said to her: What is the status of this fetus?</b> And she said to them: It is <b>from so</b>-<b>and</b>-<b>so, and he is a priest; Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Eliezer say:</b> She is <b>deemed credible; and Rabbi Yehoshua says: She is not deemed credible. And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel.</b> This shows that Shmuel had already issued an explicit ruling in Rabban Gamliel’s favor; why did he repeat himself?
The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> for Shmuel to rule twice. <b>As, if</b> he had learned it only <b>from there,</b> from the mishna discussing an unmarried pregnant woman, <b>I would say</b> he rules that way <b>there,</b> when <b>the majority are fit with regard to her,</b> as her unmarried status means that the offspring resulting from sexual intercourse with most men would be of unflawed lineage. <b>But here,</b> in the case of a betrothed woman, when <b>the majority</b> of men <b>are unfit with regard to her,</b> as she is forbidden to everyone other than her betrothed, <b>you</b> might <b>say</b> that she should <b>not</b> be deemed credible to say she engaged in intercourse with the betrothed man. It is therefore <b>necessary</b> for Shmuel to state his ruling twice.
§ <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 5:2): <b>And similarly Rabbi Elazar says: A Samaritan</b> man <b>may not marry a Samaritan woman.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> The Sages <b>established him</b> to be <b>like</b> the descendant of <b>a convert, after ten generations. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the descendant of <b>a convert,</b> he <b>is permitted to</b> marry <b>a <i>mamzeret</i></b> if he is <b>within ten generations</b> of both parents being descendants of converts; <b>from this</b> point <b>forward</b> the descendant of a convert <b>is prohibited from</b> marrying <b>a <i>mamzeret</i>,</b> as people no longer remember that he has the lineage of a convert.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And some say</b> that the descendant of a convert is permitted to marry a <i>mamzeret</i> <b>until the name of idol worship is forgotten from him,</b> i.e., as long as people remember that his roots are from gentiles he remains permitted to marry a <i>mamzeret</i>, regardless of the passage of time. Rav Yosef understands that Rabbi Elazar regards a Samaritan as being like a convert after ten generations, who may not marry a <i>mamzeret</i>. Since Samaritans assimilated among the Jewish people and are no longer recognized by the public as having Samaritan lineage, they may not marry those of flawed lineage, including, presumably, other Samaritans.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Is it comparable</b> to the case of a convert? <b>There,</b> he is <b>an old convert,</b> i.e., the conversion occurred a long time ago, <b>and she is a new <i>mamzeret</i>,</b> i.e., her status as a <i>mamzeret</i> is known. Consequently, people who see him marrying a <i>mamzeret</i> will <b>say:</b> A <b>Jewish man is marrying a <i>mamzeret</i>. Here, this and that,</b> the two Samaritans, <b>are the same as each other.</b> If people consider the Samaritan man as being assimilated among the Jewish people, and consequently he may not marry a woman of flawed lineage, the Samaritan woman should likewise be considered a Jew of unflawed lineage. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara rejects the previous explanation in favor of the following: <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said: Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b>

Daf 75b

<b>and Rabbi Yishmael holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> concerning a different <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara clarifies: <b>Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who says: Samaritans are lion converts,</b> i.e., they converted out of fear of being attacked by lions for worshipping idols in Eretz Yisrael. They were never converts for the sake of Heaven, but remained gentiles according to <i>halakha</i>. <b>And Rabbi Yishmael holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says:</b> In the case of <b>a gentile or</b> a Canaanite <b>slave who engaged in sexual intercourse with a Jewish woman, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> Since over the generations Jews assimilated with Samaritans, who have the status of gentiles, the descendants of those Jews who married Samaritans have the status of uncertain <i>mamzerim</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Yishmael hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> in this matter? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: From where</b> is it derived with regard to <b>a gentile or</b> a Canaanite <b>slave who engaged in sexual intercourse with the daughter of a priest, or</b> with <b>the daughter of a Levite, or</b> with <b>the daughter of an Israelite, that they have disqualified her</b> from marrying a priest? It is <b>as it is stated: “But if a priest’s daughter is a widow, or divorced, and has no child,</b> and is returned to her father’s house, as in her youth, she may eat of her father’s bread” (Leviticus 22:13).
He explains: It is only if she was married to <b>one who has</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>widowhood and divorce,</b> meaning a Jew, that she can return to her father’s house and partake of <i>teruma</i>. This serves to <b>exclude a gentile or</b> a Canaanite <b>slave, who do not have</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>widowhood and divorce;</b> if the daughter of a priest engages in intercourse with such a man, she may no longer partake of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And if it enters your mind</b> that Rabbi Yishmael <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> that the offspring of a Jewish woman and a gentile or a slave is a <i>mamzer</i>, what need is there for this proof? <b>Now</b> that he holds that the offspring from a gentile <b>is a <i>mamzer</i>, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state <b>that</b> the gentile or slave <b>disqualifies</b> her from marrying a priest <b>by engaging in intercourse</b> with her?
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains as follows: <b>Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who says: Samaritans are lion converts, and</b> Rabbi Elazar himself also <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says:</b> If <b>a gentile or</b> a Canaanite <b>slave engaged in sexual intercourse with a Jewish woman, the offspring is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Elazar hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva? But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar say: Although Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagreed with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>rival wives,</b> as to whether the rival wife of a <i>yevama</i> who is a forbidden relative of the <i>yavam</i> is obligated in or exempt from levirate marriage, they <b>concede that a <i>mamzer</i> is only</b> the offspring born <b>from one whose prohibition is a prohibition of forbidden relatives and punishable by <i>karet</i>.</b> Since engaging in intercourse with a gentile or a Canaanite slave is not punishable by <i>karet</i>, Rabbi Elazar would agree that the child of such a union is not a <i>mamzer</i>.
<b>Rather, when Rabin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he reported that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda</b> who <b>says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi</b> who <b>says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> There are <b>three divisions</b> of opinions <b>with regard to the matter.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael holds</b> that <b>Samaritans are lion converts, and the priests who assimilated among them were unfit priests, as it is stated: “And made unto them from among themselves priests of the high places”</b> (II Kings 17:32). <b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> What is the meaning of “from among themselves”? <b>From the thorns that are among the</b> Jewish <b>people,</b> meaning those of flawed lineage. <b>And</b> it was <b>due to that</b> reason that the Sages <b>disqualified them,</b> not due to the Samaritans themselves, who are gentiles, but due to the Jews of flawed lineage who are assimilated among them. When a Samaritan seeks to marry another Samaritan, it is possible that one of them is a Jew of flawed lineage.
<b>And Rabbi Akiva holds: Samaritans are true converts, and the priests who assimilated among them were fit priests, as it is stated: “And made unto them from among themselves priests of the high places”</b> (II Kings 17:32). <b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> “From among themselves” means <b>from the chosen ones,</b> the upper echelon <b>of the</b> Jewish <b>people. And for what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>prohibit them</b> from entering into the congregation if there is no problem with regard to their conversion or with regard to the Jews who assimilated among them? It is <b>because</b> they did not act in accordance with the <i>halakha</i>, as <b>they would perform levirate marriage with betrothed women.</b> They would perform the mitzva of levirate marriage only with one who was widowed from a betrothal,

Daf 76a

<b>and</b> they would <b>exempt married women</b> from <i>ḥalitza</i> and levirate marriage. The Gemara elaborates: In <b>what</b> way would they <b>expound</b> the verse to lead them to this conclusion? The verse states: <b>“The wife of the dead man shall not be married outside of the family to one not of his kin;</b> her brother-in-law will have intercourse with her and take her to him to be his wife, and consummate the levirate marriage” (Deuteronomy 25:5). They understood the word “outside” to be a description of the woman: <b>She who sits outside,</b> i.e., one who is only betrothed; <b>she shall not be married to one not of his kin,</b> and it is with her that the obligation of levirate marriage applies. <b>But she who is not sitting outside,</b> but who has already married, <b>shall marry one not of his kin.</b> Consequently, the concern with regard to the Samaritans is that their descendants include the children of a widow who unlawfully wed one who was not her brother-in-law.
After having explained which prohibition the Samaritans violated, the Gemara explains how this accounts for the prohibition with regard to marriage with Samaritans. <b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says:</b> The offspring of intercourse <b>for which</b> one <b>is liable</b> for violating <b>a prohibition is a <i>mamzer</i>.</b> Therefore, the descendants of a <i>yevama</i> who had transgressed the prohibition of: “The wife of the deceased shall not be married outside of the family to one not of his kin,” have the status of <i>mamzerim</i>.
<b>And some say</b> a third opinion as to why the Sages disqualified Samaritans for marriage: It is <b>because they are not well versed in the details of mitzvot.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the one indicated by the phrase: <b>Some say? Rav Idi bar Avin said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Pesaḥim</i> 2:2): <b>The <i>matza</i> of a Samaritan is permitted</b> to be eaten on Passover and is not considered to be leavened bread, <b>and a person can fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> on the first night <b>of Passover with it; but Rabbi Eliezer prohibits</b> it, <b>since</b> Samaritans <b>are not well versed in the details of mitzvot,</b> and there is concern that their <i>matza</i> might be leavened. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says</b> that this is not a concern, as with regard to <b>any mitzva that Samaritans embraced</b> and accepted, <b>they are more exacting in its</b> observance <b>than</b> are <b>Jews.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But here,</b> with regard to marriage, in <b>what</b> details are <b>they not well versed?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>because they are not well versed with regard to the laws of betrothal and divorce.</b> Consequently, it is possible that their bills of divorce were invalid, or that a betrothed woman was allowed to remarry without having received a bill of divorce, which would mean that her future children would be <i>mamzerim</i>.
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> Samaritans are of flawed lineage because <b>a <i>mamzer</i></b> resulting <b>from</b> intercourse between a man and <b>his sister and a <i>mamzer</i></b> resulting <b>from</b> intercourse between a man and his <b>brother’s wife were assimilated among them,</b> and they therefore all have the status of <i>mamzerim</i> due to the uncertainty as to the identity of those assimilated <i>mamzerim</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What is he teaching us</b> by providing the details of how they are <i>mamzerim</i> due to uncertainty? If he intended to incidentally teach us the <i>halakha</i> that the offspring from intercourse <b>for which</b> one <b>is liable to receive <i>karet</i> is a <i>mamzer</i>, let him teach one</b> example, by mentioning the example of a <i>mamzer</i> from a sister. The Gemara answers: He did not mention these details to teach us a <i>halakha</i>, but rather <b>the incident that took place, took place in this way,</b> and that is why the Samaritans were considered to be of flawed lineage.
<b>And Rava says:</b> A Canaanite <b>slave and</b> a Canaanite <b>maidservant were assimilated among them.</b> The Gemara asks: In these cases, <b>the prohibition</b> is <b>due to what?</b> It is <b>due to</b> a Canaanite <b>maidservant,</b> whose children are slaves. But if so, <b>let him teach one</b> example; why also mention a Canaanite slave, whose child resulting from intercourse with a Jewish woman is of unflawed lineage? The Gemara again answers: <b>The incident that took place, took place in this way.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A priest <b>who marries a woman</b> who is <b>the daughter of a priest must investigate with regard to her</b> background, i.e., he must check previous generations of her family tree from both the maternal and paternal sides, for <b>four mothers, which are eight.</b> How so? He investigates the lineage of <b>her mother, and the mother of her mother, and the mother of her mother’s father, and her mother,</b> i.e., the mother of her mother’s fathers’ mother. <b>And</b> he also investigates the lineage of <b>the mother of her father, and her mother,</b> i.e., the mother of her father’s mother, <b>and the mother of her father’s father, and her mother</b> i.e., the mother of her father’s father’s mother. If he seeks to marry <b>a Levite</b> woman <b>or an Israelite</b> woman, <b>he adds to these</b> an investigation of mothers of <b>one additional</b> generation.
With regard to these investigations, <b>one need not investigate from the altar and above.</b> If his ancestors included a priest who served at the altar, one checks no further, as the court would have investigated his lineage before allowing him to participate in the Temple service. <b>Nor</b> do they check <b>from the platform,</b> used by Levites for singing in the Temple, <b>and above, nor from the Sanhedrin and above,</b> since only one whose lineage has been examined and who was found to be fit can be appointed to the Sanhedrin. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>anyone whose ancestors held public posts, and</b> anyone whose ancestors were <b>charity collectors, may marry into the priesthood, and there is no need to investigate their</b> lineage, since no one of flawed lineage would be appointed to those positions.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> the descendants of <b>one who had signed</b> as <b>a witness in the old court [<i>ba’arki</i>] of Tzippori</b> do not need to have their lineage investigated. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus says: Even</b> the descendants of <b>one who was written</b> in <b>the army list [<i>be’isteratya</i>] of the</b> Jewish <b>king</b> do not need to have their lineage investigated.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is different about women</b> that <b>we investigate</b> their lineage, <b>and what is different about men</b> that <b>we do not investigate</b> their lineage? Why shouldn’t we also examine the lineage of a bride’s male ancestors for any possible flaw, as we do her female ancestors? The Gemara answers: <b>When women quarrel with each other, it is through</b> accusations of engaging in <b>forbidden sexual intercourse,</b> i.e., licentiousness, <b>that they quarrel. And if it is so that there is a matter</b> of a flaw with regard to the lineage of the woman in question, <b>it</b> would <b>not</b> generate <b>publicity.</b> By contrast, <b>when men quarrel with each other, it is through</b> accusations of flawed <b>lineage that they quarrel.</b> Therefore, <b>if it is so that there is a matter</b> of a flaw with regard to her father’s lineage, <b>it</b> would generate <b>publicity,</b> even if no investigation is conducted.
The Gemara inquires: <b>But she should also investigate his</b> lineage; why is only the lineage of the woman investigated? The Gemara comments: This <b>supports Rav, as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> It was <b>not prohibited</b> for <b>women</b> of <b>unflawed</b> lineage, i.e., daughters of priests, <b>to marry</b> men of <b>flawed</b> lineage, such as <i>ḥalalim</i>, converts, or emancipated slaves. Therefore, women are not required to investigate the lineage of potential husbands.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava taught</b> that one needs to investigate <b>four mothers who are twelve,</b> adding an additional two generations of mothers of each of the woman’s parents. <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: Four mothers who are sixteen.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Rav Adda bar Ahava,</b>

Daf 76b

<b>he interprets</b> his statement as referring <b>to a Levite</b> woman <b>or an Israelite woman,</b> about whom the mishna states that one must investigate one additional generation. Therefore, Rav Adda bar Ahava’s ruling accords with that of the mishna. <b>But</b> shall <b>we say the <i>baraita</i> disputes</b> the mishna? The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, what is</b> the meaning of the mishna’s phrase: <b>One additional?</b> It means <b>one pair,</b> i.e., two more mothers on each side.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: This</b> mishna presents <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir, but the Rabbis say: All families retain a presumptive status of fitness,</b> and do not require investigation. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> did Rav really say this? <b>But doesn’t Rav Ḥama bar Gurya say</b> that <b>Rav says: Our mishna</b> is referring only to a case <b>when an objection was registered about</b> the family concerning its lineage, but if no objection was registered, everyone agrees that the family retains its presumptive status of fitness. The Gemara answers: <b>The one who taught this</b> statement in the name of Rav <b>did not teach that</b> other statement.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that this discussion occurred as follows: <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: This</b> mishna presents <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir, but the Rabbis say: All families retain presumptive status of fitness. Rav Ḥama bar Gurya says</b> that <b>Rav says: When an objection is registered about</b> a family concerning its lineage, everyone agrees that <b>he must investigate it.</b> According to this version, there is no contradiction between these two complementary statements.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>one need not investigate from the altar and above.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the Sanhedrin <b>had not examined his</b> lineage <b>they would not have</b> allowed <b>him to ascend</b> to the altar and perform the sacrificial rites. The mishna further teaches: <b>Nor</b> must one investigate <b>from the platform and above.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>as the Master said</b> in his description of the Temple chambers (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Ḥagiga</i> 2:4): <b>For there</b> in the Hewn Chamber those of the <b>priesthood</b> with unflawed <b>lineage and the Levites of</b> unflawed <b>lineage sat</b> and examined the lineage of everyone who came to serve in the Temple.
The mishna also taught: <b>Nor</b> must one investigate <b>from the Sanhedrin and above. What is the reason</b> there is no need to investigate further? The Gemara answers: It is <b>as Rav Yosef taught</b> that <b>just as the court is clean in justice, so too, it is clean of any blemish,</b> i.e., it does not include anyone of flawed lineage. <b>Mareimar said: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived? It states: <b>“You are all fair, my love; and there is no blemish in you”</b> (Song of Songs 4:7).
The Gemara asks: But perhaps you should <b>say</b> that this is referring to <b>an actual blemish,</b> that one who has a physical blemish may not be appointed to the Sanhedrin. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> It is not necessary to derive the <i>halakha</i> that one who has a physical blemish may not be appointed to the Sanhedrin from this verse, as <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the transfer of the Divine Spirit from Moses to the Elders: <b>“That they may stand there with you”</b> (Numbers 11:16), and the phrase <b>“with you”</b> is explained to mean: <b>With similarity to you,</b> teaching that the members of the Sanhedrin must be whole in body like Moses.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>But perhaps</b> those who were with Moses had to be free of any blemish <b>due to</b> the <b>Divine Presence,</b> which rested upon them, but this is not a requirement for judges on the Sanhedrin. <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>the verse states: “So shall they make it easier for you and bear the burden with you”</b> (Exodus 18:22). The phrase “with you” is explained to mean: <b>With similarity to you,</b> i.e., without blemish. This verse is referring to the appointment of regular judges, upon whom the Divine Presence does not rest, and teaches that all members of the Sanhedrin must be whole in body. The verse from Song of Songs teaches that they must be of unflawed lineage as well.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Anyone whose ancestors held public posts</b> may marry into the priesthood without investigation. The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that we do not establish</b> officers and other public appointees <b>from</b> people with <b>flawed</b> lineage? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the following statement: <b>All are fit to judge</b> cases of <b>monetary law, but not all are fit to judge</b> cases of <b>capital law. And we discussed it: What does</b> the word: <b>All,</b> serve <b>to include? And Rav Yehuda says:</b> It serves <b>to include a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> that he may judge cases of monetary law. This indicates that even a <i>mamzer</i> may occupy a public position. <b>Abaye said:</b> The mishna is referring to public officials <b>in Jerusalem,</b> where they were particular that all their judges should be of unflawed lineage. <b>And Rav Shimon bar Zeira similarly taught in</b> the <i>baraita</i> of <b><i>Kiddushin</i> from</b> the <b>school of Levi:</b> It is referring to public officials <b>in Jerusalem.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> anyone whose ancestors were <b>charity collectors may marry</b> into the priesthood without investigation. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers: It is <b>due to</b> the fact that <b>they quarrel with people,</b> as <b>the Master said:</b> Those appointed to collect charity <b>may</b> forcibly <b>take collateral for charity</b> from those who have not fulfilled their obligations <b>even on the eve of Shabbat,</b> when people are preoccupied and rushed, leading to quarrels. <b>And if it is so that there is</b> a flaw in the lineage of the collector’s family, <b>it</b> would generate <b>publicity</b> through the quarrels that are an unavoidable aspect of his job.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava’s host was</b> the son of <b>a convert, and he and Rav Beivai were quarreling. One said: I</b> will <b>perform the service of the city,</b> i.e., I will be appointed to a position of authority, <b>and one said: I</b> will <b>perform the service of the city. They came before Rav Yosef</b> to decide between them. Rav Yosef <b>said to them: We learned: “You shall set him king over you,</b> whom the Lord your God shall choose; <b>one from among your brothers”</b> (Deuteronomy 17:15). The repetition of the verb “set” in the verse [<i>som tasim</i>] indicates: <b>All appointments that you appoint may be only from among your brothers.</b> Therefore, a convert may not serve in any official position.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>And</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply <b>even</b> if the <b>mother</b> of the person in question is born <b>Jewish?</b> In other words, does this apply to one whose father is a convert? Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> If <b>his mother is</b> born <b>Jewish,</b> the words: <b>“From among your brothers” are said about him. Therefore,</b> now that it has been determined that this person’s mother was born Jewish and that he is fit to serve a public role, <b>Rav Beivai, who is a great man</b> in Torah learning, <b>should oversee the matters of Heaven,</b> i.e., the public issues that involve the performance of mitzvot; <b>and the Master,</b> Rav Adda bar Ahava’s host, <b>should oversee the</b> other <b>matters of the city. Abaye said,</b> as a moral of the story: <b>Therefore,</b> if <b>one has a Torah scholar as a guest, let him host</b> a person <b>such as Rav Adda bar Ahava, who knows how to plead in his favor,</b> as it was the argument of Rav Adda bar Ahava that led to his host’s appointment.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Zeira would deal with</b> converts and assign them to positions of authority. Similarly, <b>Rabba bar Avuh would deal with them. In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they would not establish even an appointee over measurements from them,</b> as they extended the prohibition against appointing a convert as a king to include all positions of power. <b>In Neharde’a, they would not establish even an appointee over irrigation</b> of the city fields <b>from them.</b>
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> the descendants of <b>one who</b> had signed as a witness in the Old Court of Tzippori does not need to have their lineage investigated. The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers: In that city, they would first <b>examine</b> witnesses and only afterward <b>have them sign.</b> Consequently, anyone who signed as a witness in Tzippori must certainly have been of unflawed lineage.
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus</b> says: Even the descendants of one who was written in the army list of the Jewish king does not have their lineage investigated. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The reference is to one who was written <b>in</b> the list of <b>the military troops of the House of David,</b> who were all of pure lineage. <b>Rav Yosef said: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived? The phrase is: <b>“Reckoned by lineage for service in war”</b> (I Chronicles 7:40). The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> for this requirement that they be of unflawed lineage? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> It is <b>in order that their merit and the merit of their ancestors will help them</b> in battle.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there Zelek the Ammonite,</b> one of David’s warriors (II Samuel 23:37); <b>what, is it not</b> indicated <b>that</b> he was a convert who <b>came from Ammon?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> his name indicates only <b>that he dwelled in Ammon,</b> but he was born a Jew. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there Uriah the Hittite</b> (II Samuel 23:39); <b>what, is it not</b> indicated <b>that</b> he <b>came from Heth?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> his name indicates only <b>that he dwelled in Heth.</b>
The Gemara further asks: <b>But isn’t there Ittai the Gittite</b> (II Samuel 15:19)? <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>so too</b> his name indicates <b>that he dwelled in Gath</b> but was born a Jew, <b>but doesn’t Rav Naḥman say,</b> to explain how David could make use of the crown of the idol of Ammon in apparent violation of the prohibition against deriving benefit from idolatry: <b>Ittai the Gittite came and nullified its</b> status of an idol. The <i>halakha</i> is that only a gentile can nullify an idol, by doing something degrading to it. This indicates that Ittai the Gittite must have been a gentile.
The Gemara again questions the statement that all of the soldiers in David’s army were of unflawed lineage. <b>And further, Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: David had four hundred youths</b> in his camp, <b>all sons of beautiful women,</b> i.e., born to women captured in war, who were therefore gentiles, <b>all of</b> whom <b>had their hair cut</b> in the <b><i>komei</i></b> style <b>or</b> who <b>grew</b> their hair in <b>a gentile hairstyle [<i>belorit</i>]</b> on the back of their heads, <b>and all of them sat in gold carts [<i>bikroniyyot</i>] and would march at the head of troops</b> in David’s army; <b>and these very ones were the strong men of the House of David,</b> i.e., David would rely on their strength. This states that David’s army included men of flawed lineage. The Gemara answers: These four hundred youths did not fight in the battles, but rather <b>they would go forth</b> in front of the troops <b>in order to frighten everyone.</b>

Daf 77a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The daughter of a male <i>ḥalal</i> is unfit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood forever.</b> In other words, all daughters of male descendants of a <i>ḥalal</i> are prohibited from marrying priests, as they have the status of <i>ḥalalot</i>. If there was <b>an Israelite who married a <i>ḥalala</i>, his daughter is fit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood,</b> whereas if there was <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> who married a Jewish woman, his daughter is unfit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood. Rabbi Yehuda says: The daughter of a male convert is like the daughter of a male <i>ḥalal</i>,</b> and she is also prohibited from marrying into the priesthood.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> If there was <b>an Israelite who married a</b> female <b>convert, his daughter is fit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood, and</b> similarly if there was <b>a convert who married a Jewish woman, his daughter is fit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood. But</b> if there was a male <b>convert who married</b> a female <b>convert, his daughter is unfit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood.</b> With regard to <b>both converts and emancipated</b> Canaanite <b>slaves,</b> their daughters are unfit to marry into the priesthood <b>even up to ten generations.</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies to the offspring <b>until his mother is</b> born <b>Jewish. Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> if there was a male <b>convert who married</b> a female <b>convert, his daughter is fit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What</b> is the meaning of the statement that the daughter of a <i>ḥalal</i> is unfit <b>forever?</b> The Gemara explains: It is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> should be <b>just as it is in</b> the case of <b>an Egyptian</b> convert <b>and an Edomite</b> convert, and that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to an Egyptian and an Edomite, their descendants are permitted to enter into the congregation <b>after three generations, so too here,</b> the daughter of a descendant of a <i>ḥalal</i> should <b>also</b> be allowed to marry into the priesthood <b>after three generations.</b> The mishna therefore <b>teaches us</b> that this prohibition is permanent.
The mishna teaches that in the case of <b>an Israelite who married a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> his daughter is fit to marry into the priesthood. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon</b> that <b>it is stated here: “And he shall not profane his offspring among his people”</b> (Leviticus 21:15), <b>and it is stated there: “He shall not defile himself, being a chief man among his people”</b> (Leviticus 21:4): <b>Just as there</b> the prohibition against a priest contracting ritual impurity from a corpse applies to <b>males but not females; so too here,</b> with regard to the profanation of his offspring, where the term “among his people” is also employed, it is <b>males</b> who are rendered unfit and who render their daughters unfit to marry into the priesthood when they are <i>ḥalalim</i>, <b>but not females.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that profanation applies only to males, <b>the daughter of a High Priest</b> and a widow <b>should be permitted</b> to marry into the priesthood, and there should be no status of a <i>ḥalala</i>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Is it written</b> that <b>his son</b> is profaned? <b>It is written: “His offspring,”</b> which includes his daughter, as the verse reads: <b>“He shall not profane his offspring among his people.”</b> Nevertheless, the daughter of his <i>ḥalala</i> daughter, who is already the third generation, is permitted as a result of the verbal analogy.
The Gemara asks: If so, that the granddaughter is permitted as a result of the verbal analogy, <b>the daughter of his son should</b> also <b>be permitted.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is written: “He shall not profane his offspring,”</b> by which the Torah <b>links his offspring to him: Just as</b> for <b>him, his daughter is unfit; so too</b> for <b>his son,</b> the son of a High Priest, <b>his daughter is unfit.</b> The Gemara asks: In that case, <b>the daughter of his daughter</b> from an Israelite <b>should be prohibited,</b> just as his own daughter is unfit. The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that his daughter’s daughter is also unfit, <b>of what use is the verbal analogy</b> of: “He shall not defile himself, being a chief man among his people”? It must teach that his daughter’s daughter is fit.
§ The mishna teaches that if there was <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> who married a Jewish woman, his daughter is unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood. The Gemara questions this ruling: <b>Wasn’t this</b> already <b>taught in the first clause: The daughter of a male <i>ḥalal</i> is unfit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood forever?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since it taught</b> in <b>the first clause</b> about <b>an Israelite who married a <i>ḥalala</i>, it also taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> about <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> who married a Jewish woman,</b> to present the complete ruling.
The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dostai ben Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Dostai ben Yehuda says: Just as the sons of Israel</b> are <b>a ritual bath of purity for <i>ḥalalot</i>,</b> i.e., the daughter of a <i>ḥalala</i> who marries an Israelite does not transmit her status of a <i>ḥalala</i>, and their daughters may marry priests, <b>so the daughters of Israel are a ritual bath of purity for <i>ḥalalim</i>,</b> and their daughters may marry priests. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason of Rabbi Dostai, son of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states: “He shall not profane his offspring among his people”</b> (Leviticus 21:15), which teaches: <b>It is among one people that he profanes,</b> i.e., the offspring is a <i>ḥalal</i> only when he and his wife are both profaned, i.e., <i>ḥalalim</i>, but <b>among two peoples he does not profane.</b> If the mother is of a different people, i.e., not a <i>ḥalala</i>, the offspring is of unflawed lineage.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse states that a priest may not engage in intercourse with a woman who is forbidden to him, so that <b>“he shall not profane his offspring.” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>his offspring</b> resulting from a union with a woman forbidden to him is profaned, i.e., has the status of a <i>ḥalal</i>; <b>from where</b> do I derive that <b>she herself, i.e.,</b> the woman who engaged in forbidden intercourse with the priest, is also disqualified from marrying into the priesthood? <b>You</b> can <b>say</b> it is an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If his offspring, who did not commit a transgression, is profaned, is it not logical that she, who did commit a transgression, is</b> similarly <b>profaned?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>He,</b> the priest <b>himself, shall prove</b> otherwise, <b>as he committed a transgression but</b> he is <b>not profaned.</b> Although he may not serve in the Temple while he remains married to her, he regains his status of a fit priest once he divorces her. The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the priest? He is notable <b>in that</b> he is a male, <b>and in no case is</b> a male priest <b>profaned</b> by engaging in forbidden intercourse. Will <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to her,</b> a woman, <b>who is disqualified</b> from marrying a priest <b>in all cases?</b> For example, if she engages in intercourse with a man of flawed lineage, she assumes the status of a <i>zona</i> and is permanently disqualified from marrying into the priesthood.
<b>And if it is your wish to say</b> that this reasoning is faulty, there is a different proof: <b>The verse states: “He shall not profane his offspring,”</b> which means that the priest may not engage in intercourse with a woman who is forbidden to him so that someone <b>shall not become profaned.</b> The verse is referring to <b>this</b> woman <b>who was</b> at one time <b>fit and</b> then <b>became profaned.</b> In other words, the term profanation does not apply to his offspring, as they were never fit to begin with. Rather, it is referring to the woman with whom he engaged in intercourse, as, since she was initially fit to marry into the priesthood, she can be described as becoming profaned.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>If it is your wish to say</b> that this reasoning is faulty, in what way is it faulty? The Gemara explains the counterargument: <b>And if you would say</b> that the <i>a fortiori</i> argument <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about his offspring?</b> He is notable <b>in that he is formed through a transgression.</b> Since the woman was not formed through a transgression, one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to her from that of the offspring. The Gemara therefore continues that even if one were to state that counterargument, <b>the verse</b> nevertheless <b>states: “He shall not profane his offspring,”</b> which means that the priest may not engage in intercourse with a woman who is forbidden to him so that someone <b>shall not become profaned.</b> The verse is referring to <b>this</b> woman <b>who was</b> at one time <b>fit and</b> then <b>became profaned.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught: Who is a <i>ḥalala</i>?</b> The term is referring to <b>any</b> woman <b>born from</b> people of <b>flawed</b> lineage. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of people of <b>flawed</b> lineage? <b>If we say</b> it means she was born from someone <b>unfit for him,</b> i.e., a woman forbidden to this particular man due to a family relationship or for some other reason, <b>isn’t there</b> the case of one who <b>remarries his divorcée</b> after she had been married to someone else in the interim; she is <b>unfit for him, and</b> yet <b>her children are fit. As it is written</b> with regard to this case: <b>“That is an abomination”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:4), and this is interpreted to mean: <b>That</b> marriage <b>is an abomination, but the children of</b> that marriage <b>are not an abomination</b> and are entirely fit.
<b>Rav Yehuda says: This is</b> what the Sages are <b>saying: Who is a <i>ḥalala</i>?</b> The term is referring to <b>any</b> woman <b>born from one unfit for the priesthood.</b> The Gemara questions this: This implies that one who was <b>born, yes,</b> she is a <i>ḥalala</i>, but one who was <b>not born</b> from one unfit for the priesthood is <b>not</b> a <i>ḥalala</i>. <b>Aren’t there</b> the cases of <b>a widow, or a divorced woman,</b> or <b>a <i>zona</i></b> who engaged in intercourse with a priest? They were <b>not born</b> from one who was unfit for the priesthood, <b>and</b> yet such a woman <b>is a <i>ḥalala</i>.</b>
<b>Rabba said: This is</b> what the Sages are <b>saying: Who is the <i>ḥalala</i> mentioned that did not have a moment of fitness at all,</b> but was unfit from birth? She is <b>any</b> woman <b>born from one unfit for the priesthood.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the term: <b>Mentioned?</b> Where was she mentioned? <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avin said: This is</b> what the Sages are <b>saying: Who is the <i>ḥalala</i> whose</b> prohibition <b>is rooted in the words of</b> a verse in <b>the Torah, and it is not necessary to clarify</b> her prohibition further <b>by the words of the Sages?</b> She is <b>any</b> woman <b>born from one unfit for the priesthood.</b> With regard to such a woman the verse explicitly states: “He shall not profane his offspring.” By contrast, the <i>halakha</i> that a woman who engages in forbidden intercourse with a priest becomes a <i>ḥalala</i> is not explicit in the Torah, but is learned through an exposition of the Sages.
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> If a High Priest engages in sexual intercourse with <b>a widow, a widow, a widow, he is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes. Similarly, if a priest engages in intercourse with <b>a divorcée, a divorcée, a divorcée, he is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes.
If a High Priest engages in sexual intercourse with a woman who was <b>a widow, and</b> then was <b>a divorcée, and</b> then was <b>a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> and then was <b>a <i>zona</i>, when</b> the changes to her status occurred <b>in</b> that <b>order,</b> that she was first widowed, then remarried and was divorced, and subsequently engaged in intercourse with a priest, thereby becoming a <i>ḥalala</i>, and then she engaged in intercourse with a gentile or a forbidden relative, thereby becoming a <i>zona</i>, the High Priest <b>is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for each and every one</b> of these transgressions each time he engages in intercourse with her. By contrast, if she first <b>became a <i>zona</i></b> by engaging in intercourse with a gentile or a forbidden relative, <b>and</b> then <b>became a <i>ḥalala</i></b> by engaging in intercourse with a priest, <b>and</b> subsequently <b>she divorced,</b> remarried, <b>and was widowed,</b> a High Priest who now engages in intercourse with her <b>is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes.
The Gemara proceeds to clarify this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: If a High Priest engages in intercourse with <b>a widow, a widow, a widow, he is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances of this widow? If we say that he engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with three widows: <b>With Reuven’s widow, and with Shimon’s widow, and with Levi’s widow, why is he liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes?

Daf 77b

<b>Aren’t they separate bodies,</b> i.e., three different people? <b>Aren’t they labels [<i>shemot</i>]</b> of <b>separate [<i>muḥlakim</i>]</b> prohibitions, since each one is forbidden in her own right? It is therefore clear that he should receive lashes for each act.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps it means <b>that he engaged in three acts of intercourse with one widow.</b> The Gemara analyzes this possibility: <b>What are the circumstances? If they did not forewarn him</b> between each act, it <b>is obvious</b> that <b>he is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes, for one must be forewarned in order to be liable to receive lashes, and here he was forewarned only once for the three acts. There would be no need to state this <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the case is <b>that they forewarned him for each and every one</b> of his acts of intercourse. But if that were the case, <b>why is he liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 42a): <b>A nazirite who was drinking wine</b> in violation of his naziriteship <b>the entire day is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes. If <b>they said to him: Do not drink, do not drink,</b> i.e., he was forewarned several times, <b>and he</b> nevertheless <b>drinks, he is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for each and every</b> time he was forewarned and proceeded to drink.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> for a case <b>where he engaged in sexual intercourse</b> one time <b>with Reuven’s widow, who was</b> previously <b>Shimon’s widow, who was</b> previously <b>Levi’s widow. Lest you say</b> they are <b>separate labels</b> of prohibitions and he should be liable to receive three sets of lashes, since she was widowed from three different people, the <i>baraita</i> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that <b>we require separate bodies</b> for him to receive separate punishments, <b>and</b> as that is <b>not</b> the case here, he is liable to receive only one set of lashes.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that if a High Priest engages in sexual intercourse with a woman who was <b>a widow, and</b> then was <b>a divorcée, and</b> then was <b>a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> and then was <b>a <i>zona</i>,</b> if the changes to her status occurred in that order he is liable to receive lashes for each of them. The Gemara asks: <b>What does this <i>tanna</i> hold? If he holds</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, i.e., if an item or a person is rendered forbidden by a prohibition then another prohibition can take effect in addition to the first one, <b>the reverse</b> should <b>also</b> be the case, i.e., if she was initially a <i>zona</i> and subsequently became a <i>ḥalala</i>, the same two prohibitions should apply to her. <b>And if he holds</b> that <b>a prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, he should <b>likewise not</b> be liable to receive more than one set of lashes <b>even</b> if they occurred <b>in this order.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> In general, <b>this <i>tanna</i> does not</b> accept the principle that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where <b>another prohibition</b> already exists, but <b>he holds</b> that it does take effect in the case of <b>an expanded prohibition.</b> If the second prohibition adds people to the category of those to whom the item is forbidden, then it takes effect in addition to the previous prohibition, which had a more limited range.
In this case, <b>a widow is forbidden to a High Priest but is permitted to a common priest.</b> Once <b>she becomes a divorcée, since a prohibition has been added to her with regard to a common priest,</b> as a common priest is prohibited from marrying a divorcée, the <b>prohibition is</b> also <b>added to her with regard to a High Priest. And</b> at this stage, <b>she is still permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i></b> if she is the daughter of a priest. When <b>she becomes a <i>ḥalala</i></b> by engaging in sexual intercourse with a priest, <b>since a prohibition</b> for her <b>to eat <i>teruma</i> has been added,</b> the <b>prohibition</b> with regard to a <i>ḥalala</i> <b>is</b> also <b>added with regard to a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse with her, in addition to the prohibitions of a widow and a divorcée. It is only if they occurred in this order that each prohibition adds to the previous one, but not if they happened in the reverse order.
Yet, one could ask: <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a <i>zona</i>, what expanded prohibition is there with regard to her?</b> There is no additional prohibition with a <i>zona</i> beyond what is prohibited with regard to a <i>ḥalala</i>. <b>Rav Ḥana bar Rav Ketina said: Since the label of <i>zenut</i> disqualifies</b> her <b>in Israel,</b> it is viewed as an expanded prohibition. Although a <i>zona</i> as precisely defined in this context, i.e., a woman who engages in sexual intercourse with one who is unfit for her, is prohibited only to priests and does not add any prohibition beyond that of a <i>ḥalala</i>, the label of a <i>zona</i> in its broader sense, such as a married woman who commits adultery, does disqualify her to an Israelite, namely her husband. Therefore, there is a prohibition with regard to a <i>zona</i> that has a greater scope than the prohibition with regard to a <i>ḥalala</i>.
<b>A <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Sheshet:</b> The command addressed to the High Priest states: “A widow, or one divorced, or a <i>ḥalala</i>, or a <i>zona</i>, these shall he not take; but a virgin of his own people shall he take to wife” (Leviticus 21:14). <b>Any</b> woman <b>who is</b> included <b>in</b> the mitzva: <b>“Shall he take” is</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>“Shall he not take”</b> if she becomes a widow or a divorcée. And <b>any</b> woman <b>who is not</b> included <b>in</b> the mitzva: <b>“Shall he take” is not</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>“Shall he not take.”</b> This <b>excludes</b> the case <b>of a High Priest who engaged in intercourse with his widowed sister.</b> As his sister, she is forbidden to him even when she is a virgin, so the mitzva: “Shall he take” does not refer to her. Therefore, he does not transgress the prohibition: “Shall he not take” if he engages in intercourse with her after she had been widowed or divorced.
Rav Sheshet <b>said to him:</b> He <b>who said</b> this <b>to you,</b> in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion did he teach it? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> as a principle: <b>A prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists. Therefore, his sister, who was already forbidden to him by virtue of being his sister, is not forbidden due to the additional prohibition: “Shall he not take.” <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: One who eats</b> an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass on Yom Kippur is exempt</b> from <i>karet</i> for eating on the fast day, since the prohibition against eating an animal carcass applied to it beforehand. <b>As, if</b> you say this <i>baraita</i> follows the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, don’t they say: A prohibition takes effect where another prohibition</b> already <b>exists?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as when the Rabbis say</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition</b> already <b>exists, that statement</b> applies only when the second prohibition is a more <b>severe prohibition,</b> e.g., eating on Yom Kippur, which takes effect in addition <b>to a light prohibition,</b> in this case, eating an unslaughtered animal carcass. <b>But a light prohibition does not take effect</b> in addition <b>to a severe prohibition.</b> In this case, the prohibition of engaging in intercourse with one’s sister, which is punishable by <i>karet</i>, is more severe than that of: “A widow or one divorced, or a <i>ḥalala</i>, or a <i>zona</i>, these shall he not take,” which is punishable by flogging.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rav Sheshet said to the <i>tanna</i> as follows: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say: A prohibition takes effect where another prohibition</b> already <b>exists. And when the Rabbis say</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition</b> already <b>exists, that statement</b> applies when the second prohibition is a more <b>severe prohibition,</b> which takes effect in addition <b>to a light prohibition, but a light prohibition does not take effect</b> in addition <b>to a severe prohibition. As, if</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, now</b> that he holds that even <b>a severe prohibition does not take effect</b> in addition <b>to a light prohibition, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that <b>a light prohibition does not take effect</b> in addition <b>to a severe prohibition?</b> There would be no novelty in this ruling of the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara rejects this: It is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>a prohibition</b> involving the <b>priesthood is different.</b> You might say that since there are many stringencies that apply only to priests, then with regard to prohibitions of the priesthood, a second prohibition should take effect in addition to a first one. He therefore <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Shimon holds that the second prohibition does not take effect even when it is one addressed to members of the priesthood.
§ <b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye:</b> In the case of <b>an Israelite who engages in intercourse with his sister,</b> this <b>makes her a <i>zona</i></b> and she is forbidden to a priest. But does <b>he</b> also <b>make her a <i>ḥalala</i></b> so that a priest who engages in intercourse with her is also liable for violating the prohibition of engaging in intercourse with a <i>ḥalala</i>, <b>or</b> perhaps <b>he does not make her</b> a <i>ḥalala</i>?
The two sides of the question are as follows: <b>Do we say</b> that this is <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If <b>she becomes a <i>ḥalala</i> by</b> engaging in sexual intercourse for which she <b>is liable</b> for violating only an ordinary <b>prohibition,</b> should she <b>not all the more so</b> be considered a <i>ḥalala</i> <b>by</b> engaging in intercourse for which she <b>is liable</b> to be punished by <b><i>karet</i>? Or perhaps</b> the status of <b><i>ḥalala</i></b> results <b>only</b> from <b>a prohibition</b> addressed specifically to the <b>priesthood?</b> Abaye <b>said to him:</b> A prohibition with regard to <b>a <i>ḥalala</i></b> results <b>only</b> from <b>a prohibition</b> addressed specifically to the <b>priesthood</b> and from that <b>alone.</b>
<b>Rava says: From where is this matter that the Sages state,</b> that <b>a <i>ḥalala</i></b> results <b>only</b> from <b>a prohibition</b> addressed specifically to the <b>priesthood,</b> derived? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse need <b>not</b> explicitly <b>state</b> that <b>a divorcée</b> is forbidden <b>to a High Priest, and</b> one could <b>derive it by</b> means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a common priest. As I</b> can <b>state</b> the following argument: <b>Now</b> that a divorcée <b>is forbidden to a common priest, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that she is forbidden <b>to a High Priest?</b> But if it is not necessary to mention it, <b>why</b> is the prohibition with regard to a divorcée to a High Priest <b>stated?</b> It is in order to teach the following: <b>Just as</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a divorcée is distinct from</b> that of <b>a <i>zona</i> and a <i>ḥalala</i> in</b> the case of <b>a common priest,</b> as a divorcée is forbidden by a separate prohibition for which he is liable to be flogged, <b>so too,</b> the prohibition with regard to a divorcée is <b>distinct in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest,</b> and he will be liable to receive lashes for a separate prohibition if she was a <i>ḥalala</i> as well.
The Gemara questions this statement: This <b>is obvious; is</b> the status of a High Priest any <b>lower</b> than that of a common priest? Since this <i>halakha</i> applied to him when he was a common priest, it certainly applies to him when he becomes a High Priest. His restrictions as a priest are not lessened when he becomes a High Priest. <b>Rather,</b> teach as follows: <b>Just as</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a divorcée is distinct from</b> that of <b>a <i>zona</i> and a <i>ḥalala</i> in</b> the case of <b>a common priest,</b> since he is liable to receive lashes for each of the prohibitions, <b>so too, a widow is distinct from a divorcée, and a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> and <b>a <i>zona</i> in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest,</b> and he is liable to receive lashes for each prohibition, despite the fact that they are stated in the same verse (see Leviticus 21:14).
The <i>baraita</i> further asks: <b>Why is</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a <i>ḥalala</i> stated</b> with regard to a High Priest, as she is forbidden to him even when he is a common priest? This repetition serves to teach that <b>a <i>ḥalala</i></b> results <b>only from a prohibition</b> addressed specifically to the <b>priesthood. Why is</b> the prohibition with regard to <b>a <i>zona</i> stated</b> with regard to a High Priest, as she is forbidden to him even when he is a common priest? <b>It is stated here: “<i>Zona</i>”</b> (Leviticus 21:14), with regard to a High Priest, <b>and it is stated there: “<i>Zona</i>”</b> (Leviticus 21:7), with regard to a common priest. <b>Just as here,</b> in the case of a High Priest who engages in sexual intercourse with a <i>zona</i>, <b>his offspring are profaned,</b> in accordance with the verse: “And he shall not profane his offspring” (Leviticus 21:15), <b>so too there, in</b> the case of a common priest who engages in intercourse with a <i>zona</i>, <b>his offspring are profaned.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi says: Consequently, a priest who engages in intercourse with his sister</b>

Daf 78a

<b>renders her a <i>zona</i>,</b> as he was forbidden to her, but <b>he does not render her a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> since her status as a <i>zona</i> does not result from a prohibition specific to the priesthood, but due to the prohibition of a forbidden relative. If her brother, or any other priest, <b>again engaged in intercourse with her, he</b> thereby <b>makes her a <i>ḥalala</i>,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to a priest who engages in intercourse with a <i>zona</i>.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says: A High Priest</b> who engages in sexual intercourse <b>with a widow is flogged two</b> sets of lashes, <b>one</b> set <b>due to</b> transgressing the prohibition of: “A widow, or one divorced, or a <i>ḥalala</i>, or a <i>zona</i>, these <b>shall he not take”</b> (Leviticus 21:14), <b>and one</b> set <b>due to</b> transgressing the prohibition of: “And <b>he shall not profane”</b> (Leviticus 21:15), since he profanes the woman with whom he engages in intercourse. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him also be flogged</b> with a third set of lashes <b>due to</b> the complete phrase: <b>“He shall not profane his offspring,”</b> because the offspring resulting from that act of intercourse is a <i>ḥalal</i>. The Gemara answers: It is referring to a situation <b>where he did not complete his</b> act of sexual <b>intercourse.</b> Since this act does not lead to pregnancy, he is not flogged for profaning his offspring.
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> against Rav Yehuda’s statement from a mishna (<i>Makkot</i> 13a): A High Priest who engages in sexual intercourse with <b>a widow</b> who was previously <b>a divorcée is flogged due to two labels</b> of prohibitions. <b>What, is it not</b> stating that he is flogged due to <b>two labels and no more?</b> This indicates that he receives only one flogging for each prohibition, and not two as Rav Yehuda taught.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No;</b> it means due to <b>two labels for this,</b> i.e., he is flogged two sets of lashes for engaging in intercourse with a widow, one for transgressing: “Shall he not take,” and one for transgressing: “He shall not profane,” <b>and two labels for that,</b> i.e., engaging in intercourse with a divorcée.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of that same mishna: If a priest engages in sexual intercourse with <b>a divorcée</b> who was <b>also a <i>yevama</i> who performed <i>ḥalitza</i> [<i>ḥalutza</i>], he is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>due to only one</b> transgression, since a <i>ḥalutza</i> is not forbidden to a priest by Torah law. This is contrary to the opinion of Rav Yehuda, that he should receive two sets of lashes for engaging in intercourse with a divorcée. The Gemara answers: <b>This is</b> what the mishna <b>is saying: He is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>due to only one</b> act, that of engaging in intercourse with a divorcée, <b>but actually</b> he is liable to receive two sets of lashes for his act of intercourse with a divorcée, since she is forbidden due to <b>two labels.</b> He does not receive an additional set of lashes on account of her being a <i>ḥalutza</i>, as this prohibition is by rabbinic law.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is <b>a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> forbidden to a priest only <b>by rabbinic law? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It states in the Torah that a priest may not marry <b>a divorcée. I have</b> derived <b>only a divorcée; from where</b> do I derive that <b>a <i>ḥalutza</i></b> is also forbidden? <b>The verse states: “And a woman</b> divorced” (Leviticus 21:7), with the additional conjunction of “and” serving to include a <i>ḥalutza</i>, that she is also considered to be a type of divorced woman. The Gemara rejects this: Even so, this prohibition is only <b>by rabbinic law, and the verse is a mere support,</b> but it is not the true source of the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Abaye says:</b> A priest who <b>betrothed</b> a woman forbidden to him <b>is flogged;</b> if he <b>engaged in sexual intercourse</b> with her he <b>is flogged</b> additional lashes. The Gemara clarifies this: If he <b>betrothed,</b> he <b>is flogged due to</b> transgressing the prohibition of: <b>“Shall he not take.”</b> If he also <b>engaged in intercourse,</b> he <b>is flogged due to</b> transgressing the prohibition of: <b>“He shall not profane.” Rava says:</b> If he <b>engaged in intercourse</b> he <b>is flogged;</b> if he <b>did not engage in intercourse, he is not flogged</b> at all, <b>because it is written: “Shall he not take…and he shall not profane,”</b> which Rava understands to mean: <b>For what reason</b> is he commanded <b>not to take?</b> It is <b>so that he not profane.</b> Rava holds that he is not liable for taking, i.e., betrothing, the woman, but only for engaging in intercourse with her, as this leads to profanation.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> although <b>Abaye</b> holds that the act of betrothal itself is forbidden, he <b>concedes in</b> the case of an Israelite who <b>remarries his divorcée</b> after she had been married to someone else in the interim, <b>that if he betrothed</b> her <b>without engaging in intercourse, he is not flogged.</b> Why not? It is as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah with regard to this prohibition: <b>“Take her again to be his wife”</b> (Deuteronomy 24:4), which indicates that the act of betrothal is forbidden only if it leads to the intimacy of marriage, <b>and</b> there is <b>no</b> such intimacy here since he has not engaged in intercourse with her.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>Rava concedes in</b> the case of <b>a High Priest with a widow, that if he engaged in sexual intercourse without betrothing</b> her, <b>he is flogged</b> for the act of intercourse, as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“And he shall not profane his offspring among his people”</b> (Leviticus 21:15), <b>and he has profaned</b> her with his act of intercourse. <b>And they both concede in</b> the case of the prohibition with regard to <b>one who remarries his divorcée that if he engaged in intercourse</b> with her <b>without betrothing</b> her <b>he is not flogged,</b> because <b>the Torah forbade</b> them to reestablish their union only <b>through the manner of taking,</b> i.e., betrothal, but it did not prohibit the act of intercourse on its own.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The daughter of a male convert is like the daughter of</b> a male <b><i>ḥalal</i>,</b> and is prohibited from marrying into the priesthood. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The daughter of a male convert is like the daughter of a male <i>ḥalal</i>,</b> and is prohibited from marrying into the priesthood. <b>And logic dictates</b> that this is so: <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>a <i>ḥalal</i>, who comes from a fit drop</b> of semen, as both his parents are Jewish, <b>his daughter is</b> nevertheless <b>unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood, in the case of <b>a convert, who comes from an unfit drop,</b> as he was born a gentile, <b>is it not logical that his daughter should be unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood?
The Gemara counters this derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a <i>ḥalal</i>?</b> He is notable <b>in that he is formed through a transgression,</b> whereas the gentile parents of a convert were permitted to engage in sexual intercourse with each other. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> of the daughter of a <i>ḥalal</i> might be more stringent than the <i>halakha</i> of the daughter of a convert. The Gemara responds: The case of <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse <b>with a widow shall prove</b> that this aspect is not germane to the fitness of the offspring, <b>since the formation of</b> the High Priest <b>was not through a transgression, and</b> yet <b>his daughter is unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood, indicating that being formed through a transgression does not play a role in this matter.
The Gemara counters again: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a High Priest</b> who engages in intercourse <b>with a widow?</b> He is notable <b>in that his</b> act of <b>intercourse is a transgression.</b> This aspect is what leads to the stringent <i>halakha</i> that his daughter is unfit to marry into the priesthood. The Gemara responds: The case of <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> will prove</b> that this aspect is not germane to the fitness of the offspring, as his daughter is unfit despite the fact that his act of intercourse does not involve a transgression.
