<b>And the derivation has reverted</b> to its starting point. <b>The aspect of this</b> person, a <i>ḥalal</i>, <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> person, a High Priest, as with regard to each of them there is a unique reason for the <i>halakha</i> to be stringent. Despite this, <b>their common denominator is that they are unlike most of the congregation,</b> in that they both differ from Jews of unflawed lineage, either because their formation or their act of sexual intercourse involved a transgression, and their daughters are therefore unfit to marry into the priesthood. <b>I will also bring</b> the case of <b>the convert, who is unlike most of the congregation, and</b> therefore <b>his daughter is</b> also <b>unfit to marry</b> into the priesthood.
This is rejected: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common denominator is that</b> the reason they are not like most of the congregation <b>includes an aspect of a transgression,</b> either with regard to their formation or to their act of intercourse. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> of the daughter of a convert cannot be derived from them.
The Gemara modifies the proof: <b>Do not say</b> that <b>a High Priest</b> who engages in sexual intercourse <b>with a widow will prove</b> it; <b>rather, say</b> that <b>a first</b>-generation male <b>Egyptian</b> convert who married a first-generation female Egyptian convert <b>will prove</b> it. Although their intercourse does not involve a transgression, their offspring are nevertheless unfit to marry into the priesthood, as Egyptians may enter into the congregation only after three generations.
This proof is also rejected: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a first</b>-generation <b>Egyptian?</b> He is notable <b>in that he is not fit to enter into the congregation</b> at all, and that is why his offspring may not marry into the priesthood. The Gemara responds that <b>a <i>ḥalal</i> will prove</b> that this aspect is not germane to the fitness of the offspring, since his daughter is unfit to marry into the priesthood although his offspring may enter into the congregation.
<b>And the derivation has reverted</b> to its starting point, as the <i>halakha</i> of the daughter of a convert cannot be derived from the case of the Egyptian alone or from the case of the <i>ḥalal</i> alone. <b>The aspect of this</b> person, an Egyptian convert, <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> person, a <i>ḥalal</i>, as with regard to each of them there is a unique reason for the <i>halakha</i> to be stringent. Despite this, <b>their common denominator is that they are unlike most of the congregation,</b> in that they both differ from Jews of unflawed lineage and their <b>daughters are</b> consequently <b>unfit</b> to marry into the priesthood. <b>I will also bring</b> the case of <b>the convert, who is unlike most of the congregation, and</b> therefore <b>his daughter is</b> also <b>unfit to marry</b> into the priesthood.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common denominator is that they disqualify</b> the daughter of a priest from marrying a priest <b>through their</b> act of <b>intercourse,</b> which is not the case with a convert. The Gemara explains: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> holds that <b>a convert also disqualifies</b> the daughter of a priest from marrying a priest <b>through his</b> act of <b>intercourse, and he derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the daughter of a convert is unfit to marry into the priesthood <b>by</b> means of an analogy derived from <b>the common factor</b> of two sources, i.e., <b>from this <i>halakha</i></b> of a <i>ḥalal</i> and of an Egyptian.
§ The mishna states that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says</b> that the daughter of <b>a convert</b> and a Jewish woman is fit to marry into the priesthood. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: A female</b> who <b>converts</b> at <b>less than three years and one day</b> old <b>is fit to</b> marry into <b>the priesthood, as it is stated</b> after the war with Midian: <b>“But all the female children</b> who have not known a man by lying with him, <b>keep alive for yourselves”</b> (Numbers 31:18), i.e., you may marry them. <b>But wasn’t Pinehas</b> the priest <b>with them,</b> and yet the Torah permitted these women to all of them, which indicates that girls who are not of age when they convert are permitted even to priests. <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that even a girl who converts at less than three years and one day old is unfit to marry into the priesthood, interpret this verse? In their opinion, <b>“keep alive for yourselves”</b> means <b>as slaves and as maidservants,</b> but not for marriage.
The Gemara comments: <b>And all of</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> who have a dispute with regard to the fitness of the daughter of a convert for marrying into the priesthood <b>expounded a single verse.</b> It states with regard to priests: <b>“Neither shall they take as their wives a widow, nor her that divorced; but they shall take virgins of the seed of the house of Israel”</b> (Ezekiel 44:22). <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds:</b> A priest may marry a woman <b>only if the entire seed is from</b> those born to <b>the Jewish people,</b> but not if one of the parents is a convert. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov holds: “Of the seed</b> of the house of Israel” indicates that not all of the seed must come from the house of Israel, <b>and even</b> if <b>part of the seed</b> is from the house of Israel, that is sufficient to allow her to marry a priest.
<b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that even the daughter of two converts is permitted to marry into the priesthood, <b>holds</b> that “of the seed of the house of Israel” means <b>one who was seeded,</b> i.e., conceived, <b>in Israel,</b> and the children of converts were conceived by Jewish parents. And <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai,</b> who permits a female who converted at less than three years and one day old to marry into the priesthood, <b>holds</b> that the phrase “virgins of the seed of the house of Israel” is referring to <b>one whose hymen was formed as a Jew,</b> i.e., a woman who was already Jewish when her hymen completed its formation, which occurs at the age of three.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to Rava:</b>

Daf 78b

Concerning <b>this verse</b> from Ezekiel, <b>the first clause</b> addresses a case <b>with a High Priest,</b> as it states that he may not marry a widow, <b>and the latter clause</b> addresses a case <b>with a common priest,</b> as it states that he may marry a widow. Is that a reasonable manner in which to interpret a verse? Rava <b>said to him: Yes,</b> that is the correct interpretation of the verse.
Rav Naḥman proceeded to ask: <b>But</b> can <b>a verse be written</b> in <b>this way,</b> addressing two different subjects without any demarcation? Rava <b>said to him: Yes,</b> and there is a similar case, <b>as it is written: “And the lamp of God was not yet gone out, and Samuel was laid down to sleep in the Temple of the Lord”</b> (I Samuel 3:3). If read literally, this verse is puzzling. It apparently states that Samuel was lying in the Sanctuary, <b>but there is</b> a right to <b>sit in the courtyard</b> of the Temple <b>only for the kings of the house of David alone.</b> How then could Samuel be laid down to sleep in the Temple? <b>Rather,</b> the verse should be understood as follows: <b>“And the lamp of God was not yet gone out” in the Temple of the Lord, “and Samuel was laid down” in his place</b> outside the Temple.
Since the Gemara quoted the verse in Ezekiel, it proceeds to discuss it further. The continuation of that verse states: <b>“And a widow who is the widow of a priest, they may take”</b> (Ezekiel 44:22). Does this mean that a priest may marry the widow <b>of a priest, yes,</b> but the widow <b>of an Israelite</b> he <b>may not</b> marry? This is counter to the <i>halakha</i> that allows a priest to marry any widow. Rather, <b>this is</b> what the verse <b>is saying:</b> “And a widow who is the widow, <b>of a priest they may take,”</b> meaning that <b>of the rest of the priests, they may take.</b> In other words, it is permitted for all other priests, i.e., common priests, to marry widows, and only the High Priest may not marry them. <b>That is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Of a priest they may take”</b> means <b>of the rest of the priests, they may take.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda states</b> a different explanation of the verse: A widow who is the widow <b>of one</b> whose daughters are <b>fit to marry into the priesthood, they may take.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> above, <b>as he says: The daughter of a male convert is like the daughter of a male <i>ḥalal</i>,</b> and he ruled that <b>anyone whose daughter you may marry, you may</b> likewise <b>marry his widow; anyone whose daughter you may not marry,</b> e.g., a male convert, <b>you may not marry his widow</b> either. The verse therefore states that a priest may marry the widow only of one whose daughter is permitted to marry into the priesthood.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> if there was a male <b>convert who married</b> a female <b>convert,</b> his daughter is fit to marry into the priesthood. <b>Rav Hamnuna says in the name of Ulla:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and similarly, Rabba bar bar Ḥana says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. And from the day the Temple was destroyed, the priests were accustomed</b> to act with <b>a higher standard for themselves, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov,</b> and they would marry the daughter of a convert only if one parent was born Jewish.
<b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> Rav <b>Huna said to me:</b> If a priest <b>comes to consult</b> with us as to whether or not he should marry the daughter of two converts, <b>we instruct him</b> not to, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.</b> But if <b>he married</b> her, <b>we do not remove her from him, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> follows his opinion, as stated above.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who says: This son of mine</b> is <b>a <i>mamzer</i>,</b> e.g., if he claims that the son was born to one forbidden to him by a prohibition that carries the punishment of <i>karet</i>, <b>he is not deemed credible</b> to render him a <i>mamzer</i>. <b>And even</b> if <b>both of them,</b> the father and the mother, <b>admit that a fetus in her womb is a <i>mamzer</i>, they are not deemed credible. Rabbi Yehuda says: They are deemed credible.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is</b> the added novelty indicated by the phrase: <b>And even</b> if <b>both of them?</b> What is taught there that is not stated in the clause that taught that a father is not deemed credible to state that his son is a <i>mamzer</i>? The Gemara answers: The <i>tanna</i> <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>his</b> claim, <b>when it is not clear to him,</b> i.e., a father can never be sure that a child is his. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is the same <b>even</b> with regard to <b>her, when it is clear</b> to her who the father is, and yet <b>she is</b> nevertheless <b>not deemed credible. And</b> additionally, <b>it is not necessary</b> to state <b>when</b> the child <b>has a presumption of unflawed</b> lineage, as he was assumed to be of unflawed lineage before his parents came to testify, <b>that they are not deemed credible. Rather, even</b> in the case of <b>a fetus, who does not have a presumption of unflawed</b> lineage, as he has no status with regard to lineage until he is born, the parents <b>are</b> likewise <b>not deemed credible.</b>
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: They are deemed credible.</b> This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Expounding the verse: <b>“He shall acknowledge</b> the firstborn” (Deuteronomy 21:17), the Sages said: <b>He,</b> the father, <b>shall acknowledge him to others.</b> In other words, he is deemed credible to tell others that this is his firstborn. <b>From here, Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>a person is deemed credible to say: This is my firstborn son. And just as a person is deemed credible to say: This is my firstborn son, so too, a person is deemed credible to say</b> about his son: <b>This is a son of a divorced woman, or: This is a son of a <i>ḥalutza</i>. And the Rabbis say:</b> As far as these latter claims are concerned, <b>he is not deemed credible.</b> He is deemed credible only to state which son is his firstborn.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: Granted,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yehuda, this is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “He shall acknowledge,”</b> as he derives from these words that a father is deemed credible to attest to the identity of his sons. <b>But</b> according <b>to the Rabbis</b> in the mishna, <b>why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“he shall acknowledge”?</b>
The Gemara answers: It is necessary for a case <b>when he requires identification,</b> if the identity of the firstborn is unknown. In such a situation the verse teaches that the father is deemed credible. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this relevant? Does it refer to the requirement: <b>“By giving him a double portion”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:17), i.e., that the firstborn receives a double share of the inheritance? <b>Isn’t</b> it <b>obvious</b> that he is deemed credible with regard to this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a verse</b> to teach this? His claim is supported by the fact that <b>he could have made a more advantageous claim [<i>miggo</i>]: If he desired to give him</b> a double portion as <b>a gift</b> while he was alive, <b>would</b> the court <b>not give it to him?</b> Since the father could have given a double portion to the firstborn without having to testify that he is his firstborn, it cannot be that the verse is teaching us that he is deemed credible with regard to the <i>halakha</i> that a firstborn receives a double portion of inheritance.
The Gemara answers: The verse is referring <b>to property that came</b> into his possession <b>at a later point,</b> which he was unable to give to his son at the time that he came to testify. The verse teaches that the son whom the father states is the firstborn will receive a double portion even of that property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Meir, who says</b> that <b>a person can transfer an entity that has not</b> yet <b>come into the world,</b> which would mean that a person can give away his property even before it enters his possession, <b>why do I</b> need the verse: <b>“He shall acknowledge”?</b> The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where property came into</b> the father’s possession <b>when he was moribund,</b> at which point he cannot transfer ownership of any of his property to others. It is with regard to such property that the verse states: “He shall acknowledge,” to teach that the son whom the father states is the firstborn will receive a double portion even of that property.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case of <b>one who authorized his agent to betroth his daughter</b> to a man that the agent would deem fit, <b>and</b> the father <b>went and betrothed her</b> to someone else, <b>if his</b> betrothal <b>preceded</b> that of the agent, <b>his betrothal is</b> a valid <b>betrothal; and if</b> the betrothal <b>of his agent preceded</b> his own, the <b>betrothal</b> of the agent <b>is</b> a valid <b>betrothal. And if it is not known</b> whose betrothal came first,

Daf 79a

<b>both</b> men who might have betrothed her <b>give</b> her <b>a bill of divorce</b> in order to render her permitted to marry someone else. <b>And if they wish</b> and agree between them, <b>one gives a bill of divorce and the other</b> marries her.
<b>And similarly,</b> with regard to <b>a woman who authorized her agent to betroth her and</b> she then <b>went and betrothed herself</b> to someone else, <b>if her</b> own betrothal <b>preceded</b> that of the agent, <b>her betrothal is</b> a valid <b>betrothal, and if</b> that <b>of her agent preceded</b> hers, the agent’s <b>betrothal is</b> a valid <b>betrothal. And if they do not know</b> whose betrothal came first, <b>both</b> men who may have betrothed her <b>give her a bill of divorce. And if they wish, one may give a bill of divorce and the other marries</b> her.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who betroths his daughter as well as with regard to a woman who betroths herself. <b>As had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to</b> the father <b>himself,</b> one might say <b>that</b> it is <b>because a man is expert with regard to lineage,</b> and his decision to betroth his daughter on his own after having appointed an agent must have been due to the superior lineage of the man that he found willing to marry her. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a woman, who is not expert with regard to lineage,</b> one might <b>say her betrothal should not be</b> considered a valid <b>betrothal,</b> as she still intends for her agent to be able to accept betrothal for her from a man with superior lineage.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to</b> the woman <b>herself,</b> one might say <b>that</b> it is <b>because a woman is particular</b> about whom <b>she marries,</b> i.e., she is careful when selecting a husband for herself. Therefore, she would have chosen the partner she deems most suitable and would not want the agent to act on her behalf after she had found someone on her own. <b>But</b> with regard to the father, one might <b>say</b> that <b>he does not care</b> to the same extent, and he may authorize the agent to act in any case. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to include both cases.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> discussed the following question: If <b>her father betrothed her on the way,</b> when he was traveling, <b>and</b> in the meantime she <b>betrothed herself in the city, and she is</b> now <b>a grown woman, Rav said: She is a grown woman at present,</b> and her father cannot currently betroth her. Therefore, even if he did betroth her at some point, his betrothal is assumed not to have taken effect. <b>And Shmuel said: We are concerned with regard to the betrothal of both of them.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the case: <b>When</b> did the father’s betrothal occur? <b>If we say</b> it occurred <b>during the six</b> months when the daughter was no longer a minor and had the status of a young woman, <b>in that</b> case would <b>Rav say: She is a grown woman at present?</b> It is reasonable to say that <b>it is</b> only <b>now</b> that <b>she has reached her majority,</b> i.e., assumed the status of a grown woman, and in that case her father’s betrothal should take effect, since a father can betroth his daughter when she is a young woman. Rav would not rule that the father’s betrothal is disregarded. <b>Rather,</b> perhaps it occurred <b>after</b> the <b>six</b> months had elapsed since she became a young woman. <b>In that</b> case would <b>Shmuel say: We are concerned with regard to the betrothal of both of them? But doesn’t Shmuel say: The difference between</b> the status of <b>a young woman and</b> the status of <b>a grown woman is six months alone,</b> after which the girl has the status of a grown woman, which means her father can no longer betroth her?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where he betrothed</b> her <b>on the day that</b> these <b>six</b> months <b>were completed. Rav said: She is a grown woman at present.</b> There is therefore a presumption <b>that since</b> she is <b>now a grown woman, she</b> was <b>also a grown woman</b> when her father betrothed her <b>in the morning. And Shmuel said:</b> Perhaps <b>it is</b> only <b>now that her signs</b> indicating puberty <b>came,</b> but she might have still been a young woman when her father betrothed her.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Shmuel,</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> the case of a <b>ritual bath? As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 2:2): With regard to <b>a ritual bath</b> that was known to have contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i> of water, <b>which was</b> then <b>measured and found deficient</b> in its quantity of water, what is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>All pure items whose</b> purification <b>had been performed in it,</b> i.e., any impure items that had been purified through immersion in this ritual bath, <b>retroactive</b> to when the ritual bath was last measured, <b>whether</b> this ritual bath is found <b>in the private domain or in the public domain, are impure.</b> This indicates that the current situation, i.e., the deficient ritual bath, is presumed to extend back until when it was known with certainty to have contained the requisite amount of water. In this case too, the woman should be considered a grown woman at the time of the first betrothal, and the second betrothal should not take effect.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of a ritual bath, it <b>is different, since it can be said: Maintain an impure</b> item <b>in its presumptive status and say</b> that <b>it was not</b> properly <b>immersed.</b> There, the presumptive status of the item being ritually impure is supported by the current state of the ritual bath, which is now deficient.
The Gemara continues to compare the two cases: <b>On the contrary,</b> it could be said: <b>Maintain the ritual bath in its presumptive status,</b> that it was known to have previously contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i>, <b>and say</b> that <b>it was not deficient</b> at the time of the immersion and that the items should be considered ritually pure. The Gemara answers: <b>There is a deficient</b> ritual bath <b>at present,</b> which counteracts the presumptive status that it contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Here too, there is a grown woman before you,</b> which should counteract the fact that she was previously a young woman. The Gemara answers: In this case, <b>it is</b> only <b>now</b> that <b>she has reached her majority.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>There too,</b> in the case of a ritual bath, one can also say <b>it is</b> only <b>now</b> that <b>it has become deficient.</b> Perhaps it contained the requisite forty <i>se’a</i> shortly beforehand.
The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> in the case of the ritual bath, there are <b>two</b> reasons <b>to weaken</b> the possibility that the items are ritually pure: First, there is a deficient ritual bath at present; second, the item has a presumptive status of impurity. <b>Here,</b> by contrast, there is only <b>one</b> reason <b>to weaken</b> the possibility that she was a young woman at the time of the betrothal, i.e., the fact that she is now a grown woman. Shmuel therefore maintains that her earlier status of young woman is not nullified, and both betrothals must be taken into account.
The Gemara poses another question: <b>And</b> according to <b>Shmuel,</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> the case of <b>a barrel? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 2:8): If <b>one would inspect</b> the contents of <b>a barrel</b> to see if it still contained enough wine <b>to continually</b> mentally <b>separate <i>teruma</i> from it</b> to exempt other untithed wine he had, until all the wine in that barrel would be <i>teruma</i> and would be given to a priest, <b>and afterward</b> the contents of the barrel <b>were found</b> to be <b>vinegar,</b> which cannot be set aside as <i>teruma</i> for untithed wine, then <b>all three days</b> after he had last inspected it is <b>definitely</b> viewed as having been wine, and any untithed wine for which <i>teruma</i> was separated during those days is tithed. <b>From then onward,</b> more than three days after the previous inspection, it is <b>uncertain</b> as to whether it had already turned to vinegar, and any untithed wine for which <i>teruma</i> was separated during those days is not tithed.
Before stating the difficulty with Shmuel’s opinion, the Gemara first clarifies the <i>baraita</i>. <b>And we raised a contradiction between</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>barrel</b> and that <b>of</b> the <b>ritual bath: What is different</b> in <b>that here,</b> with regard to the ritual bath, the <i>halakha</i> is that the items are <b>definitely</b> impure, <b>and what is different</b> in <b>that there,</b> with regard to the barrel, it is only <b>uncertain</b> whether the produce remains untithed? In both cases the situation at present, the ritual bath being deficient and the contents of the barrel having turned to vinegar, should lead to a definite conclusion.
The Gemara continues its analysis of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And Rav Ḥanina from Syria says: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> that <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>barrel? It is Rabbi Shimon, who with regard to a ritual bath also considers</b> it <b>as</b> a matter of <b>uncertainty</b> rather than as definitively impure. Therefore, there is no contradiction between the <i>baraita</i> and the mishna.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All pure items whose</b> purification <b>had been performed in it,</b> i.e., any impure items that had been purified through immersion in the ritual bath that was found to be deficient, <b>retroactive</b> to when the ritual bath was last measured, <b>whether</b> this ritual bath is found <b>in the private domain or in the public domain, are impure. And Rabbi Shimon says</b> they are impure due to the uncertainty, and therefore, if the ritual bath was located <b>in the public domain, they are pure,</b> in accordance with the principle that uncertain cases of impurity in the public domain are deemed pure. But if the ritual bath was located <b>in the private domain,</b> the decision <b>is suspended,</b> i.e., if the impure items came into contact with <i>teruma</i>, one may not partake of the <i>teruma</i> due to the uncertainty, but it is also not burned as though it were definitely impure.
The Gemara returns to complete the difficulty with Shmuel’s opinion: <b>But</b> according <b>to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that in the case of the ritual bath the items are definitely impure, with regard to the wine that had been exempted from <i>teruma</i> by means of separating <i>teruma</i> from the contents of the barrel, that wine will be <b>untithed produce retroactively,</b> since they hold that the current status extends to the past. This is unlike the ruling of Shmuel, who ruled that in the case of the woman who was betrothed to two men it is uncertain to whom she is betrothed. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of the barrel, <b>it is different, as it can be said: Maintain the untithed produce in its presumptive status,</b> as when it first grew it was definitely untithed, <b>and say</b> it was <b>not fixed,</b> i.e., exempted.
The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary,</b> why not <b>maintain the wine in its presumptive status, and say it had not turned to vinegar?</b> The Gemara rejects this: That is impossible, as <b>it is turned to vinegar at present.</b> The Gemara replies: In the case of the betrothal, <b>here too, she is a grown woman at present;</b> what is the difference? The Gemara rejects this claim: With regard to the woman, <b>it is</b> possible that only <b>now has she reached her majority.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>Here too,</b> it could be that <b>it is</b> only <b>now</b> that <b>it has turned to vinegar,</b> but not earlier.
The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> in the case of the barrel, there are <b>two</b> reasons <b>to weaken</b> the possibility that the wine is tithed: First, it is vinegar at present; second, the wine has a presumptive status of being untithed. <b>Here,</b> by contrast, <b>there is</b> only <b>one</b> reason <b>to weaken</b> the possibility that she was a young woman at the time of the betrothal, i.e., the fact that she is now a grown woman. Shmuel therefore maintains that her earlier status of a young woman is not nullified, and both betrothals must be taken into account.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that it is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>:</b>

Daf 79b

The <i>halakha</i> is that a moribund person who transfers all of his property to others without leaving anything for himself can retract his bequest upon regaining his health. This is due to the assumption that one would give away all his possessions only if he believes he is going to die, and the bequest was therefore made in error. By contrast, if a healthy person gave all his property to others, he cannot later retract his bequest. The <i>tanna’im</i> discuss the case of one who gave away all his property and later, seeking to retrieve his property, claims that he was moribund at the time, while the recipients of the bequest maintain that he was healthy. <b>Who</b> is able to <b>remove</b> the property <b>from the possession of whom?</b>
<b>He</b> is able to <b>remove</b> his property held by others <b>from their possession without</b> needing to bring <b>proof</b> that he was moribund at the time, <b>and they may not remove</b> the property <b>from his possession,</b> if he still is in possession of the property, <b>without proof</b> that he was healthy. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Ya’akov. Rabbi Natan says: If he is</b> currently <b>healthy,</b> the obligation <b>is upon him to bring proof that he was on his deathbed</b> at the time of the bequest, <b>and if he is</b> now <b>on his deathbed,</b> the obligation <b>is upon them to bring proof that he was healthy</b> at the time of the bequest.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Rav spoke in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan</b> that one’s current status is paramount, <b>and Shmuel spoke in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov,</b> who holds that the question of whether he was moribund remains a matter of uncertainty, and they may not claim the property from him even if he is now healthy. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rav</b> could have <b>said to you: I spoke even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov,</b> as <b>Rabbi Ya’akov states</b> his opinion <b>only there,</b> because <b>it can be said</b> that the principle of: <b>Leave</b> the <b>property in its</b> previous <b>status,</b> applies, so the property should remain where it is. <b>But here,</b> with regard to the question of when a young woman became a grown woman, <b>shall we say: Establish the body</b> according <b>to its previous status?</b> It is obvious that her body was due to mature.
<b>And Shmuel</b> could have <b>said: I spoke even in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan,</b> since <b>Rabbi Natan states</b> his opinion that the current state is paramount <b>only there, as everyone has a presumptive status of being healthy.</b> Consequently, if <b>a person removes himself from</b> this <b>presumption</b> by claiming he was moribund, the obligation falls <b>upon him to bring proof. But here, does</b> she <b>remove herself from a presumption that was present?</b> There is no presumption that she was a grown woman in the morning.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute between Rav and Shmuel <b>is parallel to</b> a dispute between <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>:</b> With regard to a case where <b>her father betrothed her on the way,</b> when he was traveling, <b>and</b> in the meantime she <b>betrothed herself in the city, and she is</b> now <b>a grown woman, one</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught: She is a grown woman at present,</b> and her father cannot currently betroth her; therefore, his betrothal does not take effect. <b>And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>We are concerned with regard to the betrothal of both of them. What, is it not</b> the case <b>that one</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, and one</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No;</b> it is possible that both <b>this and that are in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel. Here,</b> in this <i>baraita</i>, it is referring to a case <b>where she denies his</b> right to betroth her, as she claims that she was a grown woman before his betrothal. <b>There,</b> it is referring to a situation <b>where she does not deny his</b> right to betroth her, and therefore it is uncertain which betrothal takes effect.
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let us</b> also <b>say</b> that <b>since the <i>baraitot</i> do not disagree, the</b> opinions of the <b><i>amora’im</i>,</b> Rav and Shmuel, <b>do not disagree</b> either. One is referring to a case where she denies her father’s right to betroth her, while the other is referring to a case where she does not. The Gemara rejects this: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand it that way? But Rav Yosef, son of Rav Menashya of Dabil, performed an action</b> in this case <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> and did not take the father’s betrothal into account, <b>and Shmuel took offense</b> at this <b>and said</b> sarcastically: Is wisdom <b>measured out to everyone in a small measure, and measured out to this</b> member <b>of the Sages in a large measure?</b> He was angered that Rav Yosef had the audacity to rule against him in this case. <b>Now, if it enters your mind</b> that <b>they did not disagree</b> at all, <b>why did</b> Shmuel <b>take offense?</b>
<b>Perhaps when</b> Rav Yosef <b>performed an action,</b> he did so in an instance <b>where she denied</b> her father’s right to betroth her, in which case even Shmuel would agree that the father’s betrothal does not take effect. Rather, it must be that Rav and Shmuel did disagree, and Rav Yosef must have ruled in the case of a woman who did not deny her father’s right to betroth her, which explains why Shmuel took exception to his ruling.
<b>Mar Zutra said to Rav Ashi: This is what Ameimar said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel. And Rav Ashi said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who went overseas with his wife, and returned with his wife and children, and said: This is the woman who went overseas with me and these are her children,</b> he <b>is not required to bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the woman,</b> since her lineage was already investigated at the time of their marriage, <b>nor with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the children.</b> If he returned without the woman and said: My wife <b>died and these are her children,</b> he must <b>bring proof that the children</b> were born to his wife, <b>but he does not</b> need to <b>bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the woman.</b>
If he left when he was unmarried and said upon his return: <b>I married a woman overseas, and this is she, and these are her children,</b> he must <b>bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the woman, but</b> he <b>is not required to bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the children.</b> If he said: I married a woman overseas and <b>she died, and these are her children,</b> he is <b>required to bring proof with regard to</b> both the lineage of <b>the woman and the children.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna says: And all of</b> the statements that he is not required to bring proof with regard to the lineage of the children are said <b>in</b> a case where <b>they cling to her</b> and treat the woman like their mother.
<b>The Sages taught</b> that if a man says: <b>I married a woman overseas,</b> he must <b>bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the woman, but</b> he <b>is not required to bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the children. And he</b> must <b>bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the adult</b> children, <b>but</b> he <b>is not required to bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of <b>the minor</b> children. Since their attachment to their mother is apparent, it can be assumed they are her offspring. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>in</b> the case of one who said he married <b>one woman, but when</b> it is the case of one who said he married <b>two women</b> overseas, he must <b>bring proof with regard to</b> the lineage of both <b>the woman and the children, with regard to the adult</b> ones <b>and with regard to the minor</b> ones. Even if they cling to the woman whose lineage has been found to be unflawed, they might be the children of the other wife and are merely being raised by this one.
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b>

Daf 80a

The Sages <b>taught</b> that the children’s attachment to her proves that she is their mother <b>only with regard to the consecrated</b> items of <b>the border,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i>, meaning that if she is the wife of a priest, her children may partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But with regard to lineage,</b> this proof is <b>not</b> relied upon, and her daughters may not marry priests. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If the children cling to her they are considered hers in all regards, <b>even with regard to lineage.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The court <b>flogs</b> one about whom witnesses testify that he violated a prohibition <b>on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status,</b> even if there is no testimony to definitively establish that the person violated a prohibition, as will be explained. Similarly, the court <b>stones or burns</b> one about whom witnesses testify that he violated a prohibition resulting in court-imposed capital punishment <b>on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status. But one does not burn <i>teruma</i> on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status</b> unless there is testimony that it became ritually impure.
How so? The court <b>flogs</b> one about whom witnesses testify that he violated a prohibition <b>on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda. As Rav Yehuda says:</b> If a woman <b>had</b> among <b>her neighbors the presumptive status of a menstruating woman,</b> and witnesses testified that <b>her husband</b> engaged in sexual intercourse with her, he <b>is flogged due to</b> her status as <b>a menstruating woman,</b> and there is no need for testimony that she was a menstruating woman.
The court <b>stones or burns</b> one about whom witnesses testify that he violated a prohibition resulting in court-imposed capital punishment <b>on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status, in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabba bar Rav Huna. As Rabba bar Rav Huna says:</b> With regard to <b>a man and a woman</b> and <b>a boy and a girl who grew up</b> together <b>in</b> one <b>home</b> as a single family, the presumption is that they are related, even absent witness testimony to that effect. Therefore, <b>they are stoned due to</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>each other</b> if the male child, now an adult, engages in intercourse with the woman, as it is considered incestuous sexual intercourse. <b>And they are burned due to</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>each other</b> if the man engages in intercourse with the female child, now an adult, since she is considered his wife’s daughter.
The Gemara cites a related incident: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says in the name of bar Kappara: An incident</b> occurred <b>involving a woman who came to Jerusalem with a child riding on her shoulders,</b> in the manner of a mother and a son, <b>and she raised him, and he</b> eventually <b>engaged in intercourse with her. And they brought them to court and stoned them</b> for violating the prohibition against a mother and son engaging in intercourse. This was <b>not because he</b> was <b>definitely her son,</b> as they had no testimony to that effect, <b>but because he clung to her,</b> and he therefore had the presumptive status of being her son.
Rabbi Yoḥanan stated: <b>But one does not burn <i>teruma</i> on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status. As Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: One burns</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>on the</b> basis of <b>presumptive status, and Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One does not burn</b> <i>teruma</i> in this case. The Gemara comments: <b>And they follow their</b> standard lines of <b>reasoning</b> in this matter, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 3:8): If a ritually impure <b>child is found alongside</b> ritually pure <b>started dough, and</b> he has <b>risen dough in his hand</b> that may have been removed from the larger portion of started dough, <b>Rabbi Meir deems</b> the started dough <b>pure,</b> since there is no proof the child touched it, as he might have been given the piece by someone else. <b>And the Rabbis deem it impure,</b> as they assume that he touched the started dough. The child is presumed to be impure <b>because it is the manner of a child to handle [<i>letappe’aḥ</i>]</b> items.
<b>And we discussed</b> that case: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Meir? He holds</b> that <b>a majority of children handle</b> items, in this case the dough, that are within reach, <b>and a minority do not handle</b> items within reach, <b>and</b> the <b>dough</b> itself <b>retains a presumptive status of purity,</b> since its impurity has not been definitively determined. <b>And</b> if one <b>appends</b> the <b>minority</b> of children who do not handle items within reach <b>to the presumptive status</b> of purity of the dough, the force of the <b>majority</b> of children who handle items within reach <b>is weakened.</b> Therefore, the dough is considered pure. <b>And the Rabbis</b> contend that in a case where the majority is followed, <b>the minority is considered like it does not exist.</b> Consequently, there is a conflict between the determining factors of <b>the majority</b> of impure children who handle items within reach <b>and the presumptive status of purity</b> of the dough. In that case, <b>the majority takes precedence.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish says in the name of Rabbi Oshaya: This</b> <i>halakha</i> of a child <b>is</b> an example of a presumption, i.e., that children handle items within reach, <b>that one burns <i>teruma</i> based on it,</b> since the Rabbis hold that it is sufficiently established that the dough has become impure to allow it to be burned. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is not the presumption that one burns <i>teruma</i> based on it.</b> Rather, the dough is set aside and may be neither eaten nor burned.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, what is the presumption that one burns <i>teruma</i> based on it?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>started dough is in the house, and creeping animals,</b> which impart impurity when dead, <b>and frogs,</b> which do not impart impurity, <b>are</b> also <b>present there, and pieces</b> of an unidentified creature <b>were found in the started dough, if the majority</b> of creatures in the house <b>are creep-ing animals,</b> the dough <b>is impure,</b> since the presumption is that the pieces are from a creeping animal. <b>If the majority are frogs, it is pure.</b>
The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> There is a principle that when a possible case of impurity cannot be verified, even if it occurred in a private domain, where generally cases of uncertain impurity are deemed impure, it is deemed pure. <b>Two things do not have the capacity to be questioned,</b> i.e., one cannot verify what happened through investigation. Yet in these two cases, <b>the Sages deemed them as things that have the capacity to be questioned</b> and rendered them impure in cases of uncertainty in a private domain. The two cases are that of <b>a child and an additional</b> <i>halakha</i>.
The case of <b>a child</b> is <b>that which we said</b> concerning a child holding some dough discovered alongside a larger piece of dough. All of the dough is deemed impure, since the child cannot be asked whether or not he rendered the dough impure. <b>And what is the additional</b> one? If pure, <b>started dough</b> was located <b>inside the house, and chickens and impure liquids</b> were present <b>there, and there were found</b> to be

Daf 80b

<b>small holes in the dough</b> where the chickens had pecked it, in that case the dough is <b>held in suspension; it is neither eaten nor burned,</b> since the chickens may have drunk from the impure liquids before they pecked at the dough but there is no proof of this. Despite this being a case where they cannot be asked, which generally would result in the dough being deemed pure, here it is deemed impure due to the uncertainty. The fact that in the second case of the <i>baraita</i> it is not deemed to be definitely impure supports the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who holds that in the case of the child the status of the dough also remains a matter of uncertainty.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only in</b> a case of <b>white liquid,</b> when the appearance of the peck marks provides no proof of whether the chickens had previously drunk from the liquid, <b>but in</b> a case of <b>red,</b> impure <b>liquid, if it is so that they had pecked, it would be known</b> that they had drunk from the liquid, since the peck marks would be colored red. The Gemara asks: Even if the liquid were red and there were no red marks on the dough, how can one say definitively that they did not peck? <b>Perhaps</b> the <b>dough absorbed</b> the liquid, leaving no identifiable mark?
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The Distinguished,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, <b>heard this matter, but he did not hear its interpretation,</b> and he should have supplied an additional detail: <b>They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only in</b> a case <b>of clear liquid,</b> which can be absorbed in the dough without leaving a stain. What is meant by clear? It means <b>that in which the reflection [<i>bavua</i>] of a child is recognizable</b> when he peers into it. <b>But</b> in a case of <b>murky liquid,</b> this <i>halakha</i> was <b>not</b> stated, since the liquid would have left a mark.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A man may not be secluded with two women</b> lest he sin with them, <b>but one woman may be secluded with two men. Rabbi Shimon says: Even one man may be secluded with two women when his wife is with him, and</b> in that situation he may even <b>sleep in</b> the same <b>inn</b> with two women, <b>because his wife guards him</b> from sinning with them. They further said that <b>a man may be secluded with his mother, and with his daughter, and sleep alongside them with bodily contact</b> without clothes, since there is no concern that they will engage in sexual intercourse. <b>And when they,</b> the son or daughter, <b>have grown up, this one sleeps in her garment and that one sleeps in his garment,</b> but they may share a bed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is the reason</b> that a man may not be secluded with two women, but a woman may be secluded with two men? <b>The school of Eliyahu taught: Since women are of light mind</b> they are more easily seduced.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that it is prohibited for a man to be secluded with women, derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: From where</b> is there <b>an allusion from the</b> Written <b>Torah to</b> the prohibition against <b>seclusion? As it is stated</b> concerning one who incites others to idolatrous worship: <b>“If your brother, the son of your mother, entices you”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:7).
Rabbi Yishmael considers why the Torah uses the example of “the son of your mother.” <b>But is it</b> only <b>the son of a mother</b> who <b>entices? Doesn’t the son of a father entice? Rather,</b> the verse means <b>to say to you: A son may be secluded with his mother.</b> Consequently, if a woman has two sons from two different husbands, they will both stay close to her. The Torah therefore uses the example of “the son of your mother” because half-brothers who share a mother become close to each other. By contrast, half-brothers who share a father will not become close, since one’s father’s wife who is not one’s mother is a forbidden relative. <b>And it is prohibited to be secluded with those with whom relations are forbidden by the Torah.</b>
Since this verse merely alludes to the prohibition against seclusion, the Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what is the plain</b> meaning <b>of the verse written,</b> i.e., in the context of enticement to idolatrous worship, why does it emphasize “the son of your mother”? <b>Abaye said:</b> The verse <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> to state that one should not be enticed by <b>the son of a father, who hates him</b> due to their rivalry for their father’s inheritance <b>and</b> therefore <b>gives him bad advice. Rather,</b> the same is true <b>even</b> of <b>the son of a mother,</b> who <b>does not hate him,</b> since they are not rivals for the same inheritance, as each inherits from his own father. One might therefore <b>say</b> that <b>he should listen to him</b> and accept his advice. The verse consequently <b>teaches us</b> that he should pay no heed to his enticements.
The Gemara comments: Shall <b>we say the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a child dies <b>any</b> time during the first <b>thirty days</b> after his birth, he is not given a proper funeral but <b>is carried out</b> held <b>in</b> their <b>bosom,</b> not on a bier, <b>and buried by one woman and two men. But</b> he <b>may not</b> be buried <b>by one man and two women,</b> due to the prohibition against seclusion. <b>Abba Shaul says:</b> He may <b>even</b> be buried <b>by one man and two women.</b> This indicates that Abba Shaul deems it permitted for a man to be secluded with two women.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>You</b> can <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Shaul,</b> as he permits it only in the case of the <i>baraita</i>, because <b>at the time of acute mourning,</b> i.e., immediately after a close relative has died, one’s <b>inclination</b> to sin <b>is broken,</b> and there is no concern that he might come to sin.
<b>And the Rabbis,</b> who render seclusion forbidden even then, <b>hold in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, as Rabbi Yitzḥak says</b> as follows with regard to the verse: <b>“Why does a living man complain, a powerful man due to his sins?”</b> (Lamentations 3:39): <b>Even at the time of a person’s acute mourning, his inclination</b> to sin <b>overpowers him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Abba Shaul</b> explain this verse? The Gemara answers: <b>When that was written, it was written</b> with regard <b>to one who complains about</b> God’s <b>ways. And this is</b> what the verse <b>is saying: Why does</b> one <b>complain about</b> God’s <b>ways</b> and claim that he has been treated unjustly? <b>Has he overpowered his sins?</b> God responds: <b>The life I have given him is sufficient for him,</b> and he deserves no more.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> are concerned about the possibility of sin even in times of acute mourning, <b>like that incident involving a certain woman, as there was an incident where she removed</b> her husband from his grave. When visiting her husband’s grave, she engaged in intercourse with a man who was tasked with guarding the body of one executed by the king. Meanwhile, that body was taken, and she suggested that they disinter her husband so that the guard could claim that he fulfilled his task properly. This demonstrates that even at a time of mourning one may succumb to temptation.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>But one woman</b> may be secluded with two men. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard <b>to</b> men of <b>fit</b> morals, <b>but with regard to</b> those <b>steeped</b> in sexual immorality, she may <b>not</b> be secluded <b>even with ten</b> men. <b>There was an incident where ten</b> men <b>carried out</b> a woman <b>on a bier,</b> as though she were dead, and engaged in intercourse with her. <b>Rav Yosef says: Know</b> that this is so, <b>since ten</b> people <b>will join together and steal a</b> heavy <b>beam without being ashamed before one another.</b> Similarly, several men can join together for a licentious act without shame.
The Gemara suggests: Shall <b>we say</b> the following mishna (<i>Sota</i> 7a) <b>supports him:</b> It was taught with regard to one who is bringing his wife, whom he suspects of having committed adultery [<i>sota</i>], to the Temple to perform the ritual of the bitter water, that <b>they provide him with two Torah scholars</b> to accompany them <b>lest he engage in sexual intercourse with her along the way,</b> as until the ritual has been performed she remains forbidden to her husband? It can be inferred from here: Two <b>Torah scholars, yes;</b> their presence will assure that no one will engage in forbidden intercourse. <b>Regular men, no;</b> there is still a concern that they may engage in intercourse. This indicates that ordinary people are not relied upon with regard to seclusion with a woman. The Gemara rejects this proof: The reason there is a need for them to be Torah scholars is that <b>Torah scholars are different, in that they know</b>

Daf 81a

how <b>to warn him</b> not to engage in intercourse with her, since that would neutralize the effectiveness of the examination of the waters.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that two men may seclude themselves with one woman <b>only in a city,</b> where others are present, <b>but on the road</b> it is not permitted <b>unless there are three.</b> Why are two men insufficient on the road? <b>Perhaps one of them will need to urinate</b> and will walk away, <b>and it will turn out that one</b> person <b>will be secluded with a woman forbidden to him.</b> The Gemara suggests: Shall <b>we say</b> the mishna quoted above <b>supports him: They provide him with two Torah scholars</b> to accompany them <b>lest he engage in sexual intercourse with her along the way? He and two</b> Torah scholars <b>are three,</b> which indicates that there is a requirement for three men when they are traveling. The Gemara answers: That is no proof, as <b>there,</b> in the case of the <i>sota</i>, there is a requirement for an additional two men <b>in order that they should</b> serve as <b>witnesses about him,</b> to testify whether or not he engaged in intercourse with her along the way.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav and Rav Yehuda were walking along the way,</b> and <b>a certain woman was walking ahead of them. Rav said to Rav Yehuda: Raise your feet</b> and walk quickly <b>away from Gehenna</b> so that we do not remain secluded with her. Rav Yehuda <b>said to him: But wasn’t it</b> you, <b>Master, who said that</b> it is <b>permitted</b> in the case <b>of</b> men of <b>fit</b> morals? Rav <b>said to him: Who says</b> that I referred <b>to</b> men of <b>fit</b> morals <b>such as you and me?</b> Rav Yehuda responded: <b>Rather, such as whom?</b> Rav answered: <b>Such as Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappi and his colleagues,</b> who have proven that they can withstand temptation (see 39b). All other people are not trusted in this matter.
<b>Rav says:</b> The court <b>flogs</b> a man <b>due to</b> his being <b>secluded</b> with a woman. But a wife <b>is not forbidden</b> to her husband, and an unmarried woman is not prohibited from marrying a priest <b>due to</b> being <b>secluded,</b> as it cannot be stated definitively that the secluded pair engaged in sexual intercourse. <b>Rav Ashi says: We stated</b> the <i>halakha</i> that one is flogged <b>due to</b> being <b>secluded only</b> with <b>an unmarried</b> woman, <b>but for</b> being <b>secluded</b> with <b>a married woman,</b> one is <b>not</b> flogged. Why not? It is <b>so that there should not be rumors spread concerning her children.</b> If the secluded pair is flogged, everyone will assume that they engaged in intercourse, and people will consider her children to be <i>mamzerim</i>, whereas in fact they were flogged only for being secluded.
The Gemara relates: <b>Mar Zutra would</b> even <b>flog</b> one who was secluded with a married woman, <b>and he would proclaim</b> the reason for the punishment. <b>Rav Naḥman from Parhatya said to Rav Ashi: Let the Master also flog and proclaim</b> the reason. Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> I am hesitant to do so, in case <b>there are those who hear about this,</b> i.e., the flogging, <b>and do not hear about that,</b> i.e., the reason for the flogging.
<b>Rav says:</b> The court <b>flogs</b> one <b>due to</b> his being the subject of <b>a bad rumor,</b> meaning that not only is a person flogged when the facts have been ascertained, but even when he has only reportedly committed transgressions he may be flogged. <b>As it is stated: “No, my sons, for it is no good report”</b> (I Samuel 2:24). When <b>Mar Zutra</b> would flog a person for being the subject of a bad rumor, <b>he would place</b> the <b>bridle</b> of a donkey <b>on</b> the person’s <b>shoulders and recite before him</b> when administering lashes: <b>“No, my sons,</b> for it is no good report,” so that people would know why he was being flogged.
<b>Rabba says:</b> If a woman’s <b>husband is in town, there is no concern due to</b> her being <b>secluded</b> with a man. People are afraid to sin with her, since they cannot be sure when her husband will return. <b>Rav Yosef says:</b> If there is <b>an open entrance to the public domain there is no concern due to</b> being <b>secluded.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Beivai arrived at Rav Yosef’s house. After he wrapped</b> his <b>bread,</b> i.e., ate his meal, he <b>said to</b> the members of the household: <b>Remove the ladder from beneath Beivai,</b> who was going to sleep in the upper story, so that he not be able to climb down, due to the prohibition of being secluded with Rav Yosef’s wife. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabba say:</b> If <b>her husband is in town, there is no concern due to</b> her being <b>secluded</b> with a man? The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Beivai is different, since</b> Rav Yosef’s wife <b>was his friend and she was familiar with him,</b> and therefore there was more cause for concern.
<b>Rav Kahana says:</b> If the <b>men</b> are located <b>on the outside,</b> i.e., in the outer room, <b>and the women in the inside,</b> i.e., in the inner room, <b>there is no concern due to</b> being <b>secluded.</b> Even if one of the men were to enter the inner room, he would be seen by the other men. By contrast, if there were <b>men in the inside and women on the outside, there is a concern due to</b> being <b>secluded,</b> since one of the men can claim that he is leaving and in fact join the women.
The Gemara comments: <b>The opposite was taught in a <i>baraita</i>,</b> that if the men are on the outside and the women are inside there is concern due to being secluded, as one of the men might venture inside without being noticed, but if the men are inside and the women are outside, he knows that one of the other men might go out through the women’s quarters at any time, and therefore there is no concern due to being secluded. <b>Abaye said: Now that Rav Kahana has said</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>this</b> manner <b>and a <i>baraita</i> teaches the opposite, we shall act stringently</b> in both cases.
<b>Abaye</b> would <b>arrange rows</b> of <b>pitchers</b> between the men and women, so that they would not be able to cross from one area to the other without making noise. <b>Rava</b> would <b>arrange rows</b> of <b>reeds</b> to prevent passage. <b>Avin said: The wound [<i>sakva</i>],</b> i.e., the vulnerable point, <b>of the year</b> is <b>the Festival,</b> since men and women would come together on these joyous occasions, and this would lead to sin.
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Those captive</b> women <b>who were brought to Neharde’a,</b> where they were redeemed, <b>were brought up to the house of Rav Amram the Pious. They removed the ladder from before them</b> to prevent men from climbing up after them to the attic where they were to sleep. <b>When one of them passed</b> by the entrance to the upper chamber, it was as though <b>a light shone in the aperture</b> due to her great beauty. Out of his desire for her, <b>Rav Amram grabbed a ladder that ten</b> men <b>together could not lift, lifted it on his own</b> and <b>began climbing.</b>
<b>When he was halfway</b> up <b>the ladder, he strengthened</b> his legs against the sides of the ladder to stop himself from climbing further, <b>raised his voice,</b> and cried out: There is <b>a fire in the house of Amram.</b> Upon hearing this, <b>the Sages came</b> and found him in that position. <b>They said to him: You have embarrassed us,</b> since everyone sees what you had intended to do. Rav Amram <b>said to them: It is better that you be shamed in Amram’s house in this world, and not be ashamed of him in the World-to-Come. He took an oath that</b> his evil inclination <b>should emerge from him, and</b> an apparition <b>similar to a pillar of fire emerged from him. He said to</b> his evil inclination: <b>See, as you are fire and I am</b> mere <b>flesh, and</b> yet, <b>I am</b> still <b>superior to you,</b> as I was able to overcome you.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Meir would ridicule transgressors</b> by saying it is easy to avoid temptation. <b>One day, Satan appeared to him as a woman</b> standing <b>on the other side of the river.</b> Since <b>there was no ferry</b> to cross the river, <b>he took hold of a rope bridge and crossed</b> the river. <b>When he reached halfway</b> across <b>the rope bridge,</b> the evil inclination <b>left him and said</b> to him: <b>Were it not for</b> the fact that <b>they proclaim about you in heaven: Be careful with regard to Rabbi Meir and his Torah, I would have made your blood like two <i>ma’a</i>,</b> i.e., completely worthless, since you would have fallen completely from your spiritual level.
<b>Rabbi Akiva would</b> likewise <b>ridicule transgressors. One day, Satan appeared to him as a woman at the top of a palm tree.</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>grabbed hold of the palm tree and began climbing. When he was halfway up the palm tree,</b> the evil inclination <b>left him and said</b> to him: <b>Were it not for</b> the fact that <b>they proclaim about you in heaven: Be careful with regard to Rabbi Akiva and his Torah, I would have made your blood like two <i>ma’a</i>.</b>
The Sage <b>Peleimu had the habit to say every day: An arrow in the eye of Satan,</b> mocking the temptations of the evil inclination. <b>One day, it was the eve of Yom Kippur,</b> and Satan <b>appeared to him as a pauper</b> who <b>came and called</b> him <b>to the door,</b> requesting alms. Peleimu <b>brought out bread to him.</b> Satan <b>said to him: On a day like today, everyone is inside</b> eating, <b>and</b> shall <b>I</b> stand <b>outside</b> and eat? Peleimu <b>brought him inside and gave him bread. He said to him: On a day like today, everyone</b> is sitting <b>at the table, and</b> shall <b>I</b> sit <b>by myself? They brought him and sat him at the table. He was sitting</b> and had <b>covered himself with boils and pus, and he was doing repulsive things</b> at the table. Peleimu <b>said to</b> the pauper:

Daf 81b

<b>Sit properly</b> and do not act in a revolting manner. Satan then <b>said to him: Give me a cup. They gave him a cup. He coughed up his phlegm and spat it into</b> the cup. <b>They berated him</b> for acting this way, at which point Satan pretended to <b>sink</b> down <b>and die. They heard</b> people around them <b>saying: Peleimu killed a man! Peleimu killed a man!</b> Peleimu <b>fled and hid himself in the bathroom.</b> Satan <b>followed him</b> and <b>fell before him. Upon seeing that</b> Peleimu <b>was suffering, he revealed himself to him.</b> Satan <b>said to him: What is the reason that you spoke this way,</b> provoking me by saying: An arrow in the eye of Satan? He replied: <b>But what then should I say?</b> Satan <b>said to him: Let the Master,</b> i.e., Peleimu, <b>say:</b> Let <b>the Merciful One rebuke the Satan.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi was accustomed to say, whenever he would fall on his face</b> in prayer: <b>May the Merciful One save us from the evil inclination. One day his wife heard him</b> saying this prayer. <b>She said: After all, it has been several years since he has withdrawn from</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>me</b> due to his advanced years. <b>What is the reason that he says this</b> prayer, as there is no concern that he will engage in sinful sexual behavior?
<b>One day,</b> while <b>he was studying in his garden, she adorned herself and repeatedly walked past him. He said: Who are you? She said: I am Ḥaruta,</b> a well-known prostitute, <b>returning from my day</b> at work. <b>He propositioned her. She said to him: Give me that pomegranate from the top of the tree</b> as payment. <b>He leapt up, went,</b> and <b>brought it to her,</b> and they engaged in intercourse.
<b>When he came home, his wife was lighting</b> a fire in the <b>oven. He went and sat inside it. She said to him: What is this? He said to her: Such and such an incident</b> occurred; he told her that he engaged in intercourse with a prostitute. <b>She said to him: It was I. He paid no attention to her,</b> thinking she was merely trying to comfort him, <b>until she gave him signs</b> that it was indeed she. <b>He said to her: I, in any event, intended to transgress.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>All the days of that righteous man he would fast</b> for the transgression he intended to commit, <b>until he died by that death</b> in his misery.
The Gemara explains the source that one who intended to transgress is punished even though he did not actually sin. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning a husband who nullified the vow of his wife: <b>“Her husband has made them null; and the Lord will forgive her”</b> (Numbers 30:13). <b>With regard to what</b> case <b>is the verse speaking?</b> Why would the woman require forgiveness if her husband has nullified her vow? It is referring <b>to a woman who vowed</b> to <b>be a nazirite, and her husband heard and nullified her</b> vow. <b>And she did not know that her husband had nullified her</b> vow, <b>and she drank wine and contracted impurity from a corpse,</b> violating her presumed vow.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Akiva came to this verse he would cry. He said: And if</b> with regard to <b>one who intended to eat pork, and</b> kosher <b>lamb came up in his hand,</b> like this woman who intended to violate her vow but in fact did not, <b>the Torah</b> nevertheless <b>says: She requires atonement and forgiveness, all the more so</b> does <b>one who intended to eat pork and pork came up in his hand</b> require atonement and forgiveness.
<b>In a similar manner, you</b> can <b>say</b> that the same lesson can be derived from the verse: <b>“Though he know it not, yet is he guilty, and shall bear his iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 5:17). <b>When Rabbi Akiva came to this verse he would cry.</b> He said: <b>And if</b> with regard to <b>one who intended to eat</b> permitted <b>fat, and</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> mistakenly <b>came up in his hand, the Torah states: “Though he know it not, yet is he guilty, and shall bear his iniquity,” all the more so</b> is this true for <b>one who intended to eat</b> forbidden <b>fat and</b> forbidden <b>fat came up in his hand. Isi ben Yehuda says</b> with regard to the verse <b>“Though he know it not, yet is he guilty, and shall bear his iniquity”: With regard to this matter all sufferers shall grieve,</b> since the verse teaches that one is punished even for sinning unawares.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>a man may be secluded with his mother. Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says: A man may be secluded with his sister, and live with his mother or with his daughter</b> in a permanent arrangement, without concern. <b>When he said this before Shmuel,</b> the latter <b>said: It is prohibited to be secluded with all those with whom relations are forbidden by the Torah, and even with an animal,</b> as it is prohibited to engage in intercourse with an animal as well.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>A man may be secluded with his mother, and with his daughter, and sleep alongside them with bodily contact, and</b> this appears to be <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the statement of <b>Shmuel.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel</b> could have <b>said to you: And according to your reasoning,</b> how should one explain <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>his sister, and his mother-in-law, and all those with whom relations are forbidden,</b> including his mother and daughter, <b>one may be secluded with them only</b> in the presence <b>of witnesses,</b> from which it can be inferred: In the presence <b>of witnesses, yes; without</b> the presence <b>of witnesses, no.</b> This <i>baraita</i> supports the opinion of Shmuel that one may not be secluded with his mother or sister.
<b>Rather,</b> it <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> as to whether one may be secluded with his mother or sister. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir said: Be careful with me because of my daughter,</b> i.e., make sure I am not left secluded with her. Similarly, <b>Rabbi Tarfon said: Be careful with me because of my daughter-in-law. A certain student mocked him</b> for being wary of the possibility of sinning with his daughter-in-law. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel: Not many days passed until that student stumbled</b> into sin <b>with his mother-in-law.</b>
The Gemara stated that according to Shmuel it is prohibited for one to be alone <b>even with an animal.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Abaye removed</b> the animals <b>from the entire field</b> he was in. <b>Rav Sheshet transferred</b> the animals to the other side <b>of the fence. Rav Ḥanan from Neharde’a happened</b> to come <b>to Rav Kahana in Pum Nahara. He saw that</b> he <b>was sitting and studying, and an animal was standing before him.</b> Rav Ḥanan <b>said to him: Doesn’t the Master hold</b> that one may not be secluded <b>even with an animal?</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to him: It</b> did <b>not</b> enter <b>my mind</b> that an animal was before me.
<b>Rava says: A man may be secluded with two sisters-in-law and with two rival wives,</b> i.e., two women who share a husband; <b>with a woman and her mother-in-law;</b> and <b>with a woman and her husband’s daughter.</b> Since these women typically dislike each other, each fears that the other will publicize her sins, and they will be careful not to transgress. Similarly, a man may be secluded <b>with a woman and a girl who knows the meaning of sexual intercourse,</b> i.e., one who is old enough to understand the nature of intercourse, <b>but</b> is still young enough that <b>she does not submit herself to intercourse,</b> since she does not yet desire it. In such a situation, the woman is concerned that the child will reveal her behavior.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>when</b> one’s children <b>have grown up, this one sleeps in his garment</b> and that one sleeps in her garment, but they may share a bed. The Gemara asks: <b>And how</b> old must a child be to be considered grown up for the purposes of this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Adda bar Rav Azza says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says: A girl</b> must reach the <b>age</b> of <b>nine years and one day; a boy</b> must reach the <b>age</b> of <b>twelve years and one day. There are</b> those <b>who say: A girl</b> must reach the <b>age</b> of <b>twelve years and one day; a boy</b> must reach the <b>age</b> of <b>thirteen</b> years <b>and one day. And</b> according to <b>this and that,</b> according to both opinions, the girl is considered a child <b>until</b> she has reached the stage of: <b>“Your breasts were fashioned, and your hair was grown”</b> (Ezekiel 16:7), meaning the onset of puberty.
<b>Rafram bar Pappa says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda says: They taught</b> that a man may sleep in close proximity to his minor daughter <b>only if she is not ashamed to stand naked before him, but</b> if she is <b>ashamed to stand naked before him, it is prohibited</b> for him to sleep close to her, regardless of her age. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is that the <b>inclination has a hold upon her,</b> as otherwise she would not be ashamed.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Abba arrived at the house of Rav Ḥisda, his son-in-law. He took his daughter’s daughter and placed her on his lap.</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: Doesn’t the Master think that she</b> might already be <b>betrothed?</b> Rav Aḥa <b>said to him:</b> If that is true, <b>you have transgressed</b> the ruling <b>of Rav, as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says, and some say</b> it was said by <b>Rabbi Elazar: It is prohibited for a man to betroth his daughter when she is a minor, until she grows up and says: I want</b> to marry <b>so-and-so,</b> as otherwise she might reject the designated husband and ultimately sin by committing adultery. Rav Ḥisda replied: <b>The Master has likewise transgressed</b> the words <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel says: One may not make use of a woman,</b> so how can you hold her on your lap? <b>He said to him: I hold in accordance with another</b> statement <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel says:</b>

Daf 82a

<b>All</b> such actions <b>are</b> permitted <b>for the sake of Heaven.</b> In other words, if one is acting out of familial affection, without any element of licentiousness, they are permitted.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A bachelor may not act as a teacher of children, nor may a woman act as a teacher of children. Rabbi Elazar says: Even one who does not have a wife may not act as a teacher of children. Rabbi Yehuda says: A bachelor may not herd cattle, nor may two bachelors sleep with one covering,</b> lest they transgress the prohibition against homosexual intercourse, <b>but the Rabbis permit</b> it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What is the reason</b> that a bachelor may not teach children? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>due to the children</b> themselves, that it is suspected that he may engage in homosexual intercourse with them, <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 5:10): <b>They said to Rabbi Yehuda: Jews are not suspected of</b> engaging in <b>homosexual intercourse nor of</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>an animal. Rather,</b> the reason is as follows: <b>A bachelor</b> may not be a teacher of children <b>due to the mothers of the children,</b> who come to the school from time to time, with whom he might sin. Similarly, <b>a woman</b> may not serve as a teacher to children <b>because</b> she may come to be secluded with <b>the fathers of the children.</b>
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Even one who does not have</b> a wife may not act as a teacher of children. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the students in the study hall: Does Rabbi Elazar mean <b>one who does not have a wife at all, or perhaps</b> he is referring even to one who has a wife, <b>in</b> a circumstance <b>where she is not residing with him? Come</b> and <b>hear: Even one who has</b> a wife <b>but she is not residing with him may not act as a teacher of children.</b> This statement is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar and indicates that his restriction applies even if the man is married.
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A bachelor <b>may not herd</b> cattle, nor may two bachelors sleep with one covering. <b>It is taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (5:10): <b>They said to Rabbi Yehuda: Jews are not suspected of</b> engaging in <b>homosexual intercourse nor of</b> engaging in intercourse with <b>an animal.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Anyone who has professional dealings</b> primarily <b>with women may not be secluded with women.</b> There is more of a concern that such a man might sin due to his familiarity with the women. <b>And a person may not teach his son a trade</b> that necessitates frequent interaction with <b>women,</b> for the same reason. With regard to teaching one’s son a trade, <b>Rabbi Meir says: A person should always teach his son a clean and easy trade and pray</b> for success <b>to the One to Whom wealth and property belong, as</b> ultimately <b>there is no trade that does not include</b> both <b>poverty and wealth,</b> since a person can become rich from any profession. <b>Poverty does not</b> come <b>from a</b> particular <b>trade, nor does wealth</b> come <b>from a</b> particular <b>trade,</b> but <b>rather, all is in accordance with</b> a person’s <b>merit.</b> Therefore, one should choose a clean and easy trade, and pray to God for success.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Have you ever seen a beast or a bird that has a trade? And</b> yet <b>they earn their livelihood without anguish. But</b> all these <b>were created only to serve me, and I,</b> a human being, <b>was created to serve</b> the One Who <b>formed me. Is it not right that I should earn my livelihood without anguish? But I,</b> i.e., humanity, <b>have</b> committed <b>evil actions and have lost my livelihood.</b> This is why people must work to earn a living.
<b>Abba Guryan of Tzadyan says in the name of Abba Gurya: A person may not teach his son</b> the trades of <b>a donkey driver, a camel driver, a pot maker, a sailor, a shepherd, or a storekeeper.</b> The reason for all these is the same, <b>as their trades are the trades of robbers;</b> all of these professions involve a measure of dishonesty and are likely to lead to robbery. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says in</b> Abba Gurya’s <b>name: Most donkey drivers are wicked,</b> since they engage in deceit, <b>and most camel drivers,</b> who traverse dangerous places such as deserts, <b>are</b> of <b>fit</b> character, as they pray to God to protect them on their journeys. <b>Most sailors are pious,</b> since the great danger of the seas instills in them the fear of Heaven. <b>The best of doctors is to Gehenna, and</b> even <b>the fittest of butchers is a partner of Amalek.</b>
<b>Rabbi Nehorai says: I set aside all the trades in the world, and I teach my son only Torah, as a person partakes of its reward in this world and the principal</b> reward <b>remains for him in the World-to-Come, which is not true of other professions,</b> whose rewards are only in this world. Furthermore, <b>if a person comes to be ill, or old, or undergoes suffering, and is unable to be involved in his trade, behold, he dies in hunger.
